title: Stealing Home
description: When I was 17, the only time I was grateful to be plain and ignored was in a well-lighted department store while robbing it blind. Shoplifting became my successful small business, opened during the summer of my parents' divorce, and of which I was the sole proprietor. The plan was to have shoplifted all my back-to-school clothes by Labor Day. Predictably, after my parents' divorce, our household income dropped, plummeting my security along with it. Sure, child-support payments were promptly delivered, but they were earmarked for rent and food, not for leather sneakers and bomber jackets.

title: 'Dear First Love'
description: While she washed the dishes stained and chipped by time and use, Danae created a winter landscape in her mind. Snow, miles and miles of snow, that was what she yearned for. Chunks of ice packed inside her skull, behind her eyes, a bathtub filled with frozen daiquiris she could sink into -- the only thing that came close was one of those frozen cones of caramel-covered peanuts they were making these days, or maybe a snow cone. She dried her hands, and while they were temporarily free she repositioned her tortoiseshell comb and gathered up the two strands of hair that both called attention to her eyes and infected them, filling them with yellowy pus. She liked doing housework, padding around the house while her mind drifted off into absurd daydreams. She caught herself just as she was about to cut off the tip of her finger with the bread knife, the only knife she owned for cutting anything that needed to be cut. The kitchen was tiny, hardly enough space for her to turn around in and stand over the gas stove. She lost herself in watching the milk begin to boil; she loved to watch the cream on top suddenly rise up into a frothy dome. Cream is the housewife's delight . Suddenly there was the smell of scorched milk, and once again she let herself be transported; this time, it was the memory of the contact of her lips with the condensed milk boiled in a double boiler until it turned to "mud," that dessert they had in the Schools in the Country. She looked tired, even slovenly -- it had been weeks since she'd felt like bathing, much less fixing herself up. Her hair kept slipping slowly but inexorably out of the comb, falling over her shoulders in greasy strands; her lips, dry and cracked and pale, resembled those desserts that Arabs made. There were wide brown circles under her eyes. Glassy, uninterested-looking eyes. She didnt eat; she cooked for the others but she had no appetite for any recipe she knew how to make. She went about making dinner the way she would have invested energy in preparing a performance, as though going through an aesthetic act. Her mind worked faster than her hands; all she did was think, and think some more. And that left her exhausted, drained, uninterested. She smoked a great deal, cigarettes or cigars.

title: 'The Writer and the World'
description: Coming from a small island -- Trinidad is no bigger than Goa -- I had always been fascinated by size. To see the wide river, the high mountain, to take the twenty-four-hour train journey: these were some of the delights the outside world offered. But now after six months in India my fascination with the big is tinged with disquiet. For here is a vastness beyond imagination, a sky so wide and deep that sunsets cannot be taken in at a glance but have to be studied section by section, a landscape made monotonous by its size and frightening by its very simplicity and its special quality of exhaustion: poor choked crops in small crooked fields, under-sized people, under-nourished animals, crumbling villages and towns which, even while they develop, have an air of decay. Dawn comes, night falls; railway stations, undistinguishable one from the other, their name-boards cunningly concealed, are arrived at and departed from, abrupt and puzzling interludes of populousness and noise; and still the journey goes on, until the vastness, ceasing to have a meaning, becomes insupportable, and from this endless repetition of exhaustion and decay one wishes to escape.

title: Ye Olde Borough of Queens
description: Just a few blocks off Queens Boulevard lies a time warp -- a perfectly preserved garden suburb from a time when women wore bustles. With its medieval English-style, red-tiled roofs, turrets, dormers and Tudor half-timbering, Forest Hills Gardens is virtually unchanged from 1909 when Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. designed it as a ''suburban town built on business principles.'' Olmsted, son of the landscape architect who designed Central Park and many of the nation's great urban parks, is now recognized as America's first city planner, Susan L. Klaus writes in A MODERN ARCADIA: Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. and the Plan for Forest Hills Gardens (University of Massachusetts, $39.95). Forest Hills Garden was designed down to the doorknobs as a profit-making venture. Olmsted's partner Grosvenor Atterbury developed an innovative system of prefabricated concrete construction, so that a new house could go up every nine days. Klaus notes, ''The subtle variety in materials gave the village an instant patina and helped create the illusion that it had evolved over a period of years.'' The landscaping is delightful in color, texture and scent: in one park, spring blooms of dogwood, cherry, jasmine, spiraea and forsythia are succeeded by snowballs, Indian currant and honeysuckle in the summer. Klaus, an independent scholar, has a strong feel for the period architecture and especially landscaping, but does not think through less cozy implications for urban planning, like the fact that Forest Hills Gardens was chartered to exclude Jews, blacks and working-class people or why Americans prefer ersatz historical towns like Disney's Celebration, Fla. to the realities of city life. Eric P. Nash

title: Spellbound
description: Every September, the office of the Scripps Howard National Spelling Bee in Cincinnati issues a crisp new edition of ''Paideia,'' a comic-size booklet that lists thousands of obscure words that will appear in spelling bees across the country over the coming year -- words that any competitive speller in America should know cold. Most families wait for their ''Paideia'' to arrive at school; but serious devotees know when the advance audio version of ''Paideia'' will go up on the Scripps Howard Web site. On that day each year, the Goldsteins of West Hempstead, N.Y. -- Amy, Ari, J.J. and Amanda, along with their parents, Jonathan and Mona -- assemble like the Von Trapps in a thunderstorm. The whole family squeezes into Amy's bedroom and fires up the computer, and the familiar, baronial voice of the National Spelling Bee pronouncer, Alex J. Cameron, carefully enunciates each new addition to the list -- aition, campanile, kittel, giaour. Each Goldstein sits with pen and paper in hand, as still and focused as a game-show contestant, and spells the words, one by one. It takes hours.

title: A Government Train To Tolstoy's Birthplace
description: Visiting Tolstoy's pastoral estate, Yasnaya Polyana, 125 miles south of Moscow used to require a tour bus or a trek through the industrial city of Tula. Now visitors can take a train direct to Kozlova Zaseka, a re-creation of the wooden station house that the writer himself used, two and a half miles from the estate. Each train car has a theme, like Tolstoy and Cinema, Tolstoy and Art, or Tolstoy and the Caucasus. Those who don't speak Russian will not understand the framed citations from Tolstoy's works, but no knowledge of the language is required to appreciate the originals and reproductions of photographs, watercolors, and sketches depicting the writer's life and times.

title: 'Will You Miss Me When I'm Gone?'
description: It was 1939, the tenth year of the Great Depression. There were 20 million radio sets in American homes, and every day a single voice, broadcast over the most powerful station in the Western hemisphere, burst into those homes as though it had a God-given right to be there. It was the voice of a small, bearded man speaking from a luxuriously appointed private office in a mansion on the banks of the Rio Grande. The voice was at once seductive and chiding, for he wished you to know that he was a compassionate physician, a healer of thousands; at the same time, he was an impatient builder of empires who would heal thousands more -- no, millions more -- if only they had the good sense to come unto him. This was the voice of "Doctor" John Romulus Brinkley.

title: Bits of the Past Recall World War II
description: ON Omaha Beach, at Mount Suribachi, in the skies over Europe, on battleships, at military hospitals and on the home front, men and women from New Jersey served in every theater of operation during World War II. Their stories are being told at the Morris Museum in ''Share Your Story: Reminiscences from New Jersey World War II Veterans,'' on view through Nov. 11.

title: Japanese View of an American View of Japan
description: STEPHEN SONDHEIM and James Lapine's 1976 musical ''Pacific Overtures'' was an American attempt to imagine how the Japanese experienced the so-called opening of Japan by Commodore Perry and his ''black ships'' in 1853. In Amon Miyamoto's New National Theater Tokyo production, which won high praise at Lincoln Center Festival this summer, the text is in Japanese, the actors are Japanese and the mock-Kabuki style of the original is replaced by Noh-style minimalism. As for the Americans, they appear as grotesques, with weed-gardens of multicolored hair and protruding noses. The production will be at the Kennedy Center in Washington from Tuesday through next Sunday, part of the center's Sondheim Celebration.

title: No Frigate Like a Book
description: Open ''A Book of Books,'' Abelardo Morell's glorious yet intimate collection of photographs, and you will realize that books are becoming fetish objects. Not because they aren't available -- all too available, we think, growing dazed and dull-eyed as the fall blitz of reviews approaches, telling us what to admire and what to scorn. But between books that disappear once their brief allotment of time in stores is past and books that exist only on computers, I feel as though I've entered a museum when I go to my local library. All those sturdily aging hardcovers with pages that change color and smell over the years; paperbacks too -- mysteries with the red skulls on their tattered spines -- holding up year after year. And it is very comforting to go through those cartons of used books and magazines now being sold on the streets and find traces of other lives: inscriptions, folded-down pages, frenetic underlinings and earnest margin notes.

title: Darryl F. Zanuck, Action Hero of the Studio Era
description: ''WE had a great preview up to the last 10 minutes,'' remembered Darryl F. Zanuck. ''Then the bottom dropped out. It ended on a laugh and it was no comedy.'' Standing on the sidewalk outside the theater and talking to his associates, he had begun improvising a new ending to the movie. Before Zanuck could finish his first sentence, the director Michael Curtiz interrupted him and said: ''Wonderful, Darryl. Yes! Yes!'' Zanuck glared at him and said, ''Don't say yes until I finish talking.'' Years later, Zanuck had forgotten the name of the movie, but his line remained memorable; indeed, it gave me the title for my biography of him, published in 1971.

title: French Twist
description: S.S. Fair: ''Eight Women'' is the latest cinematic souffl from France, a romp through the clichd corridors of whodunit and why. It stars Catherine Deneuve as a bourgeois wife whose husband lies lifeless in the bedroom, Fanny Ardant as the dead man's sister and Emmanuelle Bart as maid and mistress. The veteran actress Danielle Darrieux plays the mother-in-law, and the ubiquitous Isabelle Huppert chews up the scenery as the corpse's spinsterish sister-in-law. Each actress offers a musical tribute to love's disappointments, but it's the hairdos, clothes and accessories that steal the show. One of the characters is actually named Madame Chanel, although she's no slave to couture, haute or otherwise. Directed by Franois Ozon, whose ''Under the Sand'' was a gripping study of grief and loss with a splendid performance by Charlotte Rampling, ''Eight Women'' is more of a bizarre mlange: part farce, part fantasy, with one dead white male to galvanize les girls into using their feminine wiles.

The United States Postal Inspection Service began a campaign last week to alert the public, specifically the elderly, to the growing danger of fraud. Swindlers may contact people by telephone or e-mail and trick them into sending some sort of payment by mail. The postal agency said it responded to 66,000 mail fraud complaints in 2001. title: Save Face
description: During an intense Ping-Pong game, I became frustrated and threw my paddle aimlessly, accidentally striking my friend below the eye. Forty-five minutes later, he had received six stitches, and I was out $500. The next day, I asked him to repay $250. I reminded him that growing up together, we had many accidents, but neither of us expected the other to pay the hospital bills. He was mortified that I asked for the money. What should we do? title: Crowds Go but Sinatra Stays
description: This may be many people's last weekend to walk the Point Pleasant Beach Boardwalk, but Frank Sinatra isn't going anywhere. He will be there tomorrow and every day from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m., as Sinatra songs emanate from two speakers beneath the porch of a house owned by Paul Smith. Mr. Smith, 72, who retired five years ago as head of Sony Records' music distribution department, didn't work with Sinatra but is a longtime fan. He's been playing nonstop Sinatra there for 12 years now (with a month off in December for holiday music), and though his house is called ''Seascape,'' everyone knows it as ''the Sinatra House.'' Occasionally, passersby assume the place is a bed-and-breakfast. ''I had one guy walk into the house sit at my bar and order a scotch and water,'' Mr. Smith said. Is anyone unhappy with 13 hours a day of the Chairman of the Board? ''The only time I hear complaints,'' Mr. Smith said, ''is when the music is not on.'' John Holl

title: 'The Book of Illusions'
description: THOUGHT HE was dead. When my book about his films was published in 1988, Hector Mann had not been heard from in almost sixty years. Except for a handful of historians and old-time movie buffs, few people seemed to know that he had ever existed. Double or Nothing , the last of the twelve two-reel comedies he made at the end of the silent era, was released on November 23, 1928. Two months later, without saying good-bye to any of his friends or associates, without leaving behind a letter or informing anyone of his plans, he walked out of his rented house on North Orange Drive and was never seen again. His blue DeSoto was parked in the garage; the lease on the property was good for another three months; the rent had been paid in full. There was food in the kitchen, whiskey in the liquor cabinet, and not a single article of Hector's clothing was missing from the bedroom drawers. According to the Los Angeles Herald Express of January 18, 1929, it looked as though he had stepped out for a short walk and would be returning at any moment . But he didn't return, and from that point on it was as if Hector Mann had vanished from the face of the earth.

title: Totally Uncooked
description: Michael Klein sits on the garden wall dressed in bicycle shorts and a tie-dyed San Francisco Giants T-shirt, his hair pulled into a ponytail, his expression obscured by mirrored sunglasses. Behind him, rolling along a Northern California hillside, are three terraced acres of organic fig trees, plum trees, pear trees, peach trees, fraises des bois, tomatoes and melons and a bounty of edible flowers. But Klein, 47, is no farmer. A Harvard M.B.A. who made his fortune in data communications before dropping out to hang with the Grateful Dead and become an environmental advocate, he is on the well-heeled vanguard of the hottest (or, in this case, the coolest) dietary trend: raw-foodism.

title: August 25-31: INTERNATIONAL; DEVELOPMENT SUMMIT
description: Thousands of government officials converged on Johannesburg for the United Nations World Summit on Sustainable Development and struggled to produce a global plan to promote economic growth in poor countries while protecting the environment. At week's end, the delegates were deadlocked over time frames for the conversion from fossil fuels to renewable energy and for the cleanup of garbage; there also were divisions over reducing subsidies in the developed world. More than 100 leaders were expected at the summit, which comes 10 years after the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. But many delegates fear the plan will only reaffirm old promises. Rachel L. Swarns

title: Man Plans Parties. The Wind Laughs.
description: THE annual sailing party scheduled for a steamy August Saturday took place on a steamy August Sunday -- minus the sailing. ''You can't change nature,'' said James Sharp Brodsky, 35, founder of Sharp Communications, event planners and marketing specialists. He had intended to give a lunch party at sea on his family's 60-foot Swan racing yacht, the Odyssey, based in Newport, R.I. But fog stopped it from making the trip here, so Mr. Brodsky made some quick phone calls and procured the Lelanta, a restored 80-foot Alden schooner built in 1929.

title: The World; What Is it About British Men? Cheap, Drunk and Stiff Lipped
description: JUST as some women date only prison inmates, so there are those who yearn above all for Englishmen, with their exotic customs and their reputation for making even banal remarks sound like brilliant repartee. Madonna, such an enthusiast that she successfully acquired first an English accent and then an English husband, is perhaps the most prominent contemporary example.

title: Covering Opera, If Not Its World
description: Here is another spiffed-up British tome to put alongside The New Oxford Companion to Music, issued recently by Oxford University Press. The New Penguin Opera Guide, edited by Amanda Holden, is an updated and expanded version of a work edited by her and published eight years ago by Penguin Books. At 1,164 pages ($30), it claims in a press release to be ''the most comprehensive single-volume opera encyclopedia ever published in paperback.'' Comprehensive, that is, in terms of what it covers: opera, and not the opera world.

title: Global Warming an Issue For National Parks
description: WHEN President Theodore Roosevelt established the world's first national park at Yellowstone, the idea was that with careful stewardship, nature's unspoiled expanses could be preserved forever. Nowadays scientists understand these ecosystems as giant circles of change, their evolution driven by the forces of nature but also by the actions of people.

title: On Barely Getting By in Argentina
description: Nidia Quiroga (right): ''You see me here digging through the garbage -- what else can I say? I have to choose between feeding my children or clothing them. If they don't have clothes, they can't go to school. My husband is too old to work now; he's in his 50's. In this country, once you reach 40 or 50, it's just time to die. And children are supposed to stop growing when they're 6 or 7. Today it's impossible to get milk for a baby! It takes me an hour, but sometimes I walk to the office of social services to see if they can help me. They never have anything. Now there are going to be elections. But why should we waste our time and energy to go and cast a vote? To elect another delinquent to office? There are times when I want to pick up and go, just pack everything up and leave here. I don't know where to.''

title: In the Region/Long Island; In Homes, Too, Horsepower Adds to Prices

While the house, in Hauppauge, was large enough for the family, which included three children, its half-acre lot was too small for their three horses.

title: Sagaponack Golf Course Calls Off Expansion
description: The owners of the Poxabogue Golf Center in Sagaponack, the only golf course open to the public in Southampton Town, say they have abandoned their effort to expand and are moving ahead with a subdivision plan. It could carve out as many as 18 house lots on the owners' two adjacent Montauk Highway land parcels, one of which has been a golfing facility since 1957. Both properties are zoned for residential use.

title: LOW BUT STEADY ON COLLEGE TESTS
description: New Jersey high school seniors' scores on college entrance tests remained nearly identical to scores from last year, putting New Jersey in the bottom of the rankings on verbal and mathematics skills. New Jersey seniors scored an average of 498 on the verbal test, down one point from last year and below the 504 national average. Mathematics scores averaged 513, the same as last year and below the 516 national average. New Jersey students rank in the bottom 20 among states on both tests. However, New Jersey is second only to Connecticut in the number of students who take the test. Having more test-takers frequently brings down the average scores, according to the state Department of Education, which announced the results last week. In New Jersey, 82 percent of seniors took the test, compared to a national average of 46 percent. Karen DeMasters

Commuting from Los Angeles, he shaved once a week, drove a beat-up clunker and slept in a cheap motel. In an office of suits and khakis, he customarily wore cowboy boots with pinstripe suit pants, polo shirts and an earring. He became notorious for screaming and swearing at younger lawyers for offenses like the failure to underline the phrase ''provided, however'' while preparing a contract, lawyers who worked with him said.

''If you don't end up liking each one of Franzen's people, you probably just don't like people,'' David Gates wrote here. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSON, SY
description: WINSON-Sy. Died peacefully in his sleep Saturday morning August 24th. He was 76. Sy Winson was born Seymour Tennenbaum on April 3, 1926 to Polish immigrants Frieda and Jack Treitl and grew up in the depression era south Bronx. Tennenbaum was an Ellis Island appellation. Winson was a name his halfbrothers adopted. He enlisted in the army at 17 and drove a tank through Germany during World War II. He was admitted to Harvard but instead studied aeronautical engineering at Cooper Union in the late 1940's. Sy ran a series of businesses in downtown New York, changing with growing technology, in advertising, varityping and graphic design, though his great passion and immense talent was for typesetting in the years before desktop publishing irrevocably altered that landscape. He would say, ''I was there for the beginning, the middle and for the end of typesetting.'' After a brief early marriage, Sy met and immediately fell in love with painter/scholar Abbie Franks and had three children and a series of energetic german shepherds. Sy was a dynamic and sensual man of extremes with elaborate lists of great loves and a deep hates and could articulate them at length with astounding wit and fervor. What he hated, the short list: paisley, small typeface, ornamentation, piety, neckties, conceit, liberal politicians, and the great outdoors. What he loved: his dogs, his family, office supplies, war books, styrofoam, his suburban house, A.E. Housman, his children's accomplishments, pastrami, movies at home, cooking up clever practical devices of plastic and tape, all night talk sessions, and listmaking. Sy had said in recent times, ''I've had a swell life. I had great dogs and I married the woman I wanted to.'' He is survived by his wife Abbie, two of his children, Julie Winson of Santa Fe and Suzi Winson of New York City, his granddaughter Isabel Winson-Sagan from his late son Robert Winson, brother Harold Winson, assorted nieces and nephews, and his dog Gigi. Donations in his name can be made to The Humane Society.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: BERNIE DODD (William Holden), Broadway producer, gets the wrong idea about Frank Elgin in THE COUNTRY GIRL (1954) when he casts him as the star of his new musical. Frank (Bing Crosby) has been on a drinking binge since his son was killed, and he's so determined to be both sober and affable that his drab wife, Georgie (Grace Kelly, who won the best actress Oscar for the role), has to play the bad guy, making demands on his behalf. Bernie, who's a little bitter about women since his divorce, decides Georgie is the problem. ''They all start out as Juliets,'' he says , ''and end up Lady Macbeths.'' The characters get to work out there emotional misunderstandings in 1950's New York, which looks too black-and-white glamorous for words. When these people decide to go out for a cup of coffee, they head for Sardi's. George Seaton, who directed, also wrote the screenplay, based on Clifford Odets's play - Thursday at 10 p.m. and Thursday/Early Friday at 3 a.m. on WE.

title: The World: First Among Evils?; The Debate Over Attacking Iraq Heats Up
description: WHEN Vice President Dick Cheney declared last week that ''the risks of inaction are greater than the risks of action'' when it comes to ousting Saddam Hussein, the rest of the world read between the lines. Despite White House denials that President Bush has yet to decide about military action, it sounded as if Mr. Cheney was saying that he and his boss have concluded there is no diplomatic solution to the Iraq problem.

title: Sports of The Times; Augusta Compounds Its Mistake
description: SLOWLY, stubbornly, Augusta National is evolving into a little green planet revolving around itself.

title: Aleksandra Pietrzyk, William Winters II
description: Aleksandra Elzbieta Pietrzyk, a daughter of Anna Pietrzyk of Lublin, Poland, was married yesterday to William C. Winters II, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Winters of Valhalla, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph A. Blenkle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Name of Jesus in Valhalla.

title: The Promotion Of Prescription Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Is a Contact Sport
description: Dubner writes of young men who have been given educational opportunities that others are denied and who are about to start entry-level jobs at salary levels that few people ever reach. Despite these favorable circumstances, the N.F.L. finds it necessary to force-feed them instructions on how to avoid the consequences of being rich and attractive to women. The emphasis is not on what harm they might do to others, but on how their thoughtless behavior might diminish their own careers and cloud the image of the N.F.L.

title: The Truth About Confessions
description: How many people over the centuries have been executed or spent life in prison on the basis of a false confession? Eddie Joe Lloyd of Detroit, who in 1984 confessed to the gruesome rape and murder of a 16-year-old girl, was freed from prison last week because DNA testing proved that he was innocent. He had spent 17 years behind bars.

title: After the Veil, a Makeover Rush
description: IN May, Debbie Rodriguez found herself in Kabul, Afghanistan, on a relief mission with a group of American doctors, nurses, dentists and social workers. Ms. Rodriguez, a hairdresser from Holland, Mich., had volunteered to work as a videographer and gofer. But she quickly found that the need for medicine, dental fillings and counseling was nothing next to the pent-up demand for a makeover.

title: Far From Midtown, She's Fallen in Love With the Sea
description: WE'RE ghosting, sailing very slowly in a sluggish breeze, through Greenport Harbor in the 28-foot wooden schooner Annie, which the artist Arden Scott built for herself. We're pointed toward the double granite plinths of Ms. Scott's Maritime Monument, which in a less murky dusk would frame the North Star.

title: The Nation; In Tense Times, a Court Insists on Open Doors
description: WHEN a federal appeals court in Cincinnati declared last week that the Bush administration's practice of holding deportation hearings in secret was unlawful, it represented more than the first major appellate ruling on the government's post-Sept. 11 legal tactics. The decision may also prove akin to a landmark Supreme Court decision from nearly 40 years ago, Sullivan v. The New York Times, which dramatically expanded First Amendment rights and established a precedent that would have applications in cases far removed from the historic moment that gave rise to it.

title: Barbara Johnson, Christopher Johns
description: Barbara Annette Johnson, the daughter of Elizabeth Long Johnson and Lynn Douglas Johnson of Delran, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Stephen Johns, the son of the Rev. Dr. Roger D. Johns and the Rev. Dr. Louise Stowe-Johns of Rockville Centre, N.Y. The bridegroom's father officiated at Metropolitan Memorial United Methodist Church in Washington. The bridegroom's mother took part in the ceremony.

title: Private Sector; Don't Fax Me. I'll Fax You.
description: Steve Kirsch built his latest company, Propel Software, in San Jose, Calif., around speedy service. After all, his signature -- and only -- product is the Propel Accelerator, which is supposed to make dial-up Internet connections faster.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  O'REILLY, DOROTHY DOTY
description: O'REILLY-Dorothy Doty. Oct. 15, 1924-Aug. 31, 2000. Thank you for your poems and writings. You really were a special and good person, and I will always miss what might have been. Renee

title: Word for Word/Wanna Bet?; Taking the Long View And Wagering on What's to Come
description: WITH the de facto end of summer upon us, there is a natural tendency for the pulse to quicken, for the mind to snap out of repose and for debate to begin on the immediate burning questions of the fall. Will an invasion of Iraq come before Christmas? Which fashion fad will we succumb to first -- pencil skirts or rugby shirts?

title: No Tree Sitters Here
description: THE CLIFT HOTEL and its lobby bar, the Redwood Room, have spent almost an entire century playing host to this city's brandy-swilling, cigar-smoking bluebloods. Last year, when the hotelier Ian Schrager and his favorite designer, Philippe Starck, renovated the Clift, which is in the downtown theater district near Union Square, some citizens started a ''Save the Redwood Room'' campaign, demanding that it not succumb to Mr. Starck's patented brand of garish chic, with ''Alice in Wonderland''-scale seating.

title: Easier to Build, But More Difficult to Finance
description: WHILE there are scores of modular home manufacturers for consumers to choose among, the same cannot be said for modular home lenders.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GINGOLD, JEFFREY
description: GINGOLD-Jeffrey. 2/19/48-8/31/87 Missed sorely. Loved forever. Mom, Arlene and Bonnie.

title: Corpus Linguistics
description: John Rosenthal (On Language, Aug. 18) is correct in attributing the defense of ''It is I'' to prescriptive linguists, but he's off base with ''Whom shall I say is calling?'' That unfortunate locution has been put into the mouths of scores of butlers by writers who are neither prescriptivist nor descriptivist; they are simply wrong. The sentence calls for ''who,'' as the subject of the verb ''is calling,'' not for ''whom,'' as the object of ''shall say.''

title: August 25-31: INTERNATIONAL; CHARGES OF A TERROR CELL
description: Four Arab men were indicted in Detroit on charges they operated a sleeper terrorist cell plotting violent attacks on the United States and abroad. According to the indictment, when the men were arrested in September, federal agents found in their apartment what were believed to be surveillance tapes of Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., and the MGM Grand Casino in Las Vegas. All four are to be arraigned on Tuesday. Jeremy W. Peters

description: A German man who has hounded Serena Williams at tennis tournaments from Wimbledon to Australia was arrested yesterday in Flushing Meadows, Queens, on stalking charges, officials said.

title: Sleepless Nights Over Final Cuts
description: Marcus Floyd had a plan for Friday night: go out with family members who had made the trip to see him play in the Jets' final preseason game against the Eagles. And then pray. That is what fringe players who hope to survive the final cuts of an N.F.L. team do while they wait for the call that will either fulfill a childhood dream or send them packing.

Last year, 11,855 au pairs aged 18 and 26 were placed in families by six federally approved agencies. About the same number are expected this year.

description: A MODERN ARCADIA

title: Mott Street as a Path to Revolution For the Father of Modern China
description: The spirit of Sun Yat-sen can still be found along Mott Street, though few seek him anymore. Most newcomers to Chinatown do not even know his name, much less the story of his revolutionary time here more than a century ago. The father of modern China, Sun was a passionate man who transformed his nation from empire to republic when he organized the overthrow of the Manchu (Qing) dynasty in 1911 and founded the Kuomintang, or Nationalist Party.

description: All that talk about Rutgers returning to football prominence is premature at best, and maybe just wishful thinking.

title: The Sullen Majority
description: I took a taxi to the north of Tehran, looking for the secret basement. In an ordinary street on an ordinary block, I rang the buzzer, opened the door and went inside, and suddenly it hit me: from somewhere, deep in the depths, music. It was coming from underground, literally -- a rich mix of Western rock and Eastern melody.

title: Elissa Wolfson, Stephen Kress
description: Elissa Ruth Wolfson and Dr. Stephen Wayne Kress are to be married today at the couple's home in Ithaca, N.Y. Rabbi Steven J. Shaw is to perform the ceremony.

title: August 25-31: NATIONAL; NEW YORK'S OLYMPIC BID
description: The United States Olympic Committee advanced New York and San Francisco as the two finalists in the bid for the 2012 Summer Olympics. Houston and a joint Baltimore-Washington submission were eliminated for consideration by the committee's bid evaluation task force. On Nov. 3, the committee will choose between the two finalists, and the winner will then compete against the top foreign contenders. The International Olympic Committee won't announce the final selection until 2005. Kari Haskell

title: 'The Mulberry Empire'
description: The Amir Dost Mohammed Khan had fifty-four sons. And his favourite among these sons was Akbar. One day Dost Mohammed feared that he was ill, and close to dying, and he called his fifty-four sons to him. They came from the far peaceful corners of the kingdom of the Amir Dost Mohammed Khan to the great city he had caused to be built, and as they rode through the country, they were not troubled or threatened. The wisdom and strength of their father made straight roads for them, and the justice he had wrought smoothed their passage.

He respects the game, knows its history as if he were a graybeard, elevates games with humor and pokes fun at himself and his craft. He has called four World Series and would seem to have a long baseball career ahead of him, like Vin Scully's or that of his father, Jack.

title: 'The Book of Illusions'
description: EVERYONE THOUGHT HE was dead. When my book about his films was published in 1988, Hector Mann had not been heard from in almost sixty years. Except for a handful of historians and old-time movie buffs, few people seemed to know that he had ever existed. Double or Nothing , the last of the twelve two-reel comedies he made at the end of the silent era, was released on November 23, 1928. Two months later, without saying good-bye to any of his friends or associates, without leaving behind a letter or informing anyone of his plans, he walked out of his rented house on North Orange Drive and was never seen again. His blue DeSoto was parked in the garage; the lease on the property was good for another three months; the rent had been paid in full. There was food in the kitchen, whiskey in the liquor cabinet, and not a single article of Hector's clothing was missing from the bedroom drawers. According to the Los Angeles Herald Express of January 18, 1929, it looked as though he had stepped out for a short walk and would be returning at any moment . But he didn't return, and from that point on it was as if Hector Mann had vanished from the face of the earth.

title: Cameras at Traffic Lights Draw Revenue, and Doubts
description: The old joke about how red traffic lights in New York are just a suggestion may not be so outlandish. A study by the City Comptroller's office last year found that drivers run red lights in New York some 1.2 million times each weekday. That's roughly 70 violations every 5 seconds.

Its job is to synthesize musical and social traditions with high-styled vivacity, especially those that dwell on different sides of the tracks in real life. The highbrow meets the lowbrow; sweet meets hot; uptown, downtown, all around the town.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Fort Greene; Diversity, Culture and Brownstones, Too
description: SPIKE LEE has relocated to the Upper East Side and Spike's Joint, his boutique at the corner of South Elliot Place and Lafayette Avenue, is history, but the filmmaker's lens still frames the image of Fort Greene, the Brooklyn neighborhood where he grew up. When he began his career with the 1986 comedy ''She's Gotta Have It,'' he drew upon the world he knew best: the artsy, well-educated, African-American middle class that has thrived in Fort Greene since the mid-19th century.

The events of Sept. 11 scarred the skyline and jarred the language. From the first moments, the disaster required new terms to describe new facts and feelings. In the last year, a whole glossary has arisen to describe just about every aspect of the terrorist attacks. There's an ABC just for the international aspect (Al Qaeda, American Taliban, Axis of Evil . . .). A longer, more touching vocabulary has arisen specifically from the destruction of the twin towers, one reflecting strong human needs for utility and respect.

title: Hiding That New Wrinkle
description: Specialized beauty products may have their place in the bathroom cabinet, but customers seeking more versatility could turn to all-purpose balms for on-the-spot troubleshooting. The latest fixture on bedside tables and in makeup kits, these high-end salves smooth frizzy hair, eyebrows, elbows, heels and virtually everything in between. Bobbi Brown's Extra Soothing Balm ($50 at Neiman Marcus) and Jing Jang Crme ($18 at www.sephora.com) are packaged in portable pots, while L'Occitane's Beurre de Karit ($35) comes in a jumbo tin. Clinique's Moisture Stick ($13.50 at Saks Fifth Avenue) offers fine application for under-eye lines and for cuticles. For those who prefer a liquid form, Este Lauder's Healing Essence is an aromatherapeutic tonic ($35 at www.esteelauder.com).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDRES, DR. GIUSEPPE
description: ANDRES-Dr. Giuseppe. Died in Pisa, Italy, on July 28th. A pioneer in kidney research, he received his M.D. in Pisa, and his Ph.D. at the University of Rome. He served as Distinguished Professor of Microbiology, Pathology and Medicine at SUNY, Buffalo (1970-90). He then worked as Immunopathologist at Massachusetts General Hospital, while acting as Professor of Pathology at Harvard and Columbia Medical Schools (1990-99). Throughout his career, he defined the role of the immune system in certain kidney disease and studied rejection in kidney transplants. He received many honors, serving as an advisor for the WHO in Geneva, as a member of the NIH Pathology-A Study Section, as a NIH Fogarty Senior International Fellow, and as a Committee Member at the National Academy of Science. He was given SUNY's Stockton-Kimball Award, the Award of the Intern Society of Blood Purification, and the 28th Annual Ernest Wit Memorial Lecture. He was on the editorial boards of 12 journals, and a member of 15 professional societies. He published 200 works, including seven books on immunopathology. Dr. Andres would like to thank his colleagues, who for over fifty years, made his life fruitful and interesting. He is survived by his wife Maria Letizia, in Rome, and two children, Chiara and Pietro, in San Francisco.

title: Joining the No-Weight List
description: Tasti D-Lite, the low-calorie frozen dessert, which was introduced in the 1980's and became a diet staple for chic weight watchers, may be encountering competition. A new soft-serve entry, CremaLita, has been fast accumulating a following in Manhattan. These fans like the creamy base and the more than 60 flavors, including NY Cheese Cake and Dulce de Leche. An average four-ounce serving weighs in at 70 calories and zero grams of fat (unless it is smothered in one of 10 toppings, which include espresso dip and chocolate syrup). Next month, CremaLita is to begin selling Carvel-style cakes; until then, fans can make do with a cup or cone at one of three Manhattan locations: 220 Eighth Avenue (21st Street), 2174 Broadway (77th Street) and 1592 Third Avenue (89th Street). At the Third Avenue location, which opened last month, the lines are out the door. Kim Hartman, an Upper East Side mother, is a regular. ''I went to the grand opening,'' she said. ''And I've eaten it for lunch every day since.'' JENNIFER LAING

title: Roll-Up Rubber Hits the Road
description: For the traveler who has everything, travel shoes may be just the ticket. Both the Reebok and Bottega Veneta companies have come out with footwear designed to be collapsed and rolled up, allowing it to be stashed away as easily as a pair of socks. Reebok's Travel Trainers are flexible, lightweight slip-ons ($65 at Searle stores) that have a rubber sole, which allows the sneaker to be crushed flat, folded in half and fastened with an attached elastic loop; unfolded, the shoes resemble yoga shoes. To outfit dressier journeys, Bottega Veneta makes soft leather loafers for men and women ($540 to $580) that can be rolled up and packed in a matching leather bag; although the shoes are designed for outdoor walking, venturing into truly rough terrain is probably not advisable. Interestingly, both shoes are available in eye-popping bright colors like lime green and neon orange -- perhaps so their tiny shapes can be easily spotted at the bottom of a garment bag.

title: Rails-to-Trails Initiative Advances in Port Jeff
description: Port Jefferson received state grants worth nearly $2.3 million last month to help pay for two environmental initiatives in the village. The first involves $2 million to convert an abandoned 11-mile Long Island Rail Road right-of-way into bicycle and pedestrian trails. The right-of-way, which begins at the edge of the train station in the village runs east toward Wading River, was constructed in the 1890's as a railway extension but has been closed since 1938. The money will come from the state's Transportation Enhancements Program and will help pay for new asphalt lanes, lighting, signs and benches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, LEE
description: McCABE-Lee. Of Newport, RI, and Jupiter, FL, passed away on August 30, 2002, at home in Newport. Born in New York City in 1921, she is survived by her longtime companion, Kathleen O'Connell. Lee worked at the New York Times from the 1940's through the mid 1950's. She was the editor of the Sunday Times gardening section. Lee wrote several children's books, including ''I'll Take Cappy'' (with Norbert Fagan) and ''T-Shirt Tourist,'' published by Dodd Mead in 1955. She was the founder, editor and publisher of the ''Manhattan Gazette,'' a community newspaper published in the 1970's, of which the Christian Science Monitor wrote, ''So artistic is the layout that the front page is worthy of framing.'' She was a well-known graphic artist in New York City. Lee was an avid tennis player. She was a member of the ''Seventh Regiment Racquet Club'' and of the ''A'' team of the Women's League of the New York Athletic Club. Lee was also a member of the Newport Preservation Society and the Redwood Library. Services will be in Newport, RI.

Then my older sister, Jody, cornered me in her kitchen last Christmas with her plea: ''When will I ever have a chance to visit an African village, if you don't take me?'' All these years she'd heard the stories and seen the slides. Now it was her turn.

title: Baseball Without Metaphor
description: One night last fall Barry Bonds, the demon of America's pastime, caught a glimpse of his own redemption. The player who had been called a ''prima donna,'' a ''phony,'' ''overrated,'' ''a cancer'' and a ''spiritual drain on baseball'' was about to do what no one had ever done. He was having the greatest season in the history of the game, and now the 37-year-old San Francisco Giant was on the verge of breaking the single-season home-run record set by Mark McGwire only three years earlier -- and finally, as he had always vowed, ''melt'' his critics' pens.

title: Dancing With Dictators
description: For a nation that honors democracy and freedom, the United States has a nasty habit of embracing foreign dictators when they seem to serve American interests. It is one of the least appealing traits of American foreign policy. Like his predecessors, President Bush is falling for the illusion that tyrants make great allies. If Mr. Bush is not careful, Washington will be mopping up for years from the inevitable foreign policy disasters that come of befriending autocrats who maintain a stranglehold on their own people.

title: Corrections

All are part of a series that, when completed in 2008, will have commemorated each of the 50 states.

title: Confronting Anti-American Grievances
description: Nearly a year after the start of America's war on terrorism, that war faces the real risk of being hijacked by foreign governments with repressive agendas. Instead of leading a democratic coalition, the United States faces the risk of dangerous isolation. The Bush administration's definition of the challenge that America confronts has been cast largely in semireligious terms. The public has been told repeatedly that terrorism is ''evil,'' which it undoubtedly is, and that ''evildoers'' are responsible for it, which doubtless they are. But beyond these justifiable condemnations, there is a historical void. It is as if terrorism is suspended in outer space as an abstract phenomenon, with ruthless terrorists acting under some Satanic inspiration unrelated to any specific motivation.

title: BackTalk; Tape From 1965 Easier to Find Than Ill Will Toward Koufax

Sandy Koufax, his favorite player on his favorite team, was pitching at Dodger Stadium. Koufax was the best pitcher in baseball, perhaps the greatest lefty of all time; 37 years later, his hold on a new generation of baseball fans would prompt me to chronicle his career.

title: Into Their Labor
description: This Labor Day comes at the end of a 12-month period in which the face of American heroism was a worker's face. First there were the dust-covered firefighters, cops and emergency workers, and then the welders and excavators grimly digging all winter, the mail sorters risking their lives, the underpaid soldiers fighting in Afghanistan and, finally, a month ago, the nine grimy coal miners trapped deep underground in Pennsylvania. They tied themselves together with cable 240 feet below the surface of the earth -- an indelible image of solidarity that gave the country a badly needed metaphor and a happy ending as well. The year's only good news was the sudden appearance of half-forgotten virtues like stoicism and sacrifice. Working stiffs turned into bands of brothers and Joe Six-Pack became the martyr, while the rest of us received a measure of redemption. We repaid them in an outpouring of news coverage, political speeches, merchandising and movie and book deals.

title: Karen Freedman and David Sims

title: The Free-Trade Fix
description: Tina Rosenberg (Aug. 18) is clear on the point that ''bad'' globalization serves short-term corporate interests and ''good'' globalization sets out to meet long-term humanitarian goals. In the case of the United States, one way for good globalization to break free of the bad is to let the news media do its job. By focusing on the human costs, short- and long-term, of corporate globalization and on the rapid impoverishment of ecological and social systems, journalists committed to good globalization can get their words in before bad globalists rewrite the rules for free speech.

The pace is languid enough that moms quietly feed brownies to toddlers in the lazy sunlight falling on a sidewalk cafe. A backdrop of fluffy Catskill mountains rises at the end of the road.

title: Straining to Be The Nouveau Hitchcock
description: ''PLUS a change, plus c'est la mme chose,'' the French have been known to say: the more things change, the more they stay the same. That proverb has been popping into my head with increasing frequency in the past few years -- practically every time I sit down to watch a new French movie. The French cinema has, of course, changed in many ways since its last moment of glory, the 60's, when the filmmakers of the New Wave -- the likes of Jean-Luc Godard, Franois Truffaut, Eric Rohmer, Claude Chabrol, Jacques Rivette, Alain Resnais, Jacques Demy, Agns Varda and Chris Marker -- were at their collective peak. What has remained constant, though, as urgent as the craving for a Gauloise, is the French fascination with the Hitchcockian thriller. These days, it looks suspiciously like an obsession.

title: Two Faces of a Pianist Who Had Many
description: THE pianist Glenn Gould's career was bracketed, rather eerily, by landmark recordings of Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations. The day after making his New York debut in 1955, Gould, then 22, was signed to an exclusive contract by Columbia Records. Later that year he recorded the ''Goldbergs,'' his debut release. At the time, this long and complex Bach work, an original aria with 30 variations, was considered esoteric fare, but Gould's exhilarating recording became a surprise top-seller, attracting an enormous crossover audience.

title: The Nation; Where Hands Still Labor
description: IN this high-tech age of bioengineering, supercomputers, space shuttles and globalized financial markets, the men and women with hands and muscles are still there, laying bricks, sweeping cafeteria floors, making hotel beds. They are the army of manual workers doing the unheralded, largely forgotten jobs that also make the nation go. They hammer the nails, trim the meat, clean the sidewalks. There are millions of them, including 327,000 hairdressers, 2 million janitors, 265,000 file clerks, 130,000 messengers, 948,000 housekeepers, 109,000 brick masons, 24,000 hand sewers and 148,000 meat and fish trimmers. In recent years immigrants, men and women from Asia, Africa and Latin America, have filled many of these manual jobs, especially the low-end, lowest-paying positions. ''Manual labor is more with us than many people think,'' said Kate Bronfenbrenner, a professor of labor relations at Cornell. ''We will always need people to clean our streets, empty our bedpans and build our buildings. Computers can't do the most fundamental jobs at the core of our economy. There are a lot of dirty jobs, jobs requiring hard physical work, that someone's going to have to do.'' STEVEN GREENHOUSE

title: 'Nobody's Perfect'
description: Indecent Proposal stars Woody Harrelson and Demi Moore as David and Diana Murphy, a young married couple living in California. He is an architect, she sells real estate, but times are hard; the film starts in a welter of voice-overs as they look back on better days. This is sad for them but great news for the audience, which gets to see Woody Harrelson trying to play a high school kid by wearing a shaggy wig: it's one of those preposterous, sublimely wrong moments that make you glad to be a moviegoer. As I watched these early scenes, I began to tremble with anticipation: this could be the great bad film of our time, a host to all its plagues. The omens were certainly good: the director is Adrian Lyne, the man who brought us Flashdance and 91/2 Weeks . On the other hand, his last movie was Jacob's Ladder -confused, maybe, but also genuinely sombre and scary, and played without show by a haunted Tim Robbins. Was that just an aberration, or was Lyne really turning thoughtful? Would Indecent Proposal punch us awake with a study in sexual envy worthy of Polanski? No need to worry. From the moment when David and Diana sink to the kitchen floor and start to deconstruct their underwear, and the pulse of a love song throbs into life on the soundtrack, you know that Adrian Lyne is back in form. And there's more to come: a yacht that cruises into the sunset, straight from a Bacardi rum ad, and a Las Vegas casino where the dice are shot in fun-size close-up, tumbling in slow motion over the baize.

title: Another Slap at Democracy On Wall St.

title: QUICK BITE/Summit; At Last, a Pizza With Just the Right Crunch
description: My search is over . . . for now. After trekking through endless sections of Millburn, Maplewood, Springfield, Short Hills, Livingston and Summit I think I have found it -- the perfect slice. I confess, I'm addicted to Doria's Pizzeria on Springfield Avenue in Summit. Whether you get it stripped down with the traditional pizza sauce and cheese (whole pies come in two sizes for $8.65 or $9.65) or revved up a bit with sausage, pepperoni, mushrooms, green peppers and onions ($15 and $16), the result is the same -- a crunchy, tasty treat without worrying about having to dab at your chin with a napkin before the grease dribbles to your lap. Yes, Doria's has the requisite sandwiches that any neighborhood pizzeria offers, all quite good. And there are tasty and economical pasta meals (from $5.25 to $7.50) -- spaghetti, ziti, linguini, ravioli and chicken or eggplant parmigiana. But let's face it, it's the pizza that keeps bringing me back several times a week. Whether it's a whole pie fresh from the oven or a slice or two popped back in the oven or run through a miniature conveyor belt type of affair to warm it up, the result is the same -- a thin, crunchy crust slightly blackened on the bottom, no pools of grease lurking amid the pepperoni and a tasty tomato sauce that can make or break the best slab of dough. The place itself -- a roomy blue and white shop nestled amid a row of upscale shops and Realtors featuring their multimillion-dollar inventory -- is bright and always clean. And the people working there are always pleasant and efficient. Mitchell L. Blumenthal

title: A Shrine To Arts And Crafts

Ahead is a green-stained, cedar-shingled building, which from my East Coast perspective resembles an Adirondack lodge. Then I am reminded of Frank Lloyd Wright's prairie houses with their celebration of the horizontal line. An outward sweep of unpainted, broad roof overhangs, projecting outriggers, and rafter tails appear to dance with the light.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Replacement Priests Celebrate Mass
description: Replacement priests celebrated Mass yesterday in the Fairfield County churches of two parish priests who were stripped of their duties for aiding a fugitive priest accused of child sex abuse. The diocese wants the fugitive priest, the Rev. Lawrence Brett, who is accused of molesting at least a dozen altar boys and other children, to surrender to the civil authorities. The two priests, the Rev. Gerald T. Devore, above, and the Rev. David W. Howell, told no one that Father Brett, 65, had fled to the Caribbean island of St. Maarten after he was suspended from the priesthod in 1992. In Stamford, at St. Maurice Parish, the Rev. Bernard A. Keefe celebrated Mass and said he would oversee the parish instead of Father Devore. At St. Joseph Parish in South Norwalk, the Rev. Gilbert D'Souza said he would take over for Father Howell. On Saturday, Bridgeport Bishop William E. Lori said he had ordered Father Devore, 65, and Father Howell, 60, to a religious house for an indeterminate period of prayer and reflection. Bishop Lori said he was ''gravely disappointed.'' Marc Santora (NYT)

In a suit filed Thursday, State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer accused the company, Student Marketing Group of Lynbrook, of deceptive business practices, saying it distributed student surveys to high school teachers. title: Looking Past Labor Day
description: Labor Day has always been a better vantage point to view the turning of the calendar than the turning of the seasons. The day marks a transition that is mostly behavioral, a shift into a different gear. In that respect, this year is no different from other years. Children go back to school this week, the president goes back to Washington, and there is a general sense of resumption. But for better or worse, Labor Day also usually comes loaded with reluctance, the recognition that another indefinable summer is slipping away like so much sand out of the sneakers you wore to the beach. And in that respect, this year is very different. Whatever direction we may have been looking during this three-day weekend, we know that when the pace of regular life resumes tomorrow we will be looking ahead overwhelmingly to a single thing, the commemoration of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Little Girl's Suffering Becomes A Big Opera
description: The big event of the Salzburg Festival's closing days was the performance of Helmut Lachenmann's opera ''Das Mdchen mit den Schwefelhlzern'' (''The Little Match Girl''). Completed in 1996, this is beginning to seem like a piece that marks its era. It is conceived on the grand scale: a large orchestra is employed for a continuous stretch of more than two hours, with several vocal-instrumental groups participating from around the auditorium. It must be colossally expensive to present, yet it has already been staged in Hamburg and Stuttgart in Germany, and in Paris, and there will soon be a second recording. (The first was recently released by Kairos.)

title: A Wider Role in Afghanistan

The Defense Department has argued, for just as long, that the United States has more urgent tasks, such as chasing down the remnants of Taliban and Al Qaeda forces. Now, in a welcome reversal, the Bush administration appears ready to use some of its troops to stabilize areas of Afghanistan outside the capital. The change in approach needs to be made expeditiously, while American officials work to persuade other countries to join the effort.

His leadership after the attack on New York City a year ago, though not unflawed, created a measure of good will in the state's Democratic heartland. Mr. Pataki's ''Southern strategy'' -- a focus on the city and especially on its growing cadre of Hispanic voters -- is classic for an incumbent Republican and promises major electoral dividends. Equally important, the governor has plenty of money left to spend to bring his message home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADDOCK, ROBERT C.
description: PADDOCK-Robert C., 71. Retired Head Counselor of Great Neck South Senior High School, died Tuesday, July 30, at his home in Shoreham, Long Island from heart failure following complications of a stroke. His family was with him at the time. Born in Auburn, New York, in 1930, the second of three children, Paddock went on to complete a BS in Teacher Education in 1952 from Springfield College, in Springfield, Massachusetts. While an undergraduate, he met Sandra Jenkins, and they married soon after his graduation. Their marriage lasted 48 wonderful years until her death from colon cancer in February, 2001. Paddock started his educational career as a high school science teacher, first in Massapequa, NY in 1958 and later in Manhasset. He joined the Great Neck School district in 1964 as a guidance counselor. Paddock went on to complete a Master's in School District Administration from CW Post in Greenvale, New York, in 1985 while working full-time for The Great Neck Schools. By 1985 Paddock was Head of Guidance for Great Neck South Senior High School. He retired from the educational field in 1992. Paddock and his late wife, Sandy, lived in Glen Cove, New York, for over 30 years. Sandy's business, the boarding kennel The Animal Inn, was relocated to Glen Cove in 1990 so the couple could be closer to her work. In the summer of 2000, Sandy retired and The Paddocks moved to Shoreham, Long Island. Mr. Paddock is survived by his son, Bruce T. Paddock, an educational writer and editor living in Lakeville, CT, his daughter, Patricia J. Paddock, a project manager for Girl Scouts of the USA living in Manhattan, and a sister, Georgia Dudley of Woodbury, CT, in addition to daughter-in-law, Arliss, son-in-law, Gerard Cariffe and many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 7 from 1:30-5:30 P.M. at DiMaggio's On The Bay in Port Washington, NY. Donations may be sent to the James A. Baker Institute for Animal Health, Hungerford Hill Road, College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, New York 14853.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, FRED E.
description: BROWN-Fred E. 89, formerly of New York City and Morristown, N.J., passed away on Friday, August 30, 2002 at home in Lake Placid, NY. Born in Muskogee, Oklahoma, Mr. Brown graduated from The University of Oklahoma with a Bachelor of Science degree in 1934 and from the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration with an M.B.A. degree in 1936. Mr. Brown joined the staff of TriContinental Corporation, one of the early investment companies, and became associated with J.&W. Seligman & Co. in 1936. Mr. Brown served as senior partner of the Seligman firm from 1955 to 1981, as chairman and chief executive officer of J.&W. Seligman & Co. from 1981 to 1989 and as director of the latter organization until 2000. He also served as chairman and chief executive officer of the Tri-Continental Corporation and the Seligman mutual funds. In his work with TriContinental he developed the first automatic dividend reinvestment and cash purchase plan offered by a publicly traded company. Mr. Brown had been a director of American International Group, Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Co., Newport News Shipbuilding, Inc. and Seaboard Surety Co. He served on numerous boards including College Retirement Equities Fund, Morristown (NJ) Memorial Hospital, The Peck School, Vassar College, and Trudeau Institute. At the time of his death, Mr. Brown was a board member of Lake Placid Center for the Arts, Lake Placid Education Foundation, and Lake Placid Horse Show Association. He was a founding board member of the Adirondack Community Trust. Mr. Brown served in the Field Artillery and Quartermaster Corp. during World War II, attained the rank of Lieutenant Colonel and was awarded the Legion of Merit. He received the Regents Alumni Award, the Distinguished Service Citation and an Honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree from The University of Oklahoma. He as a member of The Oklahoma Hall of Fame. Mr. Brown is survived by his wife Enid and son Frederick of Austin, TX, as well as his stepchildren: Dorothy Darlington of Old Greenwich, CT, Peter Darlington of Valkaria, FL, Alice Cutler of Morristown, NJ, and Caroline Roy of Lake Placid and ten grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, September 3, 2002, at St. Eustace Episcopal Church, Main Street, Lake Placid at 10:30 a.m. Donations may be made to the Adirondack Community Trust, 105 Saranac Avenue, Lake Placid, NY 12946 or to The University of Oklahoma Foundation, C/O Ron Burton, 100 Timberdell Road, Norman, OK 73019. For more info call The Clark Funeral Home in Lake Placid, 518-523-3337.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Wantagh: Drowning In East Bay
description: A 44-year-old man drowned in the East Bay yesterday afternoon while trying to retrieve a boat, the Nassau County police said. The man, James J. Errico of Freeport, was standing in the water near the causeway that leads from Wantagh to Jones Beach, clamming with two of his nephews, 10 and 11 years old, when rising tide started to carry away the boat, the police said. Mr. Errico and the older boy tried to retrieve the boat, to no avail. The boy was rescued by a passing boat. Mr. Errico was pronounced dead at the scene, and the boys were treated for hypothermia at Nassau University Medical Center, the authorities said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Region Under Control
description: President Eduard A. Shevardnadze said that Georgian security forces had established full control of the Pankisi Gorge, a lawless region said to be home to dozens of Islamic terrorists and hundreds of Chechen fighters living among some 4,000 Chechen refugees who have fled the Russian war in Chechnya. Georgia sent 1,000 police officers and security troops to the region late last month, setting up checkpoints and vowing to impose order. Georgian officials also said they planned to build up the number of border troops near Chechnya and Ingushetia, another Russian republic. Russia has accused Georgia of allowing Chechen fighters to raid across the border. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: GAS-ELECTRIC CAR DEAL Two Japanese automakers, Toyota Motor and Nissan Motor, said they would jointly develop hybrid gas-electric cars. Toyota, which has taken the global lead in introducing mass-produced hybrid vehicles by selling 120,000 of its Prius hybrids since 1997, will supply components for Nissan models that are to be sold in the United States, starting in 2006. Hybrid vehicles reduce pollution emissions by switching between a gasoline engine and an electric motor.   (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profits Rise At Insurer
description: Europe's second-biggest insurer, Axa, which is based in Paris, reiterated that first-half operating earnings climbed 17 percent, buoyed by higher premium rates after the Sept. 11 attacks. Profit, excluding one-time items and acquisition-related costs, rose to 1.02 billion euros ($1 billion) from 876 million euros in the period a year ago, Axa said. The earnings matched preliminary figures published on Aug. 21. Still, its shares, which have fallen 44 percent this year, fell again, losing 5 percent, to 13.23 euros.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: 'Willy' The Whale Has Some Fun
description: Keiko, the gentle killer whale that starred in the 1993 movie ''Free Willy'' and was reintroduced to the wild this summer in Iceland, has spent two days frolicking with children and accepting snacks in the shallows of Sklvik Fjord near Kristiansund on the central Norwegian coast. His keepers hoped that Keiko, after seven years of rehabilitation in Newport, Ore., and Vestmannaeyjar, Iceland, would join wild orcas in the North Atlantic Ocean after leaving his pen July 7. A marine biologist, Jan Einarsen, said the whale seemed well fed after his journey but may be seeking human solace after being snubbed by his own kind. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: New Police Chief
description: Hugh Orde formally took over as chief constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland, which replaced the overwhelmingly Protestant Royal Ulster Constabulary last November with a force recruited evenly from Catholic and Protestant applicants. A former deputy assistant commissioner with the London Metropolitan police, Mr. Orde, 44, has already made headlines with his direct remarks on sensitive issues such as how the police handled warnings before the 1998 Omagh bombing, which killed 29 people, and accusations of police collusion with Protestant paramilitaries in the killing of a Catholic lawyer in 1989. His immediate challenges are the nightly clashes in Belfast and his force's low morale. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Reviving Reform in Iran
description: Iran's president, Mohammad Khatami, has finally lost patience with the unelected mullahs who have systematically thwarted his reform agenda. It's about time. Mr. Khatami is by far Iran's most popular political figure, but reactionary clerics maintain a tight grip over the country's courts, security forces and economy, and regularly veto parliamentary laws and candidates. After years of trying to avoid confrontation with the religious establishment, Mr. Khatami issued a bold challenge last week, promising to push through new laws limiting their powers and strengthening his own authority to protect constitutional rights.

Son of William and Edna DeCuir (deceased) and cherished brother of Billie Johnson, Patsy Crowder and the late Bennett DeCuir, passed away August 31, after a two year struggle with brain cancer. Born and reared in North Little Rock, Arkansas, Hank served in the army as a medic, taught junior high in Arkansas and came to New York with an MSE in Counseling and Guidance in 1969. Here he worked for New York State as an employment counselor and as a rehabilitation counselor until taking early retirement after 26 years of service. A patron of the arts, he spent his leisure time at theaters, concerts, galleries, and at the McBurney YMCA. In addition to his sisters, he is survived by four nephews, a niece and a large and adoring circle of friends.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Exports Surge
description: Colombian exports rose 3.3 percent in July on surging oil sales abroad, the government's statistics agency said. Total exports increased to $1.04 billion in July from $1.01 billion in the month last year, with the United States holding its position as the largest single recipient of Colombian goods as it bought more than 40 percent of the total. Sales of oil and its derivatives, the country's largest export, surged 18 percent to $272 million in the month. Coal, the second-biggest export, brought in $55.4 million, a drop of 21 percent from the same month last year. Coffee sales abroad fell 7.3 percent to $51.9 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold: Jury Selection In Trial Of Rabbi
description: Jury selection is scheduled to start today in the second trial of a rabbi accused of arranging the murder of his wife in 1994. The judge, Linda G. Baxter, plans to give an initial pool of about 300 potential jurors a detailed questionnaire, asking them about their knowledge of the first trial of the defendant, Rabbi Fred Neulander, and their views on the death penalty. If Rabbi Neulander, 60, is convicted, prosecutors plan to seek the death penalty. The first trial ended in a mistrial last November after the jury failed to reach a verdict. Judge Baxter moved the second trial to Freehold from Camden because of publicity during the first. Jury selection is expected to take about six weeks, with opening arguments set for Oct. 21. Robert Hanley (NYT)

Giuliani's old neckties will be sold in a charity auction to benefit families of those killed on Sept. 11. Proceeds from the auction, which takes place tomorrow evening at Henri Bendel department store on Fifth Avenue, will benefit the Twin Towers Fund, a charity Mr. Giuliani established to assist families of the uniformed rescue workers who were killed. Mr. Giuliani said he found several dozen neckties while cleaning out his office at City Hall last year. His companion, Judith Nathan, suggested they might be donated to charity, he said. Larry Levy, president of the Twin Towers Fund, said $185 million had been raised for the charity, $155 million of which has been distributed. (AP)

title: World Briefing | Haiti: Criticism From Rights Panel
description: The government has failed to stop the country's slide into lawlessness and social turmoil, a report by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights has concluded. The commission, part of the Organzation of American States, said courts were influenced by the government and armed gangs broke the law with impunity and likened the economic, health and social problems to serious rights violations. Foreign donors have suspended direct aid to the government until it resolves an electoral dispute. The Organization of American States, under pressure from Caribbean nations alarmed by Haiti's unrelenting poverty, is expected this week to consider a resolution that would unblock the aid. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GEORGIA: REGION UNDER CONTROL President Eduard A. Shevardnadze said that Georgian security forces had established full control of the Pankisi Gorge, a lawless region said to be home to dozens of Islamic terrorists and hundreds of Chechen fighters living among some 4,000 Chechen refugees who have fled the Russian war in Chechnya. Georgia sent 1,000 police officers and security troops to the region late last month, setting up checkpoints and vowing to impose order. Georgian officials also said they planned to build up the number of border troops near Chechnya and Ingushetia, another Russian republic. Russia has accused Georgia of allowing Chechen fighters to raid across the border.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Grows

The growing surplus should help to calm markets, which have been jittery because of an uncertain outcome of the Brazilian presidential election on Oct. 6, and concern about Brazil's ability to keep up payments on $250 billion in public debt. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: SAP Founders Give Up Joint Control
description: The largest European software company, SAP, said its founding shareholders had dissolved an agreement that bundled their shares. The pooled voting rights, totaling 30.17 percent, were split among the founders Hasso Plattner, left; Dietmar Hopp; and Klaus Tschira to simplify the company's capital structure and conform to generally accepted accounting practices, the company said. SAP added that the move did not indicate that the founders were intending to reduce their holdings significantly. Shares of SAP fell 5.5 percent, to 70.67 euros ($69.46), in trading in Frankfurt. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fund Manager's Profit Falls
description: Schroders, the British fund manager, said that falling stock markets and client withdrawals contributed to a 58 percent decline in profit in the first half of the year. Net income was 13.3 million ($20.7 million), compared with 31.3 million, in the period last year. Clients withdrew 2.3 billion in the first six months of the year, less than the 5.6 billion they pulled out in the first half of 2001. Schroders, which has been reorganizing its business and cutting jobs to lower costs, gave no indication of what it might do with a 700 million cash pile. Some analysts said they expected the money to be used for acquisitions. Schroders also said its chairman, Peter Sedgwick, would retire on Dec. 31, after 32 years with the company. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, SHELDON H.
description: HARRIS-Sheldon H. Professor Sheldon H. Harris passed away on August 31, 2002, after 74 years of an extraordinary life. He and his beloved wife, Sheila, were happily married for over 46 years. He was the devoted and adored father of Robin and David. A brilliant scholar, he was Emeritus Professor of History at California State University, Northridge, revered and held in the highest affection by his colleagues and students. Author of the definitive publication, ''Factories of Death: Japanese Biological Warfare, 1932-1945 and the American Cover-Up,'' which exposed the Japanese medical atrocities on the Sino-Soviet border during WWII, and was the culmination of his relentless investigations and exhaustive research over the past 25 years. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

title: Sheldon Harris, 74, Historian Of Japan's Biological Warfare

title: Ranking Risks of Gene-Altered Animals
description: A recent report from the National Academy of Sciences has helped clarify the risks posed to human health and the environment by the genetic manipulation of animals to produce food, medicines or other products. The report makes it clear that one issue of great concern to many consumers -- whether genetically engineered foods are safe to eat or drink -- is no great problem. The greater danger lies in the possibility that genetically modified fish or insects might escape into the environment and disrupt or wipe out existing species. These issues need to be vigorously addressed by federal regulators, whose jurisdiction and authority in such matters is often murky.

Bristol-Myers said that it was in discussions with the F.D.A., which sent a letter indicating that the product can be approved after certain issues are resolved. The company did not reveal what concerns the F.D.A. raised. Bristol-Myers said it expected to win F.D.A. approval of Abilify this year. Abilify might be Bristol-Myers's most important introduction since its Plavix heart medicine, approved in the United States in 1997, analysts say.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Telecom Italia To Name New Co-Chief
description: Telecom Italia will name Riccardo Ruggiero as co-chief executive, with Carlo Buora, replacing Enrico Bondi, who resigned last week, people close to the company said. Mr. Ruggiero, 42, was put in charge of the company's local and long-distance phone business a year ago, after Pirelli took control through a 7 billion euro ($6.89 billion) takeover of Olivetti. Before joining Telecom Italia last year, Mr. Ruggiero was chief executive of Infostrada, Telecom Italia's largest competitor in the traditional phone market. He is the son of Renato Ruggiero, former secretary general of the World Trade Organization who was the Italian foreign minister until he resigned in January after a dispute with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.
