title: Master's Degrees at Nyack College
description: Two new degrees, a master's in accounting and in business administration, are being introduced this fall at Nyack College, a Christian liberal arts college with campuses in Nyack, N.Y., Manhattan, Washington and Dayton, Ohio. ''My customers are demanding it,'' said GEORGE STRATIS, head of the business school, referring to undergraduate students and alumni. About 1,500 were polled about adding the programs, and 80 percent said the degrees were needed to be competitive in the work force. To enable students to get real work experience, or to earn income while studying, many classes will be held on evenings and weekends. The M.B.A.'s help move the college closer to its goal of building up graduate programs. Seventeen people have signed up, most business school graduates from the Nyack campus. Dr. Stratis said he expected at least 300 to be enrolled over the next five years. The M.B.A.'s will be offered on the Manhattan and Nyack campuses. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARIKH, SUHRID, M.D.
description: PARIKH-Suhrid, M.D. The Medical Staff Society of New York Hospital Queens mourns the loss of its distinguished colleague and extends its heartfelt sympathies to his family. Marvin Leder, M.D. President Talat Addasi, M.D. Vice President Gabriel DeAngelis, M.D. Secretary/Treasurer

title: BOEING AND GENERAL DYNAMICS FACE NAVY DEADLINE
description: The Navy yesterday gave General Dynamics and Boeing a deadline of Sept. 30 to return to the Treasury $2.3 billion paid during development of a fighter aircraft that was canceled. Dick Cheney, who was defense secretary at the time, canceled the A-12 program in January 1991. General Dynamics and McDonnell Douglas sued, causing the largest military contract dispute ever. A federal court ruled against the companies in August 2001; talks have continued since with another session scheduled tomorrow. General Dynamics called the Navy's demand ''an unseemly negotiating tactic and an apparent effort to gain advantage during settlement talks'' and said the company would ask a federal appeals court to delay the collection if negotiations failed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, MILTON A.
description: HOROWITZ-Milton A. The Partners of 425 Park Avenue Company mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Milton Horowitz. We shall miss his advice and judgement. He was a true partner and wonderful counsel. Our deepest condolences to Lila and the entire family.

title: Veterans, Recognized
description: To the Editor:

title: Stones Back to Classic Beat in New Tour
description: After youth, after sex appeal, after shock, after spectacle, after arrogance and long after guaranteed top-10 hits, what is left for the Rolling Stones is a simple thing -- music. The music of a classic rock backbeat, of two guitars tangling like strands of barbed wire, of a singer whose voice is a leathery bray and whose body twitches in syncopation from head to toe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, PHOEBE
description: FRIEDMAN-Phoebe. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Phoebe Friedman, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of her passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. May all who loved her be comforted. Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. Herbert C. Bernard, Secy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: President Tries To Fend Off Foes
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma, in a bid to stave off growing opposition, sought legislators' support for a government reform plan that would shift some of his power to Parliament. Political opponents, who are planning mass protests on Sept. 16, have accused Mr. Kuchma of corruption, and they say he was connected with the killing of Georgy Gongadze, an opposition journalist found decapitated and mutilated nearly two years ago, charges Mr. Kuchma denies. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: So Sweet a Taste, So Complex an Aroma: A Touch of Pork Is the Perfect Match
description: A CLASSIC riesling is the kind of wine that leaves you wanting to do nothing more than swirl it around in its glass, marvel at its pretty pale-straw color and wonder how such a spare-looking wine can have so much aroma. There might be passion fruit, melon, apricots, yeast, minerals and coriander, all mingling and emerging from its bouquet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, ROBERT W.
description: LEE-Robert W. 72, died Sunday at his residence following a long illness. He and his wife Brenda owned and operated the Wishing Well Restaurant in Saratoga Springs, NY-a popular spot for summer racetrack attendees. Mr. Lee was born in 1929 in Chatham, NJ, and attended Seton Hall University before enlisting in the US Navy during the Korean War. He was appointed an NYS Racing Commissioner in 1993 and served with distinction on the Board of Directors of the NYS Thoroughbred Breeding and Development Fund.

title: Sports of The Times; Monica Seles Still Loves The Game
description: WHILE waiting out the monsoon over the Labor Day weekend, Monica Seles did what tennis fans everywhere were doing: she flicked on the television.

title: Queens Man Arrested in Conspiracy to Kill Guyana Immigrants for Insurance Money
description: A Queens man was arrested yesterday in what federal prosecutors said was a conspiracy to take out life insurance policies on Guyanese immigrants and then have them killed to collect the proceeds. According to the complaint filed yesterday, the conspirators killed at least two people and collected hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about economic growth in Japan referred incorrectly to a credit analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities who discussed the country's problems with nonperforming bank loans. The analyst, Rieko McCarthy, is a woman.

title: Free-Market Upheaval Grinds Mexico's Middle Class
description: By Mexican standards, lvaro lvarez and Alma Amarillas are a solid middle-class couple. But in the 20 years they have worked to build a stable life for themselves and their children, the economic ground beneath them has never stopped shaking.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Diana Lam, the new deputy schools chancellor for learning and teaching in New York City, misstated the basis for her job offer from Chancellor Joel Klein. He met her once and spoke with her by telephone several times before the offer, he said. It was not based on one 45-minute telephone call.

title: Lord Porter, Nobelist in Chemistry, Dies at 81
description: Lord Porter, who shared the 1967 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing a technique to set off and observe chemical reactions with flashes of light, died on Aug. 31. He was 81.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Four New West Nile Cases:
description: Health officials reported four more cases of West Nile virus across the state yesterday, including two in New York City. An 85-year-old woman from Richmond Hill, Queens and a 27-year-old woman from East Tremont in the Bronx have been hospitalized with the disease since Aug. 25, city officials said, bringing the number of cases detected in the city so far this year to six, including one fatality. In Nassau County, officials reported a second case, involving a 77-year-old Mineola man, who they said became ill on Aug. 19, but whose condition was said to be improving. The other case reported yesterday was in Syracuse, where officials said a 57-year-old man who became ill on Aug. 27 was improving.

title: Who Cleans the Mess?
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprise Roles for Figs
description: ''I'M a fig junkie,'' Judy Rodgers said. ''I like them cooked, raw, even fried: we dip them in flour and buttermilk and fry them to serve as an hors d'oeuvre. Sometimes I toss fresh figs with a little anisette so they bloom with surprising flavor.''

title: U.S. to Step Up Spraying to Kill Colombia Coca
description: With the full support of the Colombian president, the United States has begun what American officials say will be the biggest and most aggressive effort yet to wipe out coca growing.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The Taliban period helped Afghans to understand the importance of freedom. So even when government officials are unhappy at being criticized, I think that they are wise enough to appreciate the fact that people like us at last have the chance to say what we think.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, PAULINE (NEE HAW)
description: YOUNG-Pauline (nee Haw). September 1, 2002. Wife of the late Albert Ming Young. Mother of Donald and Albert Walter. Sister of Frances Britt. Friends will be received on Thursday, Sept 5 from 3:30pm-7pm at True Light Lutheran Church, 195 Worth St., Chinatown. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to the Museum of the Chinese in the Americas, 70 Mulberry St., NY, NY 10013.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, SARA
description: MILLER-Sara, on August 28, 2002. Mother of Dorothy, Elinor, and Jonathan; mother-inlaw of Paula and friend David; grandmother of Daniel, Peter, Joshua, Margaret, and Katie; great-grandmother of Phoebe, Jonah, Sasha, and Eliza. Treasured memories will sustain us with warmth, strength, and love. Memorial contributions can be made to the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

title: Court Says Israel Can Expel 2 of Militant's Kin to Gaza
description: The Israeli Supreme Court ruled today that the army could expel from the West Bank the brother and sister of a Palestinian militant accused of organizing a suicide bombing and send them to the Gaza Strip.

title: People
description: * Robert Solomon was named president and chief executive at the New York office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. He had been president at Solomon Strategic, New York, a consulting company.

title: A Persistent Small Supplier Gets Contract for Hospitals
description: One of the biggest groups that help hospitals buy equipment said yesterday that it had awarded a contract to the small maker of a potentially life-saving device whose long travails in obtaining such a deal were a subject of a Congressional hearing.

title: The Dow Takes Another Beating, Falling 355 Points
description: Stocks plunged yesterday on a report that showed that manufacturing remained quite weak, fueling concerns about the already sluggish economic recovery.

title: Let Us Catch the Power of the Wind
description: To the Editor:

title: Loitering in the Mets' Clubhouse
description: Rey Ordonez was sitting in the Mets' clubhouse on Saturday morning, about an hour before the game against the Phillies was to start. Reporters are normally kicked out of the clubhouse 45 minutes before games so we had 15 minutes to go and I was passing the time standing near a bank of televisions in the center of the room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPOLIZIO, MARIA A. NEE TARANGELO
description: POPOLIZIO-Maria A. nee Tarangelo, 84. On August 30, 2002. Devoted mother of Valerie Lindquist, Donna Rosenfield and the late Hon. Michael F. Popolizio. Employed by the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of NY for more than two decades and President of the Greenwich Village Chapter of the American Committee on Italian Migration from 1976 to 1978. Maria was married to the late Emanuel P. Popolizio for 43 years. In addition to her daughters, she is survived by her brother, Robert C. Tarangelo of FL, and five granddaughters. Reposing at the Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:30 AM, at Our Lady of Pompei Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Navratilova Still Tries To Find Her Limits
description: Martina Navratilova, who played in her first United States Open in 1973, is still at it, not all-conquering anymore, but enjoying the moment.

description: Untitled

title: Consolidated's Customers Wonder: What Next?
description: Customers and employees of Consolidated Freightways, the big trucking company that shut down on Monday, spent yesterday trying to determine what happens next.

description: Untitled

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETERMAN, TOMMY
description: PETERMAN-Tommy. 9/3/92. Ten years have swiftly flown by. Fond loving memories shall ever remain. Dougla

title: When We Were Done With Our Project, We Ate It
description: Summer camp is over and grandparents have reluctantly returned borrowed children, so all members of the family are back under the same roof. School is starting, which means a treat or two is in order. Here are some new items to keep children fed, amused, busy and well behaved.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the dwindling ranks of veterans of the 761st Tank Battalion, the first black tank battalion to fight in World War II, used a misspelled given name in some copies for the member who was awarded the Medal of Honor in 1997. He is Sgt. Ruben Rivers, not Rubin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITTMAN, FRED
description: HITTMAN-Fred. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society deeply mourn the loss of Fred Hittman of Baltimore, MD. A widely respected and beloved pillar of support in our organization, he first served as president of the Baltimore Chapter 25 years ago, a position he graciously accepted and effectively managed again for the past three years. An engineer and founder of a medical manufacturing company, Mr. Hittman and his wife, Sandy, funded the Johns HopkinsTechnion Center in Biomedical Engineering and the Fred and Sandy Hittman Gifted Student Fund. They reached the highest level of support as Technion Guardians. Mr. Hittman's devoted leadership and the warmth and zealousness of his support for Israel and the Technion will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Sandy, their children and grandchildren. American Technion Society Evelyn Berger, President Lawrence S. Jackier Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President Philip E. Klein, Co-Chairman Baltimore Chapter Howard Rosenbloom, CoChairman, Baltimore Chapter Natalie Feinblum Director, Baltimore Chapter

title: Faulty Mailing By Pataki Leads to Suit By Golisano
description: Tom Golisano sued Gov. George E. Pataki for libel yesterday over a campaign mailing that stated wrongly that Mr. Golisano had fled the state in the face of criminal charges.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: POSSIBLE JANITOR STRIKE

title: Mont-St.-Michel Journal; Battle for the Future Swirls Below Soaring Towers
description: For over a thousand years, the monastery here has thrust skyward out of the sea, like the pointed finger of some giant piercing the earth's crust. The image favored by visitors is at high tide, when it rises islandlike from the smooth waters of the bay that shares its name.

title: Critic's Notebook: London Stage, a Social Mirror; Shows That Echo Hollywood, Bollywood and the Local News
description: The blood is thick on the floor, and the body parts are piled up like firewood. Euripides, in truth, couldn't have come up with a grislier finale. Seated amid the carnage, a dazed, gore-spattered boy gives voice to the wails of war victims through the ages: ''Oh, will it never end?''

title: A Black Pioneer Takes a Police Union Role in Stride
description: HERE are a few things known about Mubarak Abdul-Jabbar. He is the first African-American officer to be elevated to the executive board of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, a union long seen as a source of the hostility between the police and New York City's black and Latino residents.

title: Bertelsmann to Drop Most of a Book Unit
description: Bertelsmann confirmed plans today to abandon the bulk of its online bookselling service, BOL.

title: 150th-Year Gala, Plus Giuliani
description: Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Fort Greene, the oldest private secondary school in Brooklyn, is celebrating its 150th anniversary this year. RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI, who graduated in 1961, will speak at the sesquicentennial gala aboard the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum on Sept. 26. The school was still an all-boys Roman Catholic institution when Mr. Giuliani's classmates voted him ''class politician'' his senior year. Today the school is coeducational, and about half its 900 students are not Catholic. The school was originally part of the St. James Church on Jay Street, where the De La Salle Christian Brothers, a religious order, taught hundreds of young Irish and German immigrants. When President Lincoln's funeral train stopped in New York, the school band played at the service. In 1933, the school moved to its current home, a four-story Gothic brick building on Clermont Avenue. It is the only high school still supported by the Brooklyn Diocese. Julie Flaherty

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Typhoon Wreaks Havoc
description: North Korea reported scores of people killed, thousands of homes damaged or destroyed and farmland near the east coast border with South Korea submerged after a typhoon, designated Rusa, swept the Korean peninsula. In a reminder of the devastating impact of severe storms on the North in recent years, the Korea Central News Agency said the damage was ''huge'' and warned it would be ''hard to expect any harvest or crops'' in flooded regions. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Poll Shows Europeans Conditionally Back U.S. on Iraq
description: In a new poll, 6 out of 10 Europeans said they would favor an American-led invasion of Iraq if the United States first receives the support of allies and the United Nations.

title: Cordiant Prepares A Succession Plan
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London is expected to outline a succession plan this week for the chief executive, Michael Bungey, who is to be succeeded by David Hearn, chairman and chief executive at the largest Cordiant agency, Bates Worldwide in New York.

title: Napster Says It Is Likely to Be Liquidated
description: The chief executive of Napster said today that the company was headed for liquidation and later resigned and laid off his staff. The move appears to be the final chapter in the story of an Internet business that allowed millions of people to exchange music free online but was undone by lawsuits by the recording industry.

title: Shades of Prewar Paris, With a Jazz Score
description: FOR a close-up display of the power of design, consider Django, a spacious restaurant that opened in June in midtown Manhattan. The ubiquitous restaurant architect David Rockwell has transformed the lobby of an otherwise nondescript office building into a dazzling, shimmery evocation of a brasserie in prewar Paris.

title: A Guide to Pleasing Behavior
description: Summer camp is over and grandparents have reluctantly returned borrowed children, so all members of the family are back under the same roof. School is starting, which means a treat or two is in order. Here are some new items to keep children fed, amused, busy and well behaved.

title: Klein Says Others Must Pitch In to Improve Schools
description: Offering a few deliberately vague hints about his plans for the New York City school system, Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that examining the city's expensive and cumbersome process of building schools was among his immediate priorities, as was protecting classrooms from $100 million in imminent budget cuts.

title: Commerce Rushes In Where Art Once Ruled
description: They have been at war since brush first touched canvas on a busy sidewalk: The artist, narrow shoulders flaring beneath a beret, and the police officer, all brass buttons and nightstick and move-it-along-pal.

title: McDonald's New Recipe Lowers Goo For Arteries
description: Under pressure to make its fast food healthier, McDonald's said today that it was reducing the amount of saturated fat and trans fatty acids in its French fries and other fried foods.

title: Promoting Early Education
description: Four states -- New Jersey, Illinois, Ohio and Minnesota -- have been awarded $350,000 each from the Early Childhood Funders Collaborative, a nonprofit group that advocates education for children under age 5. The grants are to be used to strengthen early-education services, like classes for teachers and public awareness campaigns to promote early learning. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: Personal-grooming marketers decide that American men are ready for body sprays.
description: A MAN'S basic grooming regimen used to consist of a close shave, a bracing slap of cologne and a dab of deodorant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, ELEANOR BLATTEIS
description: WERNER-Eleanor Blatteis, formerly of Great Neck, NY and Palm Beach, FL, passed away on Tuesday, September 3, 2002 in Arlington VA at age 93. Wife of the late Edward A. Werner; mother of Alice W. Charwat, Frederic P. Werner and his wife Jacqueline; cherished grandmother of Robert W. Werner and his wife Suzanne, Kenneth E. Werner, James S. Werner, William E. Charwat and his wife Lauren, Catherine Abrahamson and her husband David, Linda Shaughnessey and her husband Michael; greatgrandmother of 14. Private memorial service and burial.

title: The Jets Turn a Corner And Plan to Keep Going
description: When the Jets practice today for the opening of a season of great promise, the receivers will be chasing footballs and the linebackers will be chasing runners, but no one will be chasing ghosts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTIELLO, RICHARD C., M.D.
description: ROBERTIELLO-Richard C., M.D., died on August 30, 2002. A founding director, 1953, of the Long Island Consultation Center and the Long Island Institute for Mental Health, 1960. Training psychoanalyst of several New York City institutes, author of many books and articles. Military service veteran of World War II, mentor and beloved friend to many psychotherapists and healer to countless patients. A good and decent man. Our condolences to Dr. Terryl Gagnier Robertiello and family members. Robert Moteki

title: Beijing Blocks Access to Google
description: China has blocked access to the popular Internet search engine Google as the government tightens media controls before a shift in leadership expected in November. There was no official announcement of the blockage, but Internet users said they could not reach Google through Chinese Internet servers for the last two days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPOLD, RICHARD
description: LIPPOLD - Richard. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of art.

title: COACH SAYS ITS EARNINGS MIGHT BE HIGHER THAN FORECAST
description: Coach Inc., a seller of luxury leather goods, said yesterday that it expected earnings this quarter would be higher than forecast as customers buy more Hamptons leather and suede purses and Signature fabric handbags. Profit will be at least 21 cents a share on sales of $185 million to $190 million in the first quarter ending Sept. 28, according to Coach, which is based in New York. Analysts expect a profit of 18 cents, the average estimate according to Thomson First Call. Coach earned 14 cents a share on sales of $150.7 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Street Cry's Ankle Forces Him to Retire
description: Street Cry, who, despite a defeat in the recent Whitney Handicap at Saratoga, was the early betting favorite for the Oct. 26 Breeders' Cup Classic, has been retired because of a recurring ankle problem.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Charges In Rape Of Girl, 14
description: A Brooklyn man has been charged with raping a 14-year-old Harlem girl and sexually abusing her sister on Aug. 12, on the basis of DNA evidence, the police said yesterday. A warrant to collect a DNA sample from the man was obtained after the girls identified him as their assailant from a group of photographs, they said. The man, David Pagan, 35, has been in custody since Aug. 20, the police said. The results of the DNA test were released yesterday. Detectives were still investigating whether Mr. Pagan might be responsible for any other sex attacks in the city. On Aug. 12, the police said, a rapist forced the 14-year-old to the rooftop of her building and raped her, then later sexually abused her sister inside their apartment. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Monks' Chanting and John Cage's Silence
description: The fourth annual Evening Stars Music and Dance Festival opened with two separate programs that paid oblique but strong tribute to the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks last year.

title: The Horror of Sept. 11, Replayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A highlight entry and a picture caption in the television listings yesterday, and in the Tuesday pages of the Television section on Sunday, misstated the air time and channel for ''The Caroline Rhea Show,'' a weekday series. It is seen at 12:35 a.m. on Channel 7, not at 9:30 a.m. on Channel 9.

title: Rumsfeld's Search for a Way To Fight a New Type of Foe
description: The deadliest strength of America's new adversaries is their very fluidity, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld believes. Terrorist networks, unburdened by fixed borders, headquarters or conventional forces, are free to study the way this nation responds to threats and adapt themselves to prepare for what Mr. Rumsfeld is certain will be another attack.

title: Tornado Leaves Much of Small Wisconsin Town in Ruins
description: A tornado injured dozens of people on Monday and damaged as many as 100 buildings here, and residents returned today to a town devastated by an estimated $20 million in damage.

title: Transplants Seem Source Of West Nile Virus Cases
description: Three of the four recipients of organs from a single donor who had West Nile virus also developed West Nile encephalitis, strengthening the possibility that the virus can be transmitted through organ transplants or blood, federal health officials said last night.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Financial Advice From Mayor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is fond of giving investment advice, and yesterday was no different. When asked if he minded that the city's Conflict of Interest Board told him to sell his stock portfolio last week, Mr. Bloomberg gave his pecuniary pointers for the day: Buy municipal bonds. Turn your money over to mutual-fund managers. Get a life. The latter advice came when the mayor was asked if he would incur losses when he sold his stock. ''There are other things in life than playing with your stock portfolio, get a life will you!'' snapped the mayor, whose portfolio is vast indeed, to a reporter, whose portfolio is nonexistent. ''I've got to run a city here. I'm not doing it to manage my portfolio. O.K.? Have a nice day. Thank you.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANFORD, GORDON W.
description: SANFORD-Gordon W., of Bronxville on September 1, 2002. Husband of Yvonne Dyer Sanford, father of James L. Sanford and the late Barbara Sanford Donohue, grandfather of Benjamin, Claire, and Michael Donohue, Gates, Owen, and Cooper Sanford, brother of George M. Sanford. Also surviving are three stepchildren and four step grandchildren. Memorial Service at St. James The Less, Episcopal, Scarsdale on Saturday September 7 at 9 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Yale University Class of '33 or New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx, NY.

title: And Now There Are Two
description: Andrew Cuomo's withdrawal from the Democratic primary for governor of New York was a moment of drama in a contest that had otherwise sorely lacked pizazz. Bill Clinton brought down the house by assuring everyone at Mr. Cuomo's press conference that he, Mr. Clinton, was the only person on the stage whose political career was over. (The line worked so well that he repeated it.) Representative Charles Rangel, who was furious when Mr. Cuomo tried to stand in the way of Carl McCall's becoming the state's first black Democratic governor, was all smiles. And Mr. Cuomo himself, who had appeared to be cruising toward a career-ending political defeat on primary day, salvaged his future options.

title: A Move to Trim Public Outlays For Campaigns
description: The city's Campaign Finance Board took a first step yesterday toward trimming the generous matching funds it gives to candidates for small campaign contributions, but it also recommended increasing payments to those battling high-spending opponents like Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, HOPE P.
description: WEISSMAN-Hope P. The Faculty, Students and Alumni/ ae of Wesleyan University's College of Letters, mourn the death of Professor Hope Weissman. She was a dedicated colleague, an extraordinary and daring intellectual, and a devoted teacher. Since 1974 she provided us with a unique spark, and we will miss her sorely.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: A front-page article on Aug. 16 and one on Aug. 17 reported on divisions among Republicans over President Bush's high-profile planning for a possible war with Iraq. The articles cited comments by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and by Brent Scowcroft, the first President Bush's national security adviser, among others.

title: Pret a Manger Selects Green Team
description: Pret a Manger, a sandwich chain that is one-third owned by the McDonald's Corporation, said yesterday that it had selected Green Team Advertising in New York as the first agency for its American operations. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: BUSH TO PUT CASE FOR ACTION IN IRAQ TO KEY LAWMAKERS
description: Senators urged President Bush today to make a convincing case for taking military action against Iraq, and the White House announced that the president would meet with Congressional leaders on Wednesday to make his arguments for confronting Saddam Hussein.

title: A Reporter Who Answers When Opportunity Knocks
description: Since Billy Wilder's death in March, an intriguing fact about his films has become clear to me. Wilder's best work came from actors who worked as smoothly as middleweights, tossing off nimble combinations with fluidity and deceptive power. And that is why his cynical newspaper parable ''Ace in the Hole'' (1951) -- a slugfest by Wilder's standards -- is such an anomaly. Like Alexander Mackendrick's ''Sweet Smell of Success'' (1957), ''Ace'' has a lively and frightening yellow-journalism motif; mercifully, no one has yet tried to turn it into a musical. A new print starts a run at the Two Boots Pioneer Theater today, though it's long overdue for re-release on video.

title: Helping Poor Readers
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Possible Janitor Strike
description: Talks broke down between a cleaning contractor that provides staff to Boston office buildings like the Prudential Center and the union that represents more than 10,000 part-time janitors. The janitors, who seek fulltime work, higher salaries and benefits, earn an average of $39 a day, officials of the union, Service Employees International Union Local 254, said. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: The Horror of Sept. 11, Replayed
description: To the Editor:

title: The Best Way to Cope? Even Experts Aren't Sure
description: As the anniversary of Sept. 11 approaches, bringing with it disturbing memories and emotions, mental health experts say the best strategy for many Americans may be to plan exactly what they will do and where they will be on that day.

title: 9/11 Lesson Plan
description: The Times just ran an article about the trouble teachers were having in deciding what to tell students on Sept. 11. That's a serious question. This is a moment for moral clarity, and here are the three lessons I would teach:

title: Rightists, Teachers Unions And a Poisoned Debate
description: CONSERVATIVES have attacked the National Education Association, the teachers union, for its Web site that gives advice on how to teach about the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. George Will, the Washington Post columnist, wrote that the site made the union ''a national menace.''

title: With 9/11 Flag, a Mystery Unfurls
description: There it was, one of the enduring symbols of Sept. 11: a simple American flag that became an icon when it was raised by three firefighters over the ruins of the World Trade Center. Evoking comparisons to Iwo Jima, the image of the flag, which came from a luxury charter yacht moored near the site, was captured by a news photographer and has since been seen, and imitated, around the world.

title: Recipe: Chocolate Chewies
description: Adapted from "Gottlieb's Bakery  100 Years of Recipes" (Wimmer Brothers, 1984)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Chip Maker Plans Stock Sale
description: Chartered Semiconductor, among the world's largest contract makers of computer chips, said it would try to sell new stock to existing shareholders. It hopes to raise $633 million to help pay for a new factory to catch up with rivals. Chartered's controlling shareholder, the government-owned Singapore Technologies, had already agreed to pay more than $380 million to take up its portion of the rights issue. But Chartered said it would offer its new shares at less than half the price existing shares traded at last week, an announcement that helped send Chartered's stock tumbling 24 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIRKEN, BARBARA
description: MIRKEN-Barbara, September 2, 2002. Cherished and loving wife of Alan, devoted mother of Leslie and Mitchell Rubin, and Jane and Richard Zenker; adored grandmother of Matthew Rubin, and Andrew and Scott Zenker; sister of Frances Brandt and Eileen Mack. Caring and selfless, she brought warmth and wit to everyone whose life she touched. Service Wednesday, September 4, 1PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Goddard Riverside Community Center or the Alan and Barbara Mirken Department of Neurology at Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: Princeton Teachers' Union Votes to Authorize Strike
description: Princeton's public-school teachers voted this morning to authorize a strike, in an effort to pressure the school board to yield on contract language affecting medical benefits and extra pay for playground duty.

title: Capriati Knocked Out by Mauresmo
description: NEW YORK, Sept 4 (Reuters) - Amelie Mauresmo's French resistance proved too strong for third-seeded American Jennifer Capriati on Wednesday as the 10th seed barged her way into her first U.S. Open semi-final 4-6 7-6 6-3.

title: Our Towns; For Tarnish, Buff Gently (Or Ignore It)
description: ROBERT G. TORRICELLI'S latest campaign commercial contrasts his positions on issues with what he says are his opponent's, ending with the tag line, ''Differences that matter.''

title: Jenny Bechtel Whyte, Fashion Designer, 75
description: Jenny Bell Bechtel Whyte, a fashion designer whose creations included dresses made from African printed textiles and clothing made from antique fabrics from three other continents, died on Sunday at Beth Israel Singer Division, a hospital in Manhattan. She was 75 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Parent of Janus Funds Will Reorganize Its Operations
description: Stilwell Financial Inc., the parent of a group of companies involved in mutual funds, said yesterday that it planned to merge its operations under the umbrella of its flagship Janus Capital Management unit and that a longtime Janus executive would run the merged company.

title: MOODY'S CUTS AQUILA'S DEBT TO JUNK STATUS
description: The debt of Aquila Inc. was cut to junk status yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which cited poor returns from investments outside the company's regulated utility business. The rating for Aquila was cut two levels to Ba2 from Baa3, the lowest investment-grade rating, Moody's said in a statement. The debt rating of Aquila's merchant-services subsidiary was cut three notches to Ba2 from Baa2. Aquila has agreed to sell $483 million in assets this year and plans to shed a total of $1 billion to raise cash. The company has canceled acquisitions, cut its dividend and halted energy trading. Lenders have tightened credit to energy companies since the collapse of Enron.

title: Trading Pioneer to Retire
description: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that E. E. Geduld, a onetime doughnut salesman who pioneered electronic stock trading and made a fortune in the process, would retire as head of its Nasdaq trading operations this month.

title: Cordiant Prepares a Succession Plan
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London is expected to outline a succession plan this week for the chief executive, Michael Bungey, who is to be succeeded by David Hearn, chairman and chief executive at the largest Cordiant agency, Bates Worldwide in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELAN, HELEN
description: PHELAN-Helen, of Red Hook, NY, and Stamford, CT, August 2, 2002. Wife of the late Eugene J. Phelan, mother of Mary E. Flynn, Patrick J. and the late Eugene H. Phelan. A Mass of Christian Burial will be 10:00 AM Friday at St. Christopher's Church, Red Hook. Friends may call Thursday 7-9 PM at Burnett & White Funeral Homes, Red Hook.

title: Blair Defends U.S. on Iraq, Reaffirming His Support
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair today disputed reports that a rift had developed between Britain and the United States over Iraq and said that much of the criticism against President Bush's Iraq policy in Europe was ''just straightforward anti-Americanism.''

title: Zambian Leader Defends Ban On Genetically Altered Foods
description: The president of Zambia said today that his country, which is inching toward famine, would continue to refuse relief food that may be genetically modified, calling such food ''poison'' and saying it is ''intrinsically dangerous.''

title: Ah, Sweet Mysteries Of Trenton, She's Got 'Em
description: As backdrops for best sellers go, this is an unlikely city. The architecture ranges from state office buildings that seem Soviet inspired to dilapidated old Victorians and row houses. The downtown nightspots can be counted on the fingers of one hand, the hotels on one lonely finger. The city empties out at 5 past 5, as the bureaucrats make a beeline for the suburbs. There is not even a movie theater or a mall worth walking into.

description: His team in disarray, Vlade Divac has decided to take the world championships seriously.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Standoff Over Al Qaeda Suspects
description: Tribal groups and the army were in a standoff after local leaders refused to turn over four suspected Qaeda members to the authorities, the police said. A brigade of soldiers and several helicopters and armored personnel carriers descended on the village of Janikhel, about 50 miles southwest of Peshawar, after 35 to 40 armed tribesman forced soldiers to release four suspected Qaeda members they had stopped at a checkpoint near the village. Officials said force would be used if the men were not turned over, and negotiations were to continue today. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Russia Scraps Space Plans Of Pop Star
description: The Russian Aviation and Space Agency scrubbed the teenage idol and pop singer Lance Bass today from its passenger list for an October flight to the International Space Station, saying that in the end Mr. Bass lacked the right stuff for space travel.

title: A Trattoria With a Few Surprises Up Its Sleeve
description: THREE colleagues were sitting at a table in the back of the bar area at Crispo, a new Italian trattoria on West 14th Street, looking idly at the menu. They'd been in the place maybe three minutes. Rosemary Clooney was on the stereo, singing ''Mambo Italiano.'' A waitress came along, introduced herself, said she'd like to tell them about the evening's specials. It had, however, been a long day. One of the three -- this one, as it happens -- smiled in a way that made him feel old. ''Could I have a drink first?'' he asked.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Monday about the dwindling ranks of veterans of the 761st Tank Battalion, the first black tank battalion to fight in World War II, used a misspelled given name in some copies for the member who was awarded the Medal of Honor in 1997. He is Sgt. Ruben Rivers, not Rubin.

title: Fort Lauderdale Bonus
description: More than 50 hotels in and around Fort Lauderdale are extending a deal made in conjunction with Spirit Airlines' offer of free flights on Sept. 11. Those hotels, which will provide free lodging on Sept. 11 to Spirit Airlines passengers, are now going to give a third night free from Sept. 13 to Oct. 15 to any guest presenting Spirit ticket receipts or boarding-pass stubs at check-in. The flights must be during the same period as the hotels' offer. It is based on availability and the two paid nights are at the regular rates. A listing of the hotels is at www.sunny.org . The Greater Fort Lauderdale Convention and Visitors Bureau is at (800) 227-8669.

title: Doctor Who Aided John Wilkes Booth Gains Another Day in Court
description: Just blocks from Ford's Theater, where Abraham Lincoln was assassinated in 1865, members of the Mudd family came to a federal courthouse today in the latest round of a 137-year struggle to clear the family name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPOLITANO, MARY ELI ZABETH
description: NAPOLITANO - Mary Eli zabeth. 55, critically acclaimed oil painter, died suddenly in her Upper West Side apartment on August 30, 2002. She graduated from Jersey City State College, summa cum laude, and earned a Masters of Fine Arts degree at City College, NYC. She traveled extensively, and in her junior year abroad in Copehagen, she was selected to debate world affairs in Moscow. Her work was shown frequently at NYC and regional galleries and museums, and she was awarded painting fellowships at several institutions, amongst them ''Yaddo'' in Saratoga Spring's, NY, the ''D.H. Lawrence Ranch'' in Taos, NM and the ''Villa Schifanoia'' in Florence, Italy. Her work was also periodically published and reviewed. She served as Artist in Residence at Stetson University in Florida. Mary lived every day with passion and embraced every challenge with determination and courage; she painted continually and prolifically throughout her life. She is survived by her eternally devoted and loving husband Thomas N. Frankel, loving mother Grace Dwyer, loving sisters Helen Schutz and Linda Schab, nieces Anna and Julia Schutz, and Lydia Hruska, nephews Kyle and Lucas Schab. Mary was an extraordinarily beautiful woman, with an equally beautiful generosity and gentleness of spirit that will remain forever in the hearts and minds of those that knew and loved her and were gratefully loved by her. A memorial service will be held at ''The Riverside Memorial Chapel'' at 2pm., Wednesday, September 4th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, JOHN PATRICK
description: KENNEDY - John Patrick. Loving husband of Doris, father of Maureen, father-inlaw of Ian, grandfather of John Patrick and Patricia Kathleen. He received his undergraduate and law degrees from Fordham University and practiced law in New York for forty years, specializing in real estate and transportation law. He lived in Palm Harbor, Florida and Sag Harbor, New York.

title: On the Radio, Afghans Call Their Nation to a New Day
description: For more than a thousand years, Afghans have begun their day at dawn to the sounds of muezzins summoning them to prayers at local mosques. But these days, at least for those among this nation's 23 million people with radios, there is another, distinctly secular cry rising in the early morning air.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Thief Escapes From Jail
description: A convicted thief being held for a parole violation escaped from the Essex County Jail after switching identification bracelets with another inmate on Sunday afternoon, according to Kevin Lynch, a spokesman for the Essex County sheriff's office. Icxandro Santiago, 22, of Newark switched bracelets with Henry Trabal, 25, who was to be released after posting $3,000 bail for two disorderly-person offenses, Mr. Lynch said.

She demonstrated courage and compassion working together with Father Marie Benoit to save hundreds of Jewish lives in France and Italy during Word War II. The entire Jewish world owes her a profound debt of gratitude. We will never forget her heroism. Memory of the righteous will be a blessing. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Nancy Solomon, President

title: Miami Defenders Lack Experience, But Not Effort
description: While seeking to defend its national championship, Miami has been breaking in a new starting defensive backfield, as was apparent in the Hurricanes' first game last week against Florida A&M.

title: Deadly Oak Disease Infects Firs and Redwoods in California
description: Douglas fir, one of nation's most economically important timber species, and California's coastal redwood, a cultural icon, are infected with a fast-spreading, recently discovered disease, sudden oak death syndrome, scientists said today.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: I.B.M. Will Acquire Access360
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Access360, an identity-management software company based in Irvine, Calif. Access360's programs give new employees the right to use applications they need, deny access to sensitive files and reduce costs by requiring fewer people to monitor who can use certain files, an I.B.M. spokesman, John Crowe, said. Access360's products increase security and automate access to applications and files.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: ICANN Announces Measures To Improve Accuracy
description: The group that manages the Internet's address system yesterday announced measures to improve the accuracy of information in a public database known as Whois that lists individuals and companies that have registered millions of Internet addresses. In response to complaints that many addresses have been registered with false contact information, the group, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, has established an online form at www.internic.net to report address records containing incomplete or false contact data. Susan Stellin (NYT)

description: ASHWORTH INC., Carlsbad, Calif., a designer of golf-inspired sportswear, said its board had authorized the buyback of up to $6.5 million of common stock in the next 12 months.

description: The author of a article in Vanity Fair about the actor Steven Seagal's allegation that he was extorted by the Mafia has told the police that he was threatened at gunpoint last week in Los Angeles, the police said yesterday.

title: Labor Leaders Hail Workers for 9/11 Sacrifices
description: New York City's union movement marked Labor Day yesterday in a far different way than in past years, turning its annual rally into a commemoration of the nearly 3,000 people, including 600 union members, who died in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

title: Congress Returns From Recess, and So Does the Partisanship
description: The Senate's monthlong vacation from partisan floor fights ended today moments after the Pledge of Allegiance, as members stiffened their refusal to compromise over worker rights in the proposed Homeland Security Department, which could delay the new agency for months.

title: Japanese Shares Fall 3.2% to a 19-Year Low
description: The main Japanese stock index plunged 3.2 percent today, reaching a 19-year low and reawakening fears that Japan is about to be swept by another banking crisis.

description: SEIFERT-Randolph J., of Pound Ridge, NY, on September 1st, 2002. Randolph, a graduate of Columbia College and Columbia University Law School, was an attorney first with the New Haven Railroad and later as a sole practitioner in NYC. He served in the U.S. Army during WWII and continued in the U.S. Army Reserves for over 30 years. Randolph was very active with various church organizations, including the National Council of Churches, a Trustee of the New York Annual Conference of the Methodist Church, the Church of All Nations in NYC, and a member of the Pound Ridge Community Church. For info: Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, 914-232-3033.

title: RELIANT ENERGY'S HOLDING COMPANY IS NOW COMPLETE
description: Reliant Energy Inc., the largest power company in Texas, said yesterday that it completed the formation of a new holding company, CenterPoint Energy, as it neared a board vote to separate into two companies. Reliant Energy said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that each share of Reliant Energy common stock was converted into one share of CenterPoint Energy stock. Shares will continue to trade under the REI ticker until the board votes to distribute its 83 percent stake in Reliant Resources Inc., a Reliant spokeswoman, Leticia Lowe, said. The board will meet later this week. Separation of CenterPoint Energy, a regulated utility that delivers electricity in southeast Texas, from Reliant Resources, which sells electricity in Texas and owns power stations in other states, is part of a plan to comply with the 1999 law that opened Texas's $16 billion electric market to competition.

title: Washington Extends Neuheisel's Contract
description: Rick Neuheisel, who led the University of Washington to the Pac-10 title and a Rose Bowl victory two years ago, agreed to a six-year contract extension as football coach going through 2008, school officials said yesterday. The action came three days after Neuheisel took the blame for a penalty, involving too many men on the field, that enabled Michigan to kick a winning field goal as time expired in the season opener.

title: Mayor Calls Charter Panel's Rejection of His Plan Proof of Its Independence
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he while he disagreed with his Charter Revision Commission's decision not to put a proposal on the November ballot that would ban partisan elections, the move proved the commission's independence.

title: In a Seafaring Body Lurks a Writer's Soul
description: From Bangor to Brunswick, from Boston to Block Island, Linda Greenlaw has been up and down New England this summer, talking about and signing her new book, ''The Lobster Chronicles.'' She has also been autographing lobster bibs and plastic lobsters (supplied by her publisher, Hyperion), fishing rods, gloves and oilskin overalls, whatever readers bring in to the bookstores. Not missing a book beat, she even had a signing on an Amtrak train on the way to New York.

title: Continental's Revenue Off
description: Continental Airlines said today that its unit revenue, an indicator of travel demand and fares, fell as much as 4 percent in August from the year-earlier month because of lower ticket prices.

But a question from a reporter about the criticism he has received for his close relationship with the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn seemed to rankle him a little.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Appeal Of Germ Warfare Ruling
description: Relatives of Chinese victims of Japanese germ warfare experiments appealed a court ruling rejecting their demands for compensation from the Japanese government. A Tokyo court last week rejected a lawsuit for damages filed by the 180 Chinese but recognized for the first time that Japan had conducted biological warfare experiments in China during World War II. The plaintiffs demanded that Japan pay them compensation of about $85,000 each and apologize. About 3,000 Chinese are believed to have died in the experiments. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Company Said To Seek Chief To Succeed Martha Stewart
description: Three months after Martha Stewart's name first became associated with the ImClone Systems insider-trading investigation, the company she heads is searching for someone to succeed her as chief executive, people who have been briefed on the search said yesterday.

title: City Planners Approve Cooper Union High-Rises, Citing College's Public Benefits
description: Despite strong objections from some East Village residents, the City Planning Commission approved a plan by Cooper Union yesterday to build two tall buildings that school officials hope will lift its fortunes after a decade of deficits.

title: How To Boil Four-Star Water
description: The joke was going to be that in order to get into the French Laundry I had to get a job there. And like a lot of wisecracks, this one contained more than a kernel of truth. Despite what one reads about the dot-com debacle, the Silicon Valley money that helped transform this one-time mining, timber and prune growing region into a viticultural wonderland still seems immune from what most Americans would consider economic reality. For the moment, at any rate, there is no apparent shortage of lotus eaters willing to spend the $300 or so that dinner for two can easily cost at Thomas Keller's celebrated Yountville restaurant.

Henry lived the teaching, ''Do all the good you can for your fellow man'' until the day he died-delivering food and raising funds for the hungry, teaching children and adults, counseling the sufferingwith his hands and heart. He will be greatly missed by his wife of 57 years, Betty, and his children, Connie and Jerry Von Korff, Art and Shelley Krakauer, and grandchildren, Joshua, Michael, Benjamin, Margie, Lesley and Daniel. Services Thursday, 11:30AM, at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains. description: The Boston Archdiocese has reached a tentative $10 million agreement with victims of a defrocked priest, John J. Geoghan, whose sexual abuse of minors set off the scandal that has roiled the Roman Catholic Church in Boston and around the nation this year, a church official said tonight.

description: With the approach of the first major elections since last year's terrorist attacks, candidates are responding to a sense of public insecurity with commercials that try to inspire confidence in their character and their ability to handle a crisis.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: VW Unit Reaches Accord
description: Volkswagen and the union at its Mexico unit, the only plant producing the New Beetle, settled on a contract hours before a strike was set to start. The deal calls for a wage increase of 5.5 percent and a 1.5 percent increase in benefits. A strike last year lasted 19 days and led to a 10.2 percent wage increase. Demand for the auto has fallen, and hundreds of layoffs are planned in the coming year. The union represents more than 10,000 workers. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: JOHANNESBURG SUMMIT : Energy plan without date is agreed to at summit
description: JOHANNESBURG:  The UN World Summit on Sustainable Development drew closer Tuesday to a global agreement on key environment and development issues that organizers described as a successful plan for action and activists criticized as inadequate.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Shopping Stops In Euro Protest
description: Consumers staged a 24-hour shopping boycott to protest price increases and profiteering resulting from the switch to the euro this year. The boycott was backed in part by the Socialist government amid fears that the country' s inflation, the highest in the euro zone, could climb higher and damage economic growth. Consumer representatives said that about 75 percent of Greeks took part in the boycott, and that more protests were planned. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

After all, hadn't Pete Sampras run out of energy and inspiration at last year's United States Open when required to play three-of-five-set tennis on consecutive days against the next generation? title: 150th-Year Gala, Plus Giuliani
description: Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Fort Greene, the oldest private secondary school in Brooklyn, is celebrating its 150th anniversary this year. RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI, who graduated in 1961, will speak at the sesquicentennial gala aboard the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum on Sept. 26. The school was still an all-boys Roman Catholic institution when Mr. Giuliani's classmates voted him "class politician" his senior year. Today the school is coeducational, and about half its 900 students are not Catholic. The school was originally part of the St. James Church on Jay Street, where the De La Salle Christian Brothers, a religious order, taught hundreds of young Irish and German immigrants. When President Lincoln's funeral train stopped in New York, the school band played at the service. In 1933, the school moved to its current home, a four-story Gothic brick building on Clermont Avenue. It is the only high school still supported by the Brooklyn Diocese. Julie Flaherty

title: Cheap Power Gone, Montana Is to Vote on Buying Dams
description: Even with little population growth and a lack of high-wage jobs, Montana could always count on a few good things. There was cheap electricity, thanks to a power company with the personality of a rich, domineering uncle, and there were river trout that could make people forget their troubles in a hurry.

title: Ramos Is Activated By the MetroStars
description: The struggling MetroStars got a bit of good news yesterday when the club activated the veteran midfielder Tab Ramos.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Christopher Barriscale was named president at the San Francisco office of Fitch Worldwide, owned by the Cordiant Communications Group. He had been vice president for store design and architecture at the corporate marketing group of the DFS Group, San Francisco, a division of LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: BIG VITAMIN DEAL DSM, a large Dutch chemical company, agreed to buy the vitamins and fine chemicals business of Roche of Switzerland for $2.2 billion in cash. The Roche business is the world's biggest maker of vitamins, but the unit was roiled by a price-fixing scandal in 1999. The sale will allow Roche to focus on its core health care operations and will bolster sales at DSM, which is revamping to focus on life sciences. Shares of DSM fell nearly 4 percent, to 42.36 euros ($41.67), in trading in Amsterdam. A Roche spokesman said it would use the cash to strengthen its drugs and diagnostics businesses, but he did not elaborate.

title: That Expected Bounce Is Difficult to Feel Now
description: The primary campaign is over, Andrew M. Cuomo is out of the way, and H. Carl McCall, the presumptive Democratic nominee for governor, can begin campaigning right away against the Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLECHTER, HERBERT D.
description: SCHLECHTER-Herbert D. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Herbert Schlechter, beloved father of Bruce Schlechter, a dear friend of UJA-Federation. Bruce is an associate board chairman of the Mosholu - Montefiore Community Center, a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation, and an active member of several committees at UJA - Federation, including the real estate, job development, and planning and allocations committees. Bruce and his wife, Susan, a member of UJA-Federation's Task Force on Jewish Women and the Fund for Jewish Education, are dedicated to supporting Jewish and humanitarian causes. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Bruce and Susan; their children, Anne and Alan; and to the entire Schlechter family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Rubin Shows No Fear In Her Three-Set Defeat Against Venus Williams
description: Whipping up an improbable set point, Chanda Rubin moved Venus Williams around the court with the assertiveness of a stage director, cracking ground strokes as hard as countertops into each corner, testing the elasticity of her opponent's vast reach.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Baby Found On Day Care Doorstep
description: A newborn boy was found Monday night sleeping inside a diaper bag left at the doorstep of a day care center in Mariners Harbor, the authorities said yesterday. Investigators have yet to find the boy's mother. The boy was found at 9:35 p.m. on the steps of the house, at 56 Maple Parkway, where the owners operate a neighborhood day care center, the authorities said. The baby was taken to St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital, where he remained in good condition yesterday. The police said they were looking for the baby's mother ''because of health concerns.'' Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: V.A. Plans to Give Priority In Appointments to Disabled
description: With thousands of veterans waiting six months or more for medical appointments, Anthony J. Principi, the secretary of veterans affairs, has decided to overhaul the scheduling system so the most severely disabled veterans are treated first.

title: Up a Mountain, Chasing a Cheese
description: IT is a simple dish for a complicated part of the world. Frico, they call it: cheese melted in a pan, then allowed to cool into a sheet that cracks into shards under a finger's pressure. Served as the farmers eat it, with potatoes, onions, a bit of smoky bacon, it is called frico del fattore, and it rates as one of the great regional delicacies of a nation that is filled with them. To find it -- and the Montasio cheese with which it is made -- I set out one warm, cloudless morning to drive from the high plains of this central city in Italy's northeastern corner up into the Dolomites, to the tiny village of Sauris di Sotto.

title: Incentives Fueled Record Auto Sales Last Month
description: DETROIT, Sept. 4  The nation's auto companies smashed industry sales records in August, fueled by generous incentives and a willingness by consumers to spend money on new vehicles. But with the sales reports came warnings by industry officials that the frantic pace is not likely to last through the fall, and that stiff competition for buyers would continue to eat into profits.

title: Early Sept. 11 Suspect Is Ordered Jailed and Deported

A man convicted of plotting to blow up tourist sites in Jordan on the eve of the millennium said Mr. Marabh was an agent of Al Qaeda. He lived in an apartment in Detroit just before it was rented to three men who were indicted last week on terrorism charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLS, AMELIA (NEE BLUMENTHAL)
description: PERLS - Amelia (nee Blumenthal). Died peacefully at home August 29, 2002 at age 89 following a long illness. Born in Philadelphia, Dolly attended Smith College and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia Teachers College before teaching in her own nursery school. In 1940 she married Klaus Perls and became his partner for 57 years in Perls Galleries in New York, the representative of Alexander Calder and specializing in Picasso and the School of Paris. She was also a Trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She is survived by her loving husband, Klaus, daughter, Katherine, and son - in - law, Lennart Braberg, grandchildren, Anthony, Alexander and Sarah Rousmaniere, and brother, Joseph Blumenthal. Her son, Nick died in 1987. Dolly will be greatly missed by family and friends.

title: With Strike Looming, Zimmer Stayed Focused
description: Iarrived at the Park Hyatt in Toronto at 9:20 a.m. last Friday. This would not be a glorious assignment. In two or three hours, everyone would know if the players would strike. If they did, they would not be reporting to SkyDome for their game that afternoon. In most cases, they would pack their bags, hail cabs and go to the airport, dispersing until the strike was over. It would be, to use Joe Torre's word, a mess.

description: Following are excerpts from Andrew M. Cuomo's speech yesterday announcing his withdrawal from the race for governor, as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: 15 Losses at Shea, Then Victory
description: Armando Benitez needed only three outs for the Mets to forget about their home losing streak, the most colossal disappointment in a season overrun by them. Three outs for Benitez seemed like a sure thing -- or as close to a sure thing as there is for the Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUO, JULIAN

title: The Wrong Judge
description: Priscilla Owen, President Bush's latest nominee to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, has been at times so eager to issue conservative rulings in cases before her on the Texas Supreme Court that she has ignored statutory language and substituted her own views. This criticism comes not from the ''special interest groups'' she has charged with misstating her record, but from Alberto Gonzales, President Bush's own White House counsel. Mr. Gonzales, who served with Justice Owen on the Texas high court, once lambasted her dissent in an abortion case for engaging in ''unconscionable . . . judicial activism.'' Mr. Gonzales says today that he nonetheless supports the elevation of Justice Owen. We do not.

title: More Koreans Give China the Slip, Invading Embassy School
description: About 20 North Koreans clambered over a low concrete wall and into the protection of the lightly guarded German Embassy School today, the second mass effort to gain asylum by North Koreans here in as many days.

title: OPERATOR OF MONSTER.COM TO BUY BACK SOME SHARES
description: TMP Worldwide Inc., the operator of the Monster.com Web site for job-search services and employment advertising, said yesterday that it planned to buy back as many as five million shares during the next 18 months. The shares account for about 4.5 percent of TMP's total shares outstanding as of yesterday. TMP, which is based in New York, will repurchase the stock to increase the value of investors' holdings, it said in a statement.

title: 2 Companies Reduce Roles In Lobby Group For Generics
description: Two corporate members of a powerful coalition that is lobbying for legislation to bring generic drugs to market more quickly have left the group or reduced their roles after companies that make brand-name medicines threatened to end contracts with the companies, a spokesman for the lobbying group said yesterday.

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that a former director of the Central Intelligence Agency would head a terrorism preparedness task force within the city's Fire Department, a group that will include a former director of Mossad, Israel's intelligence agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, SAMUEL
description: ETTINGER-Samuel of New York and North Miami Beach-Passed away on the morning of September 2, 2002. He was 95 years old. Beloved husband of Dr. Hana Heller, (nee Levine), and the late Charlotte Ettinger, (nee Adler). Cherished father of Philip O. Ettinger, MD, and Stephen J. Ettinger, DVM, and grandfather of Alyssa, Jonathan, Nicole, Andrew, Michael, Robert and Richard. Affectionate father-in-law of Roxanne and Patricia Ettinger, and the late Sandra Ettinger. Adopted with love by step-children Bette and Ronald Wagner, Susan and Buzz Warren, D'vorah and Joel Gorman, MD, the late Toni Heller, and grandchildren Ian and Debra Warren and Leah Gorman. Samuel was predeceased by his six sisters, Charlotte, Pauline, and Fanny Ettinger, Eve Bloom, Belle Allenberg and Ella Stone, and by his brother George. Samuel's name will surely ring a bell among the many thousands of men, women, and young people whose lives were touched and forever changed by their contact with him over so many years-as teacher and principal in the New York Public School System, and as owner and director of Camp Towanda in Honesdale, Pennsylvania. Services Thursday September 5th at 1PM. The Riverside 76th St & Amsterdam . In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made in Samuel's name to the charity of your choice. Samuel, the fortune is ours to have known and loved you for so long. You will be deeply missed!

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE TO OFFER $400 MILLION IN UNITS
description: The Public Service Enterprise Group, the owner of New Jersey's largest utility, plans to sell $400 million of participating units to pay short-term debt and to spend on certain subsidiaries. An owner of a unit, valued at $50, agrees to buy common stock on Nov. 16, 2005, the company said yesterday in a statement. The company plans to offer 8 million of the units, which also have a trust preferred security due 2007 with a liquidation amount of $50 each. Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley are the managers for the offering.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: U.S. Attorney Sworn In
description: Roslynn R. Mauskopf, who was New York State's inspector general until Friday, was sworn in yesterday as the new United States attorney in Brooklyn. Speaking with reporters, she said the fight against terrorism ''needs to be one of the primary focuses of the office,'' which prosecutes federal cases from Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island. Ms. Mauskopf, 45, was sworn in at a private ceremony in the chambers of the chief judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York, Edward R. Korman.

title: Riesling, the American Way
description: FOR winemakers in this country, the riesling renaissance has been under way for 30 years, but wine drinkers have become aware of it only during the last decade. Chardonnay, it seems, is a hard act to follow.

title: Judge Says Sept. 11 Families Can Change Minds on Suing
description: A federal judge in Manhattan said yesterday that he would allow families of Sept. 11 victims who decide to sue the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to change their minds if they later decide to seek an award from the Victim Compensation Fund.

title: Scandal-Torn Palm Beach Diocese Gets Bishop
description: Pope John Paul II named Bishop Sean P. O'Malley yesterday to lead the Diocese of Palm Beach, Fla., a troubled pocket of the Roman Catholic Church where the last two bishops resigned after admitting that they had sexually molested minors.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales Rise Slightly
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association, the main trade association for the semiconductor industry, said yesterday that worldwide sales of semiconductors reached $11.7 billion in July, a 2.9 percent increase over the June level of $11.4 billion. European semiconductor sales in July amounted to $2.156 billion, according to the European Electronic Component Manufacturers Association, a European counterpart to the American chip makers' trade group. The Semiconductor Industry Association found that the global computer chip production industry is on track for 7 percent to 9 percent sales growth in the next quarter. Though the PC industry has been battered in recent years, ''growth continues to be most robust in the digital consumer market,'' said George Scalise, president of the group. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 8 Hurt In Accidents After Robbery
description: Six police officers and two other people were injured in two accidents after a robbery at a grocery store on the Upper West Side last night, the police said. Just after 8 p.m., the police were called to the D'Agostino store on Columbus Avenue between 90th and 91st Streets. Officers followed a car with three men who were suspects and arrested them at Central Park North and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard. Four officers in two police cars headed to the scene were injured in a collision at West 114th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. And there was another accident at West 128th Street and Amsterdam Avenue involving a police vehicle and a truck, in which two officers and two occupants of the truck were injured. All eight people were taken to St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center with injuries that were not considered life-threatening, the police said.

title: Rain Checks
description: The United States Tennis Association continued to clarify its policy on options for ticket holders of rained-out sessions. For grounds pass holders from Sunday or Monday, those ticket stubs can be exchanged for grounds passes for today or tomorrow. Arthur Ashe Stadium tickets for last Wednesday's night session, Sunday's day or night session or Monday's day session can be exchanged for grounds passes or stadium tickets (if available) for today or tomorrow's day sessions. Partial ticket plan subscribers may turn in Sunday's ticket stubs for a grounds pass for today or tomorrow's day session. Lynn Zinser

title: Sears, Promising Skater, Is Found Dead at Home
description: William Sears, a 20-year-old New Yorker who teamed with Katie Boxwell to win the national novice figure skating pairs title in Los Angeles in January, was found dead Tuesday in his family's Manhattan apartment.

title: A Smart Weapon for the Links: The G.P.S.-Enabled Golf Cart
description: FOR weekend duffers, golf is often a running interior monologue composed mainly of vexing questions. Can I use a sand wedge to blast out of this rough? How many yards to the hole? Good decisions can lead to low scores, and bad hunches can wreak havoc. ProLink, a company based in Tempe, Ariz., has developed a computer system for golf carts that is intended to take some of the guesswork out of the equation.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Rates Left Alone
description: The central bank of Australia kept interest rates unchanged for a third month and investors are not expecting another increase in borrowing costs this year as evidence emerges that the economy is slowing. The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Ian Macfarlane, and his eight board colleagues left the target rate for overnight loans between banks at 4.75 percent. That followed their decisions to make increases of a quarter-point in both May and June.

title: Man With Guns Is Arrested in Washington
description: A New Hampshire man who had made anti-government remarks was arrested today about two miles from the White House after officers found 16 guns in his car, the authorities said.

title: 'Rappaport' to Close
description: ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' a revival of the 1986 comedy by Herb Gardner, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, Manhattan. title: Article 2002090592379385891 -- No Title
Technology Briefing | Deals: VeriSign And MasterCard Sign Pact
description: VeriSign Inc., a provider of payment systems for online businesses, has signed a deal with MasterCard International that could help reduce the risk of fraud by making it harder for people to use stolen credit cards for purchases online. VeriSign, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., said its nearly 75,000 merchant customers will be able to verify the identity of customers using MasterCard credit cards by using a personal identification number. As users of the new system, those merchants will benefit from a new MasterCard rule that shifts responsibility for unauthorized online purchases from the merchant to financial institutions. VeriSign, which is also the largest registrar of Internet domain names, processes nearly one-fourth of all online purchases. The specific terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: 3 Seek to Overturn Verdicts in '89 Rape of Park Jogger
description: More than a decade after the beating and rape of a woman who was jogging in Central Park and the conviction of five teenagers in the attack, a defense lawyer is asking a judge to throw out the guilty verdicts based on a convicted murderer's confession and newly emerged genetic evidence.

title: State to Close Queens Plant That Is Biggest Polluter in City
description: Settling a dispute with environmental and community groups, New York State has agreed to shut down a power plant in Astoria, Queens, that is the largest source, by far, of toxic pollution in New York City.

title: Bypassing the PC Sound Card In Favor of a Stereo Link

title: U.S. Accuses Man, 80, of Serving as a Guard at Nazi Labor Camps
description: TRENTON, Sept. 4  The federal government today accused an 80-year-old New Jersey man of serving as an armed guard at three Nazi slave-labor camps, and asked for a court order to revoke his American citizenship and deport him.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Trinidad And Tobago: Another Election
description: The third election in three years has been scheduled for Oct. 7. The government dissolved Parliament last week after another failure to elect a speaker. The two major parties are deadlocked, with each holding 18 seats.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Games For Nintendo
description: Japan's biggest toy manufacturer, the Bandai Company, will develop new video games for the Nintendo Company's GameCube video game player. The games, to be released in November, will be the first made by Bandai specifically for GameCube. Bandai has made hits like Power Rangers and the Tamagotchi digital pet, and has designed software games for Nintendo's older game machines.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Parliament Speaker Convicted
description: The speaker of Parliament, Akbar Tanjung, was convicted of graft and corruption and sentenced to three years in prison for misusing $4.5 million intended to buy food for the poor when he was secretary of the cabinet in 1999. Mr. Tanjung, who heads Indonesia's second-largest political party, is one of the highest-ranking officials to face trial for corruption in a country where it is pervasive. He said he would appeal. Dian Saputra (NYT)

The Federal Reserve chairman said raising interest rates would have caused too much damage to the economy. He said raising margin requirements would not have mattered, although senior Wall Street hands like the economist and consultant Henry Kaufman had long urged him to do so.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lending Bill Passed
description: A City Council committee yesterday passed what could become one of the nation's strictest laws curbing predatory lending practices. The bill, which is opposed by the Bloomberg administration, would ban institutions that issue such loans or purchase them on the secondary market from doing business with the city. Predatory lending is aimed at taking over a borrower's assets and unfairly singles out poor and minority residents and the elderly, advocates of the bill say. But critics argue that the Council's bill will not solve the problem and would hold financial institutions to an unrealistic standard.
