title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Version Of Windows Media Introduced
description: Microsoft released a new version of its Windows Media software with a party in Los Angeles that underscored how important Hollywood's adoption of the technology is to the company. The announcement comes on the heels of the latest release of audio and video player software by Microsoft's main competitor in this area, Real Networks. Unlike the Real Networks player, which plays back all of the major audio and video formats, Windows Media 9 will not play material encoded in the Real Networks format. But Microsoft said the new platform would allow streaming video on the personal computer to look as good as if it were on television and enable providers of digital media to secure their material. The new software platform will also allow content providers to encode high-quality 5.1 channel surround sound for streaming audio and high-definition video with file sizes as small as half of those of DVD's, Microsoft said. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Is There Life for Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Without Martha?
description: Since its inception, the fortunes of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia have been entwined with the image of its founder, Martha Stewart. Now, as legal troubles continue to swirl around Ms. Stewart and her ImClone trades, some analysts are envisioning a future for the public company without Ms. Stewart at the helm and suggesting that could even help.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer's Profit Down
description: Poor weather in Europe and logistical problems in the United States and Russia hit first-half earnings at the Belgian brewer Interbrew, the company said. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization fell 12 percent, compared with the first six months of 2001. A legal dispute with the Mexican drinks distributor Fomento Economico Mexicano has held up the integration of the recently acquired German beer Beck into Interbrew's brand lineup in the United States. Meanwhile, the Belgian company's Russian brewer Sun has lost market share by failing to switch to plastic bottles from its unpopular glass ones quickly enough. The chief executive, Hugo Powell, said that apart from these problems the first-half results were pleasing. Second-half results will suffer from the continued poor weather in Europe, he said. Brewing operations in the Czech Republic were halted by the severe flooding in August. He said it was too early to estimate the impact of the floods on sales. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: A's Set Record By Extending Streak to 20
description: In the first century of the American League, no team accomplished what the Oakland Athletics have accomplished this season -- not when the A's were located in Philadelphia or Kansas City or Northern California, or when baseball teams traveled by train and played only in the daytime. Tonight, before what was said to be the largest crowd for a regular-season game here, the A's set the league record, 20 consecutive victories, with a 12-11 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Talks On Asylum Seekers
description: Chinese and German officials discussed what to do with a group of North Korean asylum seekers who took refuge in the German School in Beijing on Tuesday, German officials said. In the past, China has allowed North Koreans in the protection of foreign embassies to leave, ultimately for South Korea. There was no word from Chinese officials on another group of North Koreans arrested on Monday during an attempt to enter a diplomatic compound. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ruling On Patents Is Reversed
description: American Superconductor, which is developing superconducting wire that could improve the efficiency of power grids, said yesterday that a federal judge in Boston had reversed a ruling by the Patent and Trademark Office that canceled crucial patents underlying its technology. The patents, which American Superconductor controls under an exclusive license from M.I.T., broadly define how brittle superconducting ceramics can be combined with noble metals like silver to allow them to be formed into wire. The Patent Office concluded last year that a similar patent application was filed in Japan by Toshiba researchers 15 days before the patent filing in the United States by M.I.T.

description: MY son, Michael, turns 16 on Sept. 11. Last year, we stood around the kitchen table -- my wife, Susan, my parents and I -- and for Mike's sake tried to put some pep into ''Happy Birthday.'' We groped for words, in the same breath trying to tell him how sorry we were that this had happened on his birthday and how much sorrier that it had happened at all.

title: Coffee and Tea Sets: Stuff Dreams Are Made Of
description: Alessi, the Italian manufacturer, has always been interested in the spirit of the time. About 20 years ago, it brought out the $25,000 Michael Graves temple-shaped tea sets, and has again set out to crystallize the moment. It commissioned 22 avant-garde architects to do coffee and tea sets. Few irregular shapes or exotic materials were left unexplored by the architects, among them Greg Lynn and UN Studio. Above, Kazuyo Sejima's and Ryue Nishizawa's titanium pear coffee set is to be available next spring.

title: BP CUTS GROWTH GOALS BECAUSE OF SHUTDOWNS
description: BP cut its goal for growth in oil and gas production this year because of shutdowns at oil fields in Alaska and a British natural gas pipeline. BP expects growth this year of 4.5 percent to 5 percent, less than the 5.5 percent previously forecast, the company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. BP's shares fell 3.5 percent, wiping more than 3 billion ($4.7 billion) off the company's value. Five weeks ago the chief executive, Lord Browne, assured investors that full-year targets would be reached. BP cited setbacks in August associated with an oil field in Britain, a natural gas pipeline from Britain to Continental Europe, and at the Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska.

title: The Temples Of Commerce As Fun Houses
description: Rem Koolhaas, with his ''Harvard Design School Guide to Shopping,'' says shopping is the essential experience of our time. A stroll through the biennale reveals that it also must be fun for architects to design a store. The exhibition is rich in examples of distinguished architects giving vent to consumer fantasies, including the London-based Future Systems' new Birmingham branch of the venerable Selfridges department store (above). It is an organic, high-energy, highly textured space awaiting its moment in the next Austin Powers movie. In the same spirit, Coop Himmelblau of Vienna presents a BMW showroom that doubles as an entertainment space; it is decked out in lozenge-shaped turntables floating in a spaceship-shaped pod building.

title: TV's Tight Grip On Campaigns Is Weakening
description: The once-overwhelming influence of television advertising on political campaigns is declining, Democratic and Republican leaders say, leading them to embrace aggressively old-fashioned campaign tools like telephone calls and door-knocking in this year's Congressional elections.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Nazi Guard Accusation
description: The federal government accused an 80-year-old New Jersey man yesterday of serving as an armed guard at three Nazi slave-labor camps and asked for a court order to revoke his American citizenship and deport him. A civil complaint filed in United States District Court said the man, Andrew Kuras, of Mays Landing, lied about his wartime activities in a 1951 interview with Army investigators in Europe and later on a visa application. A young man who identified himself as Mr. Kuras's grandson said he would not discuss the case. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Article 2002090590507814510 -- No Title
A Private Commune Near the Biggest Gate
description: It would be a mistake to look only to Rotterdam, London and Los Angeles as design centers. A surprising scene- stealer at the biennale is the huge model of the Great Wall Commune. This is a three-square-mile private residential development in the countryside within the undulating shadow of the Great Wall. It consists of about a dozen houses, some already built, all luxurious by local standards, all intended for the emerging Chinese upper-middle class and all by Asian architects. For a small guesthouse (left), Kengo Kuma, a Japanese architect, rendered the rectilinearity of modernism in stylized layers of traditional bamboo in order to make a meditative house.

title: President to Seek Congresss Assent Over Iraq Action
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  President Bush said today that he would seek approval from Congress before taking action against Iraq, as the White House opened a campaign to persuade lawmakers, reluctant allies and the public that Saddam Hussein poses a grave danger to the United States and the world.

title: Honoring Loss With The Power Of Green
description: THE first memorials were spontaneous outpourings: photographs, flowers, flags, candles, poems, teddy bears, old work boots inscribed with names. They covered the fence around St. Paul's Chapel, where a grove of sycamores protected the church from the impact and flying debris when the World Trade Center towers collapsed on Sept. 11. Memorials were also taped to the stone wall at Eagle Rock Reservation, a promontory overlooking the Hudson River in West Orange, N.J., where people rushed to watch, helpless.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Amtrak To Lease Station
description: Amtrak signed a 50-year lease yesterday on the new Rensselaer rail station. Carm Basile, a spokesman for the Capital District Transportation Authority, which owns the station, said Amtrak had agreed to pay a $50,000 annual occupancy fee and provide most of the security for the 67,000-square-foot building. The station cost $53.1 million to build and will probably open in several weeks, Mr. Basile said. Amtrak's annual operating cost for the station is estimated at $430,000. Its current station serves about 630,000 passengers annually, including many lawmakers traveling to the Capitol. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: MORGAN STANLEY NAMES CO-CHIEF OF BANKING UNIT
description: Morgan Stanley named Richard Kauffman to be a co-chief of its banking unit after the company lost ground to rivals amid a decline in mergers advice and underwriting. Mr. Kauffman, a vice chairman of Morgan Stanley International who previously oversaw stock underwriting worldwide, will join William Lewis, whose background is in mergers. They will manage the division that advises companies on mergers and helps them raise money through stock and bond sales. Mr. Kauffman joined Morgan Stanley in 1994. Mr. Lewis has been sole head of the banking division since February 2001.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial last Saturday about the Independence Party incorrectly named Abe Hirschfeld and Patrick Buchanan as previous nominees of the party. Mr. Hirschfeld lost a primary election to H. Carl McCall for the Independence Party line for comptroller in 1998. And in 2000, the party nominated John Hagelin, an official of the Maharishi University of Management, for president, not Mr. Buchanan.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: INTEL TO SELL MOST OF SOFTWARE UNIT In a move to refocus on its main chip-making operations, the Intel Corporation said yesterday that it would sell most of a division that makes software to manage computer networks. The LANDesk Acquisition Corporation, which was formed by two venture capital firms, San Francisco-based Vector Capital and vSpring Capital of Salt Lake City will buy most of the division for an undisclosed amount.Intel will keep an undislosed minority stake. Intel, the world's biggest maker of semiconductors, has been hurt by the slowdown in personal computer sales that began in late 2000. Shares in Intel rose 25 cents, to $16.11.

title: Stocks Fall Amid Concerns About Consumer Spending
description: Stock prices fell for the sixth session out of the last seven today on concerns that consumer spending, the linchpin of the economy, may be weakening.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Sees Drug Disaster
description: President Vladimir V. Putin declared drug addiction the equivalent of a natural disaster, citing new figures showing Russia has 500,000 registered drug users, three-quarters of them under 30. Experts say the true figure may be four or five times as great. While there has been a relative decline in drug use among the young, ''we cannot afford to sit idly by,'' Mr. Putin said. Drug use has grown since the Soviet collapse in 1991, largely because Russia's southern borders have been porous routes for smugglers of opium and heroin. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Signs Faulted
description: A survey by the New York City Transit Riders Council, an advocacy group whose members spent several months at 106 randomly chosen subway stations, found the state of subway signs continues to decline. Its members found that more than half the station entrances had at least one sign problem. More than three-quarters of the stations' platforms had some kind of sign problem. Colored globes at many station entrances were also found to be inaccurate. Subway officials said yesterday that they had not yet had a chance to read the survey and were not able to comment on it. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Cablevision Drops Sponsorship
description: Cablevision has told the PGA Tour that it will no longer sponsor the Lightpath Long Island Classic, a Senior Tour event it has backed since 1999, a golf industry executive said yesterday. Lightpath is Cablevision's business telephone service.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Anthrax Scare
description: An unidentified white powder was mailed to 11 police departments north of Boston, but preliminary tests showed that the substance was not anthrax, officials said. Nine of the 11 envelopes, all of which were addressed to police chiefs and contained a note with the words ''Black September,'' were tested. The unknown substance does not appear to be dangerous. Black September is the Palestinian group that killed 11 Israeli athletes and coaches at the 1972 Munich Olympics. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Nazi Collaborator Seeks Freedom
description: A prosecutor asked an appeals court not to free an aged Nazi collaborator, Maurice Papon, on medical grounds, saying his release would ''incite disturbances to public order.'' Lawyers for Mr. Papon, 92, who is serving a 10-year sentence, cited a serious heart condition. He was convicted in April 1998 for having signed orders for the deportation of 1,690 Jews between 1942 and 1944 while he was chief of police in Bordeaux. A ruling is due Sept. 18. The European Court of Human Rights ruled in July that Mr. Papon was denied a fair trial when France refused to allow him to appeal the 1998 conviction. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Lawmakers Stalled On Budget Measures
description: Less than a month from an Oct. 1 deadline, Congress has passed not one of the 13 spending bills required for the federal government. The Senate, for the first time in years, has not even adopted a budget. Lawmakers blame each other and the White House, while the White House holds Congress accountable.

title: As Schools Open in New York, Mayor Sits Front and Center
description: More than a million New York City students will return today to a school system now in the hands of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and a chancellor who serves at his pleasure, with new and potentially powerful tools to bring about change.

title: WYETH PUTS HEALTH WARNING ON HORMONE REPLACEMENT
description: Wyeth changed the labels on its hormone-replacement products to advise doctors of studies that linked some of the treatments to health risks. The drug maker, which is based in Madison, N.J., changed the product information for Prempro, Premarin and Premphase, a company spokesman, Doug Petkus, said. The medicines, intended to help prevent symptoms of menopause, are Wyeth's biggest group of treatments, with sales of $2.07 billion last year. Government researchers in July reported finding that the drugs raised the risk of cancer and heart disease.

title: Study Finds Mothers Unaware Of Children's Sexual Activity
description: Half of all mothers of sexually active teenagers mistakenly believe that their children are still virgins, according to a report released here today by a team of researchers at the University of Minnesota Adolescent Health Center.

title: Informer Says Drug Cartel Is Killing Off His Relatives in Colombia
description: A jailed informer who says his relatives in Colombia are being killed off because his testimony helped American prosecutors win convictions in a murder case pleaded tearfully yesterday for his family to be moved to the United States.

title: Golden but Not an Oldie, A Salsa Band Turns 40
description: Puerto Rico's best-known salsa orchestra, El Gran Combo de Puerto Rico, once decided to try something totally new. The group's members were seeking a crossover sound as they prepared for a European tour, so they combined traditional Puerto Rican beats with interlopers like calypso and called their album ''Latin Up.''

Nearly 80 people died after a Su-27 fighter jet crashed into spectators at a military airfield near Lviv. Unplanned maneuvers by the pilots, who survived the crash, and organizational mistakes by authorities have been blamed. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that their investigation of accounting practices at WorldCom might result in new charges and indictments against executives involved in the company's effort to hide billions of dollars of expenses.

Private interment at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY, Friday, September 6 at 1 PM.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: RESIGNATIONS AT MITSUI Japan's second- largest trading company, Mitsui & Company , appointed a new president and chairman after their predecessors resigned amid allegations that employees bribed Mongolian government officials to win overseas aid contracts. Public prosecutors in Tokyo are reportedly investigating whether Mitsui broke any laws in the case. Mitsui's senior managing director, Shouei Utsuda, 59, will replace Shinjiro Shimizu, 64, above, as president. Nobuo Ohashi, a vice president, will become chairman. The change will become effective at the end of this month. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Bid to Justify a First Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  President Bush's declaration today that he would seek the approval of Congress to oust Saddam Hussein amounted to an acknowledgment that he cannot proceed alone and that he needs to move quickly to try to resolve a rift within his administration, with many of his father's cautious advisers, and with his reluctant allies.

title: For the Obsolete-TV Owner, A Smart PC Screen May Serve
description: Most home electronic devices that generate moving images -- DVD players, game consoles, digital camcorders, computers -- produce them digitally. And apart from the computer, most connect to a television set to display the images. The hitch is that many television sets still use an older technology called composite video whose image clarity is inferior to both S-video and high-definition television. One solution is to add a television card to your computer. But some manufacturers are taking the opposite tack, adding television capabilities to their monitors.

title: Vancouver Journal; Fashion Born of New Blood and the Old World
description: When Yumi Eto, one of Canada's hottest young fashion designers, looks for inspiration in her studio, she glances at the bulletin board above her desktop computer. There are pinup pictures of Chinese dolls, Indian totem poles, Peruvian women in Quechua dress guarding their llamas, and a Japanese geisha catching a subway.

title: A Relentless Vine
description: QI have had a garden for 20 years, and every year after tilling I get a vining weed that shoots up everywhere, with growth accelerating until October. The leaves are arrow-shaped, one to two inches in length, and they grow on very skinny stems. I pull the vines continually, but as the garden peaks it is harder and harder to keep up with them. How do I get rid of this pesky plant?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit Falls For Oil Concern
description: Squeezed by lower crude oil prices and a flagging market for oil products, the European oil giant TotalFinaElf of France said net profit in the first half-year excluding nonrecurring charges, dropped 30 percent, to 3.05 billion euros, or $3.04 billion, against 4.3 billion euros last year, on a 10 percent decline in revenue, to 50.2 billion euros. Total said it had performed well, given the downturn in the oil market environment. Total's share price closed in European trading up 1.6 percent, at 134.20 euros. Hardest hit was Total's chemical division, which reported an operating loss in the period. But operating margins in the refinery sector were also squeezed, to $3.60 a ton from $16.90 a ton in the period last year. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Staking Out Space in a Hand-Held for Higher-Fidelity Sound
description: WHILE hand-held electronic gadgets are ever shrinking, their ambitions are ever growing. That is particularly true when it comes to sound. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Posts Net Income

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Elects President
description: The union representing 7,000 New York City sanitation workers yesterday elected a new president, Harry Nespoli, who ran unopposed. Public prosecutors in Tokyo are reportedly investigating whether Mitsui broke any laws in the case. Mitsui's senior managing director, Shouei Utsuda, 59, will replace Shinjiro Shimizu, 64, above, as president. Nobuo Ohashi, a vice president, will become chairman. The change will become effective at the end of this month. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mystery Boat Pursued
description: The military said it had sent a destroyer and 15 patrol boats to investigate an unidentified vessel near Japanese waters. Early today, the vessel sailed away toward North Korea, the Kyodo News Service reported. In December, a suspected North Korean spy ship was spotted in Japanese waters, leading to a chase of several hours by coast guard vessels and an exchange of gunfire. The ship sank in Chinese waters and is being salvaged by Japan. The new report comes two weeks before Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi is to visit North Korea. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Ending Legal Secrecy
description: One of the most troubling, and least scrutinized, aspects of the child sexual abuse scandal now roiling the Roman Catholic Church is the enabling role played by the court system. In case after case, judges have signed off on secret settlements of child-molestation suits, freeing the offending priests to molest again. In one Boston case, brought on behalf of a boy who was raped by a priest, the judge sealed all the records and the priest moved to New Hampshire, where he later pleaded guilty to abusing two more children.

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES WILL LAY OFF 1,000 EMPLOYEES
description: Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it was cutting 1,000 jobs this fall as a result of a seasonal decrease in capacity. Of those workers, 670 had already been cut after the Sept. 11 attacks, but were recalled for a three-month summer contract that expired last Saturday, Mary Beth Schubert, an airline spokeswoman, said. Northwest's capacity in November will be 13 percent less than what it was in July. It is unclear how much of that capacity cut is a result of the usual slowdown in the fall and how much is a result of the economic downturn and the aftermath of the terrorist attacks. description: STRATEGY, the champ was explaining, is all-important. In Scrabble, which is what we are talking about here, the very word ''strategy'' is a winner. Hooked on, as they say, to an ''S'' or ''Y'' already on the board, strategy has a face value of 12. title: A World of Experimentation Heralding a New Era
description: Is there another Bilbao on the horizon, with a building that, like the Guggenheim Museum, sets the course of world architecture? If so, it will probably be at the Eighth International Architecture Exhibition at the Biennale in Venice, which opens to the public on Sunday. Deyan Sudjic, the editor of Domus, the Italian design magazine, is the curator of the exhibition, titled ''Next.'' Last week, surveying the bounty being uncrated, he said, ''It reminds me of the last scene in 'Raiders of the Lost Ark' -- or of Christmas morning.'' Mr. Sudjic has culled notable architectural projects from around the world to be built in the next decade and put them in the Arsenale, a 14th-century factory where the Venetian fleet was built. There are more than 90 architects and 140 projects represented with models, drawings, videos and actual chunks of building. The show has been organized into 10 themes, including housing, museums, towers and shopping. One residential work is a high-concept palace in Qatar: every room has been assigned to a famous architect. One, Ron Arad of London (inset), has devised a grid of steel plates for a living-room floor that rearrange themselves into a conversation pit with edges (above and right).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, KATHARINE A.
description: WELLS-Katharine A. Teacher, historian; Dr. Wells was born in Pittsburgh, PA, July 16, 1905, the daughter of John Allen and Caroline Brentnall Powell, and died in Southbury, CT, where she lived in Heritage Village, on September 3, 2002. She was a graduate of Goucher College in Baltimore, MD, traveled to England where she studied at Oxford University, and completed a Ph.D. in history in 1932 at Clark University. She married Henry Willis Wells in 1932, a Professor of English Literature and Curator of the Branden Matthews Dramatic Museum at Columbia University, who predeceased her in 1977. She taught history at the Fieldston School in Riverdale from 1941-1945 and was a member of the academic faculty at the Juilliard School of Music from 1954-1964. An avid reader with wide-ranging tastes and a voracious appetite for historical information and knowledge, she maintained a lively correspondence with her many friends, including former students, until recently. For 65 years, she enjoyed her summer home on the Harpswell Peninsula in Maine. Survivors include her nephew, J. Brentnall Powell and her niece, Carolyn Powell Lalley. Cremation private. Those wishing to remember Dr. Wells, donations made be made in her memory to Goucher College.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: PUTIN SEES DRUG DISASTER President Vladimir V. Putin declared drug addiction the equivalent of a natural disaster, citing new figures showing Russia has 500,000 registered drug users, three-quarters of them under 30. Experts say the true figure may be four or five times as great. While there has been a relative decline in drug use among the young, "we cannot afford to sit idly by," Mr. Putin said. Drug use has grown since the Soviet collapse in 1991, largely because Russia's southern borders have been porous routes for smugglers of opium and heroin.    Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intel To Sell Most Of Software Unit
description: In a move to refocus on its chip-making operations, Intel said that it would sell most of a division that makes software to manage computer networks. The LANDesk Acquisition Corporation, which was formed by two venture capital firms, the San Francisco-based Vector Capital and vSpring Capital of Salt Lake City, will buy most of the division for an undisclosed amount. Intel will keep a minority stake. Intel, the world's biggest maker of semiconductors, has been hurt by the slowdown in personal computer sales that began in late 2000. Also yesterday, Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse First Boston reduced their financial targets for Intel. Tim Mahon, an analyst at First Boston, cited weak personal computer demand for the severity of Intel's price cutting. Lehman Brothers also lowered its sales forecasts on Tuesday. Shares of Intel rose 25 cents, to $16.11.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, ALBERT J.
description: COSTELLO-Albert J. Retired Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of W.R. Grace & Co. and American Cyanamid Company, 66, Died Tuesday, September 3, 2002. Mr. Costello was appointed to the position of Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of W.R. Grace & Co., now headquartered in Columbia, Maryland, in May 1995 and retired at year-end 1998. Previously, he had served as the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of American Cyanamid Company from April 1993 through December 1994, when it was acquired by American Home Products. Mr. Costello joined American Cyanamid as a chemist in 1957. During his career, he held a number of marketing and management posts, including various international assignments. He was named Executive Vice President of Cyanamid in 1983, President in 1991 and Chairman and CEO in 1993. He served on the board of directors of FMC Corp. and Becton, Dickinson and Co., and on the board of trustees for St. Joseph's Children's Hospital in Paterson, New Jersey. He was also involved in several charitable organizations including Eva's Kitchen in Paterson, NJ and Eastern Christian Children's Retreat in Wyckoff, NJ. Born in New York City on September 4, 1935, Mr. Costello received a B.S. degree in chemistry from Fordham University and a Master's Degree in chemistry from New York University. Surviving is his wife Barbara (nee Antolotti), his three sons, Dr. Gregory A. Costello, of Franklin Lakes, Peter M. Costello of London, England and Albert J. Costello Jr. of Wyckoff. Also surviving are five adoring grandchildren, Alessandra, Kathryn, Amanda, Ryan, and Olivia, his mother Lena Costello, and his brothers Ronald and John Costello. Funeral Mass will be held Saturday, 10AM, September 7, 2002 at Most Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church, 787 Franklin Lakes Road Franklin Lakes, NJ. Interment will follow in the Christ the King Cemetery in Franklin Lakes. Visiting is on Friday 2-4 and 79 PM at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, N.J.

title: Financing Ends Some Doubts About Qwest
description: Clearing away concerns that it could be forced into bankruptcy before the end of the year, Qwest Communications International announced arrangements yesterday with bankers to borrow $750 million and extend by two years a $3.39 billion credit line that was scheduled to expire next May.

title: Albany Names 487 Failing Schools Under New Law
description: State officials today identified 487 failing schools across the state where, under a new federal law, parents can ask to have their children tutored free or transferred to a better school.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Issues Injunction Against Madster
description: A federal judge yesterday issued a preliminary injunction against Madster, a service formerly known as Aimster that lets people swap music and other media files online. The injunction, issued by Marvin E. Aspen of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, requires Madster to prevent users from exchanging music files whose copyrights are owned by the major record companies. The record companies scored a similar victory in 2001 in their lawsuit against Napster, which they also sued for reportedly abetting copyright infringement on a wholesale basis. Yesterday, a trustee for Napster filed to convert its bankruptcy to Chapter 7 from Chapter 11; a company liquidates its assets under Chapter 7, while Chapter 11 allows a company to reorganize. The company's demise, meanwhile, appeared to be complete: the Web site of Napster, once the Internet's fastest-growing service, read only ''Napster was here.''

description: Hitler in Chicago

title: Dow and S.&P. Post First Advances in Six Trading Days
description: Stocks rose yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index higher for the first trading day in six, led by Microsoft, Pfizer and Citigroup.

title: A War Room To Die For, At Any Age
description: THE action is furious. Damien Scobie turns a corner, fires his machine gun into a group of terrorists and makes a discovery on the ground. ''I got a vest! I got a vest! I got a vest!'' he screams excitedly to his fellow soldiers. His joy is short-lived. A moment later, he is blown to bits by a foe wielding a submachine gun.

title: Funeral Services for Lionel Hampton
description: The funeral of the jazz vibraphone pioneer and bandleader Lionel Hampton, who died on Aug. 31, will take place on Saturday at 9 a.m. at Riverside Church in Manhattan, Riverside Drive at 122th Street, Morningside Heights.

title: Clinton Pretty Much Dismisses Idea of a TV Talk Show
description: Former President Bill Clinton, speaking on ''Larry King Live'' on CNN Tuesday night, said definitively that he would not become a talk show host. Well, maybe not definitively, but he all but ruled it out, at least for the short term. Unless something else interesting came up.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DANAHER CORP., Washington, the maker of Craftsman tools and devices for measuring voltage and fuel tank leaks, said it would buy Thomson Industries Inc., Port Washington, N.Y., a maker of bearings, shafts and gearboxes for $165 million. Danaher could pay more if Thomson reaches certain performance goals.

title: Miss the Sound of Vinyl? Try Super Audio CD's
description: Q. I am starting to see compact discs in music stores labeled ''Super Audio CD,'' and was wondering what this means. I assume the sound quality is better, but can these discs be played on a regular CD player?

title: A Site to Pour Out Emotions, and Just About Anything Else
description: ONLINE journals have a bad reputation: emotional train wrecks and narcissistic ramblings plastered on the Web for all to see. But the extraordinary growth of a site called LiveJournal suggests that the genre might be gaining ground in the mainstream. For many young people, keeping a Web journal is less about soul-searching than about keeping in touch with a circle of friends and perhaps expanding it.

title: A Streak of Glamour But a Lack of Lifeblood
description: OVERWHELMING evidence doesn't convince everyone. Even as Richard M. Nixon resigned, there were those who did not believe he was part of a cover-up. There were those who continued to watch ''Roseanne'' every week of its final horrible season, unable to accept that it was no longer funny. Yet there comes a time when the true believer's faith is cast into doubt, a moment of clarity when one says, ''Maybe he is guilty,'' ''Maybe this show really is bad.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Ban On Rebels Ends
description: The government ended the four-year ban on the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. The move was a condition for peace talks with the rebels, who have been fighting for a homeland for the minority 3.2 million Tamils since 1983. Talks are to begin Sept. 16 in Thailand. Both President Chandrika Kumaratunga and the powerful Buddhist clergy have expressed opposition to lifting the ban, saying the Tigers had not renounced separatism. The ban was imposed after the Tigers attacked the country's most sacred Buddhist shrine. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Waikiki Discount
description: Through this month, the 1,310-room Waikiki Beach Marriott Resort, newly renovated, has rooms for $139 a night (regular rates start at $300). They are subject to availability, and restrictions apply. The resort, across the street from Waikiki Beach, has two pools; (800) 249-4998.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''For 11 long years, Saddam Hussein has sidestepped, crawfished, wheedled out of any agreement he had made not to harbor, not to develop weapons of mass destruction, agreements he's made to treat the people within his country with respect. And so I'm going to call upon the world to recognize that he is stiffing the world.''

title: Joel Klein's First Day of School
description: New York City's new schools chancellor, Joel Klein, is best known as the lawyer who took on Microsoft for the Justice Department. If Mr. Klein needed any reminder that improving New York City's schools will be an even bigger challenge, he got it yesterday when the State Education Department released a list of schools that are in need of improvement as defined by the federal No Child Left Behind Act. This law, passed earlier this year, requires states to close the achievement gap between rich and poor children over the next 12 years and to better direct federal Title I funds to those who are furthest from meeting performance standards.

title: Political Bravery's Price in Mexico
description: Imagine a rural area where there is no electricity, no running water and no real schools for the children. Where local strongmen and a corrupt government plunder natural resources and conspire to keep the peasantry suppressed. That's not a description of some faraway continent. It's how certain parts of Mexico are portrayed in ''Cause for Murder,'' a compelling documentary to be broadcast tonight as the latest program in the PBS series ''Wide Angle.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bill On Nontaxable Goods
description: Eric Gioia, chairman of the City Council's Investigations Committee, will introduce legislation this month requiring retailers selling tax-exempt items to post a list of nontaxable merchandise near their cash registers, he said yesterday. The move, promised but not completed last year by Peter F. Vallone, then the speaker, comes after a fourth Council investigation found that a third of the 50 stores surveyed were improperly charging tax on items costing less than $110. The improper taxes cost New Yorkers hundreds of dollars each a year, said Mr. Gioia, above. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

description: The Mets had finally won Tuesday night in the second game of a doubleheader, halting their losing streak at Shea Stadium at 15 games, a National League record for consecutive defeats at home. So what was left to capture the imagination?

description: BACK in e-mail's early days, the McAllister family of Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., shared one computer, with an America Online account and a slow dial-up modem. Checking e-mail was a Sisyphean chore.

description: A bioweapons scientist whose apartment has been searched twice in the F.B.I.'s anthrax inquiry was fired from his job at a Louisiana State University biomedical laboratory after the Justice Department warned the school that it could not use him on grants financed by the department, law enforcement officials said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Schick Bidder Eliminated
description: Socit Bic, the world's largest manufacturer of disposable pens and lighters, said that Pfizer Inc. decided not to sell its Schick razor unit to Bic because the transaction would take too long to win clearance from antitrust authorities. The French company said that it was disappointed with the decision made by Pfizer, the world's biggest drug maker, and that it would concentrate on developing products like its razor with three blades.

title: Treating Rigid Solids As If They Were Liquid
description: One message of the biennale theme ''Next'' must surely be the seductive power of solid materials treated as if they were as pliant as silk. Overlapping glass louvers suggest the luminosity of fish scales in a tower by Jean Nouvel. Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron put up a life-size facade for a Barcelona exhibition hall, creased it as if it were rice paper and painted it digital blue. But none top Peter Zumthor of Switzerland, who brought a family of stoneworkers to make elongated bricks for a perforated screen wall (below) that is a key feature of his addition and renovation of the Diocesan Museum in Cologne.

title: Protesters Interrupt Powell Speech as U.N. Talks End
description: Demonstrators jeered Secretary of State Colin L. Powell today to protest the administration's environmental and foreign aid policies as the World Summit on Sustainable Development drew to a close.

Billings were estimated at $30 million. Universal McCann is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. description: A state arbitration panel has awarded the city's 24,000 police officers raises totaling 11.75 percent for the last two years, ending a bitter and protracted contract dispute between a dispirited force that felt it deserved more for its sacrifices and a city that said it could afford no large increases.

title: Op-Art
Here Glass, There Glass, Hanging Over a Harbor
description: Yesterday, the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston unveiled its design for its $37 million museum building by the New York architects Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio. The design goes on display this weekend in Venice. The 62,000-square-foot gallery, theater and exhibition space has the technological derring-do associated with the firm's most experimental work, the water-spraying Blur building in Yverdon-les-Bains, Switzerland. The new museum also has a restrained elegance befitting its Boston location: the waterfront. After completion of the Big Dig, a huge highway-construction project, the museum site, on Fan Pier, will be more closely integrated with the city. Ms. Diller described the four-story glass-on-glass box as ''built from the sky down,'' with its largest sections cantilevered over Boston Harbor (above). Completion is expected by 2006.

title: U.S. Team Is Big On Hype, Not Results
description: Down by 20 points before halftime, dumbfounded by a former Temple University point guard in need of work, 12 N.B.A. players and their tortured coach were shockingly outplayed by a team from another continent tonight.

title: Judge Denies Venue Change In 4th Trial Of Ex-Officer
description: A Brooklyn federal judge denied a defense motion yesterday for a change of venue in the coming trial of Charles Schwarz, a former police officer charged with taking part in the torture of Abner Louima five years ago.

title: Bid to Justify A First Strike
description: President Bush's declaration today that he would seek the approval of Congress to oust Saddam Hussein amounted to an acknowledgment that he cannot proceed alone and that he needs to move quickly to try to resolve a rift within his administration, with many of his father's cautious advisers, and with his reluctant allies.

title: In a City of Foreshadowing
description: ''HE who is last had best laugh,'' wrote Gore Vidal of Romulus Augustus, the last ruler of imperial Rome. In the 18th century, as the sun set on yet another Italian empire, the Venetians lived by this comic-apocalyptic code.

title: The Strut Is Carved In Stones
description: After youth, after sex appeal, after shock, after spectacle, after arrogance and long after guaranteed Top 10 hits, what is left for the Rolling Stones is a simple thing: music. The music of a classic rock backbeat, of two guitars tangling like strands of barbed wire, of a singer whose voice is a leathery bray and whose body twitches in syncopation from head to toe.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TOBACCO CONCERN POSTS GAIN Gal- laher, an acquisitive British tobacco company whose brands include Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut cigarettes, said its underlying profit rose 23 percent in the first half to 223 million ($349 million). It also announced a deal to distribute its cigarettes in China, the world's biggest cigarette market. In recent years, Gallaher has bought Tabak of Austria and Ligett-Ducat of Russia. Gallaher's shares rose as much as 5.5 percent, to 670 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, L. GARRISON JR.
description: MILLER-L. Garrison Jr., 44 of Darien, CT., died Saturday, August 31, 2002 of melanoma. He was the son of Patricia Cromwell Miller and the late Lindley G. Miller of Upper Brookville, NY. Mr. Miller was a sales executive with Command Financial Press Corporation, NY, and active with various civic and charitable organizations, including the Board of the Boys Club of New York. He was a member of the Piping Rock Club and the Racquet and Tennis Club. Mr. Miller was a graduate of the Salisbury School and Denison University. In addition to his mother, he is survived by his wife, Carrie Barr Miller, and a son, Charles David, both of Darien; four sisters, Barbara C. Miller, Alexandra M. Cooper, Patricia R. Miller and Carley M. Sullivan; a nephew, Grant Cooper, and three nieces, Kimberly Spallone and Courtney and Pepperrell Sullivan. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at ll:30 AM on Saturday, September 7, at St. Thomas R.C. Church in Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, Mr. Miller requested contributions to Camp Cromwell, C/O The Boys Club of New York, 287 E. 10th St., New York, New York 10009.

description: This is a transcript of an interview with Tom Ridge, the homeland security adviser to President Bush, as recorded by The New York Times. Mr. Ridge's spokeswoman, Susan Neely, was also present and occasionally commented.

description: The Goldman Sachs Group and Credit Suisse First Boston are being investigated by the House Financial Services Committee, which is widening its inquiry into conflicts of interest in allocations of initial share offerings at securities firms.

description: From the very beginning, the Winter Garden was a grand illusion. And yesterday, close on a year after it was severely damaged when the World Trade Center collapsed, the illusion was restored.

description: Gerhard Schrder, the German chancellor, believes that the Bush administration is making a terrible mistake in planning a war against Iraq, and he is not afraid to say so.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 - Congressional leaders said today that they would undertake weeks of hearings and debate on whether to support military action against Iraq, a move that could delay a final vote until after the November elections.

description: A decade ago, Jennifer Capriati was the beloved wonder teen, billed as the wholesome tour sweetheart, projected as the next Chris Evert, expected to be adorable from every camera angle.

title: 9/11 HOW IT CHANGED LIVES : For Sept. 11, a world chorus of remembrance
description: FRANKFURT:  If any single commemorative event outside the United States reflects the global urge to observe the anniversary of Sept. 11, it is the dramatic plan for a many-nation performance of Mozart's Requiem. At least 170 choirs from 24 countries and 21 time zones have signed up to perform the impassioned choral Mass. Starting in each time zone at 8:46 a.m., to mark the moment of the first attack on the World Trade Center, performances will begin in Wellington and Auckland, near the international date line, and then roll from one time zone to the next in a 24-hour remembrance of the victims.

title: From Directors, A Word, or Two
description: As the DVD audience broadens, so does appreciation of the disc's extra features. Consumer studies by the DVD Entertainment Group, a trade association, rank improved picture and sound as DVD's most valued attributes. Extra scenes, outtakes and especially bloopers (always a favorite with fans) and behind-the-scenes looks at movies being made also score highly.

title: Corrections

The picture showed the dead woman, not her parents placing flowers at her grave; it was from her family's collection, not by Luis J. Jimenez.

title: Special Teams Report: Not Bad
description: The Giants had so many problems with their special team last season that they dropped Fred von Appen, who coached those units, and hired Bruce Read, who specializes in special teams.

title: The Perils of High School Infatuation
description: Three years ago the movie ''Cruel Intentions'' brought us ''Dangerous Liaisons'' for teenagers. Now comes ''Swimfan,'' a high school ''Fatal Attraction,'' which is just as slavishly imitative of its source. ''Swimfan,'' like ''Fatal Attraction,'' eventually goes overboard with a loony melodramatic denouement in which a high school swimming pool substitutes for a bathtub.

description: BUNDESMAN - Bernhard Borden Sr. Mr. Bernhard Borden Bundesman Sr., 87, died Saturday, August 24, 2002 at his home in Vero Beach, FL. Bernhard B. Bundesman Sr., retired as President and C.E.O. of deHavilland Aircraft of Canada. Mr. Bundesman is survived by his wife of 68 years, Leocadia; daughter, Geraldine Cisarik and husband, Tom, of Darien, Illinois; son, Bernhard B. Bundesman Jr., and wife, Anna, of Charlotte, NC; nine grandchildren, Ashley, Doug, Alex, Alisha, Lauren, Caroline, Kendall, Lindsey and Courtney; and five great-grandchilden, Logan, Landon, Caitlyn, Hailey and Jimmy. Mr. Bundesman was preceded in death by his grandson, Jimmy. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Charlotte North Carolina Salvation Army.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 24 about John Willett, the English author, translator, cultural historian and authority on Bertolt Brecht, misstated the place of his death. It was Le Thil, in Normandy, not London.

title: On the Mean Boardwalks of Long Beach
description: The title ''City by the Sea'' refers to Long Beach, a town on Long Island that, in its brief glory (evoked in a blurry Technicolor clip during the opening credits) was a paradise of boardwalk and beach, with a grand casino and handsome waterfront hotels. In the space of a generation, it seems, Long Beach has fallen into a state of desolation: ''It looks like the Serbian army just came through here,'' one character remarks.

title: McCall Says He'd Provide More Money For Education
description: H. Carl McCall, the presumptive Democratic nominee for governor, pledged yesterday that if elected he will shrink class sizes for young students to no more than 18 children and spend $8 billion more on education by the end of his first term.

title: Woodward Doesn't Draw Top Contenders Anymore
description: There was a time when the Woodward was a championship event, as important as any race on the fall calendar, and it was won by horses like Sword Dancer, Kelso, Buckpasser and Forego. That changed with the advent of the Breeders' Cup, but the Woodward's new role was still an important one. It became a key prep for the rich Breeders' Cup Classic; it was a race that signaled who had a chance on racing's new championship day and who did not.

title: In Second Move, Germ Attack Training Center Fires Director
description: The director of one of the nation's top programs for training civilian authorities in handling germ attacks was fired on Wednesday, a day after the dismissal of the scientist named by the F.B.I. as a ''person of interest'' in its anthrax investigation.

title: Hawaii's Little Chunk of Open Road
description: YOU can drive up 13,796 feet in a morning -- probably the fastest climb by road anywhere -- on the island of Hawaii. That afternoon, you can be back at sea level, watching liquid-hot magma spilling into the Pacific. And if you choose to keep moving, by nightfall you can be cruising past the orchards, ranches and plantations that are still an economic mainstay of the Big Island, as it is known.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Tellabs Plans To Cut 800 Jobs
description: Tellabs, a maker of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that it expected to report a third-quarter loss and would cut 800 jobs, or 14.5 percent of its work force. The company, which is based in Naperville, Ill., said third-quarter sales would be down about 15 to 25 percent, compared with its second-quarter sales of $345 million. Tellabs will also close its manufacturing plant in Shannon, Ireland. The factory once employed nearly 800 people and was considered one of the most successful high-technology enterprises in Ireland. ''This is a sad day for our employees,'' said Pat Shanahan, a senior vice president, ''but it is something we can't avoid because our customers continue to spend less.'' Shares in Tellabs fell 20 cents, to $5.24. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Cameras Were Rolling The Day Time Stopped
description: In a recent essay in The New Republic, Leon Wieseltier, the magazine's literary editor, drew a distinction between Sept. 11, the actual day with its unassimilable horrors, and ''Sept. 11,'' the ever-accumulating attempts to assimilate the horror into more normal modes of experience, to make it an occasion for commemoration, reflection and healing. With the anniversary fast approaching, we are very much in the midst of ''Sept. 11,'' and the proliferating representations of that awful day have the paradoxical effect of pushing it away even as they try to recall us to it. The iconography that has been so vital in the effort to preserve what was widely and intensely felt in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks -- the American flag, the image of the martyred towers of the World Trade Center, the FDNY logo -- has also, by misappropriation and sheer repetition, become a way of pushing those emotions away. One result, perhaps equally inevitable, is confusion: What should we be feeling a year later? What is the proper pitch of grief, of anger, of political debate?

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Tries To Stem Unlicensed Use Of TurboTax
description: Intuit, the largest maker of software for preparing income tax returns, has created an activation process for most new versions of TurboTax in an effort to crack down on unauthorized use. The process will be much like the one required before new credit cards can be used. Buyers of TurboTax for Windows will have to activate the program by contacting Intuit over the Internet or by telephone, the company said. A numerical code will be used to ensure that returns prepared using TurboTax are printed out or filed electronically from only one computer. Intuit estimates that about 14 million Americans -- three times the number of copies sold -- used TurboTax to prepare their 2001 taxes this year, said Scott Gulbransen, a spokesman for Intuit, based in Mountain View, Calif. The new procedure will not prevent more than one person from using the program on an authorized computer.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Ordered To Pay $11 Million
description: Computer Associates International must pay $11 million for violating United States takeover rules when it bought On-Line Software International in 1991, an appeals court ruled yesterday. A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Brooklyn, upheld a jury's verdict that Computer Associates paid more to On-Line's founder, Jack Berdy, for his shares than it had paid other shareholders. Computer Associates, a business software maker under federal investigation for its accounting, bought On-Line Software for $15.75 a share, or almost $120 million. Jurors decided in 2000 that part of a $5 million payment by Computer Associates to Mr. Berdy amounted to extra compensation for his 25 percent stake in On-Line. Computer Associates said the payment instead covered a noncompetition agreement. The Securities and Exchange Commission's ''best price'' rule requires that all shareholders in a tender offer must get the best price offered. Jurors ordered Computer Associates to pay an award of $5.6 million to a class of 1,500 On-Line shareholders. The judge added $4.6 million in interest. The total should rise with interest since the verdict, said the plaintiff's lawyer, Roger Kirby.

title: Keeping Earth Fit for Development
description: The 10-day World Summit on Sustainable Development, which concluded on Wednesday in Johannesburg, angered both environmentalists and those who dismiss multilateral accords as so much globaloney. But by any standard -- let alone the often debased one of United Nations-sponsored meetings -- the gathering was honorable and reasonably successful. The agreements that were reached on ways to fight poverty while reducing environmental degradation can make a meaningful difference if the nations of the world work seriously to enforce them.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: PHONE COMPANY LOSS Hong Kong's main phone company, PCCW Ltd., lost $92 million in the first half of this year, somewhat more than expected and a reversal from its profit of $120 million for the period a year earlier. A loss of $232 million on the sale of a cellphone operation more than wiped out the financial benefits from reducing debt and dismissing employees, as well as other cost savings. Sales fell 9.8 percent, to $1.31 billion, as Hong Kong's recession and an eroding share of a deregulated market hurt revenue from fixed-line phone service. PCCW said it would start selling apartments next year that it had built as part of its Cyberport project, and predicted that this would help cash flow. The company said it also might be able to start paying dividends within the next two years.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Cuts Jobs
description: Zurich Financial Services, Switzerland's biggest insurer, plans to cut 4,500 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, and raise as much as $2.5 billion by selling new shares after posting its biggest loss ever. The $2.03 billion loss for the first half was in contrast to a profit of $861 million for the period a year earlier. The company, which is based in Zurich, expects to complete its share sale by the end of October. By cutting jobs and selling shares, the company will ''strengthen the balance sheet and improve the group's capital base,'' the insurer's chief executive, James Schiro, above said in a conference call.

title: Finding Screwball Romance in the Music of the 40's
description: Stacey Kent, a native New Yorker who lives in England, is far from the first contemporary jazz singer to discern in the music of the 1940's a spunky, wised-up optimism and an emotional balance that have all but disappeared from popular culture. As she sings the music of Richard Rodgers, the Gershwins, Cole Porter and others in her wonderful new show at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, through Sept. 28), she projects a double vision that suggests a young, ebullient Billie Holiday with the cheek of a Jean Arthur character. You might call the ethos she evokes in her tangy versions of songs like ''Thou Swell'' and ''Polka Dots and Moonbeams'' screwball romantic.

title: World Briefing: Europe

Dimitris Koufodinas gave himself up two months after a bungled bomb attack led to the arrest of 15 suspected members of the group. The police said Mr. Koufodinas was involved in the assassination of a British military officer two years ago.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Saudis Must Now Get Visas
description: The government has decided to require citizens of Saudi Arabia to obtain visas to visit Canada, a change reflecting Canada's desire to tighten immigration controls and security at its borders. ''The decision to lift the exemption was made because the Saudi passport is vulnerable to abuse,'' the Immigration Ministry said. Saudis had been able to enter on a visa waiver program. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Worker Hurt In Fall
description: A member of a construction crew working on an iron girder fell yesterday from the 22nd floor to the 20th floor of an office tower where two men died in an elevator fall last month, the police said. The injured man, Joseph Gaffney, 37, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center in critical condition after falling about 2 p.m., according to the police. A hospital spokesman said that his injuries were not life-threatening. On Aug. 23, George Scarpati, 34, of Howell, N.J., and James Benton, 38, of Dingman Township, Pa., were killed when a construction elevator they had been working on fell 19 stories. The 1.2 million square foot, 35-story building, at Madison Avenue and East 42nd Street, is being developed by Brookfield Properties and is to be the new headquarters of CIBC World Markets, an investment bank. title: Questioning Life and Its Meaning, In One-Acts
description: As a title, ''heard [but not scene]'' has a little too much wordplay in it to be meaningful, but evidently it has to do with the spoken word, rather than stage action, as the playwright's focus. The show, at the Red Room in the East Village, consists of two one-acts by Marc Chun, a young writer with an eagerness to experiment and a facility with the language and events of American middle-class life. It doesn't all hang together, but with a committed cast of five 20-something actors and unobtrusive but tight direction by Steven Gridley, the show has a precocious spirit that deserves encouragement.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: PALM OFFERS REFUNDS TO SOME CUSTOMERS Palm Inc. is offering a full refund to customers who purchased its new m130 hand-held digital assistant because the company has acknowledged that the model has about 6,000 fewer color combinations for its screen display than previously advertised. Palm sent e-mail messages to registered m130 users late Wednesday offering a full refund. Those who choose to keep their m130 hand-helds  each sells for $249  can download free the Palm version of SimCity, a video game valued at $29.95. The company apologized to customers recently and acknowledged that the m130 could handle about 58,621 color combinations  not the "more than 65,000 colors" the company had advertised since the product came out in March. Palm was sued on Aug. 22 by two men who accused the company of "unfair competition and fraudulent, unfair, deceptive and false advertising" because of the misleading information on the color combinations. "This is certainly a positive development for Palm consumers that Palm has decided to make refunds," said Jonathan Shub, the lawyer who filed the suit on behalf of the men. "However, the suit proceeds while we evaluate the process by which Palm is making these refunds available and the notification process that they are implementing." There was no mention of the refund on Palm's Web site yesterday, and Mr. Shub suggested that such a refund offer should have been made earlier and should have been more widely publicized by Palm. (AP)

title: On This Old Turf, A Treasured Past Is Still a Presence
description: Between the Great Depression and World War II about 600,000 Jews lived in the Bronx. My birth in the mid-30's added one more, to the Ignacz Schwartzes, a small immigrant family.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: From Soccer To A Bigger Game
description: Chung Mong Joon, the telegenic multimillionaire who helped bring the World Cup soccer tournament to South Korea, signaled his candidacy for president of the country as he met coaches and members of a North Korean team in a match seen as a major step toward inter-Korean reconciliation. Mr. Chung, 50, the American-educated son of Chung Ju Yung, founder of the Hyundai business empire, issued a statement saying that he would announce on Sept. 17 that he would join the race to succeed President Kim Dae Jung in the election on Dec. 19. He is president of the Korea Football Association and the leading stockholder in Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest shipbuilder. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Hotel Union Reaches Accord
description: The union representing 7,300 hotel workers in Chicago reached a tentative agreement with 27 hotels. Under the agreement, the workers who earn $8.83 an hour, will receive a raise of $3.37 an hour over four years and their contributions for family health coverage will drop to $30 a month from $85. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

description: The Rookie

title: No Message, No Story: The Color's About Color
description: Color is everything in Kenneth Noland's work, color that stands for nothing but itself and its ability to reverberate in the viewer's eye. With its placement in chevrons, circles, stripes and shaped canvas motifs that Mr. Noland favors, it has no truck with symbolism or storytelling, and certainly not with a message of any kind.

description: Bronx Museum of the Arts

title: Weekender | Bennington, Vt.
description: BENNINGTON is one of those places where people brag that everything is close. In 45 minutes, said T. J. Carmody, the cheerful proprietor of Carmody's Tavern, an Irish-style pub on Main Street, ''I can be in Williamstown for the theater festival'' or ''up in the mountains skiing.'' Brenda Jones, the owner of Brenda Jones Realty, said one big advantage is that an international airport is only 40 miles away, in Albany. Even the Chamber of Commerce is quick to point out what's elsewhere, within 50 or 60 miles: 12 ski areas; outlet stores in Manchester, Vt.; and concerts at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in New York and Tanglewood in the Berkshires.

description: ABRAHAM - Martha (nee Fleischmann). Born February 4, 1910, Ebelsbach, Germany, died September 4, 2002, NYC. Martha will be mourned by her husband, Gerard, and her family and friends. Graveside service today at 11 AM, Cedar Park, Paramus NJ

title: Flag-Bearer Of Fine Silver
description: Michael James was 18 when he bought his first piece of antique Georg Jensen silver. ''I had never heard of Georg Jensen when I bought the four-piece 'Blossom' tea set,'' said Mr. James, an Englishman who began selling antique silver as a teenager. ''I'd never seen anything that amazing and different in my life. Everything else looked rehashed.''

title: 36 Hours | Rochester, N.Y.
description: THOUGH in New York State, Rochester is geographically and temperamentally closer to Cleveland than it is to Manhattan, with a decidedly Midwestern character. (In 1993, a survey by California State University at Fresno declared Rochester residents to be the ''most helpful'' among those in the 36 United States cities studied.) The local cuisine revolves around deep frying, charbroiling, hot dogs (called simply ''hots'') and hot sauces; the accent is flat and nasal. Culturally, the biggest force is not a place, but a man, George Eastman, responsible for the town's cinematic and photographic history and for endowing, among other institutions, local universities and the acclaimed Eastman School of Music. Add to the mix a striking natural environment -- the Erie Canal, the north-flowing Genesee River, Lake Ontario and farmland just minutes outside of town -- and the result is a pleasant blend of big city, small town and countryside. J. R. ROMANKO

title: Venus Williams Advances to Finals
description: Every time Max Mirnyi stepped up to serve in the men's doubles final at the United States Open this afternoon, cheers for him rang out from every corner of Arthur Ashe Stadium, many of them in a decidedly Brooklyn accent.

description: KRISEL-Stuart. Beloved son of the late Doris and Jacob Krisel, and brother of Lola Finkelstein, at his home in Woodstock, NY.

title: Shipping News: Boat Gear For Foul and Fair Weather
description: BETWEEN reality and fantasy, boat people can manage to spend most of the year on the water. Even with just about a month of recreational boating left in the Northeast, frostbite fisherman, sailors in warmer climates and determinedly intrepid mariners manage to hang in there and out there a good part of the year. Those who do put their boats to bed for the winter manage to stay afloat just by dreaming on.

title: Congress Returns to New York
description: In 1790, the last time Congress met in Lower Manhattan, most lawmakers viewed New York City as a place of iniquity and a certain snootiness. Some things never change. But today, when Congress convenes at Federal Hall on Wall Street, its motive for returning to the city that served as the nation's first capital is to demonstrate solemn empathy over the events of last Sept. 11. Whatever prejudices some members of Congress may still have about New York, they have kept faith with President Bush's early pledge to help in this year of trial. The one-hour joint session this morning will be a reminder of how much the city has to be grateful for, and how much remains to be done.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Bank Merger
description: Banco Santander Central Hispano of Spain is merging its two Mexican subsidiaries in an effort to cut costs. Banca Serfin and Banco Santander Mexicano will be merged by the end of the year and will operate under the name Santander Serfin. The move will strengthen Banca Serfin, Mexico's third-largest bank, against BBVA Bancomer and Banamex, a unit of Citigroup. The combined bank will have $25 billion in assets, the company said. Santander, Spain's largest bank, has been hurt by the troubles in Argentina and Brazil.

description: LONDON, Sept. 6  Prime Minister Tony Blair is taking on his favored role of bridge builder between Europe and the United States as he arrives in Washington on Saturday. But alarm in Britain over American war talk and growing distrust on the Continent of his closeness to President Bush are making the task a tougher one than before.

title: Coca Spraying Poses No Risk To Colombians, U.S. Declares
description: The American-financed aerial destruction of coca crops in Colombia meets United States regulatory standards and does not endanger people or the environment, the State Department said today in a report to Congress.

title: Colombian Military Reports 100 Rebels Killed in Offensive
description: Dozens of rebels have been killed in the past month in clashes with Colombia's armed forces in a southern province where the guerrillas' presence has long been strong, military officials said today.

description: War is peace. Freedom is slavery. Ignorance is strength. Colin Powell and Dick Cheney are in perfect agreement. And the Bush administration won't privatize Social Security.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AOL To Use Covad High-Speed Network
description: Covad Communications said yesterday that AOL Time Warner would use Covad's network to provide high-speed Web connections to America Online customers. The five-year agreement gives AOL Time Warner, based in New York, access to a network covering 40 million homes and businesses in the United States, Covad said in a statement. Shares of Covad, which emerged from bankruptcy in December, rose as much as 29 percent, before ending the day at $1.32, up 18 cents, or 15.8 percent. As the number of new consumers using dial-up Internet access slows, AOL Time Warner is trying to add customers through agreements with companies like Verizon Communications and SBC Communications, which have regional high-speed networks. Covad sells high-speed links to the Internet through digital subscriber lines. AOL Time Warner will pay Covad an undisclosed amount a month for each subscriber. A Covad spokeswoman, Martha Sessums, declined to give the amount. An AOL Time Warner spokesman, Ed Adler, did not return phone calls seeking comment.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bond Issue Planned
description: South Korea said it would sell as much as 13 trillion won ($10.9 billion) of government bonds next year to repay debt owed by two state agencies used to bail out the finance industry since 1997. The government bonds will be exchanged for 9.7 trillion won of Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation debt and as much as 3.3 trillion won of Korea Asset Management Corporation bonds maturing next year, the Finance and Economy Ministry said. The swap is needed because of an estimated gap of 69 trillion won between the amount Korea spent bailing out financial companies and what it can recover from asset sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAHOTAN, ROBERT
description: LaHOTAN-Robert. A painter known for landscapes and still lifes of lyrical color and subtle force, died on August 30, 2002. Whether he was painting the Maine forest at dusk or a bouquet of wild flowers in morning light, LaHotan brought to his work an abiding sense of mystery, a personal way of distilling a poetic moment from the canvases' ethereal depths. LaHotan is represented by the Kraushaar Galleries in New York; his paintings are in private and public collections across the United States. He was a member of the National Academy of Art, and a recipient of a Fulbright Grant in 1951. LaHotan lived in New York City and Cranberry Island, Maine, with his lifelong companion, the painter John Heliker, who died in 2000. Their home on Cranberry Island will become the center for the Heliker-LaHotan Foundation. Memorial celebrations are being planned in New York City and on Cranberry Island. Donations can be made to: The Heliker-LaHotan Foundation, Inc, PO Box 82, Great Cranberry Island, Maine 04625.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Stake Sold
description: Lehman Brothers has concluded a $1 billion deal to invest in Woori Finance Holdings, the government-owned entity that includes Woori Bank, Korea's second-largest bank. The deal provides for Lehman to buy $250 million in bonds that may be converted into stock in Woori and to spend a minimum of $750 million in forming a joint venture with Woori to buy and dispose of Woori's bad loans. The loans have a face value of more than $13 billion. Woori Finance said the partnership would enable Woori to ''clean up its bad assets and strengthen transparency'' in hopes of making the firm more attractive to foreign investors when it was listed on a foreign stock exchange. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: New Study on Antiterror Spending Is Fodder for Rival Camps

description: The emotions will flood linebacker Sam Cowart on Sunday, but not until later, he says. There will be the obligatory handshakes with former teammates, although not many of them are still with the Buffalo Bills. And he will greet the coaches and executives who released him because they were not sure he would recover from a torn Achilles' tendon, only to call and wish him good luck as soon as he signed with the Jets a few days later.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: No. 1 Terror Suspect Surrenders
description: The country's most wanted terror suspect, accused of belonging to the November 17 urban guerrilla group, surrendered to the police. Dimitris Koufodinas gave himself up two months after a bungled bomb attack led to the arrest of 15 suspected members of the group. The police said Mr. Koufodinas was involved in the assassination of a British military officer two years ago. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: West Nile Virus and the Blood Supply
description: The possibility that the West Nile virus might be spread through blood transfusions is disquieting given the lack of a rapid, reliable test to screen it out of the blood supply. But the risk, if it exists, is apt to be slight and is surely no reason to forgo receiving a lifesaving blood transfusion.

title: Still Around, and Still Exploring Monk's Music
description: The initial lifespan of Sphere, a band that was convened to play the music of Thelonious Monk, established it as a model group in mainstream jazz. Here was firm, durable material married to soulful, playful performance. From 1979 to 1988, when the band's saxophonist, Charlie Rouse, died, it stood apart both from downtown jazz and from the young, polished structuralism of the Marsalis brothers, Terence Blanchard and Donald Harrison. Sphere's music was modern enough, it was elegant and it was mature, without the bullishness of the younger players; the pianist Kenny Barron ensured the music's quick wit and flexibility, while the blues shone through.
