title: Congress Convenes in New York to Commemorate Sept. 11
description: Congress came back to its roots in Lower Manhattan today, to commemorate the victims of the World Trade Center terror attacks and to pay tribute to the bravery of those who worked around the clock in rescue and recovery efforts.

title: Canadian Union Picks G.M. for First Talks
description: The union representing 46,000 Canadian auto workers today chose General Motors as its target -- the company that it will negotiate a new labor contract with first, to set a pattern for contracts with the others. But the union indicated that its most serious issues were with Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler, not G.M.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The Asian touches that are so gloriously in evidence at AZ, Patricia Yeo's first restaurant, are nowhere to be found in the food at Pazo, her second, which opened a month ago on East 57th Street in the space that was formerly Sono. Instead, Ms. Yeo has turned her eye for exceptional ingredients and unconventional pairings to the Mediterranean, a field that you would think had been plowed in every conceivable way over the last decade or so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLOSKEY, ELIZABETH M.
description: McCLOSKEY-Elizabeth M. Of Point Lookout, LI. On September 4, 2002. Born May 8, 1912, to John F. McCloskey and Elizabeth R. Mulhern. Ms. McCloskey was a graduate of Mount St. Vincent in Riverdale, NY, and took her law degree at St. John's University in Queens. She was President and owner of Seal Lock Burial Vault, Inc. in Forest Hills, NY. Long and charitable friend and fund raiser for the Sisters of St. Joseph Convent in Brentwood, LI, member of American Association University Women, Officer of Point Lookout Civic Association, Point Lookout Over 50 Club and many other professional organizations. She will be missed by many loving cousins and friends. Reposing after 2 PM, today, Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Avenue (Exit 28N SS Parkway), Wantagh. Funeral Mass Saturday, 8:30 AM, at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal R.C. Church, Point Lookout, NY. Interment St. Jonh's Cemetery, Middle Village, New York. Family will receive friends Friday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 PM.

title: All-Williams Final in U.S. Open
description: Near the end of a match full of bizarre ups and downs, Venus Williams stood on her service line with one last quandary to overcome in the semifinals of the United States Open today. Serving for the match in the third set, Williams had dug herself a 0-40 score against Amelie Mauresmo.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: SAUDIS MUST NOW GET VISAS The government has decided to require citizens of Saudi Arabia to obtain visas to visit Canada, a change reflecting Canada's desire to tighten immigration controls and security at its borders. "The decision to lift the exemption was made because the Saudi passport is vulnerable to abuse," the Immigration Ministry said. Saudis had been able to enter on a visa waiver program. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Yale Unions Approve Strike
description: Union workers at Yale University and Yale-New Haven Hospital have voted overwhelmingly to authorize strikes at both institutions, though contract negotiations over raises and other issues are continuing. The votes came from members of three unions: Locals 34 and 35 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, which represents clerical, technical and maintenance workers at the university, and District 1199, the New England Health Care Employees Union, which represents hospital food service workers and is affiliated with S.E.I.U. The three unions, which are part of the unions' coalition, the Federation of Hospital and University Employees, voted independently of one another. Deborah Chernoff, a spokeswoman for the federation, said the university workers voted after eight months of bargaining and after an independent labor consultant hired by the university stopped attending the sessions. She said there were no immediate plans to stage a walkout. Yale officials did not return a telephone call requesting comment. Ms. Chernoff said the hospital workers have been working without a contract for two years. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: PLUMTREE SOFTWARE REJECTS SUTTER BUYOUT OFFER
description: Plumtree Software Inc., a maker of business software for Web sites, said it rejected an unsolicited $147 million buyout offer from Sutter Opportunity Fund 2 because it would not be beneficial to shareholders. Plumtree, which is based in San Francisco, said it decided not to pursue discussions with the Sutter Capital Management unit. The $5-a-share offer was 49 percent more than Plumtree's closing price yesterday of $3.35. Plumtree shares fell 44 cents, or 13 percent, to $2.91 a share. Sutter is also based in San Francisco.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Mafia Case
description: Joseph DeFede, the reputed former acting boss of the Luchese organized crime family, has pleaded guilty to federal racketeering charges as part of a cooperation agreement with the government and will testify in prosecutions, according to the office of James B. Comey, above left, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Prosecutors also said that 19 people, including 8 described as members of the Luchese and Genovese crime families, had been indicted on loansharking, narcotics trafficking and other charges. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: International Court Questioned
description: The government has reservations about the treaty creating the International Criminal Court because ''it would hamper'' domestic law enforcement efforts, a presidential spokesman said. In a meeting, not one of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's cabinet members endorsed the treaty, the spokesman, Ignacio Bunye, said. The United States, worried that the court could be used to harass Americans involved in peacekeeping missions and military operations, has threatened its allies with aid cuts unless they sign agreements promising not to hand over Americans to the court and the American ambassador to the Phillipines, Francis Ricciardone, said last month that nations have to ''think carefully'' before ratifying the accord. American troops were sent recently to the Philippines, whose armed forces depend on United States aid. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: Accord Ends Teachers' Strike in Princeton
description: Public school teachers and the Board of Education reached tentative agreement on a new four-year contract today, the first day of classes, ending a two-day strike.

title: Panel Near a Decision on Stewart Case
description: A spokesman for the Congressional committee investigating Martha Stewart's sale of ImClone Systems stock said yesterday that the committee was close to concluding its investigation and that it would announce its next move early next week, raising the possibility that Ms. Stewart could be subpoenaed.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: INSURER CUTS JOBS Zurich Finan- cial Services, Switzerland's biggest insurer, plans to cut 4,500 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, and raise as much as $2.5 billion by selling new shares after posting its biggest loss ever. The $2.03 billion loss for the first half was in contrast to a profit of $861 million for the period a year earlier. The company, which is based in Zurich, expects to complete its share sale by the end of October. By cutting jobs and selling shares, the company will "strengthen the balance sheet and improve the group's capital base," the insurer's chief executive, James Schiro, above said in a conference call.

title: Roy Katz, 48, Fire Dept. Official, Is Dead
description: Roy F. Katz, a deputy New York City fire commissioner who managed the Fire Department's construction program for the last six years, died on Wednesday at Cornell Medical Center. He was 48 and lived in Hollis Hills, Queens.

title: Digital Link For Car Talk
description: Techies know about Bluetooth, a digital system that lets electronic devices communicate with each other without a cord running between them (though only over about 30 feet). That's more than enough for the inside of a car, where increasingly there are a lot of devices joining the buzz -- mobile phones, portable hand-held computers, laptops. Someday cellphones may function as modems in cars, bringing in video signals, for example, to be transferred to an onboard player system.

title: Corrections

title: Court Papers Detail Welch's G.E. Perks
description: Papers filed in the divorce of John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric, by his wife contend that G.E. covered enormous living costs for them while he led the company and would continue to do so for him for the rest of his life. The company never disclosed the extent of these benefits.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Medicinal Marijuana Raid
description: Federal agents arrested two prominent advocates of using marijuana for medicinal purposes in an early morning raid at their farm in Davenport, near Santa Cruz. The owners, Michael and Valerie Corral, were arrested on charges of conspiracy and suspicion of intent to distribute marijuana, Richard Meyer, a special agent with the Drug Enforcement Agency in San Francisco, said. Agents seized three rifles, a shotgun and more than 150 marijuana plants. The raid was a surprise to local authorities, who said the Corrals' farm complied with the state's medical marijuana law. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Providence's Mayor Is Sentenced to 5 Years for Corruption

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Take-Two Interactive Posts 3rd-Quarter Profit
description: A game company, TakeTwo Interactive Software, reported a fiscal third-quarter profit yesterday and raised its earnings forecast for the year because of rising sales of its video games, including Grand Theft Auto 3 and PlayStation software. Net income in the quarter ended July 31 was $4.77 million, or 12 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $665,000, or 2 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 51 percent, to $122.5 million from $81.3 million, the company said in a statement. Take-Two expects to earn $1.73 a share in the year ending Oct. 31 on sales of $755 million, helped by sales of its games, which also include Big Bass Fishing. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is $1.69. In June, the company, based in New York, forecast profit of $1.70 a share, excluding gains on Internet investments and costs related to the settlement of a lawsuit. Take-Two shares rose $2.06, or 8.1 percent, to $27.34. They had risen 56 percent this year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Criminal Inquiry Into Copter Crash
description: The chief military prosecutor said he was investigating whether criminal violations of flight rules played a role in the downing of an Mi-26 transport helicopter in Chechnya last month, killing at least 119 people. Prosecutors said they would look into whether senior military officials were negligent by allowing at least 147 people onto the helicopter, which was apparently shot down, even though military rules limited the craft to carrying cargo. title: Television's Special Day of Pain and Comfort
description: IN tribute to the victims of the 9/11 attacks, Blue Man Group has created an eloquent video. The usually explosive performance artists do not appear in it; there are no blue-painted heads in sight. Instead, pieces of white paper drift down in front of a pure black background as percussive music plays. All these papers were found in Brooklyn, where they floated across the river from the World Trade Center, and as they gently tumble from the top to the bottom of the screen some become legible: a sheet with scorched edges, filled with Japanese calligraphy; a letter that begins ''Dear Recruiter,'' a cover sheet that says ''Exhibit 13.''

Loving father of Kerry of Ho-Ho-Kus and Suzanne Morris of Hoquiam, WA; Christopher of Atlanta, GA; Edward III of Worcester, MA;, Kenneth of Atlanta, GA. Adored grandfather of eight. Edward was retired managing partner of Ernst & Young, Newark, NJ. Chairman of the Board of Beacon Trust Company, Chatham, NJ. Executive Vice-President of Balanced Foods, Inc. From 1964-1986 he served as President of the Bergen Chapter and Vice-President of the New Jersey Society of CPAs. He was President of the Brooklyn Chapter of the National Association of Accountants from 1955-1986. A US Navy veteran, he was President of the Essex (NJ) Chapter of the Navy League. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Appliance Trade Case
description: Seven Chinese appliance makers won a 15-year antidumping battle and will be allowed to sell televisions to the European Union's 370 million residents without paying punitive import duties. The seven manufacturers -- including the Konka Group, Sichuan Changhong Electric, Haier Electrical Appliances and TCL King Electrical Appliances -- no longer have to pay a 44.6 percent tariff, according to an Aug. 29 statement from the European Union cited by Konka officials.

title: SONICBLUE LAYS OFF 25 PERCENT OF ITS EMPLOYEES
description: Sonicblue Inc., the money-losing maker of Rio digital audio players, said it was cutting about 25 percent of its staff and consolidating business units to improve its financial performance. Roger Hackett, senior vice president for sales, and Andy Wolfe, the chief technology officer, are among the 100 people who will lose their jobs, the chief financial officer, Marcus Smith, said. Sonicblue, which has posted net losses for nine consecutive quarters, had 350 to 400 employees before the job cuts, Mr. Smith said.

title: We Still Have a Choice on Iraq
description: It may well be that the United States will go to war with Iraq. But if so, it should be because we have to -- not because we want to. For the American people to accept the legitimacy of this conflict and give their consent to it, the Bush administration must first present detailed evidence of the threat of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction and then prove that all other avenues of protecting our nation's security interests have been exhausted. Exhaustion of remedies is critical to winning the consent of a civilized people in the decision to go to war. And consent, as we have learned before, is essential to carrying out the mission. President Bush's overdue statement this week that he would consult Congress is a beginning, but the administration's strategy remains adrift.

His Charter Revision Commission decided on Tuesday night to go against Mr. Bloomberg's wish to have two items on the ballot this year -- one changing the rules on mayoral succession, the other making city elections nonpartisan. title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bin Laden Banned As Namesake
description: Officials denied a resident Turkish couple's request to name their newborn Osama bin Laden. German regulations require that children's names not be offensive -- the name Hitler is banned -- and that the names of foreign families' children be acceptable in their countries of origin. Registration officials in Cologne, where the couple lives, said they had rejected the name because it would not be allowed in Turkey and because of its association with the Sept. 11 attacks. The matter has been sent to a judge, who will have final say.

title: U.N. Spy Photos Show New Building at Iraqi Nuclear Sites
description: A team of weapons inspectors, studying satellite photography, have identified several nuclear-related sites in Iraq where new construction or other unexplained changes have occurred since the last international inspections nearly four years ago, a United Nations official said today.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: INTERNATIONAL COURT QUESTIONED The government has reservations about the treaty creating the International Criminal Court because "it would hamper" domestic law enforcement efforts, a presidential spokesman said. In a meeting, not one of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's cabinet members endorsed the treaty, the spokesman, Ignacio Bunye, said. The United States, worried that the court could be used to harass Americans involved in peacekeeping missions and military operations, has threatened its allies with aid cuts unless they sign agreements promising not to hand over Americans to the court and the American ambassador to the Phillipines, Francis Ricciardone, said last month that nations have to "think carefully" before ratifying the accord. American troops were sent recently to the Philippines, whose armed forces depend on United States aid. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: A Name Withdrawn
description: The German engineering company Siemens has abandoned plans to register the Zyklon trademark for home appliances, because the name was used for a poison gas employed in Nazi-era extermination camps, according to a published report. The report, published by the BBC on its Web site, said Siemens decided to withdraw its trademark application after Jewish groups said the idea was insensitive. Zyklon, the German word for cyclone, is already used on some vacuum cleaners sold in Germany. Zyklon B was the name of a poison that was originally an insecticide and was used in extermination camps.

title: 2 Pilots at La Guardia Removed From Plane for Alcohol Testing
description: A pilot and co-pilot were ordered off their plane at La Guardia Airport last night after alcohol was smelled on their breath, a Port Authority of New York and New Jersey police spokesman said last night. The pilot and co-pilot took Breathalyzer tests at a hospital, and no police action was taken against them, said the spokesman, Sgt. Eugene Leary.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Phone Company Loss
description: Hong Kong's main phone company, PCCW Ltd., lost $92 million in the first half of this year, somewhat more than expected and a reversal from its profit of $120 million for the period a year earlier. A loss of $232 million on the sale of a cellphone operation more than wiped out the financial benefits from reducing debt and dismissing employees, as well as other cost savings. Sales fell 9.8 percent, to $1.31 billion, as Hong Kong's recession and an eroding share of a deregulated market hurt revenue from fixed-line phone service. PCCW said it would start selling apartments next year that it had built as part of its Cyberport project, and predicted that this would help cash flow. The company said it also might be able to start paying dividends within the next two years.

title: Metro Briefing | Region: 2 More West Nile Cases
description: The first confirmed human cases of the West Nile virus in New Jersey and in Westchester County this year were announced yesterday by health officials. In New Jersey, a 77-year-old man from Ewing Township near Trenton was found to have been infected with the virus last month, said the health and senior services commissioner, Dr. Clifton R. Lacy. The man is in serious but stable condition at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital at Hamilton. In Westchester, an 83-year old man from Mamaroneck tested positive for the virus, county health officials said. The man is hospitalized and recovering, they said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Report On Tainted Blood
description: After two years of hearings, a high court investigation into how the government's blood bank infected 260 hemophiliacs with H.I.V. and hepatitis C in the 1980's sharply criticized the bank's safety standards and its failure to inform those it had infected until years later. But the head of the inquiry, Judge Alison Lindsay, declined to send the report to the public prosecutor, effectively ruling out criminal prosecutions or further investigations into the American medical supply companies who provided the contaminated products. Of the 104 people infected with H.I.V. and 217 infected with hepatitis C, 78 have died. Brian Lavery (NYT)

The sculptures were built in Sandy Hook by Stephen Shaheen, who designed them, and two Italian artisans. Mr. Shaheen and his business partner, Evan Urbania, received a permit to build the sculptures in the park, but federal regulations do not allow commemorative artworks in national parks until 25 years after the event they commemorate, unless they are approved by Congress or the National Park Service director.

description: A federal judge in Manhattan has revoked the citizenship of a retired Brooklyn businessman who participated in the Nazi persecution of Jews in World War II, according to an order released yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Will someone please explain to me the logic that says we can trust someone with a Boeing 747 in bad weather, but not with a Glock 9 millimeter?''

title: Disappointed By Raises, Officers Praise Their Union
description: When city police officers faced disappointing contracts in the past, they did not hesitate to blame their union leaders. In interviews this week, after an arbitration panel awarded them 11.75 percent raises -- half what the union had sought -- they were again disheartened. But this time they are not blaming their leaders.

title: Exhibiting Memory
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Alternative Designs for the Original Towers
Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, DOROTHY
description: ROSNER-Dorothy. Beloved wife of Richard, loving mother of Karin, Melanie, and Richard. Dear mother-in-law of Daysi. Reposing at Ruggiero-Farenga Funeral Home, 4346 White Plains Road, Bronx, Sunday 6-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:45 AM at St. Francis of Assisi Church.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BILLIONAIRE TO BUY RETAIL CHAIN Arcadia, a British retailer, said yesterday that its board would recommend that shareholders accept an offer to be acquired by Philip Green, a billionaire Briton, for 772 million ($1.2 billion). Mr. Green, who made his fortune in retailing, raised his offer 12 percent, to 4.08 a share from a previous bid made last month, to win the backing of Arcadia's management. Known for turning around retailers, Mr. Green at one point made an offer for Marks & Spencer when it was experiencing a sharp downturn in business. Mr. Green, who already owns the BHS chain of department stores and Mark One discount retailers, will add Arcadia brands to his holdings, including retailers of trendy clothing like Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Sound Farm Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Waiting To Inhale
description: Officials urged people with respiratory problems to avoid strenuous outdoor activity as the dense smog that has covered the city this week grew even darker, obscuring views of the famous harbor and Peak. While the city has converted many taxis and buses from diesel to alternative fuels, the rapid expansion of lightly regulated factories in Guangdong Province has sent a pall over the region. A recent study by Hong Kong University found that nearly 40 percent of the city's children had respiratory diseases. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: For Civil Court in Brooklyn
description: Of the 18 Civil Court judgeships up for election in New York City this November, only six are being contested in next week's Democratic primary. As a practical matter, that means the remaining dozen seats will be filled by men and women deeply beholden to the party pols who gave them a berth on the Democratic line and a virtually uncontested ride into office. It also means further reinforcement of the cozy courthouse-clubhouse ties that have invited serious abuses in the awarding of lucrative courthouse patronage by State Supreme Court justices, just one level above Civil Court.

title: Folly in the Face of Famine
description: It is tragic that hunger-racked Zambia is rejecting donations of American corn simply because much of it has been genetically modified. Whatever hypothetical risk may exist in genetically modified crops is trivial compared with the very real danger of starvation faced by some 13 million people in six drought-stricken countries of southern Africa, including more than two million in Zambia.

title: Franklyn D. Holzman, 83, Economist Critical of Moscow
description: Franklyn D. Holzman, an economist who uncovered regressive taxation in the Soviet Union and railed against intelligence estimates of Soviet military spending, died on Sunday at the home of his daughter, Miriam Meyer, with whom he lived in Clifton, Va. He was 83.

title: China Now Set To Make Copies Of AIDS Drugs
description: China took significant steps today to face up to its growing H.I.V.-AIDS epidemic, raising its estimate of the number infected to one million and saying it would manufacture a full complement of AIDS drugs if Western patent holders did not lower prices within the next few months.

title: Farewell to Summer and Its Buzzing Creatures
description: It's 6:45 a.m. Sitting in an alcove near the back window, I watch summer packing to leave -- the yard's hummingbirds busily feeding. Any day now they'll migrate to their winter homes. But at the moment, they're gobbling sugar to build the fat reserves they need for long solo flights.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Battered From Above And Below
description: With winds of 90 miles per hour and gusts of up to 112 miles per hour, Typhoon Sinlaku began to pound northeastern Taiwan. Heavy rain prompted fears of flooding, and two people were reported missing. At the same time, an earthquake with a magnitude of 5.5 shook the sparsely populated mountains of central Taiwan, prompting fears that the shaking could cause landslides of sodden earth, but there were no immediate reports of casualties. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: In City, Ceremonies, Candle Lightings and Concerts
description: New York City's morning ceremony at ground zero and the evening ceremony at Battery Park on Wednesday, Sept. 11, are closed to the public, but they will be broadcast live on television and radio.

title: Congress, Back in Its First City, Honors Resilience of So Many
description: In a day resonant with emotion and history, Congress convened a special meeting in New York yesterday to pay tribute to the victims and the heroes of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and, in the words of the speakers, to show the world that America had been made stronger by the assaults on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Lehigh Running Back Lacks Height, but Not Much of Anything Else
description: Jermaine Pugh was remembering how he dreamed of playing football for Notre Dame when he was 5 years old. As he recalled the details, he put out his hand and said he had wanted to play for the Irish since he was ''this high.''

title: Andrew Forge, 78, Painter And a Former Dean at Yale
description: Andrew Forge, a painter, critic, teacher and former dean of painting at the Yale School of Art, died on Wednesday in New Milford, Conn. He was 78 and lived in Washington Depot, Conn.

title: Packing Heat on the Flight Deck
description: Washington has done a startling and politically gutless turnabout on guns in the cockpit. Only last spring nearly everyone involved in regulating airline safety thought the idea of giving guns to pilots was a desperate, potentially calamitous way to prevent hijackings. Now many of the same people are stampeding in the opposite direction, spurred on by the National Rifle Association. On Thursday the Senate was swept along by the tide, voting 87 to 6 to arm pilots in a trial program. The House passed a similar measure in July.

title: Tigers Go Down Quietly as Wells Goes Distance
description: By the time the Yankees reach the postseason, their biggest challenge may be remembering how it feels to play a competitive game. They say all the right things about respecting every opponent, and Manager Joe Torre reminded them this week to keep grinding, to take every game seriously.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDINO, WILLIAM
description: LONDINO-William. On September 5th, 2002. Beloved husband of Maggie. Devoted nephew of Arnold, Christine, Rose and Rita. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, September 10th, 10 AM, St. Thomas More Church, East 89th Street, NYC.

title: Mother's Sentence Unsettles a Nigerian Village
description: At the entrance to this village, where life is lived out in mud-thatch compounds and mosques in a rhythm that long predates colonialism or Nigeria's independence, bus drivers pay a 20-naira tax, or 15 cents, next to the Texaco station.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, MAXWELL M.
description: POWELL-Maxwell M. Your strength and spirit stay alive. Missing you now, as always. Susa

title: Chic Bar, Yes, But Babies Clearly Make This Party
description: At the bar at Cipriani yesterday, it was babies and not Bellinis. The lounge of the fashionable Midtown restaurant was transformed into a nursery to accommodate the widows who gave birth after Sept. 11, who gathered yesterday in preparation for the first anniversary of the attacks.

title: Article 2002090790134980548 -- No Title
Article 2002090791894670536 -- No Title
World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Stock Sale Is Oversubscribed
description: Ericsson, the world's biggest maker of wireless networks, said that shareholders sought more shares than were available in its $3.2 billion stock sale at 1992 prices. Sweden's biggest-ever secondary offering attracted buyers even after Ericsson shares slumped 84 percent this year, shaving 364 billion kronor ($39 billion) off market value. The company needs the money to weather the phone industry's worst slowdown. The company, founded in 1876 and based in Stockholm, is heading for a second consecutive annual loss as it expects industry sales of cellular networks to decline more than 15 percent this year. Ericsson may be forced to seek new financing as early as next year as losses mount and bank payments loom, some investors have said. ''We haven't seen any signs of a rebound yet,'' said Ericsson's chairman, Michael Treschow, at a Stockholm press meeting. Still, he reiterated that the company will not need more financing.

title: Shares Rally but Not Enough to Turn the Week Positive
description: Stocks rallied yesterday after the government reported that the labor market improved last month.

title: Citigroup Near F.T.C. Accord on Unit's Loan Practices
description: Citigroup and the Federal Trade Commission confirmed yesterday that they were close to an agreement to settle accusations that a consumer lending business acquired by the company two years ago engaged in aggressive and misleading lending practices.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Aug. 29 about the development of a new digital audio format called DataPlay, and a timeline chart of audio innovations, misspelled the given name of a physicist credited with having conceived the compact disc in 1969. He is Klaas Compaan, not Klass.

title: France May Oust Chief of Phone Giant
description: Struggling to get France Tlcom back on firm financial ground, the French government appeared tonight to be ready to remove Michel Bon, the chief executive.

title: Watching Movies With Senator Kerry
description: A couple of columns ago, while plowing through a crowd of Democrats who want to be president, I threw an elbow at Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts. I suggested that his claim to be a global thinker leaned rather excessively on his 30-year-old heroism in Vietnam. And, relying on a report in the usually dependable Boston Globe, I mocked him for pulling out a movie camera after a shootout in the Mekong Delta and re-enacting the exploit, as if preening for campaign commercials to come.

title: TELIGENT SAYS IT IS READY TO EMERGE FROM CHAPTER 11
description: Teligent, a telephone services company, said yesterday that a bankruptcy judge in New York had approved its reorganization plan, clearing the way for it to emerge from Chapter 11 protection by Sept. 16. Teligent's senior secured lenders, headed by J. P. Morgan Chase, Bank of America and Toronto-Dominion Bank, will own all of the shares of the revamped company, the company said. The company, based in Herndon, Va., filed for bankruptcy on May 21, 2001.

title: 2 in Germany Accused of Plotting Anniversary Attack on U.S. Base
description: A Turkish man and his American fiance were arrested Thursday night with explosive chemicals and five pipe bombs in their apartment, and they were held on charges of planning a terrorist attack on a major American military base in Heidelberg on or near Sept. 11, German authorities announced tonight.

title: 2 Cases of Malaria Are Acquired in U.S., a Rarity
description: Two residents of Loudoun County, Va., have contracted malaria, a rare occurrence among Americans who have not traveled abroad, health officials say.

title: Florida Boys Convicted in Father's Death; Family Friend Is Acquitted in Separate Trial
description: After two trials in which the prosecution presented different accounts of the same killing, a jury today convicted 13-year-old Alex King and 14-year-old Derek King of murdering their sleeping father in November and setting their house on fire to cover up their actions.

title: Fears of a Chill on Britain's Home Front
description: The joke used to be that if two Englishmen were sent to the moon, they would promptly form a gentleman's club. These days, two Britons of either sex would probably talk -- smugly or wistfully -- about house prices.

title: SHARES OF CIRCUIT CITY INCREASE ON SALES ESTIMATE
description: Shares of the Circuit City Group, an electronics retailer, rose 10 percent yesterday after it said sales at stores open more than a year had risen more than analysts expected in the latest quarter. Shares of the company, based in Richmond, Va., rose $1.44, to $15.69. Sales at Circuit City stores open at least a year rose 10 percent in the second quarter, ended last Saturday, the company said. Circuit City said that excluding remodeling and relocation costs, it expected to break even or have a slight profit when it reports second-quarter results on Sept. 18. It was expected to break even.

title: A's Run Out of Rallies as Streak Ends at 20
description: Twenty-four days after they began creeping toward baseball immortality -- when last-swing home runs became the norm amid a slew of bedazzling ninth-inning finishes -- the Oakland A's finally went down tonight, stopping at an American League-record 20 consecutive victories.

title: Afghan Leader Vows Attacks Will Not Halt Government
description: With President Hamid Karzai safely back in the Afghan capital and making light of the attempt on his life, government officials said today that preliminary investigations showed that the failed assassination attempt in Kandahar and the car bombing in Kabul on Thursday appeared to have been the work of the Taliban, Al Qaeda or associated groups.

title: Learning in Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Pressure On United Way
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley, the ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, asked the Office of Personnel Management, the agency that handles human resources for the federal government, to reconsider its relationship with the United Way of the National Capital Area. The Combined Federal Campaign, the workplace fund-raising campaign for federal employees, accounts for more than half of the money raised by the Washington-area United Way, which has come under federal investigation over accusations of financial mismanagement. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: R.J. REYNOLDS REDUCES PROFIT FORECASTS
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings, the second-largest United States cigarette maker, cut its second-half profit forecasts yesterday as it aims to raise promotional spending and take on its larger rival, the Philip Morris Companies. Third-quarter profit will be $130 million to $155 million, or $1.45 to $1.75 a share, Reynolds said. Full-year earnings will be $620 million or $660 million, or $6.85 to $7.30 a share. Analysts had expected Reynolds, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., to earn $2.19 a share in the third quarter and $8.02 in the year.

title: Roy F. Katz, 48, Fire Dept. Official
description: Roy F. Katz, a deputy New York City fire commissioner who managed the Fire Department's construction program for the last six years, died on Wednesday at Cornell Medical Center. He was 48 and lived in Hollis Hills, Queens.

title: INSIDE
description: Data Show Weak Economy

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about exhibitions commemorating Sept. 11 misstated the opening date for ''The Day Our World Changed: Children's Art of 9/11,'' at the Museum of the City New York. As the adjoining list noted, the show opens on Wednesday; it did not open yesterday.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: OHIO: REQUEST FOR INQUIRY

title: Ignorance of Abuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Accused of Hitting Handcuffed Man
description: A Brooklyn police officer was arrested yesterday and charged with felony assault, accused of hitting a handcuffed man in the mouth with a police radio, the authorities said.

title: Unemployment Fell in August, But Drop Is Called Insignificant
description: The labor market improved slightly last month but offered little hope that the economy would soon emerge from its prolonged weakness.

title: Insurers Scale Back Corporate Liability Policies
description: Shellshocked by corporate scandals and fearful of the hefty payments they will have to make to settle shareholder lawsuits, the big commercial insurance companies are cutting back sharply on liability coverage for American corporations, their directors and senior executives.

title: PPL PLANS TO BUY REST OF BRITISH ELECTRICITY VENTURE
description: The PPL Corporation, a power supplier, agreed to pay $235 million to buy the Mirant Corporation's share of their British electricity venture. PPL, based in Allentown, Pa., plans to sell more stock to help finance it. The purchase will add $3.6 billion in assets and $2.1 billion in debt to PPL's balance sheet, the company said yesterday. It will also increase 2003 earnings about 9 percent, to $3.60 to $3.80 a share, including about 15 cents from the transaction, the company said. Mirant is based in Atlanta.

title: Article 2002090790775928047 -- No Title
Florida-Miami Is Back, And Stakes Are High
description: Two years ago, Ron Zook picked up his daughter Jacquelyn at a suburban Kansas City high school with what he thought was terrific news. His friend and mentor, Jim Haslett, had just accepted the head coaching job for the New Orleans Saints. He asked Zook, then an assistant with the Kansas City Chiefs, to become his defensive coordinator.

title: A Businessman's 'Hamlet,' Now Onstage
description: As the audience entered the theater, the old King Hamlet and Ophelia were onstage, playing a duet of Renaissance music, he on the viola da gamba, she on the cello. Then young Hamlet appeared and sat by Ophelia's side. He was followed by Gertrude.

title: Article 2002090791517160575 -- No Title
Article 2002090793506413837 -- No Title
David Bierk, 58, Canadian Artist Who Reinterpreted Masterworks
description: David Bierk, a Canadian painter, died on Aug. 28 in Peterborough, Ontario. He was 58.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGER, GLORIA
description: YOUNGER-Gloria, 79. Of Rye, NY on September 5, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Paul Younger of 55 years, loving mother of Marc and his wife Helen, Edward, Robert and his wife Robin, adoring grandmother of David, Ellis, Meg, Rebecca and Abigail, and devoted sister to Helen, Isabelle and brotherin-law Arnold. Services will be Monday 10 A.M. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York 10605.

title: Torricelli-Forrester Fight Grows Fiercer by the Day
description: The day after the first debate in New Jersey's United States Senate race, the campaigns of Senator Robert G. Torricelli and his Republican opponent, Douglas R. Forrester, were acting as if the heated encounter had never ended.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about unexplained changes at nuclear-related sites in Iraq visible in satellite photographs misstated the source of the photographs. As the article said, they were commercial, not from the United Nations.

title: BUSH ASKS LEADERS IN 3 KEY NATIONS FOR IRAQ SUPPORT
description: President Bush called the leaders of Russia, China and France today to seek their support as he tried to build an international coalition against Saddam Hussein, but he appeared, in his initial approaches, to have made little headway in convincing them that the need for action was urgent.

title: JOHANNESBURG SUMMIT : Big agenda, little action on world's problems
description: JOHANNESBURG:  In the end, the UN World Summit on Sustainable Development was just too complex. The ambitious project to increase development today and rescue the destitute from their plight without further damaging the Earth's environment for future generations ended with a sprawling document that had something for everyone but few specific promises. Many of those who invested so much in the conference  like President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa or Kofi Annan, the secretary-general of the United Nations  hope that Johannesburg will be a wake-up call, a turning point for a world in crisis.

title: 9/11 Law Means More Snooping? Or Maybe Less?
description: When Congress passed the USA Patriot Act in those first panicky weeks after 9/11, giving law enforcement more power to track down terrorists, much of the response was either bewilderment or alarm. Many lawmakers who voted for it admitted that they hadn't even had a chance to read the bill. Civil libertarians, newspaper editorial boards and others warned that the new legislation gave government worrisome new powers to pry into peoples' private lives.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: VW Names Financial Officer
description: Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker, named Hans Dieter Ptsch as chief financial officer to replace Bruno Adelt, whose contract expires at the end of next year. Mr. Ptsch, 51, has been chief executive of Duerr A.G., the largest maker of equipment for painting cars, since 1995. He will become a management board member of Volkswagen on Jan. 1 and take over Mr. Adelt's responsibilities as finance chief at the end of 2003, the company said. Volkswagen's chief executive, Bernd Pischetsrieder, is putting in place his own group of managers to help him run the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEGENNARO, MARY T.
description: DeGENNARO-Mary T. On September 5, 2002 of Peconic (formerly Ozone Park). Beloved wife of the late Salvatore. Devoted mother of Michael and John. For information regarding memorial service, contact William F. Coster Funeral Home, Cutchogue, NY at 631-734-7720.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALLECK, LEONARD C.
description: SHALLECK-Leonard C. On September 5, 2002. Beloved husband of Kalia. Loving father of Jimmy and Sheila. Dear brother of Alan, Lynn and Charles Shalleck. Adoring grandfather of Jason and Lauren. Respected matrimonial attorney. Member of the Friars Club. Board Member of the Sutton Place Synagogue. Service Monday 12 noon at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, New York City.

title: AstraZeneca Drug Granted Broader Use
description: AstraZeneca said today that it had won approval in the United States to promote its Arimidex breast cancer drug for a new use, treating early stages of the disease in postmenopausal women.

title: 2 Indian Elections Bring Vote Panel's Chief to Fore
description: By year's end, India will undergo two state elections that could determine both its next prime minister and whether it can ease tensions with its longtime rival, Pakistan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a ballot initiative in Miami-Dade County, Fla., that would repeal an ordinance banning discrimination against gays misstated the involvement of Anita Bryant with the Miss America pageant. Ms. Bryant, who led a successful effort to repeal a similar ordinance in Florida 25 years ago, was a former contestant but not a former Miss America.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Cooperation, Of Sorts, From Georgia
description: Interior Minister Boris Gryzlov said Georgia had agreed to a joint search operation to find Chechen rebels hiding in the Pankisi Gorge, but officials in Tbilisi, the Georgian capital, quickly denied a deal had been made. ''We may take one or two people from the Russian Interior Ministry, but there can be no talk of joint search operations,'' a Georgian spokesman told Reuters. A joint operation would be a sharp shift for Georgia, which has opposed Russian action on its territory. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Report Sees Gloomy Side to the Boom in Car Sales
description: A new report by Goldman Sachs is sharply pessimistic about the robustness of auto sales and the underlying health of the Big Three.

title: Once Hopeful Family Gathers in Sorrow for Son Who Died in the Andes
description: Court Demas sent his last e-mail message to his mother from Peru on July 13, giving her all the details of his coming two-week trek through the high Andes with his Peruvian girlfriend.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Strong Job Growth In August
description: More jobs were created in Canada in the first eight months of this year than in any corresponding period since 1994, Statistics Canada said in a report. The unemployment rate dipped to 7.5 percent in August from 7.6 percent in July. About 59,000 new jobs were created in August, mainly in manufacturing and construction, bringing the total so far this year to 386,000. This year's summer job market for students was the best in a decade, Statistics Canada said. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Vlado Perlemuter, French Classical Pianist, Dies at 98
description: Vlado Perlemuter, the revered French pianist who studied with Ravel and Faur and was an acclaimed interpreter of their works, died on Wednesday at the American Hospital in Paris. He was 98.

title: Article 2002090794073690697 -- No Title
Terror Suspect Admits to a Plot
description: A reputed senior aide to Osama bin Laden who has been jailed in New York since 1998 admitted in federal court yesterday that he planned two years ago to take hostages in a bid to win freedom for himself and other terrorism suspects at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Gain and Bonds Fall On Labor Market Report

title: Just 5 Guys Who Risk Their Own Lives
description: After a firefighter rescued Steve Marley's mother and sister from their burning home in Marine Park, Brooklyn, Mr. Marley asked how he could ever repay such a debt. ''There is no way to thank somebody that has literally put his life on the line,'' he says in ''These Men of Conscience,'' a documentary by Carol Ann Francis. That fireman ''put his hand on my shoulder, and he said, 'Steve, someday, somewhere in your life, if you can, help a fireman, or even one better, become one yourself.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOOD, FRED E.
description: HOOD-Fred E. September 7th, 2001. Remembered with love. His wife Miriam, children Shawn, Joel and Viviana, grandchildren Loren, Liana and Daniela, and many relatives and friends

description: COBURN-Ruth (Barnum) in Bedford, MA, September 5, 2002. Wife of Rt. Rev. John B. Coburn, formerly of St. James Church, NYC. Mother of Judith Coburn Klein of Newton, MA, Sarah Coburn Borgeson of Sherborn, MA, Thomas B. Coburn of Canton, NY, Michael C. Coburn of Providence, RI and the late Cynthia Anne Coburn. Sister of Eleanor Barnum Gardner of Shelburne, VT. Also survived by eight grandchildren and her great grandson. Services in St. Anne's in-theFields, Concord Road (Route 126) Lincoln, MA, Sunday, September 8th at 4PM. In lieu of flowers gifts in her memory may be sent to Lower Cape Outreach Council, 19 Brewster Cross Road, Orleans, MA. 02653.

title: Good Will Widespread As Congress Visits City
description: Even after the Sept. 11 attacks, Senator Don Nickles, a Republican from Oklahoma, seemed hard pressed to show a whole lot of sympathy for New York, questioning every penny Washington wanted to spend to rebuild Lower Manhattan.

title: U.S. Revokes License Plates Issued to 185 at 30 Consulates
description: The State Department yesterday revoked 185 special license plates belonging to 30 foreign consulates in New York City because of unpaid parking tickets, the result of an agreement reached with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to resolve the problem of scofflaw diplomats.

title: Where's the Left After 9/11?
description: To the Editor:

title: Venice Film Festival Tries to Quit Sinking
description: Some of the most heated chatter up and down the Lido this week was not about the movies in competition at the Venice Film Festival, even though they covered subjects as provocative as a bisexual painter and the sadism of Irish nuns.

title: Israelis Greet High Holy Days With a Renewed Nervousness
description: Israel was on high alert today, stunned by the interception of a huge bomb on Thursday, and warned that more attacks were possible, as the people hunkered down to celebrate the Jewish New Year.

title: Where's the Left After 9/11?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tough in Tehran
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Blames Taliban for Civilian Deaths in an American Raid
description: The United States Central Command acknowledged tonight that scores of civilians were killed or injured in an American airstrike on a string of Afghan villages in July, but blamed Taliban fighters for placing women and children near valid military targets.

title: Where's the Left After 9/11?
description: To the Editor:

title: PFIZER TO DELAY SEEKING APPROVAL FOR EPILEPSY DRUG
description: Pfizer will delay seeking approval in the United States for an epilepsy treatment called pregabalin until next year because it wants to include more safety studies in its application. The company expects to apply in March for approval of pregabalin in Europe and then in the United States, Pfizer said. Pregabalin is a successor to Pfizer's Neurontin, which had about $1.75 billion in sales in 2001. Pfizer may need pregabalin to help replace sales that could be lost to cheaper generic copies of Neurontin. Last year, the Food and Drug Administration asked Pfizer to withhold pregabalin from some patients after a study linked the drug to an increased incidence of tumors in mice.

title: On World Court, U.S. Focus Shifts to Shielding Officials
description: The Bush administration is shifting its emphasis in seeking exemptions for Americans from the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court, telling European allies that a central reason is to protect the country's top leaders from being indicted, arrested or hauled before the court on war crimes charges, administration officials say.

title: Jets and Mawae Reach a Deal
description: With the clock winding down toward a deadline that would have halted negotiations, the Jets agreed to terms with center Kevin Mawae tonight on a six-year contract that will pay him a $9.5 million signing bonus, according to a National Football League official familiar with the deal.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: STRONG JOB GROWTH IN AUGUST More jobs were created in Canada in the first eight months of this year than in any corresponding period since 1994, Statistics Canada said in a report. The unemployment rate dipped to 7.5 percent in August from 7.6 percent in July. About 59,000 new jobs were created in August, mainly in manufacturing and construction, bringing the total so far this year to 386,000. This year's summer job market for students was the best in a decade, Statistics Canada said.

title: Corrections
description: A jazz review and a listing in the Pop and Jazz Guide in Weekend yesterday about the band Sphere misstated the closing date of its engagement at Iridium, in Manhattan, and misstated the club's telephone number. The close is tomorrow night, not tonight. Information: (212) 582-2121.

title: Spitzer Opens Inquiry Into the Business Practices of Hospital Buying Groups
description: The office of State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that it had opened an inquiry to determine if groups that help New York hospitals to buy billions in supplies were violating federal Medicaid laws or throttling competition among medical product makers to the detriment of patients.

title: 2nd Round of Compensation For Sept. 11 Victims' Families
description: The federal government yesterday announced its second batch of awards to compensate the relatives of victims from the Sept. 11 terror attack, offering 18 families awards ranging from a low of $280,000 to a high of $3.7 million.

title: National Briefing: Health and Science
description: WEST NILE IN THE WEST

title: F.D.A. Shifts Biotech Drugs Into Main Oversight Unit
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced a significant reorganization yesterday intended to speed the review of drugs made by biotechnology.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: SOLDIER TELLS OF KILLINGS A soldier who served in the Yugoslav Army ignored warnings yesterday from United Nations judges that he was incriminating himself and told the court at Slobodan Milosevic's war crimes trial that he had helped murder 15 unarmed ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. The witness, identified only as K-41, had his image blurred so he could not be recognized in in-house television pictures in the court's public gallery or on Internet broadcasts of the hearings. "What I remember most vividly is how a baby was shot, and it was screaming unbelievably loud," the witness said, describing how he and fellow soldiers killed a group of men, women and children in the village of Trnje in southern Kosovo on March 25, 1999. He said he was following the orders of his sergeant.    (AP)

title: BONE LOSS CITED IN STUDY OF PHARMACIA CONTRACEPTIVE
description: Pharmacia's contraceptive drug Depo-Provera may lead to bone loss, according to a study from the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. In a three-year study of 440 women in the same insurance plan in Washington State, Depo-Provera users lost 1.12 percent of their bone density at the hip joint each year, compared with a 0.05 percent loss among nonusers, the study showed. The study is published in the September issue of the journal Epidemiology. Depo-Provera accounted for $283 million of Pharmacia's $13.8 billion in sales last year. The company, which is based in Peapack, N.J., did not return a call seeking comment.

Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., said in a lawsuit filed in Delaware Chancery Court that it had relied on the recommendations and assurances of the insurers when it bought more than $1.3 billion in policies from December 1993 to July 1995 to cover employees' life insurance needs and to earn tax breaks. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, passed in 1996, eliminated Wal-Mart's ability to deduct interest on money borrowed to pay for the policies, the suit said.

Even though the 27 percent decline in the real against the dollar this year raises costs for some manufacturers, it may aid the recovery for steel makers, aluminum companies and farmers by making their goods more competitive abroad and increasing revenue.

Microsoft lent the money as an advance on the value of stock options that Mr. Belluzzo received, the Securities and Exchange Commission filing shows. Mr. Belluzzo did not repay any of the loan, a spokeswoman for Microsoft said. Mr. Belluzzo agreed to the cancellation of 3.5 million shares in options grants made in 1999 and 2000. Mr. Green, who made his fortune in retailing, raised his offer 12 percent, to 4.08 a share from a previous bid made last month, to win the backing of Arcadia's management. Known for turning around retailers, Mr. Green at one point made an offer for Marks & Spencer when it was experiencing a sharp downturn in business. Mr. Green, who already owns the BHS chain of department stores and Mark One discount retailers, will add Arcadia brands to his holdings, including retailers of trendy clothing like Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins.
