title: A Masterpiece Of Animation
description: THOUGH I haven't seen the English-language version of Hayao Miyazaki's ''Spirited Away,'' I can vouch for the version that was released in Japan last year and quickly became the highest-grossing film in that country's history. It's a masterpiece, pure and simple -- certainly the finest thing that the distinctive Japanese style of animation, called anime, has produced -- and a film that can stand with the Disney classics of the 30's and 40's in the range of its imagination and the quality of its execution.

title: Sports of The Times; A Game That Argentina Has Been Waiting For
description: THE arcing 3-pointer from the left wing was settling in the net when Manu Ginobili landed awkwardly on his right ankle, then crumpled to the floor and onto his back. Good shot, bad timing. His team, Argentina, was in the second quarter of a dogfight with Germany in the semifinals of the world basketball championships.

title: In the Borough of Kings, an Ivy League Look-Alike
description: In the 72 years since Brooklyn College opened, generations of future film stars have passed through its halls. Dominic Chianese, class of 1961, went on to become Uncle Junior on ''The Sopranos,'' and Jimmy Smits, class of 1980, graduated to ''L.A. Law'' and ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' But these days, the campus itself is often in the spotlight.

title: It Took Some Time To Prepare for Prime Time
description: Douglas Forrester's public schedule, normally littered with events, was lightened last week because the Republican Senate candidate spent much of his time preparing for his first debate.

title: Books in Brief
description: THE DAY OUR WORLD CHANGED

title: Mythic, and Radically New
description: IF Matthew Barney didn't exist, Thomas Krens, the director of the Guggenheim Museum, would have invented him. Mr. Barney's ''Cremaster'' epic of five films, accompanied by numerous sculptures, photographs and drawings, which opens at the museum on Feb. 21, represents a convergence that has almost always eluded the ambitious Guggenheim: spectacle combined with substance, brought together in the form of radical new art.

title: 'The Fall of Berlin 1945'
description: Berliners, gaunt from short rations and stress, had little to celebrate at Christmas in 1944. Much of the capital of the Reich had been reduced to rubble by bombing raids. The Berlin talent for black jokes had turned to gallows humour. The quip of that unfestive season was: 'Be practical: give a coffin.'

title: Seeking Stimulation
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Sweet Tooth
description: If April is the cruelest month, as T. S. Eliot held in ''The Waste Land,'' September is the kindest in the lush land, bringing purple or translucent green hues in grapes, signifying maturation.

title: Television's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving New Meaning To 'Special Teams'
description: A football game seems to be an inconsequential footnote to the tragedies of Sept. 11. But one, last May's annual match between the city's Fire and Police Departments, was freighted with inspiration and sorrow. Of the 343 firefighters who died at the World Trade Center, seven played for the Bravest. Fifteen were alumni. Two of the dead were the team's quarterbacks.

title: Reflections on an America Transformed
description: If there is near-universal agreement that Sept. 11 changed America, there is a wide range of opinion about what that transformation consists of. For some, the change is simply a matter of perspective; for others, it is manifest in public policy, legal rules, political debate or their daily lives. We asked 12 Americans for their views on the most significant change the country has undergone in the year since Sept. 11.

title: Back From a Dark Future, Spielberg Lightens Up
description: ON a blustery day in late April, Eero Saarinen's gloriously Art Moderne T.W.A. terminal at Kennedy International Airport looked like something out of ''The Twilight Zone.'' Outside the soaring, birdlike structure, built in 1962 but abandoned last year, a fleet of finned Cadillacs and old Checker cabs waited to pick up nonexistent passengers, while a police car with dome light looked as if it had just been driven onto the property by Toody and Muldoon of ''Car 54, Where Are You?''

title: Life Goes On. A Sense of Loss Does, Too
description: ALMOST one year ago, the World Trade Center crumbled to the ground.

title: The Reptile Wrangler
description: TROMPING through the woods of the Manumuskin Preserve here, wearing a pack full of electronic gear and carrying a contraption that looks like a rooftop television antenna, Bill Smith may seem as if he is a sunstroke victim seeking incoming Martians. But his quarry -- northern pine snakes -- are a bit more earthbound, if only slightly less odd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVGIN, BONNIE B.
description: DAVGIN-Bonnie B. of White Plains, N.Y. on August 19, 2002, age 59. Beloved wife of Charles K. Davgin. Memorial service Sunday, September 22, 1:30PM at Ridgeway Alliance Church, White Plains, N.Y. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to Ridgeway Alliance Church, Deacon's Fund, Ridgeway Ave, White Plains, N.Y. 10605

title: Sept. 11 Forecast: Full At Hotels Downtown
description: The Sept. 11 commemorations in Manhattan this week are going to be a boon to downtown hotels, while those farther uptown are not expected to be full.

title: Articles of Faith
description: THE HEART OF ISLAM

title: Susannah Harris, Bryan Dicker
description: Susannah McKinley Harris, a daughter of Kathleen McKinley Harris and Dr. Everett Harris of Charlotte, Vt., was married yesterday to Bryan Todd Dicker, a son of Patricia and Michael Dicker of Oakland, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Tom Davis, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Wilson Chapel at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Linking to Dance's Future in a 21st-Century Workshop
description: WITH the formal opening on Oct. 2 of the new Dance Theater Workshop in Chelsea, New York dance officially enters the cyber universe. The new D.T.W. is the most technologically sophisticated dance theater space in the nation and perhaps the world, judging by anecdotal evidence from touring dance companies.

title: Californians in Paris; Merchant Ivory, Too
description: ON a sparkling April afternoon in the private garden of an elegant house near the Seine, James Ivory had shushed the actors, adjusted the lights and pointed the camera -- but he was not about to call ''Action!'' on a party scene until the bells from a neighboring church had stopped ringing.

title: Perspectives: Sept. 11 and Beyond
description: Following are the first four articles in a series in which national and world figures reflect on the terrorist attacks and their effect on a year of public life and policy.

title: Holding On to Luke
description: I found myself rooting for this child, even as your writer so poignantly described each hurdle, and I was certain he would pull through. So I was stunned as I read on and realized that Luke would indeed not be able to win this fight. Those paragraphs describing his final moments came so fast they caught me off guard, and I found myself fighting back tears.

title: Shareholder Power (Or Weakness)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sooners' Hybl Quiets Alabama and His Critics
description: Nate Hybl had learned to turn a deaf ear to the boos and the endless ridicule that often accompanied his performances in 2001. Despite leading Oklahoma to an 11-2 record and a No. 6 national ranking as a junior, his play at quarterback was regularly criticized.

title: Treasure Glints From Old Trash
description: MENLO PARK was once just a tiny crossroads in Raritan Township along the Pennsylvania Rail Road line. But in 1876, young men began to arrive from around the country and Europe with the hope of working for Thomas A. Edison, who had established a laboratory there.

title: Our Towns; In Their Gazes Across the River, There's a Huge Void in the View
description: ARRIVING at work at the Liberty Landing Marina on that crystal morning a year ago, Craig Makin was struck with a feeling that he now cherishes. ''I was thinking to myself, How I love this view,'' he said. ''Who knew that would be the end of it?''

title: An Emphasis on Illusion
description: THIS will be a season of choreographic surprises and startling transformations on stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMSON, JEAN
description: THOMSON-Jean. Born April 8, 1918. Reading ''NYT'' and smiling at grandchildren, Jean died at home in Minnetonka, August 29, 2002, loved by young and old.

title: Corrections
description: The introduction to an interview last Sunday with the Japanese theater director Amon Miyamoto, about his adaptation of the Stephen Sondheim musical ''Pacific Overtures,'' misidentified the librettist who collaborated with Mr. Sondheim on the show. It was John Weidman, not James Lapine.

title: Tax Break for Homes Affected by Sept. 11
description: People affected by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks who felt forced to sell their homes may qualify for a tax break, even if they lived in those homes only a short time, the Treasury Department and Internal Revenue Service decided late last month.

title: Staring at Meyer Lansky
description: BRONX BOY

title: War of Secrets; Not Much Has Changed in a System That Failed
description: EVEN though American intelligence agencies were harshly criticized after the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington for having missed signs that attacks were planned, there has been surprisingly little fundamental restructuring in the year since. Certainly there has been less change than was predicted in the weeks after Sept. 11, 2001.

title: A School For Scandal And Its Patrons
description: THE SETTING -- A long, windowless room on the 19th floor of an office building on Jay Street. Among the 80 men seated in classroom-style desk chairs were fathers and husbands, blue-collar workers and professionals, whites, blacks, Latinos and Asians. They had been summoned here one night in late August for a reason none of them wanted to talk about: they had each been charged with soliciting a prostitute and were now enrolled in ''john school.''

title: Sept. 1-7: NATIONAL; GUNS FOR PILOTS
description: The Senate joined the House in voting overwhelmingly to let pilots carry guns in their cockpits. Leaders of both houses questioned the strategy of arming pilots, as did the Bush administration and the airlines, but the idea appealed to the pilots themselves, and the public. Al Aitken, a pilot at American Airlines and a union official there, said after the vote, ''Members of Congress have come to understand what the American people have known for months: only lethal force can stop lethal intent.'' Matthew L. Wald

title: Carolyn Hanson, Erin Fitzpatrick
description: Carolyn Louise Hanson, a daughter of Kathryn and Erik Hanson of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married on Friday evening to Erin Kells Fitzpatrick, the son of Suzanne and George Fitzpatrick of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Joan Brown Campbell, a minister of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), performed the ceremony at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Powell Defends A First Strike As Iraq Option
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell defended President Bush's policy of pre-emption against countries that threatened the United States and in an interview on Friday played down talk of tensions with American allies in Europe as squabbling among friends.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Nissan 350Z; Fast Forward: Greatest 'Z' Hits, Vol. 5
description: IT'S hard to measure anticipation in exact terms, but even so, it's pretty clear that the resurrection of the Nissan Z-car is generating more buzz than just about anything else on the new-car horizon.

title: Article 2002090892363851077 -- No Title
Paid Notice: Memorials  WEXLER, MELISSA
description: WEXLER-Melissa. May 9, 1958 - September 12,1981. Sweet Missy, we will miss you forever. Love Mommy. Arline Joachim Eddie, Sheri & Larr

title: Letters
description: Life After Dunbar

title: Adventure at the City's Waterfront
description: Ask most cruising sailors about their ideal sailing destination and tales will be told of tradewind passages, white-sand beaches and tropical sunsets taken in from the protected anchorage of a low-lying atoll.

title: Historic, House-Proud Galena
description: ON a low shelf at the rear of a rare-book shop in Galena, Ill., I found a two-volume first edition of the memoirs of President Ulysses S. Grant. Often described as the best memoir ever written by an American president, it is one of those books that most lovers of American history know they should read, but few actually do. The edition I saw, bound in green covers that were only slightly faded, was priced at $175. That seemed steep, but there was an added attraction: Grant actually lived in Galena, less than a mile from the bookstore. The idea of buying Grant's book so close to where he wrote it was nearly irresistible. But before reaching for my wallet I decided to reflect awhile, and stepped out for a stroll along this town's magnificently preserved Main Street.

title: Michelina Pagano, Anthony Parente
description: Michelina Olimpia Pagano and Anthony Jude Parente are to be married today at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. The Rev. Rosemary Bray McNatt, a Unitarian Universalist minister, will officiate, and the Rev. Paul Mayer, a Roman Catholic priest, will take part in the ceremony.

title: In a Russian Governor's Race, Elements of Farce
description: Two enormous financial empires have thrown their might behind competing candidates in a closely fought election in the heart of Siberia that political analysts in Moscow say is basically a corporate battle.

title: Life Goes On. A Sense of Loss Does, Too.
description: LAST summer was a giddy one for John and Raffaella Crisci of Holbrook. They had just begun to enjoy a renewed romance as their three teenage sons grew less dependent. They held hands on the beach and resumed their after-dinner strolls. They were discovering each other just as they had as teenagers in Brooklyn, where a bond seemed fated even before they met. Only three short blocks and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway separated their childhood homes.

title: Strategies For State Parks
description: HAVING spent a delightful week camping with my husband and two young children last September at San Elijo State Beach in Southern California, I decided to try to repeat the experience this summer. But like other desirable California state parks, San Elijo requires campsite reservations in peak season, and to get one you should book six months ahead.

title: Holding On to Luke
description: I thank Rebecca Johnson for her courage in sharing her story (Aug. 25). She not only opens her heart to us and honors Luke's struggle for life but also responsibly provides what will undoubtedly prove life-altering infor-mation for many readers and their babies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HERMAN BILL
description: WEISS-Herman Bill. Of Franklin Square, NY. Beloved husband of Janet. Devoted brother of Harriet and Muriel, and the late Shirley. Loving father of Pam and Ellen. Father-in-law of Frank and Andy. Adored grandfather of Courtney, Brian, Daniel, Jordan, and Rachel. Died peacefully on September 5, 2002. He will be missed by all who knew him. Services will be held Monday, September 9, at noon, at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead.

title: Beauty and Color Rise From Devastation
description: THOUSANDS of colorful bulbs flowered from last February into June along the Greenwich Village portion of Hudson River Park, a work in progress stretching from the Battery to 59th Street. They were among the outpouring of donations that organizations from throughout the United States and the world sent to New York City to show support and empathy after Sept. 11.

title: Applause, Applause
description: I have three cookbooks written in the 50's and 60's whose titles all but declare that cooking and entertaining are about seduction, or at least about showing off: ''The Perfect Hostess Cookbook,'' ''Come for Cocktails, Stay for Supper'' (by Lois Levine and this newspaper's Marian Burros) and my favorite, ''Cooking for Compliments.'' The author of the last one, a radio personality named Martha Deane, gets right to the point. ''We may as well admit that it's fun to be complimented,'' she writes in her preface. ''Possibly sterner generations took a dim view of this thought, fearing that it smacked of the sin of vanity. But modern psychiatrists tell us that happy is she who reaps satisfaction from the work she does. Including her cooking -- of which she will average some 50,000 hours of her married life!''

title: Returning to the Polls Means More Than Just Voting
description: THERE is something creepy about the thought of voting this year. So much has changed. A year ago, voting was normal, routine, as glorious as the clear blue sky on a late summer day. Thousands of people were at the polls, or on their way, or had just left, when the unthinkable happened.

title: Kelley King and Benton Heyworth
description: Kelley Erin King, a daughter of Cynthia and Jeffery King of Malvern, Pa., was married yesterday to Benton Evans Heyworth, a son of Christine Heyworth and James Heyworth of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Arthur Namendorf, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Baptist Church in the Great Valley in Devon, Pa.

title: Campaign Season
description: Georgia Is Very Much On Democrats' Minds

title: 'The Dark Bride'
description: Then slowly the night would open and the miracle unfold. Far off in the distance, against the immense, silky darkness, strings of colored lights would appear in La Catunga, the barrio of las mujeres , the women. Men, freshly bathed and splashed with cologne, would pile into trucks on payday and come down the mountain from the oil fields to the city of Tora, drawn like moths to a flame by those twinkling electric lights that held the greatest promise of earthly bliss.

title: Don't Rebuild. Reimagine.
description: After the catastrophe of 9/11, who wanted to think about the aesthetics of architecture? Many people, it turned out. Buildings were the targets of the terrorist attacks. Fantasies of new buildings became a form of recovery: signs of the city's resilience in the face of unprecedented enemy assault. Proposals came from architects, artists and the public. And in July they came from the architecture firm formally chosen to supply these first-draft plans for what a rebuilt ground zero ought to look like. These official plans were universally derided.

title: Powell Defends a First Strike as Iraq Option
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell defended President Bush's policy of pre-emption against countries that threatened the United States and in an interview on Friday played down talk of tensions with American allies in Europe as squabbling among friends.

title: ABBEY DEVELOPMENT
description: Morris Township last week approved a plan by Benedictine monks to build a commercial housing, nursing and medical project on abbey property. The project, called Abbey Woods, has attracted opposition from environmental groups and the National Park Service, which warned of traffic and water pollution. The monks must next persuade state Department of Environmental Quality officials to allow a connection to the township's water treatment plant. Jeremy Pearce

title: In the Region/Long Island; Developers Create Offices From Industrial Sites
description: THE amount of Class B office space on Long Island has jumped in the past year, in large part because of changes in the industrial segment. As increasing numbers of manufacturers need more sophisticated facilities, developers are seeing aging industrial sites as prime candidates for conversion to office space -- if they can support parking lots that are large enough.

title: Schools Make Do With Less
description: AS the state's 563,000 public school students settle into their classrooms, Connecticut educators say they are facing another ''R'' to go along with reading, writing and arithmetic: reductions.

title: Investing; Follow Dividend Yields With Care
description: YIELDS have been climbing on many large-capitalization stocks, not because they have raised their dividends but because their prices have fallen sharply.

title: Sept. 1-7: NATIONAL; CONGRESS VISITS NEW YORK
description: Congress convened a special meeting in New York to pay tribute to the victims and heroes of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and, in the words of many of the speakers, to show the world that America has been made stronger. More than 300 lawmakers assembled in lower Manhattan at Federal Hall, the site of the building where Congress first convened 213 years ago and where George Washington was inaugurated as the first president.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Eva Amurri; Glittering in Mom's Sky
description: SO it wasn't a typical summer vacation. Eva Amurri and her friend Elissa Goldstone started in Prague because Eva's mother, Susan Sarandon, was shooting a movie there. There were a few film festivals (Taos, Santa Barbara) for Eva, 17, who had been in an award-winning mockumentary about cosmetology called ''Made-Up.'' She visited her father, the director Franco Amurri, in Italy, and finished the summer in Scotland and Ireland, where her mother and her mother's companion, Tim Robbins, were doing a play about Sept. 11 called ''The Guys.''

title: Tara Lynn Wagner, Joshua Payne
description: Tara Lynn Wagner, a cable news reporter, and Joshua Martin Payne, a talent coordinator for ''Saturday Night Live'' on NBC, were married on Friday in Beacon, N.Y. The Rev. Rayner Wilson Hesse Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated at Dutchess Manor, a caterer.

title: Sept. 1-7: NATIONAL; IRAQ HEARINGS IN CONGRESS
description: Hours after President Bush agreed to make Congress a partner in deciding whether to invade Iraq, members from both parties began gearing up the cumbersome legislative process to reach a decision. At least six committees plan several weeks of hearings to determine whether an invasion is justified and would work, and the airwaves will most likely be full of supporters and opponents through October. Legislative leaders said they might delay a vote until after the Nov. 7 midterm elections. David Firestone

title: Article 2002090890163599848 -- No Title
Threat to Redwoods Muffles Logging Debate
description: Most of the ancient redwood forests here in the Santa Cruz Mountains were sheared to the ground by loggers more than a century ago. Rotting stumps, some bigger than a banquet table, are like grave markers for the trees on the steep forest floor.

title: Dance Listings
description: KAREN BERNARD  Solo dances. Here, 145 Sixth Ave., between Spring and Broome St. (212-647-0202) Thur., Fri., 7 p.m. Through Sept. 19.

title: Karena Elwell, Martijn Rasser
description: Karena Dawn Elwell, a daughter of Roberta Elwell of Fishers Island, N.Y., and Lance Elwell of Hadlyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Martijn Rasser, a son of Marleen and Koos Rasser of London. The ceremony took place at the Fishers Island home of T. W. Russell, the father of the bride's stepmother, Sarah Russell. Louisa Evans, a town justice of Southold, N.Y., officiated.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF
description: TO REACH THE CLOUDS

title: Who's No. 1 Among No. 1's?
description: ON Sept. 24, a great battle will begin. It will last a week, after which a longstanding point of contention in pop music will be decided: Elvis or the Beatles -- who is king?

title: Sept. 1-7: INTERNATIONAL; AIDS IN CHINA
description: China raised its estimate of the number of people infected with the ASenate Judiciary Committee, voting along party lines, rejected one ) IDS virus to one million and said it would manufacture AIDS drugs if Western patent holders did not lower prices. By doing so, officials for the first time publicly asked for international help with the country's AIDS problem, which they had insisted they could handle on their own. Chinese officials had previously said that, as a new member of the World Trade Organization, China had to be vigilant about respecting patents.

title: Political Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Among the Heroes'
description: The sky on September 11 dawned cerulean blue, one of those unblemished skies that often appeared in late summer after heavy rains or hurricanes -- rinsed, cloudless, apparently cleansed of tumult. It was a week past Labor Day. The U.S. Open tennis tournament had just concluded, school was back in session, football season had begun, baseball had entered its stretch run. Casual fashion had faded to basic black. Autumn had arrived in the New York area, if not by calendar's decree, then by the urgent feel of resumption. Summer had been shaken away like sand from a beach towel.

title: Fans and Players at a Korean Soccer Stadium Root for Unity
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 7  The 60,000 spectators who filled the World Cup Stadium here saved their loudest cheers tonight for the spectacle of North and South Korean soccer players holding aloft a large "unification" flag, depicting a blue Korean peninsula against a white field with no line separating the two countries.

title: The Table Is Set, At Last, in a Home
description: JUDY CHICAGO's studio in this village of 8,300 is a long way from the trendsetting galleries of Manhattan. It's part of a converted boardinghouse she shares with the photographer and contractor Donald Woodman, her husband of 17 years. He has contributed to its safe, protected feeling, rounding the edges of many interior walls to make them appear less harsh. Her seven cats sprawl in cozy heaps throughout.

title: Blair, Meeting With Bush, Fully Endorses U.S. Plans For Ending Iraqi Threat
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain today fully endorsed President Bush's drive to destroy Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, declaring at the opening of a meeting at Camp David that ''the policy of inaction is not a policy we can responsibly subscribe to.''

title: For Most, City Grass Is Green Enough
description: Given a choice, most New Yorkers say they would prefer to live in New York City than anyplace else, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll. Fifty-seven percent of the 1,008 respondents hope to still be living in New York four years from now, while 42 percent would just as soon leave. The percentage of people who wish to relocate has risen in the short term up from 31 percent in a poll taken less than a month after Sept. 11. But far more people want to stay in the city now than in 1991. During that time of recession and high crime rates, only 37 percent wanted to remain and 60 percent wanted to leave. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: Anthropologie and Others Arrive at the Westchester Mall
description: Shoppers will have new stores to choose from at at The Westchester in White Plains. Anthropologie opened in late May on Level 3. The store carries an eclectic selection of women's apparel, along with housewares and furniture reproduced from designs culled from Europe, India and the Far East.

title: Meet Stan, Model Patient
description: THERE are working stiffs and there are working stiffs, but there is no one in the county quite like Stan, the Quarter Million Dollar Man. Stan works at the Cochran School of Nursing at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. The 406-bed hospital, which opened in 1869, decided last year that they wanted to provide students at the nursing school, founded in 1894, with a most modern teaching aid. It's one that can help students learn in a way that goes beyond patient rounds or book studies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, RAY (BERNSTEIN)
description: MARCUS-Ray (Bernstein). Passed away on September 5, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Mother of Neil, Erica, and Jay. Sister of Sonny. Active in her Concord Village Community. Services will be held at Congregation Mount Sinai, 250 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn, NY, Monday 11:30 AM. Donations to Enterprise Foundation.

title: Bowling Alleys and Big Hair
description: THE LAST GOOD CHANCE

title: Officials Doubt That Couple Had Links to Terror Groups
description: Neighbors and co-workers describe Astrid Eyzaguirre as a chatty, vivacious woman who bounced through several jobs at the military shopping center in this romantic university town where the European headquarters of the United States Army is based.

title: What Was, And What Could Be
description: A special issue of The Times Magazine today takes two long looks at Lower Manhattan. The first is a biography of the World Trade Center towers: the dizzying ambition that led to their rise and ultimately figured in their fall. The second is a series of blueprints for the future, dreamed up by a panel of architects that includes Peter Eisenman, Charles Gwathmey, Zaha Hadid, Steven Holl, Rem Koolhaas, Maya Lin, Richard Meier, David Rockwell, Frederic Schwartz and Rafael Violy, moderated by The Times's architecture critic, Herbert Muschamp.

title: A Dream in Green
description: FROM its restful green walls to its earnest, inquiring chef, Andiamo is a restaurant that I want to love. Tucked between quaint antique shops and near its more famous neighbor, a restaurant called No. 9, its crisp white tablecloths and Sinatra music seem a respite from one too many meals of roasted chicken, baby vegetables and garlicky mashed potatoes.

title: Saving Rolando
description: IN AMERICA'S COURT

title: A Rite of Summer That Offers a Taste of Danger
description: Summer vacation was over, but that did not stop children and teenagers from heading to the Bronx River after school last Thursday for a dip in their favorite forbidden spot: the water atop a manmade waterfall where the Bronx Zoo meets Bronx River Park. The more daring flaunt their bravado by hurling themselves over jutting rocks and cascading water into the deep pool about 12 feet below.

title: Dana Pearce, Roger Van Voorhis
description: Dana Carole Pearce and Roger Bernard Van Voorhis were married yesterday at St. Andrew's Church in Rochester. The Rev. Michael Mayer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday with the Economic View column, about the reliability of economists' forecasts, mislabeled percentage figures from a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. The bars denoted economists' estimate of the chances that the economy would shrink in the next quarter -- not the percentage of economists who said the economy would shrink.

title: One Small Party's Primary Could Have a Big Impact
description: What suspense remains in Tuesday's statewide primary elections arises from a party that has just 2 percent of New York's voters, is riven by factional warfare, and has little ideology, no history of significant primaries, and many voters who have never voted before.

title: Edwards Makes Unlikely Return
description: DAVIE, Fla., Sept. 5  Robert Edwards rubbed the inside of his left knee, where a nearly footlong scar serves as a daily reminder of how far he has come. Call him Miracle Man. Some in the medical profession thought Edwards would be a cripple now, certainly not a Miami Dolphins running back.

title: He Keeps Marching Bands' Feet in Step With the Beat
description: For 30 years, as patriotic expression has waxed and waned and pop music styles have changed faster than you can say Milli Vanilli, Eugene Bennett has plugged away at a peculiarly enduring American art form: drum and bugle corps competitions. He has spent thousands of hours teaching local children and adults to march with rolling steps while beating out rhythmic or syncopated tunes. He titles the initial class that he teaches to a high school band ''Introduction to Your Feet.''

title: Boy, 5, Dies After Being Hit by Car in Bronx
description: A5-year-old Bronx boy was killed Friday night when he apparently left the side of his mother and darted in front of a passing sport utility vehicle, the authorities said. The driver of the car had not been charged.

title: Diana Simpson, George Feaver IV
description: Diana Christine Simpson, the daughter of Anne and Patrick Simpson of Raleigh, N.C., was married yesterday to George Winifred Feaver IV, the son of Jane G. Hilles of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Ralph M. Feaver of Lagoa, Portugal. The Rev. John Pilutti, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Valley View Farm Guest House in Hartwick, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An automobile review of the Lincoln Navigator last Sunday misstated its fuel consumption. In city driving, the car travels about 11 miles on a gallon of premium gasoline, not on a tankful.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PERSPECTIVES/Colin L. Powell; Juggling the Demands of Diplomacy and a Different Kind of War
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, aboard his plane returning from Africa, on Friday:

title: A Plan to Keep the Towers From Taking Over
description: Donald Trump probably won't move to Park Slope anytime soon, but if he does, there are certain rules he'll have to follow. After years of lobbying from Community Board 6 and other neighborhood groups, the south part of Park Slope is likely to join the north Slope and north Prospect Heights, with zoning regulations that would limit building height in most of the area to 50 to 75 feet. In commercial zones, the plan would also allow for taller buildings than do current regulations.

title: Baby, What's Your Sign?
description: Susan Lazar's Egg baby blankets bring this season's craze for intarsia (knitting with interwoven color blocks of yarn) to a whole new infant stage. Each of the 12 Egg blankets -- whose fans include Cate Blanchett and Julianne Moore -- bears an abstract graphic symbolizing a different sign of the zodiac, like the crab of Cancer at left. In cashmere ($280) or cotton ($96, both at Henri Bendel), the coverlets can also double as travel blankets for adults who like to be babied en route.

title: Buddha in Every Borough

title: Holding On to Luke

One physician, she writes, ''wouldn't even let'' her tape their conversation. But surely she must know that for a doctor who was not on the scene to second-guess the decisions of those who were is highly unethical. She goes on to note that the ''fear of litigation'' was ''palpable'' in her own doctor's written account of her treatment and that ''all doctors are defensive about malpractice and none more so than obstetricians.'' It is little wonder. And if I were an obstetrician, I would be heading for the nearest exit, too.

description: Ending a colorful and enduring political career, the longtime mayor of Providence, R.I., Vincent A. He will not have to report to prison until Dec. 6, pending a bail appeal, but Mr. Cianci was forced to give up his job immediately, leaving a City Hall he had occupied for 21 of the last 27 years. title: A Secret Society of the Starving
description: Claire is 18. She is a pretty teenager, with long strawberry-blond hair, and she is almost abnormally self-possessed for a girl from a small town who has suddenly been descended upon by a big-city reporter who is there to talk to her, in secret, about her secret life. She is sitting on the track that runs around the field of her high school's football stadium, wearing running shorts and a T-shirt and shivering a little because even though we are in Florida -- in the kind of town where, according to Claire, during ''season'' when you see yet another car with New York plates, you just feel like running it down -- there's an evening chill.

title: Sept. 1-7: NATIONAL; FLORIDA BOYS CONVICTED
description: A jury in Pensacola, Fla., convicted two teenagers, Alex King and Derek King, of murdering their sleeping father in November and setting their house on fire to cover up their actions. A separate jury acquitted Ricky Chavis, a 40-year-old family friend accused of being sexually obsessed with Alex, who was prosecuted in a separate trial for the same killing of Terry Lee King. The boys, who were 12 and 13 at the time of the murder and were tried as adults, face sentences of 22 years to life in prison. They face possible sentences of 30 years for the arson conviction.

title: Notes on the Darkest Day
description: The first question, and the toughest one to answer, about the great drifts of Sept. 11 books now blowing into stores and libraries, is why do we need even one book about what happened when we saw the whole awful thing happen for ourselves, again and again, in telephoto detail, and we saw it so recently, just 12 months ago? Can the books help us remember? We haven't forgotten -- and for those who wish to relive things anyhow and achieve a catharsis that wasn't possible during that lurching, dissociated morning, television has powers that print can't match. Can the books help us move on? It feels too soon for that. Can they place the disaster in context? Well, contexts change -- faster than ever these days, and often violently. Before a reader can finish even one of the countless first-anniversary publications, we may be at war with Iraq, or under attack again. When the floor is still heaving, it's tough to take the long view.

title: The Last Color Line
description: Since our political culture has been dominated for much of the last 40 years by the dynamic of race -- by an acceptance of moral responsibility that over time has curdled into an endless round of accusation, guilt, repudiation and more accusation -- it's probably unwise to pronounce the hostilities finished. Certainly the underlying problems that afflict many black Americans -- impoverishment, educational failure, social and geographic isolation -- have abated but hardly disappeared. Yet as the second national election of the new millennium approaches, black political culture seems to be moving further and further from an adversarial, race-conscious model. There is a new black candidate on the campaign trail, a candidate who presents himself or herself in race-neutral terms and whose political views are eclectic and pragmatic. The two most prominent examples of this phenomenon are Ron Kirk, who has a real shot at becoming the first black senator from Texas, and H. Carl McCall, who, if August polls are accurate, could be poised for a surprise victory over the better known and more liberal Andrew M. Cuomo in the Democratic primary for governor of New York this Tuesday.

title: Wow, I Was a Director, and I Wanted to Say, Whoa!
description: MEETINGS happen all over Hollywood all the time. Right now there are three or five or seven bright people sitting on couches with clean lines staring at one another over Calistoga water and cups of tea. There is original art on the walls, a framed letter from the Clinton administration thanking somebody for something. People nod and exchange ideas, solve problems and nod some more. As a screenwriter, I have attended hundreds, maybe thousands, of these meetings, and in every one I answered questions, asked questions, talked and talked and talked. But it wasn't until I became a director that I realized nobody had been listening. Oh, they look as though they're listening to you, the writer, as you make the sounds we associate with speech; but really they're waiting, thinking private thoughts about fingernail colors and evening traffic on the Ventura Freeway, waiting to see if the director is listening to you. And then they listen to the director.

title: Smoke, Grief and Dinosaurs
description: Sometimes it takes a child's-eye view to transcend artifice, and this comes through vividly in THE DAY OUR WORLD CHANGED: Children's Art of 9/11 (Abrams, $19.95), a collaboration between the New York University Child Study Center and the Museum of the City of New York. The drawings, paintings and collages were done by students from New York, Connecticut and New Jersey between the ages of 5 and 18, and chosen by a jury of art curators, educators and a child psychologist. Among them are a heartbreaking crayon scrawl, by 10-year-old Edwin, of towers as billowing chimneys with small stick figures raining from the smoke-filled tops; a colored pen and pencil rendering by 7-year-old Julian Cortez and 8-year-old Paul Keim, whose ''Dinosaurs Rebuild the Twin Towers'' blends simplicity and surrealism; and a cut-paper collage by 9-year-old Nesita Abreu of a boy and girl holding one of the ubiquitous ''missing'' fliers, this one for Police Officer Jerome Dominguez. Many of the works reveal the navet of their young creators, but some, like the nighttime cityscape of the Brooklyn Bridge and twin towers from across the East River by 8-year-old Yvette Miller, display so much emotional exuberance that they belie the artists' ages. The drawings reveal varied emotions, from a giant Osama angrily devouring the towers, by 17-year-old Annie Mak, to 17-year-old Wanda Martinez's moody landscape of candles quietly facing a smoldering Ground Zero, to a joyful drawing by 8-year-old Kevin Wang of red hearts forming the twin towers dispersing and flying off into the sky. The book's cover image, a cut-paper design titled ''Memorial,'' by 11-year-old Andrew Emil (the son of the owner of Windows on the World), suggests the life and death of the building. A quotation accompanies it: ''My father worked on the 106th and 107th floors of the WTC Building Number One. Luckily he wasn't there.'' Steven Heller

title: Along a Remote Coastal Highway

Nothing on my map had indicated that the 270-mile detour from Wairoa to Opotiki was to be temporal as well as geographical. title: QUICK BITE/Lawnside; Barbecue Plays a Double Encore
description: Time was when both sides of Evesham Avenue in Lawnside were filled with revelers every weekend night, particularly when it was warm and the smell of grilling ribs and chicken filled the air. Segregation in Philadelphia entertainment spots brought African-Americans nine miles southeast to Lawnside, a town founded by free blacks in the 18th century, which has stayed primarily black and middle-class ever since. By 1999, the remaining two barbecue joints there folded. But this summer, two purveyors of the art sprung up from the ashes (the coals, anyway) of the Lawnside legacy. Both Nina's Bar-B-Que & Soul Food and Snow Hill Kitchen cook on huge grills near the highway, so they serve as both kitchen and olfactory advertising. You can eat inside or under wood-roofed picnic areas, Nina's being a bit more pleasant because it is in the rear, rather than on busy Evesham. Five or six large pork ribs go for $10 at Nina's, while four huge ribs cost $9 at Snow Hill. Chicken leg-and-thigh dinners are $7 and four wings are $3 at each. Dinners include two side dishes like yams, heavily buttered greens, potato salad or baked macaroni and cheese. Snow Hill's dessert specialty is carrot cake, while Nina's is sweet potato pie. Nina's barbecue sauce tends toward the heavy and spicy, while Snow Hill's is lighter and sweeter. Part of the charm in both places is that they are often out of what is on the menu but also have something else going for the night. One day, Snow Hill offered a family-of-four fried fish special for $23. Another time, Nina's offered a pound of steamed Alaskan Snow crab legs for $12.99. The astonishing politeness at both places is another reason to again go roadside in Lawnside. Robert Strauss

title: SMOG INCREASES
description: New Jersey's smog levels increased dramatically last year and have continued to worsen this year, according to the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group. The number was 190 in 2001, compared with 92 the previous year. As of August 3, the safety level already had been exceeded 205 times this year, the group said. The increase was due to hotter summers, the group said. Only California, Texas and Pennsylvania had higher numbers during 2001. Karen DeMasters

We want to be a nation that serves goals larger than self. We've been offered a unique opportunity, and we must not let this moment pass.'' description: SOME people meet cute, like bumping into each other at an ice cream shop and dribbling sorbet on each other. Jennifer Belle, 34, and Andrew Krents, 33, met short.

title: Wells Slightly Hurt in Early-Morning Assault, Police Say
description: David Wells, the 39-year-old Yankees pitcher, was assaulted early yesterday morning by a knife-wielding man at an Upper East Side diner, the authorities said.

title: Brave Enough to Be Himself
description: PHILIP GUSTON (1913-80) made his reputation in the 1950's with lyrical abstractions. Colors jostled and floated in the middle of his canvases. Then, in the 70's, he started painting bloated heads, floating eyeballs, hairy legs, cigarette butts, garbage can lids and hooded figures crammed into rickety cars. His style became cartoonish -- the colors pink, black, red and white; the tone creepy, black-humored and mysterious. Critics hated it.

title: Learning the Value Of Being Intimidated
description: ALISON LOHMAN may be considered brand-new in Hollywood. But there are those in the California retirement community Rancho Mirage who have long known her as the daughter of the architect Gary Lohman and the bakery owner Diane Lohman -- and as half of Sing-Sation!, a locally touring teenage duo.

title: POSTINGS: New Condo Units on Sale in Chelsea; Chain Works Is Converted To 18 Lofts
description: If Christian Pompa and Barry Leistner were to offer a lesson based on their conversion of the former factory at 144 West 18th Street in Chelsea into 18 condominium lofts, it would be that persistence pays off.

title: Back to the Starship Enterprise, as the Franchise Goes Where It's Gone Before
description: When ''Star Trek: Nemesis'' opens this December, audiences will learn that the United Federation of Planets is about to make peace with its adversary, the Romulan Empire. The initiative may founder, though, because of an enemy who is surprisingly close to the captain of the U.S.S. Enterprise.

title: Habitats/Williamsburg, Brooklyn; A Giver of Parties Now Also Gives Leases
description: TOSHI wasn't looking for a building to buy, and he certainly wasn't planning to become a landlord.

title: A Transplanted Pastime
description: The rumblings would seep through the classroom doors and into the corridors. Small heads swiveled sideways, in discreet efforts to see what had been forbidden. Gat Lee remembers those days as a boy in Toisan, China, remembers the roars from just beyond the school yard and pressing up against the roped-off space with his friends. He remembers the days the volleyball tournaments would come to town.

title: Beauty and Color Born of Devastation
description: THOUSANDS of colorful bulbs flowered from February into June along the Greenwich Village portion of Hudson River Park, a work in progress stretching from the Battery to 59th Street. They were among the outpouring of donations that organizations from throughout the United States and the world sent to New York City to show support and empathy after Sept. 11.

title: Reminiscent of Japan in Taste and Setting
description: KIKU SUSHI in the Springdale section of Stamford is so tiny that it is like wandering into a snug sushi bar in the labyrinthine side streets of Tokyo's Ginza district.

Devoted father of Steven Morello, Alfia Morello and Jessica LoRe. Loving grandfather of Presley Morello. Cherished son of Fay (nee Toscano) and Alfio Morello. Dear brother of Kathleen Campisano. Brother-in-law of Kathleen Zur and Mary Ellen Clark. Father-inLaw of Victor LoRe. He is also survived by several nieces and nephews. Family request that all meet at church. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington, NJ. For information G. Keenen O'Brien Funeral Home, Inc., There will be no visitation at the funeral home.

title: Johannesburg Asks Visitors to Stay Awhile
description: THE City of Gold, as this old mining town likes to call itself, has never had the luster that lures so many travelers to Cape Town, the Kruger National Park or the Drakensberg Mountains. And with none of the natural beauty that defines so much of South Africa, chances are it never will. So why is this hub of international commerce, home to Africa's biggest businesses and busiest airport, trying so hard to entice travelers to linger on their way to South Africa's more scenic attractions?

title: Business; Bloomberg, Without Bloomberg, Faces an Industry in Retreat
description: THE once and perhaps future desk of Michael R. Bloomberg, in the Park Avenue headquarters of the company he invented, has long since been filled. When Mr. Bloomberg moved downtown to the New York mayor's desk in City Hall in January, Peter Grauer, the company's new chairman, took his old chair. Elsewhere on the 15th floor sits Lex Fenwick, the man who took Mr. Bloomberg's old job as chief executive.

title: A Fight Against Junk E-Mail
description: Many consumers have long been annoyed by junk or ''spam'' e-mail. But complaints have risen considerably over the last year, along with the number of unwanted messages.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: YOU can't ask more of a teddy bear than to save a lock of Mom's hair for 2,000 years. Many people either love Teddy's movie -- Steven Spielberg's A.I.: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (2001) -- or despise every minute of it, but who could resist the little bear (with the deep, grown-up voice of Jack Angel), a supertoy who sticks by his owner to the end? The owner is David (Haley Joel Osment), a little-boy robot who can be adopted by humans and programmed to feel love. Unfortunately, when his adoptive parents' human son finally comes out of his coma, David can't be deprogrammed. In some ways this is two films: the Kubrickian first half (sterile serenity) and the Spielbergian second half (honky-tonk future Vegas). And it's now clear why the movie doesn't end after the Blue Fairy encounter: it would have robbed Teddy of his big moment -- Saturday at 10 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: Classic Sports: Excitement Builds for Men's Final
description: The individual roars, the celebrations for Pete Sampras's and Andre Agassi's semifinal victories in the United States Open, were separated by three hours yesterday afternoon, but they became one. A rivalry that seemed past its time had sprung back to life.

title: Eurostar to Get Faster, But First, Fewer Trains
description: Eurostar, the high-speed train linking London with Brussels and Paris, will operate less frequently during the next few months because of the construction of a new rail link on the English side of the Channel.

title: POSTINGS: Skadden, Arps Signs White Plains Lease; 48,842 Sq. Feet In Westchester
description: The law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom has signed a 10-year lease for 48,842 square feet at the Reckson Metro Center in White Plains. It plans to use the space -- about one-and-a-half floors of the 12 in the building -- for an alternative data center.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 28 about the passage of a broad trade package by the House of Representatives referred imprecisely to the timing of the vote cast by Robin Hayes, Republican of North Carolina. Mr. Hayes, who opposed the measure, had told Republican leaders several hours before that he intended to vote no, according to aides. He did not wait until the final seconds to see if the Republicans needed his support in the vote, which was 215 to 212. The congressman's office asked in mid-August for a clarification, but the request was e-mailed to a vacationing reporter.

description: TIMOTHY C. MCDONOUGH is looking forward to firing himself. Not a typical attitude for someone just named to an executive position, but in Mr. McDonough's mind, it makes sense.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Brazilian State Battles Crime in High Places
description: Its murder rate is higher than Colombia's, drug trafficking is flourishing, the central government is dithering and just recently a bomb exploded inside the local bar association. So it is hardly surprising that people here have begun referring to their city as ''the Medelln of Brazil.''

title: Sept. 1-7: INTERNATIONAL; TYPHOON LASHES KOREA
description: A powerful typhoon swept across the Korean peninsula, first smashing the southern island of Cheju, then the harbor and industrial complex at Pusan on the southeast coast, blasting ports, factories and farmland before blowing out to sea. By week's end, rescue workers had found 120 bodies, with scores more missing. Damage estimates from Typhoon Rusa, South Korea's worst storm since 1959, have soared well above $2 billion. Don Kirk

title: No Rest for the Hopeful as Florida Primary for Governor Nears
description: With polls showing them in a near dead heat, Janet Reno and Bill McBride charged into a final weekend of hand-shaking and speech-making before the Democratic primary on Tuesday to determine which will take on Gov. Jeb Bush in November.

title: Old Recordings Make a New Mix
description: THERE are enough musical instruments in Nicholas Brooke's small apartment to equip a sizable -- albeit motley -- orchestra. But the 33-year-old composer and Princeton University music graduate student is mostly preoccupied these days with recorded music, specifically a 1915 Victrola, one of the first phonographs manufactured.

title: NEW SUPERFUND SITES
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency last week placed three New Jersey locations to the Superfund federal hazardous water clean-up program, making 115 sites total, more than any other state. They are the former Atlantic Resources Corporation industrial site in Sayreville, the Quanta Resources Inc. oil and coal tar storage site in Edgewater and the Diamond Head oil refinery in Kearney. John Holl

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 25 with a review of ''Centaur: The Life and Art of Ernst Neizvestny,'' misstated the location of the Siberian town of Magadan, where a monument by Neizvestny honors the victims of the gulag. It is in eastern Siberia, not western.

title: Minimalism With Sweep
description: IT promises to be an exciting season for admirers of the Minimalist school, or whatever one is supposed to call it now that the music also has a neo-Romantic sweep.

title: The Jets' Defense Needs an Introduction
description: There will come a time in the season opener at Buffalo today, perhaps as he peers into Eric Moulds's eyes, when Jets cornerback Aaron Beasley will look over to linebacker Sam Cowart and yell ''In!''

title: For 11 States, a Close Eye on High-Profile Primaries
description: In the biggest burst of primaries of the election season, voters in 11 states will choose candidates for Congress, Senate and governor on Tuesday in contests that could determine the political future of Janet Reno, the former attorney general, and Senator Robert C. Smith, the New Hampshire Republican who is facing an intense challenge from within his own party.

title: War of Secrets: Judicial Restraint; The Imperial Presidency vs. the Imperial Judiciary
description: IN its aggressive conduct of the war on terrorism's domestic front, the Bush administration has encountered few obstacles from Congress or public opinion. Rather, it is federal judges, across the ideological spectrum, who have responded with skepticism, alarm or downright hostility in recent weeks to the administration's sweeping claims of unbridled executive authority to hold secret deportation hearings, label and incarcerate ''enemy combatants'' without access to lawyers or judges, and commingle activities of counterintelligence agents and criminal prosecutors.

title: Lyle Humphrey, Patrick Johnson
description: Jacqueline Lyle Humphrey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Ben Humphrey of Greensboro, N.C., was married there yesterday to Patrick Joseph Johnson, the son of Mary Jo Adams Johnson of Alexandria, Va., and Oscar Mecklin Johnson of St. Petersburg, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Sidney Franklin Batts performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church and the Rev. Richard W. Turner, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: When Nomads Paused to Be Brilliant
description: THE Metropolitan Museum of Art is about to add significant information to our knowledge of the bold and beautiful tribal art of ancient Eurasia. In ''Nomadic Art of the Eastern Eurasian Steppes: The Eugene V. Thaw and Other New York Collections,'' opening Oct. 1, artifacts in bronze, gold, silver and jade reveal a little-known pastoral side of the ancient tribal peoples of north China and Mongolia.

title: TV fame is fleeting. Does anyone recall O-Town?
description: VIC DAMONE watched ''American Idol,'' and here is what he thought: Sigh.

description: Just when the world has learned to pronounce his name, he's changing it.

title: Get Out Your Handkerchiefs
description: THAT anyone would dare make a film -- much less a star-studded mainstream one -- based on ''The Hours,'' Michael Cunningham's delicate fictional homage to Virginia Woolf's ''Mrs. Dalloway,'' is almost unimaginable. Mr. Cunningham's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, written in a refined Woolfian style, explores the thoughts of three women in different eras, all confronting death and the possibility of suicide. One of them is Woolf herself (played by Nicole Kidman), on the day of her suicide in 1941. Advance word has it that Ms. Kidman, in prosthetic makeup, virtually becomes the author's physical double.

title: Melissa Modarressi, Hewett Woodward
description: Melissa Tracy Modarressi, the daughter of Maryam Ashari Edelman of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and Dr. Ahmed Modarressi of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Hewett Griggs Woodward, a son of Sara and Thomas Aiken Woodward of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Before Barbie, There Was Shirley Temple
description: WHEN Suzanne Kraus-Mancuso helped her paternal grandmother run her doll hospital in 1973, one out of every five dolls that needed mending was a Shirley Temple doll. Ever since then, she has known that doll restoration, collecting and Shirley Temple were destined to be parts of her future.

description: FOR all the resources American agents are devoting to watching the myriad tentacles of Al Qaeda, one of the things they have been forced to consider is that Al Qaeda may be watching them.

description: BELLIZZI - Ronald Patrick. On September 6, 2002. A true artist, strong in character, gentle in manner and brave in heart. Survived by his beloved wife Linda, his loving daughters Jennifer and Heather, and his dear mother-in-law and father-in-law, Barbara and Dewain Robinson. Family will receive friends Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Williams Funeral Home, Inc, 5628 Broadway at 232 St, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Gabriel's Church, Tuesday, 10 AM. Entombment Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

title: War of Secrets; Of Hiding And Seeking
description: IT probably wasn't very long after human beings developed language that they began telling secrets. And this was surely followed by the need to keep one's secrets safe from the prying of interlopers (who operate in secret, of course).

title: War of Secrets; When Playing the Field, the Game Gets Rough
description: THE conventional wisdom about what is troubling American intelligence, particularly human intelligence -- the stuff spies do -- is that the system is broken; that on Sept. 11 the Central Intelligence Agency just did not have enough language-qualified spy handlers on the ground around the world to do the job.

title: Too Quietly, a New Shelter Comes to the Neighborhood
description: The day before the city's Department of Homeless Services turned the Skyway Motel on Ditmars Boulevard into a residence for 49 homeless families, it alerted Queens officials about its intentions. By then, Aug. 19, it was too late to stop or even modify the plan. But that is what Helen Marshall, the Queens borough president, and other officials said they wished to do.

title: Hotel, Conference Center Planned for Yonkers Site
description: Forest City Ratner Company has agreed to invest more than $400 million to develop Ridge Hill, an 84-acre tract of state-owned land in Yonkers along the New York State Thruway, according to Yonkers officials. The development is expected to bring 4,300 jobs to the region and to produce nearly $50 million in tax revenue, officials said.

title: Once Mayor of a Wounded City, Reflecting on the Hard, Dark Days
description: There is no right way to observe the Sept. 11 anniversary, advises former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. ''My advice is, the way you want to do it is the right way to do it,'' he said at a news conference on Wednesday. ''You have to let people do these things on their own. There is no one way to mourn.'' (Journalists agreed not to report his comments until today.)

title: Deposit Another 50 Cents, Please. Many Subway Phones Don't Work.
description: Nearly one in three pay phones in the city's subway stations do not work, according to a recent report by the Straphangers Campaign, a transit advocacy group. That is a striking deterioration in service from last year, when the group found that only one in five telephones did not work.

title: With Many Candidates, Primary for West Side Assembly Seat Becomes a Spirited Race
description: One candidate is a former costume designer for Broadway shows, and another was once a television cameraman. One candidate is the brother of a famous talk show host and comedian, while another is a proctor for exams given to police officers. Yet another is a 20-year-old student who says he is working on his high school diploma.

title: Executive Life; Can a Test Gauge the Value of an M.B.A.?
description: ROB FREYTAG, a part-time M.B.A. student at DePaul University in Chicago, believes that hard-to-measure qualities like a well-rounded personality are more important in landing a management job these days than getting the right answers on some standardized test. Nevertheless, he plans to be one of the first to sign up for a new M.B.A. certification exam that he hopes will narrow the competitive edge enjoyed by students at name schools like Harvard and Wharton.

title: INVESTING WITH/Brian Matthews; Payden Core Bond Fund
description: BRIAN MATTHEWS, lead manager of the $250 million Payden Core Bond fund, describes himself as an old-fashioned bond manager.

description: Deirdre Christine Whelan, a daughter of Dr. Margaret Whelan and Patrick Whelan of Long Beach, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Matthew Thomas Del Negro, a son of Ernesta Del Negro of Somers, N.Y., and Arthur Del Negro Jr. of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Neil O'Connell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Martyr.

description: Alisting of Sept. 11 anniversary events yesterday misstated the location for a concert on Wednesday in memory of the Rev. Mychal Judge and other victims. It is scheduled for 7:30 p.m. at the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West 31st Street in Manhattan, not at the Church of St. Francis of Assisi on Maple Street in Brooklyn.

title: Armstrong Will Skip Race in Belgium
description: Lance Armstrong, the four-time winner of the Tour de France, will not compete in the world championship race at Zolder in Belgium on Oct. 8 to 13, Johan Bruyneel, director of the United States Postal Service team, said.

title: Two Months of Treats At Restaurants on the Hudson
description: The Historic Towns of Westchester, a consortium of 13 municipalities along the Hudson River, are proud of their restaurants, so they created the Hudson Heritage ''Feastival,'' a two-month celebration of food and dining.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Aug. 25 showing profits made by companies' insiders on the sale of telecommunications stocks in the last three and a half years included two names erroneously. Paul D. Carbery and Dino J. Vendetti, former board members of Allegiance Telecom, did not profit personally from the listed sales of its stock; they acted only as representatives of investment firms that sold Allegiance shares. As a result, their names appeared on the federal stock-sale forms used by Thomson Financial, a research company, to compile the data.

title: Allison Ross, J. Matthew Hanna
description: Allison Virginia Ross and J. Matthew Hanna were married yesterday at the National Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated, and the Rev. Christopher J. Devron, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Harold E. Masback III, a Congregational minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Things That Go Missing: Money, Persons, Clues
description: GIVEN a choice between the season's two biggest trends -- gloopy nostalgia and slick crime-solving -- go for the crime wave.

title: Slings and Arrows, Whispers and Grumbles
description: TO hear most people describe the Senate race in New Jersey, it is just another facet of the annual rite of fall. But the slash-and-burn campaign about to be inflicted on voters has several provocative sidelights that would ordinarily be confined to the tightest of political circles.

title: Poll Finds Unease on Terror Fight And Concerns About War on Iraq
description: Americans increasingly doubt that their government has done enough to protect them against terrorist attacks and are convinced, despite misgivings, that there will be a war against Iraq, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows. Majorities do not want war without Congressional and allied support first and a clear explanation from President Bush.

title: Introduction
description: Rebecca Johnson's account of her traumatic pregnancy -- and of her son's losing fight for life -- prompted an overwhelming response. Readers said it held them riveted even as it moved them to tears. Our report on walrus shoots, on the other hand, prompted many to declare open season on the big-game hunter featured.

title: Lido Palace Wins Woodward
description: NEW YORK (AP), Sept. 7  Lido Palace loves the Woodward Stakes.

title: A Forecast for Uncertainty
description: Robert J. Shiller, the Yale economics professor who coined the phrase ''irrational exuberance'' in the stock market bubble, has been monitoring a decline in investor confidence this year.

title: Australia Casts Net for Fish Poachers
description: Australia has begun a campaign against international pirates plundering its declining stocks of Antarctic fish.

title: Once More Into the Sudan, Once More the Balderdash
description: AMID grave warnings that our world has changed forever, that America has grown up, that Islam is now to be taken very seriously, it may be some small comfort to born cavalrymen and their ladies that Hollywood cannot keep itself from going back to the preposterous racist folderol and high entertainment known as ''The Four Feathers.''

title: Personal Business; As Portfolios Shrink, Retirees Warily Seek Work
description: MOST of the patients seeking help at the SLS Wellness Center in Brewster, N.Y., suffer from addictions or behavioral or psychological disorders. But lately, Dr. Michael Nuccitelli, the executive director of the clinic, has been seeing a steady number of job seekers, particularly former retirees who have had to go back to work because of financial reversals. Many of them, he says, are looking for ways to improve their memories and stamina so that they can better compete in the workplace.

title: U.S. SAYS HUSSEIN INTENSIFIES QUEST FOR A-BOMB PARTS
description: More than a decade after Saddam Hussein agreed to give up weapons of mass destruction, Iraq has stepped up its quest for nuclear weapons and has embarked on a worldwide hunt for materials to make an atomic bomb, Bush administration officials said today.

title: Sept. 1-7: NATIONAL; CUOMO WITHDRAWS
description: Andrew M. Cuomo pulled out of the race for the Democratic nomination for governor of New York with just one week to go before the primary, avoiding a near-certain defeat at the hands of his opponent, H. Carl McCall, the first black candidate with a viable shot at the governorship. Mr. McCall will now face Republican Gov. George E. Pataki in the general election. Shaila K. Dewan

title: War of Secrets; Eyes in the Sky, Ears to the Wall, and Still Wanting
description: ON Oct. 4, 2001, less than a month after terrorists attacked the Pentagon and World Trade Center, a news bulletin sent fresh chills throughout much of the world. A jetliner packed with Israeli tourists exploded high above the Black Sea several hours after taking off from Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion airport, killing all 78 people aboard. Immediately, sabotage or a suicide bombing related to the Sept. 11 attacks was suspected, and Israeli officials refused to rule out the possibility of ''a terrorist act.''

title: Leslie Miller, Alicia Salzer
description: Dr. Leslie Jennifer Miller and Dr. Alicia Jana Salzer affirmed their partnership yesterday in a commitment ceremony on Fire Island. The ceremony was led by Ellen Landress-Bowkett, a nondenominational spiritual counselor.

title: The Height of Ambition
description: Guy Tozzoli guided his black Mercedes sedan past a jumble of swaybacked old warehouses and manicured condominium developments on the back streets of Hoboken, N.J., winding his way toward the Holland Tunnel. Over the years he had figured out how to cut to the front of the 10-block line of traffic in front of the tunnel, shaving a few minutes off his journey to Lower Manhattan from his home in Bergen County. Tozzoli firmly believed that there was a work-around for every problem; his daily commute was no exception. His shortcut took him down Jersey Avenue, under a rusty train bridge and straight into the Holland Tunnel plaza near the tollbooths.

title: A Machine Inspires A Break With Dcor
description: A BRIGHT red George Foreman grill sits on the counter of Liz Lange's kitchen -- a cheerful, chubby sentry amid the gleaming white marble surfaces and stylized 1930's French dcor. ''Isn't it fabulous?'' said Ms. Lange, a designer who is a pioneer of high-end clothes for pregnant women. ''It's the chicest appliance I own.''

title: Editorial Observer; 9/11/00: Air Congestion, a Hot Enron and Unhung Chads
description: On Sept. 11, Al Gore told Oprah Winfrey and her seven million viewers that Wheaties was his favorite cereal. Elsewhere in Chicago, Aubrey Harvey Jr., a 51-year-old supervisor with Argenbright Security who served at Chicago O'Hare's United terminal, was being feted. He'd just been named the Federal Aviation Administration's National Screener of the Year.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Upscale Apartment Communities for Older Renters
description: THE next generation of so-called active adults -- baby boomers now 38 to 56 -- is a highly diverse group that will seek all sorts of lifestyles in its retirement years, demographers say. Naturally, developers are interested in producing housing to suit any and all of them. title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: AUSTERLITZ, by W. G. Sebald. (Modern Library, $13.95.) Before Sebald's death in a car accident last December, the editors of the Book Review named this elegiac novel, a dreamlike meditation on the moral treachery of memory, one of the best books of 2001, and last spring it won a National Book Critics Circle award. It tells of an architectural historian who learns in his 50's that his parents sent him to Britain from Central Europe at the age of 4 to escape the Nazis, a discovery that leads him to revisit his family's terrible past and reclaim his spiritual heritage. ''Sebald stands with Primo Levi as the prime speaker of the Holocaust and, with him, the prime contradiction of Adorno's dictum that after it, there can be no art,'' Richard Eder wrote in these pages.

title: Sept. 1-7: NATIONAL; BUSH JUDGE REJECTED

The committee's Democrats used their 10 to 9 majority to defeat the nomination of Priscilla Owen to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. It was Mr. Bush's second defeat in a judicial confirmation fight. Democrats complained that Ms. Owen, like the other defeated nominee, Charles W. Pickering, exemplified Mr. Bush's efforts to pack the courts with conservatives. Mr. Bush said the Owen defeat was ''bad for the country and bad for our bench.'' Neil A. Lewis

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCHER, ROBERT IRWIN
description: DEUTSCHER-Robert Irwin, was a highly repected trial lawyer who combined his professional life and philanthropy with his love of music and opera, creating a lasting legacy in each area of his life. Mr. Deutscher, a resident of Seattle and Gig Harbor, Washington, died Thursday, September 5, 2002, following a brief illness. Mr. Deutscher was born in New York City on March 3, 1943, to Eugene and Evelyn Deutscher. Mr. Deutscher created his own highly respected and successful law firm in 1985, located in Tacoma, Washington, and was widely acknowledged and recognized as a national leader in the area of tort law and medical malpractice. Mr. Deutscher was a well-known figure in both Seattle and Tacoma, known for his graciousness, wit, and generosity of spirit, which combined with impeccable sense of style and taste. Mr. Deutscher is survived by his wife and law partner, Ann; his stepsons Charles and Robert Truxal; his mother Evelyn Halbreich of Aventura, Florida; his son John Deutscher; his daughter Stacey Purdue; and his sister Lois Rubin of Olney, Maryland. Mr. Deutscher is also survived by four grandchildren, Katie, Claire, Lexi and Sarah, whom he dearly loved. Funeral service Monday, September 9, 2002, noon, Butterworth-Arthur Wright Chapel, 520 West Raye, Queen Anne, Seattle, 206-282-5500. Interment at Hills of Eternity Cemetery. Memorial contribution may be given to the University of Washington Medical Center, Heart Transplantation Program.

title: What Would Orwell Do?
description: Christopher Hitchens is a prolific and clubbable political columnist known mainly in news media circles, before Sept. 11, as a left-wing Clinton hater. After Sept. 11 he assumed the larger role of conscience of the left. His job was to castigate those who opposed the war in Afghanistan and claimed that America got what it deserved. Hitchens was so good at this -- so forceful and ubiquitous -- that The New York Observer's Ron Rosenbaum called him a George Orwell for our time. (Rosenbaum called Andrew Sullivan another.) With impeccable timing, Hitchens then released an extended essay called ''Why Orwell Matters,'' published in England this summer and coming out here next month.
