Good Shepherd Hospice, 528 Mineola Avenue, Carle Place 11514 or a charity of your choice would be greatly appreciated.

title: UNHELPFUL COMPANIES
description: A survey by the State Department of Banking and Insurance found that automobile insurance companies were often unhelpful and rude when dealing with customers on the phone. The survey, which does not name specific companies and has not been released to the public, was conducted by the acting insurance ombudsman, Anne Marie Narcini, and her staff over the summer. It found that many of the companies would not provide information like phone numbers and office locations and that some companies gave incorrect information concerning their obligations under state law. Assistant Commissioner Mary Caffrey said another survey would be taken this fall and that names of companies that did not improve customer service would be released to the public. John Holl

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Great Neck; Great Site for Schools, Parks and Trains
description: ON the north shore of Long Island in Nassau County, Great Neck is a place name that carries a high reputation, and this effect is reflected in the village of Great Neck.

title: In Defense of the Men
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: Numbers Look Better, but Markets See the Worst
description: THE stock market is still in the doldrums. But economic data are looking a lot better and may mean that the summer slow-growth scare, which sent stocks to a five-year low, is over.

title: Karzai, Under Heavy U.S. Guard, Travels to Honor Assassinated Resistance Leader
description: Less than 48 hours after surviving an assassination attempt President Hamid Karzai, traveled under heavy American guard today to pray at the mausoleum of the assassinated resistance leader Ahmed Shah Massoud.

title: From Cuomo And McCall, Vague Plans For Unity
description: Andrew M. Cuomo did not quite agree to trumpet the virtues of H. Carl McCall, the man who drove him out of the contest for the Democratic nomination for governor.

title: Hearst Predicts Davis Will Make Comeback
description: It is Garrison Hearst's faith in himself and in his friend that leads him to predict that Denver Broncos running back Terrell Davis will one day make a return to the football field. Hearst, the San Francisco 49ers' starting running back, missed two seasons when the bones in his broken ankle needed many operations and thousands of hours of rehabilitation before he returned to rush for 1,206 yards last season.

title: An Earlier Showbill
description: To the Editor:

title: A Boat Without a Paddle? Worse. No Parking Place.
description: Tori Gilbert's search for a parking space is more quixotic than most.

title: A PATH Expansion Plan Commuters Might Like but Some Neighbors Don't
description: Peter Nadin, a longtime Greenwich Village resident, still doesn't want the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to expand the PATH stations at Ninth and Christopher Streets. But he is a notch happier than he was.

title: Taking 'Treasure Island' Into Space And Animation Onto the Imax Screen
description: Disney is hoisting the Jolly Roger and giving Captain Long John Silver another ship. A spaceship. The newest animated feature from the Disney studio sets Robert Louis Stevenson's classic novel ''Treasure Island'' among buccaneering space travelers and replaces Long John's quaint wooden leg with an up-to-the-minute, 3-D spare part borrowed from a cyborg.

title: Kenseth Captures Monte Carlo 400
description: Matt Kenseth rallied to get laps back twice in the early going and dominated last night, outrunning everyone to win the Nascar Monte Carlo 400 in Richmond for his series-high fourth victory of the year.

title: Leslie Dottor, Antony Kerz
description: Leslie Ann Dottor, the daughter of Joan and Livio Dottor of Kensington, Conn., was married on Friday to Antony Leo Kerz, a son of Louise Kerz Hirschfeld of New York and the late Leo Kerz. The Rev. Conrad Strauch, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bridegroom's mother and stepfather, Al Hirschfeld, the artist and caricaturist, in New York.

title: Holding On to Luke
description: In 1935, my mother had pre-eclampsia; my sister lived. In 1955, I had pre-eclampsia; my daughter is alive. But knowledge is about as limited today as it was then. Treatment, then and now, includes bed rest, restricted diet and Epsom salts or diuretics. Not much progress has been made in the past 67 years. We still do not know what causes pre-eclampsia and have no new methods of treatment. Why?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HACK, YETTA
description: HACK-Yetta. Suddenly, on September 4, 2002 in Rome, Italy. Beloved wife of the late Leonard, loving mother of Stuart and his wife Diann, devoted grandmother of Leah and Corey, dear sister of Rosalyn Buchsbaum. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Parkside'', 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: A Regulator as Educator (and Entertainer)
description: ARTHUR LEVITT may never eat lunch on Wall Street again. Or on Capitol Hill, either. But Mr. Levitt, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, should be able to enjoy at least a cup of coffee on any Main Street in America if enough investors read his lively and illuminating new book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, MILTON
description: HOROWITZ - Milton. Uncle Miltie, you will be missed. Your humor, your kindness, your wisdom, your love-you will missed. Kathy, Warren, Sarah and Emily Nadel

title: Asheville
description: Asheville, N.C., is experiencing a boom not seen since the 1920's, when Thomas Edison and Henry Ford enjoyed good hotels set in some of the highest mountains on the East Coast. Part of this city of 68,000 people looks much as it did in that early heyday: downtown boasts more than 170 vintage buildings, including a stock of distinctive Art Deco and Gothic Revival structures.

title: Light From the East
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than Pizza. Art.
description: Pizza, it sometimes seems, makes the city go round. Here are some notable pizza places, on and off the beaten track.

title: A Campaign to Remember, Or Is It Best Forgotten?
description: Welcome back to work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALLECK, LEONARD C.
description: SHALLECK-Leonard C. On September 5, 2002. Beloved husband of Kalia. Loving father of Jimmy and Sheila. Dear brother of Alan, Lynn and Charles Shalleck. Adoring grandfather of Jason and Lauren. Respected matrimonial attorney. Member of the Friars Club. Board Member of the Sutton Place Synagogue. Service Monday 12 noon at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, New York City.

title: Flaunt Them, but Careful on the Court
description: Tennis bracelets, anyone? Named in honor of the diamond bracelet that Chris Evert lost during a 1987 United States Open match (she stopped the game until she found it), these glittering baubles are back in the swing -- as seen on the famous wrists of Natalie Portman, Halle Berry and Jennifer Lopez.

title: Will ID Checks Keep the Voters Away?
description: To the Editor:

title: Singers Present And Oddly Absent
description: IN any season, there are the ''important'' events, the premieres and the happenings. Then there are the individual performances you treasure in hindsight like jewels against the velvet of passing winter nights. The events I anticipate most this season are vocal performances that promise to resonate.

title: Commercial Property/Westchester; Signs of an Upturn in Downtown White Plains
description: FOR two decades, Leon Silverman, the owner of 300,000 square feet of downtown retail and office space here, watched helplessly as many property values plummeted. After some of the larger stores migrated to malls in the 1980's and 1990's, many of the smaller merchants in the heart of the downtown shuttered their businesses. By the late 1990's, the area of the city that was once known as Little Fifth Avenue barely resembled the one Mr. Silverman first invested in 30 years earlier.

title: Gazeteer
description: 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath colonial at 35 Cary Road, $599,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, ERNA
description: RUBIN-Erna. On September 5th, 2002, of Glen Cove, Long Island, formerly of Flushing, NY. Beloved wife of the late Theodore. Devoted mother of Shulamith Kane and Lewis Rubin. Adored grandmother of Nicole, Rebecca & Lauren. Cherished great grandmother of Matthew. Services on Monday 1 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI. Contributions may be directed to the American Heart Association.

title: After the 'Darkest Year,' a Changed Wall St.
description: PHILIP J. PURCELL, the chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley, still chokes up when he talks about the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. His eyes grew misty last week, during an interview in his Times Square office, as he recounted how he had watched on television as a jumbo jet smashed into 2 World Trade Center, where 2,700 Morgan Stanley employees had worked. Seven of them, along with six consultants to Morgan, died that day.

title: Late-Summer Ritual: Crabbing on the Hudson
description: ''Watch it, they really hurt,'' my 11-year-old son said.

title: She Breaks the Rule That Says Actresses Can't Age
description: IN a new comedy called ''The Banger Sisters,'' Susan Sarandon plays a former rock 'n' roll groupie named Lavinia, now a terminally respectable Phoenix matron whose condescending teenage daughters and politically ambitious husband are unaware of her sizzling past. Until, that is, her old partner in naughtiness, Suzette (a raffish-looking Goldie Hawn), turns up to touch her for a loan but, seeing a need greater than her own, gets busy liberating Lavinia from all that soul-killing self-effacement.

title: Idol Returns, Her Image Remade
description: IT'S been three years since Christina Aguilera released her first album, a self-titled disc that sold eight million copies. The album established her as a teen-pop star, a first-rate diva, a sex symbol and, acording to one list, one of the country's worst dressed celebrities. She insists that the long wait for the follow-up album may turn out to be a blessing in disguise. ''I wanted to get out of the spotlight and let people forget a little bit of the old image,'' she said.

title: Seeking What Lies Beneath
description: ON the southern edge of Cold Spring stands a strange forest. Tall trees have grown around rusty iron clamps, weathered rods poke up from the dirt, felled oaks have bricks tangled within their roots and the steep hillsides are held in place with boulder-size stone walls. It is all that remains of the West Point Foundry, a huge industrial complex that helped fuel American industry for almost 100 years.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Robin Laidlaw, Jonathan Lincoln
description: Robin Welch Laidlaw, a daughter of Amy and Robert Laidlaw of Groton Long Point, Conn., was married there last evening to Jonathan Seabury Lincoln, the son of Pamela and Jeffrey Lincoln of Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Richard S. Monkman, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Duty Free
description: The judge was old, stern and irritable. I was 31, dressed conservatively for me (tattoo covered), and trying to look appropriate (though I'm not sure what that means). Marty, my lawyer, stood beside me. He was a friend, a man my son, Henry, has considered a father figure since he turned 2, when his real dad, Michael, moved out. Marty was the casual acquaintance of the roommate I temporarily got to help with rent in Michael's absence, until I found out he was a heroin addict; Marty liked us enough to stick around long after Smack split.

title: A Library Of the Web, On the Web
description: IT'S called the Wayback Machine, and as far as the Internet is concerned, that's what it allows a seeker of information to do -- go way back, to the dawn of the World Wide Web, to the tune of billions of Web pages of online information, and at no charge.

title: Private Sector; Revving Up the Labs at Pfizer
description: DR. PETER B. CORR, the new research chief at Pfizer, says he lives by the 80-20 rule.

title: Bearing Gifts of the New
description: MORE of the same is exactly what the San Francisco Ballet and the French modern-dance troupe Ballet Preljocaj are not bringing to New York this fall. Even in a dance season studded with premieres, the San Francisco Ballet and Angelin Preljocaj's group stand out, with an accent on creativity and musical experiment.

title: Wanted: Unclaimed Words
description: Thousands of products and services are introduced every year, and each needs a recognizable name. An online survey of 218 marketers from several industries found that 57 percent preferred authentic-sounding names, but that 60 percent of the respondents had to seek outside help to come up with names because most had already been taken. In the English language alone, there are more than six million words, and virtually all of them are registered, said Julie Cottineau, a managing director at Interbrand, a brand consulting company, which conducted the survey this summer.

title: Future of French Tennis in Focus
description: France's Richard Gasquet has the look of any 16-year-old who has just grown to 5 feet 11, his 157 pounds stretched to new, not entirely comfortable proportions. He accentuates the look with a backward baseball cap and an attention span that wanders visibly even during tennis matches.

title: A Healing Economy?
description: Widespread fears after Sept. 11 that the economy would fall into deep recession have not been realized. Instead, a mild recession appears to have ended near the end of last year, thanks largely to the resilience of consumers and a surge in government spending. But growth remains meager, with businesses reluctant to invest in new equipment, and a few sectors, including airlines, still suffering greatly.

title: Another Essential Attraction Sojourns in Queens
description: Queens is the place to be at the moment, and another important piece of the art action goes into play there this month when the Museum for African Art opens headquarters in Long Island City, two blocks from MOMA Queens.

title: Holding On to Luke
description: I too had early onset, fulminant pre-eclampsia and none of the risk factors

title: Artful Murders
description: Q: You've been an artist for more than 20 years. This fall you have two shows, plus a novel about a serial killer in the art world, ''The Death Artist,'' that has just come out. What inspired you to write the book?

title: Sept. 1-7: NATIONAL; SHAPE UP!
description: Americans need to exercise more -- a lot more -- in order to stay healthy and maintain a normal body weight, according to new guidelines from the Institute of Medicine. A panel of of 21 experts suggested that people exercise a minimum of one hour a day, twice as much as previously recommended, and that adults get 45 percent to 65 percent of their daily calories from carbohydrates. They recommended a maximum of 25 percent of calories from added sugars, 20-35 percent from fats and 10-35 percent from protein. Bon apptit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, DR. ARNOLD
description: HOROWITZ-Dr. Arnold. Of Tamarac, FL, unexpectedly on September 3, 2002. A compassionate practicing physician for 40 years. Adored husband of Louise. Beloved father of Mavis, Diane and Eve and stepchildren Sandy, Mark, Cheryl. Loving fatherin-law of The Three Michaels, brother Bill and his wife Sandy, and brother-in-law of Karen and Marty. Cherished grandfather of Charlie, Nicole, Julia, Joshua, Paige, Ianna, Ian and Jacquie, as well as many nieces, nephews and friends. Funeral services were held on September 6.

title: Informality Takes the Reins at the Hampton Classic
description: Last Sunday at the Hampton Classic Grand Prix in Bridgehampton, N.Y., benefit-lunch tables surrounded three sides of the jumping ring. The style of the lunch guests has evolved from the spectacle of ascot-style dressing popular in the early 1990's to a stylish informality that suggests a luxury dude ranch. Sweaters and jackets bearing horse motifs were in evidence, along with cowboy hats and denim jeans and, at one table, Mexican sombreros replaced fancy millenary. The day's cool weather and a threat of rain helped contribute to the change in dress.

title: Stravinsky Meets Jazz, for Fun's Sake
description: Don Byron's annual concert series at Symphony Space in Manhattan is called ''Contrasting Brilliance,'' which is a fitting rubric for his work as a jazz musician and composer. Every year or so, it seems, he has a new project exploring various styles of music in an intense, cerebral manner, be it klezmer, Latin jazz, funk or German lieder.

title: Men Who Step Up to the Scale and Crow
description: AT least since the young and beautiful Lily Bart fretted about maintaining a slender physique in Edith Wharton's 1905 novel ''The House of Mirth,'' discussing dieting has been a woman's thing.

title: Ah, the Hamptons, Home of Martinis, Models and . . . Boxing?
description: THEY held a fight and a cocktail party broke out.

title: A British Designer Elbows In
description: CALVIN KLEIN -- tanned, dressed in gray, his cropped hair at attention -- surveyed the crowd that had gathered Thursday night in his boutique on Madison Avenue, for a cocktail party to benefit American Ballet Theater. Marianne Faithfull, on tour with her new album, was there. So were Blaine Trump, Diane Von Furstenberg and her husband, Barry Diller, who, on seeing Kelly Klein, remarked with surprise, ''You've grown taller.''

title: Volume Control
description: Recently my future son-in-law, an electronics expert, adjusted my sound system. The result was a piercingly accurate rendition of jazz recordings, symphonies and action-adventure cable movies, as well as several noise complaints from neighbors. When the police arrived for the second time, I demanded the name of the complainant, but the policeman refused to provide it. Don't I have the right to face my accuser? David Graham Halliday, Naugatuck, Conn.

title: Life in the Hamptons, According to Rivers
description: Larry Rivers, who died at his Southampton home on Aug. 14, three days short of his 79th birthday, lived and worked in the Hamptons for more than half a century. A quintessential iconoclast, he chronicled aspects of his singular life in a 1992 memoir, ''What Did I Do? The Unauthorized Autobiography'' (Harper Collins), written with his longtime friend, the playwright and lyricist Arnold Weinstein.

title: Sept. 1-7: INTERNATIONAL; KARZAI ESCAPES DEATH
description: For months, it has been the nightmare of just about everyone who knows him: Hamid Karzai, the Pashtun tribal leader chosen by the United States to lead Afghanistan to democracy, being gunned down while pushing into a crowd or leaning through the window of his car in a crowded street. When the moment came in Kandahar, Mr. Karzai was lucky: a gunman with purported Taliban links opened fire at the Afghan leader's vehicle from 30 feet, but was tackled to the ground after narrowly missing with his first two shots. He was then shot dead by bodyguards from the American Special Forces. John F. Burns

title: Anne Carey, Michael Kelly
description: Anne Dix Carey, a stock sales assistant, was married on Friday to Ernest Michael Kelly, the deputy director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Office of Ocean Exploration in Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. Morley Frech, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Four Seasons Resort Maui in Wailea, Hawaii.

title: Who's Next At the Fed? A Look At the Field
description: ALAN GREENSPAN has just completed 15 years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, and at 76 he is still going strong. His current term, his fourth, runs until June 2004, and he could very well be appointed to a fifth if he feels up to it.

title: Rachel Zimmerman, Seth Teller
description: Rachel Marya Zimmerman, the daughter of Selma Zimmerman and Robert L. Zimmerman, both of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Seth Jared Teller, a son of Joan Teller and Judge Samuel H. Teller of Bolton, Conn. The wedding will be held at the Crosby Mansion, an 1888 house in Brewster, Mass., and will be led by Anne Reifenberg, a friend of the bride, who has been granted permission by Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Here a New Museum, There a New Museum
description: September

title: Where Service Is Keen and Pastas Fresh
description: THE sparkle of pin lights marks the entrance to Tre Angelina, lodged in a narrow storefront space. The restaurant lacks architectural advantage, but its new ownership has redecorated , and has wisely drawn attention to its other assets.

title: ATP Approves Testing For E.P.O.
description: Not all players on the ATP Tour marvel at an opponent who can play five sets with an indefatigable bounce in his step, particularly when that same player looks as fresh as a new coat of paint by the next afternoon.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 8, 2002
description: Weeks

title: The Search Is On For a Mind Most Beautiful
description: Wanted: Earthshaking genius with the leadership of a conductor, the charisma of a matador. Noble profile, interest in history, mathematics, social and natural sciences helpful.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Aug. 25 with a review of ''Centaur: The Life and Art of Ernst Neizvestny,'' misstated the location of the Siberian town of Magadan, where a monument by Neizvestny honors the victims of the gulag. It is in eastern Siberia, not western.

title: A Sampling Of 9/11 Events
description: BROOKVILLE -- C. W. Post University Chorus, Great Neck Choral Society, Master Works Chorus and Long Island Philharmonic Chorus sing Mozart's ''Requiem,'' 8:46 a.m. Wednesday, Tilles Center, C. W. Post Campus, Long Island University. (631) 262-0200.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDBERG, WILLIAM ERIC
description: GOLDBERG-William Eric. Jan. 2, 1971 to Sept. 7, 2000. Today marks two years since you left us. We miss your smile, your laughter and your unending support. You are forever in our hearts and we miss you every minute of every day. You are our angelplease watch over us. Love, Mom

title: Designing in the Dark Workshop of the Soul
description: PRAY for Steven Holl. He's chosen to make architecture in the most difficult way imaginable. Guided mainly by intuition, Holl descends into the darker recesses of his inner world to find architecture. Usually, he comes back with light.

title: Monthly Reader
description: This book of the month club won't include the latest by Stephen King or John Grisham. The September selections include ''The Stray Dog,'' by Marc Simont, and ''Johnny Appleseed,'' by Patricia Demuth, and the audience is children in kindergarten through third grade. The Governor's Book Club was started by Governor McGreevey in support of a campaign pledge to help all third graders become proficient readers, and he is selecting the books. Scholastic Book Clubs will provide copies of the selections to every grade school in the state and to public libraries and the state will set aside $45 million to assign reading coaches to low-performing schools and to train reading teachers. The governor was at Watsessing Elementary School in Bloomfield last week to kick off his club by working with second graders and ''Johnny Appleseed.'' He stayed for more than an hour to read the entire book with the class. Maria Newman

title: Dancers Who Stand Apart
description: THIS is the season of the dancer in all that extraordinary mortal's glory. One performer to watch closely is Marcelo Gomes, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, when that troupe's City Center season opens in October. Mr. Gomes would seem to have it all. He is tall, an increasing rarity among ballet men. He is a sensitive partner and a dancer with an unassuming technical virtuosity.

title: FOR YOUNG VIEWERS
description: CORNELIUS FILLMORE AND Jimmy Neutron lead a parade of animated heroes this week, while Scooby-Doo celebrates a new era and a few other old friends, like the Bear in the Big Blue House and Mr. Rogers, reflect on the anniversary of Sept. 11. Games, quizzes and more information on this week's premieres can be found at www.disney.go.com (Bear and Fillmore), www.kidswb.com (Scooby-Doo) and www. nickjr.com (Jimmy Neutron). Five new public service messages to help young viewers better understand the concept of tribute will be shown during regular broadcasts of ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood'' (Tuesdays and Thursdays at 2:30 p.m. on Channel 13) and on the PBS Web site at www.pbs.org.

title: For Unmarried Mothers, a City of Jobs
description: NEW YORK CITY'S late (and lamented) economic boom appears to have had a suprising group of beneficiaries: single mothers. The proportion of unmarried women with families who held jobs leapt in the late 1990's, at a rate far greater than the national average.

title: Access to Minutes of Co-op Meetings
description: Q. I would like to buy a small one-bedroom apartment in a brownstone co-op on the Upper West Side. The building has 11 apartments, has undergone recent renovations and, from what my lawyer says, the financials look good. The board members all live in the building. The board says it cannot give my lawyer the minutes of board meetings because it has none except for a meeting this May. Is this an actual possibility? What risks am I taking by not reviewing the minutes? May the co-op board sign a document that protects me against such risks? . . . Marianna Malaspina, Manhattan.

title: Tales of the Tube, From Tawdry to Absurd
description: So it's come to this. After all these decades -- after films about world leaders, imperious royals, famous authors, great inventors, brave gladiators, troubled rock stars and even schizophrenic mathematicians -- Hollywood has reached the end of its biographical rope. This season we're down to game-show hosts and old sitcom stars.

title: A Big Game
description: When children tear the wings off butterflies, we counsel them (one hopes) against such behavior. But when adults surround themselves with the severed heads of majestic animals, most people hardly bat an eye. Would anyone want as a friend someone who in his spare time sits at home and studies the ''kill zones'' of different animals? In a bizarre twist, many trophy hunters will even tell you that they ''admire'' the animals they blast to kingdom come. I say to Pete Studwell, Go to the tundras, savannas and forests and take photographs.

title: It Ought to Be a Movie, They Said, and Said . . .
description: SO why did it take 27 years to make a movie of the hit Broadway musical ''Chicago''? With a classy pedigree, a hot, jazzy score and a story crammed with sex, murder and courtroom drama, it seems perfect for the movies. Speculation about who would play the juicy leading roles filled gossip columns for years. But none of the boldface names supposedly attached ever stuck. Was ''Chicago'' destined to remain a movieland bridesmaid but never a bride? Here's the lowdown on who woulda, coulda, shoulda -- and who finally dunnit, and how.

title: Faith Markham, Oscar Sloterbeck
description: Leslie Faith Markham, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. J. Richard Markham of Danville, Va., was married yesterday evening to Oscar Thomas Sloterbeck, a son of Gracey Stoddard Sloterbeck of New York and David P. Sloterbeck Jr. of Weston, Vt. The bride's father, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Feedback on Tennis
description: International Game Is Doing Just Fine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASH, RICHARD M., 71, AKA ''RICARDO PESTANA,''
description: LASH-Richard M., 71, aka ''Ricardo Pestana,'' died August 28 in San Juan, PR, after long illness. Founder of two non-profit organizations and tireless advocate for people with disabilities and their families, especially in low-income communities. Influential in the development of special education and human service systems. Noted for his courage, innovation and irreverent humor. Survived by his loving wife and professional partner, Myrta Cuadra, and by seven children, four stepchildren, fifteen grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Catherine Waite Fowler and Jacob Norman Shapiro referred incorrectly at one point to a parent who is chairwoman of Seer Analytics, a data analysis company in Tampa, Fla. She is the bridegroom's mother, Joan Shapiro; Mary Ann Fowler is the mother of the bride.

title: ATP Approves EPO Testing
description: The ATP Tour board and the Player Council approved changes in their antidoping program this past week to allow more thorough out-of-competition testing and adopted language that will allow testing for EPO, a banned endurance-enhancing substance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, GABRIELE D.
description: SCHIFF-Gabriele D. Selfhelp Community Services, Inc., and United Help, mourn the passing of a devoted staff member of thirty-eight years. Her passionate commitment to services for victims of Nazi persecution inspired everyone with whom she worked.

title: Against the Grain at the Vice Fund
description: Socially responsible investing  the practice of funneling money into companies whose activities are deemed by the investor as good for society  has become increasingly popular.

title: From the Epic to the Jazzy
description: THERE is a tendency among concert presenters simply to latch onto the anniversary of the birth or death of a master composer as a convenient hook for programming. One result, too often, is that audiences just wind up rehearing a lot of well-known repertory.

title: Acceptance
description: In his essay on the Princeton hacking scandal, Walter Kirn (The Way We Live Now, Aug. 25) makes the interesting argument that we are disinclined to look too closely at the Ivy League's murky admissions practices because we need the ''myth'' that the process is truly meritocratic.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Aug. 18 about ''By the Hand of Mormon,'' which examines evidence for and against the Book of Mormon, misstated the prospective date of a coming book, Robert V. Remini's ''Joseph Smith.'' It is scheduled by Lipper/Viking for October, not September.

title: Waiter Who Lost Job on Sept. 11 Struggles to Get By
description: There are days when Sultan A. Salim wishes he had gone to work on Sept. 11. As a catering waiter at Windows on the World he probably would have perished, as surely as his 72 colleagues did, in the inferno and collapse of the World Trade Center.

title: Theater & Dance
Pop, Jazz & Classical
Television & Visual Arts
September and October Releases
November and December Releases
U.S. Open
Jets Stun Bills in Overtime
description: Chad Morton's 96-yard touchdown at the start of overtime led the Jets to a season-opening victory against Buffalo.

title: Venice Journal; Chilling News for Speeders: Traffic Cops Astern
description: A city can post extra signs all over advertising the speed limit, and still motorists ignore it. A city can buy more radar-style guns and assign more men and women to operate them, and still motorists zoom heedlessly from place to place.

title: Mixed Ratings on Saturday
description: The men's semifinals of the United States Open produced sharply higher ratings for CBS on Saturday. Pete Sampras's victory over Sjeng Schalken generated a 3.4 overnight rating, up 48 percent from the Lleyton Hewitt-Yevgeny Kafelnikov match last year. Andre Agassi's victory over No. 1-seeded Hewitt posted a 4.8 rating, up 41 percent from last year, when Sampras defeated Marat Safin.

title: Altered-Food Allergies
description: To the Editor:

title: In Japan, phones make mischief
description: TOKYO  Europe may be anticipating the arrival of the camera-equipped cell phone that lets people swap snapshots over the mobile network, but in Japan, photo-phone use has shown a nasty underbelly.

title: Why So Many Disabled Workers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Locked Up and Patted Down: A Year of Making U.S. Safer
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  Cockpit doors are stronger, but not all cargo is screened for bombs. The directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency now jointly brief the president on terrorist threats, but there are still critical gaps in intelligence gathering and analysis. The Super Bowl has become a superfortress, but the local cineplex remains a soft target. The government issues a rolling rainbow of threat alerts, but Congress and the White House are still battling over the creation of an agency to coordinate security.

title: Lancaster Falls Apart On Final Hole in Canada

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ADRIENNE K.
description: JOHNSON-Adrienne K. 74, died Thursday, September 5, 2002. She was born in New York City and moved to Manhasset, Long Island as a young girl. Her mother was a medical doctor and her father was a pharmacist, chemist, and perfumer, owning several pharmacies. She loved going to Jones Beach and spending weekends with her relatives. She was the oldest of three children, predeceased by her sister Leila Wager and survived by her brother Aldrich Krepela. She attended Hofstra University and Ohio Wesleyan College, where she was a Phi Beta Kappa. She pursued a career as an officer in the U.S. Air Force where she met her true love, James Johnson. They had three children, Adrienne, Helen, and Ken. They traveled throughout Europe and the United States, retiring in south Florida to be near her parents. She enjoyed attending cooking classes and creating gourmet cuisines. She also loved to paint ceramics and was exceptional at creating flowers. She loved gardening and grew a variety of fruit, flowering, and palm trees. She liked to fish and crab for ''blues.'' In later years she became an avid reader and was fondly known as ''Mrs. Webster.'' The daily crossword was but little challenge to her. She loved her grandchildren immensely and they became her focus after the loss of her husband. She had eight: Andrew, Gienah, Robert, Victor, Austin, Conrad, Kaitlyn Danielle, and Adrienne Caitlyn. She will be missed enormously by her family, friends, and her beloved dogs.

Films will be distributed with software meant to prevent customers from copying the films or viewing them for more than 24 hours.

title: Chief Is Leaving Cordiant in London
description: Michael Bungey, chief executive at the Cordiant Communications Group in London since its founding in 1997, is retiring, effective in March, and will be succeeded by David Hearn, chief of the Cordiant flagship agency, Bates Worldwide in New York.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DOMESTIC SECURITY -- The Nuclear Threat; Tracking the Goods And the Guardians
description: There is no evidence that Al Qaeda has nuclear weapons, experts say. But the cold war left the world awash in the materials and knowledge needed to create nuclear weapons, and indeed awash in the weapons themselves.

title: Growing New Body Parts
description: This is a story about the power of family and the power of medicine. Four brothers collaborate on a bold new technique that hopes to save thousands of lives. Have they unlocked the key to repairing the body? Its a guided tour into an exciting new possibility: growing new parts for our bodies.

title: Long-Term Jobless Rose by 50 Percent Over the Last Year
description: Darrel Reiter has been out of work for nine months, and his wife, Norma, had not worked in five months when they climbed into their pickup truck to scour the West for jobs. But from Grand Junction, Colo., to Carson City, Nev., to Pendleton, Ore., the news was always the same, even if it came in different forms.

title: Adam Sandler Is Wary of the Media but Not Shy About the Box Office
description: Notoriously media-shy, Adam Sandler prefers to communicate directly with his fans by way of vignettes delivered over the Internet. One recent communiqu caught him slogging wearily across Sony's film lot in Culver City, Calif., gasping for air as he rattled off a list of his coming projects.

description: The last rays of sun vanished from the upper deck of the east stands at 7:09 p.m. Pay no attention to the calendar: this is when autumn actually begins in New York, on the last evening of the United States Open, when the sun goes down.

description: KONEFSKY-Roma Tenenbaum. On September 6, 2002. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Samuel J. Konefsky, loving mother of Margaret and Fred, adored grandmother of Seth, Stephen, Logan and Justin, treasured sister of Eva and George, cherished mother-in-law and aunt.

description: ORENSTEIN-Dr. Fred. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Sunday 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. title: Emerging From Cocoon of Grief; Town Tries to Get Back to Normal After Painful Year
description: Even now, a year after her husband, Louis, disappeared at the World Trade Center, Barbara Minervino struggles with the competing pulls of rejoining the living or remaining curled up in the shelter of her cream yellow ranch home with its comforting memories and distracting mounds of 9/11-related paperwork.

title: A Reggae Force in Jamaica (Queens, That Is)
description: Jamaica, Queens, is probably not the first place you would look for a reggae label. And you probably would not expect the moguls to be the Chins, a family of Chinese descent from Kingston, Jamaica.

title: Bush Officials Say the Time Has Come for Action on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8  Led by Vice President Dick Cheney, who warned grimly that "time is not on our side," President Bush's top national security officials said nearly in unison today that Saddam Hussein's efforts to build an arsenal of immensely destructive weapons left the United States little choice but to act against Iraq.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Sean Kane, partner at the Tucker Partnership, New York, was promoted to senior partner, leading Tucker Draddy Kane & Partners, a promotion marketing division of Tucker being created as Tucker acquires Carlson Draddy & Associates. Sue Draddy, president and chief operating officer at Carlson Draddy, was named partner at the Tucker Draddy division. Bonnie Carlson, who had been chief executive at Carlson Draddy, left to become vice president for integrated marketing at the grocery foods group unit of ConAgra Foods, Irvine, Calif.

title: Santa Monica Journal; On the Beach, a Subculture of Lords of the Rings
description: ''Look at this,'' Lawrence Kolb, known by the nickname Indian, said, slipping a finger into the loose waistband of his jeans. ''My waist size has gone down from 32 to 28 inches in six months.''

title: Many at U.N. Seek Evidence For U.S. Case Against Iraq
description: In the diplomatic scramble before President Bush's address to the General Assembly on Thursday to explain why the United States is moving toward a military strike against Iraq, the key issues for the United Nations are what weapons Baghdad is developing and how fast.

title: Write It, Stage It, Tweak It; Tony Kushner Continues to Tinker With 'Homebody/Kabul'
description: Some plays are written, others are rewritten. The works of Tony Kushner belong firmly in the second category. Sitting in his office in Union Square, a tiny, book-lined room that is taller than it is wide (with a long ladder leading to the topmost shelf), he talked in specific detail about how he nurtures a work through its creative process. After seeing a play performed, he goes on ''tinkering and tightening and tweaking and trying to get it right.'' This was the case with his first great success, ''Angels in America,'' and it is equally true with ''Homebody/Kabul,'' which had its world premiere last December at the New York Theater Workshop.

title: dRush Agency to Be Dissolved
description: An agency formed in 1999 by Deutsch in New York and the rap impresario Russell Simmons, which specializes in campaigns aimed at younger and urban consumers, is closing, effective in 90 days.

title: Russian Officials Uncover Mass Grave in Chechnya
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 9  Russian authorities uncovered a mass grave in Chechnya over the weekend, and a prominent human rights organization said today that the grave contained the bodies of at least seven Chechens who had been arrested during Russian security operations in May.

title: Garbage Truck Kills Boy Lying in the Grass at Orchard Beach
description: A 14-year-old Manhattan boy was killed yesterday after he lay down in a grassy area of Orchard Beach in the Bronx and was run over by a garbage truck, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 26 about a plan to use electronic toll devices to track traffic in the San Francisco Bay area referred incorrectly to precedents. The system would not be the first to use toll sensors; similar systems are used in Houston and San Antonio.

description: To the Editor:

title: Musharraf, at Harvard, Says He Supports U.S., to a Point
description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, speaking at Harvard University on the first day of a weeklong visit to the United States, underscored his support today for the American-led international coalition against terrorism and for the role of the American military in rebuilding Afghanistan.

title: Basque March Reflects Gains In Anti-Madrid Separatism
description: About 3,000 Basque nationalists marched through the sunlit center of San Sebastin today shouting pro-independence slogans, allowed to proceed by the Basque regional police despite an official ban on the demonstration.

title: Hidden In Nature
description: Ever wonder how a gecko can climb straight up a wall? Or what makes a cockroach so fast? What if we could actually harness natures secrets to create remarkable new inventions - insect based robots, armies of artificial ants? Scientists are just beginning to reap the benefits of using natures way to solve problems.

title: Lovable and Eccentric And Living in Brooklyn
description: Plays, and maybe comedies in particular, are delicate enough organisms that sometimes a production just a little bit out of sync is more painful than an out-and-out disaster. Such is the case with the Off Broadway revival of ''Three-Cornered Moon,'' an obscure but not unappealing period piece from 1933 whose balance of screwball comedy and earnest, Depression-era philosophy fits well within the lovably-eccentric-family tradition of American entertainment.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PERSPECTIVES/Jacques Chirac; French Leader Offers America Both Friendship and Criticism
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Jacques Chirac of France. The interview was conducted in French and translated by The New York Times.

title: A Year of War, Anxiety and Questions
description: Letters containing anthrax arrive at the offices of NBC and The New York Post; five people are infected between them. Two workers at American Media, in Boca Raton, Fla., are hospitalized after inhaling anthrax.

title: New York, a Year Later; Filling In the Void
description: In Lower Manhattan, the great hole at ground zero seems even emptier because it is surrounded now by so much life. The wounded community is knitting itself back together with startling speed. Residential buildings are almost all fully occupied, the demand for apartments booming. Great office buildings have the shiny look that comes with having been recently scrubbed. Places that appeared almost unsalvageable under the weight of debris and broken glass, like the World Financial Center, are restored, ready to get back in the game. But still the great hole remains, waiting for someone to decide what to do next.

"Viruses which target Windows could send confidential documents from my machines to random people  and that could send me to prison."

title: From Cradle to Grave, Singing Clumsily
description: Variety is a sparsely used spice in the life of the title character of ''Joe,'' another disturbing and compelling exercise in monotony from the downtown theater artist Richard Maxwell. While Jaques, the sentimental cynic of Shakespeare's ''As You Like It,'' described seven ages of man, Mr. Maxwell offers only six. And to tell the truth, there's not a whole lot to distinguish one from the others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGGEMANN, LYNN
description: ROGGEMANN - Lynn. Wo men's League for Israel mourns the untimely death of our beloved Lynn Roggemann. A third generation Women's Leaguer, she served in every capacity, from chapter to national officer. She was the Metropolitan Region's president. We will miss her warmth, her intelligence and her common sense. She was a good, loyal friend, a hard worker, conscientious and caring, devoted to Israel and to all who needed her. Our hearts go out to her husband Dennis; her children Mark, Florence and Ellen; grandchild Amber; Howard and Robin; the Bier family and dear friends. We loved her and we grieve for her. Harriet Lainer, National Pres. Women's League for Israel

description: The formerly heated battle between Web browser software made by Microsoft and Netscape has all but ended in an overwhelming victory for Microsoft.

title: Last Call May Be Near For Emergency Phones
description: Californians have coped with earthquakes, fires, the dot-com collapse and rolling energy blackouts. They rarely get rattled about their filthy air. But will they keep so cool when their beloved freeway call boxes come under assault?

title: White, His Finger Bent, Hopes His Bat Is Straight
description: Rondell White's left middle finger is shaped like a hook, bent at the knuckle and severely swollen. In the three months since he ruptured a tendon, White has hit .212. He can grip a bat but otherwise keeps the finger immobilized, and he will see a hand specialist this winter to determine if surgery is needed.

title: Black Police Officers' Group Seeks New Jogger Case Inquiry
description: A group representing black police officers called yesterday for an independent investigation of the 1989 case of a jogger who was beaten and raped in Central Park.

title: Anniversary Party Mixes Innovation and Nostalgia
description: The urge to innovate mingled with 1970's nostalgia during ''Thrill Jockey Turns 10'' at Irving Plaza on Thursday night. It was the first of three New York concerts -- two at Irving Plaza and a sold-out show Saturday night at the Bowery Ballroom -- celebrating the 10th anniversary of Thrill Jockey Records, an independent label of idiosyncratic and discerning taste that started in New York City and moved to Chicago in 1995.

While Mr. Baird criticized corruption in the legal system, he did not cite the case; it was mentioned by the writer as an example of issues underlying the speech.

title: Afghans, Too, Mark a Day of Disaster: A Hero Was Lost
description: For Fahim Dashti, the only truly striking thing about the two Arab men with the Belgian passports was that there was nothing really striking about them at all: blue jeans, T-shirts, running shoes, an easy manner, and -- as far as anybody in the room could judge -- no shred of nervousness or hesitation, right up to the last.

title: Champion of Open-Source Is Out at Hewlett-Packard
description: For nearly two years, Bruce Perens was a senior strategist for open-source software at Hewlett-Packard -- an evangelist and rabble-rouser on behalf of a computing counterculture that is increasingly moving into the mainstream. Part of the job description, he was told, was to ''challenge H.P. management.''

title: Government Ready to Fingerprint and Keep Track of Some Foreign Visitors
description: Immigration agents at the nation's border crossings, airports and seaports will begin this week to fingerprint foreigners who they suspect may pose security risks and will require those visitors to regularly report where they are staying and what they are doing in the United States.

title: Wendy's Is Looking for Smaller Deals
description: The chief executive of Wendy's International, John T. Schuessler, said today that the company was seeking purchases or investments of less than $50 million to help sales and profit, after spending $275 million in June to buy the Baja Fresh Mexican Grill restaurant chain.

title: Helen Giuliani, 92, Mother Of Former New York Mayor
description: Helen Giuliani, the mother of former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, died yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 92 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: French Leader Offers Formula To Tackle Iraq
description: President Jacques Chirac of France proposed a two-stage plan today that could lead to United Nations authorization of military force against Iraq.

title: Hurricanes' Dorsey Has the Winning Answer
description: Dianna Coker planted a kiss on Ken Dorsey while her husband, Larry, stood on a podium a few feet away and conceded that Dorsey, his University of Miami quarterback, did not turn in his most sterling performance on Saturday. Yes, Dorsey found his teammates for four touchdowns, but Dorsey also found three Florida Gators for interceptions, and one of those was returned for a touchdown.

title: Bledsoe Didn't Want a Dream Debut to End
description: When the Jets' Chad Morton ran past him on the sideline, Buffalo Bills quarterback Drew Bledsoe ignored him and held on to his own grand plans.

title: Orders for Machine Tools Were Lower in July
description: Orders for machine tools declined in July to the lowest level in more than six years, according to an industry survey released today.

title: Sports of The Times; Spurrier Is Right on the Button in Debut
description: FOR Steve Spurrier, the Washington Redskins' 31-23 victory over the Arizona Cardinals yesterday resembled most of his sometimes tempestuous triumphs at the University of Florida -- the coach's Fun 'n' Gun Offense chewing up 442 yards while he stalked the sideline in a white visor, black golf shirt, tan slacks and white sneakers.

title: Wells Will Not Miss a Start
description: David Wells was back at Yankee Stadium before 10 a.m. yesterday, missing two teeth but insisting, through a team spokesman, that he will make his next scheduled start on Thursday.

title: New Estimates On Ad Spending
description: Two forecasters of advertising spending whose predictions are closely followed are adjusting estimates for 2002 and 2003 in the United States and around the world.

title: Locked Up and Patted Down: A Year of Making U.S. Safer
description: Cockpit doors are stronger, but not all cargo is screened for bombs. The directors of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency now jointly brief the president on terrorist threats, but there are still critical gaps in intelligence gathering and analysis. The Super Bowl has become a superfortress, but the local cineplex remains a soft target. The government issues a rolling rainbow of threat alerts, but Congress and the White House are still battling over the creation of an agency to coordinate security.

title: Distance Compounds Grief of Lonely Vigils
description: Lower Manhattan is a little more than 1,000 miles from here, but some days it might as well be on another planet. Just ask Sally Rubinstein, who has been to New York just once in nearly 40 years and yet considers herself to be one of its aching own.

title: Edwards Is Baffled By Jets' Flag Football
description: The exhilaration of the Jets' dramatic overtime victory against the Bills was enough to make Coach Herman Edwards forget what a mess his team had made for itself today. But not for long.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Around a City Remade
Holding On to What Is Left
Times Appoints an Investigations Editor
description: The appointment of Douglas Frantz as investigations editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Howell Raines, executive editor. Mr. Raines said investigative reporting would be elevated to a separate newsroom department with Mr. Frantz's arrival in a few weeks. It was formerly an interdepartmental desk.

description: Russian authorities uncovered a mass grave in Chechnya over the weekend, and a prominent human rights organization said today that the grave contained the bodies of at least seven Chechens who had been arrested during Russian security operations in May.

title: Laurence C. Abel: Bond Analyst and Car Lover
description: Laurence C. Abel was a sports enthusiast  he played as much tennis, basketball and golf on his Sony PlayStation as he did on the courts  and a car lover. In 2000, Mr. Abel, 37, bought a Honda Accord Coupe in shiny black. "We must have gone to 10 different car dealers in all five boroughs and the tri-state area," said his companion, Beverly C. Williams. "That car was half his heart, or a quarter of his heart."

title: Gentle Message From a Heavenly Empire
description: Who says a joyful noise has to be noisy? Bill Gaither brought some two dozen performers to the Continental Airlines Arena here tonight for the second performance of a 29-date tour. For more than three hours, Mr. Gaither and his musical family entertained a small but eager crowd, preaching to the converted with a mixture of well-known spirituals and country-influenced originals. It may have been ''shouting time in heaven,'' but it was crooning time onstage.

title: Service Chiefs Say Afghan Battle Will Help Military Get Smarter, Stronger and Faster
description: America's military is applying the lessons learned in Afghanistan, examining everything from whether the standard rifle cartridge fired by each soldier packs enough punch to whether floating oil platforms can be towed around the globe as secret bases for marines and Navy SEALs.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Predicts Strong Year
description: Nextel Communications, the mobile-telephone company backed by the billionaire Craig McCaw, said it would meet or beat 2002 forecasts for customers and profit excluding some items. The carrier is on track to add two million subscribers this year, Nextel said. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization will top $3 billion, said Nextel, whose phones include a walkie-talkie feature popular among construction crews and financial traders. The chief executive, Tim Donahue, has increased Nextel's sales force and focused on selling more phones and services to existing customers. The company said in July that it added 471,000 customers in the second quarter, even as some analysts forecast that the wireless industry would add subscribers this year at the slowest pace since 1985. Nextel's average monthly customer bill rose to $71 in the second quarter from $68 in the first quarter.

title: Anthony J. Coladonato: 'It's Not About Winning'
description: Anthony J. Coladonato almost never left his wife's side. "We were attached at the hip," said Debbie Razzano. They went into the city together early in the morning, so they could both go to the gym. She worked at the Citicorp Building in Midtown; Mr. Coladonato, 47, worked in customer service for the eSpeed division of Cantor Fitzgerald, in the World Trade Center's north tower.

title: Woman Who Sought U.S. Asylum Is Arrested
description: A West African woman whose plea for political asylum drew national attention after she said she feared genital mutilation in Ghana was arrested in Queens yesterday on charges that she lied under oath and entered the United States with a fraudulent passport in 1997.

title: Waiting for Takeoff, Designers Offer a Peek of Spring
description: It seems contradictory now, but there was a time not long ago when designing clothes seemed like a very melancholy job. Following the terrorist attacks on New York last year, ''Everything I was making was severe,'' the designer Peter Som said last week. The clothes he created for this fall, Mr. Som said, ''attempted to convey strength and protection as a reaction to everything that was going on.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Troupe Returns And Dreams Grow Bigger
description: There was more going on in ''Kaleidoscope,'' presented on Saturday night at Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, than simply a first full evening of dances by Erica Dankmeyer, a modern-dance choreographer of welcome intelligence and promise. Ms. Dankmeyer and most of her dancers are members of the Martha Graham Dance Company, which has performed only once in the last two years because of financial and legal problems.

title: John A. Cooper Jr.: An Inquisitive Mechanic
description: John A. Cooper Jr. was only 5 when he started removing the backs of the transistor radios in the apartment in Williamsburg with a screwdriver. He was looking for something. "He wanted to see where the man was talking from," said his mother, Clowdia Cooper, "and he'd put it back together but it wouldn't work then. And the clocks!"

title: Discovering Amazon Rain Forest's Silver Lining
description: Many Brazilians have regarded the Amazon jungle as a barrier to progress that should be replaced as quickly as possible with ranches and farms. But in this remote corner of Brazil's most isolated state, people increasingly see the rain forest as a solution to the region's chronic poverty.

title: Cantor Seeks To Relocate To Union Sq.
description: Cantor Fitzgerald, the bond broker that lost 658 employees in the attack on the World Trade Center, is negotiating to build a $100 million headquarters in a former department store in Union Square, an area that has not traditionally drawn financial services firms.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: SOUTH PLAINFIELD: FIRE LEAVES 60 HOMELESS A multi-alarm fire destroyed a 24-unit block of condominiums yesterday, leaving 60 people homeless. A resident reported the fire around 1 p.m. None of the tenants were injured, although officials said some firefighters had minor injuries. The authorities were investigating the cause of the fire. Mayor Daniel Gallagher, who lives in the complex, said the developer was putting up displaced residents in hotel rooms. (AP)

title: U.S. Rift With Allies on World Court Widens
description: Senior Canadian and European officials, openly expressing their frustration with Washington's objections to the International Criminal Court, pledged today to work to extend its jurisdiction worldwide.

title: James Maounis: A Friend for a Lifetime
description: How many guys would blow off drinking with their pals in order to drive their sister to the beauty parlor? ("You got a brother?" asked Anthony Giammona. "Would he do that for you?")

title: Rocco Nino Gargano: High Taste at an Early Age
description: To many 12-year-olds, X-Men comics are the limits of high art. But at 12, Rocco Nino Gargano was painting his own Renaissance-style pictures after school  St. John the Baptist, the Resurrection of Christ, the Virgin holding the blessed infant.

title: Revisiting an Unnerving Collection
description: On the evening of Sept. 9 last year, Miguel Adrover, who had already collected his first silver statue from the Council of Fashion Designers of America, presented his fifth collection. He called it ''Utopia,'' and among the looks he showed were mosaic-patterned coats, head scarves and a caftan painted with images of spires and palm trees, as if taken from an Egyptian postcard.

title: Ford, Defying Forecasts, Says It Expects Quarterly Profit
description: Buoyed by strong industry sales and progress in its cost-cutting efforts, the Ford Motor Company said today that it expected to post an operating profit for the current quarter.

title: Post-9/11 Coping, From Preparedness to Fatalism
description: Growing up in Pass Christian, Miss., on the storm-battered Gulf Coast, Todd Erichsen learned to prepare for the worst, especially after Hurricane Camille killed 256 people and crushed his family's garage on Aug. 17, 1969, a date imprinted on his memory.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: British Energy Falls
description: Shares in the nuclear power generator British Energy lost two-thirds of their value after the government gave it a 410 million ($639 million) bail-out loan until Sept. 27. British Energy has until that date to come up with financing to avert bankruptcy, the Department of Trade and Industry said. The formerly state-owned company, sold to investors in 1996, generates one-fifth of Britain's electricity from eight nuclear power stations. Earlier this year it reported an annual loss of $780 million. Trading in British Energy shares was suspended last week after the company said it was negotiating with the government to avoid insolvency. The shares fell by as much as 68 percent, to 27.75 pence (43.24 U.S. cents) when trading resumed. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: For Survivor, Home Is Still a Hospital
description: Sadly, wryly, Deborah Mardenfeld describes herself as first in, last out.

title: Delphi Wins G.M. Orders
description: The Delphi Corporation has received contracts to make steering columns for cars and light trucks, including full-size pickup and sport utility vehicles from General Motors in the 2003 model year.

title: When Grief Takes Hold Of the Body
description: At 8:30 a.m. on Sept. 11, from her office on the 105th floor of the World Trade Center, my sister Karen talked to her best friend. No one ever heard from Karen again.
