description: If Napoleon fought wars on his soldiers' stomachs, the United States is fighting this desert war on air-conditioned tents.

title: New York Primary Choices
description: This list summarizes our recommendations in some of today's primary election races throughout New York State. In some cases the primary is tantamount to election. In others, we may endorse again for the Nov. 5 general election. Polling hours in the metropolitan area are from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: IMMUNE RESPONSE TO CUT HALF OF HEADQUARTERS STAFF
description: The Immune Response Corporation said yesterday that Dennis Carlo had resigned as chief executive, and that the company, which has struggled to develop an H.I.V. treatment, was cutting more than half the staff at its headquarters. Immune Response said it had promoted its vice president for medical and scientific affairs, Ronald Moss, to president and was seeking a new chief executive. Immune Response will cut 28 of the 42 jobs at its headquarters in Carlsbad, Calif.

title: Inventories Rose in July And Shoppers Added to Debt
description: Wholesale inventories rose in July for a second consecutive month, the first back-to-back increase in 19 months, the government reported today.

title: Can These Boxes Be Locked Against Terror?
description: As postal authorities scramble to strengthen security of the mail, they face a daunting realization: the process will take years, it will cost at least a billion dollars and until it is finished the nation is probably even more vulnerable than it was last fall, when anthrax-tainted letters killed five people, sickened at least 17 more and caused widespread disruption and fear.

title: A Tournament Filled With Trial and Error
description: Arlen Kantarian is not to be confused with HBO's Arliss, though he has swung a few big deals in his time, or with a contrarian, though he is prone to switch positions at any moment.

title: J. P. Frank, 84, a Lawyer In Landmark Cases, Dies
description: John P. Frank, a lawyer and law professor who helped shape the argument in the landmark Brown v. Board of Education case and represented Ernesto Miranda in the United States Supreme Court, died on Saturday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURMAN, EVELYN KATZ
description: FURMAN-Evelyn Katz. September 9, 2002. Beloved wife and mother. Trained as a medical social worker, she was guidance counselor at Riverdale Country School, The Fieldston School, and Brooklyn Poly Prep. Longtime member of the Board of Trustees of the Bronx Organization for the Learning Disabled (BOLD) and its President for 13 years. It is a major provider of services to learning disabled children and young adults in the South Bronx, where the Furman Evaluation Center has been named in her honor. She is survived by sons Bruce, Gary and Neil, and brothers Louis, Walter, Frederick, and husband Seymour. Donations to BOLD, 770 Beck St., Bronx NY 10455, or Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research at Cornell Medical Center, 428 East 72 St., NY. Services Wednesday, September 11, at 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Waiting for Takeoff, Designers Offer a Peek of Spring
description: It seems contradictory now, but there was a time not long ago when designing clothes seemed like a very melancholy job. Following the terrorist attacks on New York last year, ''Everything I was making was severe,'' the designer Peter Som said last week. The clothes he created for this fall, Mr. Som said, ''attempted to convey strength and protection as a reaction to everything that was going on.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Senators Seek More 9/11 Aid
description: Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that they would press the federal government for future aid to New York for its recovery from the terrorist attack last fall. In addition to seeking money to study the health of workers at ground zero, the senators said they had introduced legislation to extend unemployment insurance to June 1, 2003, for eligible New Yorkers, and would push legislation to forgive student loans for spouses of those killed or permanently disabled in the attack. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Quantum To Cut Jobs
description: Quantum, a maker of computer data-storage devices, said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by 1,100 as its new chief executive, Richard Belluzzo, sought to pare costs and return to profitability by March 2003. About 80 percent of the workers cut will be hired by Jabil Circuit Inc., which is taking over some Quantum manufacturing, a spokeswoman said. The job cuts and other restructuring costs will trim earnings by $100 million in the second and third quarters, Quantum said. Mr. Belluzzo said last month that he planned to tighten Quantum's spending and increase sales of products that were more profitable than hardware systems, like services and software, amid a slump in demand for corporate technology. The shares of the company, based in Milpitas, Calif., fell 21 cents, or 6.5 percent, to $3.01.

title: Senator Shelby Faults the Intelligence Agencies
description: These interviews are the seventh and eighth of a series in which national and world figures reflect on the terrorist attacks and their effect on a year of public life and policy.

title: New York Primaries
description: Voters in New York select their parties' nominees for governor, lieutenant governor, state comptroller and local legislative districts today. Polling places will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. in New York City and Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Putnam and Erie Counties. In other counties, they will be open from noon to 9 p.m. Questions about voting eligibility or to determine a district or polling place in New York City may be telephoned to the Board of Elections: 212-VOTE-NYC (212-868-3692).

title: Louis Mariani: His Town and His Pictures
description: Wherever Louis Mariani went, he was sure to have his trusty Minolta camera with him. "He just loved taking pictures," recalled his daughter, Lauren Peters.

title: Hernandez Apologizes to the Mets
description: Keith Hernandez, the former Met turned team announcer, apologized yesterday for an online analysis last week in which he said that his former team had no heart and ''quit a long time ago.'' He said he hoped to be able to apologize to the team before it took batting practice before tonight's game in Atlanta.

title: H.M.O.'s For 200,000 Pulling Out Of Medicare
description: Health maintenance organizations serving 200,000 elderly and disabled people said today that they would pull out of Medicare next year, raising to 2.4 million the number of beneficiaries who have been dropped by H.M.O.'s since 1998.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON REPORTS DRUG FAILED TEST
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would not seek Food and Drug Administration approval to market the Topamax epilepsy drug for use in bipolar disorder, or manic depression, because it was not effective in a study. Johnson & Johnson said it would seek F.D.A. approval to promote Topamax for two other new uses: as migraine prevention and as a stand-alone epilepsy treatment. Topamax is now approved in the United States as an add-on treatment for epilepsy, a brain disorder that causes seizures.

title: In a Somber Week, an Eye on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, ISABEL W.
description: ROSENBERG-Isabel W. Isabel dearest.

title: Aon Is Moving to New Offices, but Will Avoid Tall Buildings
description: A year ago, Aon, the world's second-largest insurance broker, was reorganizing itself, concentrating its operations in four centers around the country.

title: Patriots Open Stadium, and Season, Impressively
description: The Patriots own a Super Bowl championship, a new stadium and a firm grip over the Steelers. All three were evident on an exhilarating night for Patriots fans as New England began defense of its title with a 30-14 thumping of Pittsburgh before 68,436 fans.

title: Publisher Tries Literary Lightning Rod To Attract Latino Writers and Readers
description: By the time Victor Villaseor attempted to sell his fourth book about two years ago, he was a best-selling author in the Southwest and a cherished figure among Mexican-Americans who had seen their lives reflected in the pages of his family memoir, ''Rain of Gold'' (Arte Pblico Press, 1991).

title: Thomas Dowd: Jokes and Furious Sports
description: It was easy to tell if Thomas Dowd liked you, because if so, he would insult you.

title: Footlights
description: Heroes' Heyday

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDELL, EVA.
description: BANDELL-Eva. On her 100th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Albert, loving mother of Lester and Shirley Bandell, Flo and Eddie Gross, and Rosalie Levine and the late Harold Levine. Caring and devoted grandmother and great-grandmother. Services today, 12 noon, at Sherman Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

title: Nicholas A. Bogdan: With a Protective Side
description: Nicholas A. Bogdan had an idea of his perfect wife. "She had to like computer games, she had to like to read, she had to be interested in Dungeons and Dragons, and she had to be single," said the woman who eventually filled out the ticket. "I had everything on the list except the single part, so he set about to make that happen."

title: You Know You're a New Yorker When...
description: "... when the World Trade Centers Twin Towers fell, you felt like youd lost part of your childhood, your home, and yourself," wrote DickytNYC .

title: Robert J. Foti: Lessons of Helpfulness
description: To know Robert Foti, 43, meet his children: Alycia, 13, Robert Jr., 12, and James, 5. This winter, Robert Jr. walked down a snowy mountain  twice  to retrieve a stranger's snowboard. When Alycia was 11, she spent the holidays with her stepmother's family and cheerfully helped out in the kitchen. James, little James, is obsessed with the twin towers that claimed his father's life.

title: At Sea With the Godfathers of Techno and a Hard Steady Pulse
description: It's not unheard of for a techno D.J. to begin with a loud blast, as a way of letting dancers know it's time to pay attention. On Sunday night Kevin Saunderson's set began with the sound of a foghorn, but it was no mere D.J. convention. Mr. Saunderson and Derrick May were the headliners aboard the Star of Palm Beach, a floating nightclub plying the Hudson; the foghorn was a signal that the boat had pulled away from the pier.

title: Arafat Covers Old Ground in Keynote Speech
description: In a rambling, hourlong speech, Yasir Arafat treated restless Palestinian legislators today to a familiar litany of grievances and exhortations, but failed to discuss political reforms, as many had hoped, or to make the explicit condemnation of suicide bombings that foreign leaders had sought.

title: Bush and Chrtien Discuss Easing Customs Delays
description: President Bush and Prime Minister Jean Chrtien of Canada met today at the continent's most active border crossing for trade and announced new steps to reduce customs delays for authorized truckers and travelers while remaining vigilant against terrorists.

title: Veterans of Secret Unit Celebrate Their War Hero: Radar
description: Nowadays, radar is probably mentioned most often in connection with a weather forecast or a speeding ticket.

title: Firefighter Statue Puts Down Roots
description: The 6-foot-tall bronze statue of a kneeling firefighter, which had sat on a truck bed in the street outside the Milford Plaza Hotel in Midtown Manhattan, has found a permanent home just a few feet away. It has been moved from Eighth Avenue near 44th Street to the sidewalk as a permanent memorial to firefighters and members of law enforcement agencies who died on Sept. 11.

title: Interview With Richard C. Shelby
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Senator Richard C. Shelby, the Alabama Republican who is the ranking minority member of the Intelligence Committee:

title: Some Senate Republicans Break With Bush on Drought Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  With many Republicans from agricultural states defying President Bush, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to provide almost $6 billion to help farmers and ranchers hurt by the drought.

title: To avoid looking exploitive, a great many big marketers will not run advertising tomorrow.
description: CONCERNED about being considered crass or exploitive, more marketers have decided against running advertising of any kind tomorrow, whether or not it would appear during coverage commemorating the terrorist attacks.

title: 2 Public Advocates on Charter Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Patriotism Can Stand Tall Once More
description: Just in time for flying the red, white and blue for Sept. 11, this village backed down today from its crackdown on flagpoles.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about the funeral of the jazz vibraphonist Lionel Hampton misstated the name of the band in the procession. It was David Ostwald's Gully Low Jazz Band, with Wynton Marsalis as guest trumpeter, not the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESTEL, ELIAS
description: MESTEL-Elias, 89, of Pompano Beach, FL, formerly of Middle Village, NY passed away September 7, 2002. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Lynn, Andrea and Karen. Grandfather of Ted, Rebecca, Willa, Owen, Blair, Matthew and Peter. Beloved brother and uncle. 2nd Ltd. in the Army in WW II; practiced law in Middle Village for 50 years. He was a man of true integrity, honesty and principle who helped many throughout his life. He will be missed. Chapel service Tuesday September 10th 11:45AM at Star of David Cemetery & Funeral Chapel, 7701 Bailey Road, N. Lauderdale 954-722-9000

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINKERHOFF, LILLIAN WESTAWAY
description: BRINKERHOFF - Lillian Westaway. Died September 8, after a long illness. Born March 7, 1922 to Lillian Jourdan Westaway and Robert Westaway, president and chairman of A.D. Juilliard and Co. She was raised in Englewood, NJ and Quogue, NY and attended Dwight, Shipley, and Sarah Lawrence. Her marriage to John Lutrell of Mason's Island ended in divorce but brought a son, John W. Brinkerhoff, who predeceased her. Her marriage to George Brinkerhoff of Mahwah, now Pinehurst, also ended in divorce but brought three more sons, George E. III of Quogue, Peter Booth of Metuchen and Robert Westaway of Bulle, Switzerland, who all survive her. In addition she is mourned by her brother Robert Westaway of South Carolina, her sisters Ann W. Bell of Pennsylvania and Elizabeth W. Cookman of North Carolina, and grandchildren Luc, Josh, and Davis Brinkerhoff of Momont Dessus, Switzerland, and Thomas Brinkerhoff of Metuchen, as well as Mrs. John W. Brinkerhoff of Bedminster. She was extraordinarily beautiful. Episcopal services will be scheduled. For time: Follett & Werner, 631-288-1231.

title: Citigroup Moves to Clear Up Troubles at Investment Unit
description: Sanford I. Weill's decision to promote his former chief legal counsel to run Citigroup's investment bank, Salomon Smith Barney, shows just how much Mr. Weill, Citigroup's chief executive, wants to rid the bank of the legal and regulatory problems confronting it, analysts and investors said.

title: DuPont Allowed To Settle Suits
description: A federal judge has approved the DuPont Company's $44.5 million settlement of consumer lawsuits that contended that the company tried to block generic competition to its blood-thinning drug, Coumadin.

title: Lung Ailments May Force 500 Firefighters Off Job
description: As many as 500 New York City firefighters may have to retire early as a result of ''respiratory disability,'' chronic breathing problems caused by their exposure to dense clouds of dust, smoke and fumes at the World Trade Center, health officials said yesterday.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: YUGOSLAVIA: MONTENEGRO CONVICTS SERB A Montenegrin court convicted a Serb of war crimes, jailing him for 15 years for his role in the killing of 19 civilians, most of them Muslim, during the 1992-1995 Bosnian war, the Beta news agency reported. The court in the town of Bijelo Polje found the man, Nebojsa Ranisavljevic, guilty of involvement in the abduction of the 19 from a train traveling through eastern Bosnia in February 1993, and in their torture and murder. It was the second such conviction in Yugoslavia. The first occurred in July, when a former army reservist was sentenced to eight years for killing two Kosovo Albanians. (Reuters)

title: Using a Gift for Giving to Help 9/11 Victims
description: IN the pantheon of churlish chief executives, Joshua Gotbaum deviates from the template: he's in this one for the charitable glow, not the capitalist rush, and dresses the part. His tie is askew, more nuisance noose than sartorial accouterment. His shirt, with two gauche plastic pens peeking from the pocket, is too capacious to be custom. His myopic eyes glitter behind thick wire-rimmed specs. His sandy hair and matching mustache are trimmed for propriety, not panache.

title: Commerce and 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Decades of Warnings Fail to Get Americans Moving
description: The finding was so serious that it could be comparable in its health effects to a vitamin deficiency, medical experts said. It was so shocking that U.S. News & World Report published a special 11-page section warning the nation.

title: Interview With Bob Graham
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, the chairman of the Intelligence Committee:

title: Added Warning for Malaria Drug
description: The maker of a widely used antimalaria drug, Lariam, says it will notify doctors about reports of a link between the drug and suicide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIULIANI, HELEN
description: GIULIANI-Helen. The faculty and staff of the New York University Child Study Center mourn the loss of Helen Giuliani, the mother of our great friend and supporter, Rudolph Giuliani. Helen gave her son a love of learning, a dedication to our city, state and country, and a love of children. Rudy has continually supported our efforts in improving the mental health of children and adolescents in New York City and throughout the United States. We send our sympathy to Rudy, Andrew, Caroline and the entire Giuliani family. Brooke Garber Neidich, Chairman, Board of Directors Harold S. Koplewicz, MD, Founder and Director New York University Child Study Center

title: A Band's 40th Birthday Party as Salsa Festival
description: El Gran Combo, a Puerto Rican dynastic institution that has become synonymous with classic salsa, likes to recognize its own milestones. It has put out albums and produced concerts to mark its 20th and 30th anniversaries; this year the band wraps up its fourth decade, and on Saturday night it put on a retrospective at Madison Square Garden that didn't skimp on either generosity or self-admiration, ending with confetti, tailored Puerto Rican-flag uniforms, and a song about the band turning 40.

title: A Rosy, Pink Cloud, Packed With Pollution
description: A faintly pink haze, in the unexpectedly innocuous hue of a baby's coverall, clung to this city's famous harbor and curled among the skyscrapers today as Hong Kong recorded its worst air pollution yet.

title: Tandem Effects of Spouses' Health
description: Want a snapshot of your health? Try looking across the breakfast table.

title: Jane Simpkin: 'An Ongoing Art Project'
description: Jane Simpkin seemed drawn to the unusual, and vice versa. When she was standing on her mother's porch in Wayland, Mass., one day, a baby bald eagle landed at her feet. While she was driving to work one time, a bright blue parakeet flew into the car.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: New Maoist Attack
description: In their second major attack in two days, Maoist rebels in Nepal killed 58 people in a remote town Sunday night, according to Reuters. Government officials said Maoists overran the town, Sandhikharka, about 185 miles west of Katmandu. On Saturday, 49 police officers were killed by Maoist rebels in eastern Nepal. The violence comes after a lull in rebel activity brought about by a successful government offensive in May. David Rohde (NYT)

title: McDonald's Planning Changes in Menu
description: DES MOINES, Sept. 9 (Dow Jones/AP)  The McDonald's Corporation will offer its franchisees in the United States subsidies to win their support for a nationwide $1 menu and for a major restaurant remodeling effort, company documents say.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a shake-up at Citigroup's investment bank unit misspelled part of the unit's name in some copies. It is Salomon Smith Barney, not Salmon.

title: Israel Strips Citizenship From Arab Suspect
description: An Israeli Arab accused of aiding a suicide bomber was stripped of his citizenship today by Interior Minister Eli Yishai, the first time such a measure has been taken against an Israeli accused of a security offense.

title: India Freezes Sale of State-Owned Shares
description: A widening rift in the Indian cabinet has disrupted, at least temporarily, an ambitious program to reduce the government's pervasive involvement in business and the economy by selling many state-owned companies.

title: Germans Resurrect the East's Methods
description: East Germany may be gone, but its sports system is being resurrected.

title: Tiberias Journal; Israel Waits for Sea of Galilee's Low Tide to Turn
description: These days, even the lowest sinner can walk out onto the Sea of Galilee.

title: Genentech Says Cancer Drug, Avastin, Failed Clinical Trial
description: The biotechnology company Genentech said late yesterday that an experimental cancer drug that tried to block the flow of blood to tumors had failed its first late-stage clinical trial -- a blow to the company and to what had been considered a promising approach to treating cancer.

title: Full Text: The Four Freedoms
description: 'Four Essential Human Freedoms'

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Stake Bought
description: The International Finance Corporation and the Bank of Nova Scotia said they had agreed to acquire an equity stake in Xian City Commercial Bank in western China. A Bank of Nova Scotia spokeswoman said that the Canadian bank's stake would be substantially less than the limit of 24.9 percent limit imposed by the Chinese government. The Chinese bank, which was set up in 1997 by combining 42 urban credit cooperatives, is presently 22 percent owned by the Xian municipality, with the remaining 78 percent held by local businesses and individuals. The finance corporation and the Bank of Nova Scotia will also provide management and technical assistance. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Tapes Show Plans for Attacks Evolved Over 2 Years
description: The Jazeera satellite television network broadcast brief new footage today that it says shows the hijackers planning for the Sept. 11 attacks and the station will show an interview with two of the most wanted suspects who reveal details of the planning, including that nuclear targets were considered.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRAVERMAN, JUDY
description: BRAVERMAN - Judy Be loved Mommy. Four years without you and the pain of your absence remains. Missing you always. Love, Melissa.

title: BJ'S WHOLESALE NAMES NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: BJ's Wholesale Club, a warehouse-club retailer that has seen its shares lose 47 percent of their value this year, promoted Michael Wedge to chief executive and president after John Nugent resigned. Mr. Nugent, 56, is leaving BJ's, the third-largest United States chain of warehouse-club stores, after 12 years for personal reasons, the company said, without giving details. Mr. Wedge, 48, had been executive vice president of club operations. Warehouse-club chains are facing increased competition amid slow consumer spending, analysts said. BJ's, based in Natick, Mass., owns 138 wholesale stores. The company's net income declined 37 percent last year. BJ's trails the Costco Wholesale Corporation and Sam's Club in sales.

title: Chemical threat exists, and 'nuclear wild card' is raised : A report on Iraqi arms spells out risks
description: PARIS:  Iraq probably does not have enough chemical or biological weapons or long-range missiles to offer serious military resistance to U.S. armed forces protecting nearby countries or even invading Iraq itself, according to an independent assessment by a leading Western think tank.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 29 about Per Anger, a Swedish diplomat who helped save Hungarian Jews from deportation to Nazi death camps, referred incorrectly to the German presence in Hungary in 1944. The Nazis did not invade Hungary, which had allied itself with the Axis powers at the start of the war. Instead, as the Hungarian government wavered in its support of Germany, Nazi troops occupied the country and a puppet regime was installed.

title: Eric Taube Olsen: Firefighter Who Saw Beauty
description: What Taube and Barbara Olsen recall about their son was his ability to see things not as they were, but as they could be.

title: New Russian Cathedral Stymied by Interfaith Rift
description: On a gentle bend in the Pskova River, near the center of this city steeped in religious history, the skeletal brick walls of a new cathedral rise unfinished, shrouded in wooden scaffolding and mired in the deepening tensions between the Roman Catholic and Russian Orthodox Churches.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Law Department Sets Up 9/11 Tort Unit
description: The New York City Law Department has established a new World Trade Center unit to handle more than 1,560 tort claims seeking about $9 billion relating to the Sept. 11 attack. The specialized unit will consist of 25 full-time litigators, about half of whom already work for the Law Department. The rest will be drawn from lawyers in the private sector.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUSTEIN, MARTIN L.
description: BLAUSTEIN-Martin L. Beloved husband of Frances. Devoted father of Scott, Sharon, Robert, Michael. Cherished grandfather. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at Temple Bet Am Shalom, 295 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. Donations can be made to the Lions Club of Greenwich or the Rabbis Goodwill Fund at Bet Am Shalom in his memory.

title: High-Fat Diet: Count Calories and Think Twice
description: The debate over high-fat versus low-fat as a means of weight control flared up again this summer, leaving many weight-conscious Americans thoroughly confused and most nutrition experts up in arms.

title: Jason Sabbag: An Anonymous Reviewer
description: Was it Jason Sabbag who noticed the "total mayhem" at the Elephant bistro, the "gentle prices" at Miracle Grill, the fact that "women feel comfortable" at the Post House steak restaurant?

title: 'Of Mice and Men' and the Apocalypse
description: You know the feeling, I'm sure. It's pretty common currency of thought. You read the paper in the morning, or watch the television news, and day after day there are the reports about broken families, the decline of education, the abuse of children, children abandoned, children having children, children killing children. And you can't help but imagine the worst: the end of the world is at hand.

title: Joe J. Zuccala: 'Everybody's Best Friend'
description: Joe Zuccala left a big void when he died, and not just because he was 6-foot-5 and weighed about 275. Mr. Zuccala, 54, a banking consultant who was at Fuji Bank in the south tower on Sept. 11, was, as his pal Tim Horgan put it, "everybody's best friend," and that included his wife, Madeleine, his two daughters and Mr. Horgan's two sons.

title: New Uranium Plant Will Be in Tennessee
description: A partnership of American, Canadian and European nuclear companies that is seeking to build the first new uranium enrichment plant in this country in 50 years said today that it had selected a site, in Hartsville, Tenn., for the $1.1 billion project, state officials said today. Officials said the partnership hoped to apply to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for a license by the end of the year.

title: What Belongs in the Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Bill May Force Co-Op Boards To Explain Rejection
description: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, proposed a bill yesterday that would force condominium and co-op boards to explain why some potential buyers are turned away. The bill aims to enforce current county laws that ban discrimination based on religion, sexual orientation or race. The bill would require boards to explain, in writing, their reasons for rejecting applicants within five business days of a decision. A public hearing will be scheduled before the bill goes to a vote.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Sets Deadline For Napster
description: Shareholders of Napster Inc., the Internet music-swapping site whose proposed sale to Bertelsmann was rejected, have until Friday to elect a board to avoid a liquidation case, a judge ruled. United States Bankruptcy Judge Peter Walsh delayed his ruling on converting Napster's bankruptcy case to a Chapter 7 until Friday after the committee of unsecured creditors asked the court for more time to find a buyer and pursue claims against Bertelsmann.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MILBURN D., JR.
description: SMITH-Milburn D., Jr., on September 8, 2002, of Forest Hills, NY. Husband of Mollie, father of David, Jonathan, Eliza and Benjamin. Visiting Tuesday, September 10, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY. Service 12 PM, Thursday, September 12, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway South Forest Hills, NY 11375. Donations to St. Luke's Church appreciated.

title: Article 2002091094268072683 -- No Title
Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Cut Debt
description: Verizon Communications plans to reduce debt by 10 percent this year, Ivan Seidenberg, the chief executive, said yesterday. Net debt, or borrowing minus cash and equivalents, fell to $58.6 billion in June from $63.3 billion at the end of last year. A 10 percent reduction would cut that figure to $57 billion in December. Verizon had its first sales drop in two years last quarter as businesses and consumers canceled phone lines. Mr. Seidenberg reiterated a forecast that sales would be little changed or fall 1 percent this year.

title: Police Remember Their Own In a Quiet Ceremony of Loss
description: The Sept. 11 attack is nearly a year in the past, but the raw pain still creeps back as if it were yesterday. It feels that way to Geraldine Gilliam, who lost her son, Rodney C. Gillis, a New York Police Department sergeant. The pain never left for John T. Vigiano, a retired firefighter, who lost his sons Joseph, a police detective, and John Jr., a firefighter.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PERSPECTIVES -- In Senate, a Call for Answers And a Warning on the Future; C.I.A. and F.B.I. Faulted
description: After months of work on a joint Congressional committee investigating the events of Sept. 11, Senator Richard C. Shelby said he feared that Congress would adjourn before all the facts are unearthed. As a result, he said, he would not oppose an outside investigating commission.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Inmates' Hunger Strikes
description: Two inmates at a maximum security prison in Pontiac may legally starve themselves rather than face years of solitary confinement for misbehavior, a Livingston County circuit judge has ruled. The two -- John Barrell, 39, convicted of armed violence, and Leon Snipes, 41, a convicted rapist -- have ended their hunger strikes, but the ruling may set a precedent for the handling of such strikes in prisons. The state's attorney general is reviewing the decision. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: A Tax Break for the Rich Who Can Keep a Secret
description: When most Americans sell stock they must pay taxes on their profits by the following April 15. But a few Americans are delaying taxes on their stock profits for years or decades -- or, in some cases, never paying at all.

title: In Defense of Deterrence
description: The suddenness and ferocity of last September's terror attacks tore the United States free from the foreign-policy moorings that had served the nation well for more than five decades, including the central notion that American military power could by its very existence restrain the aggressive impulses of the nation's enemies. In its place, the Bush administration has substituted a more belligerent first-strike strategy that envisions Washington's attacking potential foes before they hit us. That may be appropriate in dealing with terror groups, but on the eve of the anniversary of Sept. 11 there is still an important place in American policy for the doctrine of deterrence.

title: Chief of Ford Unit to Quit
description: The chief executive of Ford Motor's German unit, Rolf Zimmerman, is planning to step down for personal reasons, the company said today.

title: An Investor Helps Rebuild Research Unit At Keefe
description: A few days after Sept. 11, Michael Corasaniti, a longtime investor in bank stocks, anxiously scanned the Web site of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, an investment bank that specializes in the financial services industry and had its headquarters in the World Trade Center. He knew many traders and analysts there, and wanted to see who had survived.

title: Some Friends, Indeed, Do More Harm Than Good
description: Friends are supposed to be good for you. In recent years, scientific research has suggested that people who have strong friendships experience less stress, they recover more quickly from heart attacks and they are likely to live longer than the friendless. They are even less susceptible to the common cold, studies show.

title: Bushes Lead a Commemoration
description: President Bush and Mrs. Bush joined a group of entertainers tonight at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here for a concert to ''reaffirm our nation's spirit and honor those who were lost on Sept. 11, 2001.''

title: TRANSACTIONS

title: New Policy Delays Visas For Specified Muslim Men
description: Under a policy quietly imposed by the Bush administration three months ago, tens of thousands of Muslim men, from more than 26 countries, have not been able to get United States visas, disrupting lives, creating diplomatic tensions and causing headaches for American diplomats.

title: Environmentalists Hail the Ranchers: Howdy, Pardners!
description: Ever since the great cattle drives of the Old West, ranching has been suspected of chewing up Western ecosystems. For decades, environmentalists have tried to limit grazing from public lands, where ranchers lease pastures from the government. But some scientists and conservationists are now saying that cattle ranches may be the last best hope for preserving habitat for many native species.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDT, ALAN
description: BRANDT-Alan. The Executive Committee of the National Association of Dealers in Ancient, Oriental & Primitive Art are saddened by the death of Alan Brandt, distinguished dealer in tribal art, colleague and friend.

title: Serene Woman, Practical Joker, Gentle Uncle and Brilliant Niece
description: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Carlos Segarra: A Final Act of Kindness
description: Three years ago, after Carlos Segarra's only son decided to marry, Mr. Segarra and his wife, Antonia, decided to sell their home of 24 years in Brooklyn and get a bigger one so their son, his new wife and even the wife's mother could move in. "We had never been separated," said Antonia Segarra, who had been married to him for 31 years. "We were always such a united family."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COONEY, DENNIS J.
description: COONEY-Dennis J. On September 8, 2002. Beloved son of Katherine (nee Horgan) and the late Dennis. Reposing at Buckley's Funeral Home, 445 West 43 St., NYC. Friends may visit Tuesday, 4-9 pm, or Wednesday, 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm. Requiem Mass Thursday, 10:30 am, at Holy Cross Church, West 42nd St.

title: Sports of The Times; Jets' Coaches Offer Extra: True Loyalty
description: HERMAN EDWARDS learned one of his first lessons about loyalty some seven years ago. He was the defensive backs coach for the Kansas City Chiefs -- a very good one by all accounts -- when Marty Schottenheimer, then the coach, called Edwards into his office and fired him.

title: Looking for the Point of Stretching
description: For many athletes, amateur and professional alike, the importance of stretching is nothing less than an article of fact. The goal is to reduce the risk of injury or muscle soreness, or to improve performance.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: A New Brewer
description: The Czech Republic's best-known beer, Pilsner Urquell, brewed since 1843 only in the West Bohemian city of Pilsen, will be made under license in Poland, the brewery's new owner, SABMiller, said. SABMiller, the former South African Breweries, said it hoped to make Urquell one of the world's five best-selling beers. Demand for beer is rising in Eastern Europe. SAB's Czech and Polish beer sales rose 8 percent combined in the last three months, the company said. The Czech Republic is the world's leading beer consumer, averaging 160 liters per capita per year. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the financial outlook for the Big Three automakers paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by Scott Sprinzen, managing director for corporate and government bond ratings at Standard & Poor's. He said the Ford Motor Company and General Motors should be able to obtain financing for the foreseeable future from the market for asset-backed securities, not from the bond market.

title: Kindness to a stranger : OUR READERS REMEMBER
description: September 11, 2001: Wherever we are, wherever we were, we can remember what we were doing when we heard the news. Responding to the IHT's request to share experiences, nearly 200 readers have offered poetry and prose, photographs and artwork as their testimony about events that defied belief. The selections have been edited to permit the use of as many as possible; we are sorry that we cannot print each one.

title: The Long Haul
description: Americans should be proud of their reaction to Sept. 11. They didn't respond to calls for sacrifice, because no such calls were made. But they did respond to horror with calm and tolerance. There was no panic; while there were a handful of hate crimes, there were no angry mobs attacking people who look different. The American people remained true to what America is all about.

title: HARTFORD FINANCIAL TO RAISE $600 MILLION
description: The Hartford Financial Services Group, the seventh-largest United States insurer, said yesterday that it would raise about $600 million by selling $300 million of stock and a similar amount in convertible bonds. The company will use the proceeds to increase capital at some subsidiaries, it said in a press release. Vanessa Wilson, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Securities, said the decline in equity markets had put pressure on life insurance companies' investment portfolios and products like annuities that are linked to the stock market. On July 29, Hartford Financial said its second-quarter profit fell 18 percent on losses from investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPPARD, VIRGINIA
description: SHEPPARD-Virginia. In loving memory of Virginia, beloved wife of the late Dr. A.L. Sheppard. Devoted sister-inlaw of Bernice Sheppard and aunt of Steve Sheppard and Barbara Reede.

title: To Protect Anonymity
description: To the Editor:

title: Furor Over Toxic Microbes
description: To the Editor:

title: In Court, The Fight For Funnies Is Serious
description: Good grief, indeed. Connecticut's highest court weighed in today to settle a two-year battle between The Hartford Courant and a suburban competitor over, of all things, the Sunday funnies.

title: Text: Gen. Eric K. Shinseki, Army Chief of Staff
description: Gen. Eric K. Shinseki, the Army chief of staff, commanded the NATO Stabilization Force in Bosnia and all American Army forces in Europe. He was wounded twice during two combat tours in Vietnam.

title: Fall in France Tlcom Shares Raises Pressure for Rescue
description: Investors continued to pummel France Tlcom's shares today, increasing the pressure on the government to come up with a rescue plan for the battered telecommunications giant.

title: Orasri Liangthanasarn: Loving Her First Job
description: Orasri Liangthanasarn loved flowers, especially sunflowers. "She's very joyful," her sister, Dr. Passara Liangthanasarn, said in a telephone interview from California. "She makes everyone around her happy."

title: Editors' Note; Pieces of a Puzzle
description: More on Pages A14 and A15:

title: As the Right Falls Into Disarray, Austrians Call Early Elections
description: The Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schssel, called early elections today to end a government crisis brought on by a feud in his far-right coalition partner, Jrg Haider's Freedom Party.

title: Liam Joseph Colhoun: Always a Free Spirit
description: As Liam Colhoun's career took off, reaching a position as a manager of options operations at Bank of America Securities, he had to part with some of the trappings of what his parents called his free spirit. He relegated his leather motorcycle jacket to weekend wear, trimmed his auburn hair, pocketed his earring.

title: Eileen M. Greenstein: A Sense of Loyalty
description: When she finally moved from her old neighborhood of Jackson Heights, Queens, to the leafy suburb of Morris Plains, N.J., three years ago, Eileen Greenstein was determined to stay in touch with her extended family. So she helped start a cousins' club and went to dinner or a show with them once a month.

title: MEMO PAD
description: United Airlines Joins the Crowd

title: Waiting for Takeoff, Designers Offer a Peek of Spring
description: It seems contradictory now, but there was a time not long ago when designing clothes seemed like a very melancholy job. Following the terrorist attacks on New York last year, ''Everything I was making was severe,'' the designer Peter Som said last week. The clothes he created for this fall, Mr. Som said, ''attempted to convey strength and protection as a reaction to everything that was going on.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 29 about Per Anger, a Swedish diplomat who helped save Hungarian Jews from deportation to Nazi death camps, referred incorrectly to the German presence in Hungary in 1944. The Nazis did not invade Hungary, which had allied itself with the Axis powers at the start of the war. Instead, as the Hungarian government wavered in its support of Germany, Nazi troops occupied the country and a puppet regime was installed.

title: No Rest for Jets' Defense After the Bills Run Wild
description: There was no Victory Monday for the Jets today. Chad Morton's dazzling kickoff returns were good enough to salvage a 37-31 overtime victory over Buffalo on Sunday but not enough to salvage the day off that Coach Herman Edwards usually gives his players after a victory.

title: The Forecast Is the Usual But Different
description: IT'S warmer today than it has been of late. The temperature has climbed to the mid-80's, and the skies are overcast. They say it will rain before the day is through. Well, we could use it.

title: Joyous Serbs Revel in Basketball Title
description: Hundreds of thousands of Serbs took to the streets today, intoxicated with national pride after Yugoslavia's basketball team won a nail-biting world championship final over Argentina in Indianapolis on Sunday. Three fatal heart attacks were attributed to the excitement.

title: Dorothy A. deAraujo: Follower of Artistic Dream
description: An artistic longing stayed with Dorothy deAraujo from a childhood in Depression-era Chicago to a retirement spent painting in vivid colors in the Naples community of Long Beach, Calif.

title: What Lowell Really Saw When He Watched Venus
description: While an observatory in Arizona bears his name, Percival Lowell is best known for his obsession with Mars and his conviction that intelligent life had once existed on the planet.

title: Hopes Raised of Using Stem Cells For Treating Muscular Dystrophy
description: A rare natural experiment has given researchers hope of using stem cells to treat muscular dystrophy, a group of genetic diseases that cause progressive wasting of the muscles.

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PERSPECTIVES -- In Senate, a Call for Answers And a Warning on the Future; Focus on Iraq Criticized
description: Senator Bob Graham, the chairman of the Intelligence Committee, calls the Bush administration's focus on Iraq a distraction from the campaign against terrorism and lists Syria and Iran as countries that should be the first targets of any aggressive effort against state sponsors of terrorist activity.

title: Michael O'Brien: 'Didn't Believe in Shortcuts'
description: Pity anyone who fell asleep at one of Michael O'Brien's parties. A drowsy offender might wake up with a mascara mustache, hands full of shaving cream or, as his brother-in-law Don once discovered, shaved legs.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SENATORS SEEK MORE 9/11 AID Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton said yesterday that they would press the federal government for future aid to New York for its recovery from the terrorist attack last fall. In addition to seeking money to study the health of workers at ground zero, the senators said they had introduced legislation to extend unemployment insurance to June 1, 2003, for eligible New Yorkers, and would push legislation to forgive student loans for spouses of those killed or permanently disabled in the attack. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Martin Michael Wortley: Happy to Be 'Grumpy'
description: Among the ways Karen Wortley remembers her husband, the most visible must be the tattoo on her ankle  "Grumpy."

title: Michael C. Sorresse: Making a House a Home
description: e always had a plan and a project, and even the occasional Homer Simpson-like harebrained scheme," recalled Michael C. Sorresse's wife, Catherine. The best of these contributed to Mr. Sorresse's success at Marsh Inc., where, at 34, he was already a vice president. But there were also his small-scale ventures in real estate with his brothers, his long efforts to get his mother, Maria, and brother Lenny to eat healthy and his notorious home repair projects, most with mixed results.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Orders for new machinery, a leading gauge of private capital spending, unexpectedly rose in July, suggesting companies are continuing to bet on an economic recovery. Orders rose 1.9 percent in July from June, the fourth consecutive monthly gain. The last three gains have defied the predictions of analysts, who expected orders to decline. Japan's recovery thus far has been heavily reliant on exports, so continued growth in corporate capital spending could give the economy an extra push. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Parents Sue 14 Teenagers Over Son's Death
description: The parents of a Westchester County football player who died after being punched at an after-school drinking party sued 14 teenagers today, saying they caused their son's death through misconduct and negligence.

title: James Pappageorge: Dedicated to Saving People
description: As a boy, James Pappageorge was afraid of doctors. But he spent much of his adult life learning about medicine and saving people — as an emergency medical technician, then a paramedic and, finally, a firefighter. "He was always carrying books, and he was always enrolled in some sort of course," said Gina Pinos, his fiancée.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Terror Suspect Says He Lied To His Lawyer About Escape
description: A reputed senior aide to Osama bin Laden who pleaded guilty to stabbing a jail guard testified yesterday that he lied to his lawyer when he told him he had carried out the attack, in November 2000, in an attempt to escape from a jail in Lower Manhattan.

title: Venturing Outside Actors Studio (to Paris)
description: Having persuaded themselves that cinema should be about art, not money, France's educated elites have never disguised their disdain for much of what reaches French movie and television screens from the United States. Yet one American television show, ''Inside the Actors Studio,'' is quietly changing how some French view Hollywood by dwelling on the craft of acting rather than the glitter of stardom.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Fiber Optic Cuts
description: Telia will write down the value of assets at its fiber optic business and eliminate 400 jobs, or half the division's work force, leading to about 9.5 billion kronor ($1.01 billion) of costs in the third quarter. The job cuts, representing 2.4 percent of the 16,561 employees of Telia, will lead to costs of 3.5 billion kronor, mainly in the third quarter, the chief executive, Anders Igel, said. Telia will cut the value of assets at the fiber optic division, which runs a 40,000-kilometer network, by 6 billion kronor. The write-down may lead to a record loss this quarter, analysts said.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Voyage of the Darned

title: A Firm Adds Staff and Woos Veterans Back Into the Fold
description: Harsh as it must have seemed, Michael Murray thought he had no choice after Sept. 11 but to bring in another investment firm to help oversee $800 million in funds he had entrusted to Fred Alger Management.

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Contract Agreement
description: Workers and management at five of Waikiki's largest hotels have agreed to a tentative contract settlement, averting a strike that would have put 4,000 housekeepers, servers and other employees on the picket lines, dealing a blow to the state's struggling tourism industry. The four-year agreement will increase wages for workers by as much as 12 percent over the life of the contract and will increase pension contributions by almost 50 percent. It will also bring lower-paid subcontractors up to union scale over five years. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: A Primer on Fat, Some of It Good for You
description: While competing scientists argue furiously over whether eating fat leads to being fat, it is clear that many fat-laden foods carry serious health risks.

title: Police Say Son's Wife Was Focus Of Man's Ire
description: The enraged man who shot his way into his son's home in Massapequa Park and set it on fire Sunday morning had been feuding for years over family property and access to his grandchildren, the Nassau County police said today.

title: Grand Slam Is Therapy For Piazza
description: Mike Piazza walloped a grand slam tonight that jumped off his bat with a concussive crack and rolled into an exit ramp at Veterans Stadium -- the same massive concrete ballpark Piazza used to go to often as a boy.

title: A New and Difficult World for Frequent Fliers
description: It has been a tough year for business travelers. Here are first-person accounts by four frequent fliers of experiences they have had and adjustments they have made in the post-Sept. 11 A New and Difficult World for Frequent Fliers By THE NEW YORK TIMES

title: Ad Pages in Magazines Decreased in August
description: The number of advertising pages in magazines fell in August, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York, after pages increased in July for the first time since December 2000.

title: U.S. Raises Terror Alert Level
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 - President Bush ordered the country's military and civilian authorities to a high state of alert today, closing embassies abroad and putting surface-to-air missile batteries on alert around Washington. Officials said a Qaeda operative now in custody had warned that terror strikes against American facilities were planned for the Sept. 11 anniversary.

description: The nation's most secret appellate court met today, apparently for the first time in its 24-year history, to consider a request from the Justice Department for broad new wiretap powers, department officials said today.

Uzi Gal, 79, Israeli Arms Expert And Inventor of Submachine Gun
description: Uzi Gal, the Israeli armaments expert who invented the widely used 9-millimeter submachine gun called the Uzi, died on Saturday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, GLORIA
description: SILVERSTEIN - Gloria. On September 5. Beloved wife of the late George Silverstein. Devoted sister, aunt and friend to many. Gloria was a former model and entertainer who was devoted to many charitable organizations. She was most proud of her work for The Lighthouse and the Sutton area community. Family will receive friends on Tuesday, 2-4PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral services Wednesday, 1PM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: NEPAL: NEW MAOIST ATTACK In their second major attack in two days, Maoist rebels in Nepal killed 58 people in a remote town Sunday night, according to Reuters. Government officials said Maoists overran the town, Sandhikharka, about 185 miles west of Katmandu. On Saturday, 49 police officers were killed by Maoist rebels in eastern Nepal. The violence comes after a lull in rebel activity brought about by a successful government offensive in May. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about sermons that are focusing on Sept. 11 misstated the days on which Rabbi David H. Lincoln of the Park Avenue Synagogue planned to speak about it at Yom Kippur services. They are this Sunday and Monday, not Saturday.

description: STEIN-Adele E. On September 7, 2002. Wife of the late J. Zachary Stein. Sister of the late Clarence Epstein. Mother of Dr. Ann S. Roberts and Howard S. Stein. Grandmother of J Zachary and Luke Stein, Jennifer Mammen, Justine, Clement and Zachary Roberts. Great-grandmother of Eva Mammen. Funeral services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Friends may call Monday evening, 5-8 PM.

title: Westchester Votes Against Indian Point
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators passed a resolution tonight calling for the eventual closing of the Indian Point nuclear power plant, a move that both the plant's supporters and opponents were quick to claim as a victory.

title: Robert C. King Jr.: Fires and Furniture
description: Robert C. King Jr. was married on a Saturday and had to be back at the Fire Academy nine days later. On their honeymoon, the couple read academy manuals and practiced tying emergency knots. "For the nine years he was on the job, he always came home happy," Theresa King said.

title: Tunnel Vision; Eyes Meet, Hearts Flutter. Must Be the Subway.
description: It would have taken a great deal of poetic license last Friday night to describe the first car of the Manhattan-bound F train as a happening place, the place to meet that special someone.

title: The War on Civil Liberties
description: It would be easy to dismiss the harm that has been done to our civil liberties in the past year. Most of us do not know anyone whose rights have been seriously curtailed. The 1,200 detainees rounded up after Sept. 11 and held in secret were mainly Muslim men with immigration problems. So were the people the government tried to deport in closed hearings. The two Americans who were labeled ''enemy combatants,'' hustled off to military brigs and denied the right even to meet with a lawyer, are a Saudi-American man captured in Afghanistan and a onetime Chicago gang member.

title: Rulings on Primary's Eve Put 2 On State Senate Ballot in Bronx
description: After weeks of twists and turns, substitutions and deletions, there will be two candidates for the State Senate on the ballot today in the Democratic primary in the 32nd District in the Bronx.

title: Hewlett Takes A Step Forward In the World Of Tiny Chips
description: Researchers at Hewlett-Packard laboratories have developed a manufacturing process capable of producing molecular-scale circuits vastly denser than today's most advanced semiconductor chips.

title: Morton Laments Catch That Did Not Count
description: Chad Morton was bearing a scar from the play he was thinking about most today. The long gauze wrap, which covered an artificial-turf burn on his left arm, did not come from either of the kickoffs Morton returned for touchdowns against Buffalo on Sunday, but from a play that was not a touchdown.

title: Lisa M. King-Johnson: A Day Off for Kindergarten
description: Ayear ago today, Lisa King-Johnson's younger daughter, Katie, was starting kindergarten, and so she took the day off from her job at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods on the 89th floor of the World Trade Center's south tower. She got Katie dressed for school and was there waiting for her in the sunshine when everyone was ready to go home.

title: Tokyo Offers An Aid Plan For Its Banks
description: Desperate to defend the nation's banks from plunging share prices, Japanese lawmakers today introduced a plan to bolster the equity market, but critics say the plan erodes Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's credentials as a reformer.

title: At Disease Centers, a Shift In Mission and Metabolism
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is going through an uncomfortable metamorphosis, from an agency that focused on controlling naturally transmitted diseases to one heavily involved with bioterrorism and its possible effects on national security.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Maker In China Deal
description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world's largest supplier of made-to-order chips, will invest $898 million in its first chip factory in China. The company filed an application with the Taiwan government to build a factory in Shanghai that will have the capacity to turn out 35,000 8-inch silicon wafers a month. The move to the mainland will couple one of the world's largest chip makers with the third-largest market for semiconductors.

title: Text: Adm. Vern Clark, Chief of Naval Operations
description: Adm. Vern Clark, the chief of naval operations, has commanded the Carl Vinson carrier battle group and the United States Atlantic Fleet, and was director of the military's Joint Staff.

title: Houston Journal; City's Hurts Are Eased By Football
description: Oh, the insults. Mother Nature delivered the first more than a year ago with catastrophic flooding during Tropical Storm Allison. Then hometown Enron collapsed into bankruptcy and shame. Only last month the United States Olympics Committee dropped Houston as a candidate for host of the 2012 Games.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: VERIZON TO CUT DEBT Verizon Communications plans to reduce debt by 10 percent this year, Ivan Seidenberg, the chief executive, said yesterday. Net debt, or borrowing minus cash and equivalents, fell to $58.6 billion in June from $63.3 billion at the end of last year. A 10 percent reduction would cut that figure to $57 billion in December. Verizon had its first sales drop in two years last quarter as businesses and consumers canceled phone lines. Mr. Seidenberg reiterated a forecast that sales would be little changed or fall 1 percent this year. (Bloomberg News)

description: The foundation that runs the Apollo Theater in Harlem has held off plans for a large-scale performing arts center that was to have been centered on the historic theater, prompting the foundation's president and chief executive, Derek Q. Johnson, to resign.

title: F.B.I. Warns Local Agencies To Be Aware
description: The F.B.I. has issued an advisory to local authorities warning of possible terrorist attacks on the anniversary of Sept. 11, but senior government officials said today that the warnings were precautionary and not based on specific or credible threats.

It was 48, not 94. According to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, he still has 2,636,661 shares, not 129,000 -- plus 40,000 held for him by the company and in a trust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, RAY (KATZ)
description: GOLD-Ray (Katz). Of Fair Lawn, NJ, on September 5, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Max ''Larry'', cherished mother of Ava (Roger) Brown, Marion and Stanley, and loving grandmother of Taylor and Scott Brown. Her laughter and great strength live on in those she loved-and she lives on with her ''Larry'' for eternity. We know they will take care of each other. Love, Marion and Jerry

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: FALSE LOAN DATA The Ssangyong Corporation, the trading arm of the Ssangyong chaebol that fell apart during the Korean economic crisis of 1997 and 1998, falsified trade bills to obtain $95 million in loans from six banks, according to the Financial Supervisory Service, the agency that governs the Korean financial industry. The principal victim was the government-owned Cho Hung Bank, which provided more than half the loans and which took an equity stake of nearly 50 percent of the company in place of payment on the nonperforming loans. A Ssangyong executive, Choi Hyung Jin, said the company is refiling correct papers and acknowledged that two Ssangyong managers had been arrested.   Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Word Is Out: Hit Rams Hard and Often
description: No offense has been more productive or more pulverizing than the St. Louis Rams' over the last three seasons. But in their past two games -- the loss to New England in the Super Bowl and Sunday's slip-up against Denver -- the Rams scored 17 and 16 points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMPTON, LIONEL
description: HAMPTON-Lionel. The New York Republican County Committee will greatly miss its treasured friend and longtime Vice Chairman, Lionel Hampton. For 40 years, we have been blessed by Lionel's charm, devotion, and irrepressible goodness. He brought enduring music into the hearts of all those he touched: ''And those musicians who shall play to you hang in the air a thousand leagues from hence.'' William Shakespeare.

title: William O'Keefe: Watching Daughters Run
description: One night at a club in Staten Island, two young men approached two young women. They paired off and chatted for a few minutes, until one of the men whispered to his friend that he wanted to switch partners. So they did. And that is how William O'Keefe met his wife, Ginny.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Commack: Teller Charged With Stealing Nearly $700,000
description: A Levittown man has been charged with grand larceny after stealing almost $700,000 from the Commack bank where he worked as a teller, the Suffolk County police said. The suspect, James Lin, 26, was arrested Sunday at a motel in Roslyn, where the authorities said he was staying under an assumed name. Mr. Lin stole the money from the safe and from his teller's draw at the HSBC Bank on Route 25 last Friday, before other employees arrived, the police said. Officers from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the United States Marshals Service and the Suffolk and Nassau County Police Departments were involved in the investigation. The money, minus about $300, was recovered. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: For Coach Burns and the Devils, It's a Clean Sheet of Ice
description: Since being named coach of the Devils nearly three months ago, Pat Burns has resisted the urge to throw in the videotapes of last season's team.

title: Market Place; Siebel Systems picks up the pieces from the bubble by salvaging sunken options.
description: ONE leftover of the burst bubble in technology stocks is the existence of millions of employee stock options that are far out of the money. Such options provide little in the way of incentive for employees to stay, and companies have looked for ways to change that without outraging existing shareholders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNDORF, RUTH BLUM BERG
description: TURNDORF - Ruth Blum berg. Bridgewater, NJ. The legal assistant to the legal department of the city of Paterson for 35 years, died on September 8th. She was 94. Ruth was the wife of prominent attorney Charles Turndorf. Born in New York City, Ruth was raised on the lower east side. After her marriage, she and her husband moved to Paterson, NJ. She and Charles then moved to Hackensack, spending their winters in West Palm Beach, FL. She is survived by her sons, Dr. Herman Turndorf of Miami, FL, recently retired chairman of anesthesiology at NYU School of Medicine, and Gary Turndorf of Skillman, NJ; sister Lilian Izenberg of Wayne, NJ; six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to Cancer Care of New Jersey, 141 Dayton Street, Ridgewood, NJ 07450, where Ruth was a longtime volunteer. Please write on the memo line ''In Memory of Ruth Turndorf.''

title: Marsh & McLennan Is Maintaining a Policy of Silence
description: When the first plane hit the north tower of the World Trade Center last September 294 employees of Marsh & McLennan were working in offices on the upper floors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCELROY, PATRICIA H.
description: McELROY-Patricia H., on September 8, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Robert E. Loving mother of Anne, Robert, Jr., Mary and Matt. Graduate of Mt. St. Mary's Academy and Georgian Court College in New Jersey. Longtime parishioner of St. Andrew's. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Grieving New Yorkers Witness the Changing Face of Ground Zero
description: For the most part, the mood on the part of Liberty Street with the view of ground zero is solemn. It is often quiet enough to hear the cameras clicking as the crowds, overwhelmingly from out of town, shuffle along. But Jeff Pucillo, 35, and Carl Palmer, 42, broke that silence yesterday. Since 9 a.m., the two, New York actors standing there, had been reading from a book of brief portraits of those killed in the attack that had been published in The New York Times.

title: Liberty Bonds to Finance New Brooklyn Offices
description: A new Brooklyn office tower to be built by Forest City Ratner Companies and occupied by the Bank of New York will be the first commercial construction project to be financed by Liberty Bonds, which were approved by Congress in response to the Sept. 11 attacks, city and state officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COCHRAN, ELISABETH NASH
description: COCHRAN-Elisabeth Nash, of Plainfield, NJ, died on September 7, 2002. Widow of Homer P. Cochran. Surviving are three sons: The Rev. Fergus Cochran of Dorset, VT, Thomas N. Cochran of Far Hills, NJ and James W. Cochran of Johnstown, PA; five grandchildren; and two greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Crescent Ave. Presbyterian Church, Plainfield, on Saturday, October 19, at 11 AM.

title: Bank of America Asks Agencies to Compete
description: Bank of America in Charlotte, N.C., asked the parent companies of agencies that work for it to assemble teams to compete for assignments that make up most of its account, with spending estimated at $165 million to $170 million.

title: The scars that remain : OUR READERS REMEMBER
description: September 11, 2001: Wherever we are, wherever we were, we can remember what we were doing when we heard the news. Responding to the IHT's request to share experiences, nearly 200 readers have offered poetry and prose, photographs and artwork as their testimony about events that defied belief. The selections have been edited to permit the use of as many as possible; we are sorry that we cannot print each one.

title: U.S., Citing Better Human Rights, Allows Aid to Colombia Military
description: The Bush administration released about $42 million in aid to the Colombian military today after determining that there was enough improvement in its human rights record to meet Congressional requirements for such aid.

title: Penny in Their Thoughts: 2 Camps Debate New Look for Coins
description: Change is good. But changing change, as the United States Mint is finding out, may prove to be tricky business.

title: Critic's Notebook; An Audacious Thinker With a Passion for Prints
description: The most magnetic historians, the ones we keep coming back to for the sound of their voices as much as for their exacting scholarship, do funny things with history. They demystify and dramatize it, record it and shape it, approach it objectively but react to it with complex, proprietary emotions: desire, amusement, exasperation.

title: Lawmakers Urge Justice Dept. Inquiry of Stewart's Statements
description: ACongressional committee said this afternoon that it has "strongly suggested" to the Justice Department that it investigate whether Martha Stewart made false statements during the panel's inquiry into Ms. Stewart's trading of ImClone Systems shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, CATHERINE GRACE
description: SMITH - Catherine Grace. Passed away peacefully September 2, 2002 at New York University Medical Center. Catherine held a Master's Degree in Nursing Education, she was project manager and director of Day Surgery at New York University Medical Center until retirement. Memorial Mass, September 12, 2002, 10:30AM Church of the Sacred Hearts, 307 E. 33 St. Friends are invited. Donations to the American Cancer Society in lieu of flowers.

title: Maurita Tam: Awesome, but With a Giggle
description: Perfect was not quite the right word for Maurita Tam of Staten Island. After all, she flunked her first driving test.

description: One of President Vladimir V. Putin's top national security aides suffered head and chest injuries in a deadly auto accident today on a rain-slicked road in Russia's Far East, and was to be flown to Moscow for further treatment, Russian television and news services reported.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Counterterrorism Chief Appointed
description: The state attorney general, David Samson, announced yesterday that a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation would take over as director of the New Jersey Office of Counterterrorism. The former agent, Sidney J. Caspersen, 54, will succeed Kathryn Flicker as head of the agency responsible for passing security information to the state attorney general's office. Mr. Caspersen was with the F.B.I. for 25 years before leaving the agency in May to become deputy director of the New York State Office of Public Safety. He begins his new position on Oct. 1.

title: Text: Gen. John P. Jumper, Air Force Chief of Staff
description: Gen. John P. Jumper, the Air Force chief of staff, served two tours as a fighter pilot in Southeast Asia, and was the senior military assistant to then-Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. He commanded American Air Forces in Europe during the 1999 air war in Kosovo.

description: These interviews are the seventh and eighth of a series in which national and world figures reflect on the terrorist attacks and their effect on a year of public life and policy.

title: Scotland Is Cut Adrift By the Faroe Islands
description: There is still more than a year of qualifying matches to be played before the 2004 European championships, but it would be hard to tell from the splenetic reaction in Scotland to the national team's 2-2 draw against the Faroe Islands (ranked No. 123 by FIFA) last Saturday.

title: Race for Governor Grows Tighter, Drawing Attention
description: A few weeks ago, most experts expected Connecticut's race for governor to remain a largely perfunctory exercise for John G. Rowland, a confident and well-financed two-term Republican incumbent who was considered almost invincible on Election Day.

title: THE POINTS PILE UP
description: Back in the safety and relative sanity of his Nashville office, the Tennessee Titans' general manager, Floyd Reese, exhaled and began chronicling the madness that visited the N.F.L. on its opening weekend.

description: EUNIVERSE, Los Angeles, an interactive entertainment network, said it had acquired the assets of privately held ResponseBase, Los Angeles, an online marketing company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: False Loan Data
description: The Ssangyong Corporation, the trading arm of the Ssangyong chaebol that fell apart during the Korean economic crisis of 1997 and 1998, falsified trade bills to obtain $95 million in loans from six banks, according to the Financial Supervisory Service, the agency that governs the Korean financial industry. The principal victim was the government-owned Cho Hung Bank, which provided more than half the loans and which took an equity stake of nearly 50 percent of the company in place of payment on the nonperforming loans. A Ssangyong executive, Choi Hyung Jin, said the company is refiling correct papers and acknowledged that two Ssangyong managers had been arrested. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an interview with Jacques Chirac including his perspectives on the Iraqi threat of weapons of mass destruction misstated the timing of Israel's destruction of Iraq's French-supplied nuclear reactor. It occurred in 1981, not 1979.

title: Tower at Financial Center Changes Hands for a Song
description: A major downtown skyscraper is changing hands for a surprisingly low price, in what may be the latest indication of how steeply property values have dropped in Lower Manhattan in the last year.

title: QAEDA FIGHTERS SAID TO RETURN TO AFGHANISTAN
description: United States intelligence officials say Qaeda operatives who found refuge in Pakistan are starting to regroup and move back into Afghanistan, less than a year after a successful American military campaign forced them to flee their onetime sanctuary by the thousands.

title: Investigators Are Said to Support Wells's Account of Diner Assault
description: A senior New York police official said yesterday that investigators believed Yankees pitcher David Wells was not the aggressor in a fracas in an Upper East Side diner that came hours after he pitched a complete-game victory Friday night in the Bronx.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: NIGERIA: STONING SENTENCE STANDS The government of Katsina state, the home of Amina Lawal, who was convicted by an Islamic court of having sex outside wedlock, will not intervene to overturn her sentence of death by stoning, a spokesman said. The fate of Ms. Lawal, 30, now rests solely with her legal appeals, as the federal government has also refused to gainsay the court. The decision is a blow for rights campaigners and organizers of the Miss World contest, who had hoped the issue might be settled early in order to head off protests from beauty contestants in Lagos, where the event is to take place in November. (Reuters)

title: Last Word on Finals For the U.S. Open
description: Mary Carillo and John McEnroe analyzed the men's and women's finals of the United States Open for CBS, but they were only effective in one of them, Pete Sampras's four-set victory over Andre Agassi on Sunday. In that match, they were superb diagnosticians, maintaining a running commentary on Sampras's superiority through the first two sets, and Agassi's mysterious lethargy.

title: Waiting for Takeoff, Designers Offer a Peek of Spring
description: It seems contradictory now, but there was a time not long ago when designing clothes seemed like a very melancholy job. Following the terrorist attacks on New York last year, ''Everything I was making was severe,'' the designer Peter Som said last week. The clothes he created for this fall, Mr. Som said, ''attempted to convey strength and protection as a reaction to everything that was going on.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPIN, LEE (LEAH)
description: LAPIN-Lee (Leah). Age 85, of Sarasota, FL, died September 6, 2002. She was born November 16, 1916, in Paris, France and moved to Sarasota from the New York area in 1988. A widow of the late William Lapin. Survivors include a daughter, Lucy L. Lapides of Lakewood Ranch, FL, a son, Philip of Frenchtown, NJ, four grandchildren one greatgrandson. Services will be private. Memorial donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association or a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Linking Deadly Cancer and Diet
description: Women who are sedentary and significantly overweight may have a higher risk of developing pancreatic cancer if their diets are high in starchy foods like potatoes and rice, researchers have found.

title: On Plotters' Path to U.S., A Stop at bin Laden Camp
description: On Nov. 29, 1999, a 31-year-old architecture student in Germany named Mohamed Atta, unknown to the world but already determined to strike an unforgettable blow against those he believed to be his enemies, boarded Turkish Airlines Flight 1662 from Istanbul to Karachi, Pakistan. Mr. Atta took at least a couple of days to reach his final destination: a training camp in Afghanistan run by Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's sprawling international terrorist organization.

title: Weapons Development Called Iraq's Priority
description: Iraq has sizable stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons and could quickly expand their production, but will be unable to build a nuclear weapon for years unless it obtains radioactive material on the black market, a leading research organization said today.

title: WARNACO SEEKS APPROVAL FOR PLAN TO CLOSE STORES
description: The Warnaco Group is asking a federal bankruptcy judge to approve its plan to close 26 Calvin Klein outlet stores and liquidate the inventory. Warnaco, the maker of Calvin Klein jeans, Speedo swimsuits and Olga bras, filed for Chapter 11 protection in June 2001, hurt by the slowing economy and heavy debt from acquisitions and licensing agreements. The company, based in New York, is selling assets in a bid to reorganize and come out of bankruptcy. In court papers filed Friday, the company asked Judge Richard L. Bohanon in Manhattan for permission to close the Calvin Klein outlets in 13 states, saying the stores were either unprofitable or ''marginally performing.'' A hearing on Warnaco's plan to close the outlets is scheduled for Sept. 17.

title: Torre Has 4 Bases to Touch Before the Postseason Arrives
description: There is very little intrigue in the Yankees' remaining schedule. The Baltimore Orioles and the Tampa Bay Devil Rays each appear seven more times, the Detroit Tigers and the Chicago White Sox three. Another American League East title will soon belong to the Yankees, and there is nothing glamorous about their opponents.

description: In percent
