description: In the garden of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, high adventure is unfolding in the mountain defiles leading from ancient China to India.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Cross-Dresser Quits Race
description: A candidate for sheriff in La Plata County has dropped out of the race after acknowledging that he killed a New Mexico teenager while dressed as a woman. The candidate, Robert Bouslaugh, 56, shot and killed an 18-year-old in Albuquerque in late August. He said the man had kidnapped and robbed him while he was wearing women's clothing for an undercover assignment. Mr. Bouslaugh has been questioned by the Albuquerque police, who said they could not find evidence of an undercover assignment. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Cattle Disaster Still Felt in Britain
description: Caroline Macaulay still recalls how it felt to see the investment of her lifetime's savings brought low by last year's outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, which scared tourists away for months from places like her country guest house in the Lake District.

title: Douglas Oelschlager: A Family on a Motorboat
description: Sometimes Douglas Oelschlager's consuming twin loves  his family and fighting fires  conflicted. "I used to tell him all the time to get your priorities straight," said his wife of 13 years, Suzanne. It wasn't easy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Jury Selection Begins In Louima Trial
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the fourth trial of Charles Schwarz, a former police officer charged with taking part in the assault of Abner Louima in 1997 in the bathroom of a Brooklyn police station house. Court officials said 310 people answered jury summonses yesterday and filled out lengthy questionnaires asking such questions as whether they had formed views about Mr. Schwarz's guilt or innocence. Mr. Schwarz, left, was convicted of one perjury count by a jury that deadlocked on three other charges in July. Two earlier convictions of Mr. Schwarz were overturned in February. Testimony in the new trial is expected to begin on Sept. 23. William Glaberson (NYT)

description: ''New employees come up to me and say, 'You know, people here have issues,' '' says Howard W. Lutnick, the chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, reflecting on life today inside Cantor, the bond trading firm that lost more people in the Sept. 11 attacks than any other American company. ''And I say, 'I know. Me, too.' ''

title: Springsteen in Paris
description: It's not Asbury Park, but for Bruce Springsteen fans, Paris should do nicely instead. That's where he will present a concert on Oct. 14. Adventures in Rock, based in Brookline, Mass., has a weekend tour package Oct. 12 to 15 that includes three nights' accommodations in the Hotel du Pantheon in the Latin Quarter with daily breakfast, a guided walking tour of the neighborhood, a ticket to the concert at the Palais Omnisports and transportation to and from the show. The price is $825 a person, based on double occupancy. For information: (877) 788-7625 or on the Web at www.adventuresinrock.com .

title: Flying as a Statement Of Defiance to Terror
description: WE may count Tancred Agius as a no-show for tomorrow's stage-managed commemorations of the anniversary of last September's terrorist attacks. Mr. Agius, who sells advertising in the Yellow Pages to national clients, has bigger fish to fry.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Pageant Winner In Court
description: Rebekah Revels, one of two claimants to the title of Miss North Carolina, will return to the state today from Atlantic City to testify in federal court against pageant organizers. Ms. Revels, who resigned as Miss North Carolina when word surfaced that she might have been photographed topless, has asked Judge James Fox of Federal District Court to issue an order making her the sole state finalist, saying her resignation had been coerced. A state court judge's order sent her to the Miss America pageant with Misty Clymer, the runner-up, who was given the title upon Ms. Revels's resignation.

title: Wai C. Chung: Abiding Gentleness, and Wit
description: Wai C. Chung was quiet and painfully shy  if a stranger said good morning, he'd be flummoxed  but neither quality muffled his abiding gentleness. "You couldn't not like him," recalled Jon Worth, his boss at UBS PaineWebber in Weehawken, N.J., where Mr. Chung, 36, was a vice president. His co-workers have not had the heart to touch his desk, or take down the cards that poured in.

title: AOL Expects Internet Ads To Be Weak
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that advertising on its flagship online service this year will be 6 percent lower than its previous forecast, a drop of $100 million. As a result the unit's pretax operating profit will also be $100 million below its expectations. But the media conglomerate said that its other businesses were performing modestly better than expected and that it would meet its current profit and revenue targets for the rest of the year.

title: Kenneth Albert Zelman: Inseparable From Daughter
description: Kenneth Albert Zelman and his daughter, Olivia, had their routines. When Mr. Zelman walked through the door of his house in Succasunna, N.J., Olivia, who will be 5 in November, would throw her arms around him and say, "Daddy's home." When Mr. Zelman put Olivia to bed, they would make up stories and tell them to each other.

title: Webber Indicted On Charge Of Lying
description: Chris Webber, one of the National Basketball Association's premier players, was indicted yesterday in Detroit on charges that he lied to a grand jury about a financial arrangement with a University of Michigan booster more than 10 years ago.

title: Democrats, Using Finesse, Try to Neutralize the Gun Lobby's Muscle
description: Senator Jean Carnahan, the Missouri Democrat, pulled out her 20-gauge Browning Citori shotgun the other day and fired off a few rounds as part of a skeet-shoot benefit for a home state research center.

description: FText: Blair's Address in Britain

title: It Isn't Easy, but Sandler Thrives
description: When the workday is over and business distractions end, the people at Sandler O'Neill & Partners find they cannot keep the memories of Sept. 11 at bay. The terrorist attacks that day claimed the lives of 66 of the company's 171 employees.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Kansas City; Border-Hopping, Barbecue and Rolling Hills
description: Border-hopping is a part of daily life in Kansas City, which is at the intersection of the Kansas and Missouri Rivers and divided by the boundary between the two states. Many locals live in one state and work in the other. And as a traveler you are likely to visit both states without ever realizing you have crossed a border. Regardless of which side you're on, you'll see green rolling hills and smell the crisp Midwestern air.

title: Security and Freedom
description: When we look back at how our country has handled the last year, we have much to be hugely proud of -- and, perhaps, one thing to be just a bit embarrassed about.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BRITISH ENERGY FALLS Shares in the nuclear power generator British Energy lost two-thirds of their value after the government gave it a £410 million ($639 million) bail-out loan until Sept. 27. British Energy has until that date to come up with financing to avert bankruptcy, the Department of Trade and Industry said. The formerly state-owned company, sold to investors in 1996, generates one-fifth of Britain's electricity from eight nuclear power stations. Earlier this year it reported an annual loss of $780 million. Trading in British Energy shares was suspended last week after the company said it was negotiating with the government to avoid insolvency. The shares fell by as much as 68 percent, to 27.75 pence (43.24 U.S. cents) when trading resumed.   Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Lillian Frederick: A Modest Woman of Faith
description: At Aon Corporation , where Lillian Frederick was an administrative assistant, her colleagues heard only a few tales from the warm, serene woman who was an office presence, but hardly its social butterfly. They heard the reactions of Ms. Frederick, a native Manhattanite, after she and her husband, Henry Lambert, bought a house in Teaneck, N.J. Flowers had to be . . . planted? In the dirt? With all those slugs?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, GEORGE B.
description: ADLER-George B. Of Harrison, NY and Boca Raton, FL died on September 9, 2002 at 76. Beloved husband of Marion, cherished father of Gary, Andre' and Roger and his wife Vicki, proud grandfather of Jason and Spencer. A native of Switzerland, who graduated from the top Swiss business school with an MBA, George came to NY in 1952. He was first an analyst with Loeb Rhodes and later with Smith Barney, rising to managing director and member of the steering committee. He was voted a star analyst for an unprecedented sixteen consecutive years. Funeral services will be held at 10 a.m. on Thursday, September 12, at the Zion Memorial Chapel, Mamaroneck, NY. 914381-1809. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Cardiovascular Institute of Mount Sinai Hospital or UJA.

title: Thomas Moody: Fire Officer and Engineer
description: Captain Thomas Moody loved to give people "the elbow." He would be telling a joke, kidding someone, and if they didn't get it right away, "he would give you the elbow in the ribs," said his wife, Maureen. "He loved to tease."

title: The Plot Leaders and Lingering Questions
description: A year after Sept. 11 investigators are still struggling to piece together the planning, preparation and connections between the leaders of the attacks. Below, the suspected leaders, some of what the authorities have revealed and questions they continue to try to answer. SARAH SLOBIN

description: New York City's morning ceremony at ground zero and the evening ceremony at Battery Park tomorrow are closed to the public, but they will be broadcast live on television and radio.

description: Gen. James L. Jones, the Marine Corps commandant, has commanded the 2d Marine Division and was senior military assistant to Defense Secretary William Cohen. He has been nominated by President Bush to be NATO's supreme allied commander.

title: Giants' Running Game Getting Nowhere Slow
description: No matter which philosophy you embrace the run sets up the pass, or the pass sets up the run -- there is one constant in pro football: you can't win consistently if you can't run.

title: Eyes on Future, Hearts in Past
description: The candle wax that used to add two inches to the sidewalk has long been scraped off. Inside the firehouse, the walls have been coated with a fresh layer of off-white paint, and the kitchen has been refurbished with new cabinets. Most of the lockers -- walk-in spaces, really -- have been emptied out and reassigned. And half of the faces are new, forming a low-key junior fraternity that is more likely to melt into the scenery than the previous crew of cut-ups and free spirits.

title: Aventis Loses Crawfish Ruling
description: Aventis must face hundreds of claims by crawfish farmers who say that the company, which makes pharmaceuticals, produced a pesticide that wiped out their catch, a Louisiana appellate court has ruled.

title: WAL-MART REPORTS A RISE IN SALES FOR THE WEEK
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, said yesterday that sales last week at stores open at least a year rose within the company's forecast as consumers bought back-to-school supplies and clothing. Wal-Mart, the discount retailer, had forecast an increase of 4 to 6 percent for September, said a spokesman, Tom Williams. He was not more specific about results. Sales at Wal-Mart's Sam's Club warehouse stores will be better than the 1.1 percent increase last month, he said. Wal-Mart said last week that August sales were less than expected, the second consecutive month that sales were below the company's forecast.

title: Cardinal Lucas Moreira Neves, 76, Once a Papal Contender
description: Cardinal Lucas Moreira Neves, one of Latin America's leading Roman Catholic figures, who was once considered a contender to succeed Pope John Paul II, died in Rome on Sunday. He was 76.

title: John Sbarbaro: A Knack for Getting a Laugh
description: On birthdays, John Sbarbaro sent sympathy cards, said Kathy Pinto, his sister. When he went to Florida for the Mets' spring training, he and his friends played the kazoo and led cheers and danced. Every year the local newspaper ran a photo of them with the same caption: "The Crazy Guys From Brooklyn."

title: Charles A. Zion: Family, Company and Golf
description: Charles A. Zion loved his job as executive vice president at Cantor Fitzgerald, and he loved golf. "It was hard to get him out of there," said his wife of 20 years, Carole. "When he started to play golf, I thought that was a good thing for him, because it gave him another focus." Mrs. Zion took up golf as well, as did their son, Zachary, 19.

title: Carlos Dominguez: Deeply Shared Values
description: There was always enough room for a Christmas tree and a menorah in the Dominguez living room in December. The holidays reflected a commitment that Carlos Dominguez and his wife, Maureen, made to each other in 1991 — a wedding ceremony presided over by both a priest and a rabbi, and with the blessings of both families. "When you got down to it," Mrs. Dominguez said, "our values were the same."

title: Blair Says 'Action Will Follow' Should Iraq Spurn Resolutions
description: LONDON, Sept. 10  Prime Minister Tony Blair today took on British critics of his hard-line stance on Iraq, pledging to work for a solution through the United Nations and not to take any action without submitting the case to Parliament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, FLORENCE
description: KLEIN-Florence. 90, passed away August 31, 2002, in Boca Raton, FL. She was the mother of Sandy (Sara Ann) Kane, of Boynton Beach, FL, and Herbert Klein of Aspen, CO. Florence, the daughter of David and Dora Pollock, was born and raised in the Bronx, NY. She was married to Jack Klein, of Jersey City, NJ, who preceeded her in death. Florence and Jack made their home on Teaneck, NJ, where they ran the Plaza Youth Center Clothing Store for over 30 years. Florence was active in community and Jewish organizations and was a life-long member of Hadassah, and member of the National Council of Jewish Women. She was an accomplished concert violinist, an avid reader, and speaker on Jewish history and contemporary issues. She is survived by her son-in-law, Stephen Kane, of Boynton Beach, FL., her daughter-in-law, Marsha Klein, of Aspen, CO, and her grandsons, Matthew Kane, Daniel Kane, and Evan Klein. Contributions in her honor may be made to your local chapter of Hadassah.

title: A New and Difficult World for Frequent Fliers
description: It has been a tough year for business travelers. Here are first-person accounts by four frequent fliers of experiences they have had and adjustments they have made in the post-Sept. 11 world.

title: Newfoundland:Newfound love : OUR READERS REMEMBER
description: September 11, 2001: Wherever we are, wherever we were, we can remember what we were doing when we heard the news. Responding to the IHT's request to share experiences, nearly 200 readers have offered poetry and prose, photographs and artwork as their testimony about events that defied belief. The selections have been edited to permit the use of as many as possible; we are sorry that we cannot print each one.

title: Oil Companies Receive Saudi Ultimatum
description: Saudi Arabia has moved to end a yearlong deadlock with the world's biggest oil companies over a $25 billion project to develop some of its largest natural gas fields, asking the companies to decide by early October whether to continue talks under new, arguably more risky, conditions.

title: Real Battles and Empty Metaphors
description: Since last Sept. 11, the Bush administration has told the American people that America is at war. But this war is of a peculiar nature. It seems to be, given the nature of the enemy, a war with no foreseeable end. What kind of war is that?

title: Changing Times, Changing Strategies
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Where They Were
description: Sometimes a single, awful event can stop and shake a nation so thoroughly that, years later, all its citizens can recall precisely where they were and what they were doing when they heard the news.

title: The Capital City Becomes a Fortress
description: The look of Washington today has changed, with its visible signs of increased security.

title: A DNA Match Reveals Zinfandel's Parent
description: THE great zinfandel mystery has been solved. No, really.

title: WHERE THEY WERE: Frozen in Memory, the First Moments of a Transformed World -- Condoleezza Rice; National security adviser
description: Sometimes a single, awful event can stop and shake a nation so thoroughly that, years later, all its citizens can recall precisely where they were and what they were doing when they heard the news. Dec. 7, 1941, was such a day. So was Nov. 22, 1963. Now there is Sept. 11, 2001.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Suspect In Girls' Killing Goes To Court
description: Protesters threw eggs and plastic bottles at a police van carrying Ian Huntley, 28, after he appeared in court for the first time charged with the murder last month of two 10-year-old girls, Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman -- a crime that transfixed Britain. Mr. Huntley, a former school caretaker, is undergoing psychiatric tests and was ordered by the court in Peterborough, central England, to spend a further 28 days in a high security hospital. His companion, Maxine Carr, 25, has been charged with conspiring to pervert the course of justice in connection with the killings. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Resilience And Grief: 365 Days
description: From ground zero to the Pentagon to Shanksville, Pa. From Wabash, Ind., to Dearborn, Mich., to Ghazni, Afghanistan. A Nation Challenged, a two-part special section, looks at the new age of terror one year later: the human toll -- the faces and names of most of the 3,025 victims -- and the effort to learn to live with death as a constant companion.

title: Your Stories, Your Tributes
description: Over the last year, we have asked readers their stories about Sept. 11. This article comprises messages from survivors, witnesses and loved ones of those who died.

title: Firefighters' Pain of Loss
description: In October and November, the major symptom we saw was the pain of losing a friend. It was a few months after Sept. 11 that we began to see other symptoms. Sleep disturbance is No. 1. Virtually everybody in the Fire Department has had that symptom at some point this year. It varies from not being able to fall asleep to falling asleep for two or three hours and waking up to having nightmares so distressing you don't want to go back to sleep.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MILLER, ROBERT ALAN
description: MILLER-Robert Alan. 6/2/559/11/01. Dear Rob, It's hard to believe a year has gone by. We love you and miss your smiling face, your laughter and all your oneliners you delivered with such grace! Your spirit lives on in everything we do. We know you are watching over us and that gives us strength. You will always be in our hearts. Hugs and kisses from your loving family, Faith, Dina and Melanie.

title: Gallo to Acquire Premium Napa Valley Winery
description: E.& J. Gallo, the world's largest wine producer, has agreed to acquire the Louis M. Martini Winery of St. Helena, Calif., one of the oldest premium wineries in the Napa Valley. Terms of the deal, announced late Monday, were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLKIN, ANDREW
description: GOLKIN-Andrew. November 3, 1970-September 11, 2001. Dearest Andy, forever in our hearts, we miss your beautiful smile and generous heart. Love, Mom, Dad and Susan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 2 about William Dean Singleton, chief executive of the newspaper company MediaNews Group, misstated the ratio of the company's debt to its cash flow for its 2002 fiscal year. Based on estimated debt of $955 million and estimated cash flow of $150 million to $160 million, the ratio is between 5.9 and 6.3 -- not about 7.

title: Wines of the Week
description: Want to experience Bordeaux but don't know where to start? The Cazes family has the answer.

title: Intelligence and Politics Ratchet Up Color Wheel
description: President Bush's decision to move the nation to a heightened terrorist alert represented the convergence of new intelligence reports and political factors that really left the White House with no other choice.

title: Sailors Enter Degree Program at SUNY Maritime
description: Some 250 sailors began charting a course for college this summer, thanks to the new ''Seaman to Admiral-21'' program at State University of New York Maritime College in Throgs Neck. The program enables qualified Navy personnel to receive full tuition toward a bachelor of engineering or science degree. Maritime College also offers a program leading to work in the Navy's nuclear power program. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: McDonald's Fat Debate Goes On
description: MCDONALD'S scored a brilliant marketing coup last week by reducing the level of artery-clogging trans fatty acids and saturated fats in the oil it uses for frying, and it didn't pay a nickel for the reams of favorable publicity that followed.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: INSURER PLANS SHARE OFFERING Legal and General , the British life insurer, said that it would raise 786 million ($1.17 billion) from a sale of new shares to offset stock market declines and falling profits. The insurer said it would issue as many as 1.3 billion shares at 60 pence each, a 47 percent discount to Monday's closing price. The issue is expected to be completed by Oct. 22. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Its Ranks Depleted, A Weary Fire Dept. Is Trying to Regroup
description: There are several ways to describe how the past 12 months have gone for the New York City Fire Department, and none of them are good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, WILLIAM
description: SCHWARTZ - William. The Board of Governors and members of the Falls Country Club, Lake Worth, FL., acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, William Schwartz. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Marlene and their family. Elliott Solomon, President

title: Our Towns; For Better And Worse, Life Goes On
description: THAT morning, the controlled chaos of the New Jersey Turnpike turned haywire. Cars were abandoned. Doors were flung open.

title: One Miss North Carolina Pleads Her Case
description: They began with the basics.

title: In a Stricken Big City, a Small Town Sees Itself
description: NEW YORK has a way of making small-town people feel small. For those who grow up here in northern Indiana, where towns like Wabash seem stranded in a limitless sea of corn, the city can be overwhelming.

title: THE ALERT AND THE DAY
description: No Assessment of Iraq

title: For This Guy, Gelato Is the Answer
description: AT first glance, Il Laboratorio del Gelato seems like your standard-issue hipper-than-thou storefront on the Lower East Side: the paint is blinding white, the equipment is brand-new and the guy who owns it, Jon F. Snyder, is a babe. But this babe's mother and cousin are standing in the back, side by side, cutting up nectarines for the sorbet.

title: Ramallah Journal; 'Moonlight' and Mendelssohn in the West Bank
description: The old Steinway grand had seen better days, but when Daniel Barenboim drew the first nostalgic notes of Beethoven's ''Moonlight'' Sonata from it today, 200 neatly uniformed Palestinian students froze in delight.

title: Democrats Regain Edge In Nassau
description: Nassau Democrats recaptured a precarious one-member majority in the County Legislature tonight, winning a special election to fill a vacant seat and putting their party back in control.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Adoptions By Gay Couples Approved
description: The country's highest court ruled that gay and lesbian couples can adopt children. The ruling by the Constitutional Court affirmed a lower court ruling striking down provisions of two laws that barred such adoptions. The high court said that a child could receive proper care and support from a same-sex couple and that in prohibiting such adoptions the laws failed to consider adequately the interests of the child. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: You Can't Judge A Loaf of Bread By Its Crust
description: Broccoli rabe sauted with garlic and olive oil is delicious on its own. Then there's what Rocco Tocci, right, the owner of Pane d'Italia in Whitestone, Queens, does with it. He adds it to bread dough.

title: Hong Kong Issues Report On a Fiasco In the Market
description: A government-appointed panel of inquiry concluded today that some officials had made errors in connection with the issuance of a trading proposal that set off a steep decline among penny stocks here, angering many investors.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Making Cars Again
description: The Daewoo Motor Company announced that it would resume making cars again today after a crucial supplier, Korea Delphi Automotive System, agreed to resume shipping parts. Daewoo suspended production on Aug. 28 when Korea Delphi and 190 other suppliers demanded payment of several hundred million dollars. The carmaker said it had agreed to repay some bills. The resumption of production was expected to speed the inauguration of GM-Daewoo Auto and Technology, the company that General Motors has set up to take over Daewoo's plants in Korea and some overseas sites. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Refusing To Give In Without A Fight
description: ON the morning of Sept. 11, United Flight 93 was scheduled to depart Newark at 8:01 for San Francisco. At least 15 of the 40 passengers and crew members decided to fly at the last minute or switched from another flight. Some passengers were on business trips; others were taking a late vacation; others were on personal missions, like John Talignani of Staten Island, who was retrieving the remains of a stepson who had been killed in an automobile accident while on his honeymoon.

title: JACK IN THE BOX SAYS FOURTH-QUARTER PROFIT WILL FALL
description: Jack in the Box Inc. said its fourth-quarter profit would fall because rival hamburger chains were luring away customers with lower prices. Profit will be about 34 cents a share in the quarter, which ends this month, compared with a prior estimate of 67 cents, Jack in the Box said. The company, which is based in San Diego, earned 52 cents in the year-earlier period. Sales at restaurants open at least a year are expected to fall 3 percent in the quarter, compared with a 3.8 percent increase in the year-earlier period. Sales were hurt after a slowdown in consumer spending prompted competitors like Wendy's International and McDonald's to promote low-price menus, investors said.

title: Yankees Won't Punish Wells For Role in After-Hours Fight
description: After conducting an investigation into pitcher David Wells's fight in an Upper East Side diner early Saturday, the Yankees determined yesterday that they would not discipline him. Wells will make his scheduled start tomorrow.

title: A Pause to Bind Up the Wound in Our Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Still New York, in All Its Pain and Glory
description: NOTHING has been forgotten. That could never be. But things go on, start anew, revert to some mean. Even on the E train downtown, where the stations still advise, ''To World Trade Center all times,'' and the conductors intone, ''E train to World Trade.'' One year after it faced its own mortality, New York, in its daily curiosities and unexpungeable flavor, is still New York. For some time, no one knew if that could happen.

title: Seeking Urban Resurrection From a Hole in the Skyline
description: Looking ahead, not looking back, is the theme of ''Rebuilding Ground Zero,'' a documentary to be broadcast tonight on the Discovery Channel. Co-produced by New York Times Television, this hourlong program examines options for the 16-acre site where the World Trade Center stood until a year ago. Those options, burdened with political, commercial and emotional baggage, are what make rebuilding a slow, complicated process, and make this show worth watching.

title: A Pause to Bind Up the Wound in Our Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale Symposium on Revolutionary Legacies in France and U.S.
description: Scholars will examine how the French and American Revolutions still shape politics in both countries at a free public symposium at Yale on Sept. 20 and 21. The symposium, ''Revolutionary Traditions and the Law: France and the United States,'' is sponsored by the Whitney Humanities Center, the Yale Law School, the French Embassy and the Florence Gould Foundation.

title: Davis Cup Team Has 3 Young Players
description: Forget those two old-timers, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi. When the United States plays France on Sept. 20-22 in a Davis Cup semifinal in Paris, the American singles players are almost sure to be the youngsters Andy Roddick and James Blake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLDER, MURIEL
description: MOLDER-Muriel. On September 10, 2002. Beloved mother of Robin Friedman of Hastings - on - Hudson and Howard Molder of Florida. Loving grandmother to six. Longtime resident of Queens and a member of ORT. Funeral at 12 Noon today, at Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry (Saw Mill Exit 17). Memorials to the Leukemia Foundation.

title: Steel From Fallen Towers Is Reborn in Sculptor's Hands
description: Several long steel girders that once helped support the World Trade Center lie in the yard outside a sculptor's studio here, witnesses of a sort to a historic tragedy.

title: Anger at U.S. Said to Be at New High
description: Anger at the United States, embedded in the belief that the Bush administration lends unstinting support to Israel at the expense of the Palestinians, is at an unparalleled high across the Arab world, according to analysts and diplomats in the region.

title: Housing May Be Strong, but That Doesn't Mean It's a Bubble
description: Here are some interesting tidbits about housing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOENFELD, ANNA
description: SCHOENFELD - Anna. Be loved aunt of many nieces and nephews. Longtime employee of Social Security Administration. Graveside services Wednesday 11am at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Day to Reflect on Terror and War
description: To the Editor:

title: After Countless Hours Of Handing Out Supplies, Stopping to Smell the Roses
description: IN the hours after the World Trade Center collapse, hundreds of volunteers streamed into Lower Manhattan, wanting to help somehow. Among the more resilient was Perry Flicker, who arrived by ferry from New Jersey and quickly helped to establish a makeshift supply center for rescue workers. If you needed anything -- a pair of rubber boots, a granola bar -- you saw the man with the bullhorn, the man called Flick.

title: Police Ask for Help in Identifying Woman
description: The police are asking for the public's help in identifying a woman who apparently was raped and killed before her body was discovered early Sunday morning in front of an apartment building in Manhattan. Yesterday, officers arrested a suspect in the attack.

title: Fall in Provence
description: EuroBound Tours, based in Los Angeles, offers a package with six nights in four-star Provencal hotels and a week's car rental for $869 a person, based on double occupancy, Sept. 29 to Oct. 31 and $699 Nov. 1 to Dec. 28. The air-conditioned car is an automatic and comes with unlimited mileage. The package includes three nights each in the Hotel Les Bories set on eight acres near the village of Gordes and the Chateau de la Pioline, a restored 15th-century chateau in Aix-en-Provence. Air fare is extra. Information: (888) 837-6448 or www.eurobound.com .

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Profit Falls 86% At Comverse
description: Comverse Technology, a large maker of telephone voice mail software, said yesterday that second-quarter profit dropped 86 percent as sales fell 47 percent. Net income was $3.92 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with $28 million, or 15 cents, a year earlier, according to Comverse, of Woodbury, N.Y. Sales in the period ended July 31 fell to $181.2 million from $345.1 million. The company said in July that it would cut about 1,200 jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPPARD, SOPHIE V.
description: SHEPPARD-Sophie V. Died September 7. Devoted grandmother to Mary, loving mother to Toni Piesman and mother-in-law to Edward Piesman. Widow to Abner Sheppard. Always in our hearts.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Today and tomorrow we'll be reliving a horrible reminder of what is possible in the 21st century -- that is, no country is immune from attack.''

title: Frozen in Memory, the First Moments of a Transformed World
description: Where were you when you first heard?

title: MANY OBSERVANCES
description: One year after the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon killed 3,025 people, plunging the United States into war and a suddenly fearsome future, the country today marks the anniversary of 9/11 in countless public ceremonies and private moments, expressions of patriotism and what for some is a deep desire to turn the page.

title: Long After the Towers Came Down, Two Friends, Still Holding Hands
description: The tears have mostly stopped, but Dee Howard and Inez Graham are still fragile survivors, their sleep and waking hours ruled by the memories of Sept. 11, when they made a lucky dash through falling debris and emerged from the darkness like ash-covered wraiths. The two women from New Jersey, employees at the Port Authority, had just walked down 61 floors when tower two cascaded around them. Even as they trudged uptown, barefoot and in a daze, they never stopped holding hands.

title: Real Solace in a Virtual World: Memorials Take Root on the Web
description: THERE is no grave site for Tracy Orr to visit. The body of her husband, Alex Steinman, was never found in the rubble of the World Trade Center, and her guess is as good as any as to when a permanent memorial to the victims will be built.

title: Fichaud Is Back, Joining Montreal
description: Montreal signed goalie Eric Fichaud, a former first-round draft pick who retired last October, to a one-year contract with an option yesterday.

title: Morally Accountable for the 'Disappearances' and the Atrocities
description: You can feel the wheels of justice relentlessly grinding toward a day of judgment in Patricio Guzmn's eloquent, meticulously structured documentary film ''The Pinochet Case.'' A gripping step-by-step account of the case mounted by a Spanish judge against the former Chilean military dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet for human rights abuses, the movie re-examines one of the most painful episodes of recent Latin American history and its aftermath. Sober political and legal analysis alternates with grim first-hand accounts of torture and murder in a film that has the structure of a choral symphony that swells to a bittersweet finale.

title: SHARES OF CUBIST FALL AFTER VENTURE WITH GILEAD ENDS
description: Shares of Cubist Pharmaceuticals fell 30 percent after the drug maker and Gilead Sciences ended a collaboration to market Cubist's experimental antibiotic Cidecin in Europe. Shares of Cubist fell $2.24, to $5.16. A study last month showed Cidecin was not effective in treating pneumonia. Cubist will file for Food and Drug Administration approval of Cidecin for treating skin infections later this year, the company said. Gilead will focus on virus-fighting drugs.

title: U.S. Steps Up Alert as Solemn Day Arrives
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10  President Bush ordered the country's military and civilian authorities to a high state of alert today, closing embassies abroad and deploying surface-to-air missile batteries around Washington. Officials said a Qaeda operative now in custody had warned that terror strikes against American facilities were planned for the Sept. 11 anniversary.

title: You Know You're a New Yorker When...
description: "... when the World Trade Centers Twin Towers fell, you felt like youd lost part of your childhood, your home, and yourself," wrote DickytNYC .

title: UAL Weighs Asking U.S. For More Time To Seek Loan
description: United Airlines said yesterday that it could ask the federal government for an extension of a mid-September deadline to revise its application for a federal loan guarantee. But the carrier said it would first talk with its unions about proposed concessions.

title: A Pause to Bind Up the Wound in Our Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Europeans Curbing Their Appetite for Stocks
description: In the early 1990's, douard Winckler decided to bet on the future. A scholarship he landed to finish business school offered him a nest egg to invest. Beginning with low-risk money market funds, he gradually diversified into stock. The market was rising, and the French government, short of cash to balance its budget, was selling off chunks of nationalized industries like the oil company, the phone company and the national airline.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Back to Normal: The Fulton Fish Market, Once Again Near Fulton
description: IN the dark upstairs office of the Arrow Seafood Company, one of 59 wholesalers crowded into the three-block stretch of the Fulton Fish Market along the East River, there is a makeshift mural of dozens of color glossy photographs stapled in rows inside the office door.

title: The Nation Carries On, Jumpy but Still Resolute
description: It was really nothing. The overhead cable to a downtown streetcar snapped. A loud grinding of metal and the rustling of tree branches occurred. But it was enough to send pedestrians, nerves on edge, scurrying for cover at a nearby office building.

title: Ex-Council Members Fail In Bids for Higher Office
description: In an election in which turnout was lower than many candidates had expected, incumbents in legislative races generally fared well despite a larger-than-usual number of hotly contested races.

title: Finding the Chocolate Shop, and No Road Map Is Needed
description: Chocolat Bla Bla Bla is tucked alongside a beauty salon at 359 East 50th Street, sharing the entry. But Lorraine Belmont, a caterer who said she "had to open a chocolate shop" after seeing the film "Chocolat," said that somehow, customers never seem to mistake one store for the other. "People manage to find anything chocolate," she said.

title: Angels' Color Commentator Brings His Act to the Bronx
description: Iwas standing in the Yankees' clubhouse a few weeks ago when a wide-eyed, balding, 40-something man wandered in, gaping at the scenery. "I can't believe they let me have a locker in here," he said.

title: For Many New Yorkers, a Tentative Normality
description: MAYBE it is willful ignorance, some suggest. Maybe it is the conviction that living in fear is no way to live. But one year after the attack on the World Trade Center, nearly half of all New York City residents say the event has not changed their lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, MILBURN D., JR.
description: SMITH-Milburn D., Jr., on September 8, 2002, of Forest Hills, NY. Husband of Mollie, father of David, Jonathan, Eliza and Benjamin. Visiting Tuesday, September 10, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY. Service 12 PM, Thursday, September 12, at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway South Forest Hills, NY 11375. Donations to St. Luke's Church appreciated.

title: Hunger in Zimbabwe Takes Toll on Education
description: In ordinary times, more than 450 teenagers crowd into the shabby high school here, giggling over tattered notebooks and precious dreams. But since hunger began spreading through this country, the students have been dropping out one by one.

title: WHERE THEY WERE: Frozen in Memory, the First Moments of a Transformed World -- Alan Greenspan; Chairman of the Federal Reserve
description: Sometimes a single, awful event can stop and shake a nation so thoroughly that, years later, all its citizens can recall precisely where they were and what they were doing when they heard the news. Dec. 7, 1941, was such a day. So was Nov. 22, 1963. Now there is Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIACCIO, EMMA
description: CIACCIO-Emma. On September 10, 2002. Member of the NYU Dental Women's Auxiliary and the Columbus Citizen's Foundation. Beloved wife of the late Salvatore Ciaccio, DDS. Mother of Theo Berman. Sister of Betty Glianna. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St) NYC, Wednesday 7-9 PM. Funeral mass, Thursday, 10 AM at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Columbus Citizen's Foundation, 8 East 69th Street, NY, NY 10021, in her name will be greatly appreciated.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Upholding Grandparents Law
description: By a 4-to-3 vote, the state's highest court has upheld a law giving grandparents the right to visit grandchildren, but it ruled that the grandparents must prove that a child's well-being would be harmed without the visits. Previously, judges could permit visits if they thought it was in the child's best interest. The ruling by the Supreme Judicial Court stems from the case of John Blixt of Bridgewater, who sued his daughter, Kristin, for visits with her son. Ms. Blixt, who is single, filed to dismiss the suit on the grounds that it was unconstitutional. The case will return to Plymouth County Family and Probate Court. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, MICHAEL J.
description: SIMON-Michael J. One year ago today we lost Michael J. Simon, a Cantor-Fitzgerald employee, North Tower, Floor 105. Michael was proud to work in that soaring edifice that exemplified the American and world capitalist financial system. Like those ramrods straight towers soaring into the heavens, Michael's morality and character was a beacon of light in this difficult world. Michael, you can be proud of your wife. You can rest easy with the assurance that your children are handling life well, partly due to the years of love and example you were able to give them. We miss you terribly. We thought we had time with you, Michael. We will honor you all the days of our lives. Barbara and Jim Romaine

title: Moving Beyond Fatalism in the Heartland
description: THE local front page had been devoid of 9/11 stories for months, leaving Jeff Grant, the editor of The N'West Iowa Review, debating with his staff just how far to go with any anniversary coverage.

title: Past and Future Preoccupy Rivals in Governor's Race
description: ''The sweet dance of democracy,'' H. Carl McCall told a ballroom of cheering supporters last night at the Grand Hyatt New York, ''is a powerful tribute to those lost on Sept. 11.''

title: Transcript of News Conference by Ashcroft and Ridge on Increased Alert
description: Following is a transcript of the news conference yesterday at which Attorney General John Ashcroft and Tom Ridge, the homeland security adviser, discussed upgrading the terrorism alert, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILVER, DAVID S.
description: SILVER-David S. 3/14/66-9/11/01. Our hearts will always ache for you. Your loving family

title: U.S. Says Oui, and France Sends Sausages to These Shores
description: Dried sausages made in France are now being sold in the United States for the first time, having passed stringent government inspections. The Jean de France line of saucissons, made in Lyon, has a garlicky complexity enhanced by flavorings like wine, nuts or peppercorns. Whole 10-ounce sausages are about $8 at Citarella stores, Dean & DeLuca, Zabar's, Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory. There is also a plain, slow-aged traditional version called Rosette de Lyon, and one flavored with Beaujolais, sliced, each for about $12 a pound.

title: Next-Generation Space Telescope Chosen to Peer Into Past
description: NASA chose a successor to the Hubble Space Telescope today, announcing that it would launch a next-generation space observatory in 2010 that would study light produced in the earliest days of the universe.

title: The Burkas Come Off, But Equality Falters At the Edge of Kabul
description: A YEAR ago, a 19-year-old named Mishgan was confined to this village 37 miles south of Kabul, unschooled and without hope that the future held anything but the prospect of more children being pulled from her slight frame.

title: Pettitte Keeps His Focus as Yankees Beat Orioles
description: The playoffs are on the horizon for the Yankees, who figure they can use the next three weeks to sharpen their pitching and collect a fifth straight American League East title. Individually, the players can make their bids to be included on the postseason roster.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, PAUL J.
description: FRIEDMAN-Paul J. Lost on September 11 on Flight 11 at the World Trade Center. Our precious son, brother, husband and daddy is held close to our hearts every moment of every day. Selma, Iris, Amy, James Meryl, Audrey & Baby Rocky

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Leaves Rate Unchanged
description: Expectations that the United States will attack Iraq, combined with the sluggish American economy, pose a risk to Thailand's otherwise healthy economy, Thailand's central bank said. The central bank said it was leaving its benchmark interest rate unchanged, at 2 percent, but would watch for events that could affect the price of oil or demand for Thai exports. Thailand's economy is still expected to grow as much as 4 percent this year. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Stores Open in Vermont Town, but Squabbles Live On
description: Best Buy, big box, shining in the night: won't you make your sign less bright?

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Monday about a production of the 1933 play ''Three-Cornered Moon,'' at the New Heron Center in Manhattan, cited a comedy incorrectly among other snappy, loopy and frenetic works that it predated. ''The Front Page'' was first produced in 1928, before ''Three-Cornered Moon.''

title: Approved sites may profit from blockage : Googles loss spells gain for Web firms in China
description: HONG KONG:  In a case of what might be called dot-communism, Chinas government is turning away Internet surfers who try to visit the popular search engine Google and sending them to domestic commercial Web sites that toe the government line and stand to profit from the visits.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: State To Impose New Water Test
description: On Saturday, New Jersey will require all private water wells to be tested for a range of pollutants before the property can be sold, the state environmental commissioner, Bradley M. Campbell, said yesterday. Officials say New Jersey will be the first state in the country to do so. The new rules are part of a law passed by the State Legislature and will affect about 30,000 property sales a year. Private wells that fail the test will need to have appropriate filters or treatment systems installed. The state telephone line for questions is 1-866-4PW-TEST. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAYNARD, KEITHROY (KEITHY)
description: MAYNARD - Keithroy (Keithy) Firefighter, Engine 33 & 220. Sadly missed, but not forgotten. We will always love you. Sharon & Keithroy II

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  QUACKENBUSH, CHRISTOPHER
description: QUACKENBUSH - Christopher. September 11th. In memory. Happy Anniversay in Heaven. For a wonderful human being and a great boss. Never forgotten. Your Secretary, Gerry Barbezat.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mining Company's Profit Rises
description: The mining company Anglo American announced first-half profits of $767 million, saying cost-cutting had helped the company through a slump in commodities markets. Profits were up slightly from the period last year, when, after discounting one-time gains, the company earned $765 million. Anglo said its base metals division, which includes copper and zinc, had shown substantial improvement, offsetting poor performances by its coal and platinum units. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: On the Wings of a Sparrow, Comfort and Celebrity Came Down on a Teenager
description: ''THE bird,'' Nick Chirls said, ''has a life of its own.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Change In Mammogram Payments
description: The State Health Department has increased the Medicaid payment to medical facilities for mammographies. As of Oct. 1, the reimbursement for a screening of both breasts will rise to $90 from $51. Kristine Smith, a Health Department spokeswoman, said health care providers have complained about losing money on the screenings. About 64,000 Medicaid patients received such tests between October 1999 and September 2000, she said. Ms. Smith said the department was expecting the number to increase by 10 percent once the measure takes effect.

title: Pakistan Joins U.S. Cause, Cautiously
description: FROM a shabby ground-floor office where power shortages leave him in darkness every 30 minutes, 82-year-old Nawabzada Nasrullah Khan and his tiny political party here have battled the generals and land barons who have ruled Pakistan with varying degrees of autocracy and corruption since the country's inception 53 years ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bloomfield: Extra Money For Waste Cleanup
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has set aside an extra $10 million to continue the cleanup of radium-contaminated residential areas in Glen Ridge and Bloomfield. Richard Cahill, an agency spokesman, said yesterday that since 1991, the agency had cleaned up 115 of the 156 contaminated properties in those towns, as well as in Montclair and West Orange. It hopes to have the rest completed by the end of 2004, he said. Cleanup of the sites, contaminated by a defunct company that produced cosmetics and art supplies, has so far cost the federal government $143 million. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: He Is Alive, and What's Left of His Squeegee Is in the Smithsonian
description: HE has stopped counting, but Jan Demczur figures he has given 100 interviews to people around the world who want to know about the way he used his squeegee to cheat death on a World Trade Center elevator.

title: Angels Get Their Wings, in Loving Memory
description: THE number used for the dead in the early days was 5,000, so the potter, Lorrie Veasey, trying to get her mind around that figure and make it less of an abstraction, made 5,000 little angels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, JAMES J.
description: PETERS - James J. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of James J. Peters, the Executive Director of the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association. For the past eighteen years, the Association has generously supported clinical research on spinal cord damage at Mount Sinai. Under James Peters's leadership, the Association also made major contributions to the Wound Care Program, research fellowships, and other scientific and clinical programs to improve the lives of people with disabilities. James Peters's courage and commitment to health care were inspiring, and he will be very much missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Mary Ann, and to his many friends and colleagues. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Board The Mt Sinai Medical Center Kenneth I. Berns, MD, PhD President and CEO The Mt Sinai Medical Center Nathan G. Kase, MD, Interim Dean Mt Sinai School of Medicine Larry H. Hollier, MD, President, The Mount Sinai Hospital

title: Finding the Chocolate Shop, And No Road Map Is Needed
description: Chocolat Bla Bla Bla is tucked alongside a beauty salon at 359 East 50th Street, sharing the entry. But Lorraine Belmont, above, a caterer who said she ''had to open a chocolate shop'' after seeing the film ''Chocolat,'' said that somehow, customers never seem to mistake one store for the other. ''People manage to find anything chocolate,'' she said.

title: Sept. 11 ... And a Year of War, Anxiety and Questions
description: 8:46 a.m. North tower hit.

title: Pasta, the Irish-Italian Way
description: HOW a working-class Irish girl from South Boston became a chef with a national reputation for making pasta is one of those virtually unanswerable nature-vs.-nurture questions. But to watch Barbara Lynch as she mixes dough with her hands and feeds it into an old pasta machine that's no bigger than a home model is to see a young woman with the soul of an Italian grandmother.

title: New York Institute of Technology Names Dean
description: New York Institute of Technology has named JACQUELINE KRESS dean of the School of Education and Professional Services. Dr. Kress, director of graduate studies at Fordham since 1993, is charged with producing teachers who can meld technology and education. Stephanie Rosenbloom

title: With ad revenue down, Yahoo tries to win agencies' favor.
description: ONE hot Friday last month, 40 people from three advertising agencies in Manhattan boarded a chartered bus for a hilly estate in the Westchester town of Purdy's. Their destination: Camp Yahoo, where the wine flowed liberally, the lobsters were boiled by the dozens and the pool offered a chance to lounge on giant purple-and-yellow beach towels being given away.

title: N.H.L. Planning to Reduce Obstruction
description: Any N.H.L. defensemen worth his ice time has learned that the most effective way to stop a speeding forward is to use his stick as a roadblock.

title: A Restaurant Survives the Attack, but Not the Cleanup
description: DUANE AND JOANNA ANZALONE know restaurants; they know how to serve a customer's usual before he asks, and how to find a wedding cake for a desperate regular. They are not so good dealing with corporate lawyers.

title: Forrester Denies Backing Increase in Gasoline Tax
description: Trying to recover from the first significant misstep of his campaign, Douglas R. Forrester, New Jersey's Republican candidate for United States Senate, spent most of today trying to clarify his comment in a newspaper article that he would consider an increase in the federal gasoline tax to help pay for the cleanup of toxic waste sites.

title: U.S. Lacks Up-to-Date Review of Iraqi Arms
description: Senior intelligence officials acknowledged today that the government had not compiled an updated, cross-agency assessment of Iraq's nuclear, chemical and biological weapons capacities, although the Bush administration is pressing for a quick statement of support for military action against Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTCHEK, SALVATOR
description: ALTCHEK - Salvator. Be loved doctor who practiced medicine the old-fashioned way for over 60 years in Brooklyn Heights. He will be dearly missed by his family, Phyllis and Al, and Susan and Alberto; his grandchildren, Amelia, Kristina, Alessandra and Gian Paolo; his five great - grandchildren; his brother, Victor, and sister, Stella; his friends, and the patients to whom he dedicated his life. Graveside service, September 12, 11 AM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Foreigners Ache for U.S., but Also Take Issue With It
description: ROME, Sept. 11  Just after midnight, many of the taxi drivers in one company's fleet here turned off their meters and pulled to the side of the road, pausing for a minute to honor the dead of last Sept. 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Luxembourg: Tobacco Makers Rejected
description: The advocate general of the European Court of Justice has rejected arguments by two British tobacco manufacturers against a European Union law on packaging and branding of cigarettes. The advocate general, Leendert Geelhoed, said in a preliminary opinion that the law passed last year did not overstep the lawmakers' mandate, as the tobacco companies, British American Tobacco and Imperial Tobacco, contended. The law bans the words ''light'' and ''mild'' from cigarette packs and calls for health warnings on the front and back of all packs. The advocate general's opinion is usually supported by the court a few months later. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Mill Reorganization Hits A Snag
description: Creditors of the Asia Pulp and Paper Company postponed debt-overhaul talks, after Asia Pulp said it would not be able to pay the $100 million that creditors demanded by the end of the month. The company operates pulp and paper mills in Indonesia and China. Creditors had sought the $100 million as a sign that Asia Pulp was committed to meeting its obligations.

title: Inside the Lives They Lived (and Lost)
description: In the days immediately after the Sept. 11 attacks, relatives and friends of the missing papered building exteriors, lampposts and subway walls throughout the city with homemade fliers -- a photo, last-seen information, a phone number. Reporters from The New York Times, still sorting out how to cover the missing when there was no official list of the dead, began calling the numbers, and what emerged -- first on Sept. 15, then daily through the end of the year and now from time to time -- was the series Portraits of Grief.

title: The Strains Are Showing in Air Travel
description: The grace period for air travel has ended.

title: Team to Beat In the N.F.L.: The Patriots
description: New England, whose team colors include red, white and blue, was professional football's patriotic symbol and champion last season. The Patriots' championship embodied a country at war, a team that coalesced in the postseason to claim the seemingly unattainable, a stretch offering a snow-filled victory over Oakland, a special teams delight over Pittsburgh and a chilling kick in the last seconds over St. Louis.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Siebel Names Sales Chief
description: Siebel Systems, which makes software for businesses, has appointed Richard P. Chiarello as head of worldwide sales amid reports that William R. McDermott, executive vice president for sales, is leaving. Mr. Chiarello, who has worked at I.B.M. and Computer Associates International, will start as senior vice president for worldwide sales on Oct. 1, according to Siebel, which is based in San Mateo, Calif. Mr. McDermott could not be reached for comment. Siebel said Mr. Chiarello would succeed Mark Hanson, who will remain in a senior executive role.

title: Some Earnings Optimism Cited as Rally Has a 3rd Day
description: Stocks rose yesterday, giving benchmark indexes their first three-day winning streak in a month, on optimism an economic recovery will bolster companies' earnings.

title: A Change in Play for Children
description: Isee kids that are 2 and sometimes even younger. Those that were capable of doing any kind of pretend play would build block towers and knock them down with airplanes. Or build whole cities with the blocks and then have airplanes crashing into the buildings and the towers. Or they would play with houses, like a Fisher-Price dollhouse, and would have bad guys come attack the houses, the kind of play that hadn't been in their play until this happened.

title: Heightened U.S. Alert to Bring Little Change Across Country
description: Most Americans will see few signs that the nation has moved to the highest state of alert since the Sept. 11 attacks because state and local police agencies were already strengthening security for the anniversary. Most officials said few changes were planned as a result of the federal decision yesterday to upgrade the terrorism alert level to code orange, the second-highest status.

description: Davide Campari-Milano, the Italian liquor maker, said that first-half profit had increased 41 percent as its purchases of Skyy Spirits in December and the Sella & Mosca winery in January increased sales. Net income rose to 32 million euros ($31 million) from 22.7 million euros in the first six months of last year, Campari said. Sales increased 31 percent, to 306.5 million euros.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: DAEWOO MAKING CARS AGAIN The Daewoo Motor Company announced that it would resume making cars again today after a crucial supplier, Korea Delphi Automotive System, agreed to resume shipping parts. Daewoo suspended production on Aug. 28 when Korea Delphi and 190 other suppliers demanded payment of several hundred million dollars. The carmaker said it had agreed to repay some bills. The resumption of production was expected to speed the inauguration of GM-Daewoo Auto and Technology, the company that General Motors has set up to take over Daewoo's plants in Korea and some overseas sites. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Siding With Witnesses
description: The Chicago Police Department has routinely violated the rights of witnesses by interrogating them in small, locked rooms for up to 24 hours with no lawyer present, a federal judge ruled on Monday. The ruling by Judge Milton I. Shadur of Federal District Court comes in a lawsuit filed last year by the First Defense Legal Aid, a nonprofit group representing more than 40 indigent witnesses it says had been detained illegally. Judge Shadur said witnesses were often treated no differently than suspects by the police. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hand-Held Sales Drop In Quarter
description: Worldwide sales of personal digital assistants, like Palm hand-helds, declined 9.3 percent in the second quarter from a year ago, according to IDC, a research firm in Framingham, Mass. IDC said 2.62 million units were sold in the second quarter, in contrast with 2.89 million units a year ago. It was the second consecutive quarterly decline. IDC expects sales for the rest of the year to be the same as last year. Hewlett-Packard's acquisition of Compaq Computer allowed Hewlett to become the No. 2 hand-held vendor in the second quarter, behind Palm, the leader. Palm holds a 32.2 percent market share, while Hewlett holds 16.5 percent. Sony, Handspring and Hi-Tech Wealth of China rounded out the top five.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Units Merge To Focus On Publishing
description: Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali will merge with its RCS Editori unit, the publisher of Italy's two most-read daily newspapers, as it sells its fashion businesses to focus on media. Holding di Partecipazioni, based in Milan, and RCS will combine by next June, the chief executive, Maurizio Romiti, above, said. The company sold the Valentino fashion house and is seeking a buyer for its Fila Holding sportswear unit. RCS publishes Corriere della Sera and Gazzetta dello Sport, which have a daily readership of about six million.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Acquires XDegrees
description: Microsoft plans to acquire XDegrees as part of an effort to improve the ability of its Windows operating system to store corporate data. The terms were not disclosed. XDegrees, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes software for securely viewing information stored on corporate networks. Microsoft has been working to improve the ability of Windows to protect data that is shared across a network. The company has said it plans to complete work on a new version of Windows for server computers, used to anchor networks, later this year. It will probably go on sale early next year.

description: MUNICH, Sept. 7  As German voters prepare to elect a chancellor on Sept. 22, the conservative challenger, Edmund Stoiber, never fails to remind his countrymen that four million of them are out of work.

description: THE Washington Redskins' exhibition game was about to begin, and Lt. Kevin Shaeffer, retired, was pacing the sideline, snapping photographs every few minutes of his favorite players and joking with the man who saved his life nearly one year ago.

description: Nassau County officials estimated today that a surge of voluntary retirements would help shrink the county's work force by a 10th, or nearly 1,000 jobs, by year's end. But they warned that a worsening fiscal crisis might force the county to lay off 200 people beyond that.

title: Vote System Chaos Triumphs Again in Florida Election
description: Florida held its first statewide election on Tuesday since spending $30 million to upgrade its voting system, but the result was a striking echo of the botched 2000 presidential election, with malfunctioning voting machines, closed or short-staffed polling places and frustrated voters across the state unable to cast ballots.

title: A Mobile Clinic Delivers Good Health and Grades
description: FOUR years ago Dennis Doyle, an assistant superintendent of schools in this town on the Mexican border, reviewed attendance and test score data at the elementary schools. Not unexpectedly, schools with low scores also had poor attendance. Dr. Doyle figured that achievement would rise if he could keep the children, many from low-income and non-English-speaking families, in class.

title: Corrections

Rowland, who invented a device to separate the colors of the solar spectrum. The carving, which Eakins designed, depicts a portion of the spectrum, not the measurements of Rowland's device.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, DR. CURT C.
description: SILBERMAN-Dr. Curt C. Funeral services for Dr. Curt Silberman of West Orange, NJ will be today at 1:15pm at Temple B'nai Abraham, 300 E Northfield Ave, Livingston, NJ. For information, Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Funeral Home. Dr. Silberman, a lifelong leader of European and American Jewish communities, died September 9, 2002 at the age of 94. He was active in philanthropic activities and his private law practice until his death. Born in 1908 in Wurtzburg, Germany, Dr. Silberman practiced law there. During the 1930's, he was responsible for the saving of life and the immigration of Jews from the Wurtzburg region, as a result of extensive negotiations with the Gestapo. He was imprisoned briefly by the Nazis during this period. Married in 1937 to Else Kleemann in Wurtzberg, the couple immigrated to New Jersey in 1938 where he continued his devotion to the welfare of Jews from Europe and in his newly adopted country. While working for the Jewish Federations Family and Child Service, he attended Rutgers Law School in the evenings, and was admitted to the NJ Bar in 1947. He was subsequently admitted to practice before the US Supreme Court. During the subsequent 4 decades, he was instrumental in the founding and leadership of major Jewish organizations. He served as President of the Jewish Family Service Association of Essex County. He was a Founder of the American Federation of Jews from Central Europe, of which he was President from 1963-1986. He was a Co-Founder of the Leo Baeck Institute in NYC, the leading research institute for German Jewry. He continued his leadership as Founder and President of the Jewish Philanthropic Fund. He was a Member and Trustee of Temple B'nai Abraham, Livingston, NJ. His stature as a leader of these communities was recognized by Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower and Lyndon B. Johnson, during whose administration Dr. and Else Silberman were guests at White House state dinners. As WWII was ending, and refugees were dispersed around the globe, he was instrumental in pursuing restitution rights for the victims of Nazi aggression, working not only with the post - WWII German government, but with the US government. In his private international law practice, he represented European and German companies and foundations, both here and globally, travelling frequently on their behalf. A crowning achievement was the establishment, by Dr. Silberman and his wife Else, of a program of Jewish and Holocaust studies at Middlebury College, for which he endowed a Chair, and was awarded an Honorary Doctorate in 1995.

title: Even Santa's Lap Doesn't Seem as Safe Anymore

He is disappointed that the parents of the children he listens to, and smiles to, and sends on their way, do not trust him as much as they used to. He is also disappointed in himself, and his distrust of those same parents.

title: Hernandez Apologies To Players

Vaughn was one of the players who strongly disagreed with Hernandez's remarks on an Internet site last week that the team had no heart and ''quit a long time ago.'' Hernandez apologized to the Mets today before receiving his pardon.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Mass Desertion By Soldiers
description: In a stark display of low morale and eroding discipline in the country's military, 54 soldiers from the 20th Motorized Infantry Division in the southern city of Volgograd deserted en masse on Sunday, reportedly to protest the brutality of one of their commanders. The military's chief prosecutor, Lt. Gen. Aleksandr N. Savenkov, announced yesterday that his office would investigate the accusations of the soldiers, who have since been detained. ''We intend to hand down tough punishments to the officials for violating the law, irrespective of their ranks,'' General Savenkov said. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2 Companies To Share Costs
description: The European Commission said yesterday in Brussels that it would let two mobile phone operators, T-Mobile and MMO2, share the costs of a setup in Britain for third-generation mobile telephones. The permission to share networks of antennas and transmission stations follows a similar decision announced last month between the same companies in Germany. Europe's competition commissioner, Mario Monti, said customers would benefit from the arrangement because it would speed the introduction of new technologies. Paul Meller (NYT)

Survived by her husband, David C. Beebe, Jr., a daughter, Evelyn B. Handy, two sons, David C. Beebe III and Scott M. Beebe, as well as seven grandchildren. title: Botox Commercials Mislead Consumers, Government Says

title: A Pause to Bind Up the Wound in Our Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Course I Know Which Buttons To Push, Dear. I Installed Them.
description: The first time I saw Aviva Jane Carlin, four years ago, she was sitting stark naked (all 200-plus middle-aged pounds of her) in a theater on Bond Street. Ms. Carlin was performing her one-woman show ''Jodie's Body,'' which managed to combine, gracefully, some brave talk about body image and some painful memories of South African apartheid.

title: QWEST TO REFILE APPLICATIONS FOR LONG DISTANCE
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that it had withdrawn applications to provide long-distance telephone service in nine states and would refile to address accounting concerns raised by the Federal Communications Commission. Qwest, which is based in Denver and provides local-phone service in 14 Western states, will file the new applications by the end of the month. The states are Colorado, Idaho, Iowa, Montana, Nebraska, North Dakota, Utah, Washington and Wyoming. The company, whose accounting is under federal investigation, said in July that it would restate results after misreporting at least $1.16 billion in revenue from 1999 to 2001.

title: The Board Of WorldCom Begins Search For Next Chief
description: WorldCom's board decided yesterday to begin a formal search for a new chief executive as the company, hampered by investigations into its accounting, struggles to emerge relatively intact from the nation's largest bankruptcy filing.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Avanex Cuts 140 Jobs
description: The Avanex Corporation, which makes fiber optical equipment, said yesterday that it would cut about 140 jobs to help lower costs and refocus its operations. The company has about 430 employees worldwide. Avanex said that most of the layoffs would be in its American operations and that it planned to shift some manufacturing to companies in China. Avanex said it would keep its design, engineering, product integration and prototype abilities at its headquarters in Fremont, Calif., and would focus its American operations on its fiber optic networks.

title: Downtown Rising
description: ''WHY try to open a restaurant in these bad times?''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CISNEROS ALVAREZ, JUAN P.
description: CISNEROS Alvarez-Juan P. 2/16/1977. In memory of our beloved son, brother, grandson, boyfriend and friend. With heartfelt love and remembrance. Loved forever.

title: Golisano Appears Set to Defeat Pataki in the Independence Primary
description: Tom Golisano appeared to defeat Gov. George E. Pataki in the Independence Party primary for governor yesterday, a serious setback to Mr. Pataki in his bid for a third term. In the Democratic camp, H. Carl McCall won his party's nomination to run for governor in November.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Plans Share Offering
description: Legal and General, the British life insurer, said that it would raise 786 million ($1.17 billion) from a sale of new shares to offset stock market declines and falling profits. The insurer said it would issue as many as 1.3 billion shares at 60 pence each, a 47 percent discount to Monday's closing price. The issue is expected to be completed by Oct. 22. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Nokia Lowers Sales Target But Is Optimistic on Profits
description: For the fifth time this year, Nokia, the world's biggest cellphone maker, has reduced a target for sales. But the company said today that its profits in the third quarter would come in at the top end of its forecast range.

title: Citizens of the World, on Time for a Meeting in Harm's Way
description: ON the last day of her life, Amy E. Toyen got up at 4 a.m. in Boston to catch a plane and attend a conference at the top of the World Trade Center. The day was Sept. 11. About the same time, in northern Virginia, Mark E. Shurmeier, who also died that day, was stirring so he could catch an early train to New York and arrive at the same conference on time.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COSGROVE, KEVIN M.
description: COSGROVE-Kevin M. September 11, 2001 The ever present fixture in all we did, counted on for your good humor! Ah, to have one last moment with you, but remembered with warmth and love. God bless and keep you, dear Kevin. Your loving family

description: Sometimes a single, awful event can stop and shake a nation so thoroughly that, years later, all its citizens can recall precisely where they were and what they were doing when they heard the news. Dec. 7, 1941, was such a day. So was Nov. 22, 1963. Now there is Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Blair Speech Mutes Protests By Union Leaders on Iraq

description: A message left on Mike Westhoff's voice mail last week from another N.F.L. special teams coach turned out to be prophetic.

After class, the man approached Professor Vallejo, asking leading questions about whether he felt safe walking home alone and whether he had known a colleague who had been murdered.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: XSTREAM BEVERAGE GROUP, Boca Raton, Fla., a beverage company, said it agreed to buy Dark Dog, a maker of energy drinks based in Salzburg, Austria, for $34 million in cash and stock.

He refocused the company on pharmaceuticals, not on specialty chemicals.

description: MATTHEWS-Judy. Granddaughter Juliette is beautiful. We think of you and remember you everyday. Love always, Howard, Sandy and Steve

description: INDIA: PRE-ELECTION VIOLENCE IN KASHMIR A political worker for the People's Democratic Party was shot dead on Monday night in Kashmir as anti-India militants continued their effort to try to derail state elections scheduled to start on Monday. In another incident, gunmen tried yesterday to kill a candidate who is the brother of the state's chief minister. Indian security forces, meanwhile, said the army had killed three commanders of the main rebel group, Hizbul Mujahedin, on Monday night. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Investigating 9/11: An Unimaginable Calamity, Still Largely Unexamined
description: Of course the country had to understand what went wrong. One of the largest structures ever built had failed, at a terrible cost in lives. When warned of danger, those in charge had shrugged. Many died because the rescue effort was plagued by communication breakdowns, a lack of coordination, failure to prepare.

title: History Lessons on Tax-Policy Strife
description: THE GREAT TAX WARS

title: Man Is Freed in Killing in Which His Brother Admitted a Role
description: Thirteen years after he was imprisoned for a murder he said he did not commit, Lamont Branch walked out of a Brooklyn courthouse a free man yesterday, after declaring that it was his brother who, armed and angry, confronted a drug dealer who became the victim of the killing.

title: Big Rise in G.E.D. Test-Takers in 2001
description: Nearly 71,000 New Yorkers took the G.E.D. tests in search of a high school equivalency diploma last year, an 11 percent jump from 2000, according to recently released figures from the American Council on Education, which administers the tests.

title: Ex-Councilman Is Expected to Plead Guilty in Funds Inquiry
description: Sheldon Leffler, a former longtime city councilman, is expected to plead guilty soon to charges stemming from an investigation into illegal fund-raising for his failed 2001 campaign for Queens borough president, an official with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Corrections

The error also occurred in a picture caption on Monday. As the related Monday article said, she is Janet Napolitano, not Jane.

Friends may visit Tuesday, 4-9 pm, or Wednesday, 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm. Requiem Mass Thursday, 10:30 am, at Holy Cross Church, West 42nd St.

description: Wall Street was open for business today, but business was not the first order of business.

description: IF you examine the Zagat Survey commentaries on New York's top Mexican restaurants, like Maya, Zarela and Mi Cocina, you'll notice immediately what they all have in common: margaritas that are ''scary,'' ''extra strength'' or ''drop dead.''

title: The Fears of a Child, Reflected in the Clouds Above Any U.S. City
description: FOR Michaela Bigsby, 8, the nightmares and bouts of sleeplessness began the evening of Sept. 11, and have flared periodically ever since.
