A memorial service in celebration of Bill's life will be held on Sunday, Sept. 15, at 2 PM, at All Souls Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, New York, NY. Memorial gifts to the New York City Police Foundation, 345 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10154, would be appreciated.

title: CarMax Spinoff Approved
description: Shareholders of Circuit City Stores have voted to split off the CarMax Group, a used-car division, effective Oct. 1, when the unit will become a separate publicly traded company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAVERS, WALLY P.
description: TRAVERS-Wally P. May 22, 1957-September 11, 2001. Every day you are remembered for your love of life, joyous spirit and ready smile. You will be forever in our thoughts and hearts. We will never be the same without you. We love you. Patti, Chris, Brennan and Baby Liam Walter Gallaghe

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIZZO, JOHN FRANK
description: RIZZO-John Frank. We think of you often and what a truly fine and decent person you were to your wife, children, parents and all who came in contact with you. We miss you. Jean and Joseph Ryan

title: America Enduring
description: By now we've all mapped our whereabouts in the city of memory -- where we stood, what we saw, who we knew or lost, how close we came, how far away we felt. We've learned to calibrate our anxiety. (The federal government yesterday for the first time raised its terror alert to code orange, the second-highest level.) We've told the stories again and again, to friends and strangers. The stories have become part of the currency of our lives. We exchange them with one another, and like all stories, true or false, they suffer a kind of attrition in the telling and retelling. Stories that seemed unbearable a year ago are no more bearable now -- words caught on the fly from witnesses shrouded in ash, from family members drenched in anxiety and grief, even the sound of our own thoughts sifting through our minds. But what those words gain in familiarity they lose in immediacy. The truth within the stories doesn't subside, but it becomes somehow less accessible. Because, at root, it is an emotional truth we are still reaching for, and the emotions of that day lay somewhere beyond language. They still do a year later.

title: Chinese to See Visiting Envoys Of Dalai Lama
description: Two envoys from the Dalai Lama have arrived for an extended visit to Beijing and Tibet, opening the first official contacts between the exiled leader and the Chinese government since 1993, Tibetan officials abroad said today.

title: WHERE THEY WERE: Frozen in Memory, the First Moments of a Transformed World -- Representative Jerrold L. Nadler; United States congressman
description: Sometimes a single, awful event can stop and shake a nation so thoroughly that, years later, all its citizens can recall precisely where they were and what they were doing when they heard the news. Dec. 7, 1941, was such a day. So was Nov. 22, 1963. Now there is Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Con Ed and Insurers Sue Port Authority Over 7 World Trade
description: Consolidated Edison and five of its insurers have filed a $314.5 million lawsuit against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, asserting that huge diesel tanks in 7 World Trade Center, an office building that collapsed late in the day last Sept. 11, were improperly designed and maintained. The suit charges that fires fed by the fuel in those tanks played a major role in the collapse.

title: Impatient Shockey Expects More
description: Jeremy Shockey finished warming up about 90 minutes before the Giants' first game of the season last week and noticed the rookie place-kicker Matt Bryant trying some field goals. Wearing a Giants cap backward, Shockey stood about 5 yards behind Bryant and started screaming at him, trying to simulate what Bryant might hear in the game.

title: A Country Starting to Rebuild A Step at a Time
description: EVERYWHERE Americans go in Afghanistan, they hear Afghans say it: Sept. 11 was an immeasurable tragedy for the United States, but one that brought Afghanistan its salvation. Only 26 days after the attacks in New York and Washington, on Oct. 7, the United States launched the first bombing raids on the Taliban government and Osama bin Laden's organization, Al Qaeda, in Afghanistan. After 37 more days, on Nov. 13, with the flight of the Taliban's forces from Kabul, their days of oppressing an entire people were over.

title: A Pause to Bind Up the Wound in Our Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Delighting Once More In the Joyful Squeals Of the Preschool Set
description: ON the first day of class after the attack, 11 of 120 children were present for roll, leaving a void so huge at Battery Park City Day Nursery that administrators wondered if the preschool -- just a block from ground zero -- would ever recover. Denise Cordivano, the nursery's director of education, thinks back and is haunted by the silence: ''I hated it. It was so quiet without the children.''

title: Scholastic Store to Hold Workshops for Teachers
description: The Scholastic Store, at 557 Broadway in SoHo, is sponsoring free workshops for elementary school teachers next month. The ''Classroom Educator Series'' will focus on teaching basic literacy skills. Textbook authors and education experts will lead the 90-minute courses. Information is available by calling (212) 343-4903. Jennifer Medina

title: A Day of Vigilance on Anniversary of Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11  With security locked down to its tightest level in a year at American installations in the United States and abroad, the first anniversary of the hijackings passed without serious incident through late afternoon. Nevertheless, senior government officials continuing their warning about the risk of an attack.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hearing Delayed In 1989 Jogger Rape
description: A court hearing has been delayed for six weeks for the five teenagers convicted in the 1989 rape of the investment banker who came to be known as the Central Park jogger. A judge ruled yesterday that the teenagers' lawyers must wait until Oct. 21 to argue that the youths were wrongfully convicted. The lawyers are seeking to have the verdicts dismissed on the basis of new DNA evidence linking the crime to a convicted murderer-rapist, Mathias Reyes, who claimed earlier this year that he alone raped the jogger. Justice Charles J. Tejada granted the prosecution's request for an adjournment, angering the defendants' lawyers, Michael W. Warren and Roger Wareham. Prosecutors have said that proof of Mr. Reyes's involvement does not necessarily undo the convictions of the teenagers, who were convicted largely on their own confessions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, MARIANA CONKLIN
description: REYNOLDS-Mariana Conklin. Of Morristown, N.J. Died September 9, 2002. Widow of Frederic Clinton Reynolds. Mother of Frederic Clinton Reynolds, Jr. of Bedminster, N.J., Mariana Reynolds Heap of LaMorra, Italy, Jane Reynolds Riggan of Arcatia, CA. and the late Christopher Conklin Reynolds. Also survived by seven grandchildren and fifteen great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Saint Bernard's Cemetery, Bernardsville, NJ. Saturday, September 14th, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association of Somerset Hills, 12 Olcott Ave, Bernardsville, New Jersey 07924.

title: Sports of The Times; Golf Might Have Been a Lifesaver
description: THEN or now, Ken Eichele didn't remember what he shot playing golf that morning, but he distinctly remembered what he was told.

title: After Months in a Coma, Quickly Walking and Laughing Again
description: FOR an international symbol of hope and courage, Lauren Manning turns out to be a lot of fun -- and often very funny. Mrs. Manning, who was engulfed by a fireball in the lobby of 1 World Trade Center while on her way to work on Sept. 11, refers to the time she spent in a coma as ''that three-month hiatus when I was napping.''

title: A Portrait of One Forum's Grief
description: The events of Sept. 11 affected online communities in a unique way. Many people who had never participated in chats or posted on message boards felt the need to express their thoughts in a public forum, and the Web provided that outlet. What long-time forum participants experienced was different- the expressions of grief and political theorizing were entwined with worry about the missing members of their particular group. How do you find out if your friend is safe when you don't know where they work, how to get in touch with them or perhaps even their last name?

title: Braves, Another Title Clinched, Storm Back to Bury Mets
description: The Braves were off on Monday, when the Mets' victory in Philadelphia eliminated the Phillies and handed the National League East title to Atlanta. So the Braves held a short pregame ceremony tonight to celebrate their 11th straight division title, displaying a banner along the stands in left field. Fireworks followed.

title: Tyco Is Set to Announce a New Financial Chief
description: Tyco International plans to announce today that it has selected David J. FitzPatrick, a senior vice president and chief financial officer of the United Technologies Corporation, to be its new chief financial officer as it tries to restore the company's credibility among investors, executives briefed on the appointment said.

description: To the Editor:

description: BONDARENKO - Alan. No vember 18, 1947-September 11, 2001. We miss you and think of you daily. In remembrance of the pride and excellence you brought to both your professional and personal life, we carry on your devotion to our engineering craft and your kindness and decency to others. The Pittsburgh Engineering Community

title: Ed Warner, 73, College Star Convicted of Shaving Points
description: Ed Warner, who was a star forward for the City College basketball team that won the National Invitation Tournament and N.C.A.A. tournament championships in 1950 but shattered his career in the point-shaving scandal that engulfed the game, died Saturday at his home in Harlem. He was 73.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Privacy Bill Passes Hurdle
description: The House Judiciary Committee approved legislation that would require all federal agencies to analyze the impact of proposed regulations and actions on privacy and make that analysis public, much as they now must do for actions that affect the environment. The bill, sponsored by Representative Bob Barr, Republican of Georgia, is supported by groups including the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Rifle Association. It may be acted on by the full House this month. Adam Clymer (NYT)

title: Heinz Says Its Quarterly Profit Fell 11%
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its quarterly profit fell 11 percent because of higher marketing costs and expenses related to the spinoff of its tuna and pet-food businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEON, DAVID, HAZZAN
description: LEON-David, Hazzan. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of our Past President (1969-1971) and revered colleague of over five decades. A wonderful Hazzan, he quietly and gently served the spiritual needs of the Jewish community of Bridgeport, Connectucut for over forty years with dignity, warmth and care. His kindness, his humanity and his caring inspired us all. We extend our sympathy to his family and loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Sheldon Levin, Pres. Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice President Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: Echo of the Bullhorn
description: At 4 a.m., I was awakened by the roar of F-16's, once more patrolling.

title: 2 Pillars Are Crucial to Helping Children Adjust
description: The community I've been concerned about and working with is the West Side of downtown: Tribeca and Battery Park City. I have two sons, ages 9 and 6, who were attending P.S. 234. On the morning of Sept. 11, I had just dropped them off and was returning home when I heard the crash and looked up and saw the debris flying. Many of the children in the school as well as other schools downtown really saw everything, including people falling or jumping out of the buildings.

title: U.S. Steps Up Alert as Solemn Day Arrives
description: President Bush ordered the country's military and civilian authorities to a high state of alert today, closing embassies abroad and deploying surface-to-air missile batteries around Washington. Officials said a Qaeda operative now in custody had warned that terror strikes against American facilities were planned for the Sept. 11 anniversary.

title: Henri Rol-Tanguy, French Resistance Figure, Dies at 94
description: Henri Rol-Tanguy, one of France's most decorated Resistance heroes, who organized the popular uprising against the German occupation of Paris and, a few days later, joined the Gaullist general, Philippe Leclerc, in taking the surrender of German forces stationed here, died Sunday. He was 94.

title: Hamburg Police Raid 2 Import-Export Firms
description: The police raided two export-import firms today that are owned by a Syrian-born German who is suspected of ties to the Sept. 11 plotters who once lived in this northern port city.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Orange: 2 Die In Apartment Fire
description: Two people were killed after a three-alarm fire broke out on the seventh floor of an eight-story building just before midnight last night, a fire official said. One person jumped from the building, at 299 South Harrison Street, while another person died in an apartment on the seventh floor, said the official, Timothy Weiss, chief of the East Orange Fire Department. The names of the victims were not released last night, and the cause of the fire was under investigation. About 200 residents were evacuated from the building. None of them were injured, although numerous firefighters suffered heat-related injuries, Chief Weiss said. They were all treated at the scene and able to return to work, he added. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: A Flood of Money, Then a Deluge of Scrutiny for Those Handing It Out

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATWOOD, DOUGLAS JOHN
description: ATWOOD-Douglas John. 52, of AIDS, in New York City, on July 20th, 2002. Born April 18, 1950, Manchester, NH. Poet, sober adventurer, friend. Civil servant, AIDS activist, political agitator, volunteer and advocate for prisoners and homeless. Lehman College graduate. Vocational rehab specialist for NYC HIV/AIDS Services Admin. Survived by his lover, John Masterson; friends, Robin Kunstler and Barton Kunstler; mother, Natalie Atwood of East Hampton, CT, nine sisters and brothers. Memorial Friday, September 20, 7pm, LGBT Center, 208 W. 13th St., NYC. Generous spirit, conversationalist extraordinaire, man of giant hands and great heart. ''Pray for God,'' Doug wrote, ''God needs our prayers too.''

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: 2 COMPANIES TO SHARE COSTS The European Commission said yesterday in Brussels that it would let two mobile phone operators, T-Mobile and MMO2 , share the costs of a setup in Britain for third-generation mobile telephones. The permission to share networks of antennas and transmission stations follows a similar decision announced last month between the same companies in Germany. The commission's competition commissioner, Mario Monti, said customers would benefit from the arrangement because it would speed the introduction of new technologies. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: About the Survey
description: To chart the residential rebound in Lower Manhattan, The Times surveyed more than 7,000 housing units near ground zero. Occupancy data was obtained for 27 rental and condominium buildings within a four-block radius of the World Trade Center from individual landlords and the Battery Park City Authority. The buildings ranged from 4-unit walk-ups to 1,700-unit complexes. The vacancy statistic represents apartments to which either a rental tenant or condominium owner decided not to return, even after the buildings had been cleaned and reopened.

title: Terrorism Suspect, Expressing Regret, Says He Stabbed Jail Guard to Seize His Keys
description: A man reputed to have been a senior aide to Osama bin Laden testified yesterday that he never wanted to stab a guard in the Metropolitan Correctional Center in November 2000, but that he did so anyway because he felt it would be the only way to seize his keys.

title: Putin Seems to Issue Ultimatum to Georgia Over Militants
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 11  President Vladimir V. Putin threatened today to order military strikes in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, saying that Russia had a right to defend itself from what he called terrorist attacks launched from Georgian territory.

title: U.N. Delegates Wait for Bush to Make Case Against Iraq
description: Five days of phone calls and intensive consultations by President Bush with world leaders have helped ease fears that the United States would sidestep the United Nations and initiate a swift attack on Iraq on its own, diplomats said today.

title: PLAN TO ATTACK EMBASSIES CITED
description: The Bush administration's decision today to declare a higher terrorist alert status was made after investigators uncovered a plot by a radical Islamic organization with links to Al Qaeda, American officials said. The group was planning attacks at several American embassies in Southeast Asia, the officials said.

title: The Old Days Never Looked So Good; Yesteryear's Cultural Symbols Are Today's Hot Tickets
description: Pick up a paper, turn on the radio, surf the Net, and you just might get the impression that the hottest thing among critics today is . . . yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISH, CHARLOTTE BLACKMAN
description: FISH-Charlotte Blackman, 90. On September 3, 2002, after a short illness in Deerfield Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Joseph T. Fish, of Logan, West VA. Mother of Jacqueline Fish, and Frances Fish Tompkins. Mother-inlaw of Judge Harold Tompkins. Grandmother of Laurence Alan Fish Tompkins, Michael Barnett Lembeck, Alyssa Rae Lembeck Klein, and her husband, Andrew Klein. Great grandmother of Olivia Danielle, and Ellie Jordana Klein. A native of Cincinnati, Ohio, she came to Logan, West VA. in 1938 as a bride, until her move to Florida in 1990, after her husband's death. A supporter of many West VA charitable organizations. The West Virginia Boy Scout Service Center, was renamed The Joseph T. and Charlotte B. Fish Scout Building, in recognition of scouting programs. She was a Founding Member of The Alef Society of The Central Capital Agency for Jewish Education in Broward County, FL. She received many awards from Hadassah, especially for The Youth Aliyah Program, and Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. Many recognitions were presented by The State of Israel Bonds, and The UJA. She and her husband were given a special award by The Associates of Hebrew Union College Jewish Institute of Religion. Her wisdom, love, and devotion to family, her endearing sense of humor, and her fierce commitment to philanthropy will long be remembered by those privileged to have known her. In lieu of flowers, contributions to B'nai Sholom Congregation, PO Box 2674, Huntington, West VA. 25726, would be appreciated. For additional information, please contact: Plaza Memorial Chapel, at 212-769-4400.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Rocket Aimed At Satellite Business
description: Ending a string of recent failures, Japan launched a new rocket that officials hope will pave the way toward a commercial satellite launching business. The 190-foot H-2A blasted off from Tanegashima, about 625 miles southwest of Tokyo. Officials said two satellites -- a data relay satellite and an unmanned space experiment recovery system -- were deployed, but after repeated recent failures they were cautious about early declarations of succcess. Howard W. French (NYT)

description: Performing Art

title: Embassies in Southeast Asia and Elsewhere Close After Alert
description: Already in a state of heightened vigilance, American embassies and installations around the world increased precautions today after the Bush administration said it had raised its global terror alert level.

title: Vivendi Messages About Audits Seized
description: French securities regulators have seized documents showing that the former management of Vivendi Universal sought to press its French auditor into accounting for the sale of shares that Vivendi held in the British pay television service B Sky B in a way that would have inflated Vivendi's annual profit.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Jury Selection Begins In Wendy's Murders
description: Jury selection got under way yesterday in the case against the man accused of accused of planning the killing of five employees at a Wendy's restaurant in Flushing, Queens, in May 2000. Officials said that 750 potential jurors reported to State Supreme Court to answer 19 juror questions, such as whether serving would cause them financial or child care problems. The presiding judge, Steven W. Fisher, said the trial of the defendant, John B. Taylor, above, may last five weeks. It will have two phases, one to determine whether Mr. Taylor is guilty, and the other, if Mr. Taylor is convicted, to determine whether he should be sentenced to death. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Neiman Marcus Earnings Beat Expectations
description: The Neiman Marcus Group had a quarterly profit of $5.32 million as it sold more designer boots, women's suits and turquoise jewelry at full price, the company said today.

title: Critic's Notebook; Theater As Solace In a Time Of Anguish
description: What a complicated evening, perhaps as necessary as it was insufficient. Terribly long and indulgent but full of honest, inspiring effort and sprinkled with occasional bolts of rewarding light, this was Monday at Town Hall, the first installment of ''Brave New World,'' the rubric under which four programs of original songs, performance pieces and playlets are being presented this week to commemorate the somber anniversary of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: One Camera, Then Thousands, Indelibly Etching a Day of Loss
description: IT started with one shot. At 8:46 a.m., Jules Naudet, a rookie filmmaker making a film about a rookie firefighter, was practicing his camera work. He heard a roar overhead and pointed his camera up. Kenneth T. Jackson, the president of the New-York Historical Society, believes that was the only camera that captured American Airlines Flight 11 hitting the north tower.

title: Senate Rejects Bush Call And Approves Farm Aid
description: The Senate rejected administration pleas to halt deficit spending and voted overwhelmingly today to give $6 billion in emergency drought relief aid to American farmers and ranchers.

title: President Meets Muslim Leaders In Post-9/11 First
description: For the first time since Sept. 17, President Bush met yesterday with a group of Muslim and Arab-American leaders, some of whom had been pressing to meet him since early this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Many Look To 9/11 Date For Luck
description: People buying lottery tickets and hoping that today's date would bring them luck were disappointed yesterday after the numbers 911 sold out for yesterday's midday New York Numbers drawing. ''It is not unusual to have sold out numbers,'' said Carolyn Hapeman, a spokeswoman for the New York Lottery, who said that any time 10,000 tickets are sold for a particular set of three numbers, sales of those numbers are cut off. The numbers 111, one of the most popular combinations played, are usually sold out a week in advance, she said. The winning numbers for yesterday's midday drawing were 993.

title: Strangers, Dads, Sisters, Friends
description: The human toll of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, is still unimaginable: 2,801 killed in the towers of the World Trade Center and in the two airplanes that were flown into them, 125 dead at the Pentagon and 59 aboard the plane that struck it, and 40 passengers and crew members aboard Flight 93 killed when that hijacked plane crashed into a field near Shanksville, Pa. In all, 3,025 victims united by a date -- Sept. 11. Here are those people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARKMAN, JEAN

title: In a Red Hook Diner, Cheeseburgers Are Not Enough
description: DEEP in Red Hook, Brooklyn, down Van Brunt Street, where you can smell the salt off New York Bay, there's a new diner, the Hope & Anchor. It's a neighborhood place in a neighborhood that doesn't have a lot of people, and it needs to serve a number of purposes at once.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMBERG, DR. HAROLD M.
description: SOMBERG-Dr. Harold M. On Tuesday September 10, 2002. Dr. Somberg, 84, of West Orange, NJ, formerly of Maplewood, NJ. Devoted husband of Ethel Somberg (nee Weiss), beloved father Eric Somberg, Ann Robbins, and Judith Somberg. Cherished brother of Milton Somberg, loving grandfather of Jesse, Adam, Lucia, Elizabeth, Max, Ben, and Molly. Past President of New Jersey Neurosurgical Society and The Medical Staff of Newark Beth Israel Medical Center, Newark, NJ. Chief of Neurosurgery at Newark Beth Israel Medical Center, Newark, NJ, Saint Michael's Medical Center, Newark, NJ, Clara Maass Medical Center, Belleville, NJ, and Irvington General Hospital, Irvington, NJ. Past Chairman of The Physicians Division of The United Jewish Appeal of Metropolitan, NJ. Funeral services will be conducted from The Menoral Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd, Union, NJ, on Thursday September 12, 2002 at 11:30 A.M. Interment B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, NJ.

title: TRW Gets Contract For Space Telescope
description: TRW announced today that it had won an $824.8 million contract to build NASA's Next Generation Space Telescope, which is scheduled to replace the Hubble observatory in 2010.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Pre-Election Violence In Kashmir
description: A political worker for the People's Democratic Party was shot dead on Monday night in Kashmir as anti-India militants continued their effort to try to derail state elections scheduled to start on Monday. In another incident, gunmen tried yesterday to kill a candidate who is the brother of the state's chief minister. Indian security forces, meanwhile, said the army had killed three commanders of the main rebel group, Hizbul Mujahedin, on Monday night. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Joint Venture Ends After a Brief Life
description: The three largest agency companies are closing a media management agency that they had started with much fanfare only last year.

title: JETBLUE ENDS PLANS FOR SECOND SALE OF SHARES
description: The JetBlue Airways Corporation, a low-fare carrier that sold stock to the public in April, suspended plans for a second sale because major shareholders expressed little interest in selling their shares. Shares rose $3.98, to $43.76, after the chief executive, David Neeleman, told investors on a conference call that the plans were suspended. ''This is an incredibly positive statement for those people who are insiders and a statement for anybody who is looking at this company as far as an investment,'' said David Menlow, president of IPOfinancial.com. The airline has expanded, while most larger rivals reduced flight capacity after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: A Tear Falls, But President Holds Tightly To His Image

title: And Now, Back to Our Regularly Scheduled Programming
description: IN the uncertain days after 9/11, one of the few things asserted with absolute certainty was that our culture would be indelibly altered. A year later, very little has changed.

title: Threat of Terrorism Is Shaping the Focus Of Bush Presidency
description: Only 48 hours after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, George W. Bush first defined the role that the campaign against terrorism would play in his untried presidency. ''The nation must understand,'' Mr. Bush said somberly, speaking to reporters on a sparkling morning in the Oval Office, ''this is now the focus of my administration.''

title: An Indonesian Dish Puts the Coconut to Full Use
description: TEAMING coconut milk with coconut meat is a recipe device rarely seen outside Southeast Asia, and even there, coconut milk is almost always the flavor provider. Almost always.

description: HOW much of life has really changed since Sept. 11, 2001, some people have been heard to ask. For others it is clear.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: MASS DESERTION BY SOLDIERS In a stark display of low morale and eroding discipline in the country's military, 54 soldiers from the 20th Motorized Infantry Division in the southern city of Volgograd deserted en masse on Sunday, reportedly to protest the brutality of one of their commanders. The military's chief prosecutor, Lt. Gen. Aleksandr N. Savenkov, announced yesterday that his office would investigate the accusations of the soldiers, who have since been detained. "We intend to hand down tough punishments to the officials for violating the law, irrespective of their ranks," General Savenkov said. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

description: SAMUELS-Warren. Beloved son of Bessie. Devoted brother of Barbara (Donald) Greenberg, Burton and Renee. Loving uncle of Andrew Greenberg and Pam Bilecki. Dear friend to many. Services Thursday, 12 noon, Weinstein-Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, Coney Island Ave. at Ave. H, Brooklyn. description: Balls squirted across the field, wriggling through the grass and players' fingers tonight at Damaschke Park, where the Yankees and the Tigers opened a championship series -- in the Class A New York-Penn League, that is.

title: Teenagers Charged With Assault in Burning of Friend
description: Two New Jersey teenagers accused of pouring gasoline on a 15-year-old friend and then lighting him on fire twice during a late-night party in a wooded area last month have been charged with aggravated assault, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KELLERMAN, PETER RODNEY
description: KELLERMAN-Peter Rodney. In loving memory of my husband, Peter Rodney Kellerman. Honeybear, I miss you more and more every day. You are the best thing that ever happened to me.

title: Europe Lists Hundreds of U.S. Exports That May Face Tariffs
description: The European Commission has compiled a list of hundreds of American products, from cereals and soybeans to clothing and steel, on which it may impose retaliatory tariffs if the United States refuses to eliminate a tax break for American exporters.

A service will be held on Thursday, September 12 at 3PM at West End Collegiate Church, 368 West End Avenue and 77 St. Donations may be sent to North American Conference on Ethiopian Jewry, PO Box 757, Milwaukee, WI. 53201-9338.

title: A New Job Altered By Grief From Day 1
description: THERE is a photograph of Brogan Healy taken on his last day at the New York City Fire Academy. It is one of those embarrassing shots that shows him posing stiffly at the back of a fire truck. He is standing in his gear and looks so overjoyed that his big, proud, happy smile barely seems to fit on his face.

title: For Towers' Refugee Businesses, a Year of Struggle and Change
description: WHEN the World Trade Center towers fell, they took more with them than human lives. A huge segment of the downtown economy collapsed with the falling steel and concrete, and the disaster encompassed far more than the large financial firms that are most often identified with the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, MARGARET
description: HERTZ-Margaret. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our cherished member Margaret Hertz. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. description: The head coach put a positive spin on a train wreck. His players seem uncomfortable or unwilling to dwell on anything negative. The party line does not change much. ''We're going to get things turned around; things are headed in the right direction,'' they all seem to say.

title: Corrections
description: The Arts Abroad column on Aug. 28, about the Irish music festival Fleadh Cheoil na hEireann, gave a misspelled surname at some points for the chairman of the governing body of traditional Irish music. He is Labhras O Murchu, not Murch. A picture caption misspelled the surname of a pub owner whose son was shown leading a group of musicians outside. The owner was the late writer John B. Keane, not Kean. The article also misspelled the name of a type of Irish drum. It is a bodhran, not bodhrn.

title: Senator Loses Nomination After Changing Party Twice
description: Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire, who quit and rejoined the Republican Party in an episode that turned many of his own supporters against him, lost his party's nomination to return to Washington last night.

description: Often described as a model for chief executives, John F. Welch Jr. appears to have also created the model employment contract.

description: Roxana Pourshapour was on a flight from Shiraz to Tehran last month when she smelled something burning. Then the oxygen masks dropped.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the United States Mint's plans to redesign American coins referred incorrectly to an obsolete design on the back of the penny. The design, replaced in 1959 by the Lincoln Memorial, shows stalks of wheat, not a laurel.

title: REMEMBERING SEPTEMBER 11: Cargocontainers as weapons
description: SINGAPORE:  Last October, barely a month after the terrorist attacks on the United States, the authorities in the southern Italian port of Gioia Tauro made a discovery that alarmed international intelligence agencies and shippers.

title: A Firefighter Asks Why He, Alone, Survived . . . and Why He Remembers So Little
description: SHORTLY after the first tower fell, Kevin Shea, an off-duty firefighter, was found on West Street, with a broken neck, severed thumb, internal injuries, and very little memory of what he had done as the buildings burned. His amnesia caused him anguish, especially because the 12 other firefighters who raced to the World Trade Center from his fire company that morning never came back. Had he gone into the building with them? Why was he alone spared?

title: Dispensing Spice to Provide Some Variety in Life
description: This clever spice rack, a sheet of steel fitted with metal tins with magnetized bottoms, is meant to be hung, but you could also use the spice tins without the rack. The tins have many attributes. They are opaque, except for the top, which allows the contents to be viewed. Their lids have openings for shaking or pouring. Several sets and configurations are made by SoHo Spices and sold at the Art of Cooking, 555 Hudson Street (11th Street). A rack of five costs $39.95, and a rack of 20, which can hold up to 32 tins, is $179.95. Tins sold separately in sets of five are $29.95. Spices for the tins are extra.

title: Securing Freedom's Triumph
description: The Sept. 11 attacks moved Americans to grief and horror and moved our nation to war. They revealed the cruelty of our enemies, clarified grave threats to our country and demonstrated the character and decency of our people. At a moment of great testing, the spirit of men and women in New York City, at the Pentagon and aboard Flight 93 became the spirit of our country. Tonight in New York, I will be speaking of what our nation has lost, what we have discovered about ourselves and what lies ahead.

title: Militants in Kashmir Kill Candidate and Attack Bus Stop
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 11  Militants in the Indian state of Kashmir killed a state government minister who was campaigning for re-election today, signaling an escalation of violence as elections approach. The killing, the second of a candidate in less than a week, was followed by an attack on a bus stop in which at least seven people were killed.

description: True to its wildly spontaneous-seeming self, the eighth dancenow/NYC festival of downtown dance had two opening events this year. In the first, dancers of all varieties wound through and sprang up among wandering audiences in a performance and party on Thursday night at the handsome new Firehouse Community Space on Lafayette Street in Lower Manhattan. Then came the ''Main Event,'' a three-program marathon on Sunday afternoon uptown at the John Jay College Theater.

title: Arbitrator Explains Reasons Behind Police Pay Decision
description: Releasing a long-awaited decision to award New York City police officers an 11.7 percent raise over 24 months, the chairman of a state arbitration panel took pains yesterday to explain why the panel gave the police a slightly more generous deal than most other uniformed city unions.

description: Ballot Chaos Anew in Florida

title: For the Corn Ice Cream, Hold the Salt and Pepper
description: Corn ice cream is not as odd a notion as it might seem at first. Consider how many manufactured foods, ice cream included, are sweetened with corn syrup.

title: A Bright Yellow Reminder of a Frightful Cloud, and of Americans Who Became Her Heroes
description: THESE days the stroller, with its Tonka-toy colors, is coated with crumbs, the happy detritus of quick meals and a hectic schedule. But the last time Melody Belkin saw it on Sept. 11, when she had taken her son, Noah, to his preschool in downtown Manhattan, it was laden with the frightful dust that used to be the World Trade Center.

title: Guthrie Sees Hope for the Mets Next Year
description: Mark Guthrie made the correlation more than a month ago, when the Mets actually appeared capable of turning their season around. He spent last season in the Oakland Athletics' bullpen and was part of the team that overcame a rocky start to post one of the best records in baseball, going 61-17 to finish the season. They won 102 games, and finished 14 games behind the stunning Seattle Mariners. Guthrie thought the Mets were capable of such a run.

title: Klein Bypasses Local Boards And Names 3 Schools Chiefs
description: Exercising his new power for the second time in a week, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein has permanently hired three superintendents whose local school boards have been trying to fire them for several years.

title: House Panel Defers to Justice Dept. on Stewart
description: The chairman of the Congressional committee examining Martha Stewart's sale of ImClone Systems stock turned the matter over to the Justice Department today to determine whether Ms. Stewart may have caused ''materially false representations'' about her trading to be made over the last several months.

title: Going by 'Joe,' Not 'Yussef,' but Still Feeling Like an Outcast
description: AT a recent meeting of the Wednesday Club, two dozen Arab-American businessmen traded bawdy jokes across a table laden with plates of fettoosh and flaming platters of broiled meats, until Ahmad Chebbani interrupted with an announcement.

title: Polite Warriors Gird for Saturday's Bout
description: With exaggerated politeness, Oscar De La Hoya and Fernando Vargas ignored two nine-foot-tall plexiglass screens intended to keep them apart until Saturday's big fight and behaved themselves like nice little warriors today.

title: Death as a Constant Companion
description: IN its essence, the World Trade Center calamity is not about geopolitics, or security, or even terrorism. It is about death: a sudden, wholesale death whose aftershocks continue to rumble through the ground of the living, refusing to ease into memory's recesses in conformance with the natural order of things.

title: The Capital as 3 Cities, Each One Now a Fortress
description: THE 184 deaths at the Pentagon were modest compared with the toll at the World Trade Center, and the damage did not spread beyond part of one building. But no other city was more heavily subjected than Washington to the apocalyptic refrain of pundits and politicians that everything had been changed by the terrorist attacks, and that nothing would ever be the same again.

title: Instead of Cipro, Offering Panicky New Yorkers a Healthy Dose of Reality
description: Last fall, Dr. Steven C. Garner was the man to see for the magic pill  the antibiotic Cipro. As panic spread about anthrax, there was such a rush for the medicine that Dr. Garner, the chief medical officer of St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, found himself grudgingly prescribing three-day supplies to people just to calm them down.

title: Bush Finds a Friend in Carpenters' Union President
description: In a movement whose anthem is ''Solidarity Forever,'' Douglas J. McCarron, president of the carpenters' union, defiantly marches to a different drummer, so much so that some union leaders worry that he has marched into the enemy's camp.

title: Death Toll Is Near 3,000, but Some Uncertainty Over the Count Remains
description: IN the first chaotic weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, the list of missing and presumed dead soared to nearly 7,000. A year has passed, the rubble has been dug out, and what human remains could be found, have been meticulously collected. In that time, the count has been cut more than in half, offering a strange if unsatisfying sense of relief for a scarred nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAISDELL, ELAINE FRENCH
description: BLAISDELL-Elaine French, 81. Of Beechhurst, Whitestone, Flushing, NY, September 7, 2002. Predeceased by husband Philip E. (Tex) Blaisdell; mother of Barbara F. and Bruce F. Blaisdell; grandmother of Nicholas C. Blaisdell; sister of Barbara F. Crawford. ''Laney'' was a professional dancer in summer stock at Jones Beach Theater and USO Folies Bergere; was with McCrossen Real Estate over 35 years in sales and management. Visiting hours at Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150 St., Whitestone, NY Friday, Sept. 13, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Last respects Saturday 9/14 9am, followed by interment at Moravian Cemetery, Staten Island. All invited to join celebration of her life Saturday, Sept. 14, 1:30-4pm at Friends and Company, 154-17 Roosevelt Ave., Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to causes Laney supported during her life: Southern Poverty Law Center, Sierra Club, the Susan B. Anthony House, and North Shore Animal Shelter.

title: Agency Chiefs Readjusting To the New Imperatives
description: Moving up through the ranks in the Coast Guard for 38 years, Adm. Thomas H. Collins has rescued hapless boaters, chased drug runners, caught smugglers of illegal immigrants and promoted maritime safety. It never occurred to him, Admiral Collins said, that when he reached the pinnacle of his career and became commandant, the principal focus of his work would be protecting the nation's shores from terrorist attacks.

title: Noah and 9/11
description: Over the past year several friends have remarked to me how much they still feel a pit in their stomachs from 9/11. One even said she felt as if this was the beginning of the end of the world. And no wonder. Those suicide hijackings were such an evil act that they shattered your faith in human beings and in the wall of civilization that was supposed to constrain the worst in human behavior. There is now a big jagged hole in that wall.

title: At Ground Zero: Bagpipes, Readings and Flowers
description: Hours before sunrise today — with klieg lights still bathing the site where a year ago the twin towers of the World Trade Center stood — the crowds had already started to gather in Lower Manhattan near ground zero.

title: Katrin Cartlidge, 41, Known for Bold, Offbeat Roles

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, MARGARET DELANO

title: Rebuilding and Recovering
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Scenes Revisited, Lives Resumed
description: How much of life has really changed since Sept. 11, 2001, some people have been heard to ask. For others it is clear. New York Times photographers recently revisited people and settings they recorded on 9/11 and in the week after. Their subjects were among the survivors, the grieving and the public servants. How are those people today, those witnesses to so much death and destruction then?  Dust and ash are gone, but not the memories of those days.

title: Hidden Storage Space
description: Benches and stools that do double duty: seating and storage.

description: One year later, a ceremony to commemorate those killed on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILTON, JOHN ALLEN
description: HILTON-John Allen. Of Sea Bright, NJ, on September 11, 2002. Husband of Lucy (nee Scott), father of John, Sarah, Mark, Peter, Hank, Jamie, and Judith Hilton, and Lucy Minder. Brother of Norman Hilton, and Bobbie Rogers. Grandfather of 12. Visitation Friday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. at The Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad Street, Red Bank, NJ. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9 A.M. at Holy Cross R.C. Church, Rumson, N.J. Memorial donations to The John Hilton Memorial Fund at The Monmouth Association For Retarded Citizens, 1158 Wayside Road, Tinton Falls, New Jersey 07712, are preferred.

title: Thwarting Love and Greed In Puccini's Three One-Acts
description: Last year the New York City Opera was to open its season on Sept. 11. Rallying itself, the company bravely opened just four days later. Before that performance, Paul Kellogg, the general and artistic director, appeared onstage with his entire company -- singers in costumes, technical crew, choristers, administrators -- to offer some words and lead the audience in the singing of the national anthem. It was a helpful sign that the city's cultural life would go on.

title: A Life Begins
description: Sometime between 6 a.m., when the contractions start, and 1:22 p.m., when Julia Kordas emerges from her mother's body, Edyta Duda turns to Karol Kordas, her curly-haired husband and high school sweetheart, and says, ''No more children.''

title: Campaign Season; Hip-Hop the Vote For Black Candidates
description: By Representative Charles B. Rangel's count, it is easy to calculate the power surge for black lawmakers if Democrats retake the House in November: 2 committee and 17 subcommittee chairmanships.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Battered By Storm
description: Nineteen people were injured by strong winds and businesses, government offices and schools closed at mid-day when a severe tropical storm veered toward the Chinese territory. The American Chamber of Commerce canceled a Sept. 11 memorial service at the city's concert hall at which Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, had been scheduled to speak. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Long Day And Year Take a Toll On the Mets
description: The Mets' dugout was full of players before this afternoon's game, most of whom stood on the top step looking out toward the scoreboard in center field and the video recalling what took place a year ago in New York. Bobby Valentine and Mike Piazza leaned against the railing, their right hands on their foreheads, Valentine tugging at his hair. When the public address announcer asked for a moment of silence to honor the victims of the terrorist attacks, Valentine lowered his head against the railing before standing upright.

title: 3 Groups Already Squabbling Over Oil-Flush North Iraq Should Hussein Be Toppled
description: While the Bush administration has yet to decide whether to attack Iraq, rival ethnic groups in the north of that country are already squabbling over the spoils of any future war.

title: Judge Rebuffs a Miss North Carolina's Effort to Reclaim Title
description: Close. But no tiara.

title: Campaign Season; Family Matters, But It's Not Enough
description: In the days before Tuesday's Democratic primary, Kennedys seemed to pop up everywhere in the Maryland suburbs, stumping for Mark Shriver, the nephew of Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts. But the firepower of one of the nation's most prominent political families did not help. Mr. Shriver lost, barely, to Christopher Van Hollen, a seasoned state legislator.

title: How Mac and Windows Can Talk to Each Other
description: Q. I have been a PC user since 1984. Until recently it has been my understanding that Mac files and Windows files are incompatible. Is that still true? If I should buy an iMac, could I still exchange files with people who use Windows 98 or XP?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the final minutes of the Marriott Hotel at 3 World Trade Center misstated the citizenship of Abdul A. Malahi, a hotel employee who was killed there. He was a native of Yemen but a naturalized United States citizen.

title: A Day of Tributes, Tears And the Litany of the Lost
description: They followed one another down, down into a seven-story hole in Lower Manhattan yesterday, thousands of them, filling with their sorrow the space where their husbands and wives, mothers and fathers, sisters and brothers, sons and daughters, had died a year ago to the day. Some left cut flowers on the hard earth; some left photographs; some left whispered words.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Jobless Rate Steady
description: Britain's unemployment rate maintained a 27-year low of 3.1 percent last month. The number of people claiming jobless benefits fell unexpectedly by 6,400 to 943,300, according to official figures. Economists attributed the fall to increased hiring by government agencies seeking to improve public services. Some retailers are also taking on workers, partly offsetting a decline in manufacturing jobs. The report said annualized wage increases in the quarter to July were only slightly above expectations of 4 percent, strengthening arguments that the Bank of England is unlikely to raise interest rates soon. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Justice in the Shadows
description: In a dark moment for the American legal system, a federal appeals court met behind closed doors earlier this week to hear the Justice Department argue for increased power to wiretap suspected spies and terrorists. The United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review, a special panel established to oversee such wiretaps, violated two cherished principles of American judicial process: it met in secret, and it allowed only one side in a controversy to be heard.

title: Fed Official Wants Executives' Pay Cut
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York called on corporations yesterday to cut the pay of executives.

title: For the Ecletic Apartment Owner Who Needs Everything
description: THE complete eclecticist should have a substantial list of unusual resources to start with, as Brad Floyd, James Iha's architect, did. His included the following, all in Manhattan:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RAYMOND
description: GOLDBERG-Raymond. On September 11, 2002. The love of Estelle (Sunkin), devoted father to Andrea and Robyn. Adoring Grandpa of Rachel and Ashley. Brother to Joe, Sidney and Sanford. Ray cared about everyone and everything. He will forever live in all our hearts. Services Friday 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Every Inch a King, Every Moment A Revelation
description: The words are spoken lightly, a punch line of sorts in a bantering exchange with a fool. Yet even as it leaves the old man's mouth, the phrase seems to return in reproachful echo: ''Nothing can be made of nothing.'' The smile on King Lear's face melts into cloudedness. Where has he heard those words before?

title: Germany's Cautious Candidates
description: Germany's lackluster election campaign continues Europe's recent trend of blurring the difference between the major parties of the center-left and the center-right. Chancellor Gerhard Schrder, the Social Democratic incumbent, and Edmund Stoiber, his Christian Democratic challenger, have hewed as closely as possible to the uncontroversial center ground. Neither has offered any bold proposals for reviving Germany's sluggish economy, the No. 1 concern of most Germans, nor has there been much heated debate on other issues.

title: Kashmir Violence Increases as Election Nears
description: Militants in the Indian state of Kashmir killed a state government minister who was campaigning for re-election today, signaling an increase in violence as elections approach. The killing, the second of a candidate in less than a week, was followed by an attack on a bus stop in which at least seven people were killed.

title: The Split in the Saudi Royal Family
description: Fifteen of the 19 suicide bombers who killed 3,000 Americans a year ago yesterday were Saudi citizens.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's not another world, it's not another place. Iowa is the same as New York, Iowa is the same as Texas -- America is America.''

title: It's a Pack of Gum? A Lighter? Nope, an MP3 Player
description: The Nomad MuVo, a digital music player and file-storage device from Creative, is a nifty gadget. Unlike most peripherals, it requires no cable to connect to a computer. Its core -- smaller than a pack of gum -- plugs directly into a U.S.B. port and acts as an additional drive. No file-transfer software is needed, and for Windows XP, 2000 and Me and Mac OS 9 and X, no drivers are needed either. (Drivers for Windows 98 are included on a CD.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, CURT C.
description: SILBERMAN-Curt C. The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany (Claims Conference) deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Curt C. Silberman, a veteran member of our Board and Chairman of major committees. Since the advent of Hitler to power in 1933 Dr. Silberman devoted his entire life to fighting for the rights and serving the interests of Jewish victims of Nazi persecution. We shall miss his wise counsel and warm friendship. Israel Singer, President Julius Berman, Chairman Gideon Taylor, Exec VP Saul Kagan, Exec VP Emerit.

title: President and Wife Draw Warm Response in Meeting With Families
description: An hour after the 40 victims of Flight 93 were formally commemorated as the first citizen-soldiers in the war on terrorism, their loved ones walked today onto the jetliner's impact site, a sward of an old strip mine, to be greeted by President Bush on a bracingly windy, cloudy day.

title: A Silent City, Except for the Wind
description: A somber hush enveloped much of the city and surrounding region yesterday during four moments of silence observed on the anniversary of the World Trade Center attack.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Exports Fall
description: German exports fell for a second month in three in July, adding to signs the country's economy will struggle to grow in the third quarter. German companies sold 4.5 percent less in other countries in July than in the previous month, adjusted for seasonal swings, the Federal Statistics Office said. The trade surplus still widened to 12.1 billion euros from a revised 10.8 billion euros in June as imports dropped 7.3 percent, the office said.

title: INSIDE
description: Johnny Unitas Dies

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Billions More For The Military
description: The cabinet approved a 36 percent increase in military spending on new equipment, maintenance and research and development, in line with promises made by President Jacques Chirac during his campaign for re-election in the spring. The increase, to about $16.5 billion a year from about $12.1 billion, includes money for a second aircraft carrier to project French military might more effectively. The number of people in the armed forces, including the paramilitary gendarmerie, is to rise to 446,000 by 2008, from 437,000. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; 'When You Know What You're Doing'
description: ANYBODY who was at Yankee Stadium in the dusk of that late afternoon in 1958 will never forget how Johnny Unitas heisted the National Football League championship that the Giants thought they had won.

title: A Tribute in Flowers
description: At 3 a.m., Richard Janmaat is standing in a Long Island warehouse gazing at the 27,000 roses that will soon be placed at ground zero as a tribute to the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Honoring Those Lost and Celebrating a New Symbol of Resilience
description: The ceremony next to the Pentagon's new limestone facade this morning was part memorial service, part call to arms and part celebration of the building's remarkable reconstruction.

title: Leggett & Platt Profit
description: CARTHAGE, Mo., Sept. 11 (Bloomberg News)  Leggett & Platt , a leading maker of furniture springs, wires and fabric, said today that third-quarter profit would be 27 cents a share, less than forecast, because of costs to close and sell five plants.

title: China Toughens Obstacles to Internet Searches
description: Some Chinese Internet users seeking the popular search engine Google today instead are now instantly routed to GlobePage, which calls itself the ''premier Asian search engine.''

title: Painful to Hear
description: Long before Helen Simpkin Whalen steps onto ground zero, the wind swirling around her, she is determined to be there. She wants to make sure that her sister and the other passengers on the planes are remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAINTON, ROBERT LEWIS
description: BAINTON - Robert Lewis. (President/Ownwer of the former B & B Beverage, Long Branch, N.J.) Died September 10th, 2002 at St. Barnabas Hospice, Long Branch, N.J. He was predeceased by his daughter, Mary Joy Bainton and his brother John W. Bainton. He is survived by his wife Florence Joy Bainton; a son, William Lewis Bainton; a brother Donald J. Bainton; a sister, Patricia Bainton and several nieces and nephews. Visitation will be Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave, Red Bank, N.J. Mass of Christian Burial will be held 10AM Saturday at the Church of the Nativity, Fair Haven, N.J. Memorial donations may be made to St. Barnabas Hospice at Monmouth Medical Center, 300 2nd Avenue, CW6, Long Branch, N.J. 07740.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Electronics Maker Lowers Outlook
description: Hitachi Ltd. lowered its profit forecast to break-even in the first six months of its fiscal year because of declining profits at its overseas power equipment and digital appliance businesses. Hitachi, Japan's biggest electronics producer, previously expected to earn 5 billion yen ($41.7 million) in the April-to- September period. The company also slashed its expected operating profit by 25 percent, but left its sales projections unchanged.

title: Offering Messages of Love To the Parents They Lost
description: The world, or so it has sometimes seemed over the last year, is awash with tributes. From simple scrawls to elaborate orations, thousands of people have tried to put into words their thoughts about those who died.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Plan For Asset Sales
description: The chairman of ABB, Jrgen Dormann, who took over as chief executive last week, plans to speed up asset sales to restore profits at the company, Europe's largest electrical engineering company. Mr. Dormann may sell parts of the oil-drilling unit, one of the company's least profitable, he said on a conference call. ABB, which last week sold part of a finance unit to the General Electric Company, has earmarked its building-systems division for sale in 2003. ''ABB's portfolio is too broad,'' Mr. Dormann told investors and analysts. He said more divestments were expected.

title: G.O.P. Presses Democrats to Act Quickly on an Iraq Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 — Republican leaders on Capitol Hill pressed Democrats today to act quickly and show the world that Congress backs President Bush in his resolve to confront Iraq if necessary.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: AUSTRIA: HAIDER READY FOR COMEBACK Jorg Haider appeared set to return as leader of the far-right Freedom Party after its executive committee nominated him as chairman. Defense Minister Herbert Scheibner, one of the party members in the coalition government that collapsed on Monday, said the nomination would be voted on at a convention on Sept. 21. Mr. Haider, an anti-immigrant populist who gave up the chairmanship of the party two years ago after it entered the government, led a party revolt over tax policies that prompted Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel to break up the coalition and call for early elections, which are expected in November or early December. (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Growth
description: Japan's economy grew at a 2.6 percent annualized rate in the April-June quarter, slightly better than previous estimates. The gross domestic product figure was a revision of the 1.9 percent growth estimated by the government two weeks ago. The report said larger inventories and faster exports were behind the upgrade. However, consumer spending, which makes up the largest part of the economy, was largely unchanged from the initial report. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: JAMES IHA stuck a table lamp on the ceiling of his new apartment in New York to use as an overhead lighting fixture, but that piece of upside-down thinking didn't quite work out.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Larry Drury, chief executive for the Americas at FutureBrand Worldwide, New York, was named to the new post of worldwide director for multinational clients. Also, Denis Riney, executive director for new business in North America, was named executive vice president for worldwide marketing, also a new post. FutureBrand is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Bush's Pilgrimage Ends With Vow to Prevail Over 'Terrorist or Tyrant'
description: President Bush went on a memorial pilgrimage yesterday to ground zero, the Pentagon and a windblown Pennsylvania field, touching once again the scars of the Sept. 11 attacks, bearing witness to thousands of dead and seeming to foreshadow another war ahead.

title: Europe Pauses and Grieves, But Takes Issue With U.S.

description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar advanced on expectations that a recovery will be stronger in the United States than in Europe and Japan. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.40 yen, up from 119.88 on Tuesday.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Day
description: There are no more words, right now, for us to use about Sept. 11. The organizers of the ceremonies at ground zero understood that yesterday, when they structured the anniversary remembrance around the reading of the names of the victims rather than speeches. It was impossible for anyone who listened to avoid noticing the range of ethnicities and nationalities on that long, long list. That spoke more to the question of what America is, what it has to protect and carry forward, than anything else that happened yesterday.

title: Journey Back From the Abyss in Beijing
description: True-life stories of battles with drug addiction, when they don't end in death, have a predictable arc: the hero's fall into degradation, his touch-and-go struggle for a cure, then redemption as a witness for the clean and sober.

title: 2 Indians Acquitted In Protest Over Land
description: Two Shinnecock Indians who were arrested two years ago while protesting the development of land that they claimed was stolen from their tribe were found not guilty yesterday in Southampton Town Court.

title: Family Mourns a Breadwinner And a Dream That Perished
description: Today, in a simple Mass, the family of Leobardo Lpez laid their hopes, but not his body, to rest.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the French Resistance leader Henri Roi-Tanguy yesterday misstated the name of a medal he was awarded. It is the Grand'Croix de la Lgion d'Honneur, not the Grand-Croix de la Lgion de l'Honneur.

title: Kim Hunter, 79, an Actress Lauded as Stella in 'Streetcar'
description: Kim Hunter, whose eclectic 60-year career included an Oscar, two Emmy nominations and a Broadway triumph with her portrayal of Stella in the legendary 1947 debut of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' died on Wednesday at her New York apartment. She was 79.

title: VIGILANCE AND MEMORY: PERSPECTIVES/Gen. Pervez Musharraf; U.S. Must Develop a 'Consensus in the Muslim World'
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with the president of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. The interview was conducted in English.

description: Every so often, The Times sends its theatre critic to London to report on the latest plays and musicals there. Often, what he finds there is a preview of what will soon be coming to Broadway.

title: The Wisdom of Imagining The Worst-Case Scenario
description: Like most Americans, I've reflected this week on the personal impact of the tragedy of Sept. 11, recalling most vividly the trauma of emptiness I felt in the pit of my stomach as I watched the towers of the World Trade Center vanish from my television screen. The feeling still periodically recurs. In a flash, the inconceivable had become real, the horror of the unbelievable had become part of my and every American's existence.

title: Man Leaps From Fire to Death After Killing Woman, Police Say
description: A 36-year-old man jumped to his death from an eighth-story apartment window Tuesday night, after apparently stabbing a woman to death and setting the apartment on fire, the authorities said today.

title: Somehow, Having Fun
description: After the Masses and the station-house memorials and a day spent looking over their shoulders, a few dozen firefighters gather at the Spring Lounge, a shot-and-a-beer joint in Little Italy, and start doing what was unthinkable a year ago.

title: From Pew to Barstool, New Yorkers Take a Poignant Look Back
description: The men of Ladder Company 14 and Engine Company 35 in Harlem muster at 8:46 a.m. They pull their trucks onto Third Avenue, raise the American flag and step back inside the empty firehouse bay to say a prayer.

title: Giving Peace A Chance, Again
description: Immediately after the terrorist attacks of last Sept. 11, most songwriters said that the acts were of such magnitude that they could not respond to them in song so soon. As months passed, however, a variety of musicians -- Neil Young, Bruce Springsteen, Papa Roach, Alan Jackson, Sleater-Kinney, the Wu-Tang Clan -- began to set their thoughts to music. A year later, there are scores of such songs.

title: A Man of Words, and an Event That Defies Them
description: THERE are events in human life that, ultimately, must always remain mysterious. The worst tragedies that beset us are often beyond comprehension and elude description. These tragedies gnaw at us, churning around inside, at once coloring all we do yet refusing to be captured and contained.

title: War Emblem Sold; Will Stand at Stud
description: War Emblem, this year's Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes winner, has been sold to Japanese interests and, after a final start in the Oct. 26 Breeders' Cup Classic, will be sent overseas to stand at stud.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Introduces Faster Chips
description: The Intel Corporation has introduced two faster Xeon microprocessors for low-end server computers. Intel's 2.8-gigahertz Xeon for two-processor servers, typically used to distribute Web pages and do scientific calculations, is 17 percent faster than the current top-of-the-line chip in that category, a spokesman, Robert Manetta, said. It sells for $562 in batches of 1,000, 9 percent less than the 2.4-gigahertz chip that until now was the fastest Xeon. Intel hopes to increase demand by selling speedier chips at lower prices. Server sales fell 20 percent in 2001 compared with the previous year and are expected to decline another 5 percent this year, according to the research concern IDC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISH, CHARLOTTE BLACKMAN
description: FISH-Charlotte Blackman, 90. On September 3, 2002, after a short illness in Deerfield Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Joseph T. Fish, of Logan, West VA. Mother of Jacqueline Fish, and Frances Fish Tompkins. Mother-inlaw of Judge Harold Tompkins. Grandmother of Laurence Alan Fish Tompkins, Michael Barnett Lembeck, Alyssa Rae Lembeck Klein, and her husband, Andrew Klein. Great grandmother of Olivia Danielle, and Ellie Jordana Klein. A native of Cincinnati, Ohio, she came to Logan, West VA. in 1938 as a bride, until her move to Florida in 1990, after her husband's death. A supporter of many West VA charitable organizations. The West Virginia Boy Scout Service Center, was renamed The Joseph T. and Charlotte B. Fish Scout Building, in recognition of scouting programs. She was a Founding Member of The Alef Society of The Central Capital Agency for Jewish Education in Broward County, FL. She received many awards from Hadassah, especially for The Youth Aliyah Program, and Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. Many recognitions were presented by The State of Israel Bonds, and The UJA. She and her husband were given a special award by The Associates of Hebrew Union College Jewish Institute of Religion. Her wisdom, love, and devotion to family, her endearing sense of humor, and her fierce commitment to philanthropy will long be remembered by those privileged to have known her. In lieu of flowers, contributions to B'nai Sholom Congregation, PO Box 2674, Huntington, West VA. 25726, would be appreciated. For additional information, please contact: Plaza Memorial Chapel, at 212-769-4400.

title: Skandia Weighing What to Do With Its U.S. Unit
description: Seeking to stem losses from a costly United States expansion, Skandia, the large Swedish financial services company, is exploring several options for its American subsidiary, including an outright sale or merger with a rival, people involved in the discussions said today.

title: The Industry Hardest Hit Pauses for Rituals of Remembrance Big and Small
description: Business took a back seat to heartache yesterday as a subdued Wall Street found public and private ways to observe the anniversary of events that tore into the heart of the nation's financial community a year ago.

title: Debris Flies And a Boater Is Drowned In High Wind
description: Wind gusts of up to 60 miles per hour pummeled the New York metropolitan region yesterday, causing at least one death and more than a dozen injuries as debris blew from construction sites, heavy tree limbs snapped and high seas tossed small boats.

description: World Feels Pain of U.S.

description: People who had hoped that yesterday's date would bring them luck in the lottery were pleasantly surprised after the New York Lottery's winning numbers for the evening drawing, 911, were chosen.

title: VIGILANCE AND MEMORY: SOME MOMENTS -- Guantnamo Bay; Taps Is in the Air, Inmates in the Cells
description: The 598 men in custody here in connection with last year's war in Afghanistan were invisible today, shielded from view inside their metal prison camp in this isolated military outpost in the Caribbean.

title: Campaigns are scaled back as sales of special new malt beverages show an early peak.
description: A NEW category of alcoholic beverages is starting to show signs it is a fad rather than a trend, jeopardizing the advertising spending windfall expected by Madison Avenue.

title: The Same Feelings
description: Mohammed Hossain stops his taxi at a light on the Avenue of the Americas and reaches under his seat for his Bangladeshi newspaper. The front page shows a blurry picture of Lower Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, GERALDINE
description: KRAMER - Geraldine. On September 9, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Manny. Mother of Nathaniel and Robert, and their wives Georgia and Geri. Grandmother of Cheryl, Seth and Rori, David and his wife Jody, great grandmother of Justin and Caroline. Sister of Mitchell Eason and his wife Cynthia. She enriched the lives of many with her warmth and love, and will be dearly missed. Funeral service Friday, September 13, Schwartz Bros, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Bloomberg Is, by Turns, Pensive and Peripatetic
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's public role may have appeared minimal yesterday, but the hats he wore were many. He was the master of ceremonies at ground zero, host to the president and other officials, and the source of comfort to those who chose to look to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YABLON, PHILIP
description: YABLON-Philip, DDS, MPH, PhD. Suddenly on September 11, 2002. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Loving father of Susan and Jeffrey Yuhas and Paul and Jill Yablon. Dear brother of Mildred and Larry Maslow. Devoted grandfather of Sophie, Isabelle, Nicole and Stephen. Memorial Service, Friday, September 13, Noon at Zion Memorial Chapel, 767 E. Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, Dean's Office, 630 W 168 Street, N.Y., N.Y 10032

title: For the Families, a Long Year's Journey Into Grief, and Back Again
description: Grief, the initial body blow of loss, and mourning, the absorption of that blow, are unpredictable. The families of those who died in the World Trade Center attack absorbed deaths that were unexpected, violent, traumatic, public and even seemingly apocalyptic. Those deaths created distinctive forms of grief: traumatized, uncomprehending, unrelentingly public.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil For the United States
description: Russia's largest oil producer, Lukoil, said it would unveil a plan in October to ship oil to the United States. Lukoil previously said it wanted to export to the United States from the port of Murmansk on the Barents Sea, but first sought financing for improvements needed for the port. Lukoil would be the second Russian oil company, after Yukos Oil Company, Russia's second-largest producer, to export oil to America. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT).

title: Keeping It Quiet
description: The clunky Panasonic radio from the 1960's usually blares pop music at Mr. Giuseppe's Belle Harbor Barber Shop. The owner, Frank Giambra, whose father started cutting hair here on Beach 129th Street in 1966, switches on Z-100 in the morning, even before he lays out the shears, the talc and the shaving cream.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: ALOSS FOR PERFORMANCE TECHNOLOGIES Performance Technologies Inc., a maker of communications and networking equipment, warned that it would have a third-quarter loss and would cut another 7 percent of its work force to trim expenses. The loss will be 7 cents to 9 cents a share on an operating basis, on revenue of $3.6 million to $4.1 million, Performance Technologies said. In July, the company, which is based in Rochester, projected profit of 2 cents to 6 cents a share and $6 million to $7.5 million in revenue. Performance Technologies plans to reduce annual expenses by about $1.2 million. Costs related to the job cuts will reduce third-quarter profit by about $400,000. About 12 jobs will be affected, based on a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that said the company had about 168 employees as of Jan. 31. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTLEY, EUGENE LEON ARD
description: HARTLEY - Eugene Leon ard, Ph.D. Born 1912, died September 9, 2002. Psychologist, Professor Emeritus, City University of New York; Dean Emeritus, University of Wisconsin, Green Bay; Past President, The Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues. Devoted husband, father, grandfather, greatgrandfather, ever in our hearts. For information Neptune Society of Northern CA, Chico Branch.

description: To the Editor:

title: Expectations? Hey, He Calls Himself Ugly
description: Isaac Brock stepped up to the microphone to explain what was about to happen. ''Tonight,'' he said, ''we're going to play a whole bunch of songs based on -- you guys seen the movie 'Waterworld'?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCBRYDE, THOMAS HENRY
description: McBRYDE-Thomas Henry. Died at his home in Gainsville, FL, August 31st. Survived by his wife Barbara W. McBryde, daughter Elise McBryde, sons William and John McBryde, and grandson Evan Maloney. A memorial service will be held at Christ's Church, Rye, NY on Friday, October 4th at 11 AM.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the French Resistance leader Henri Roi-Tanguy yesterday misstated the name of a medal he was awarded. It is the Grand'Croix de la Legion d'Honneur, not the Grand-Croix de la Legion de l'Honneur.

title: As People Try to Work, Memories and a Hush
description: From the moment the workday began for Paul Robitaille, things were different.

title: Pistons' Stackhouse Traded to Wizards
description: Jerry Stackhouse and Richard Hamilton exchanged cities in a six-player trade last night, a surprise ending to Michael Jordan's complete overhaul of the Washington Wizards starting lineup as he prepares for his final season.

title: Leak at Indian Point 2 Plant Leads It to Curtail Operations
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear plant shut down its electricity production today to repair a hydrogen leak in its nonnuclear operations that plant officials said was first discovered by workers about two weeks ago.

title: In the Bronx, Totals Are Close and Real Close
description: With the primary over and all the machine votes counted, a few legislative races in the city remained close yesterday, and one candidate called for a court-sanctioned investigation to ensure that no voter fraud occurred.

title: Sweeping Charges Expected for Tyco's Ex-Chief and 2 Others
description: The Manhattan district attorney and the Securities and Exchange Commission plan to bring new and wide-ranging criminal and civil charges today against Tyco International's former chief executive and two other former executives, people briefed on the plan said last night.

title: Moscow Journal; The Kick in the Fruit Punch Could Be Atomic
description: Good news for Muscovites! ''There are practically no cases of radioactive watermelons this year,'' says Andrei A. Buyanov.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Two Men Who Can Talk

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, SYLVIA
description: SEGAL-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Devoted mother of David & Christina Segal and Donald and Mindi Segal. Adored grandmother of Jayme Segal.

title: Afghanistan's Faltering Reconstruction
description: Despite the ouster of the Taliban from power last November, the hard struggle to bring stability to Afghanistan continues, as shown by the car bombing in Kabul last week that killed 30 people and the assassination attempt against President Hamid Karzai in Kandahar the same day.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN
