description: Following are the main provisions of the United Nations Security Council 1991 resolutions on Iraq:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLGOFF, DEBORAH
description: DOLGOFF - Deborah. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the sister of its distinguished Administrative Committee member Sanford Lurie. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: Talking Heads, By E-Mail
description: ONLY a few years into the e-mail age, ''the memo'' has already become an all-purpose punch line. Guest 1: ''Where's Bob? It's his wedding, for goodness' sake!'' Guest 2: ''Maybe he never read the memo.''

title: One Year: Snapshots of an America in Mourning; Complete the Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: E-Mail Spam Startles Some Anti-Spammers
description: Tens of thousands of readers of e-mail newsletters have recently been inundated with unsolicited overtures from pornography Web sites and get-rich-quick schemes, the newsletter publishers say, and they are blaming the company that manages and distributes the newsletters for them.

title: A Cozy Corner Good For Art or Dining
description: Unfinished furniture allows buyers more creativity, with custom colors or finishes. Sometimes the price is right, too: this week one supplier with solid wood pieces, Pop's Unfinished Furniture, is having a sale. ''Our customers are from the foothills to Beverly Hills,'' said Ira Friedman, an owner.

title: Most Any Climate Can Grow a Grape
description: GRAPES are among the most forgiving of vines, growing almost everywhere people choose to live. Growers have tinkered with them for generations, crossing and recrossing varieties in search of the sweetest, the hardiest, the most jelly-eligible.

title: Departing Rights Commissioner Faults U.S.
description: In the final days of her five years in office, Mary Robinson, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, has sharply criticized the United States for eroding civil liberties at home and human rights standards around the world since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: VIGILANCE AND MEMORY: SOME MOMENTS -- San Diego; Flight Instructor Defends His Name
description: Rick Garza, a flight instructor here, wants his countrymen to know that he was not the man who trained Saudi assassins to fly American Airlines Flight 77 into the Pentagon.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Rating Raised
description: Fitch Ratings raised the bond rating of Kookmin Bank, the largest commercial bank in South Korea, setting off a gain of more than 2 percent in its stock price. Fitch raised Kookmin, which merged last year with Housing and Commercial Bank, to A- from BBB after concluding that its management seemed capable of successfully handling the challenges of the integration process.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS, Glenview, Ill., a maker of security seals and locks, bought the security business of U.K.-based Envopak Group, to increase its manufacturing capacity and sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKMAN, RAY L.
description: BERKMAN-Ray L. (nee Gutterman). On September 11, 2002. Predeceased by her beloved Leonard. Devoted mother of Paula and George Akst, Eileen and Howard Berkman. Adored grandmother of Jill & Craig Sheflin, Rebecca Akst, Deborah and Emily Berkman. Cherished baby sister of Samuel, the late Charles and the late Benjamin. Treasured sister-inlaw, aunt and friend. Services Thursday, September 12 at 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Big Picture On Digital TV: It's Still Fuzzy
description: IT was a torrid 111 degrees in Woodland Hills, Calif., the Sunday before Labor Day, and the action at the local air-conditioned electronics store was hot. Scores of people were admiring the large wide-screen high-definition digital television sets, and at least one family was ready to buy.

title: Durable Martin Isn't Sure He'll Be Able to Face Patriots
description: Curtis Martin has such a high pain threshold that he has not missed a game in the last two seasons, despite twice tearing the medial collateral ligament in his left knee and once having a ligament tear away from a bone in his buttocks.

title: Corrections
description: Picture credits were reversed in Business Day yesterday with an article about the condition of the airline industry. The photograph of passengers waiting to pass through a security checkpoint at Hartsfield Airport in Atlanta was by Erik. S. Lesser for The New York Times. The one of a flight attendant being checked in Chicago, was by Tim Boyle/Getty Images.

title: Johnny Unitas, N.F.L.'s Genius of the Huddle, Dies at 69
description: Johnny Unitas, who rose from a $6-a-game sandlot player to become perhaps professional football's greatest quarterback, died yesterday in suburban Baltimore. He was 69.

title: In America's Heartland, Children With Stars and Stripes in Their Eyes
description: The first graders, in white, were the stars, sprinkled amid the tiny blue T-shirts of the kindergartners. Fifth graders, shoulder to shoulder, made up the long red stripe at the bottom. The middle school stood behind: sixth grade a red ''U,'' seventh a white ''S,'' eighth a blue ''A.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bond Payment Withheld
description: AT&T Canada Inc. said that it could not make interest payments due later this month on $1.35 billion of bonds. The telecommunications company, based in Toronto, is 31 percent owned by the AT&T Corporation. In spite of deregulation of the Canadian telephone market, AT&T and others have struggled to compete against Bell Canada and the Telus Corporation, which previously held government-sanctioned monopolies in Ontario, Quebec and Alberta. AT&T Canada reported a first-half loss of 1.51 billion Canadian dollars. It is presently in talks with creditors to restructure its debt. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: To Landlords' Vexation, Cities Embrace the Dish
description: TELEVISION has changed the American city from top to bottom. In the days of Lucy and Ricky, antennas covered apartment rooftops. Then came the cable lines buried under the streets or snaking along utility poles. Now, a device once identified with the countryside is showing up in urban landscapes: the satellite dish.

title: Metro Matters; A Modern Rite Of Mourning: Must-See TV
description: THE sun shone in New York City yesterday. A rainstorm approaching from the south went out to sea instead.

title: Rams Need to Do Something to Contain Strahan
description: Kurt Warner may never have done Chunky Soup commercials if St. Louis Coach Mike Martz had a weaker personality and the range of Marshall Faulk's brilliance remained unfulfilled. And Tom Brady may never have realized national celebrity if Martz had a more modest perspective of his own system.

title: For Annan, U.N. Offers 'Broad, Sustained and Global Response'
description: Following are excerpts from a speech prepared by Secretary General Kofi Annan for delivery to the General Assembly on Thursday:

title: Military Stays Popular, for Travel and School
description: War is on their minds: the war on terrorism, the threat of war in Iraq, the possibility of combat.

title: A Little Bit of Taliesin, Closer to Lake Tahoe
description: To sell land in Northern California, an hour from Lake Tahoe, it helps to have a name-brand designer attached. The Nakoma Resort and Spa is based on a design by Frank Lloyd Wright. A 427-lot subdivision, known as Gold Mountain, surrounds the resort and has many houses designed by Taliesin Architects, a subsidiary of the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation. The architects have planned the remote community to ''fit the site, using materials found in the mountain setting,'' said Peggy Garner, one of the developers. The most expensive homes have acid-aged copper trim in Frank Lloyd Wright-inspired patterns. Community guidelines mandate nonreflective building materials and indigenous colors, so stained red-cedar siding, above, is encouraged while Colonial yellow house paint is not.

title: From Pew to Barstool, New Yorkers Take a Poignant Look Back
description: FIRE STATION

title: Listening Closely
description: It is just after noon as John T. Odermatt, the commissioner of the city's Office of Emergency Management, speeds in a truck bound for his new $8 million headquarters on Water Street in Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about efforts by Sandler O'Neill & Partners, a boutique investment bank, to rebuild after Sept. 11 misstated the number of founders, including two who were killed in the attack. There were seven, not three.

title: Zurich Theater Director Becomes a Public Issue
description: In the Swiss version of democracy, almost every public issue is decided by referendum. Thus when Zurich's voters approved an increased subsidy for the city's main theater on June 2, its acclaimed artistic director, Christoph Marthaler, felt confident that he would weather a storm of criticism of his management. He certainly did not expect to read in a local newspaper just three months later that he had been fired by the theater's board.

title: Sports of The Times; Reflections on Making the Proper Decision Over Postponing a Game
description: The silence at Coffey Field, on Fordham University's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx, was broken at about 8:30 yesterday morning -- 9/11/02 -- by only the soft groan of a small red tractor mowing the grass on the gridiron under a gentle sun, a maintenance man hosing an end zone and a solitary man with bagpipes coming along the walk beside the empty bleachers and playing the melancholy Scottish tune ''Will Ye No Come Back Again.''

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: INTEL INTRODUCES FASTER CHIPS The Intel Corp- oration has introduced two faster Xeon microprocessors for low-end server computers. Intel's 2.8-gigahertz Xeon for two-processor servers, typically used to distribute Web pages and do scientific calculations, is 17 percent faster than the current top-of-the-line chip in that category, a spokesman, Robert Manetta, said. It sells for $562 in batches of 1,000, 9 percent less than the 2.4-gigahertz chip that until now was the fastest Xeon. Intel hopes to increase demand by selling speedier chips at lower prices. Server sales fell 20 percent in 2001 compared with the previous year and are expected to decline another 5 percent this year, according to the research concern IDC. (Bloomberg News)

title: Gail Collins on Sept. 11
description: Gail Collins, editorial page editor of The Times, answers reader questions on Iraq, the anniversary of the terrorist attacks in America and media coverage of both.

title: Footlights
description: Mexico's World

title: Angels Inching Closer To the First-Place A's
description: The Anaheim Angels have never made it to the World Series. They have not even qualified for postseason play since 1986. Tradition? The only tradition this franchise has established is finding a way to waste great opportunities.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: A Loss For Performance Technologies
description: Performance Technologies Inc., a maker of communications and networking equipment, warned that it would have a third-quarter loss and would cut another 7 percent of its work force to trim expenses. The loss will be 7 cents to 9 cents a share on an operating basis, on revenue of $3.6 million to $4.1 million, Performance Technologies said. In July, the company, which is based in Rochester, projected profit of 2 cents to 6 cents a share and $6 million to $7.5 million in revenue. Performance Technologies plans to reduce annual expenses by about $1.2 million. Costs related to the job cuts will reduce third-quarter profit by about $400,000. About 12 jobs will be affected, based on a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that said the company had about 168 employees as of Jan. 31.

title: Tourist Paradox
description: There is no moment of silence 86 stories up. The wind carries up sirens and church bells and wailing jet engines and sweeps cigarette butts and lens caps past overlapping chatter.

title: Container Ship Is Held Offshore After Search Discovers Radiation
description: Department of Energy technicians and F.B.I. agents continued today to pore over a German container ship that raised security concerns when its cargo showed traces of radioactivity after it steamed into port here early Tuesday morning.

title: One Year: Snapshots of an America in Mourning; A True Response
description: To the Editor:

title: Putin Warns Georgia to Root Out Chechen Rebels Within Its Borders or Face Attacks
description: President Vladimir V. Putin threatened today to order military strikes in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, saying that Russia had a right to defend itself from what he called terrorist attacks launched from Georgian territory.

title: Messier Will Stay, On a One-Year Deal
description: Mark Messier did not want his contract stalemate to be a distraction to his teammates when they open training camp tomorrow in Burlington, Vt. So, on the eve of the Rangers' team physicals, Messier, the 41-year-old captain, agreed to a one-year deal with a base salary of $4 million, with incentives that could increase the package to $5 million.

title: From Lava to Sconces, a Lamp for Every Taste
description: SOME things you are not allowed to complain about.

title: Hershey Trust Asks Court to Lift Ban on Sale of Company
description: Lawyers for the charitable trust that controls Hershey Foods argued in a Pennsylvania court yesterday that a temporary injunction preventing the trust from selling the company should be overturned, contending that the injunction prevents the trustees from carrying out their obligation.

title: Islanders' Peca Is Eager, But Milbury's in No Rush
description: The Islanders need Michael Peca as much as he needs to start playing hockey again, but neither the team nor Peca is working against a clock -- or, for that matter, a calendar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, WITTEN RUSS
description: SINGER-Witten Russ, 35. on September 10, 2002. Beloved son of Cynthia Russ and Arnold M. Singer, stepson of Phyllis B. Singer, adored brother of Lisa N. Kelly, Susan J. Kerschner, Richard W. Catlin, Jacqueline E. Singer, Elizabeth C. Young, and Reagan M. Singer. Favorite uncle of nine and inspired friend to many. Brilliant interior designer who brought style, humour, and enthusiasm to those who knew him. He will be greatly missed. Donations: God's Love We Deliver, 166 Ave. of Americas NY, NY 10013 (212) 294-8100 or your charity of choice.

title: Remorse at a Stop of Hijacker
description: LAUREL, Md., Sept. 11  "People are nice, but they mind their business," Janita Wilson said. "It's probably why they picked this place."

title: A Welcome Home For Fall Antiques Shows
description: A YEAR after the fall antiques shows were moved out of the Seventh Regiment Armory to make room for the National Guard, a new show season will begin there this month with two fairs. A third show will make its debut at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: One Year: Snapshots of an America in Mourning; Clouds of Dust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABACHY, MELEK M.
description: HABACHY-Melek M. (nee Dimyan). On September 10, 2002. Beloved wife of Nazeeh Saba Habachy, cherished mother of Tiya Saba Habachy and Dora Gamila Habachy, and loving sister of Amin, Wafik and Magid Dimyan. Born in Egypt, Melek graduated from the American University in Cairo. She came to the United States in 1972 when she married and made her life in NYC. She worked at the United Nations for 12 years until her passing. Funeral services will be held Friday, September 13, 11AM in the Chapel of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55th St. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent in her name to the American Cancer Society or the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUDDIHY, ARTHUR B. JR.
description: CUDDIHY-Arthur B. Jr. On September 8, 2002, of Florida, formerly of Rye, NY. Beloved father of John B. Cuddihy of Coral Gables, FL and Christopher A. Cuddihy of Venice, CA. Loving brother of Mary Alice O'Conor of Point Verde, FL. Cherished grandfather of Claire and John B. Cuddihy, Jr. and dear father-in-law of Catherine B. Cuddihy, all of Florida. Mr. Cuddihy retired from Spencer Stuart & Associates in 1980. He was a graduate of the University of Michigan Law School and went on to serve as a Jr. Lieutenant with the Navy in WWII. Funeral services will be held at Holy Cross Cemetery in Brooklyn, NY Friday 12 noon, followed by interment.

title: THE GLOBE: In Looking Back on 9/11 Attacks, Nations Show a World of Emotions -- Afghanistan; Ruin, Rebuilding And Reflections
description: A year ago this Afghan morning, with the terrorist attacks in the United States still hours away, the World Trade Center in New York was still standing, and the American Embassy in Kabul was a ruined shell after standing empty for nearly 13 years.

title: The Glow of Devotion
description: Msgr. Donald Sakano keeps the lights low at the Church of the Holy Innocents on West 37th Street, an oasis amid the garment district's bustle. But the church is glowing -- from hundreds of devotional candles.

title: Campaign Season; G.O.P. Is Relieved At Republican's Loss
description: Republicans were not popping open bottles of champagne to celebrate the humiliating primary defeat on Tuesday of their fellow Republican, Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire. But they were not lamenting the loss either.

title: From Symantec, a Hybrid Of Firewall and Spam Buster
description: It's not true. Despite that promise in the e-mail subject line, the vice president for marketing does not love you. So you won't be fooled again, Symantec has upgraded its Norton Internet Security software suite to intercept more viruses, mass mailers and worms. It also promises to eliminate bandwidth-hogging pop-up ads and reduce spam. If that sounds like a Herculean task, it is. Symantec has cataloged 61,000 threats to your data and program files, and it says there are 10 to 15 new ones appearing daily.

title: Pakistani Wants No Part in an Attack on Iraq
description: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan said yesterday that an American decision to attack Iraq would inflame Islamic extremism in his country and across the region and that therefore ''we would not like to be involved'' in it.

title: Campaign Season; Any Publicity Is Good Publicity
description: No matter how the Democratic primary for governor between Bill McBride and Janet Reno shakes out, even some Florida Republicans think their party outfoxed itself in broadcasting a barrage of TV ads upbraiding Mr. McBride for his performance at one of the state's top law firms. Instead of driving up support for Ms. Reno, many believe the ads benefited Mr. McBride, who saw a surge in name identification in the closing weeks of the primary.

title: A Nation Challenged
description: New York's Heart

title: For the Florist Who Seeks Variation in a Vase
description: Gabrielle Lewin's polished bud vase displays stems at one of three heights: depending on which arms are employed as legs, it can stand 4, 6 or 8 inches tall. A hidden metal ball joins the tubes. ''I like the minimalist approach,'' said Ms. Lewin, 27, who created the vase for her company, Make Room. ''You can look at something bulbous and tell it was done on a computer. This is more about use.''

title: Coach Proud His Team Took a Stand
description: The Jets observed the anniversary of the terrorist attacks with a moment of silence at 8:46 a.m. today, just as their morning meeting began. Coach Herman Edwards told the players that he was proud of them because last year they had decided to forfeit their next game if the N.F.L. had decided to play games on the weekend after the attacks. Edwards supported that action and, ultimately, the league postponed the games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, JOAN
description: STRAUSS-Joan. (nee Johanna Goldschmidt) 91, born Darmstadt, died September 9. Her family will miss her deeply. Funeral: Maple Grove Cemetery, 83-15 Kew Gardens Road, Friday September 13, at 10:45 AM.

title: For Some Students, Attacks Lose Their Grip
description: Though the importance of Sept. 11 has not faded for Liz Morrison, a social studies teacher at Parkway South High School here and a former flight attendant, her biggest challenge in facing her ninth-grade students this morning was overcoming not their horror, but their sense of fatigue.

title: HOLLINGER INTERNATIONAL WILL CUT DIVIDEND IN HALF
description: Hollinger International, the publishing group controlled by Conrad M. Black (also known as Lord Black of Crossharbour), said that it would more than halve its quarterly dividend as part of an effort to cut debt. The company, which has its headquarters in Chicago, has declared a dividend of 5 cents a share, down from 11 cents previously. Hollinger is also reducing the management fees it pays to another of Mr. Black's companies to $22 million a year, from $37 million in 2000. Hollinger International owns The Chicago Sun-Times, The Daily Telegraph in Britain and The Jerusalem Post. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A brief report with the Nature column last Thursday about a series of prints made by Susan Rowland, an artist, using the impressions of plants she found growing near ground zero, misstated the name of the Brooklyn printing shop owned by Marina Ancona, who helped her. It is 10 Grand Press, not 10 Press Studio.

title: A New Arena for the Game Console
description: IF the struggle for supremacy of the multibillion-dollar video-game world were being played out at the console, Sony would be the gleaming behemoth entrenched on the high ground. Climbing up from opposite sides would be two battle-worthy challengers: a veteran, Nintendo, and a relative newcomer to the game, Microsoft.

title: At Yankee Stadium, Tributes and a Monument to Heroism
description: There were 9 runs scored in 11 innings, the New York team won and a New York native was the winning pitcher. There was symbolism all over Yankee Stadium last night, beginning well before the first pitch of the Yankees' 5-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIA, HELEN
description: LURIA-Helen. On September 10, 2002. She is survived by family members and wonderful close friends. Services Friday 11:15 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The President's Vision of the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: In Suburban Gatherings, Pain Is Unsoothed by Time
description: Reflected faintly in the lenses of her sunglasses was the truncated skyline of Lower Manhattan. Behind those lenses fell Sheila O'Malley's tears as she considered the abbreviated horizon to the east and the sun-dappled Sept. 11 a year ago that forever reshaped it.

title: For Shadow Play, Put Out a Beanbag or Two
description: A palm-size directional lamp from the Italian manufacturer Flos has a leather beanbag base. A movable spotlight, it throws sharp shadows from shelves and tabletops. Gino Sarfatti invented the fixture, called the 600P, back in 1966, and this year Flos U.S.A. has brought it back to America.

title: On to the Election
description: Gov. George Pataki got the unwelcome news yesterday that Tom Golisano appeared to have bested him in the race to win the Independence Party's nomination for governor. Mr. Pataki had hoped to take advantage of the loathsome New York tradition of allowing third parties to rent out their lines to the major party candidates in return for the hope of future political favors. But Mr. Golisano's raft of self-financed TV commercials may have swung the tide.

title: Transcript of President Bush's Address to the Nation on Sept. 11 Anniversary
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's address to the nation from Ellis Island last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Again, Domesticity Hits A Bachelor and His Butler
description: When it comes to shameless recycling, television executives are right up there with those raggedy guys with shopping carts who pull soda cans from trash barrels. So out of the Dumpster comes the revived ''Family Affair,'' beginning tonight on the WB network. Whatever effervescence this vessel once contained is long gone.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Suspected Spy Ship Salvaged
description: Japan raised a suspected North Korean spy ship from the bottom of the East China Sea. The boat, apparently camouflaged as a fishing vessel and carrying a crew of about 15, sank last December with the presumed loss of all hands after a firefight with Japanese coast guard patrol vessels. The salvage operation came less than a week before Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi makes the first visit by a Japanese leader to North Korea in a bid to normalize relations between the countries. Japan is expected to insist that North Korea stop sending such ships into its waters. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Children Realize '01 Bush Visit to Their School Was Unique
description: Even a year later, they clearly remember President Bush's reaction when he was told that the World Trade Center had been hit by hijacked airplanes.

title: A Gaze That Dictates, With Intuitive Software as the Scribe
description: PEOPLE who cannot use a keyboard or mouse -- quadriplegics or those with Lou Gehrig's disease, for instance -- often use their gaze instead.

title: THE GLOBE: In Looking Back on 9/11 Attacks, Nations Show a World of Emotions -- Egypt; Lingering Skepticism Of U.S. Accusations
description: The people in the down-at-heel middle-class neighborhood where Mohamed Atta grew up remain skeptical that the silent, lonely teenager led the attack on the World Trade Center. What is the proof? they ask.

title: U.S. Said to Be Investigating Another Enron-Merrill Deal
description: Federal investigators are looking into a 1999 energy deal between the Enron Corporation and Merrill Lynch & Company to determine whether it was a sham transaction intended to help Enron increase its year-end profit, people who have been interviewed by the government said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, GABRIELE
description: SCHIFF-Gabriele. We mourn the recent death of our Director Emeritus. Her service on our Board for more than 30 years, after initially helping the planing and creation of our Nursing Home, will remain an inspiration to us all. The Margaret Tietz Center For Nursing Care sponsored by The New York Foundation For Nursing Homes, Inc.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: NORTH KOREANS ARRIVE Twenty-one North Koreans arrived in Inchon early today after several months holed up in South Korea's consulate in Beijing, the latest of more than 100 defectors to reach the country via China. The North Koreans have slipped into diplomatic premises in China and been allowed to leave after delicate negotiations. Another 15 North Koreans who took refuge in a German school in Beijing last month are en route to South Korea. (Reuters)

title: Splatters for Gov. Bush In Another Mucky Vote
description: Over the past six months, advisers to Gov. Jeb Bush have grown increasingly confident about Mr. Bush's prospects for re-election, concluding that memories of his role in President Bush's messy Florida victory in 2000 were fading from the minds of voters. No longer were they afraid that one Bush's victory had planted the seed for another Bush's defeat.

title: THE GLOBE: In Looking Back on 9/11 Attacks, Nations Show a World of Emotions -- Pakistan; True Believers Of False Rumors
description: Raising his voice so people gathered around him on the train platform could hear, Sohail Kabir announced his reaction to the one-year anniversary of the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington.

title: A Return Visit
description: People run across the Brooklyn Bridge this morning, but it is for health, as opposed to life. A few clouds sail west to east, but they're just clouds. You have to shield your face from debris as the wind kicks up, but it's just dust and leaves.

title: One Year: Snapshots of an America in Mourning; Helping a Survivor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Sept. 11 memorials gave an incorrect day in some copies for a ceremony in which surfers dropped World Trade Center ashes in the Pacific Ocean near San Clemente, Calif. It was held on Tuesday; the original date, yesterday, had been changed.

title: NEW JERSEY MUTUAL FUND AGREES TO BUY WEST ESSEX BANK
description: The Kearny Financial Corporation, a closely held New Jersey mutual fund and savings bank, agreed yesterday to buy West Essex Bancorp for about $170 million. Kearny, a unit of Kearny MHC and owner of Kearny Federal Savings Bank, will pay West Essex shareholders $35.10 in cash for each share they own. The purchase price is based on the company's 4.85 million shares outstanding as of July 31. Kearny plans to merge the savings bank in Caldwell, N.J., with its operations and expand its business in the state.

title: Council Deals Arafat a Blow by Forcing Cabinet to Quit
description: Confronted by demands for democratic change from a newly defiant legislature, Yasir Arafat was compelled today to accept the resignation of his entire cabinet.

title: Restrained End To Volatile Year In Stock Markets
description: A subdued trading session produced only small moves in the stock market yesterday as a quiet day of remembrance ended an extraordinarily volatile year on Wall Street that reflected increased uncertainty in the wake of the terrorist attacks.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: E.D.S. Asks For Money
description: Electronic Data Systems, the computer services seller, asked a court to force WorldCom to return $14.7 million it says the telecommunications company owes to local telephone companies. WorldCom received the money to pay local carriers that handled services for E.D.S. in areas that WorldCom's long-distance network does not reach, E.D.A. said in a filing Friday with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. WorldCom, the No. 2 domestic long-distance phone company, kept the money instead, E.D.S. said. WorldCom provides long-distance phone service to E.D.S. clients under a 1999 agreement; E.D.S. manages WorldCom's computers. Service has not been interrupted because of the disagreement with WorldCom, E.D.S. said.

title: Agency Added for Army Recruiting

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Dispute Continues
description: The Nvidia Corporation, the sole supplier of graphics chips for Microsoft's Xbox video-game console, must keep selling processors to Microsoft as the companies try to settle a pricing dispute, an arbitration panel ruled. In an interim ruling, the panel said Nvidia must supply Microsoft's ''reasonable requirements of chipsets,'' without specifying the exact quantities, according to a Nvidia filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Nvidia expects the arbitration to be finished by the end of June. The ruling will remain in effect until the dispute is resolved. Microsoft contends that it should have paid at least $46 million less than it has for chips used to generate graphics in the Xbox, the filing said. In April, Microsoft asked an arbitration panel to order Nvidia to cut prices and to supply as many chips as necessary. Microsoft has been trying to save money on Xbox parts to lower the cost of the machine, which sells for $199 in the United States, less than it costs to produce. David Hufford, the product manager for Xbox, has said Microsoft will not replace Nvidia as a supplier because the processors were designed specifically for Xbox.

title: Interview With Vicente Fox
description: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- Following is a transcript of an interview with President Vicente Fox of Mexico, conducted in Spanish and translated by The New York Times. Q. I want to take you back one year ago; we want try to get your thoughts about Sept. 11 in Mexico. A little more than a year ago you were in Washington and you challenged the U.S. to adopt new immigration laws, and doing so you also challenged the U.S. to look at Mexico as more than a poor neighbor; as an equal partner. Some analysts in Mexico have said that after the United States and Afghanistan, Mexico has been the country most affected economically and politically by Sept. 11. How do you see the scope of the impact? A. The first thing, I would confirm that, yes, there was an unprecedented effect on Sept 11. It was unexpected, surprising but at the same time of the highest impact. This impact was felt in the United States, in Mexico and in the whole world. It was a shock for the whole world. And in Mexico's case it hit us at a summit in our relationship. At that moment we were in Congress, where we had won favorable reaction to our proposals. We were at the closest possible point to an agreement with the government of President Bush both on immigration and on a deepening of integration under NAFTA. That is why for us the impact is stronger; to go from the summit of optimism, of positive results, to the unprecedented shock of the terrorist attack. And this effectively forced the United States to concentrate its attention on the issue of security. By dedicating so much concentration to the issue of security, bilateral matters pass to a secondary level. Those matters continue to have enormous importance to us. I ask myself if it is necessary to choose between the two issues. I believe that work can be done on security, in combating terrorism in Mexico we have done our part in this area. But at the same time, the world must continue working. The world must continue advancing, and even more our bilateral relations with the United States. So beginning from Sept. 11, we did introduce in our agenda the issue of security and commitment to fighting terrorism. It's a commitment that we not only made to the U.S. government but also particularly with United Nations Resolution 1373. But at the same time we're working on putting our bilateral agenda back into discussion and the truth is that we haven't managed to reach the levels we had before Sept. 11. So what are we doing? As a consequence we are working on issues that have to do with migration but they are only partial [steps] such as issuing the identification card, the consular identification card, as a security measure in that it fully identifies our compatriots. On the other hand, it also advances the recognition of the rights of illegal immigrants who work in the U.S., who work with U.S. companies, who work with U.S. families, who work with U.S. citizens, and who merit the greatest respect and the greatest acknowledgment for what they do. Q. After Sept. 11, political costs of your support for the United States began to mount. People began to criticize you as having a subservient attitude toward the United States, that you were giving so much and getting nothing in return. You canceled trips to the United States. Congress denied permission for you to travel there. There have been disputes with the United States over the death penalty, water, trade. How do you feel? A: My first clear and resounding answer is that the relationship continues, just as strong, just as friendly. Our partnership is increasingly more committed to the U.S., our partnership for prosperity _ the document signed in Monterrey (inaudible). Regarding your comment, we would have to separate the response into various baskets. One: the reasons for which I did not go on two trips to the United States. The first because effectively the Congress denied me permission to leave. And on this matter I take the opportunity to comment that in Mexico, I find contradicting reactions in regards to relations with the United States. On one side, citizens have great respect for the United States, they have a great feeling of friendship. That is solid. But in the opposition and in the political arena I often find criticism of the closeness of relations with the United States. That is a reality. And it is a reality that flares up every time a new issue arises. And the issue comes up every day. The death penalty, the execution of Javier [Suarez Medina], the Mexican citizen executed in Texas, for us the defense of human rights is a very important issue. It's a priority and we express it each time that a situation that has to do with human rights comes up as in the case of this execution. We had to let the governor of Texas know that we do not share support the death penalty. At the same time we had to let the justice system of Texas know that some elemental rights of this Mexican were violated, as in not having advised the Mexican Consulate of his arrest and of the charges against him. This is a commitment that both Mexico and the U.S. have signed in the Convention of Vienna and which requires us to advise the consulate when this situation arises. And thirdly, well, I could not make a visit to Texas eight days after this Mexican was executed. I let the governor of Texas know. I asked for clemency or that Javier's sentence be changed. I asked that the execution be postponed so that documents could be presented showing the violation of Javier's rights. I asked that the time-frame be extended to make the visit and I did not receive a response. So I saw myself obligated to cancel the trip. As far as the dispute over water is concerned, I think that it was on very good terms. It's an issue where a resolution was pending. The conditions of the Rio Grande River Basin have changed. The level of rainfall that we receive each year has changed and so we have to change the the responses we give. Fortunately, as always happens, we found the response through dialogue with United States authorities and now the the issue of the Rio Grande River Basin is resolved for the next five years. Conflicts like this are constantly arising, problems that we deal with and resolve in a relationship as intense as the one between Mexico and the U.S.. Q. But are you frustrated that your efforts to embark on a new relationship with the United States has not been reciprocated? A. There are feelings on my part that I would not describe as frustration or resentment. But I feel strongly that we need to deal with bilateral issues. I constantly make it known to the American government that we need the same kind of attention for Latin America. Things aren't going well in Latin America and we have to work very hard so that things improve in Latin America. The U.S., Canada and Mexico right now enjoy better conditions of stability and economic development and so we are the most obligated to pay attention to Latin America. In the case of the U.S. and Canada, they should pay attention to Mexico. So, without it being a complaint, without it being a product of frustration, I do constantly call on the administration of President Bush to dedicate more time to bilateral and Latin America issues. Q. Your foreign minister said in an interview recently that Mexico would embark on a new strategy to get the immigration back on the U.S. agenda. Talk to me about that. A. It isn't anything spectacular or terribly innovative. We simply realize that at this moment while the U.S. elections process is going on it won't be possible to raise the migration agenda. In the same way it wasn't possible immediately after Sept. 11. So we are waiting for an important window of opportunity after the U.S. elections. I think that it is the right time to push this theme strongly. And there we would expect reciprocity. We would expect fulfillment of goals. President Bush himself expressed that he would really be an ally in the cause of migration, that we would work together to return the issue to the highest priority, [that we would] work with U.S. legislators as well so that they would look favorably upon this development. This window of opportunity next year [will occur] because the U.S. economy will surely begin growing again and it will require more and more workers [to fill] more and more jobs. So the strategy is to take advantage of this window of opportunity. We will have a very active migration policy next year. Q. Will you work directly with (political) parties and Congress? A. With everybody, legislators, local levels where there is a strong Mexican presence, where the presence of Mexicans is appreciated and valued such as Texas, California, Chicago, and in other parts of the U.S. At the local government level, with the governors, with the state congresses we will have a very active policy on this issue so that hopefully we can fulfill our intention of reaching a result by the end of 2003. Q. Will those plans be successful if there is an attack on Iraq? A. The consequences of an attack on Iraq are not predictable. It appears to me that it would have very broad effects at the global level on many things and it would have very broad effects on bilateral issues and issues on the Latin American agenda. I believe that the issue of Iraq must be the product of deep reflection. It seems to us that this is a matter that should be channeled through the United Nations Security Council; that there should be an opportunity for a visit by United Nations inspectors to Iraq. We, as a country, will be pushing strongly in that direction; in that it will be the U.N. that makes the visit, that it's the U.N. which certifies what conditions are there. But first [we need] objective information to be able to then reflect on the best decisions to take. I think the Iraq situation would have an impact that would affect the whole world. Q. Would you support President Bush? Last night on Televisia, a poll showed that 70 percent of Mexicans are opposed to an attack against Iraq. How does your government feel. A. At this moment we can't take a position, nor make a decision precisely because information is lacking. It would be very important to really know what are Iraq's activities regarding terrorism, what are Iraq's activities regarding weapons of mass destruction, what are its activities in terms of its ability to deliver these weapons. The debate which must take place in the United Nations and in the U.N. Security Council, where we are present, is also important. So for me and for Mexico first we need a lot of information, a lot of objectivity, deep reflection and then we will be able to give an opinion. Q. Last question., you call yourself the president the 123 million Mexicans, including 23 million who live in the United States. Since Sept. 11 deportations have increased, arrests on the border have declined but the number of Mexicans dying on the border has not. How have Mexicans in the United States been affected by Sept. 11. Are their rights in danger? A. Well, as long as we do not reach a solution on immigration, which is the intention, these painful circumstances will occur. We are trying to avoid these painful deaths. We're there on the border, we're in the mountains, we're there with the army. We're there with our border agents dedicated to migration issues. We're working intensely to try to stop these deaths from happening. In the same way, we continue to be very committed to Mexicans in the U.S. We have managed to get the consular identification card accepted throughout the U.S. banking and financial system. With this, migrants can now open checking accounts. We have managed to get this accepted as a full identification card by city, country and state authorities. We have managed to get the card accepted so that Mexicans, even if they are in the United States illegally, can apply for driver's licenses in various cities and counties. We have managed to remove discrimination against them regarding their entry into state universities. In sum, we are working through the consulates to be close to our compatriots and to help them as much as possible. But in the end the best solution is a migration accord.

title: Southeast Asia

From Bangkok, participants fly to Sukhothai, the cradle of Thai civilization. Stops also include Luang Prabang, Laos, with caves containing thousands of Buddhas, and Hue, Vietnam's capital during the Nguyen Dynasty, with its tombs of 13 kings. The Angkor Wat temple complex is the last stop before the return to Bangkok. The price, $999 a person based on double occupancy, includes moderate-class accommodations (private bath and air-conditioning), all meals, admission fees, flights from Bangkok and back, taxes and tips. Airport taxes and visa fees are extra, and air fare from the United States is not included. Information: (800) 952-0226 or www.scenicworldtour.com .
