title: Storage Space Just a Seat Away
description: IT is one of life's inescapable quandaries: everyone has things to store, but nobody has enough space. One solution is to use benches and stools that do double duty throughout the home -- from the entryway to the foot of the bed. For those who need more than a bench or a box, a new service will deliver an empty cedar-lined closet, to be packed with off-season clothing and gear, and then take it away for storage in its warehouse. It beats dragging the stuff to mini-storage.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Train Wreck Death Toll At 106
description: The death toll from the derailment of a prestigious train rose to 106, with officials divided over the cause. Sixteen cars of the Rajdhani train, which runs through state capitals to New Delhi, jumped the tracks of an 85-year old British-built bridge in the state of Bihar on Monday night. Railways Minister Natish Kumar said he was sure that sabotage was responsible, since the area is home to rebels, but local elected and law enforcement officials said they believed that poor maintenance of the bridge was to blame. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Flexible Enough for a Picnic, Elegant Enough for the Salon
description: Erik Magnussen, a highly regarded Danish industrial designer, has introduced the Zdown, a folding chair so urbane it deserves a place in the living room. As the Zdown opens, two Italian leather slings stretch across a pair of Z-shaped frames of tubular steel. The metal has a satin finish like the one Mr. Magnussen used on his signature ship's lanterns for the home, which are sold by the European manufacturer Stelton. The Danish company Engelbrechts makes the chair in black, brown or natural leather. ABC Carpet & Home sells it from its second-floor contemporary furniture gallery. The price is $780; 888 Broadway (19th Street).

title: A Year Later, Air Passengers Are Few, but Determined
description: Some said they were nervous. A few said they were scared. But many passengers today boarded their flights with a clenched jaw and determination, as if daring a suicide hijacker to try again.

title: Candidates Are Bracing For an Ad Blitz
description: In a sign of how a third-party candidate, especially a rich one, can roil the political waters, Tom Golisano, the presumed winner of the Independence Party primary and a persistent annoyance to Gov. George E. Pataki, plans a fresh barrage of television advertisements within a couple of days.

title: Shrinking Oil Inventory Puts Pressure on OPEC, Agency Says
description: The International Energy Agency, an adviser to 26 nations on oil policy, said today that crude oil inventories were ''uncomfortably low,'' indicating that OPEC needed to increase production to prevent a jump in prices.

title: Market Place; Regulators Find More Red Flags In Another Analyst's Optimism
description: Securities regulators examining the activities of Wall Street research departments have turned up evidence that an analyst at yet another firm advised investors to buy shares of a company that he acknowledged in an e-mail message were unworthy of purchase.

title: 50 Senators Ask Daschle for Debate on Renewing Welfare Law
description: More than half the Senate, including many Democrats, called on the majority leader today to schedule a debate on reauthorizing the welfare program created by an innovative 1996 law that expires in three weeks.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jabil To Close a Plant
description: Jabil Circuit Inc., a maker of electronic products for brand-name companies, will close a plant in Boise, Idaho, and dismiss its 500 workers amid a slump in demand from telecommunications equipment makers. The factory, which will close by the end of the year, assembles products, including printed circuit boards, used in telecommunications gear. Work performed there will be moved to plants in Michigan and Florida.

title: A Flight Instructor Tries to Clear His Name
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 11 - Rick Garza, a flight instructor here, wants his countrymen to know that he was not the man who trained Saudi assassins to fly American Airlines Flight 77 into the Pentagon.

title: Online Dating Site's New Twist: Offline Partying, for $25 Fee
description: The idea behind online personals is that you can quickly sift a list of potential mates to find people who might tickle your interest. It is more efficient than random meetings in a bar, and no one is asking, ''Come here often?''

title: A Joke Is Wearing Thin for Voters in Florida
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 11  Over the past six months, advisers to Gov. Jeb Bush have grown increasingly confident about Mr. Bush's prospects for re-election, concluding that memories of his role in President Bush's messy Florida victory in 2000 were fading from the minds of voters. No longer were they afraid that one Bush's victory had planted the seed for another Bush's defeat.

title: A Patriarch's Victory, Built on Practicality
description: There is some scientific evidence to support the contention that playing bridge is conducive to a long life. Whether it is valid or not, octogenarians and nonagenarians fight regularly for small victories in clubs all across North America. One of them is 83-year-old Kenneth Cox of Riverdale in the Bronx, who has been associated with the game for more than half a century. For 12 years he was the executive secretary of the small American Bridge Association, and he continues to play each week at the Triangle Club in the Senior Citizens Center at 120 West 140th Street in Harlem.

title: Bush to Warn U.N.: Act on Iraq or U.S. Will; He Leads Nation in Mourning at Terror Sites
description: President Bush plans to challenge the United Nations today to enforce resolutions it has passed since 1991 requiring Iraq to ''unconditionally accept'' the destruction of its chemical and biological weapons and nuclear research facilities, according to administration officials. He will warn that if the United Nations fails to act, the United States will step in to force Iraqi compliance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDEZ, ROSE MARIE
description: MENDEZ-Rose Marie. Architectural designer and educator, died in Los Angeles, Saturday, September 7, 2002 of cancer. She was 32. Rose turned candor into virtue and and rendered life with startling clarity. It was infectious. And beautiful. Born in New Jersey, Rose received undergraduate and masters degrees in architecture from Cornell University. She practiced architecture at Morphosis in Los Angeles and received the Grand Prize in the 1997 San Francisco Prize for her redesign of Union Square, now part of the SFMoMA's Permanent Collection. She taught at Cornell University, State University of New York at Buffalo, Southern California Institute of Architecture, and UCLA. She is survived by her husband, Gregory Fischer; her mother, Maria Bornia-Mendez; and her sister, Ligia Mendez Goodwillie. A memorial gathering will take place Saturday, September 14, at SPF: a Gallery, 3384 Robertson Place, LA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Rose Mendez Undergraduate Archtitectural Memorial Scholarship at Cornell University, Department of Architecture, Art and Planning, 129 Sibley Dome, Ithaca, New York 14853.

title: Vintage Russel Wright, Circa 2002, Coming Soon
description: In the early 1950's, Russel Wright introduced Pinch flatware for everyday use. The latest version reproduces the original ergonomic shape. But the new pieces are bigger, shinier and heavier, in keeping with current tastes. The knives are forged rather than stamped, and the tines of the forks have been extended slightly. ''I'm adjusting to the adjustments,'' said Annie Wright, the designer's daughter, who received one of the first shipments last month and put her vintage Pinch pieces away. ''They are so valuable now, I use them only for special occasions,'' she said. A 20-piece set of the new flatware will be available next month at selected Bed Bath & Beyond stores for $49.99; or www.oneida.com. Pinch glassware will arrive at stores next year, followed by Russel Wright aluminum bowls and trays.

title: Stabbed Pharmacist Dies
description: A 70-year-old pharmacist died yesterday morning after he was found lying behind the counter of an Upper East Side store with stab wounds in his chest, the police said.

title: Again, Sunshine State Is in Dark a Day After the Vote
description: For the second time in less than two years, Florida voters woke up this morning not knowing whom they had elected the day before.

title: YES Network Picks Nets Broadcast Team
description: Ian Eagle and Kelly Tripucka are to be named today as the Nets' television team for the YES Network. Tripucka replaces Bill Raftery and Jim Spanarkel, the team's analysts on Fox Sports New York.

title: HCA AND TENET ARE COMPETING TO BUY HEALTH MIDWEST
description: HCA and Tenet Healthcare are each bidding for Health Midwest, a 14-hospital system based in Kansas City, Mo. Health Midwest, which had $2.4 billion in revenue last year, decided in August to seek formal bids after receiving several unsolicited acquisition offers, the company said. The system's board agreed to focus on the HCA and Tenet bids as it decides whether to pursue a sale. The acquisition would be among the largest in recent years for HCA or Tenet. HCA, which is based in Nashville, has almost 200 hospitals; Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., has 114 hospitals.

title: They May Be Stemless But They're All Flower
description: Lewis Miller, a florist who opened a store, LMD, in the East Village this summer, shocked some of his new neighbors with a display of decapitated succulent rosettes clustered on bare steel factory trays. ''A man was very concerned that I had murdered them for my window display,'' Mr. Miller said.

title: Economic Scene; The value of different football strategies on fourth down, analyzed from a mathematical point of view.
description: FOOTBALL season has begun, and in stadiums, sports bars and living rooms across the land fans are asking the same question: ''It's fourth down and what does the Bellman equation say?''

title: Summer's Last Gift: Buckets of Purple
description: WHEN September rolls in at our farm in central Maryland, everything shifts. The light looks more golden as it slants low over the fields. The nights are cool, a special blessing after a cruel summer of intense heat and very little rain. And if you go out the back kitchen door, maybe to grab a beer from the old refrigerator and go look at the moon, the air smells like grapes.

title: Text: Bush's Speech to U.N. on Iraq
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's address to the United Nations on Thursday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merrill Lynch and Enron Face Inquiry on Energy Deal

title: Black Magazine Tries Book Club
description: Everyone seems to be getting into the book-club act, and it's probably a good thing, too, since perhaps the only upbeat note in a rather flat sales season this spring and summer for book publishing has been the apparent success of the post-Oprah clubs, even if the clubs don't quite fill the void she left.

title: Gadgets and Gizmos
description: IN Japan the race is always on for electronic gadgets, appliances and telecommunication tools that are smaller or faster or more nimbly able to multitask. TKNY, as a New York source for the latest in Tokyo, carries several products for early adopters and gadget lovers.

title: A Place for Solace
description: Sean Boggs was downtown last year when the planes hit. He saw the explosion when the second tower was struck, and later panicked when it collapsed. He started running and didn't stop until he reached Central Park.

title: A Bit of Normalcy
description: The television set above the washers at Kleener King at 823 West 181st Street in Washington Heights is tuned to images from ground zero and Spanish-language chatter,... and then there is a moment of silence. Two women, both workers at the laundry, keep quietly folding T-shirts, sheets and boxer shorts fresh out of the dryers and stacking them in neat piles on a blue counter. An elderly woman puts down her A.A.R.P. Bulletin to peer into the round hole of a washing machine and then yank out wet clothes.

title: One Year: Snapshots of an America in Mourning
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Celebrating Life'
description: The early morning flight from Newark to San Francisco draws a mix of suited business travelers, silver-haired vacationers and those heading to the bedsides of ailing relatives.

title: One Year: Snapshots of an America in Mourning; The Evacuees
description: To the Editor:

title: Poet Turned Antic Architect Keeps Exploring Inner Space
description: Vito Acconci, the artist best known for biting himself in public (''Trademarks''), masturbating under the floorboards of a gallery (''Seedbed'') and struggling to enunciate words with his mouth held wide open (''Open Book''), has been working in architecture for 20 years now. His firm, Acconci Studio, near the Manhattan Bridge in Brooklyn, employs a half-dozen young architects. It's working on a coffee cup for Alessi, the Italian company, that grows as the drink is poured and shrinks as it is drunk. (The principle is a kind of bellows system.)

title: So That a Disaster Isn't a Communications Disaster
description: WHEN commanders gave the order for firefighters and other emergency workers to withdraw from the Pentagon crash site on Sept. 11, some heard it and evacuated. But others did not.

title: 'Happy Birthday'
description: ''Happy Birthday to you. . . .''

title: Some fear a global recession if the shooting starts in Iraq : War talk shakes up oil markets
description: LONDON:  The intensifying U.S. drumbeat for a war in Iraq is driving up oil prices, shaking already fragile confidence in world equity markets and could, some analysts say, tip the global economy back into recession if the shooting starts.

title: MobilCom's Fate Is in the Hands of the French Cabinet
description: The future of MobilCom, the second-largest long-distance carrier in Germany, Europe's biggest and hardest-fought phone market, hung in the balance as the French cabinet met late into the evening to devise a rescue plan for France Tlcom. Members made no comment as they adjourned.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Accusation Against Kremlin Critic
description: The prosecutor general's office accused Boris Berezovsky, a former Kremlin insider who is now a fierce critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, of embezzlement at Russia's biggest car company. Deputy Prosecutor General Vladimir Kolesnikov said Mr. Berezovsky and a partner had stolen 2,033 cars from the company, AvtoVAZ, through a dealer they controlled. Mr. Berezovsky, who has also been called to testify in an embezzlement case in Russia's international airline, Aeroflot, denied the charges. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Yellow in Autumn

title: F.B.I. Searches Home Of Researcher Again
description: Agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched the Maryland home of Dr. Steven Hatfill today for a third time in connection with the hunt for the anthrax killer, the authorities said.

title: For the Price of a Hand-Held, A Lightweight Laptop With Juice
description: More people might be carrying laptop computers if they didn't weigh so much, cost so much and run out of battery power so quickly.

title: Young Students Get an Early Taste of Commemoration and Ceremony
description: No detail was too insignificant when Poly Prep Country Day School in Brooklyn planned its day of commemoration for children as young as 5 and as old as 18.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about cooperation between ranchers and environmentalists misidentified a rancher at a prescribed fire. He was Bill McDonald; Warner Glenn is another rancher who works with environmentalists. The picture credit was also omitted; the photographer was Jon Christensen for The New York Times.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: JOBLESS RATE STEADY Britain's unemployment rate maintained a 27-year low of 3.1 percent last month. The number of people claiming jobless benefits fell unexpectedly by 6,400 to 943,300, according to official figures. Economists attributed the fall to increased hiring by government agencies seeking to improve public services. Some retailers are also taking on workers, partly offsetting a decline in manufacturing jobs. The report said annualized wage increases in the quarter to July were only slightly above expectations of 4 percent, strengthening arguments that the Bank of England is unlikely to raise interest rates soon. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Saving Sprung Seats
description: STACY MORRISON does not take furniture lightly. ''You have to commit to it,'' said Ms. Morrison, who bought her first grown-up piece, an overstuffed sofa bed with a skirt and deep cushions, nine years ago. ''I have crazy sentimental feelings,'' she added.

title: SUNOCO WILL LIST COST OF STOCK OPTIONS AS AN EXPENSE
description: Sunoco said yesterday that it would begin recognizing the cost of stock options as an expense, a move that will reduce profit by $5 million this year. The accounting change will be adopted in the fourth quarter and be retroactive to Jan. 1 to provide investors a clearer picture of financial results, Sunoco said. The change will lower 2002 net income by 7 cents a share, it said. The company, a refiner and fuel seller, is expected to earn 7 cents in 2002, the average estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Estimates ranged from a profit of $1.12 a share to a loss of $1.10. Sunoco lost $1.37 a share in the first quarter because of reduced demand for heating oil.

title: Floods in France Leave Brown Lakes and Ruined Vineyards
description: Jacques Fraud, a sturdy factory worker, has lived in a daze since Monday night when he failed to save his mother. Infirm at 84, she drowned inside her home.

title: Campaign Season; Back to the Races, On to the Next Round
description: The cease-fire is over. While campaigns made much of their decisions to halt campaign and advertising out of respect for the anniversary of Sept. 11, they are not wasting time returning to the fray. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is among the first out of the box. Today, it will begin broadcasting a new commercial in Maine hitting Senator Susan Collins, a Republican, for her votes on workplace injuries.

title: From Games to Gateways; Boxes That Would Deliver the Web
description: In the end, Internet-equipped game consoles might be so many Trojan horses. So says Edward S. Williams, senior vice president at Gerard Klauer Mattison, an investment research firm that publishes a newsletter on the interactive entertainment industry.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Another Catholic Priest Barred
description: A Roman Catholic priest, the fifth this year, was denied re-entry into Russia, where he has served for nine years in the city of Rostov-on-Don. The Rev. Edward Mackiewicz, a Polish citizen, was stripped of his visa at a border crossing between Poland and Belarus, which shares a common border policy with Russia. The priest was told by border guards that his ''parish is liquidated, the church is closed; that's why there's no longer any need for a parish rector in Rostov,'' a Catholic news agency in Moscow reported. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: 2 Restaurant Chains Are Making Changes
description: Two restaurant chains are making changes to their advertising.

title: Greenspan Warns on Budget Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned today that the economy would suffer if Congress fails to keep the federal budget deficit under control, but he then advised against Democratic efforts to replenish the government's coffers by rolling back or delaying the $1.3 trillion tax cut signed into law last year by President Bush.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: ELECTRONICS MAKER LOWERS OUTLOOK Hitachi Ltd. lowered its profit forecast to break-even in the first six months of its fiscal year because of declining profits at its overseas power equipment and digital appliance businesses. Hitachi, Japan's biggest electronics producer, previously expected to earn 5 billion yen ($41.7 million) in the April-to- September period. The company also slashed its expected operating profit by 25 percent, but left its sales projections unchanged.

title: For an Irregular Lens, An Optical Blueprint
description: AS a computer graphics specialist, Brian A. Barsky has conjured up intricately rendered worlds on a PC screen. But in the real world, he has trouble seeing in the dark, and occasionally in broad daylight. For the last 27 years, Dr. Barsky, a professor of computer science and an affiliate professor of optometry at the University of California at Berkeley, has suffered from keratoconus, an abnormal thinning of the cornea that can wreak havoc with depth perception and night vision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPEL, HERBERT
description: KOPPEL-Herbert. Age 79 on September 11, 2002 in Atlanta after a long illness. Survived by his wife Charlotte (nee Spieler), sons James and Charles. Daughter Nancy Cohen. Sister Marjorie Moses and two grandchildren. Graveside service Friday September 13, 1 P.M. at New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, New York.

title: Fans Wear Their Emotions
description: Even with less distinctive clothing, Mike Figliuolo of Patchogue, N.Y., would stand out in a crowd. A burly man with bright eyes and a dark beard, Figliuolo came to the Baltimore-Yankees game at Yankee Stadium on impulse yesterday after working at his job in electronics on Long Island.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Clinton Lets Wallet Talk
description: After three requests for a $20 donation went unanswered, a small church in Loango has received $200 from former President Bill Clinton to help maintain a cemetery where his great-great-grandparents are buried. An official of Pleasant Grove Baptist Church in Loango in rural Covington County said the church received the check on Friday. Mr. Clinton's maternal great-great-grandfather, George Cassady, and his wife, Josephine, are buried in the older of the church's two cemeteries. Loango is about 80 miles south of Montgomery.

title: Sailing Gleefully Into the Wild Blue Yonder
description: Christine Ebersole is one of those innately gifted performers hard-wired to convey the kind of madcap exuberance that spreads like electricity through an audience. Once on the stage, she becomes the life of the party without even seeming to try. The particular flavor of zest she emits in her cabaret act, which opens the fall season at the Cafe Carlyle, evokes flashes of Marilyn Monroe, Bette Midler, Bernadette Peters and above all the much-missed Madeline Kahn.

title: A Borrowed Tear
description: The subway, as it nearly always does, soldiers on, pausing for nothing. A man in an American flag tie heads to work. A man in a white sailor's hat digs through the trash. A woman sits on the train and reads ''Bonfire of the Vanities,'' which must seem like a book of ancient history.

title: Splatters for Gov. Bush in Another Mucky Vote
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 11  Over the past six months, advisers to Gov. Jeb Bush have grown increasingly confident about Mr. Bush's prospects for re-election, concluding that memories of his role in President Bush's messy Florida victory in 2000 were fading from the minds of voters. No longer were they afraid that one Bush's victory had planted the seed for another Bush's defeat.

title: Agency Added For Army Recruiting
description: Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, the lead agency for the Army, has selected Muse Cordero Chen & Partners in Los Angeles, part of Muse Creative Holdings, as the subcontractor to handle the duties of marketing the Army to potential black recruits. The Army spends $5 million to $10 million a year on advertising to attract black recruits, out of its estimated $95 million annual budget.

title: With Ashes, a Gathering of All Faiths
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 11  Four hundred people gathered today on the front lawn of City Hall for a vigil, where a Muslim imam, a Roman Catholic priest and three Protestant ministers blessed an urn containing ashes from ground zero.

title: Surveyed Reactor Guards Feel Vulnerable
description: Security guards at 24 nuclear reactors at 13 sites, interviewed by a nonprofit watchdog group, said they feared being outnumbered and outgunned by terrorists in an attack. They also said that rules on when they might use deadly force were ambiguous and could allow terrorists to succeed.

title: One Year: Snapshots of an America in Mourning; In Solidarity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZIG, AARON L.
description: DANZIG-Aaron L. On September 10th, 2002. Beloved husband of Gwen and the late Elinor. Loving father of Richard and his wife, Andrea, Jill & her husband, Eric Tarlow. Dear brother of Monroe Danzig, Frieda and her husband, Jerry Berkeley. Adoring grandfather of David, Lisa, Drew and Elinor. Uncle to many loving nieces and nephews. Attorney at Brown, Raysman, Millstein, Felder & Stiener, LLP. Brilliant lawyer, magnificent human being. Service today, September 12th, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St & Amsterdam Ave

title: A Plea for Healing
description: As the drone of a lawn mower drifts through an open window, the chanting begins. Men and boys in stocking feet kneel and touch their heads to the green wall-to-wall carpeting, while a toddler pulls at his traditional Muslim cap, or kaffiyeh.

title: Prostate Cancer Surgery Found to Cut Death Risk
description: For the first time, scientists have shown in a rigorous study that surgery to remove a cancerous prostate gland can reduce the risk of death from the disease.

title: Digitized Doctoring
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Segregation Revisited
description: This fall, the public schools in Charlotte, N.C., are more segregated than they have been in a quarter-century.

title: Beauty and the Feast
description: A New Age cosmetics guru entertains the flock.

title: Navy Seals Join Federal Search Of Cargo Ship
description: For a second day, investigators and technicians just outside New York Harbor pored over a ship and its cargo today, concerned about low-level radiation readings detected the day before the anniversary of the World Trade Center attack.

title: Bridgestone Names a U.S. Chief
description: Bridgestone/Firestone Americas Holding Inc. named an executive of its Latin American business to head its North American tire unit as the company tries to rebuild after recalling millions of Firestone tires since August 2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, OTTO
description: BECKER-Otto. The Riverdale Mental Health Association expresses its profound sorrow on the death of Otto Becker, our former treasurer, Board member and loyal supporter. We will miss his wise counsel and friendship. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Marie-Jeanne Gwertzman President Joyce M. Pilsner Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RAYMOND
description: GOLDBERG-Raymond. On September 11, 2002. The love of Estelle (Sunkin), devoted father to Andrea and Robyn. Adoring Grandpa of Rachel and Ashley. Brother to Joe, Sidney and Sanford. Ray cared about everyone and everything. He will forever live in all our hearts. Services Friday 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: P.& G.'s national campaign is aimed at making its Clairol brand vibrant again.
description: WHEN Procter & Gamble acquired Clairol in November for $4.95 billion, the company inherited a formidable challenge: to make Clairol, the company which made instant blondes acceptable, vibrant again.

title: The Life and Violent Times Of a 1970's Serial Killer
description: As a filmmaker, Matthew Bright can't be accused of inconsistency. He made a splash at the Sundance Film Festival in 1996 with ''Freeway,'' a liberal adaptation of ''Little Red Riding Hood'' that found a teenage Reese Witherspoon grappling with a serial killer named Bob Wolfson (Kiefer Sutherland). Mr. Bright's 1999 ''Freeway II: Confessions of a Trickbaby'' did the same for ''Hansel and Gretel,'' turning the pair of lovable tykes into a lesbian serial killer (Maria Celedonio) and her hooker sidekick (Natasha Lyonne).

title: A Neighborhood Mourns a Pharmacist It Knew for 40 Years
description: Outside the Rexall Drugs pharmacy on the Upper East Side yesterday, flowers were strewn on the pavement and the door was blocked by orange cones.

title: Golisano Favors Curbs on Campaign Contributions
description: Tom Golisano, the Rochester billionaire who has set no firm limit on how much of his money he may spend on his campaign for governor, said yesterday that he would push for changes in campaign finance that would ban all contributions except those from individuals.

title: A Role For Solar, But It's A Cameo
description: SUN, 93,000,000 miles,'' reads a billboard in Times Square. ''Solar-powered station, the Bronx.'' The subject is a new BP Amoco filling station. Do not assume, however, that the station has anything to do with running a car on energy from the sun. The solar power doesn't go into the car; it helps run the pumps.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 5 about a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan accusing Iraq and other defendants of having supported and sponsored the Sept. 11 attacks misstated the nature of the suit. It consolidates 1,400 individual cases of people who lost relatives or suffered injuries in the attacks; it is not a class action.

title: Trying to Put the Best Face on Our Coins
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about commemorations around the nation honoring victims of the Sept. 11 attacks misstated the title of Desmond Tutu, who preached at the Washington National Cathedral. He is emeritus archbishop of Cape Town, not of South Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, SUZANNE KENNEDY
description: FLYNN-Suzanne Kennedy. Suddenly on September 11, 2002. Beloved mother of Kerry Kennedy Flynn of Nantucket, MA., and Tracy of San Francisco, CA. Sister of Peachy Kennedy Regan and Mary Baumslag. For information, contact Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, 212-288-3500.

title: The Euro Did It!
description: Emmanuele Piccari marched in front of the Italian Parliament this afternoon to protest rising prices for everyday products, increases that he believes are a result of the introduction of the euro in January. But his actions were more rebellious than his words.

title: National Briefing | Labor: U.S. Sues Plumbers' Union Over Hotel
description: The Department of Labor filed a federal lawsuit to remove the trustees of the Plumbers and Pipefitters National Pension Fund, accusing them of breaching their fiduciary duty by imprudently investing $800 million in a single hotel, the Westin Diplomat Resort and Spa of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., without doing a feasibility study or market analysis. The $800 million represents 20 percent of the fund's assets. The trustees include the union's president, Martin J. Maddaloni, who has called the hotel a good investment. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Couple Charged With Faking Reports on Asbestos in Homes
description: A couple who ran an asbestos removal business in Westchester County have been charged with operating illegally for years, using forged documents to renew a state license and issuing false air-sample analyses to hundreds of homeowners, the Westchester County district attorney said today.

title: Police Identify Girl Thrown to Her Death
description: The authorities have identified the body of a 15-year-old girl who the police believe was raped and then thrown from the roof of a 14-story apartment building in East Harlem on Sunday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Crime Down, Government Says
description: Street crime in some of the most crime-plagued areas of Britain fell by 14 percent in the last six months. According to the Home Office, the decline took place in 10 areas of the country where 80 percent of the robberies, muggings and purse snatchings are committed. Crime in one area, Lancashire, increased, but in London -- where half the country's street crimes take place -- offenses dropped by 19 percent. The new figures follow a huge increase in crime in 2001 and are evidence, the government said, that its $104 million street crime plan, started in March, is working. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: As Bavaria Droops, So Does Its Favorite Son
description: As German voters prepare to elect a chancellor on Sept. 22, the conservative challenger, Edmund Stoiber, never fails to remind his countrymen that four million of them are out of work.

title: The Iraq Test
description: After a summer of discordant and belligerent rumblings about Iraq by various members of the administration, President Bush gave some welcome coherence to Washington's policy yesterday in a strong and, for the most part, sensible speech to the United Nations. While Mr. Bush reserved the right to act independently to restrain Iraq, he expressed a preference for working in concert with other nations and seemed willing to employ measures short of war before turning to the use of force.

title: When Not Making Love, They Dress Fabulously
description: Paris: Early 1830's. In her apartment, the novelist George Sand (Juliette Binoche), notorious in the French literary world for smoking cigars, mocking marriage and preferring men's clothes, is dressing for a party. No crossdressing tonight: instead of the habitual jacket and cravat, she selects an off-the-shoulder, full-skirted gown made of satiny bronze-colored taffeta. Suddenly, her new love interest, the hot-headed young poet Alfred de Musset (Benoit Magimel), bursts in and begins to criticize her frock.

title: Pentagon Dress Code
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tall, Green New Yorkers
description: Nobody knows what kind of tree slammed my great-grandfather the forester in the head, killing him about a century ago in Ukraine. There have been no lasting grudges, though, and his family tree is filled with generations of woodworkers and tree lovers. My grandfather was a cabinetmaker, and with my father he opened a business, still in operation, in store fixtures made of wood. I grew up knowing the differences in hardwoods, but I learned to recognize them from factory samples.

title: That Potent Hormone Brings Lots of Trouble
description: The play about the missing purse is the puzzle. The four other short plays in Program 1 of Estrogenius 2002 have something to say about women's roles, treatment and behavior. The message of ''The Handbag,'' by Andrea Stolowitz, seems to be, ''Oh my goodness, isn't bureaucracy a bother!''

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro To Delay Chip
description: Advanced Micro Devices, which competes with the Intel Corporation in personal computer processors, will delay the desktop version of its Hammer chip by a few months, its marketing manager, John Crank, said yesterday. Advanced Micro, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., will start selling the chip late in the first quarter of next year or early in the second quarter, instead of late in the fourth quarter, he said in an interview. Mr. Crank declined to comment on the specific reasons for the delay. There are no flaws in the Hammer chip, he said. Advanced Micro's Athlon XP desktop chips are doing well enough that the company does not need to rush out Hammer, he said. Advanced Micro, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., would not have generated much revenue from Hammer this year, so the effect will be ''very minimal,'' he said.

Having exhibited in New York since 1988, she began as a sculptor, took up video in 1992, and has seven solo shows to her credit. The centerpiece of her solo No. 8, Ms. Pearlstein's first show at Artemis Greenberg Van Doren Gallery, delivers just that: more, and better.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ZIMBABWE: GETTING TOUGHER WITH WHITES The government plans to stiffen the penalties faced by white farmers who defy eviction orders. Farmers currently face a fine of about $385 if they ignore government orders to leave their farms; under the proposed plan, which requires Parliament's approval, the farmers would face fines of about $1,925. Officials say bigger fines are necessary to persuade white farmers to hand over their properties to blacks in compliance with the land-redistribution program. A tiny white minority owns more than half the fertile land.

title: Tragedy Kindles Dance of Hope
description: Eric Underwood was waiting for a dress rehearsal to begin at Purchase College in Westchester County on Sept. 11, 2001, when he heard about the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. He and other members of the Dance Theater of Harlem were preparing for a performance in the Evening Stars series in World Trade Plaza. The troupe piled into the company bus, which got as far as the Macombs Dam Bridge. No vehicle was allowed to enter Manhattan, so the dancers got out of the bus and continued on foot. ''All these ballerinas and guys walking across the bridge to Manhattan,'' Mr. Underwood recalled. He made it home and began trying to reach his parents in Washington.

description: A semiautomatic handgun belonging to a private security company has been reported missing at the Indian Point nuclear complex. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday that the Entergy Corporation, which owns Indian Point, immediately notified the commission that the gun was missing from its usual storage place late Wednesday. Entergy told the commission that its workers were searching for the gun after taking a weapons inventory in a safe outside the plant's nuclear operations. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jordanian Sues U.S. In False Arrest
description: A Jordanian student who was detained and then freed filed suit yesterday against a group of F.B.I. agents, a federal prosecutor and Attorney General John Ashcroft. The student's detention after the Sept. 11 attacks was ruled invalid by a federal judge who said the government could not use the material-witness law to hold people in grand jury investigations. The suit by the student, Osama Awadallah, accuses the authorities of false arrest, malicious prosecution and excessive force. In finding last April that Mr. Awadallah was detained illegally, Judge Shira A. Scheindlin also dismissed charges that he had lied before the grand jury when he denied knowing the name of one of the suspected hijackers. Spokesmen for the United States attorney's office and the F.B.I. in New York would not comment. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC WINS APPROVAL FOR ARTERY DEVICE
description: Boston Scientific said yesterday that it had won federal approval for a tiny tube that helps keep arteries from re-clogging, the first clearance for one of the devices developed in its own laboratories. Doctors have said the device, the Express2, which combines the Express stent with a balloon catheter, is easier to place in the body. The product is available in Europe and will begin selling in the United States immediately. The company is also testing a drug-coated version of the Express2 stent. Sales of stents in the United States accounted for about $25 million of Boston Scientific's $708 million in second-quarter sales.

title: A Father and Son Reaching Across the Generations
description: ''Quitting,'' a new film by Zhang Yang, tells the story of Jia Hongsheng, a rising Chinese movie star of the early 1990's whose career was derailed by drug problems and mental illness. In outline, Mr. Jia's story might have, for American audiences, a wearying familiarity: addiction and recovery, especially when it involves celebrities, is so ubiquitous a theme as to seem like a touchstone of our culture. And at least superficially, ''Quitting'' suggests that Beijing, where the movie takes place, is not so different from New York or Los Angeles. It is a big, impersonal city that draws ambitious young people from the provinces and subjects them to temptation, loneliness and danger.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Phone Unit Sale Postponed
description: Enel S.p.A wrote down the value of its Wind telecommunications unit by 1.51 billion euros ($1.47 billion) and postponed the sale of the unit, Italy's second-biggest telephone company, for at least two years. Wind needs another 1 billion euros from Enel, said the chief executive, Paolo Scaroni, who joined the state-controlled company in May. France Tlcom holds 27 percent of Wind, which does not expect a net profit until at least 2004. Mr. Scaroni wants to focus on Enel's power and gas units, and a fourth attempt at a public offering of Wind had been considered for the fourth quarter.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Buys Holosofx
description: I.B.M. bought the closely held software maker Holosofx to add products that help companies link inventory management, customer relations and other processes. Financial terms were not disclosed. Holosofx, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., makes integration software for companies that include Aetna, J. P. Morgan Chase and the Wachovia Corporation. The $14-a-share cash acquisition will add to net income immediately, said Albert Holtzappel, a spokesman for Heineken. It will pay for the purchase from existing cash. The chief executive, Anthony Ruys, said he was considering the purchase of more companies in Russia, China and Latin America. The company also said profit rose 11 percent in the first half and would increase at the same rate in the second, down from 15 percent for all of 2001.

title: Taking On Junk E-Mail
description: It will come as no surprise to anyone with an e-mail account that the scourge of spam has reached near-intolerable levels. One new study estimates that this year 7.3 billion e-mail messages will be sent each day, and spam -- bulk, commercial e-mail -- will make up nearly one-third of it. Increasingly, opponents of spam are using federal and state law to fight back. This growing movement is worthwhile, and deserves support from Congress, federal agencies, state legislatures and the courts.

Calvin Palmer (Ice Cube), the reluctant heir to his father's barbershop, cooks up improbable get-rich schemes in his basement and presides over a team of cheerful comic types. They include a clueless, good-hearted African immigrant (Leonard Earl Howze), a pompous, priggish college graduate (Sean Patrick Thomas) and a glowering ex-convict (Michael Ealy) as well as a token white boy with a fat S.U.V. and a mastery of hip-hop dialect (Troy Garity) and a token woman with man trouble (Eve).

title: Mountains of Mourning, Vistas of Better Days
description: Tina Howe's 20-minute play, ''Disorderly Conduct,'' is about New Yorkers on a particularly notable morning, during which people of every stripe find themselves staring upward in disbelief at the twin towers of the World Trade Center. Easily, and not really sneakily, it emerges that this is not Sept. 11, 2001, but Aug. 7, 1974, and that the spectacle drawing together businessmen and women, a mother and her daughter, a bicycle messenger, two women in dashikis, a street drummer, a bag lady and maybe a dozen other recognizable elements of the city's human quilt is not an act of terror but an act of creativity and daring.

title: NORTHROP IS SELLING 2 BUSINESSES TO L-3 COMMUNICATIONS
description: Northrop Grumman, the military contractor, agreed yesterday to sell two electronics businesses to L-3 Communications Holdings, saying the units were no longer part of its long-term strategy. Terms were not disclosed. The businesses make computers and displays used by the military, as well as parts for microwave devices. They employ 900 people. Northrop Grumman acquired the businesses last year through its $5.2 billion acquisition of Litton Industries. Northrop is selling the businesses as it prepares to complete its $11.8 billion acquisition of a rival military contractor, TRW. L-3 makes communications networks and aircraft simulators for the military. (Bloomberg News)

description: Cantor Fitzgerald , the bond and equity broker that lost 658 employees last year in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, expects to give yesterday's trading profits of $4 million to its family-relief fund. Maricle's long, diverse career included Broadway/National Company/Off-Broadway productions of Bye Bye Birdie, Paint Your Wagon, Allegro, Butterflys are Free, Carousel and Hair. She appeared in many commercials and on the Jackie Gleason, Ed Sullivan and Arthur Godfrey television shows. In 1991, she was invited to perform a one-woman show recapping her career at the LBJ Library and Museum. Born in Wichita Falls and a graduate of the University of Texas, she kept her roots in her home state, even though she resided in Manhattan for over 50 years. Her many friends across the country will remember her extraordinary spirit, humor and graciousness.

description: The Masco Corporation, the maker of Delta and Peerless faucets and KraftMaid cabinets, said yesterday that it had bought four building-products installers for more than $800 million in cash and stock. The four businesses are Service Partners of Richmond, Va.; SCE Unlimited of suburban Chicago; and the IDI Group and Diversified Cabinet Distributors, both of Atlanta. The acquisition is expected to add ''modestly'' to 2002 earnings, the company said. Masco reaffirmed its forecast for annual profit of $1.50 to $1.55 a share.

title: Bush Is Doubtful Iraq Will Comply With U.N. Demands
description: President Bush said yesterday that it was ``highly doubtful'' that Saddam Hussein would meet United Nations demands to disarm, and American officials said they would seek wording in any new Security Council resolution authorizing the United States to use force if Iraq did not comply.

title: At a Mosque in London, bin Laden Is Hailed as a Hero
description: Even as much of Britain mourned America's loss and its own on Sept. 11, Muslim leaders known here as supporters of holy war seized on the moment of grief to hail Osama bin Laden as a hero and to evoke the ''positive outcomes'' of the attacks in New York and Washington.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Antitrust Penalty Upheld
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit has upheld a 2000 ruling that Southwestern Bell, a subsidiary of SBC Communications, had violated antitrust laws in the pay telephone market in Oklahoma. The court, based in Denver, found the phone giant liable for more than $25 million on Tuesday. Charlie Sullivan, who with 10 partners formed Coin Link, an independent pay phone operator that sued Southwestern, said: ''We know that Southwestern Bell was trying to monopolize the market. In reality, they still have such a great percentage.'' In 2000, an Oklahoma jury awarded the plaintiffs $7.4 million in damages. State antitrust law permits the damages to be tripled, bringing the total to more than $22 million, plus lawyers' fees. The award could eventually total $29 million to $30 million, including interest, Robert Edinger, a lawyer representing the plaintiffs, said. The judges said that Southwestern Bell froze out competition through long-term contracts with the owners of sites for pay phones. The contracts included stiff penalties for early termination. Southwestern also ''employed several other measures to freeze out competition,'' including failing to remove its pay phones when site owners requested removal, the judges wrote. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: AHOLD UNIT IS BUYING ASSETS OF LADY BALTIMORE FOODS
description: Royal Ahold, the world's largest food distributor, said that its U.S. Foodservice unit would buy the assets of Lady Baltimore Foods. Financial terms were not disclosed. Lady Baltimore, based in Kansas City, Kan., sells and distributes more than 14,000 food items and kitchen supplies to institutional customers, including schools, restaurants and hospitals in Kansas, Missouri, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Iowa and Nebraska. Ahold, based in the Netherlands, bought U.S. Foodservice in 2000. The company provides 43,000 food products to more than 300,000 institutional customers, according to Ahold.

description: A large gas main ruptured yesterday by construction crews working along busy Routes 1 and 9 in North Bergen caused gridlock for nearly three hours. As a precaution, Amtrak and New Jersey Transit suspended service on tracks adjacent to the road and near a tunnel into and out of New York's Pennsylvania Station. James P. Fox, the state transportation commissioner, said that about 9,000 New Jersey Transit commuters on 17 trains were delayed by the 10 a.m. accident, as were 1,000 Amtrak travelers on 5 trains. The gas main was repaired by 12:53 p.m. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

description: Charlie Bolling survived a three-over-par 73 and finished with a 54-hole total of 209 to win the Met P.G.A. Championship at the Country Club of Fairfield, Conn.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Dismisses Executive
description: After four years of falling profits and declining share prices, the British insurer Royal and Sun Alliance announced the dismissal of its New York-born chief executive, Bob Mendelsohn, 56, saying he would step down ''with immediate effect.'' His compensation will be worth about $1.5 million, the company said. Bob Gunn, 57, the chief operating officer, will take over until a permanent replacement is found. Like other insurers after the Sept. 11 attacks, Royal and Sun is seeking extra cash to cover claims. It said it would decide by Nov. 7 whether to sell extra shares. A rival insurer, Legal and General, has already announced a sale of new equity. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Action On Foundation Fraud
description: The Federal Trade Commission has filed complaints in Federal District Courts around the country against companies and people who fraudulently promise to match consumers to foundations that will give them grants with no strings attached. Foundations said they had been flooded with requests from people seeking assistance to pay medical bills, repair rotting floors and other projects outside the scope of their missions. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Another Extension In Fatal Fire Inquiry
description: The 11-month-old grand jury investigation of the fatal dormitory fire at Seton Hall University in January 2000 will continue for three more months, until mid-December. When the inquiry began last October, the acting Essex County prosecutor, Donald C. Campolo, said he hoped to finish it in March. Since then, he has asked for three extensions. Yesterday, Mr. Campolo called the case complex and said he could not rule out asking for a fourth extension in December. The fire killed 3 freshmen and injured 58 people. Besides evaluating evidence of murder and arson, the grand jury is reviewing safety-related issues. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: A Pay Raise for the Police
description: Since the Sept. 11 attack, the Police Department has grown even more important to New Yorkers. So it was comforting when a state arbitration panel finally ended the police officers' long-running contract dispute with the city, eliminating the distraction of heightened labor tensions.

title: Just Don't Let the Dog Drive
description: THERE may be dogs that do not like car trips, but they keep a very low profile. No dog that this dog-besotted writer has ever known has not loved the feel of the wind in its ears, the elevated view from a car seat and the reassuring sound of a purring engine that signals automobile adventure. Any destination is fine -- as long as you're together.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Murder Victim Is Identified
description: The authorities have identified the body of a 15-year-old girl who the police believe was raped and then thrown from the roof of a 14-story apartment building in East Harlem on Sunday. The girl, Shaienna Morales, had turned 15 about two weeks ago. On Tuesday, the police arrested William Hernandez, 21, after detectives found evidence linking him to the crime on the roof of the building the girl fell from, at 219 East 97th Street, off Second Avenue, the authorities said. Mr. Hernandez, of Third Avenue and East 103rd Street, was charged with murder, rape, assault and tampering with evidence, the authorities said. Al Baker (NYT)

Born in Chicago, B.A. and M.B.A. from Stanford University, he spent the majority of his career with Bank of America, retiring as the general auditor of the corporation. In retirement he served on the boards of the Roundabout Theatre, A.R.T., New York, and the Vilar Center in Beaver Creek, Colorado. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Grows
description: India's industrial output rose 6.4 percent in July, compared with 2.6 percent in July 2001, helped by strong growth in the manufacturing, mining and electricity sectors, according to government data. It was the fourth consecutive month of gain for the country's industrial sector. Manufacturing grew 5.7 percent in July, and the mining industry grew 12.5 percent. But analysts fear that a drought, the worst in more than a decade, might crimp the rural economy and reduce demand for goods from consumers. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Archbishop Appeals To Rights Groups
description: The country's Roman Catholic archbishop, the Rev. Tadeusz Kondrusiewicz, warned in an appeal to human rights advocates that actions against Catholic priests and parishes in Russia had reached such a peak that they ''to all intents and purposes, throw us back in time to the former regime.'' Five foreign Catholic priests have been stripped of their visas this year, construction of a new cathedral has been blocked in Pskov, and a church in southern Russia was shot at last weekend. ''Don't allow freedom of conscience to be trampled on once again in the country which suffered through the Golgotha of the 20th century,'' the archbishop wrote. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

North and South Korean military officers are to meet today to talk about tearing down fences and clearing mines on the east and west routes across the demilitarized zone, which has divided North from South since the Korean War. title: 36 Hours | Irvington, Va.
description: ASK most people if they've heard of the Northern Neck of Virginia and you will probably have to mention famous Williamsburg, an hour south, to help them get their bearings. The state's northernmost peninsula, jutting out to the widest part of Chesapeake Bay, flanked by the Potomac and Rappahannock Rivers, is home to old fishing villages, former steamboat ports and a wooded waterfront that has resisted large-scale development in a way few American shore towns have. It's every bit as bucolic as Maryland's Eastern Shore.

title: U.S. Labeling of Group in China as Terrorist Is Criticized
description: The Bush administration's decision to brand as terrorist an obscure Muslim group with roots in western China has been greeted with skepticism by many Western diplomats and scholars. They say the Americans have offered little hard evidence for applying the label, and seem more concerned with softening Chinese opposition to a possible attack on Iraq than with the potential threat posed by the group.

title: BLUES RE-SIGN TKACHUK
description: The St. Louis Blues signed left wing Keith Tkachuk to a five-year contract yesterday. The first four years are guaranteed at $40 million, while the team holds an option for the fifth year, the newspaper said. (Agence France-Presse)

title: FORD SAYS IT WILL ACCOUNT FOR OPTIONS AS AN EXPENSE
description: The Ford Motor company, the world's second-largest automaker, will start accounting for stock options as an expense in January to reflect the cost of paying executives and other employees, the company said yesterday. The expense last year would have been about $150 million, or 8 cents a share, the company said. Ford employees hold options to buy more than 172 million common shares. Ford, based in Dearborn, Mich., joins General Motors, the world's largest automaker, in counting options as an expense. More companies are under pressure to make the change after accounting scandals led to the collapse of Enron and WorldCom.

title: A Sailor With a Dream Awaits a Gathering of Boats
description: MICHAEL FORTENBAUGH stands on the promenade overlooking New York Harbor, his arm gesturing widely as he envisions the scene tomorrow. He's an optimistic sort, and rain or shine, he sees hundreds of sailboats parading slowly, majestically, each with a personalized flag in memory of the dead from Sept. 11.

title: National Briefing | Washington: A Checkup For Cheney
description: Vice President Dick Cheney will have a routine medical examination today to check the condition of a sophisticated pacemaker that was placed in his chest last year, aides said. The exam will include an electrocardiogram and a type of ultrasound test known as an echocardiogram. When Mr. Cheney had his last checkup, in February, doctors said they detected no irregularities. His doctor will electronically scan the pacemaker to ensure that it is working and to see whether it was ever activated. Robert Pear (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Raising Business District Assessments
description: The City Council's Finance Committee voted yesterday to allow many of the city's business improvement districts to raise assessments on their members for the first time in several years. Known as BID's, the 44 districts are public-private partnerships to supplement city services and are financed by property owners. The committee authorized a total of $7.1 million in budget increases for all but one of the 20 BID's that asked for the increases. (The committee postponed action on the Brighton Beach BID's request because its members had not been given adequate notice.) The full Council is expected to approve the budgets, said David I. Weprin, the committee chairman. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: HONEYWELL REDUCES ITS PROFIT FORECASTS
description: Honeywell International, the aerospace company, reduced its third-quarter and 2002 profit forecasts yesterday for the second time this year, citing a sluggish economy. Third-quarter profit will be 50 to 52 cents a share, said Honeywell, which is based in Morris Township, N.J. Full-year profit will be $2 to $2.05 a share. Sales of commercial aerospace equipment, of automation controls like those used to measure liquid in factories, and of chemicals have not been meeting the company's projections. In July, the chief executive, David M. Cote, cut the forecast to as low as $2.25 for the year and to as low as 60 cents for the quarter. Shares of Honeywell fell 18 cents, to $28.34.

title: An Odd Kidnapping Widens a Mother-Daughter Rift
description: Claude Miller's finely layered screen adaptation of Ruth Rendell's novel ''Tree of Hands'' is such an accomplished piece of filmmaking that it interweaves enough characters and themes to fill three movies. At the heart of this film, which portrays two overlapping worlds -- one comfortable and suburban, the other urban and scuffling -- is a benign kidnapping, if such a thing could be imagined.

description: To the Editor:

title: 2d set of links approved between the 2 Koreas
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea:  U.S. and North Korean generals on Thursday authorized the construction of a second set of road and rail links between North and South Korea as 36 North Korean refugees arrived here from China.

title: France Tlcom Chief, Under Pressure, Resigns
description: Michel Bon resigned as chief executive of France Tlcom today as the company's board cut off financing for the money-losing German wireless affiliate, MobilCom, to try to lighten a crushing $70 billion debt load.

title: Romancing the Loons; A Certain Red-Eyed Charisma Brings Chivalry to the Wild
description: Robert E. James straps a Kevlar canoe to his back and sets out for the most remote places under the most trying conditions: glaring heat, blood-sucking flies, even a cracked rib or two.

description: Every month, the Reading Group discusses a book chosen by a vote from the readers. The authors often drop by to answer readers' questions. This list includes recent book choices, with links to the discussions and book reviews.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bertelsmann May Sell Stakes
description: Bertelsmann may sell all or part of its stakes in the online businesses Pixelpark and Lycos Europe as the company, Germany's largest media concern, reverses an Internet expansion, the chief executive, Gunter Thielen, said. ''Pixelpark is not one of our core businesses and the same is true for Lycos,'' Mr. Thielen said in a briefing with journalists in Frankfurt. Bertelsmann, which owns 60 percent of the Web-site developer Pixelpark and 18.4 percent of the Internet search engine Lycos Europe, may also find a partner for the units, he said. Since Mr. Thielen took over from Thomas Middelhoff, who resigned in July, he has been selling assets and cutting costs in an effort to reduce debt amassed on an expansion onto the Web.

title: Study Says ChevronTexaco Evaded Taxes In Price Scheme
description: ChevronTexaco, the world's fourth-largest oil company, evaded $3.25 billion in federal and state taxes from 1970 to 2000 through a complex petroleum pricing scheme involving a project in Indonesia, according to a new research paper by two accounting professors.

title: Corruption Protest in China Leads to Charges, Top and Bottom
description: Six months after workers protested in a northeastern city, accusing urban leaders of fraud and theft, several of the officials they named have been jailed or fired.

title: Wesley Naylor, Composer, Is Dead at 44
description: Wesley Naylor, a creator and composer of the long-running gospel musical ''Mama, I Want to Sing'' as well as two sequels, died on Aug. 25 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 44.

title: Technology Briefing | Information Technology: Gartner Hires Financial Officer
description: The information-technology consultant and researcher Gartner has hired Maureen O'Connell from Barnes & Noble as its chief financial officer. Ms. O'Connell, 40, will join Gartner on Sept. 23 to replace Regina Paolillo, who resigned in May, the company said. Ms. O'Connell helped Barnes & Noble sell bonds and raise $325 million in a sale of stock in the GameStop Corporation, the bookseller's video-game store unit. Gartner, which is based in Stamford, Conn., has been hurt by lower spending on information-technology research.

description: Vivendi Environnement, the water company, agreed yesterday to sell the equipment distribution unit of its U.S. Filter Corporation for $620 million to private equity firms.

description: Complaints that the Rev. Robert V. Gale was molesting young boys first reached the attention of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston in 1979.

description: CAMPBELL-Vanessa. New York cabaret singer, on August 25, 2002. Survived by daughters, Justine CampbellElliott and Sophie Harris as well as loving friends and family. Her laughter and music will live with us always.

title: Where Iraq Fits in the War on Terror
description: The core of President Bush's forcefully delivered message on Iraq at the United Nations yesterday was irrefutable. Saddam Hussein is a serial liar, a bully and a threat to peace. He has used chemical weapons, and he yearns to impress an Arab world that despises him by building a deliverable nuclear bomb.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Seven More West Nile Cases In Region:
description: Five more city residents have tested positive for the West Nile virus, including two with the first human cases this year in Staten Island and Brooklyn, the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced yesterday. There have now been 14 cases of the mosquito-borne virus in the city, including one fatality. The new cases include a 22-year-old Staten Island man, a 78-year-old Brooklyn man, a 40-year-old South Bronx man, a 72-year-old Queens man, and a 79-year-old Queens woman. The woman is the only one of the five who remains hospitalized. She was in stable condition, the Health Department said. In Connecticut, two new cases were reported Wednesday, bringing the year's total to five. The new cases include a Hartford woman in her 20's and a Greenwich resident in her 70's, who has been hospitalized in serious condition. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: Swimfan

title: Attuned to the Interplay of Adolescents
description: Lauren Ambrose, the dark-eyed young redhead who plays Claire Fisher on the HBO series ''Six Feet Under,'' gives a quietly effective, disarmingly naturalistic performance in Robert J. Siegel's ''Swimming,'' an independent feature made before Ms. Ambrose's television success.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Getting Tougher With Whites
description: The government plans to stiffen the penalties faced by white farmers who defy eviction orders. Farmers currently face a fine of about $385 if they ignore government orders to leave their farms; under the proposed plan, which requires Parliament's approval, the farmers would face fines of about $1,925. Officials say bigger fines are necessary to persuade white farmers to hand over their properties to blacks in compliance with the land-redistribution program. A tiny white minority owns more than half the fertile land. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: On the Outs With Almost Everything
description: ''Igby Goes Down,'' a corrosively sarcastic comedy that lifts the lid off the gleaming casserole of post-yuppie American culture, establishes Kieran Culkin as the movies' Boy Brat of the Moment. Or should I say Alternative Boy Brat, since his character, 17-year-old Igby Slocumb, is in full rebellion against the values embodied by the typical Hollywood teenage sports hero.

title: Delhi Journal; Where the Mighty Mogul Ruled, It's Mighty Unruly
description: When the Moguls laid out a broad avenue linking the imperious glory of the Red Fort to the Fatehpuri Mosque, they saw it as a sweeping public space, a sedate counterpoint to the grandeur of their monuments.

title: Stocks and Bombs
description: ''This stock-market situation -- what are the military options?'' That was the caption of a New Yorker cartoon last month. But these days reality has a way of outrunning satire; way back in June the CNBC pundit Larry Kudlow published a column in The Washington Times with the headline ''Taking Back the Market -- by Force.'' In it he argued for an invasion of Iraq to boost the Dow.

title: 14 Migrant Workers Drown as Van Plunges Into Maine Waterway on Way to a Job
description: They were guest workers, up from Honduras and Guatemala to spend six months or so clearing brush in the thick, wild forests of deepest northern Maine.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Cicero's New President
description: Ramiro Gonzalez, who was sworn in on Tuesday night as the president of the Town of Cicero, said he would seek advice from Betty Loren-Maltese, the former town president who was found guilty last month of theft in an insurance scheme that prosecutors say cost the city $12 million. Mr. Gonzalez, 35, will serve until an election in April; he said he had not decided if he would run for the office. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: In Alabama, Battling the Ghost Of a Golf Legend
description: TUCKED around a corner -- near the bathroom of all places -- in the spacious, wood-beamed clubhouse of the Capitol Hill golf complex near Montgomery, Ala., hangs a large photograph of Robert Trent Jones Sr., America's pre-eminent golf-course architect, who died two years ago at 93.

title: Truth From Nature
description: ''Cultivated Landscapes,'' an exhibition of more than 75 Chinese paintings at the Metropolitan Museum, offers a chance to consider the present through the eyes of the past -- specifically, the eyes of artists. Below, a detail from ''Living Aloft: Master Liu's Retreat'' (1543) by Wen Zhengming.

description: ONE day, one grand, one car. That was the challenge. Is it still possible, in 2002, to buy a car for $1,000?

description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips has finally found his silver lining for this season: seeing how the organization's prospects perform in September.

description: Radek Dvorak agreed yesterday to a two-year contract and accompanied the Rangers to Burlington, Vt., where they will hold their first practice of training camp this morning.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Job Growth Accelerates
description: Australia's economy added three times the number of jobs as forecast in August, with builders and retailers hiring workers. The economy added 88,500 jobs last month, the Bureau of Statistics said. Almost all the extra jobs were full time. The unemployment rate remained at 6.2 percent as more people looked for work, confident they would find jobs in an economy growing three times the rate of growth in the United States. The August rise was the biggest monthly increase in jobs in 11 years.

title: Strange Expects A Close Ryder Cup
description: Nobody knows exactly what to expect when the 34th Ryder Cup is finally played Sept. 27-29 at the Belfry in Sutton Coldfield, England.

He is secretary of the commonwealth, not attorney general.

title: Turning Music Into Math, And Math Into Images
description: For Harry Smith, art was often a matter of placing the right things in the right order. It's true of his most famous work, the pioneering ''Anthology of American Folk Music,'' which he assembled from 78-r.p.m. recordings and released in 1952, without bothering to clear the copyrights. (An authorized, fully legal version of the collection was issued by the Smithsonian Institution in 1997.)

title: Really Cool New Seats
description: He's wearing socks and a sturdy crew-neck shirt with his khaki shorts. Her summer wear is far less substantial. It's a setup for an argument about setting the air-conditioner, even with separate fan adjustments on each side of the car. Or maybe one of the passengers is the type who's never cool enough on a blistering day, even with the air-conditioning at its top level. What to do? The next logical step in cooling -- and personalization -- is cooled seats.

Beloved brother of Aileen Pryde, Ita Mullervy and the late Thomas and Kathleen. Beloved uncle of Michael Canny, Aileen Swider, Maureen Rimmer, Joan Canny, Ellen Canny Goldberg, John Canny, Brian Canny, Terence Mullervy, Brian Mullervy and Joan Pryde.
