title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: European Official Expelled
description: The government expelled the acting head of the Minsk mission of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. The previous mission chief and deputy chief were stripped of their visas in April. President Aleksandr Lukashenko has been at odds with the organization over his crackdowns on the press and political opposition and recent charges that Belarus is selling weapons to Iraq. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Vermont Senator Wants Study Of Terror Link to West Nile Virus
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said today that the authorities should examine whether the spread of the West Nile virus in this country is a result of biological terrorism.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Delran: Catholic School Strike Ends
description: An eight-day strike ended yesterday after teachers at Holy Cross High School approved a new contract. The agreement, approved 42 to 4, calls for raises of $1,300 this year, $1,400 next year and $1,500 the year after. Currently, the average annual salary is about $40,000, the president of the Association of Catholic School Teachers, Rita C. Schwartz, said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Residential Real Estate; On East Side, New Option for Elderly
description: When it is completed next month, Carnegie East House, a 19-story subsidized assisted-living residence on Second Avenue between 95th and 96th Streets, will represent a tale of perseverance in the face of bureaucratic roadblocks and rising costs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about music at the Sept. 11 observances in New York City misspelled the names of two soloists who played in the morning at ground zero. They were the flutist Paula Robison (not Robeson), and the violinist Gil Shaham (not Shahan).

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KERR McGEE, Oklahoma City, an oil and natural gas producer, sold stakes in its Ecuadorean oil and gas properties and a pipeline to Perenco, Paris, a closely held oil explorer; and an unnamed company for $88 million.

title: Qatar of 2 Minds About a War, Envoy Says
description: The foreign minister of Qatar said today that his nation opposes war against Iraq, but he did not rule out the possibility that Qatar, on the Persian Gulf, would allow the United States to use its military bases to launch such an attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, BORIS
description: STERN-Boris. S/A/R Academy extends condolences to our longtime friend and supporter Joel Stern; to our former parent Roberta Horowitz and to Jaqui Endelson and to Russell Stern upon the loss of their beloved father. May the entire family find comfort in his memory. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: Bush Presses U.N. on Iraq, Calling Action Unavoidable
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 12  President Bush challenged the United Nations today to force Saddam Hussein to disarm and end torture and repression of his people, saying that if Iraq continued its defiance of international resolutions, "action will be unavoidable."

title: 'Though they died in tragedy, they did not die in vain' : On day of remembrance, Sept. 11 vigils and prayers
description: WASHINGTON:  From an isolated research facility near the South Pole to the trading floor of the Tokyo stock exchange, the world Wednesday solemnly remembered the terror attacks of a year earlier that killed thousands of Americans.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT GROWS India's industrial output rose 6.4 percent in July, compared with 2.6 percent in July 2001, helped by strong growth in the manufacturing, mining and electricity sectors, according to government data. It was the fourth consecutive month of gain for the country's industrial sector. Manufacturing grew 5.7 percent in July, and the mining industry grew 12.5 percent. But analysts fear that a drought, the worst in more than a decade, might crimp the rural economy and reduce demand for goods from consumers. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: 2 Top Tyco Executives Charged With $600 Million Fraud Scheme
description: The former chief executive and the former chief financial officer of Tyco International Ltd. were indicted yesterday on charges that they reaped $600 million through a racketeering scheme involving stock fraud, unauthorized bonuses and falsified expense accounts.

title: Bush Presses U.N. to Act Quickly on Disarming Iraq
description: President Bush challenged the United Nations today to force Saddam Hussein to disarm and end torture and repression of his people, saying that if Iraq continued its defiance of international resolutions, ''action will be unavoidable.''

title: Plaid's Out, Again, As Schools Give Up Requiring Uniforms
description: They tried hard to keep school uniforms going. They relented on the requirement for the logo. They allowed casual Fridays. They phoned every parent in a school of 1,300 students and reminded them that uniforms were mandatory -- though yes, there was the opt-out provision for anyone who really objected.

title: America Online Is Making More Changes at the Top
description: AOL Time Warner reshuffled the management of its America Online division yesterday, aiming to move beyond the unit's recent accounting problems and begin developing new, more elaborate interactive programming.

title: Mob Life Resumes, Darker by the Day
description: OF all the intentionally hurtful names adolescents fling at their parents, ''Mr. Mob Boss'' is not the most common, but in the Soprano family it's the most cutting. In Episode 2 of the new season of ''The Sopranos,'' Tony's daughter, Meadow, is distraught about the death of her former boyfriend and is milking it for every bit of sympathy she can get (shades of her beloved grandmother Livia). When she sarcastically screams that ugly phrase at her father, Tony jumps toward her, his finger pointed at her face, his head looking as if it's about to explode.

title: New Video Releases
description: Changing Lanes

title: Sept. 11 Suspect Captured
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 - Ramzi bin al-Shibh, who investigators say is a high-ranking operative for Al Qaeda and one of the few people still alive who know the inside details of the Sept. 11 plot, has been captured and is in custody, American officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Indonesia: Trial For Islamic Leader
description: A court in Jakarta ruled that the leader of Laskar Jihad, the militant Islamic group that has spearheaded the violence against Christians in the Moluccas and Sulawesi, must stand trial. The government had been reluctant to move against Jaffar Umar Thalib, for fear of backlash among Muslims. He has been charged with inciting violence and insulting the country's president in a speech. Dian Saputra (NYT)

title: Sing Your Mind
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the previous night's Yankees-Orioles baseball game referred imprecisely to pitcher David Wells and the source of the injuries he suffered during a scuffle in a Manhattan diner last weekend. A Yonkers man, Rocco Graziosa, has been charged with assault and menacing but has pleaded not guilty. There has been no legal finding that Wells was assaulted.

title: Prosecutors Say Drug Gang Has Been Routed in Camden
description: A federal and state narcotics task force said yesterday that it had broken up a violent drug gang that sold heroin and cocaine on three street corners in downtown Camden, N.J., for five years.

title: Election Reform's Exhibit A
description: Florida, poster child for botched elections, has done it again. Tuesday's primary was plagued by malfunctioning equipment and incompetent poll workers, forcing Gov. Jeb Bush to keep polls open for two extra hours. As of yesterday Janet Reno, citing voting irregularities, had still not conceded to her opponent, Bill McBride, in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. But while infuriating its own voters, Florida may have done the rest of the nation a favor by resurrecting the cause of federal election reform, which had stalled in Washington, and by reminding us that the 2000 Election Day meltdown was neither a fluke nor a bad dream.

title: Riley Is Forced to Face Reality of Rebuilding
description: With the announcement today that Alonzo Mourning, the Miami Heat's All-Star center, is likely to miss the season because of a setback in his fight against a kidney disorder, Heat Coach Pat Riley is faced with something he once swore he would rather quit than do.

title: New Instability Feared After Macedonia Election Sunday
description: When Macedonia votes in a general election on Sunday, Western officials will be less interested in who wins than in whether the results will create new threats to this troubled country's survival.

title: Canadian Teenager Held by U.S. in Afghanistan in Killing of American Medic
description: A Canadian teenager accused of killing an American medic while fighting with Al Qaeda in Afghanistan is being held there by the United States, Canadian officials say.

title: Suit Says U.S. Long Had Doubt About Billings By HealthSouth
description: Medicare officials have been raising questions about the HealthSouth Corporation's billings to the government for at least four years, according to a Justice Department lawsuit filed against the company earlier this year.

title: Betraying the Foreign Victims
description: Shockingly, many of those who were grieving the loss of a loved one at ground zero on Wednesday are now subject to deportation. Congress ought to rectify this unconscionable situation immediately. It should grant the hundreds of family members of lawfully employed foreigners who perished in last September's terrorist attacks the right to reside in the United States, regardless of when their original visas expired. It would also be fitting to honor the foreign casualties of this attack on American soil by offering citizenship to any of their dependents who wish it.

title: Democrats, Wary of War in Iraq, Also Worry About Battling Bush
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  A day after President Bush's speech to the United Nations, many Democrats are still tormented and uncertain over Iraq, not ready to give President Bush a blank check to wage war, yet wary about opposing him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, INA
description: KAY-Ina. Hadassah The Womens Zionist Organization of American Inc mourns the passing of Ina Kay. Beloved wife of Jack, devoted mother of Shelley Kay and Lauren and Richard Pollin, and loving grandmother of Sander and Kennis Haskins, Alyssa Perper and Julie Zitin. As a Guardian of Tomorrow, Ina was a generous benefactor of Hadassah. She was devoted to Israel and the Jewish people. Her legacy will live on through the Ina and Jack Kay Hospice and the visionary projects she supported at the Hadassah medical organization. May her memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, President

title: Judge Questions Bid to Use 9/11 Tapes in Trial
description: The federal judge overseeing the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui suggested in a ruling today that she would not allow a jury to hear cockpit voice recordings from the hijacked United Airlines jet that crashed in Pennsylvania on Sept. 11 because the tapes could unfairly prejudice the jury.

title: New Teammates, New Coach and a New Position for Elias
description: The center on the famed A-Line has been gone since late last season. The right wing was shipped west in a postseason trade. Another of his front-line teammates defected as a well-rewarded free agent. Another is holding out. On top of all that, the Devils' Patrik Elias shook the hand of his third head coach in less than a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIEHMANN, THEODORE E.
description: VIEHMANN - Theodore E. Died Thursday, September 12, 2002 at age 86 of natural causes. A native of Brooklyn, NY, Ted was a Chief in the US Navy during World War II, serving in both Europe and the Pacific and was a boilermaker for the city of New York Dept. of Sanitation until his retirement in 1978. He is survived by his beloved wife Helen, devoted daughters Joan Authenrieth of Saugerties, NY, Susan Bottari of Larchmont, NY, Gretchen Viehmann of Todos Santos, Mexico, his grandchildren Kate, Nick, Laura and Paul, his dear sister Florence Cline and many nieces and nephews. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York 10538. Saturday, Sunday 2-4, 7-9PM. Service at Fox, on Monday, September 16, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, family requests that donations be made in his name to the Brooklyn Public Library Foundation, Grand Army Plaza, Brooklyn, New York 11238.

title: United Airlines Unions Are Set To Offer Concessions Proposal
description: The unions at United Airlines said yesterday that they would offer a proposal for concessions to the carrier late next week to help it obtain a federal loan guarantee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, BRUCE W.
description: MITCHELL-Bruce W. The staff and board of the Alliance of Resident Theatres/ New York are profoundly saddened by the passing of our friend and Board member Bruce W. Mitchell. Bruce's passionate concern, clear headed analysis, and unwavering belief in our mission have made this a better organization. And his tremendous generosity, dignity and humor have made all of us who work here better human beings. He was adventurous, he lived his life to the fullest and he could give a hell of a party. Our thoughts are with his amazing wife Carol, his children and the rest of his family. Virginia Louloudes Executive Director

title: A Philosopher With New Disciples (in Music, Not Philosophy)
description: In Thomas Mann's ''Doctor Faustus,'' the music teacher Wendell Kretschmar plays Beethoven's Opus 111 piano sonata for his students. As he plays, he speaks and shouts and stutters, commenting on the music, combining the most vulgar observations with the most sublime. He invents lyrics, singing along with the music's spare, otherworldly themes. He reveals how a single note confers an ''overpowering humanity'' on a simple musical gesture. And he spins out speculations about subjectivity and death, culture and barbarism.

title: Yonkers Police Seeking Man Who Tried to Abduct Girl, 11
description: The police said today that they were looking for a suspect in the attempted abduction of an 11-year-old girl on Thursday. The city was already on edge after several complaints from young women that a man had exposed himself.

title: Bush gains praise over U.S. return to Unesco
description: PARIS:  The surprise announcement of U.S. intentions to rejoin Unesco, the UN body promoting global cultural and educational cooperation, helped drive home President George W. Bush's message of readiness for effective international cooperation, diplomats say.

title: Corrections
description: A heading in the Business Digest column yesterday about the current account deficit, the broadest measure of trade with foreign countries, misstated its movement in the second quarter. It grew; it did not fall.

title: On the Ropes, Fire Company Calls Off Topless Fights
description: A volunteer fire company has canceled a fund-raiser featuring wrestling by topless women. Supervising fire officials here, who have been trying to recruit women into the department, had suspended two company officers and threatened to sue to stop the event.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Oil prices jumped sharply after Iraq rejected American demands to allow weapons inspectors into the country. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 96 cents, or 3.3 percent, to $29.81 a barrel.

title: Fighting the Menace of Unwanted E-Mail
description: A few days ago I created a new e-mail account, and within 24 hours I had received over 25 unsolicited commercial e-mail messages, otherwise known as spam. Even though I'm a professor of computer science, I, like so many others, have failed to protect myself from this daily nuisance. So I welcome the efforts by consumer groups that this month filed a petition with the Federal Trade Commission to enact a federal rule that would require senders to identify themselves more clearly and give recipients an effective way to opt out of such mailings.

title: Air Pollution Regulations Extended to Snowmobiles
description: A final regulation issued today by the Environmental Protection Agency will impose stringent new pollution regulations on some of the country's dirtiest engines, the first time snowmobiles and all-terrain vehicles will fall under the Clean Air Act.

title: Homeless Man Slain
description: One of two homeless men who were attacked in a Brooklyn park earlier this week has died, the police said last night.

Today, one candidate, Janet Reno, went so far as to do what many Democrats wish Al Gore had done back then. Ms. Reno demanded a statewide recount of a primary in disarray.

title: Arafat's Last Hurrah?
description: Nine years ago today, Yasir Arafat stood on the White House lawn, at the zenith of his long career. It was a moment he invoked again and again in his speech to the Palestinian parliament on Monday, how he signed the ''peace of the brave with my friend Yitzhak Rabin.''

title: Federal Judge Drops Charges Of Perjury In Chicago
description: A federal judge in Chicago today threw out a perjury indictment against an Islamic charity and its leader, who were accused of lying about ties to Osama bin Laden and whether they had secretly funneled money to his terrorist network, Al Qaeda.

title: BIG GAME ON CAMPUS: Swagger Is Back in South Bend; At Notre Dame, Irish Regain Their Fight
description: It is not the Ed Sullivan Theater, and the lights of Broadway do not sparkle outside its windows. It is a field house in what most around here consider the cathedral of college football, and they believe it is haunted by the benevolent ghosts of the Four Horsemen, the Gipper and a granite-jawed coach named Rockne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCALPIN, ELEANOR
description: McALPIN - Eleanor New block. Passed away at her residence in St. Louis, MO on Wednesday, September 11, 2002. She was also a resident of Brandreth Park, NY. Beloved wife of the late Charles Williston McAlpin II. Dear mother of Charles Newblock McAlpin. Mother-in-law of Anne Stupp McAlpin. Grandmother of Charles Newblock McAlpin, Jr. The Funeral Service will be conducted in St. Louis, MO on Saturday, September 14. For information Lupton Funeral Chapel at phone 314-721-1870.

title: William Phillips, Co-Founder and Soul of Partisan Review, Dies at 94
description: William Phillips, the co-founder and longtime editor of Partisan Review, the forum for the brilliant and contentious stable of writers who became known as the New York Intellectuals, died yesterday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINKERHOFF, LILLIAN
description: BRINKERHOFF - Lillian Westaway. Services today 10:30 AM, Church of the Atonement, Quogue Street, Quogue, NY. Interment Quogue Cemetery. Reception following at Slumberside.

title: Battleground Of Sounds, Whizzing By
description: Calm sustained notes, perhaps sampled from a viola, came from Marcus Schmickler's laptop to begin his concert on Thursday evening at the Goethe Institute. They were decoys for the mayhem to follow.

title: U.S. Tasks in Afghan Desert: Hunt Taliban, Tote Plywood
description: The air operation to Afghanistan's front line starts every morning before the sun breaks over the hills. With daytime tarmac temperatures sometimes hitting 130 degrees, Army cargo pilots like to take off at first light, catching the better lift that comes with cooler temperatures.

title: Poly Prep and New Coach Get Early Test at St. Anthony's
description: Poly Prep lost only one game in the last six seasons, and much of the credit for the Blue Devils' success went to their coach, Dino Mangiero.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: BCE Sells Phone Directory Unit
description: BCE, Canada's dominant communications group, said that it was selling 90 percent of its telephone directories unit for $567 million cash plus the assumption of $1.3 billion in debt to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts of New York and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan. The unit publishes more than 200 white pages and yellow pages directories in Ontario and Quebec. Money from the sale will be used to help finance BCE's proposed $3.9 billion purchase of the 20 percent stake in its Bell Canada telephone subsidiary presently held by SBC Communications of San Antonio. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Bush Is Doubtful Iraq Will Comply With U.N. Demands
description: President Bush said yesterday that it was "highly doubtful" that Saddam Hussein would meet United Nations demands to disarm, and American officials said they would seek wording in any new Security Council resolution authorizing any member nation to use force if Iraq did not comply.

title: More Proof, If Needed, That Funk Still Works
description: What worked in the 1950's, 1960's and 1970's is good enough for Soulive, which set a packed house dancing at the Mercury Lounge on Thursday night. Soulive, which was briefly a quartet, is back to the lineup of the basic 1950's organ trio, with Neal Evans playing a Hammond B-3 organ or a Hohner clavinet; Eric Krasno on guitar and Alan Evans, Neal's brother, on drums.

title: A Measured Pace on Iraq
description: Now that President Bush has outlined his strategy for dealing with Iraq, there will be a strong temptation at the White House to press ahead at warp speed in the United Nations and Congress. Mr. Bush was already sounding impatient yesterday, just a day after his address to the U.N. Unless the president has evidence indicating that Iraq is on the brink of fabricating nuclear weapons, he would be well advised to give the Security Council and Congress ample time to deliberate. He will only undermine support for his policy if he tries to stampede everyone into action.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KWIKSET CORP., Lake Forest, Calif., the world's leading manufacturer of residential lock systems, will close its Waynesboro, Ga., plant because of lagging sales. About 550 people will lose their jobs.

title: AT&T and AT&T Canada Hire Bank for New Appraisal
description: The AT&T Corporation, the largest United States long-distance telephone company, and AT&T Canada Inc. hired Morgan Stanley to appraise the value of the Canadian company's shares that AT&T does not own already and plans to buy next month.

title: Dele's Boat Found in Tahiti; F.B.I. Searches for Brother
description: The catamaran belonging to the former N.B.A. player Bison Dele has been found in Tahiti, but Dele, his girlfriend and the boat's captain are still missing, the F.B.I. said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about a shortage of international studies experts at elite universities included an erroneous statement from Yale about its political science department. The department indeed includes a full-time specialist on South Asia -- Arun Agrawal, an associate professor who is also a specialist on the politics of the environment.

title: Britain Plans Army Exercises; Parliament Is to Debate Iraq
description: As the United States steps up pressure for the removal of the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, Britain's Defense Ministry said today that 6,000 British troops would embark on a major exercise to test the army's ability to marshal large amounts of fuel, ammunition and other military equipment.

title: Lucent Plans To Eliminate More Positions
description: Lucent Technologies, the nation's largest maker of communications equipment, warned yesterday that it would continue to eliminate jobs as sales plunge, an indication of worsening problems in the telecommunications industry.

title: Ship's Radiation Is Traced to Harmless Tiles
description: A German container ship was allowed to dock in Port Newark today after more than two days of inspections determined that the radioactive readings that it registered were emanating from naturally occurring radiation in ceramic tiles among the cargo.

title: Pakistan Court Bars Former Prime Minister From Election
description: A court today rejected an appeal by a former prime minister, Benazir Bhutto, seeking permission to run in Parliamentary elections in October.

title: Shares Mixed on Varied Economic News and Iraq Talk
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday as news on the economy and continued talk about action against Iraq kept the outlook cloudy. Although stocks managed to climb on Monday and Tuesday before the Sept. 11 commemoration, they fell Wednesday and Thursday and are down for the third consecutive week.

title: Bush and Baghdad: The Temperature Rises
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Court Bans Protests
description: A court banned protests against President Leonid D. Kuchma planned for next week, the Russian news agency Interfax reported. Opposition leaders, who have said they will gather thousands of protesters on the streets of central Kiev next week, said they would ignore the court ruling. In another blow to the opposition, Yulia Timoshenko, an outspoken critic of Mr. Kuchma, was detained at the Kiev airport and blocked from flying to a protest rally. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Was 'Old' Map Faked To Tweak the Nazis?
description: The Vinland Map must be the world's most contested piece of parchment. Donated to Yale University by the philanthropist Paul Mellon in 1957, the map, which famously describes the Viking discovery of North America, has been stuck in scholarly deadlock ever since. The subject of endless studies and counterstudies, the map is either a rare medieval artifact -- the first cartographic representation of the continent -- or else a modern fake.

title: Israel to Follow U.S. Lead if Iraq Is Attacked
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that his country would follow the lead of the United States in any war against Iraq.

title: Yankees Struggle to Stay Close Before Faltering Late
description: The deceptive thing about the Yankees' game last night was not the final score. The Chicago White Sox did embarrass the Yankees, and the 13-2 score reflected how poorly the Yankees played.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, ROBERT
description: GALLAGHER - Robert. On September 10, 2002 in Plainfield, Massachusetts. Beloved husband of the late Patricia Engel Gallagher. Father of Liese Gallagher Howarth of Ashfield, MA, Martha S. Gallagher and Paula Gallagher Abeles, both of Washington, D.C. Grandfather to Joseph Howarth and Winthrop Abeles. Brother to William Gallagher and Evelyn McConnoughie of Weymouth, MA. A former attorney with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington, DC, his legal practice concentrated on issues of transportation law, spanning from the elimination of the gateway requirements for household goods carriers to bringing Reiter v. Cooper to the Supreme Court. A longtime advocate for transportation intermediaries, he founded the Transportation Brokers Conference of America (now the Transportation Intermediaries Association) and the Freight Forwarders Council of America. He was the author of Gallagher on Transportation Brokerage (1986); Freight Brokerage (1988); and the Freight Forwarders Manual (1994). For several months prior to his death he had been working on a book on the teachings of Jesus Christ. He was actively involved in town and regional government, serving as Chairman of the Board of Selectmen of Plainfield, MA and as the Representative of Plainfield to the Hampshire County Board of Commissioners and the Democratic State Convention. Born in Quincy, MA, December 26, 1930, he attended Boston College from high school through law school. He lived for many years in Mendham, New Jersey. The funeral will be from Pease Funeral Home, Northampton, MA., Saturday at 8:30AM with a mass of Christian burial at St. Mary's Church, Haydenville, MA. Burial will be in Hilltop Cemetery, Plainfield, MA. Memorial contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was brought up to shoot only what I can eat -- I don't shoot them just to kill. Now we go out and shoot a deer and you throw it in the Dumpster.''

title: Golden Quits Post in Brooklyn Prosecutor's Office
description: The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday that he had accepted the resignation of Howard Golden, a former Brooklyn borough president whose hiring in January for a $125,000-a-year position in the prosecutor's office drew sharp criticism.

title: Europe Lists U.S. Goods Facing Retaliation
description: The European Union threatened again today to impose sanctions of up to $4 billion on American imports as it published a list of potential products for retaliation if the United States does not scrap a tax break for its exporters.

title: De La Hoya and Vargas to Settle Feud
description: After trading insults for years, Oscar De La Hoya and Fernando Vargas are finally ready to trade punches.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOORE, JOHN MCDONALD
description: MOORE-John McDonald. January 11, 1919-September 14, 1999. Devoted teacher, beloved parent, grandparent and cherished husband. ''And if the earthly has forgotten you, say to the still earth: I flow. To the rapid water speak: I am.'' R.M. Rilk

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORREST, LEONARD
description: FORREST-Leonard. We at Congregation B'nai Yisrael mourn for our longtime friend. We will miss his energy, warmth and love. We share our sorrow with Margi and the members of their family. Barby K. Siegel, President Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz Rabbi Seth M. Limmer, Cantor Miriam Eskenasy

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: GERMANY: PORSCHE SEES RISING PROFITS Porsche's profit will rise "significantly" this fiscal year, bolstered by the Cayenne, 911 and Boxster models, its chief executive, Wendelin Wiedeking, left, said yesterday. "The August figures were very good," Mr. Wiedeking said in an interview. "We'll definitely grow significantly this year in terms of unit sales, and if unit sales rise, you can assume other results will develop correspondingly." Porsche, which is based in Stuttgart, said that increased demand for the company's 911 model has offset falling sales of the lower-priced Boxster model in the United States. The company has added extra shifts at its factory outside Stuttgart to increase production of the 911, which has higher profit margins.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Easyjet Founder To Resign Sooner
description: Stelios Haji-Ioannou, 35, the founder and chairman of the low-cost airline Easyjet, said that he would bring forward his resignation to Nov. 26. Easyjet is completing a $583 million acquisition of the rival Go carrier to overtake Ryanair as Europe's biggest budget carrier. The announcement helped calm the jitters surrounding Easyjet's share price, which fell 12 percent on Thursday because of fears that Mr. Haji-Ioannou, left, planned to sell his stake in the company. The shares recovered 7 percent yesterday after Mr. Haji-Ioannou said he would remain a ''significant shareholder in EasyJet for a very long time.'' Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 80 HOG FARMERS FILE A LAWSUIT AGAINST TYSON FOODS
description: A group of 80 hog farmers from Arkansas, Iowa and Oklahoma sued Tyson Foods Inc., contending the company defrauded them when it scaled back its live swine operations. The farmers, who raised hogs under contract for Tyson, said they were given ''repeated reassurances'' that the meat processor was ''in the live swine business to stay,'' according to a lawsuit filed Thursday in state court in Russellville, Ark. Instead, Tyson said Aug. 18 that it would sever relationships with 132 contract hog producers as part of a restructuring of its money-losing hog business. The company said it had met with contract farmers after announcing the revamping and presented a proposal it believed ''satisfied our obligations under existing contracts.''

title: McDONALD'S FRANCHISE OPERATORS SUPPORT AN OVERHAUL
description: The owners and operators of McDonald's restaurants approved a plan by the company, the world's largest hamburger chain, to remodel restaurants and change menus across the country. About 98 percent of the people who run the company's franchises voted in favor of the plan yesterday, McDonald's said in a statement. McDonald's will try to invigorate sluggish sales by advertising $1 sandwiches, selling a fruit-and-yogurt dessert and renovating some of its more than 13,000 restaurants. Shares of the company are near their lowest point in almost seven years because of concern that the changes will hurt profit and may not stem customer losses to rivals like Wendy's International. McDonald's is based in Oak Brook, Ill.

title: Bullpen's Success Allows Rivera to Take His Time
description: Mariano Rivera returned to the Yankees yesterday, but it may be another week before he pitches for them. That is fine with Rivera, who said his comeback from a strained right shoulder muscle was easier because his replacements were flawless.

description: STAHL-Esther (nee Ludmer). Beloved wife of Al. Cherished mother of Madeline and Jerry Breslaw, Mark and Pat. Loving sister of Ruth Cohen and Rose Dakss. Adored grandmother of Sheryl and Cory Wein, Michelle and Scott Bellin, and Danielle Stahl. Great-grandmother of Zachary, Jordan and Matthew. Services Sunday 10AM at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: NOULAS-Arthur M. On Friday, Sept. 13, 2002. Beloved husband of Sophie (nee Safiol) for 50 years. Loving father of Alexis and Basil Livanos, Joyce and Paul Cutrone, Evan and Chrisia Noulas. Loving grandfather of Peter, William, Katherine, Arthur, Andrew, Carolyn, Sophia and Arthur. He was an Archon, a member of The Order of Saint Andrew The Apostle, a veteran of W.W. II. His body will lay in rest at the Holy Cross G.O. Church, 8401 Ridge Blvd, Brooklyn, N.Y. on Sunday, Sept 15, 2002 from 6 PM until 9 PM. Divine Liturgy Monday, 8:30 AM. Funeral Service 9:45AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Holy Cross G.O. title: TEXTRON WINS $300 MILLION AIRCRAFT ORDER FROM NETJETS
description: The Cessna aircraft unit of Textron Inc. won a $300 million order from NetJets Inc., the world's largest private operator of business jets, for as many as 112 airplanes. NetJets is owned by Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett. It agreed to buy 50 CJ3 business jets and 12 Citation X planes, and took options to buy another 50 CJ3's. NetJets sells fractional ownerships of small jets to corporations and wealthy individuals in a type of time-sharing arrangement. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., also makes Bell helicopters, industrial fasteners, golf carts and construction equipment. In the second quarter, Textron's sales fell everywhere but in its aircraft and military business.

description: JOE DRAPE'S TOP MATCHUPS

title: A Brooklyn Inventor Eases an African Headache; An Inexpensive Handcart Catches On in Malawi, Where Women Have Long Used Their Heads
description: For centuries, women in rural Africa have carried heavy loads on their heads as they take goods to market. But a man in Brooklyn thinks he has a better way, and -- as far-fetched as it may seem -- people in one African nation have begun to listen.

title: Reeve's Class Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGERT, MARGARET
description: BOGERT - Margaret. The Trustees of the National Foundaton for Facial Reconstruction deeply mourn the death of Margie Bogert. She served with distinction on our board for better than 15 years and will be greatly missed. She attended board meetings with outstanding regularity including the last year of her remarkable life. Her sunny disposition coupled with her most wise counsel and generosity contributed enormously to this organization while benefiting countless children suffering craniofacial anomalies. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her sons Larry and Jerry and grandchildren. Joseph G. McCarthy, M.D. John R. Gordon, President J. Peter Hoguet, Chairman

title: Vivendi's Latest Spin Campaign: No Sale Option Is Left Unspun
description: Since taking the helm of Vivendi Universal, Jean-Ren Fourtou has not publicly ruled out the sale of any business, from publishing to telecommunications to movies, music and theme parks. He has left analysts and some investment bankers puzzled by creating the impression that the entire company could potentially be up for sale.

title: Foot Locker May Trim Orders of Nike's Most Expensive Shoes
description: Foot Locker Inc., the largest United States retailer of athletic shoes, said yesterday that it might trim orders of higher-price shoes and other products from Nike Inc. by $150 million to $250 million next year because of tepid demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, WILLIAM
description: PHILLIPS-William. Editor-inchief of Partisan Review for 68 years. A beacon of light in the intellectual world, he was honest, discerning, uncompromising. He made PR required reading for decades for anyone interested in the issues and culture of our time. Our condolences to his loving wife, Edith Kurzweil. Funeral private. Memorial service November 14, his 95th birthday. The Advisory Board of Partisan Review Joanna S. Rose, Chairman

title: At Least Mets Manage More Runs Than Errors
description: The Mets had played so well recently that they appeared to have relaxed after a long losing streak had wiped out their season. With the pressure of playing for a playoff spot gone, they excelled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, GEORGE R.
description: ADLER-George R. The Faculty and Staff of The MarieJosee and Henry R. Kravis Center for Cardiovascular Health and The Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute of Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of George R. Adler. A thoughtful and compassionate benefactor, George shared our special commitment to improving the lives of those suffering from cardiovascular disease. He will be remembered fondly for his kind and generous support. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Marion, and to the entire family. Valentin Fuster, M.D., Ph.D. Richard Gorlin, M.D./Heart Research Foundation Professor Cardiology Director The Marie-Josee and Henry R. Kravis Center for Cardiovascular Health The Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute The Mount Sinai Medical Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMELBACHER, HANS M.
description: HAMMELBACHER-Hans M. Beloved husband of Hella. Father of Ralph and Frank. Grandfather of Jill and father-in-law of Faith and Janet. Passed away peacefully on September 13, 2002 at the age of 91 after a brief illness. He will be remembered for his devotion to his family, for his abiding friendships and for the lasting impact he made on so many lives. He cared passionately about community and charitable work and served, for many years, on the Board of The Blue Card, Congregation Habonim and The Margaret Tietz Center for Nursing Care. He loved music, books, the arts and learning, and stayed active to his last days. We will miss his love, generous spirit and wonderful, quick sense of humor. Services Sunday at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial, 9:30AM, Queens Blvd and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: No Decision in Contempt Case Against a Gotti Jail Warden
description: A federal judge delayed a decision yesterday about whether to seek contempt charges against a prison warden who did not obey the judge's order this week to release Peter Gotti from solitary confinement.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: A Call To Restore A Soviet 'Knight'
description: Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov of Moscow proposed returning the statue of Feliks Dzerzhinsky, godfather of the Soviet secret police, to its pedestal in Lubyanka Square, opposite the former K.G.B. headquarters. The statue of Dzerzhinsky, whom Stalin called ''the steadfast knight of the revolution,'' was pulled down in the euphoric days after the abortive coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev in August 1991, which hastened the collapse of the Soviet Union. The proposal is not ''a return to the past,'' Mr. Luzhkov said. ''Some associate this man with the K.G.B., others with the crackdown on child neglect and railroad restoration,'' he said, according to Interfax. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: China Seems To Refine Bid To Restrict Web Access
description: The Chinese authorities appear to have refined their attempts to block access to popular United States-based Internet search engines, people who use the Web in different parts of the country said today.

title: It's Either Me Or the G.O.P., Torricelli Tells Democrats
description: Chip Casto is a reliable Democrat, unable to recall ever voting for a Republican. When he considered registering as an independent years ago, said Mr. Casto, 36, his parents would not hear of it.

title: Beliefs; Two books paint portraits of today's rabbis that go enthusiastically beyond the black and white.
description: Shouldn't rabbis be photographed in black-and-white? Shouldn't they be portrayed stroking bearded chins or poring over texts in book-lined offices? Isn't that the proper image, especially before the holiday of Yom Kippur, when rabbis who lead congregations must deliver perhaps the year's most important sermon?

title: Terror's Trojan Horse
description: Much of our recent national conversation has revolved around nuclear weapons and the potential of terrorists to wreak havoc on America. But while the Bush administration is focusing attention on a potential war with Iraq, it is ignoring a less costly and less controversial method that could protect us more permanently from nuclear attack: tightening our borders by installing devices that could detect nuclear weapons as terrorists attempt to smuggle them into the country.

title: Tears for Migrant Workers Killed in Van Crash in Maine
description: In an apartment over Tracy's Gun Shop, Hugo Bonilla spent much of the day talking on the telephone to Honduras and Guatemala, giving families the news that they will not see their relatives working in the United States again. At the kitchen table, his wife, Connie, wept.

title: Isles Already Working To Develop Yashin Line
description: More than two hours after the Islanders' first practice of training camp, Aleksei Yashin hovered over a tool bench, diligently working on his stick as if it needed to pass a military inspection. Oleg Kvasha hovered next to him, working on his stick.

title: Georgia Seeks to Ease Tensions With Russia Over Chechens
description: Georgia took several measures today in an attempt to defuse tensions with Russia, which had threatened military action against Chechen fighters on Georgian territory.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN SLIPS. The dollar gained against the yen as a bigger-than-expected rise in American retail sales indicated that the recovery may be strengthening. In New York, the yen settled at 121.73, from 120.11 on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASSLER, BLANCHE
description: FASSLER-Blanche. Of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin David Fassler and the late Akiva Taubenschlag. Devoted mother of Gertrude Hecht, Rita Elmer and Claire Meistrich. Dear sister of James Grosflan and Murray Gross. Loving grandmother of seven grandchildren. Services on Sunday at ''Gutterman-Musicant''. For information 1-800-522-0588

title: Giants Fined for Taunts, With Chatty Rams Next
description: Tiki Barber will not say much when the Giants play the St. Louis Rams on Sunday, and he will be in the minority. Barber genially taps the helmet of the defenders who tackle him and sometimes adds, ''Nice job'' -- probably a form of reverse psychology, Barber mused today, laughing a little.

title: Executives Ordered Shredders as ImClone Inquiries Began
description: Samuel D. and Harlan W. Waksal, the two top executives of ImClone Systems, ordered paper shredders in early January, around the time federal investigations of the company were beginning, the company said in a letter sent to Congress yesterday.

title: Lab Suggests Qaeda Planned To Build Arms, Officials Say
description: Pentagon officials disclosed new details today about equipment found in a laboratory near Kandahar, Afghanistan, that they contend Al Qaeda intended to use to make biological and chemical weapons.

title: AOL TIME WARNER NAMES HEAD OF MARKETING ARM
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that it had hired Michael Kelly, a former Time Inc. executive, to run a marketing group created a year ago to increase advertising sales in all of the company's units. Mr. Kelly spent 17 years at Time Inc., where he was Entertainment Weekly's publisher from 1996 to 2000, before founding American Town Network, an online guide to suburban communities. America Online, the world's largest provider of Internet access, has reported three quarters of declining ad sales, and government regulators are investigating marketing deals in the unit.

title: Where a Doctor's Office Is a Comic Scene
description: ''Alone No More,'' a program of dance by Alona Mor presented on Sunday night at the Gene Frankel Theater, was the work of a savvy novice. Ms. Mor came to New York from Israel five years ago to train as a doctor but changed careers after her first dance class.

title: Bloomberg Seconds Bush In Defending Use of Arms
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the fourth mayor of New York to address the United Nations General Assembly, used the occasion yesterday to make a subtle case for military action against Iraq, underscoring the message President Bush delivered just a day earlier.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kohl Bows Out
description: The political career of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl, 72, ended as he retired as a member of Parliament, but he skipped the final session before the Sept. 22 national election. Mr. Kohl joined Parliament in 1976 and was Germany's leader from 1982 to 1998. He was tarnished by a campaign financing scandal in 1999 and addressed Parliament only twice in the last four years. His final days in Parliament were overshadowed by remarks he reportedly made saying the current president of Parliament, Wolfgang Thierse, was the worst since Hermann Gring, the Nazi war criminal. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: Verizon, the largest provider of local phone service in New York, filed a lawsuit yesterday to block the reconstruction of 7 World Trade Center unless the developer agrees to either redesign the 52-story tower or pay for moving critical parts of a vast telephone network that would be buried beneath it.

description: When it comes to casino gambling, a $369 million pillar of Connecticut's tax revenue portfolio last year, the message from the state's most powerful elected officials has suddenly become loud and clear: Enough is enough.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Thumbs-Up For Cheney's Heart
description: Vice President Dick Cheney said he received good reports after a routine heart checkup. ''Everything is fine,'' he said on Rush Limbaugh's radio program, shortly after giving a thumbs-up sign while leaving George Washington University Hospital. Mr. Cheney, who is 61 and has a history of heart trouble, had a pacemaker implanted in his chest in June 2001. He has been staying at an undisclosed secure location since the nation went on a higher alert this week. David Stout (NYT)

title: Corrections

description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in Buchanan, N.Y., resumed operations yesterday after a hydrogen leak in a nonnuclear part of the plant prompted a shutdown on Wednesday for repairs.

title: In the Race for Governor, Still Debating Over Debating
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who avoided debates in his two previous successful campaigns for governor, said yesterday that he ''absolutely'' would debate the Democratic nominee, H. Carl McCall.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: U.S. Soldiers Face Court-Martial
description: The United States Army headquarters in Seoul said two sergeants would be court-martialed on charges of negligent homicide in the deaths of two teenage girls who were run over by an armored vehicle during a training exercise on June 13. One sergeant, Mark Walker, was driving the vehicle while the other, Fernando Nino, was responsible for watching the road. The Army said other soldiers involved in the exercise faced administrative punishment for the accident, a focal point for anti-American protests demanding withdrawal of all 37,000 American troops from Korea. The United States command rejected a South Korean request to hand over the sergeants for prosecution by Korean courts. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Hard Drive Problem
description: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's biggest maker of business computers, said that it might replace as many as 300,000 hard disk drives after discovering a fault. Its shares declined 4.9 percent, their biggest one-day decline in almost two months. The flaw may affect 2 percent to 3 percent of the 10 million hard disk drives it produced from September 2000 to September 2001, a spokeswoman, Emi Watanabe, said. The disk drives are found in Fujitsu's own computers, as well as those of two customers, NEC and I.B.M. Fujitsu declined to say how much it would cost to replace the drives. title: LILLY SUES TEVA OVER GENERIC PSYCHIATRIC DRUG

Teva, based in Israel, said the patent protecting Zyprexa was either invalid, unenforceable or not infringed. Lilly, which is based in Indianapolis, filed the suit Monday in federal court there. The company seeks a ruling that Teva is infringing a valid patent for olanzapine, the main ingredient in the drug. The lawsuit asks that Teva be blocked from selling a generic version of the drug until after the patent expires in 2011.

title: Never Forget What?
description: Candor is so little prized in Washington that you want to shake the hand of anyone who dares commit it. So cheers to Andrew Card, the president's chief of staff, for telling The Times's Elisabeth Bumiller the real reason that his boss withheld his full-frontal move on Saddam Hussein until September: ''From a marketing point of view, you don't introduce new products in August.'' Mr. Card has taken some heat for talking about a war in which many may die as if it were the rollout of a new S.U.V. But he wasn't lying, and history has already proved him right. This campaign has been so well timed and executed that the new product already owns the market. The unofficial motto of the 9/11 anniversary may have been ''Never forget,'' but by 9/12, if not before, the war on Al Qaeda was already fading from memory as the world was invited to test-drive the war on Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Sees Rising Profits
description: Porsche's profit will rise ''significantly'' this fiscal year, bolstered by the Cayenne, 911 and Boxster models, its chief executive, Wendelin Wiedeking, left, said yesterday. ''We'll definitely grow significantly this year in terms of unit sales, and if unit sales rise, you can assume other results will develop correspondingly.'' Porsche, which is based in Stuttgart, said that increased demand for the company's 911 model has offset falling sales of the lower-priced Boxster model in the United States. The company has added extra shifts at its factory outside Stuttgart to increase production of the 911, which has higher profit margins.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Deal Is Approved
description: Hana Bank won final government approval to buy SeoulBank in a deal that will turn Hana into Korea's third-largest commercial bank. Hana has agreed to pay $960 million worth of its shares for SeoulBank, taken over by the government at the height of Korea's economic crisis at the end of 1997. The government last month named Hana as the preferred bidder ahead of Lone Star Funds of Dallas pending the go-ahead by the Public Fund Oversight Committee, under the aegis of the finance ministry. SeoulBank is owned by the Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation, also under the finance ministry. The K.D.I.C., which owns a number of other Korean banks, will hold 30.9 percent of Hana Bank's shares after the sale goes through. The government tried for four years without success to find a foreign bank to buy SeoulBank. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Dances With Hens
description: In the Irish writer Sebastian Barry's new novel ANNIE DUNNE (Viking, $24.95), human beings remain a mystery to each other even when they share a life, a home, even a bed. It is the late 1950's, and Annie Dunne and Sarah Cullen are cousins in their 60's who work a small farm together in County Wicklow. Neither has ever married -- Annie has a hump on her back and never had suitors -- and the two have forged a symbiotic bond in their mutual need for survival. The farm demands their attention from daybreak to dusk, and they don't see much of other people -- until one summer when Annie's great-niece and great-nephew come to stay while their parents look for work in London. The children delight Annie, filling her with youthful energy. They confound her, too; they play strange games that aren't altogether innocent, and their impulsiveness disrupts Annie and Sarah's spartan routine. Further disruption comes in the form of Billy Kerr, a local laborer who comes to call on Sarah too often for Annie's taste. Billy is a dark and complex character, but Barry's real triumph is Annie, who lives a quiet life set to ''the small music of the hens'' but inside churns and rages like a waterfall. ''Annie Dunne'' suspends rural Ireland in a time when women still make their own butter and cars are only just becoming common. Barry is also a playwright, and his dialogue is clear and musical. But it's Annie's passionate observations and shifting moods -- rendered in dense prose that's close to poetry -- that fuel this fine novel. Emily Gordon

title: Americans Don't Go for the Gold
description: To promote its new gold-colored dollar coin, which features Sacagawea, an American Indian woman, the United States Mint called on corporate America for help. It distributed the coins in Wal-Mart stores, spread them in Cheerios cereal boxes from General Mills and even persuaded IHOP to rename its ''Silver Dollar Pancakes'' as ''Golden Dollar Pancakes.'' But the marketing campaign, which began two years ago, has failed to persuade the public to use the coin widely, according to a report released last week by the General Accounting Office. The G.A.O. recommended that the promotion stop, and that is just as well, since the mint has already ceased production.

The discussion of a subplot in which several teenagers contract a mysterious sexual disease descends into a round of dirty jokes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIEHMANN, THEODORE E.
description: VIEHMANN - Theodore E. Died Thursday, September 12, 2002 at age 86 of natural causes. A native of Brooklyn, NY, Ted was a Chief in the US Navy during World War II, serving in both Europe and the Pacific and was a boilermaker for the city of New York Dept. of Sanitation until his retirement in 1978. He is survived by his beloved wife Helen, devoted daughters Joan Authenrieth of Saugerties, NY, Susan Bottari of Larchmont, NY, Gretchen Viehmann of Todos Santos, Mexico, his grandchildren Kate, Nick, Laura and Paul, his dear sister Florence Cline and many nieces and nephews. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York 10538. Saturday, Sunday 2-4, 7-9PM. Service at Fox, on Monday, September 16, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, family requests that donations be made in his name to the Brooklyn Public Library Foundation, Grand Army Plaza, Brooklyn, New York 11238.

His own Fatah movement led a campaign in the Palestinian Legislative Council, the parliament he had long disregarded that forced Mr. Arafat to fire his entire cabinet, including ministers he had named in June under American pressure. The Palestinian leader also decreed that elections for president and parliament would be held Jan. 20.

title: Page Turner
description: So where has she been all our lives? By Hollywood's time line for actresses, Naomi Watts, who turns 34 this month, is already entering the second act of her career as a movie star. Her assignments during Act I included ''Children of the Corn IV: The Gathering'' and dubbing a mouse's voice in ''Babe: Pig in the City.'' Now, in a leap that strains credulity even by the promiscuous standards of show-biz fables, she has five films on the way, from big-studio horror (''The Ring,'' from the producer of ''Men in Black'') to Merchant-Ivory lit (''Le Divorce,'' adapted from Diane Johnson's novel) to art-house chic (''21 Grams,'' Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu's follow-up to ''Amores Perros''). Her co-stars have been upgraded from digitized swine to movie aristocracy on the order of Sean Penn, Benicio Del Toro and Kate Hudson.

title: A Woman's Work
description: Slaughter, and then worse, came to Butare, a sleepy, sun-bleached Rwandan town, in the spring of 1994. Hutu death squads armed with machetes and nail-studded clubs had deployed throughout the countryside, killing, looting and burning. Roadblocks had been set up to cull fleeing Tutsis. By the third week of April, as the Rwanda genocide was reaching its peak intensity, tens of thousands of corpses were rotting in the streets of Kigali, the country's capital. Butare, a stronghold of Tutsis and politically moderate Hutus that had resisted the government's orders for genocide, was the next target. Its residents could hear gunfire from the hills in the west; at night they watched the firelight of torched nearby villages. Armed Hutus soon gathered on the edges of town, but Butare's panicked citizens defended its borders.

title: Two-Lane Tour Guide
description: Mark Di Ionno has lived in 15 towns in six New Jersey counties, and has spent a lifetime wandering the state's 6,788-mile network of intercounty or ''500'' series of two-lane highways. In ''Backroads, New Jersey: Driving at the Speed of Life'' (Rutgers $19) he describes the trip, aided by about 50 illustrations and 9 maps. He participates in traditions he considers a ''byproduct of the landscape,'' a muskrat dinner at a Salem fire department fund-raiser, for instance, and a re-enactment of the Battle of Monmouth. Mr. Di Ionno's ''weekend wanderings'' create more than the typical travel guide. From the ridges of the Watchungs to the flatlands of the western Ocean counties, down a Delaware River dead-end or into the towns where Walt Whitman worked and Alexander Hamilton's life ended, in ''Backroads,'' he matches cultural subtext with topographical diversity. Melissa Bannon

He has sold more than 100 million records, which is more than any solo artist except Garth Brooks and Elvis Presley. He has dated supermodels, and he married one of them. Drunk people will sing ''Piano Man'' for as long as there are karaoke bars, so he shall live forever. This fall he will embark on a stadium tour with Elton John, and they will sell out Madison Square Garden on the strength of songs that are two decades old; next month, Twyla Tharp will take a play to Broadway titled ''Movin' Out,'' which will wordlessly interpret 24 of Joel's songs through the idiom of modern dance.

title: The Politics of Drought
description: Many of America's farmers and ranchers are in a bad way. Some parts of the country are now enduring a fifth consecutive year of drought. Yields are dismal, families desperate. That said, it was mainly politics, not compassion, that drove the Senate last week to approve nearly $6 billion in emergency drought relief, thereby defying President Bush and deepening Washington's budget woes. Budget experts say that with only modest adjustments, the Senate could have easily extracted the $6 billion in drought relief from the extravagant $180 billion farm-subsidy bill it approved last spring. But that would have required trimming some of the bill's lavish entitlements, a step few senators were prepared to take.

description: Recently a friend told me that he and his wife were expecting a baby, cautioning me that this news was confidential. Once they went public, I told my wife, who is very upset that I didn't tell her the news the minute I heard. She says that on nonprofessional matters like this, there is an expectation that a husband would tell his wife and that the confidentiality would not be violated. I say confidential is confidential. What do you say? P.J.M., New Jersey

title: Spellbound
description: My daughter, too, competed in the National Spelling Bee, and I had the pleasure of watching J. J. wow the audience with her performance and her poise. I especially remember her delighted grin when she nailed a particularly tough word. Your photographs fail to capture her spunk and pride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYATT, JACQUELINE STED MAN
description: WYATT - Jacqueline Sted man, 62. Passed away August 7, 2002 in Guadalajara, Mexico from complications associated with pneumonia. A longtime resident of Palm Beach, FL, Dallas, TX and Ajijic, Mexico, Jackie was born in New York, N.Y., September 15, 1939 to the late Florence Leavitt Schick and the late Admiral Giles Chester Stedman. She attended Manhattanville College in NY and Southern Methodist University in Dallas. A Clairol model in her youth, a painter and writer of poetry, Princess Jacqueline rose to prominence during the late sixties and early seventies as a world class Backgammon player and promoter under the tutelage of her wonderful late second husband and Backgammon champion Prince Alexis Obolensky. Jackie was a five time cancer survivor whose courage, grace, warmth, intelligence, generosity and humanitarianism touched the lives of so many. She possessed incredible style, charm and charisma and a passion for the arts, literature, music, crossword puzzles, medieval mythology, unicorns, and toy Pomeranians. After three decades she romantically reunited with her first love and husband, Brady Thomas Wyatt and lived happily in Ajijic, Mexico. She is survived by loving husband Brady Thomas Wyatt, twin sons Christopher Thomas Wyatt and Michael Stedman Wyatt, daughter-in-law Piper Sanders Wyatt, previous husband Bruce Calder, stepdaughter Anne Obolensky, stepsons Chris Calder, Curtis Calder and Bruce Calder Jr., devoted lifelong friend and confidant Jon Elliot, loyal friend Maria Hernandez. God - daughter Eugenia Hernandez, and companion, toy Pomeranian Tsaravich. She will be dearly missed by many whose lives she changed. Her ashes will be scattered on September 15, the day of her birth. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to the Schick Foundation c/o Baylor Healthcare Foundation, Baylor University Medical Center, 3500 Gaston Suite #

title: Comfort Food, Northern Italian Style
description: WHEN I was a young girl in northern California, my father liked to treat the family to dinner at the old Sonoma Hotel. A drive past dairies, plum orchards and vineyards led to great platters of salami, cheese ravioli in red sauce, Shirley Temples and best of all little bowls of spumoni. This was long ago, in a time before Italian restaurants metamorphosed, Cinderella-like, into trattorias and ristorantes. Which is why I was happy to find Nino's Restaurant, owned and run by five brothers from Montenegro, where the northern Italian food is unfussy, affordable and full of heart.

description: REAL estate specialists find it discomfiting to think about, but they agree that last September's attack in New York strengthened, for a time, the commercial real estate market in New Jersey. title: Music; Walton, at 100, Is Winning the Race
description: THE tourists on Ischia, a small volcanic island northwest of Capri in the Bay of Naples, tend to be elderly Germans, there for mud-bath treatments. The Austrian maestro Herbert von Karajan was a devotee. And that would exhaust the island's claim to musical fame but for the existence of a fabulous exotic garden -- ''domain'' might be a better word -- that runs in terraces along a valley. Densely planted, and cooled by rock pools, waterfalls and fountains, it offers panoramic views that stretch from the extinct volcano (or so everyone hopes) out to the sea.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ''HE doesn't even belong to the Harvard Club,'' one of the posh New York Setons says in George Cukor's HOLIDAY (1938), making it clear that Johnny Case (Cary Grant) is not the right man for his cousin Julia. Johnny doesn't even know that Julia (Doris Nolan) is filthy rich until he visits her at home, which is a marble-and-pillars mansion with grand staircases and an elevator. Some of Johnny's ideas don't go over well with his staid prospective in-laws. He plans, for instance, to make some money fast, then retire young to enjoy life as a permanent holiday. Luckily for him, one Seton sees life the same way: Linda (Katharine Hepburn), Julia's unhappy but forceful older sister -- Tuesday at 6 p.m. on TCM.

title: In Case of Emergency, A Map for Long Beach
description: DURING Labor Day's torrential rains, Mindy Ferrentino, who lives in a Long Beach high rise, drove inland to go shopping. Because Lido Boulevard, the main road leading to Loop Parkway, was flooded, she had to drive down the middle of the road, right on the yellow divider. The day brought sporadic weather-related power failures, she later learned. The washed-out road and power interruptions made her wonder: in the event of a hurricane, how could nearly 48,000 people on this barrier island, extending from Point Lookout to Atlantic Beach, evacuate?

With the package tours no longer crowding the narrow streets, Prague is suddenly more accessible to independent travelers, who will find a warm welcome from a city desperate to attract visitors.

title: Holding the Bag in Italy
description: WHEN Marco Polo returned home to Venice from China in 1295, his journal was crammed with tales of golden palaces, silk brocades, exotic spices, astrology. Somehow, he missed the big story: tea. It's been the great Italian blind spot ever since. The culture that gave us Dante and Michelangelo and a credible view of the solar system routinely botches what I consider -- no, what I know -- to be the elixir of life, the most soul-satisfying beverage of all time.

''I have this thing in my hand,'' he said. ''A guy comes up: 'John, congratulations!' 'Thanks.' Then he says, 'Hey man, where's Chrissy?' ''

title: Film; An Experiment Goes Very Awry
description: IN ''Das Experiment,'' a psychological thriller from Germany opening Wednesday in New York, a journalist played by Moritz Bleibtreu (the boyfriend in ''Run Lola Run'') goes undercover and answers an ad for male volunteers to act as the guards and inmates of a mock prison for a two-week behavioral research project. Assured that there will be no violence, the men are told that in exchange for being well paid, they will be locked in for the duration. Needless to say, the experiment spins out of control, and violence becomes the order of the day.

That left the trainer Michael Gorham with one option: come up with a new plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHEWS, DEBORAH
description: MATHEWS-Deborah. 52, of New York City and previously, Baton Rouge and New Orleans. Of cancer, July 29, 2002. Passionate advocate and agent of professional dancers, producer of Broadway and Off Broadway plays, social worker and counselor who most recently was developing a project to nurture the emotional health of children through movement. Survived by two sisters, Sidney Gay Mathews, Santa Barbara; and Rivette Rae Mathews, New Orleans; an aunt, Pauline Ahrens, Metairie; a niece, Claudia Shultz, New York City; and two step brothers, William Mattox II, Baton Rouge; and Robert Mattox, Boston. title: Baseball Without Metaphor
description: What amazes me is the contempt with which players and management treat the fans. To the extent that fans ''matter'' (not very much), they are seen as a leverage point for commercial or franchise value. By insisting on so little and putting up with so much, the fans ensure that baseball will not pay more for their support than their lowest price.

title: Music This Week; A Cool Display Of Vocal Fireworks
description: In the pop music world, album release dates are anticipated and hyped; in classical music, they often pass nearly unnoticed. But last week, Harmonia Mundi France released a classical album that truly deserved the term ''long-awaited.'' ''Arias for Farinelli,'' showcasing the Alaskan mezzo-soprano Vivica Genaux and the Belgian early-music conductor Ren Jacobs, came out in Europe in April to huge acclaim, generating eager anticipation of its release in the United States.

title: Banning Drivers' Cellphones
description: Governor McGreevey said last week that he favored a law banning the use of handheld cellphones while driving and promised he would sign one by the end of January. If that happens, New Jersey would be the second state after New York to enact a such a ban. But drivers still could chat on hands-free devices under the proposed measure being drafted by the state Department of Transportation, he said. And motorists still could use hand-held phones to make 911 and emergency calls. A transportation spokesman said staff members were studying the year-old New York statute, which includes penalties of $100 to $500, and measures that have been introduced by New Jersey legislators in the past. George James

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAHAM, ALEXANDER
description: ABRAHAM-Alexander. The President, Board of Trustees, staff, and extended family of Dana-Farber Cancer Institute mourn the passing on August 25 of our esteemed friend, colleague, and benefactor, Alexander Abraham. Mr. Abraham's ardent belief in the possibility of progress in childhood cancer research being conducted at DanaFarber inspired his fellow trustees. His generosity was instrumental in advancing our mission to lead the way in researching, treating, and preventing cancer. The Institute will be forever grateful to Mr. Abraham for his foresight and generosity in establishing the David Abraham Clinical Investigators Program and the David Abraham Fellowship Fund. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. Edward J. Benz, Jr., M.D. President, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute

title: Suzanne Lopez, Keith Prisco

title: Like the Song, Love the Car
description: ROCK 'n' roll was born in an automobile and given its sound by the road. Fifty years ago, Ike Turner composed ''Rocket 88,'' the closest thing to a ''first'' rock 'n' roll song on which historians can agree, inside a Buick carrying the Kings of Rhythm through the Mississippi Delta. En route, the band's amplifier fell from the car's roof to the pavement. The damaged speaker gave the song, a paean to Oldsmobile's high-compression engine, a muffled tone that would become the signature of early rock records produced by Sam Phillips for the Chess and Sun labels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LING, VIVIAN Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBIN, RHEA
description: WERBIN - Rhea. Passed away August 27. At the age of nine, after the violent deaths of her mother and siblings in the pogroms, she escaped Russia with her sister, Gussie. Arriving in the U.S., she lived with friends and also confronted language barriers. Despite these obstacles and an era that was not conducive she became a successful businesswoman and manufacturer while raising two children alone. After running ''Baby Headwear'' for many years, she established a plant in the Dominican Republic. Upon retiring she worked for the NYC Dept. of Social Services assisting the elderly.

title: Good Students and Good Citizens

title: 'Why Terrorism Works'

The next chapter shows how the international community, and especially the United Nations and our European allies, have refused to follow these obvious rules since at least 1968, and in fact have deliberately violated them, thereby encouraging increased resort to terrorism, both in frequency and in severity.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) At the center of McCullough's rich portrait is John Adams's devotion to his wife, Abigail, and hers to him, a deep connection revealed in their large correspondence over several decades. This humanizing portrait, which won a Pulitzer Prize and was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2001, also makes the case that the feisty, talkative Adams -- not Jefferson -- was in many ways the pre-eminent statesman of his time. ''The wonderfully congenial subject of McCullough's carefully researched, lovingly written biography is . . . consistently companionable,'' Pauline Maier said in these pages. In Jefferson's Pillow: The Founding Fathers and the Dilemma of Black Patriotism (Beacon, $14), Roger Wilkins, a distinguished journalist and a scion of an eminent African-American family, weaves personal experience with scholarship to explore the profound implications of the founders' inability to muster the moral and intellectual courage to free their slaves. Wilkins ''offers an extraordinarily thoughtful and illuminating meditation on American history,'' Ira Berlin wrote here last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACS, MARIAN CLAIRE
description: ISAACS-Marian Claire. Died on August 13, 2002, after a long illness, at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. She served at Memorial for 41 years as an attending physician of the Renal Service of the Department of Medicine. Esteemed as an expert on kidney function, dialysis and electrolyte management, she displayed a devotion to her patients that was widely noted by her colleagues. Her great-grandfather, Abraham Isaacs, established himself in Leadville, Colorado during the mining boom of the 1880's, as proprietor of a general hardgoods store. Dr. Isaacs was born in Leadville in 1926, shortly before her family moved to Denver. She studied medicine at the University of Colorado and became a resident of New York City in 1952. She was well loved for her gentleness, insight and generosity of spirit. She is survived by her sister, Edith Posel of NYC, her brother Ernest Isaacs of Sacramento, CA., and her niece and nephews, Rebecca Isaacs of Santa Monica, CA, Joseph Isaacs of Sacramento, CA, Benjamin Posel of NYC, and Daniel Posel of Seattle, WA.
