description: It is a new role for him, to be the savior of a franchise that has not made the playoffs in five seasons, to make people take the Rangers seriously again. Bobby Holik, coming off 10 hard-nosed and often triumphant years on the other side of the Hudson, seems ready for the challenge.

title: Corrections
description: An illustrated timeline last Sunday about the history of espionage misstated the date of Alger Hiss's conviction for perjury. Hiss was convicted in 1950, not 1951. The piece also omitted attribution for the suggestion that documents supporting Hiss's innocence were covered up. This was the position of Hiss and his supporters in a petition to set aside his conviction. The petition was denied and later appeals failed.

title: Laura O'Donnell and Quinn Fanning
description: Laura Elizabeth O'Donnell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. O'Donnell of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Quinn Paul Fanning, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Fanning, who lived in Chicago. The Rev. E. William Beauchamp, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Assumption in Osterville, Mass.

title: Dance; Putting a Label on Him Doesn't Get Any Easier
description: JOHN KELLY was a student at the Parsons School of Design in the late 70's when he saw Marcel Carn's classic French film ''Les Enfants du Paradis'' (''The Children of Paradise'') for the first time. A friend had, as he put it, ''dragged me to it,'' and he was transfixed by its depiction of a teeming world of actors, mimes and low-lifes in 1830's Paris. Mr. Kelly immediately felt a connection with its central character, the heartsick and brilliant mime Baptiste, in his billowing white costume.

title: 'This Thing of Ours'
description: Midway through the first season of The Sopranos , the protagonist`s psychotherapist, Jennifer Melfi, has a not-exactly-traditional family dinner with her middle-class Italian parents, son, and ex-husband Richard La Penna ["The Legend of Tennessee Moltisanti"/1008]. She lets slip (hmm!) that one of her patients is a mobster, much to Richard`s consternation. An activist in Italian anti-defamation politics, he is incensed at the opprobrium the Mafia has brought on all Italians. What is the point, he protests, of trying to help such a person? In a subsequent scene he contemptuously dismisses Jennifer and her profession for purveying "cheesy moral relativism" in the face of evil. His challenge boldly proclaims what until then has been implicit: the richest and most compelling piece of television-no, of popular culture-that I`ve encountered in the past twenty years is a meditation on the nature of morality, the possibility of redemption, and the legacy of Freud.

title: On Death, Life's Cruelest Lesson
description: NOT all the flowers and poetry and memorials of the last few weeks have been for victims of the Sept. 11 attacks. Here and there have been reminders that loss doesn't have to occur on a catastrophic scale to have a profound effect on a family, a school, a town.

title: A New Garden at Windsor
description: A new garden filled with roses, flowering shrubs and trees has been created at Windsor Castle, 21 miles west of London.

title: Lost to 9/11, Names and Places From Across the State
description: THE terrorist attacks were a year ago, but it was not until Aug. 19 that the New York City medical examiner's office released the first official list of the dead. It put the Connecticut dead from the attacks at 65.

title: Requiring Well Testing
description: Under regulations issued by the state Department of Environmental Protection last week, state homeowners with private wells will be required to have their wells tested and the results shared with buyers before their properties can be sold. The department said the regulations could affect almost 30,000 real estate sales a year. Tests must be conducted for nitrates, iron, coliform, Ph and lead. Wells will also be tested for arsenic, mercury or radium, depending on the county. All results will be sent to the department, which will construct a database of drinking water quality. There are about 390,000 private wells in the state, according to the department. John Holl

title: Campaign Season; Leading the Majority, Leading the Minority
description: Much of the talk about a change in control of the House centers on hypothetical situations featuring the likes of a Speaker Richard A. Gephardt, for example. But what of Speaker J. Dennis Hastert? Would he serve as minority leader in the event Republicans lost the House?

title: Karachi Raid Provides Hint Of Qaeda's Rise in Pakistan
description: In the predawn darkness on Wednesday, about 20 intelligence officers and policemen who had been staking out an apartment building in a middle-class neighborhood here intercepted a man when he emerged, and interrogated him. He and his family lived in one apartment, the man said. Heavily armed Islamic militants were in another.

title: Campaign Season; Farm-State Drought Can Dry Up Votes, Too
description: It rained some in South Dakota in recent days, but not enough to extinguish the drought or its prominence as an issue in the tight Senate race there and in other farm states.

title: An Insurance Door Opens, but Only by a Crack
description: THE trade bill signed last month by President Bush contained some good news for workers who lose their jobs each year because of foreign competition: a 65 percent tax credit to help cover health insurance premiums.

title: With White House Approval, E.P.A. Pollution Report Omits Global Warming Section
description: For the first time in six years, the annual federal report on air pollution trends has no section on global warming, though President Bush has said that slowing the growth of emissions linked to warming is a priority for his administration.

title: Editorial Observer; History Lessons for Wartime Presidents and Their Generals
description: Among the indelible images of American wartime presidents, two stand out in this moment of talk of a war against Iraq. During the Vietnam War, President Lyndon B. Johnson, a man with little military expertise, obsessively approved bombing targets himself, fearing that an aggressive air war would provoke Russian or Chinese counterattacks. Johnson's famous caution helped create a widely accepted myth: that Vietnam was lost in part because of artificial restraints by a tremulous commander in chief, who had no business second-guessing his military leaders that way.

title: Tie Me Up, Tie Me Down: Shoes Get Naughty
description: FARIDAH CRISPE cruised the shoe department at Jeffrey New York in downtown Manhattan last week, considering two options: a pair of shapely Manolo Blahnik lace-up boots, or a high-heeled sandal by Chlo, racily decorated with a latticework of straps. ''With shoes like this, I think in terms of comfort and investment,'' Mrs. Crispe said.

title: Nascar-Lovin
description: Lincoln Davis is running for Congress in central Tennessee, in the district where they've been distilling Jack Daniel's whiskey since 1866. Davis is a Democrat, and he knew from the start that if he was going to win the race for an open seat, he was going to have to get past the wine-and-cheese stereotype that Democrats carry in rural America.

Henes, D.V.M., Pet Photography, where he combines his love of animals with his passion for photography. But Maryland, the defending A.C.C. champion, seems not to have gotten the message. Fifth-ranked Florida State handed Maryland its second loss of the season tonight, 37-10, at Byrd Stadium in front of a sold-out crowd.

description: ROBERT BISHOP grew up next door to one of Australia's immigrant hostels after World War II and remembers marveling at the creative talents of his Spanish, Greek and Latvian neighbors. Many of the women were educated professionals, a rarity in those days, and their children almost always rose to the top of their classes.

The huddle of sleek, abstract trees is the focal point of the Kaufmann Conference Center, designed by the renowned Finnish architect Alvar Aalto in 1964 for the Institute of International Education at 809 United Nations Plaza. Visits to these woods require an invitation.

Expect loads of black currant and the scent and flavor of crushed berries. On chilly nights, it can be comforting. This Spanish red is exceptionally popular at Martin Brothers, 2781 Broadway (107th Street), Manhattan. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

description: A new Pataki administration study acknowledges widespread failings at New York's adult homes for the mentally ill, concluding that the state is allowing some of its most vulnerable citizens to be exploited in a system plagued by inept, wasteful and fraudulent services.

title: Saying Summer One Day And Fall the Next

While shoppers once puzzled over how to wear boiled wool in 80-degree heat, designers this year have eliminated much of the seasonal guesswork by integrating warm-weather style elements, like pale colors and relaxed cuts, into lightweight cool-weather looks. Here are some of the season's best transition pieces, built to stand up to fall -- and even serve double duty come spring.

Its owners, Kathy and Michael DiBiase, call it a cafe, and for once that all-purpose noun has real meaning.

description: DEBRA LOBEL, a lawyer, and Beverly Dashevsky, a retired teacher and a literacy volunteer, have been life partners since 1958. In their wills they name each other as beneficiaries. They jointly own a house and an office building, both in East Hampton. And Ms. Lobel said that in case of serious illness, their families have agreed that each woman would be the sole decision maker for the other.

description: In the Taliban's scheme of things, the only true beauty lay in the contemplation of God. So, no question, the Taliban mullahs with their hair-shirt version of Islam, chased from power 10 months ago by American bombing, would take a wretched view of what has been happening lately on Fridays in Kabul and many other Afghan cities and towns.

Halloween witches have already appeared in the local supermarket, and the first Christmas catalogs came in August. But what do you do with a pool? You can't hide it away in the garage like a barbecue, or put it out for garbage collection like a broken lawn chair.

title: Lisbon-to-Algarve Road Is Now Complete
description: The final 39-mile stretch of the A2 highway has recently opened, linking Lisbon and the Algarve region along Portugal's coast. At the top speed limit of 75 miles an hour, the 147-mile journey through the wheat fields, cork forests and olive groves of the Alentejo region now takes just a little over two hours in normal traffic on the mostly straight four-lane highway. Previously, before the final section was built, the trip lasted twice as long on a narrow, winding and sometimes perilous road.

The tanks in this laboratory hold cells from more than 30,000 people with a family history of genetic disease including autism, schizophrenia and diabetes.

So it's not surprising that the Mercedes-Benz G500 S.U.V. has found a happy home here. Los Angeles practically created the urban S.U.V. craze in the aftermath of the 1992 riots, when navigating the city in an armored personnel carrier of the mind suddenly seemed prudent and, once the dust had settled, roguishly stylish.

title: Police Shooting Victims
description: State and local police officers in New Jersey shot and killed 54 people and wounded 128 between 1996 and 2001. The overwhelming majority, 84 percent of the victims, were black or Hispanic, 70 percent of the officers involved were white, and nearly half of the shootings occurred in Essex County. The statistics, which appeared last week by The Star-Ledger, have prompted the state attorney general's office to start a review of the guidelines for police use of deadly force. Two police officers involved in shootings were indicted. Of the people fatally shot, all the white victims were armed, while half of the black victims were armed. Karen DeMasters

title: Indian Ritual Taken to a Wider Audience
description: DOZENS of seekers sat in a circle around the fire pit, knee to knee on the ground under a low, dome-shaped tent fashioned out of sticks and heavy blankets. As a medicine man chanted and banged on a drum, other participants brought glowing-hot rocks into the tent, which was then sealed shut. Once the tent was pitch-dark, the medicine man, Charles Thom Sr., sprinkled herbs onto the rocks and poured water on them, filling the tent with a heat as intense as any sauna, but somehow redoubled by the aroma of the secret herbs.

Within the past few months Madonna, Gwyneth Paltrow and Matt Damon have underscored the point by turning so-so plays into box-office successes, and Woody Harrelson and Kyle MacLachlan will be doing the same till Oct. 27 at the Comedy Theater with John Kolvenbach's ''On an Average Day,'' about two psychologically damaged brothers in upstate New York. But who would have thought that, during a fall that will also bring Judi Dench, Sean Bean, Maggie Smith, Elaine Stritch, John Hurt, Michael Gambon and Brenda Blethyn to London, the autograph hounds are most likely to be crowding around the National Theater's stage door?

title: Dude, Where's My Car?
description: In the year I've been driving my beat-up '78 ''Tuscan Villa'' Chevy Nova and the two decades it has been in the family, I have seen only one like it. And it was up on blocks in the backyard of a chop shop. My Nova, I figured, was mine and mine alone. So how that day there came to be two Novas, same year, same toffee hue, parked in the same row of a giant lot of the Clearspring strip mall confounds me. And I never did figure out how my key started the ignition of the other Nova, but how the cops eventually got involved, that I can tell you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLY, MARION
description: DONNELLY - Marion. A member of The New York Times Editorial Department for 17 years, who retired in 1994 for a second career as a charity volunteer, died on Wednesday, September 11th, 2002, at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 71, and lived in Manhattan. The cause of death was lung cancer, her son Victor Van Carpels said. Ms. Donnelly was on the original staff of New York Magazine in 1968, rising from ''a Lily Tomlin switchboard,'' as she called it, to the position of Publicity Manager. ''Before that, Mom worked for a couple of defunct publications, including Look Magazine and the New York Herald Tribune. She liked to joke about folding shops. She was one of the ones who jumped ship at New York Magazine when Rupert Murdoch bought the magazine in 1977.'' She landed at The New York Times Magazine, serving as Secretary to the Deputy Editor and later for editors in the Style and Travel sections. In retirement, she took on a number of volunteer jobs, working for the Housing Works and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Thrift Shops as well as the Museum of Modern Art and the New York Public Library. A trained hospice worker, Ms. Donnelly volunteered at the Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Medical Center. She was honored by the Retired Community Service Society of New York, among other organizations, for her volunteer work. Her choice of service often reflected a personal loss: her second husband, Gerard E. Leys, died in 1983 of myeloma and her son, Thomas Van Carpels, died of AIDS complications in 1988. Born on March 3rd, 1931, in New York's Hell's Kitchen, Ms. Donnelly graduated from the Abbey Business Institute and attended Fordham University and the Arts Students League. She is survived by her son, Victor Van Carpels, her daughter-in-law, Margaret King, and her grandson, William Van Carpels, all of Ulster Park, NY. William's mother, Rebecca Fall, and her husband, Myron Baker, formed a special part of her family. Her wit, devotion to family and friends, and generosity of spirit will be missed by many. Friends are invited to share in a celebration of her life to be held at her home on Saturday, September 21st, from 1 to 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Save the Strays, the Jacob Perlow Hospice and Housing Works. For further information and to RSVP, please contact Joan Dworkin at 212-661-0006 or Deborah Harkins at 212-744-2109.

title: Bear Warnings
description: The state last week warned residents of northwestern New Jersey that the summer drought has reduced food supplies for black bears and has advised them to bear-proof their homes. The lack of rain has reduced the number of acorns and other food sources and is partly blamed for bears breaking into 46 homes, mostly in Warren and Sussex Counties, as of the end of last month. Homeowners and campers are warned to keep all food and garbage secured and to remove bird feeders. Information on black bears and how to avoid encounters is at www.state.nj.us/dep/fgw. Karen DeMasters

title: Segregation Revisited
description: This fall, the public schools in Charlotte, N.C., are more segregated than they have been in a quarter-century. In a controversial decision, a federal judge, Robert D. Potter, ruled that no present-day racial inequities were the result of deliberate segregation and set into motion the end of busing. The revamped neighborhood-school plan has produced many schools notably more segregated by race and income. The prospect of resegregation brought back memories for the graduates of Charlotte's Second Ward High School, which was one of the most beloved institutions in the black community from the time it opened in 1923 to the day it was bulldozed in 1970. Recently, former students held their annual reunion; amid their celebration of their all-black alma mater, they took time to discuss the achievements and shortcomings of desegregation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKER, GABRIEL WARD
description: LASKER-Gabriel Ward. 90, of Beverly Hills, Michigan, died August 27, of complications of kidney disease. Dr. Lasker was Emeritus Professor of Anatomy and Adjunct Professor of Anthropology at Wayne State University in Detroit. He was known for his work expanding the study of surnames and pedigrees into the realm of human genetics. With an international reputation in physical and biological anthropology, he was honored by the American Association of Physical Anthropology with its hightest recognition, The Darwin Award and by the Human Biology Association with The Franz Boas Award. He was a member of the Wayne State University Academy of Scholars and in 2000 recieved an Honorary Doctorate of Science from the Univerity of Turin, Italy. He was a conscientious objector during WWII and remained committed to involvement with peace organizations for the rest of his life. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Dr. Bernice (Bunny) Kaplan, his sons, Robert and Edward, his daughter, Anne, and her son Wilson. A Memorial is planned for 2 PM, October 20, at the Birmingham Temple, 28611 West 12 Mile Road, Farmington, MI. For those who wish, tributes may be sent to the Southern Poverty Law Center, The Council for a Livable World, Union of Concerned Scientists, The War Resistors League, or a charity of your choice.

title: 'One Man's Bible'
description: It was not that he didn`t remember he once had another sort of life. But, like the old yellowing photograph at home, which he did not burn, it was sad to think about, and far away, like another world that had disappeared forever. In his Beijing home, confiscated the police, he had a family photo left his dead father: it was a happy gathering, and everyone in the big family was present. His grandfather who was still alive at the time, his hair completely white, was reclined in a rocking chair, paralyzed and unable to speak. He, the eldest son and eldest grandson of the family, the only child in the photo, was squashed between his grandparents. He was wearing slit trousers that showed his little dick, and he had on his head an American-style boat-shaped cap. At the time, the eight-year War of Resistance against the Japanese had just ended, and the Civil War had not properly started. The photograph had been taken on a bright summer day in front of the round gateway in the garden, which was full of golden chrysanthemums and purple-red cockscombs. That was what he recalled of the garden, but the photo was water-stained and had turned a grayish yellow. Behind the round gateway was a two story, English-style building with a winding walkway below and a balustrade upstairs. It was the big house he had lived in. He recalled that there were thirteen people in the photograph - an unlucky number - his parents, his paternal uncles and aunts, and also the wife of one of the uncles. Now, apart from an aunt in America and himself, all of them and the big house had vanished from this world.

title: Buddhist Treasures On Display in Honolulu
description: One of the most comprehensive collections of Shingon Buddhist objects ever assembled outside Japan is on display at the Honolulu Academy of Arts through Nov. 10. Drawn exclusively from the denomination's headquarters at Mount Koya, known to the Japanese as Koyasan, a shrine complex in south-central Japan, ''Sacred Treasures of Mount Koya: The Art of Japanese Shingon Buddhism'' spans nine centuries and includes 91 sculptures, paintings, textiles and cosmic diagrams called mandalas, important meditative devices. Many of the objects have never been seen abroad, and two are designated Japanese national treasures.

title: QUICK BITE/Highland Park; Forget the Spelling, and Scoop the Ice Cream
description: As the summer winds down and the days and nights cool, the glass-enclosed counters filled with chocolates from places like Belgium, Germany and Italy will begin to rival the ice cream at the Corner Confectionary. But whatever the climate, ice cream is popular all year at the 78-year-old shop at Raritan and South Third Avenues. Even in the dead of winter, customers dip into their ice cream treats, although not always at the outdoor benches and tables that have been popular these last few months. Among the customers at the shop recently was 5-year-old Minerva Safir, and her father, Ken. ''I promised her if she ate her whole dinner, I'd take her out for ice cream,'' Mr. Safir said. For $5.65, you can get a banana split, and for $3 or $3.75, an ice cream soda. The dcor inside consists of wood paneling made of South American mahogany and Victorian-style ceiling fans and simulated gas lights. The shop was originally the Third Avenue Sweetshop when it was founded in 1924. When Laura Levitt and her sister, Emilia Palacio, bought it in 1992, in the window was a sign saying ''The Corner Confectionary.'' And so it remains, complete with that ''a'' (it's usually ''confectionery'') as in, ''a'' double-dip cone, please. Norm Oshrin

title: Ideas & Trends: Theology and History; Catholics, Jews and the Work of Reconciliation
description: AT a time when religious conflict is on a lot of people's minds, Catholics and Jews have taken another a little-noticed step toward togetherness.

title: Music; A Sincere Approach To Western Swing
description: Perhaps the first thing one notices when listening to the Hot Club of Cowtown is its lack of irony, self-consciousness and forced hipness in embracing a style of music that so easily lends itself to such things. On the trio's fourth album, ''Ghost Train'' (Hightone), the band not only cavorts with string-band jazz and western swing, but it also performs the Aerosmith song ''Chip Away the Stone'' in this style -- with tongue firmly out of cheek.

title: Radium Cleanup
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency last week announced a $10 million appropriation to finish cleaning up radioactive soil at 21 home sites in Bloomfield, Montclair, West Orange and Glen Ridge. The U.S. Radium Corporation plant in Orange, which produced glow-in-the-dark products like luminous paint and watch dials from 1915 to 1926, contaminated the soil, which was later used to fill in low-lying areas in Essex County. The radiation was revealed in 1983, and $143 million has been spent on the sites since 1991. Jane Kenny, regional administrator for the E.P.A., said hopes were to have the work completed by the end of 2004. John Holl

title: The Curse of the Dubya
description: THIS has been a dreadful year for the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average, for example, is down 17 percent since Jan. 1. The reasons given for such dismal performance are familiar by now: terrorism, corporate and Wall Street corruption, the business cycle, which demanded a downturn after the long years of growth.

title: Theater; What Euripides Knew About Refugees: Everything
description: DRESSED in an orange prison jumpsuit, a head of state is brought in chains to a microphone behind a clear plexiglass shield. An old woman in a black shawl accuses him of atrocities that have turned her grandchildren into homeless refugees, but he looks past her with a patronizing smile and justifies his actions as a necessary defense against blood feuds that began before he was born.

title: Stealing Home
description: You will doubtless get letters lamenting Lisa Gabriele's morality, or lack thereof (Lives, Sept. 1). They'll wax wroth at how she still wears her swag among ''the rabble who were probably swindled by Enron,'' as if burglarizing trendy clothes from department stores helps right the balance. They'll be infuriated by her smug tone.

An improved system has nearly doubled the number of lights -- bringing it to 600 energy-saving spotlights -- that illuminate the arches and the previously hard-to-see travertine decorations on the upper outside walls.

title: Art/Architecture; For Faces Almost Lost to History, a Chance to Speak
description: THE 19th and 20th centuries saw the invention of a lot of new ways to do away with people. But the same 200 years ensured that more people might be remembered, thanks to new recording devices, photography most of all. Many who might once have completely disappeared from view now leave behind visible traces of themselves. But what do these images signify if the people who knew what the photographs and other documents meant die before passing on the knowledge?

title: Baseball Without Metaphor

I wrote to Lamb, and told him the address was `22 Lisson Grove, North, at Rossi's, halfway up, right hand corner'. Humankind, T. S. Eliot reminds us, cannot bear very much reality, and for those seeking escape from this week's reality, the season premiere tonight of ''The Sopranos,'' however dark and bloody it may be, will serve as a welcome diversion simply because it is fictional.

title: A Whole New Ballgame
description: At our local high school, girls' sports have proved so popular and successful that we've run out of locker rooms, and this fall we need to float a bond to build new ones. Our girls don't just win championships; some of them have so thoroughly embraced the jock ethos that they behave as stupidly as the boys. A year ago, all the seniors on the field-hockey team were suspended for devising a preseason hazing ritual that involved duct-taping the mouths of the sophomores, locking the girls in the bathroom of the team bus and then peeling off the tape and requiring them to fellate bananas in public. All this because of Title IX, the landmark 1972 law that required universities and colleges to grant equal financing and resources to male and female athletics. (We also have Title IX to thank, at least indirectly, for the WNBA, for the gold medals won by our national women's hockey and soccer teams and, on a grimmer note, for the fact that girls, just like boys, can die while playing football.)

That, the reporter says, is how he ended up in Karachi, Pakistan, interviewing two members of Al Qaeda's hierarchy who said that they had planned the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

The Sahara is usually seen as a cultural divide in Africa, separating the Arabized north from the rest of the continent. But in Mamar Kassey's music there were elements from all sides, a legacy of trans-Saharan exchanges and of ethnic groups spread across borders.

title: The Glow Of Youth At Toronto Film Festival
description: The dour narrative twists that whip through many of the films shown at this year's Toronto International Film Festival are undeniable. One of the most compelling of them is ''The Magdalene Sisters,'' from the actor turned writer and director Peter Mullan. A period drama, it is set in the 1960's in an Irish convent where young women who are thought to be irredeemable sinners -- they've engaged in premarital sex or even borne children out of wedlock -- are confined. The punishments inflicted by the sisters running the convent are so rococo this picture could be called ''The Shawshank Nunnery.'' Sister Bridget (Geraldine McEwan), the head nun and de facto warden, is a blandly smiling disciplinarian under a habit of steel who hoards the money the convent earns by taking in laundry. Mr. Mullan's direction isn't glib or overstated, and the reward is a brace of memorable performances by the girls, played by Anne-Marie Duff, Eileen Walsh, Mary Murray and Nora-Jane Noonem who has the vivid beauty of Gene Tierney and the charismatic pugnacity of Jimmy Cagney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COX, WILLIAM W.
description: COX-William W. Lawyer for the United Nations and former resident of Manhattan, died August 18, 2002 at The Quadrangle in Haverford, PA. He was 88. A Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Ohio Wesleyan University, he earned a law degree from Columbia University in 1939, where he was an editor of the Law Review. After naval intelligence service in London during World War II, he worked for the United Nations until his retirement in 1974. His career spanned a broad range of service as UN lawyer in many of the world's hot spots during the late 1940's, 1950's and 1960's, including Vienna, Geneva, Bolivia, Jerusalem, Gaza, and the Congo. In later years, he served in a variety of deputy director positions at UN headquarters. He is survived by his wife of 56 years Nancy, whom he met in London during the war when they both worked in intelligence translating German documents. Other survivors include nieces Marguerite Bartlett and Barbara Prunty. No memorial service is planned. Memorial contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood, 810 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10019.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Home Health Aide Is Found Dead
description: A 51-year-old home health attendant was found dead from head wounds yesterday in the living room of a patient, an elderly Queens woman, the police said. They said the victim's body was discovered by the elderly woman's daughter, who entered the home, on 111th Street in Richmond Hill, on a routine visit to her mother. The victim, who the authorities declined to identify, was declared dead at the scene by officers who arrived at 5:50 p.m., responding to a call from the daughter. Investigators said the elderly woman the attendant cared for was on the home's second floor, and was not injured. They declined to describe the type of head wounds sustained by the home health attendant, pending analysis by the medical examiner. There were no arrests last night, and the case remained under investigation. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Support For Energy Efficiency
description: The City Council has approved a bill that would require the city to purchase energy-efficient products when possible. Those products typically use half as much electricity as standard appliances, Council officials said. But the Bloomberg administration opposes the bill, approved Thursday, saying that the requirement complicates an already complex purchasing system. It also opposes a bill passed by the Council that would suspend alternate-side parking rules on Purim, Ash Wednesday and Asian Lunar New Year. The administration said the city loses money on such suspensions. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMANN, FRANCIS G.
description: FRIEDMANN - Francis G. Died peacefully on Sunday, September 15, 2002. He is survived by his loving wife Rosalie Kennedy Friedmann, five children, Chris LeVeen, Jane Friedmann, Ann Schara, C. Edward Friedmann, Mary Leech and 11 grandchildren. Two brothers, Jack and Paul Friedmann, and one sister, Ruth Walsh, also survive. Frank attended Yorktown High School and graduated with honors in 1952 from Fordham University. He began a distinguished military career in November, 1942, as a master sergeant in the US Army Air Force. He was honorably discharged in January, 1946. In 1963 he became a sales manager with Chrysler Corporation, retiring in 1989. A Mass will be held Wednesday, September 18, 10 AM, Assumption Church, Peekskill, followed by interment at Assumption Cemetery. Visiting at Dorsey-Carlone Funeral Home, Peekskill, Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Donations to the Alzheimer's Association, 785 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Magazine Imitates a Catalog And Has a Charmed Life, So Far
description: Publishers of women's magazines realized years ago that an ad was more than an ad. Lush fashion advertisements, festooned with pretty models, name-brand photographers and soothing text, were an important part of a reader's relationship with a magazine.

description: A raven, as the legend goes, grew tired, and so dropped stones into the sea and created the Haida Gwaii islands to have a place to rest.

description: A flame-spewing rocket fills the theater's six-story screen, not quite life size but close enough for discomfort, its roars and rumbles shaking the high-back seats and vibrating the concrete superstructure.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Paul Donald was named to the new post of creative director at Sunset magazine, Menlo Park, Calif. He had been owner and creative director at Graphic Detail, San Francisco. Sunset is published by the Sunset Publishing Corporation, part of the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEWARK: GIRLS-ONLY PUBLIC SHELTER New Jersey will officially open its first girls-only shelter for delinquents, runaways and victims of abuse today. The 14-bed shelter, run by the Girls and Boys Town of New Jersey, was built with a $1 million donation from a Newark native and receives operating money from a federal grant. Between 1983 and 1993, the most recent data available, arrests of female juveniles rose 31 percent, compared with 21 percent for boys. More than half of female delinquents are victims of sexual abuse. Some are pregnant, and family dysfunction and drug abuse are common.   (AP)

title: China's Looming Catastrophe
description: China took some halting steps forward this month in its belated efforts to catch up with a widening H.I.V.-AIDS epidemic. Health officials raised their estimate of the number of Chinese infected with the AIDS virus, asked for international help in combatting the epidemic and pressed for a sharp reduction in the prices charged for drugs needed to treat these patients. China is also preparing a $90 million grant application to the new Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.

title: Korean Mob Briefly Detains U.S. Soldier After Subway Fight
description: An American soldier was briefly abducted Saturday evening by an angry mob and forced to make apologies in a university stadium here, after a scuffle that broke out over the deaths of two Korean girls in June, United States military officials said here today.

title: Bush Presses U.N. on Iraq and Congress on Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16  President Bush traveled today to Iowa, a politically crucial state, where he campaigned for loyal House Republicans and challenged the United Nations to do something about Saddam Hussein.

title: A Supreme Court Ruling Roils Death Penalty Cases

They pleaded guilty.

description: Treat Williams has rarely looked as comfortable as he does in ''Everwood,'' a promising new drama full of wry touches that has its debut tonight on WB. Now if he would just get rid of that annoying teenage son!

title: Why Iraq Will Defeat Arms Inspectors
description: Many voices are now calling for renewed United Nations inspections in Iraq. Some belong to critics of the Bush administration who are opposed to war. Others belong to those who favor war but see inspections -- which they fully expect to fail -- as the needed triggering event for war. Still other Iraq experts believe that Saddam Hussein himself will invite the inspectors back as a means of forestalling invasion if troops begin to move in his direction.

title: Dr. Robert Apfel, 59; Studied Physics of Liquids
description: Dr. Robert E. Apfel, a professor and engineer who designed pioneering studies that examined the physics of liquids and saw his results applied to areas as diverse as the manufacture of cosmetics and the cleanup of environmental oil spills, died Aug. 1 in New Haven. He was 59.

title: OPEC Feels Pressure to Produce More Oil
description: With the United States pushing for action against Iraq and oil prices rising on fears of war in the Persian Gulf, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is being pressed to pump more oil to soothe jittery markets.

description: CHARLES F. DOLAN, the chairman of Cablevision, and his son James F. Dolan, the chief executive, have been trying to persuade Wall Street of the viability of the company's plans for averting a projected $600 million cash shortfall. Last week, at the company's headquarters in Bethpage, N.Y., the Dolans discussed Cablevision's prospects. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

description: When the nation was observing the anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, a new Department of Homeland Security should have been one symbol of our determination to keep history from ever repeating itself. But legislation to create that department has been stuck in a dispute between the Bush administration and Senate Democrats. The major disagreements aren't unbridgeable. Time is running out on this Congressional season, and each side should start to give a little.

He was happy to oblige, though admittedly taken aback by the interest in his team such a long way from home.

The center will focus on journalism's efforts to offer information important to citizens at a time when there is intense economic competition for public attention.

You taught us how to lead our lives. We give to others as you gave to us. And for that we love you. And we will never forget you. Scott H. title: Relying On Saddam
description: George W. Bush has just placed his faith in Saddam Hussein's reliability. If the Iraqi tyrant remains true to form -- again misreading America's once-in-a-decade resolve -- Bush's recently evolved Four Resolution Strategy will bring about his overthrow.

title: Advice and Songs on Death Row, but No Easy Answers
description: When a serious new American opera is embraced by audiences, it's a rare and encouraging achievement. Since its premiere at the San Francisco Opera in the fall of 2000, ''Dead Man Walking,'' with music by Jake Heggie and a libretto by Terrence McNally, has been picked up by companies across the country. The elaborate staging presented by the New York City Opera on Friday night and directed by Leonard Foglia is a co-production with the Cincinnati Opera, Austin Lyric Opera, Michigan Opera Theater, Pittsburgh Opera, Baltimore Opera and Opera Pacific. As at the premiere, the audience responded with an enthusiastic standing ovation.

title: Student Skill Is Expected To Bolster Technology
description: Today's college students -- the first truly wired generation -- are far more Net-adept than the general population, and will graduate with expectations of a high-speed Internet world that could push the technology development of the workplace and the home, according to a new report.

title: Paying People to Work, but Not Enough to Live
description: Barbara Ehrenreich, in her book ''Nickel and Dimed,'' showed how difficult it is for a worker in the United States to survive on wages of $6 to $7 an hour. It's almost impossible. And if that worker has a family to support, forget about it. Which is why so many low-wage workers are toiling away at two jobs, or three, or even more.

title: U.S. Satellite Channel Offers Unfiltered Views From the Middle East

title: Wholesome Fries
description: It's hard to say whether the news that McDonald's will be making lower-fat French fries should be regarded as a public-health victory. We've come a long way from the World War II era, when federal officials were passing out copies of a food pyramid that gave butter a category all its own. But the fast-food addict who is thrilled by news of new, improved French fries is much like the smoker who believes switching to low-tar cigarettes is a sign of terrific progress.

title: Sixth Man Is Arrested In Terror Cell Inquiry
description: The F.B.I. has arrested a man of Yemeni descent, family and friends said, in addition to the five young American citizens charged in western New York on Saturday with providing ''material support'' for Qaeda terrorists.

title: Tyco Planning To Disclose Making Loans To Employees
description: Tyco International is planning to report as early as today that millions of dollars of previously undisclosed loans were made to dozens of employees and later forgiven on the instructions of the former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, said people who were briefed on the company's planned filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: After Two Days of Sloppiness On and Off Field, Yanks Win in Rain
description: The Yankees fell behind early yesterday against the Chicago White Sox, and they did not know how many chances they would have to come back. It was raining so hard, it seemed doubtful that the game would make it to the seventh-inning stretch.

title: Improvising Takes Off To the Envy Of Sparrows
description: Jennifer Monson is a downtown dancer and choreographer with the mysteriously purposeful look of a small animal intent on the task at hand. She has found the perfect medium in ''Bird Brain,'' a five-year project she describes as a navigational dance-touring program. Last year Ms. Monson started following the migration of whales and is continuing with birds, starting with ospreys.

title: For Officers, 4 Cases of Gunfire in 5 Hours
description: City police officers discharged their firearms on four separate occasions within about five hours late Saturday and early yesterday, hitting a man who fired at them in one of the shootings in Brooklyn, the authorities said. A woman was injured by a suspect's bullet in that case, the police said.

description: A man has been arrested and charged with strangling his mother last week in the home they shared in the Bronx, the police said yesterday. The motive for the killing is unclear, they said.

description: Most of us seem to want to experience an artistic creation as a finished product, not as a mound of raw materials. So an exhibition called ''Gobs of Paint'' or a concerto titled ''Loads of Notes'' would probably have some problems attracting an audience.

title: Collins Makes Accorsi Look Like a Genius
description: In the months following the Giants' Super Bowl XXXV appearance in 2001, the team's general manager, Ernie Accorsi, quietly signed a multiyear contract extension. In typical Giants fashion, the deal was kept hush-hush, shrouded in Pentagon-like secrecy. It was never reported in the news media and details of it leaked out only this past week.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mozart's Amoral Don and His Fate
description: There was a back-to-school sense about the season's first performance of ''Don Giovanni'' at New York City Opera on Saturday night; things were a little rusty. In the first act, it looked as if the singers and technical staff were still working out the blocking. The wooden motion and traces of uncertainty extended to the set: at one point a bridge, suspended from above, yoyoed up and down, seeking its supports, for a few moments after the singing had started.

title: Offense Catching Up To Patriots' Defense
description: The Patriots marched into Giants Stadium yesterday and looked like a band that had brought its musket, fife, drum, needle, hammer, drill and a huge dose of comic relief to boot.

title: A 60's-Style Retreat Faces Modern-Day Challenges
description: When a winter storm four years ago sent a hillside crashing into the mineral baths at Esalen, the coastal healing retreat that became synonymous in the 1960's with California's New Age consciousness, Eastern mysticism and self-awareness, the damage nearly doomed a way of life.

title: G.E. Says S.E.C. to Look Into Welch's Compensation Package
description: General Electric said today that it had agreed to cooperate with a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into a compensation agreement with its former chief executive, John F. Welch Jr., and that the company had acceded to a request by Mr. Welch to reduce the compensation he receives.

title: Shock Waves
description: Last month, New York City radio ''shock jocks'' Gregg (Opie) Hughes and Anthony Cumia were fired from WNEW after they staged and broadcast a stunt in which a couple had sex at St. Patrick's Cathedral. They were the latest radio personalities to be in trouble, but hardly the first. Here are some others who stirred the pot. MACAULAY CAMPBELL

title: Dr. Orvan W. Hess, 96, Dies; Developed Fetal Heart Monitor
description: Dr. Orvan W. Hess, an obstetrician and gynecologist who pioneered the development of the fetal heart monitor and was instrumental in the first successful clinical use of penicillin, died on Sept. 6 at Yale-New Haven Hospital, his family said. He was 96.

title: Howard Odum, 78, a Pioneering Voice on Ecology
description: Howard Thomas Odum, a founder of the modern science of ecology and an influential voice in the restoration of the Everglades, died on Wednesday at a hospice here. He was 78.

title: Why Japan Steps Gingerly in the Middle East
description: When OPEC ministers meet in Osaka on Thursday, the world will be reminded not just of the cartel's power on the global stage, but also the group's sway over its Japanese hosts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 14 about potential successors to Yasir Arafat and one on Aug. 15 about the indictment of Marwan Barghouti, a Palestinian leader who is being tried by Israel on murder charges, misstated the history of his arrests and deportation. He was first arrested in 1978 at the age of 19, not 16. He was deported once, in 1987, not twice, and returned to the West Bank in 1994, not 1993. (A reader reported the errors by e-mail on Sept. 2; this correction was delayed for fact checking.)

title: Accounts
description: * Value City Department Stores, Columbus, Ohio, to Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, for a new assignment, helping develop the brand images of the company's discount retail chains, which include DSW Shoe Warehouse, Filene's Basement, Value City and Schottenstein Stores. Spending was estimated at $50 million.

title: Infernal Machines
description: Christie Whitman is to be commended for bringing the nation's growing army of off-road vehicles under the regulatory umbrella of the Clean Air Act. Last Friday, the Environmental Protection Agency issued rules that for the first time will require significant reductions -- up to 50 percent by the year 2012 -- in pollutants like carbon monoxide from snowmobiles, swamp buggies, dune buggies and marine engines. One can only hope that her decision will cause some soul-searching by Interior Secretary Gale Norton, who has been a good deal more sympathetic toward off-road vehicles in general and snowmobiles in particular. Earlier this year, Ms. Norton angered environmentalists by reversing a Clinton-era plan to ban snowmobiles from Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks.

title: How Africa Landed Mother Lode Of Gold
description: Of all the gold that has ever been mined, 40 percent -- more than 40,000 tons -- has come from a single location in South Africa.

title: Sex in Unison: Just One Quirk Among Many
description: It takes a lot to make an I.R.S. agent the good guy in a series -- a lot of nerve, imagination and clever writing, a combination that sets the inspired ''Push, Nevada'' apart from every other new show of the season. This wry mystery with a difference begins when the agent, a meek-looking guy named Jim Prufrock, gets a misdirected fax and realizes that $1 million or so is missing from the Versailles Casino in the town of Push.

description: College students can recognize signs of stress like headache, upset stomach, fatigue and insomnia. But the worst, said Micaela Mendlow, a physics and music major at Amherst, are anxiety attacks, when it can seem difficult even to breathe.

title: 6 in Metropolitan Region Die of Food-Borne Illness
description: Six people in the New York City metropolitan area have died this summer of the food-related illness listeriosis, according to city health officials, who have issued warnings to the elderly; pregnant women; and those with weakened immune systems, advising them to avoid soft cheeses and deli meats.

description: Even in astronomy, there are some tough acts to follow. After parting a curtain to the universe with the Hubble Space Telescope and allowing millions to experience previously hidden wonders in space, what do you do for an encore?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Satellite Venture Talks
description: The French electronics group Alcatel said it had been approached by Europe's biggest aerospace company, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, or EADS, with a proposal to merge satellite businesses. The satellite industry is pressed to consolidate as telecommunications companies, seeking to cut costs, order fewer broadcast satellites. Alcatel said contacts, which were reported in The Wall Street Journal, are in a preliminary stage. Alcatel builds satellites for commercial, military, and scientific use. EADS owns Europe's biggest satellite manufacturer, Astrium, and a stake in Arianespace, the rocket launching group. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Israeli preparations for a possible new attack on Iraq misstated the reason United Nations weapons inspectors left Iraq in 1998. They departed in advance of bombing raids by American and British forces because the United Nations feared that they might be harmed or taken hostage. They were not expelled.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: TWO MORE WEST NILE CASES: Two more cases of West Nile virus have been reported in the city, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced yesterday. A 59-year-old woman from the Bronx and a 66-year-old man from Brooklyn are hospitalized in stable condition. Spraying has been scheduled in northeast Queens from 8 o'clock tonight to 2 a.m. at Flushing Airport, Kissena Park and Golf Course, Cunningham Park, Alley Pond Park and parts of Oakland Gardens, Hollis Hill, Bellaire, Queens Village, Bellrose, Floral Park and Glen Oaks. In Brooklyn, spraying has been scheduled from 8 p.m. Thursday to 2 a.m. at the Marine Park and Golf Course and parts of Sheepshead Bay, Gerritsen Beach, Marine Park, Flatlands, Georgetown, Mill Island, Mill Basin and Bergen Beach.    Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Hyundai Heir Declares Candidacy for South Korea's Presidency
description: Chung Mong Joon, the son of a billionaire tycoon who ran unsuccessfully for president of South Korea 10 years ago, declared his candidacy for president today on a platform that promises to continue President Kim Dae Jung's policy of reconciliation with North Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, HARRY JR.
description: SHERMAN-Harry Jr. On Friday, September 13, 2002 of North Caldwell, New Jersey. Husband of the late Betty Zimmer Sherman; mother of William R. of Maplewood, Catherine A. of North Caldwell and Susan J. of Landenberg, PA. Brother of Jeanne S. Neideck of Westchester, PA. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the memorial service at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 271 Roseland Avenue, Essex Fells, NJ. on Thursday at 1:00 P.M. Interment Fairmount Cemetery. Friends may call 10-12 at the O'Boyle Funeral Home, 309 Broad St., Bloomfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial donations be made to the Salvation Army, PO Box 3170 Union, N.J. 07083, attn: Nancy Wellbrook, Director of Development.

title: Challenge of the Unthinkable; John Adams Delivers a Commissioned Work on 9/11
description: Ever since Sept. 11 of last year, artists have wondered how to address a tragedy of such magnitude. The dangers of exploiting or aestheticizing grief seem painfully self-evident. Yet art must respond, and it has begun to do so.

title: A Need to Back Off From Emotion
description: Choreographers have begun in recent months to address the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. Michael Smuin turned to ritual in his new ''Stabat Mater,'' performed by Dance Theater of Harlem in the ''Evening Stars'' series at Battery Park on Saturday afternoon, a year to the day after the ballet troupe was to have performed in the series at the World Trade Center Plaza.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new Intel manufacturing process that would allow digital and analog technologies to be combined on a single chip misstated the precedent. The first such combination was created by National Semiconductor in the early 1970's, not by I.B.M. in 1998.

title: Throngs Rally Against Ukraine's Scandal-Scarred Leader
description: Thousands of protesters filled downtown Kiev's central square today to demand the resignation of Ukraine's scandal-ensnared president, Leonid Kuchma. An unrepentant Mr. Kuchma gave no hint of acceding to them.

title: Global Crossing Files Its Plan To Reorganize
description: Global Crossing Ltd. filed a reorganization plan yesterday that its new owners, an investor group from Hong Kong and Singapore, hope will allow it to become profitable after emerging from bankruptcy by the beginning of next year.

title: Nuclear Plant Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: G.E. Agrees to Purchase Leasing Unit of Deutsche
description: The General Electric Company announced today that it had agreed to buy the American leasing unit of Deutsche Bank for about $2.9 billion in cash and assumed debt, its second takeover of a European-owned financing business this month.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments To Produce New Chip
description: Texas Instruments, the big maker of chips for mobile phones and other electronic devices, is producing a new chip for video-conferencing equipment and set-top boxes that connect to the Internet. The company, based in Dallas, said yesterday that its new chip, which it calls a programmable 600-MHz ''digital media processor,'' offered improved performance over existing products and could run numerous multimedia formats, like MPEG-2, Microsoft's Windows Media 9 and MPEG-4. Pradeep Bardia, a worldwide marketing manager at Texas Instruments, said the processor had the highest performance in the industry and offered ''connectivity options that our customers need for reduced system cost and ease of development.'' Texas Instruments has been shoring up its video product line, adding chips for digital projectors, cameras and hand-held computers. The new chip makes video that is streamed to a computer or television appear smoother. Shares in Texas Instruments fell 73 cents, to $18.27. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Jiang to keep a decisive role in China, Lee Kuan Yew says
description: SINGAPORE:  Jiang Zemin will maintain a decisive role in China even after he gives up the title of president soon, according to Singapore's former prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Sharp Drop In Parkway Toll Summonses
description: The state police issued 86 percent fewer tickets to toll evaders on the Garden State Parkway in the first seven months of this year than in the same period last year, the State Department of Transportation said yesterday. From January through July, troopers issued 1,330 summonses, down from 9,558. Micah Rasmussen, a department spokesman, said the drop reflected fewer toll evaders. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Civic Virtues and the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN SLIPS. The dollar rose to its highest level against the yen in three months as traders speculated that Japan may sell currency to help spur economic growth. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.24 yen, from 121.73 on Friday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: News Groups Seek 9/11 Suspect's Filings
description: Several news organizations went to court today to try to force a federal judge to unseal court motions filed by Zacarias Moussaoui, the French national who is accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks and who is acting as his own lawyer.

title: Caution: That Dose May Be Too High
description: Twenty percent of prescription drugs are marketed with instructions for use that must later be corrected by the manufacturer, researchers say -- almost always to lower the recommended dose or to warn that the drug may be hazardous to certain patients.

title: One to Go On Johnson But No Rush
description: Robert A. Caro is easing himself back into harness. A restorative summer in Paris over, a warm-up spell in East Hampton done with, he's set to begin the fourth and, he swears, final volume of his biography of Lyndon Baines Johnson.

title: Ewing, Forever Linked to Knicks, Will Retire With All but a Title
description: For most of 17 seasons, Patrick Ewing would call it a night by standing up next to his locker-room cubicle and, after a night of banging with another 7-footer, gruffly proclaiming, ''I'm done, fellas.'' Today, the man whom Willis Reed called the greatest player in Knicks history is indeed done, retiring after an often-magnificent and often-maligned career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPLAS, ROMAIN JEAN BERNARD
description: dePLAS-Romain Jean Bernard. On September 14, 2002 at age 31. Beloved son of Pierre dePlas and Roberta Gootrad. Devoted brother of Joanna dePlas. Dearest grandson of Violet Butler Ledger. Memorial service on Thursday, September 19, at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at 73rd St., 3 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Museum of Modern Art to support the Internship Program in the Memory of Romain dePlas.

title: Some Things Considered
description: Every devoted radio listener has experienced it at some time or another -- a favorite station changes its format. The effect is unsettling. Last year, National Public Radio listeners in Lake Charles, La., experienced something even more alarming. The two affiliates that provided NPR programming were crowded off the airwaves by a new station owned by American Family Radio, a Christian broadcasting network owned by the Rev. Don Wildmon, based in Tupelo, Miss. The NPR affiliates were translator stations, low-power broadcasters retransmitting the signal from a bigger, more powerful station. The American Family Radio station applied for and received a license for a full-power station. That gave it priority, according to Federal Communications Commission rules.

title: States Ration Low Supplies Of 5 Vaccines for Children
description: States have begun rationing vaccines for children, including those for measles, rubella and chickenpox, and have reduced immunization requirements because of shortages, federal investigators said today. They also warned of future shortages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLING, WILLIAM HENRY
description: WELLING-William Henry. On September 14. Father of Marie and Donna. Visiting Monday, 2-5 and 7-9, at Andrett Funeral Home, Second Ave. and 21st St. Funeral Tuesday, 11:15, at St. Francis Xavier, 16th St. off 6th Ave.

title: Samsung Sees Strong Earnings Even as Chip Prices Decline
description: Executives of Samsung Electronics forecast today that the company's high-end products would guarantee another year of robust earnings, shrugging off the sagging prices of memory chips

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Beer Ads Restricted
description: Russian beer producers, the fastest-growing segment of the Russian economy, were dealt a blow on Friday by Russian legislators, who voted to significantly tighten restrictions on beer advertising. The bill, which faces a final vote, would ban beer advertisements on prime-time television, and would restrict advertising content. The vote infuriated Russian producers of beer, which is gaining ground against vodka as Russia's most popular drink. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: War Horrors Take a Toll On Reporters At the Front
description: The stereotype of the flinty, hard-bitten war reporter, immune to the blood and carnage of the battlefield, is common not just in Hollywood but among many reporters themselves.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 14 about potential successors to Yasir Arafat and one on Aug. 15 about the indictment of Marwan Barghouti, a Palestinian leader who is being tried by Israel on murder charges, misstated the history of his arrests and deportation. He was first arrested in 1978 at the age of 19, not 16. He was deported once, in 1987, not twice, and returned to the West Bank in 1994, not 1993. (A reader reported the errors by e-mail on Sept. 2; this correction was delayed for fact checking.)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Prices dropped after Saudi Arabia said it would support an attack on Iraq as long as the United Nations backed such action. In New York, crude oil for October delivery fell 14 cents, to $29.67.

title: W.T.O. to Rule on Possible Steel Quotas
description: The World Trade Organization agreed today to rule on a United States complaint that European Union quotas and tariffs on steel imports are illegal.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Off-Duty Officer Fatally Shoots Man
description: An off-duty police officer shot and killed a man in Washington Heights last night, the police said. The shooting occurred at the corner of West 178th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue at 7:45 p.m., and the victim was pronounced dead at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at 8:22 p.m., said the police. They did not release the name of the victim or the officer, who was not injured. A .32-caliber gun was found at the scene near the victim, said Sgt. Vito Marrano. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Aaron Danzig, 89, Who Argued Landmark Case on Court Power
description: Aaron L. Danzig, a lawyer who served as counsel to the losing side in Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins, the landmark 1938 Supreme Court case that limited the power of the federal courts, died in New York City on Sept. 10. He was 89 and lived in Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CLONING RESEARCH UNIT FOR SALE Unable to find a buyer for its stem cell research unit, PPL Therapeutics, the company that helped clone Dolly, the sheep, said it would close the division to cut costs by about 700,000 ($1 million) a year. The company said it still hoped to sell or spin off in a stock offering a division that researches ways to ready animal organs for transplant into humans. Recent work in that area has focused on piglets. Failing to live up to the economic promise of scientific breakthroughs like cloning, PPL Therapeutics has been reorganizing its operations to curtail losses. The company reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss for the six months ended June 30 to 5.5 million ($8.4 million) from 6.6 million a year earlier. Revenue for the period declined 52 percent, to 134 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: WAL-MART SALES ROSE TO EXPECTATIONS LAST WEEK
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that sales last week at stores open at least a year rose within the company's forecast as consumers bought household goods and food. Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., has forecast a 4 percent to 6 percent gain in September same-store sales. The sales results were difficult to compare with the year-earlier period, when the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks led consumers to stock up on items like batteries, gas cans and bottled water, Wal-Mart said. Fabrics and crafts, intimate apparel, electronics and food had the strongest increases in sales, the retailer said. Wal-Mart's August sales were less than expected, the second consecutive month they were below forecast.

description: To the Editor:

title: Tanjore Viswanathan, 75, Indian Musician
description: Tanjore Viswanathan, a flutist and teacher who was one of the most influential south Indian musicians in the United States, died on Sept. 10 in Hartford. He was 75 and lived in Middletown, Conn.

title: An Uncommon Alternative
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENTILCORE, MARIE W.
description: GENTILCORE - Marie W. Passed away September 16, 2002, at home. Mass Wednesday, 10am, St. Mary's Poughkeepsie, NY. Miller Funeral Home, Poughkeepsie.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Teenager Struck By Tree Limb Dies
description: A 14-year-old girl who was critically injured when a 1,500-pound tree limb struck her on the head during a violent windstorm last week has died. The teenager, Greta Schoenemann, was pronounced dead Sunday evening at University Hospital, said Rogers Ramsey, a hospital spokesman. She had been listed in critical condition since Wednesday, when she was injured as she and other students ate lunch outside Westfield High School. Another student, Amanda Gross, 14, remained hospitalized yesterday in fair condition.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Bail For Woman In Fire Case
description: A federal judge ruled that the woman who the authorities have said confessed to starting the largest wildfire in Colorado history might leave a halfway house. The woman, Terry L. Barton, a 38-year-old mother of two, will be electronically monitored while she is out on $600,000 bail. Ms. Barton, a former United States Forest Service employee, is accused of starting a fire on June 8 that charred 137,000 acres and destroyed 133 homes. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Czechs, in New York Debut, Play an American's Piece
description: The Czech World Orchestra, which introduced itself to New York on Saturday evening at Town Hall, was founded in Prague in 1999. Its roster, which looks relatively young, is drawn from players who also work with other Prague Orchestras; a representative likened the arrangement to that of the Orchestra of St. Luke's in New York. The Czech World's conductor and artistic director is an American, Jesse Mark Peckham, and for the occasion, he led his musicians in works by Dvorak, Beethoven and Nathan Scalzone, an American composer born in 1976.

title: The Story of Noah
description: To the Editor:

title: McCall Uses Others' Praise to Make His Point
description: This 30-second commercial is H. Carl McCall's first since he won the Democratic nomination for governor, and stations around the state began broadcasting it yesterday. It is part of the initial ad blitz of the general election. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican who is running for re-election, put up his first advertisement since the primary last Friday, and Tom Golisano, the apparent victor in the Independence Party primary, will begin advertising tomorrow, his aides said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Worldcom Plans To Cut 2,000 Overseas Jobs
description: WorldCom plans to trim 2,000 jobs, about a quarter of its work force in Europe, Africa and the Middle East, as it proceeds with a restructuring effort. It filed for bankruptcy in July. About 1,550 of the job cuts are in addition to the elimination of 17,000 positions that the company announced in June, before its bankruptcy filing. WorldCom, which is based in Clinton, Miss., is trying to cut costs even as it seeks to retain important business customers outside the United States, especially in Europe. WorldCom, one of just a few American telecommunications companies with an extensive global presence, has already signaled that it is trying to sell unprofitable operations in Latin America, but it remains to be seen whether the company will also seek buyers for other operations abroad. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TV Shows Start This Week, Hoping to Get Early Jump

title: S.E.C. to Consider Disclosure Of Mutual Funds' Proxy Votes
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will consider a proposal this week that would require mutual funds to reveal how they vote shares in corporate proxy contests.

title: Web and State Face Off in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Smiles, No Scowls, as Ewing Says Goodbye
description: For this day, at least, there was no acrimony. No angry fans. No critical news media. Patrick Ewing's retirement after 17 mostly distinguished seasons as a pro basketball player turned into a lovefest.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits on Sept. 5, about a picture editing program called Photoshop Elements 2.0, referred incorrectly to a trial version. The software's maker, Adobe Systems, says it plans to offer a 30-day trial soon, but the trial software is not yet available from its Web site.

title: Rangers Don't See 50 as Limit for Bure
description: Only twice in their 76 seasons have the Rangers had a player score 50 or more goals. Pavel Bure has done it elsewhere 5 times in 11 N.H.L. seasons.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Rare Flag Sighting
description: Apparently for the first time, the North Korean flag was flown legally south of the demilitarized zone that has divided North from South Korea since the Korean War. The flag was among those of 44 nations raised outside the main media center in Pusan for the Asian Games, which will run from Sept. 29 to Oct. 14. Most South Korean newspapers showed photographs of the flag-raising in color, but the flag remains otherwise illegal in the South. The North is sending several hundred athletes, officials and fans to the games. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: For Sale Upstate: Home and Underground Silo (Missile Extra)
description: For sale: In beautiful Adirondack Park, just 20 minutes from golf courses and ski areas, the ultimate in mountain luxury. Three bedrooms, three baths, septic system, Jacuzzi and seven-story underground missile silo designed to absorb the shock of a direct nuclear hit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSOFF, RUTH
description: ROSSOFF-Ruth. Formerly of Bayside, Queens, on September 16, 2002. Devoted mother of Sherri Rossoff, mother-inlaw of Benjamin Chevat, grandmother of Caroline and Michael. Beloved sister and aunt. Services on Wednesday 10:30 at Gutterman's, 98-60 Queens Boulevard.

title: Spending by Consumers Is Surging in Thailand
description: At $23,000 and up, a new Toyota Camry costs more than 10 times what the average person earns yearly in Thailand. Even so, demand for Toyota's best-selling passenger car is so hot that buyers are joining waiting lists of as long as three months to get one.

title: A Rivalry Reflected In Coaches' Words
description: Even with Bill Parcells safely ensconced in retirement, the bad blood between the Patriots and the Jets has not dissipated. Jets Coach Herman Edwards bristled today when asked about Patriots Coach Bill Belichick's contention that he thought some of Edwards's comments last week slighted the New England defense.

title: St. John's Long Wait For Stadium Is Over
description: St. John's, ranked No. 2 among N.C.A.A. Division I men's teams, will finally have a top-shelf place to call home.

title: Dilemma on Prostate Cancer Treatment Splits Experts
description: You're a man, 65 years old, and you've been having trouble urinating. Your doctor tells you that you have a cancer in your prostate making the gland press on the tube that carries urine. The good news is that the cancer seems confined to your prostate; there is no evidence that it has spread.

description: To the Editor:

description: MANDLER-Ronald E. ,68, of Becket, MA. Ron was a very special man who left this world how he lived in it, with dignity and gentle humor. He is survived by his wife Barbara, his sons Rick and Drew, his daughters-in-law Paula and Sloan, and grandchildren Charlotte, Henry and Brett. Services Wednesday 11:15 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St Amsterdam Ave.

In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Daniel G. Collins Memorial Fund, C/O The Development Office, NYU School of Law, 161 Avenue of the Americas, New York, New York 10013.

title: No Headline
description: On my desk is a set of self-help books that I've been buying at gun shows and on the Internet. If you want to kill a few thousand people, these are the books to consult.

title: Learning to Avoid a Deal-Killing Faux Pas in Japan
description: The after-lunch business meeting started nicely. The black suits from the New York public relations firm sat on one side. Across the table were the Japanese suits, prospective clients.

title: Holmes Is Finding His Way On Giants
description: For some players, change comes on the practice field. For others, it might come from lonely hours studying film. For Kenny Holmes, the change came while sitting next to Michael Strahan on the team plane as the Giants traveled to St. Louis.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Sentenced For Helping Mob Leaders
description: John J. Connolly Jr., a former F.B.I. agent convicted of helping organized crime leaders who were his confidential informers, was sentenced today to 10 years in prison, the maximum under federal sentencing guidelines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAVITIAN, ARMENO
description: TAVITIAN-Armeno. On September 15, 2002 at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Ohanes Tavitian. Loving mother of Henry and Aso Tavitian. Dear sister of the late Anahit Ohanessian and Haroutun Hokotzian. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, Tuesday, September 17th, 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral service at Saint Vartan's Armenian Cathedral, 630 2nd Avenue at 34th St, Wednesday 10:30AM.

title: Toasting the New But Thinking About 'Scarface'
description: ''I didn't know that,'' the director Brian De Palma says, responding to the information that Shaquille O'Neal, the Los Angeles Laker centerpiece and semirapper, has a tattoo with the letters ''Twism,'' an abbreviation of ''The world is mine,'' the words that the Cuban migr Tony Montana uses to rocket himself to the top in Mr. De Palma's 1983 film ''Scarface.''

title: WORKERS AT DIAL SOAP PLANT RATIFY 4-YEAR CONTRACT
description: The union for the Dial Corporation's workers at the plant in Aurora, Ill., ratified a new four-year labor agreement after voting down a contract proposal earlier this month. The union represents about 300 workers at the plant, where the company manufactures Dial soap. The contract, approved Sunday, expires in September 2006, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The prior contract expired at the end of August.

description: A Jam-Packed Seventh on Sixth
