description: A Successor to Hubble

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Flaws Found In Spousal-Abuse Program
description: The Police Department's online database for tracking domestic violence cases has failed to meet many of its objectives, according to an audit released yesterday by City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. The audit found that the $1.17 million domestic violence tracking system is not adequately linked to the Department of Probation, and that many users find it cumbersome. The Police Department said that it agreed with many of the recommendations and that it had already started to address the problems. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Worst-Hit Firm Faults Fairness Of Sept. 11 Aid
description: Officials with Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost more people than any other company in the World Trade Center attack, have concluded that the federal fund meant to compensate survivors of victims is unfair, violates several laws and threatens to shortchange the families of its 658 slain employees by hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Review/Fashion; In London, It Seems, the Unknowns Are Most Knowing
description: Except for Paul Smith Sir Paul now -- their names are hardly known outside England: Jessica Ogden, Peter Jensen, Aaron Sharif and Sachiko Okada of Blaak. What could they mean in a world awash in Zara shops and luxury swag? Even Hamish Morrow, who last week had a window at Bendel's, wouldn't be in danger of overexposure. Bendel's is the only store that carries his stuff, anywhere.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Karen Blair was named to the new post of director for production services and account supervisor at Kurman Communications, Chicago. She had been a freelance production associate in television. Xenia Boone was named executive director at the Direct Marketing Association Nonprofit Foundation, New York, succeeding Lee Cassidy, who retired. Ms. Boone had been director for government relations and legal counsel for the National Newspaper Association, Arlington, Va. Kraft & Werk, Maribor, Slovenia, joined the International Communications Agency Network, Rollinsville, Colo., an association of more than 70 independent agencies in more than 50 countries. Lowe & Partners Worldwide, New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, hired two executives to head departments. Valerie Cunningham joins as executive vice president and director for creative services, succeeding Bruce Balkin, who left in April. Ms. Cunningham had been senior vice president and director for print operations at Deutsch, New York, also part of the Partnership. Nick Felder joins as executive vice president and director for broadcast services, succeeding Bob Nelson, who left in February to join D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, part of the Bcom3 Group. Mr. Felder had been head of his own company, Alt Spec, New York, and before that was a senior broadcast producer at Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York. Bernie Prazenica was named president and general manager at WTVD, Raleigh-Durham, N.C., part of the ABC Owned Television Stations Group, succeeding Valari Dobson Staab, who recently joined a sibling station, KGO, San Francisco, as president and general manager. Mr. Prazenica had been sales director at another sibling station, WPVI, Philadelphia. The stations group is part of the ABC division of the Walt Disney Company. Alon Shoval joined Spirit Advertising, London, as creative partner, succeeding Mitch Levy, who left to become executive creative director at Joshua, London. Mr. Shoval had been a creative director at the Martin Agency, Richmond, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Director Resigns
description: Qwest Communications International said yesterday that Hank Brown had resigned from its board. Mr. Brown, a former United States senator from Colorado and president of the University of Northern Colorado, said in a statement issued by Qwest that he had resigned to devote more time to his new job as president and chief executive of the Daniels Fund, a foundation that supports education initiatives in four Rocky Mountain states. Mr. Brown was a holdover from the board of U S West, a regional phone company; he joined that board in 1998, the year before Qwest won control of the company.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Velocita Seeks Approval To Auction Assets
description: The Velocita Corporation, a closely held fiber optic network operator that never turned a profit, has asked a bankruptcy judge for approval to auction all its assets to help repay creditors owed more than $827 million. After suffering crippling debt, intense competition and waning demand for phone services, Velocita sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in May. The company, based in Falls Church, Va., cited $482.2 million in assets, almost half the amount of its debts, in Chapter 11 papers filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Newark. Velocita said in a court filing late Friday that it had not been able to find a bankruptcy credit line to complete its 20,000-mile network and emerge from Chapter 11. Faced with dwindling cash, Velocita said it would immediately start looking for buyers. Velocita said the minimum offer it would accept for its assets at auction was $75 million.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: TEENAGER STRUCK BY TREE LIMB DIES A 14-year-old girl who was critically injured when a 1,500-pound tree limb struck her on the head during a violent windstorm last week has died. The teenager, Greta Schoenemann, was pronounced dead Sunday evening at University Hospital, said Rogers Ramsey, a hospital spokesman. She had been listed in critical condition since Wednesday, when she was injured as she and other students ate lunch outside Westfield High School. Another student, Amanda Gross, 14, remained hospitalized yesterday in fair condition.    (NYT)

title: Goldman Insiders May Sell Some Shares
description: The Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said today that it would permit executives and other shareholders affiliated with the firm to sell as many as 28.4 million shares, worth $2.1 billion at recent prices.

title: NASA Starts Planning Hubble's Going-Away Party
description: Although the Hubble Space Telescope is only halfway through its anticipated career, planning has begun for its retirement party.

title: Tunnel Vision; With Station's Reopening, Even Commuters Smile
description: Sometimes it seems as if the subway is not manmade, but has been around forever, like a rock formation or a river, and so it should abide by certain steadfast natural laws. Such as:

title: TYCO REPORT TO THE S.E.C. IS EXPECTED TODAY
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it planned to file a report today with the Securities and Exchange Commission that people who were briefed on the report said would disclose the results of an internal investigation into the company's corporate governance and accounting practices. In a brief statement, Tyco said only that it would file a form 8-K report with the S.E.C. The people briefed on the report said it would disclose that millions of dollars of previously undisclosed loans were made to dozens of employees and later forgiven on the instructions of the former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski. The filing is a result of an internal investigation by the lawyer David Boies and the staff of his firm, Boies, Schiller & Flexner.

title: Ruling Favors Phone Providers In White Plains Fee Dispute
description: The city of White Plains cannot take a portion of the revenues from the telephone companies that want to provide local service to residents and businesses in the city, a federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled last week.

title: Inaugural Rates
description: The 252-room Occidental Grand Cozumel is scheduled to open next month on San Francisco Beach in the southwestern part of Cozumel, and it will offer a rate of $110 a night per person, based on double occupancy (regularly $149), through Dec. 21. That includes all meals, snacks, alcoholic drinks, nightly entertainment, a children's program, nonmotorized water sports, beginner scuba clinics, diving trips and two free tanks a day for certified divers. Information: (800) 858-2258, Web site www.occidental-hoteles.com .

title: GOVERNORS' RACES REACH NEW HIGHS IN EXPENDITURES
description: Governors' races across the country are setting records for campaign spending, driven by wealthy, self-financed candidates, tight contests, donors seeking access in statehouses and aggressive fund-raising by incumbents.

title: Pataki Takes the Offensive
description: Arule of thumb in politics is that a front-runner sitting on a big lead does nothing to roil the waters, and that often includes not saying anything negative about the opposition.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: More Time Needed In Hijacking Case
description: Karim Sadok Chatty, the man accused of planning to hijack a London-bound plane last month, was ordered held until the end of this month after prosecutors told a Swedish court they needed more time to prepare formal charges. Chief Prosecutor Thomas Haggstrom told the judge in Vasteras, the airport town 60 miles from Stockholm where Mr. Chatty, 29, was arrested with a gun in his carry-on luggage, that if released the suspect might escape, destroy evidence or complicate the investigation. Mr. Chatty was stopped as he prepared to board a flight on Aug. 29 with a group attending an Islamic conference in Birmingham. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Helping Babies Sleep More Safely
description: Swaddling, or wrapping infants tightly before putting them to bed, appears to help them sleep on their backs, reducing the risk of sudden infant death syndrome, a study this month in The Journal of Pediatrics says.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Singapore Exchange To Trade Chip Futures
description: Analysts have long said that computer memory chips have become commodities, traded much the same way as corn, wheat or coffee -- and subject to the same cycles of boom and bust. Now the Singapore Exchange, which runs Singapore's stock and futures exchanges, says it will begin offering the world's first futures contracts for dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips next year. Singapore's memory futures will be denominated in units of 10,000 chips and divided by capacity of 256 megabytes, 512 megabytes, etc. The exchange says the contracts will help chip industry members hedge against price fluctuations and give traders new opportunities. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cloning Research Unit For Sale
description: Unable to find a buyer for its stem cell research unit, PPL Therapeutics, the company that helped clone Dolly, the sheep, said it would close the division to cut costs by about 700,000 ($1 million) a year. The company said it still hoped to sell or spin off in a stock offering a division that researches ways to ready animal organs for transplant into humans. Recent work in that area has focused on piglets. Failing to live up to the economic promise of scientific breakthroughs like cloning, PPL Therapeutics has been reorganizing its operations to curtail losses. The company reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss for the six months ended June 30 to 5.5 million ($8.4 million) from 6.6 million a year earlier. Revenue for the period declined 52 percent, to 134 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Out of Sheba Came a Queen (Maybe Not)

Certainly it has not prevented the mysterious lady from southern Arabia from living a full life in religious texts and in the popular imagination for well over 2,000 years. And it has not stood in the way of an exhibition at the British Museum called ''Queen of Sheba: Treasures From Ancient Yemen.''

title: PREMCOR, AN OIL REFINER, LAYS OFF 130 EMPLOYEES
description: Premcor Inc., an oil refining company that went public in April, said yesterday that it would lay off 130 workers at plants in Ohio and Texas and offices in St. Louis to cut costs. About 20 percent of 650 nonunion jobs at refineries in Port Arthur, Tex., and Lima, Ohio, and its St. Louis administrative offices will be eliminated, resulting in a third-quarter charge of about $10 million, the company said. The job cuts will save about $15 million a year. Job cuts at the refineries will be made in October with about half of the annual savings realized in the fourth quarter, Premcor said. The rest will be reflected in the first quarter of 2003. Premcor is based in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: DEATHS FROM SPOILED FOOD At least 200 people in Tangshan, near Nanjing, became ill Saturday after eating tainted breakfast items from a popular snack shop. Reuters, citing a report by the official China Radio International quoting local officials, said the death toll had reached 49, including 2 soldiers. Officials said they suspected rat poison was put in cakes and rice, a view that was tentatively confirmed by the Center for Disease Control in Nanjing. The shop supplies food to a boarding school for junior high students, and The China Daily quoted a local doctor as saying, "It is really unbearable to see young children dying right before my eyes." Local officials said they were under orders not to discuss the casualties.    Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Zurich: Swiss Life To Raise Funds
description: Swiss Life announced plans to sell shares worth as much as $790 million, to try to shore up its business because of investment losses. The news set off a 12 percent decline in its share price. The chief executive, Roland Chlapowski, has been cutting jobs and selling businesses to raise cash. Swiss Life now joins some European rivals that are asking investors for about $10 billion to bolster reserves after a two and a half years of stock market declines. Swiss Life will ask shareholders to approve its sale of stock on Oct. 23, the company said. More details will be released tomorrow when Swiss Life posts first-half results.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor To Make European Trip
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will leave tomorrow night for Greece and Turkey, where he will address a conference of mayors, tour the Athens site of the 2004 Olympics and visit Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, the spiritual leader of 220 million Orthodox Christians worldwide. He will return on Sunday, his aides said. He is scheduled to travel with several Greek-American politicians. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Ex-Mayor Has His Say
description: Ten days after being sentenced to prison for racketeering, former Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. of Providence, has a new job as a talk-radio host. Mr. Cianci, who left office the day of his sentencing, told listeners he decided to take to the airwaves because his freedom of speech was not restricted and he had to pay bills. Mr. Cianci, whose radio show would end when his 64-month prison term is to begin on Dec. 6, has appealed the conviction. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: BIG LOS ANGELES LAW FIRM ACQUIRES NEW YORK OPERATION

O'Melveny will pick up 88 lawyers from the transaction, and the combined firm will have more than 800 lawyers worldwide, 206 of them in New York. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. title: Corrections

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SWEDEN: MORE TIME NEEDED IN HIJACKING CASE Karim Sadok Chatty, the man accused of planning to hijack a London-bound plane last month, was ordered held until the end of this month after prosecutors told a Swedish court they needed more time to prepare formal charges. Chief Prosecutor Thomas Haggstrom told the judge in Vasteras, the airport town 60 miles from Stockholm where Mr. Chatty, 29, was arrested with a gun in his carry-on luggage, that if released the suspect might escape, destroy evidence or complicate the investigation. Mr. Chatty was stopped as he prepared to board a flight on Aug. 29 with a group attending an Islamic conference in Birmingham.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

The company said the forecast was in line with its expectations but was below the 26 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Forward earned 19 cents a share in the period a year earlier. The company has 80 freight terminals at or near airports in the United States and Canada.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Mobilcom Rescue Scrutinized
description: The European Commission's competition office will scrutinize any attempt made by the German government to rescue the cash-short mobile phone operator Mobilcom, a commission spokeswoman said. The German economy minister, Werner Mueller, promised on Sunday that the government would provide state guarantees for loans totaling 400 million euros in a bid to save the company and its 5,500 employees from bankruptcy after France Tlcom abandoned Mobilcom last week. The move comes days ahead of German national elections. The commission could agree to government involvement in the rescue only if the loans were granted at least at the rate charged to healthy companies, the spokeswoman, Amelia Torres, said. Paul Meller (NYT)

description: Bausch & Lomb in Rochester has named three units of the Interpublic Group of Companies to handle the consolidated United States account for its eye care and contact-lens products, with billings estimated at $30 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 14 about potential successors to Yasir Arafat and one on Aug. 15 about the indictment of Marwan Barghouti, a Palestinian leader who is being tried by Israel on murder charges, misstated the history of his arrests and deportation. He was first arrested in 1978 at the age of 19, not 16. He was deported once, in 1987, not twice, and returned to the West Bank in 1994, not 1993. (A reader reported the errors by e-mail on Sept. 2; this correction was delayed for fact checking.)

title: Survey Finds Artists Since 9/11 Have Less Work and More Debt
description: A survey of the city's artistic corps has found that a vast majority of working artists are still reeling from the effects of last year's terrorist attacks, with significant lost income, spent savings and the threat of eviction among their chief concerns.

title: No Urgency in Starting Talks For W.N.B.A. and Players
description: The players' four-year contract with the Women's National Basketball Association expired Sunday without a new agreement in place.

title: Military Sales Of Sex Materials Can Be Banned
description: The government may ban the sale of sexually explicit magazines and videos on military bases, a three-judge panel of a federal appeals court in San Francisco has ruled.

title: Leader of Austria's Right Cites Threats as Reason for Quitting
description: Of all the theatrical turns taken by the Austrian right-winger Jrg Haider, perhaps none was so astonishing as the explanation he offered today for his decision not to reclaim the helm of his Freedom Party.

description: FROSS-Alvin. Age 77, of Scarsdale, N.Y. On September 11, 2002. Beloved husband of Phyllis and father of Erica Stuart and Tony. A founding partner of Fross, Zelnick, Lehrman & Zissu. Memorial service to be held Sunday, September 22nd, at 4 P.M. at the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: Singapore Announces Arrests of 21 Men Linked to Planned Attacks on U.S. Targets
description: Authorities in Singapore announced today the arrests of 21 men they identified as members of an extremist Islamic organization that spans Southeast Asia, strengthening evidence gathered by American investigators that the group was preparing attacks on American targets.

title: Sleep Apnea, a Noisy but Often Invisible Threat
description: John Holman of St. Paul is a very busy man, and he was not accustomed to having to ''let things go'' because he was too tired to do them. But tired he was, tired driving to and from work, tired during the day at the warehouse company he runs, too tired some days to play his beloved game of tennis after work, and really tired in the evening -- in bed by 8:30 to arise at 6.

title: G.E.'s Ex-Chief to Pay for Perks, But the Question Is: How Much?
description: John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric, will pay for most of the corporate perks he negotiated to receive in retirement, including the use of a Boeing 737 business jet and an apartment overlooking Central Park, the company confirmed yesterday.

title: No Guns in Flight
description: In an attempt to make America more safe, Congress has approved legislation that will make flying more dangerous. Earlier this month the Senate passed a measure that would allow pilots to be armed, and the House approved a similar bill in July. Many details of this bill have yet to be worked out, and the Bush administration has expressed reservations about some aspects of it. As Congress considers this measure, it should include a provision to allow airlines that meet certain other security requirements to opt out of the program.

title: A Letter From Iraq To the Chief Of the U.N.
description: Following is the text of a letter that was sent yesterday by Naji Sabri, Iraq's minister of foreign affairs, to Secretary General Kofi Annan, allowing the return of United Nations weapons inspectors without conditions:

title: Learning Beyond Measure
description: When the U.S. News & World Report annual rankings of undergraduate programs at American colleges and universities appeared this week, I breathed a sigh of relief that my university continued to appear among the top 10 in the ''national universities'' category. As the dean responsible for undergraduate education at the University of Pennsylvania, I have found that the task of keeping alumni and donors happy about Penn's status has been made much easier by our rise to prominence in those rankings. And of course a good ranking has also played a significant role in driving both the numbers and quality of our student applicant pool steadily upward.

title: David Grene, Colorful Expert On the Classics, Is Dead at 89
description: David Grene, whose translations of ancient Greek spoke with such clarity that the writer Saul Bellow suggested he was on a first-name basis with Sophocles and Aristophanes, died on Sept. 10 in Chicago. He was 89.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Immigrants' Deaths Prompt Inquiry
description: Interior Minister Giuseppe Pisanu began an investigation into a weekend shipwreck off the coast of Sicily that plunged scores of illegal immigrants into stormy waters, killing at least 15. The disaster was the latest incident to draw attention to the desperate Africans and Asians trying to enter Europe along Italy's coast. The people who died were among as many as 300 who left Liberia aboard a merchant ship in early September, Italian officials said. As they neared Porto Empedocle in southern Sicily, they were transferred onto smaller boats, one of which capsized. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLOSOFF, MORTY
description: WOLOSOFF - Morty. Gone one year. Always and forever loved. Rest in peace with all my love. Gloria

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Two More West Nile Cases
description: Two more cases of West Nile virus have been reported in the city, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced yesterday. A 59-year-old woman from the Bronx and a 66-year-old man from Brooklyn are hospitalized in stable condition. Spraying has been scheduled in northeast Queens from 8 o'clock tonight to 2 a.m. at Flushing Airport, Kissena Park and Golf Course, Cunningham Park, Alley Pond Park and parts of Oakland Gardens, Hollis Hill, Bellaire, Queens Village, Bellrose, Floral Park and Glen Oaks. In Brooklyn, spraying has been scheduled from 8 p.m. Thursday to 2 a.m. at the Marine Park and Golf Course and parts of Sheepshead Bay, Gerritsen Beach, Marine Park, Flatlands, Georgetown, Mill Island, Mill Basin and Bergen Beach. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Stocks Close at Lowest Levels Since Early August
description: The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 index dropped to their lowest levels since early August today as more sour economic news drove both stocks and interest rates lower.

title: When 'Health' Supplements May Do Harm
description: Recently, I entered a store specializing in dietary supplements, curious about the information I would receive when I explained to the teenage clerk that I was particularly interested in preventing a heart attack.

title: The Physics Of the Wave, In Stadiums, Not Oceans
description: In physics, there are standing waves, longitudinal waves and transverse waves, to name just a few. In football, soccer and baseball, there is only the Wave, the sweeping mass of spectators rising in sequence around a stadium.

title: Challenger To Torricelli Attacks Curbs On the C.I.A.
description: Trying to stay on the offensive on the issue of national security, Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican nominee in New Jersey's United States Senate race, demanded today that Senator Robert G. Torricelli drop his support for a policy that placed restrictions on the Central Intelligence Agency's ability to recruit informers who have a criminal history.

title: A Feverish West Nile Reaction
description: Senator Patrick Leahy must have been a lot more spooked than anyone realized when he became a target of one of those anthrax-laced letters sent to Capitol Hill last fall. That attack posed a genuine threat to the Vermont Democrat and his staff. But now the senator is seeing terrorist attacks where none exist. In comments on a radio talk show last week, he suggested that the West Nile virus could be ''something that's being tested as a biological weapon against us.'' That overwrought speculation ignored the consensus of health authorities that the West Nile virus arrived here naturally -- brought to this hemisphere by an infected person, bird or mosquito from areas abroad where it has circulated for decades.

title: Pressed From Two Sides, Kashmiris Turn Out to Vote
description: The men walked to the polls as grimly as if they were being marched to prison. They had been ordered to vote, they said, by Indian soldiers who had rousted them from their village homes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about support among Washington Democrats for H. Carl McCall's campaign against Gov. George E. Pataki misstated the amounts the two candidates reported having raised in their latest filings. Mr. Pataki's figure was $35.5 million, not $23.3 million. Mr. McCall's was $9.8 million, not $2.5 million. The smaller amounts were what the campaigns reported having available to spend.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Egyptian Deported In Document Fraud
description: An Egyptian man living in Astoria has pleaded guilty to fraudulently obtaining identification papers, including a federal student pilot certificate, and will be deported to Egypt, the authorities said yesterday. Officials said they had not found any link between the man, Hassan Abdelhamid, 29, who obtained a tourist visa in 1995, and terrorist groups. Mr. Abdelhamid is one of 225 people arrested since February as a result of a statewide crackdown on fraudulent identification. The authorities said that Mr. Abdelhamid had received a student pilot certificate from the Federal Aviation Administration after supplying false information. He was likely to receive a prison sentence of six months, but agreed instead to be deported. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: SPIDER-MAN PUBLISHER APPOINTS SUCCESSOR TO CHIEF
description: Marvel Enterprises Inc., the publisher of Spider-Man comic books, said yesterday that Allen Lipson would become the chief executive after Peter Cuneo retires at the end of the year. Mr. Lipson, 59, has been Marvel's executive vice president for business and legal affairs since November 1999. Mr. Cuneo will continue to serve as a board member and adviser, the company said. Mr. Cuneo, 58, who became chief executive in July 1999, has been credited with helping the New York-based publisher rebuild interest in Spider-Man, X-Men and its other comic book characters. Marvel also publishes Incredible Hulk and Daredevil comic books.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Chip Outlook Lowered
description: Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing Ltd., which is seeking cash from its investors for the fourth time in three years, said it would miss its fourth-quarter sales target because of weak demand for computer chips. The company, one of the world's largest providers of custom-built chips, said two weeks ago, when it announced its latest share sale, that it would meet a previous target that sales would double from the first quarter, to $168 million in the fourth quarter. That is no longer the case, the company said in a regulatory filing.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Appoints New Financial Chief
description: Gateway, a money-losing maker of personal computers, named Roderick Sherwood of Opsware as chief financial officer yesterday, succeeding Joseph Burke, as the company struggles to increase sales and return to profitability. Mr. Burke, who has been with Gateway, based in Poway, Calif., since 1995, will become senior vice president for business development, Gateway said. A spokeswoman, Ashley Wood, said the change was not related to the company's performance. Mr. Sherwood was the chief financial officer of Opsware, the software company founded by Marc Andreessen that was formerly called Loudcloud. Mr. Burke became Gateway's financial chief in January 2001 after the founder, Ted Waitt, returned as chief executive following a yearlong absence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Fassel Continues to Stand by Dayne
description: Ron Dayne got more chances to carry the ball Sunday, as Giants Coach Jim Fassel said he would, with seven rushes in the first quarter -- one more than he had in the entire first game.

title: American Dance Festival Directors to Receive French Arts Medals
description: Charles and Stephanie Reinhart, the co-directors of the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., are to receive the medals of Commander and Chevalier, respectively, of the French Order of Arts and Letters on Thursday. They are being awarded the honors for their continued and significant contributions to furthering dance in France and throughout the world.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: WORLDCOM PLANS TO CUT 2,000 OVERSEAS JOBS WorldCom plans to trim 2,000 jobs, about a quarter of its work force in Europe, Africa and the Middle East, as it proceeds with a restructuring effort. It filed for bankruptcy in July. About 1,550 of the job cuts are in addition to the elimination of 17,000 positions that the company announced in June, before its bankruptcy filing. WorldCom, which is based in Clinton, Miss., is trying to cut costs even as it seeks to retain important business customers outside the United States, especially in Europe. WorldCom, one of just a few American telecommunications companies with an extensive global presence, has already signaled that it is trying to sell unprofitable operations in Latin America, but it remains to be seen whether the company will also seek buyers for other operations abroad.

title: N.C.A.A. to Rule On S.E.C. Teams
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will announce decisions today on appeals by Alabama and Kentucky of penalties against their football programs.

description: As if they were law students presenting cases in a study group, the Giants' defensive backs met Saturday night to assess the subject assigned to each of them. Will Peterson talked about St. Louis receiver Torry Holt, Will Allen discussed the talents and tendencies of Isaac Bruce, and Jason Sehorn gave a dissertation on Ricky Proehl.

description: Having flopped in bowling, the investment bankers at the Goldman Sachs Group are trying their hand at a game they should know a little better.

description: Lolita Torres, a leading actress and singer from Argentina who became an international symbol of that nation's golden age of moviemaking in the 1950's, died on Saturday in Buenos Aires. She was 72.

description: Iraq, responding to worldwide pressure after President Bush demanded that it comply with United Nations resolutions, said today that it would allow international weapons inspectors to return ''without conditions.''

title: Miscellany
description: * Radio Advertising Bureau, New York, reported that ad revenue for radio improved in July, continuing a trend, increasing 9 percent from July 2001. Local ad revenue rose 7 percent, the bureau reported, and national revenue rose 16 percent. For the first seven months of 2002, according to the bureau, ad revenue increased 2 percent from the corresponding period last year, as local ad revenue rose 1 percent and national ad revenue rose 6 percent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ISLE OF CAPRI CASINOS INC., Biloxi, Miss., an owner of 14 casinos in six states, said it had agreed to purchase the State Line and Silver Smith Casino Resorts in Wendover, Nev., for $30 million in cash. The agreement is subject to approval by state regulators and Federal Bankruptcy Court.

title: Up, Down, In and Out in Beverly Hills: Rats
description: ''Beverly Hills is a nice place to be a rat,'' Ray Honda explained, admiring the cool, verdant landscape of the moneyed class, with its fruit trees, bird feeders, swimming pools and dog-food bowls. ''It's a very good address.''

title: Diocese to Take Over Riverhead School, Reversing Trend
description: At a time when schools in some Roman Catholic dioceses are closing or facing cutbacks, Long Island's bishop said today that he would raise $10 million over five years to keep the doors open at a Catholic high school here.

title: An Allergy That's on the Money
description: As the euro coins introduced in January start to become worn, some Europeans may find themselves becoming allergic to money, or at least small change, according to an article last week in the journal Nature.

title: Police Seek Suspects in Killing Of Health Care Aide in Queens
description: The police were searching last night for suspects in the stabbing death of a home health aide who was found Sunday in the living room of the Queens house where she cared for an 89-year-old woman and the woman's 69-year-old daughter.

title: The Iraqi Chessboard
description: Iraq's offer yesterday to allow United Nations weapons inspectors back to Baghdad without conditions could open the way to resolving the crisis peacefully and should certainly be tested. Given Saddam Hussein's machinations over the years, however, the offer could also be an insincere gambit aimed at delaying and dividing the Security Council as it begins to consider President Bush's demand to force Iraq to give up its unconventional weapons. It shouldn't take long to tell whether Iraq will really give inspectors a free hand, or will follow its invitation with limitations that render it meaningless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROVAN, DAVID T.
description: PROVAN-David T. Age 60, died September 15, 2002, of Fort Montgomery, New York, formerly of New City, NY. George M. Holt Funeral Home Inc, 845-492-2159.

description: What Sal Calabrese has always loved about Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, the city's largest Italian neighborhood, is that it provides the intimacies of a village.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Bid For Retail Group
description: The Belgian holding company Ackermans & Van Haaren made a takeover bid for the local retail group GIB, hastening the end of a gradual liquidation of company. Ackermans offered 41 euros a share for GIB, the owner of chains ranging from fast food outlets to sports shops. Recent sell-offs by GIB, including the sale of the GB supermarket chain in 2000, have amassed 1.3 billion euros ($1.2 billion) in cash. GIB's remaining operations include the Quick hamburger chain, but analysts said the cash was the main attraction for Ackermans. Guy Wyser-Pratte, an American investor who owns 5 percent of GIB, said shareholders should reject the bid. ''We have absolutely no intention of accepting this price. The thing is worth a good deal more than 41,'' he said. GIB shares rose 5.8 percent, to close at 41.15 euros. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: TERRORISM SUSPECT TAKEN TO U.S. BASE FOR INTERROGATION
description: Ramzi bin al-Shibh, the suspected member of Al Qaeda captured last week, was flown from Pakistan today under armed guard to a military base outside the United States in preparation for what senior government officials said would be a lengthy interrogation and a possible trial before a military tribunal.

title: A Microsoft Pioneer Leaves to Strike Out on His Own
description: Charles Simonyi, a computer scientist who joined Microsoft when it had 40 employees and who helped set its technical strategy for years, is leaving the company to found his own software start-up.

title: Hospitals to Get $140 Million For Losses in 9/11 Response
description: Hospitals and medical clinics that lost money responding to the Sept. 11 attack are to receive $140 million in federal grants, with more than $130 million designated for New York City institutions, according to state and federal authorities.

title: Lawmaker, on Iraq Visit, Insisted on Inspectors
description: A veteran West Virginia lawmaker who visited Iraq over the weekend said he told that nation's leaders that allowing ''unconditional and unfettered'' access to weapons inspectors was the only way to prevent military action by the United States.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: SINGAPORE EXCHANGE TO TRADE CHIP FUTURES Analysts have long said that computer memory chips have become commodities, traded much the same way as corn, wheat or coffee  and subject to the same cycles of boom and bust. Now the Singapore Exchange, which runs Singapore's stock and futures exchanges, says it will begin offering the world's first futures contracts for dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips next year. Singapore's memory futures will be denominated in units of 10,000 chips and divided by capacity of 256 megabytes, 512 megabytes, etc. The exchange says the contracts will help chip industry members hedge against price fluctuations and give traders new opportunities.

title: Residents Evicted From a Building in Debt
description: More than 100 residents of a bankrupt condominium here were forced to find new homes today when city officials closed the building, citing health code violations and more than $3 million in unpaid bills.

title: U.S. Accuses Cuba of Trying to Disrupt Antiterrorism Effort
description: The State Department today accused Cuba of deliberately subverting American efforts to fight terrorism by steadily providing Washington with erroneous tips and other false information about potential threats.

title: The Rise And Rise Of a Prodigy
description: The juggernaut that is the career of Zac Posen motors along, seemingly unstoppable. Or at least there are no obvious jitters about a sophomore slump. Mr. Posen is the fabulously networked wunderkind whose first collection, in 2001, was greeted by the press with hosannas and by buyers with cautious appetites. At a dinner party in Milan last year, the tyro designer found himself being paid court by three of the industry's most powerful C.E.O.'s (Yves Carcelle, the president of LVMH Fashion Group; Sidney Toledano, the president of Dior; and Domenico De Sole, the president of Gucci Group).

title: Tuscany 101: Simplicity Perfected
description: WHEN good food writers die -- to misquote Oscar Wilde -- they go to Italy. I, however, am taking no chances with what will be coming to me in the afterlife and so have decided to spend as much time as possible there while alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCHARD, ANNE HILL
description: BLANCHARD-Anne Hill, 48. Of Manhattan and Erwinna, PA., died on September 16, 2002. Beloved wife of Edward Vermont Blanchard Jr. and loving mother of Lydia, Catherine and Cordelia; she was also the cherished daughter of W.T. Hill of Huntsville, AL and devoted sister of Liz Hill of Ann Arbor, MI; Bill Hill and Susan Hill of Huntsville, AL; and James Hill of Mineola, NY. Professor of economics at Queens College and former Chair of the department, Anne was an energetic and tireless advocate for women's education and economic well-being. She was a dedicated Trustee of the American Folk Art Museum and served on the Museum's Executive Committee. A prominent collector, Anne was instrumental in recognizing the work of contemporary self-taught artists and helped shape the burgeoning field of outsider art. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, September 21, 2002 at 11AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave at 90th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53 Street, New York, New York 10019.

title: Beneath Those Frogs' Legs Beats the Heart of a Bistro
description: THERE'S an old story about Park Slope that has two young fathers of the Polarfleece-wearing adman-lawyer-environmentalist variety standing at Seventh Avenue and Union Street complaining about the neighborhood's lack of bars. A wizened coot walking past turns on his heel on hearing their dirge. Time was, you couldn't swing a cat for hitting a bar in Park Slope. No longer. ''And just why,'' the old man says, ''do you suppose that is?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSHALL, RUTH
description: WEINSHALL-Ruth. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Ruth Weinshall, beloved motherin-law of our dear and devoted friend, The Honorable Charles E. Schumer, Senior Senator from The State of New York, and a long-time Honorary Trustee of Beth Israel. To Senator Schumer, his beloved wife, Iris Weinshall, and the Weinshall and Schumer families, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Peter A. Kelly, President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Beth Israel

title: Cement Plant's Foes Present Petitions
description: Environmentalists representing 28 preservation groups presented petitions today urging a stop to a massive cement plant here and asking the state to set a date for hearings on the project.

title: Iraq, Upside Down
description: Recently, I've had the chance to travel around the country and do some call-in radio shows, during which the question of Iraq has come up often. And here's what I can report from a totally unscientific sample: Don't believe the polls that a majority of Americans favor a military strike against Iraq. It's just not true.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, JOHN CURTIS III.
description: WOLF-John Curtis III. A resident of Brooklyn Heights, died after a long illness on September 11, 2002, at his summer home in Virginia. He was 66. Mr. Wolf was a native of Martinsburg, WV and was a graduate of Shepherd College. He studied under Paul Baker at Baylor University and began his television work in Maryland. He continued in NYC at WABCTV and WOR-TV. After retiring, he worked independently at Universal Studios in Orlando and with Corniche Productions in NY. For many years, Mr. Wolf directed Romper Room, aired nationally and internationally. He received Emmy Award nominations for Straight Talk and other programs and was active with the National TV Arts and Sciences Dramatic Workshop. He also directed Off-Off Broadway productions of Cardinal Man and The American Flu. John Wolf is survived by his wife, Nancy A. Wolf and by two daughters, Ellen Wolf and Laura Wolf, all of Brooklyn Heights. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM on September 22, 2002 at the First Unitarian Church, Monroe Place and Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn Heights. Memorial contributions may be made to The Actors' Fund, 729 7th Ave, 10th Floor, NY, NY 10019.

title: F.B.I. to Question Suspect in Malaysia
description: After resisting for months, the Malaysian government has agreed to allow the F.B.I. to question a man who Malaysian and American authorities say was the host for a meeting in January 2000 of plotters for Al Qaeda.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer's Profit Up
description: Tesco, Britain's biggest supermarket chain, reported first-half net profit rose 15 percent to $360 million, despite a slowdown in the growth of its same-store sales at its British stores from 7 percent last year to 3.9 percent. As it presses to expand overseas business in 10 countries from Thailand to Ireland, the retailer also reported a 79 percent increase in international operating profit, to about $90 million. Tesco's shares fell by 5 percent, however, because of slowing sales growth in Britain and disappointment with the firm's international sales growth, analysts said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Conservative Churches Grew Fastest in 1990's, Report Says
description: Socially conservative churches that demand high commitment from their members grew faster than other religious denominations in the last decade, according to a study released yesterday by statisticians who count American religious affiliations every 10 years.

title: A Dismal Retail Season
description: Retailers, suffering through a dismal back-to-school season, have plenty of culprits to blame, from the hot weather of late summer to their customers' anxiety over the economy.

title: Dodgers Are Relying on Gagne as Giants Increase the Pressure
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17  The closer did not want to capitulate. He wanted to conquer. He has been conquering all year.

title: Spain Sees Arrests of Basque Separatists as Group's Unraveling
description: Spanish officials today hailed the arrest in France of two leaders of the armed Basque separatist group E.T.A. as ''the beginning of the end'' of an organization that has killed more than 800 people in its fight for Basque independence.

title: Columbia and London School Team Up
description: Columbia's School of International and Public Affairs is teaming up with the London School of Economics and Political Science to offer a joint master's degree in public administration, beginning next year. Students in the 21-month program, announced this week, will spend a year at each institution and earn degrees from both. Applicants accepted by either school may immediately apply to the second or wait until the fall semester of their first year.

title: The Tangled History of Karzai's Would-Be Killer
description: The soldier who recently tried to assassinate Afghanistan's president here enlisted in a guard unit shortly after winning release from the nation's most notorious prison for Taliban captives, Afghan officials say.

title: Tyco Details Lavish Lives Of Executives
description: Tyco International, whose former top executives have been indicted on charges of looting the company, said yesterday that it had uncovered a web of deception and personal enrichment that spread throughout its management ranks.

title: Floods in Europe Leave Behind a Muddied Political Landscape
description: The waters from the calamitous floods in Europe last month have receded. What is left -- in Austria, Germany and the Czech Republic -- is the political debris, wreaking more havoc than expected.

title: Eyeing a Japanese Slugger
description: The Yankees have an interest in the Yomiuri Giants slugger Hideki Matsui, but it is not connected in any way to a deal that would bring Yankee games to Japanese television and Japanese games to the YES Network, a baseball official said.

title: Welfare Reform Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Treason Conviction Upheld
description: The Supreme Court upheld the treason conviction of Oleg D. Kalugin, a retired K.G.B. general now living in the United States. Mr. Kalugin was convicted in absentia in July, stripped of his military rank and honors and sentenced to 15 years in prison, a largely symbolic sentence. His prosecution was seen as evidence of the resurgent influence of the intelligence services under President Vladimir V. Putin, a former K.G.B. officer. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Homes for Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Revamped Proposal Suggests Strategies to Tighten Online Security
description: A long-awaited report from the Bush administration intended to help citizens, businesses and government shore up the nation's cyberdefenses will be revealed today.

title: Footlights
description: Championed

title: A Road Map for Iraq
description: The cat-and-mouse game with Iraq has begun -- again. With his ambiguous promise to welcome back weapons inspectors, Saddam Hussein has stirred new uncertainty at the United Nations about the proper course of action. That makes it all the more important to clarify what really counts in this conflict. The answer is the destruction of Iraq's unconventional weapons and the dismantling of its program to develop nuclear arms. That should be the lodestar of American and United Nations policy.

title: On Edge Of a Void, An Oasis Reopens
description: On a crisp morning strikingly reminiscent of that other day in September -- the identical azure sky and astonishingly brilliant sun -- the doors of the Winter Garden opened to the public yesterday for the first time in 371 days. For many, it was like coming home.

title: Expert Business Panel Puts Stock Options on a List of Reforms
description: A panel of business leaders proposed changes yesterday in the way corporations pay their top executives. Included in the changes are the prior disclosure of executive stock sales and the uniform treatment of stock options as expenses.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Telecom Job Cuts
description: Europe's biggest manufacturer of phone equipment, Alcatel of France, said it would cut 1,050 jobs, or two-thirds of the work force at its optical components affiliate, as sales plunge. Alcatel Optronics expects third-quarter revenue to drop as much as 50 percent from the previous quarter because phone companies are spending less. Alcatel previously announced plans to cut about 43,000 jobs. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: J.P. Morgan Says Earnings For Quarter Will Be Weak

title: That Full, Cruel Mouth Just Gives the Game Away
description: Whenever the word ''experiment'' is used in a movie title, it's almost never the sign of a sunny-dispositioned musical comedy. As a harbinger of dread, the bountifully coldblooded ''Das Experiment'' doesn't disappoint; it's as unsettling as cafeteria meatloaf. It's hypnotic, a slick and well-told story that's all the more haunting because it's finally empty.

title: Big-Price Screening Machines Are Said to Get Little Use
description: Even as the Transportation Department races to install million-dollar machines in airports to screen checked baggage, most of the devices are operated less than two hours a day, and some hardly screen any bags at all, two congressmen said today.

title: Waiters Celebrate a Judge's Decision on Tips
description: Workers and labor activists gathered yesterday outside a Chinatown dim sum restaurant with a history of complaints of labor violations to celebrate a federal judge's ruling that managers illegally took a share of waiters' tips.

title: Hernandez Retracts His Criticism
description: Bad teams do not win at home, as Mo Vaughn concluded in the Mets' 15-game losing streak at Shea Stadium, which set a National League record. They also attract plenty of unwanted attention.

title: The Transfer At Secaucus Edges Closer To Reality
description: The Secaucus Transfer, the long-awaited station that will connect 11 of the state's 12 commuter rail lines and shave minutes off commuting times to Midtown Manhattan for thousands of commuters, will be slowly phased in beginning next fall, New Jersey Transit officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUNSTEIN, RITA, 83, (NEE POGOSTIN)
description: BRAUNSTEIN-Rita, 83, (nee Pogostin) on September 16, 2002 in Aventura, FL. Formerly of Woodmere, Long Island, NY. Mrs. Braunstein was predeceased by her husband Irving (1996). Loving mother of Harriet Braunstein and Stephen Braunstein. Also survived by a sister Shirley Friedman and two grandsons Paul and Eric Braunstein. Graveside services will be today 11 A.M. at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York. Donations may be made to Vitas Hospice Unit of Aventura Hospital, Aventura, FL.

title: NORTH KOREANS SIGN AGREEMENT WITH JAPANESE
description: At a landmark summit meeting that featured an astonishing admission by North Korea that its agents helped to kidnap 11 Japanese beginning in the late 1970's, the leaders of Japan and North Korea agreed today to begin normalizing relations after decades of bitter hostility.

title: Decades After Their Pop Hits, 2 Singers Show What Else They Have
description: Darlene Love and Freda Payne are prime examples of rhythm-and-blues singers who are considerably more complex than the sound of the vintage hit singles that typecast them vocally on the nostalgia hit parade. And in their exciting act, ''Love and Payne,'' which plays through Oct. 5 at Feinstein's at the Regency, both singers present three-dimensional musical personalities that their hits only hinted at.

title: A Quest for a People Who May No Longer Exist
description: ACROSS THE SABBATH RIVER

title: Corrections
description: Unmarried Mothers

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Kills Woman In Wheelchair
description: A disabled 73-year-old woman died yesterday when fire ripped through the top two floors of the building where she lived in Morningside Heights. The cause is under investigation. The victim, identified by a relative as Norma Martin, was in a wheelchair and could not escape from her fifth-floor apartment. The fire destroyed the fifth and sixth floors of 521 West 111th Street. All other occupants escaped without injury, but two firefighters suffered minor burns and were treated at New York Weill Cornell Medical Center, said Firefighter Robert Calis, a department spokesman.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Protesters Detained
description: The police detained 54 protesters in a sweep through a tent city set up outside the office of President Leonid D. Kuchma after a demonstration on Monday. Some 120 tents had been erected against government orders after the protest, which drew 20,000 people to downtown Kiev. Several thousand more protesters gathered yesterday and opposition leaders called for another protest next week. Mr. Kuchma, 64, has been snarled in scandal since recorded conversations seemed to link him to the kidnapping of a journalist in 1999; he strongly denies the charge. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Salt Lake Profit Tops Forecast
description: The Salt Lake City Winter Olympics, which hoped to break even on a $1.3 billion budget, had a $101 million profit, organizers said.

title: Sidney Epstein -- Journalist, 81
description: Sidney Epstein, a Washington journalist who covered or supervised coverage of news events including the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and the 1968 riots that devastated large parts of Washington, died on Sunday in Rockville, Md. He was 81 and had Alzheimer's disease, said his nephew Jerry Ceppos.

title: LaWanda Page, 81, the Aunt On TV's 'Sanford and Son'
description: LaWanda Page, the acid-tongued comedienne who, as the cantankerous Aunt Esther, traded barbs with Redd Foxx on the 1970's sitcom ''Sanford and Son,'' died on Saturday in Los Angeles. She was 81.

title: National Briefing: Consumers
description: RECALL OF TAINTED BEEF

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin's Pressure On Georgia
description: President Vladimir V. Putin dismissed actions taken by Georgia to control its border with Chechnya, and criticized a letter from President Eduard A. Shevardnadze, saying it provided no guarantees that Georgia would stop Chechen fighters from operating on Georgian territory. Last week Mr. Putin threatened military strikes against what he called terrorists operating from Georgia. Georgia, to placate Russia, promised yesterday to extradite 13 men Russia says are Chechen guerrillas. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, MARTIN
description: UNGER-Martin. Town and Village Synagogue-Tifereth Israel mourns the loss of its long standing member and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Frances and the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Cantor Shayna Smith Dr. Roselyn Kolodny, Pres.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Irvington: Bus Terminal Expansion
description: The state plans a $4 million expansion of the Irvington bus terminal, New Jersey's second busiest, James P. Fox, the state transportation commissioner, announced yesterday. Construction is expected to begin in August 2003. The project would add two bus lanes, a parking lot, more public restrooms and a larger waiting area. The terminal, built in 1947, handles 10,000 passengers daily and is second only to the terminal in Newark.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about Kmart's quarterly results misstated the company's loss for August. It was $126 million, not $144 million.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIMMEL, ARNOLD
description: KIMMEL-Arnold. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 19th at 4PM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISKIN, ANNA E.
description: DISKIN-Anna E. On September 16, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Martin J. Diskin and Annie (nee Duffy). Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St), NYC Wednesday, 3-5 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday at 10 AM at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Plainfield, NJ.

title: More Offerings Are Questioned
description: Congressional investigators have asked the Goldman Sachs Group and Credit Suisse First Boston for information on more companies that the firms helped to take public.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bad loans and weak trading will reduce J.P. Morgan Chase's earnings more than expected.
description: EARNINGS at J. P. Morgan Chase & Company will be even worse than expected in the third quarter because of bad loans to telecommunications companies and weak trading results, the company said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about a plan to incinerate chemical weapons at the Army depot in Anniston, Ala., referred incorrectly in some copies to the deadline set by a global treaty for the destruction of such weapons. It is 2007, not 2004.

title: Toshiba and NEC Join Forces To Develop Magnetic Chip
description: Toshiba and NEC, Japan's two largest chip makers, said today that they would jointly develop a new generation of memory chips.

title: Rivera's Return Is Set for Weekend
description: The return of Mariano Rivera is finally coming into focus for the Yankees. After another strong session throwing batting practice today, Rivera will rest Wednesday, throw a light bullpen session Thursday and return to the Yankees in Detroit this weekend.

title: Editor From Fortune Gets Entertainment Weekly Post
description: In a move that surprised many on the outside and disappointed some inside Entertainment Weekly, Rick Tetzeli, the deputy managing editor of Fortune magazine, was named managing editor of Entertainment Weekly yesterday.

title: Rebel Wants Japan's Inventors To Get Some U.S.-Style Rewards
description: Ordered to stop the scientific research he thought extremely promising, Shuji Nakamura hid the work from his superiors at a Japanese chemical company. He secretly obtained patents in the company's name.

title: To These Pestos, Basil Is Just a Beginning
description: In New York City's Greenmarkets, Craig Colvin, far left, and Katie Booth are called the pesto people. With good reason. Mr. Colvin, who owns Sweet Pea Organics and Bear Pond Farm in Washington Depot, Conn., and Ms. Booth, who works with him at the Greenmarkets, sell pesto that he makes from the organic herbs he grows.

title: Daschle Attacks Bush's Record on the Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18  The Senate majority leader offered a blistering assessment of President Bush's fiscal record today, citing a "tragic trend" of two million lost jobs, weak economic growth and a stock market decline he called unparalleled since Herbert Hoover.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSKY, MORTIMER
description: LIPSKY-Mortimer. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Co., P.C., mourn the passing of our esteemed partner and founder. His intellect, his passion for knowledge and learning, his resolve and determination, was an inspiration to all. He so ably taught and guided us. This compassionate man had a deep understanding and love for all mankind. He deeply loved his family, whom he protected, fought for, honored, and was so proud of. This was so evident in his actions and deeds. The love, devotion, care, respect, and dedication that he bestowed upon his wife Ann, who passed away, was admired & respected. To his children, Mark, Judy, Joel & Shari, his wife Norma, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, our heartfelt condolences. Mort will be truly missed, but not forgotten.

title: A Fierce Battle Over Cats . . . in a Township Named Morris
description: Dian Freeman keeps 12 cats at her handsome Tudor home, which really bothers Sharon Remlinger, her neighbor across Brigade Hill Road. Ms. Remlinger has a big German shepherd, which really bothers Ms. Freeman.

title: A Contrarian From Istanbul Arrives, Bearing Non-Turkish Delights
description: Ayse Dizioglu, left, had a bakery in Istanbul. Being something of a contrarian -- one trained to make French- and Italian-style pastries -- she specialized in American-style cheesecake, not baklava. And at the Polka Dot Bake Shop, which she opened last month at 312 Bleecker Street (Grove Street), no baklava is to be found. ''I like to make nicely decorated small cakes,'' she said.

title: Shanghai Journal; The Brothers Are in the Deconstruction Business
description: Ni Daimei values Shanghai's old European-style row houses as much as any preservationist. He knows exactly how much they are worth, every brick, plank and tile.

title: In Nassau, A Warning About Taxes Rising in 2006
description: As soon as County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi delivered his $2.3 billion budget proposal for 2003 today, his fellow Democrats on the Nassau County Legislature endorsed it as a solution to the county's fiscal crisis.

title: Baltic Bones, Laid Bare
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Still Expects Increase In Revenue
description: Intuit, the world's biggest maker of tax-preparation software, said it still expected $1.7 billion to $1.8 billion in revenue for fiscal 2003, a 25 percent to 33 percent increase from the previous year. The company, which had $1.36 billion in revenue for the year ended July 31, expects about 37 percent of its revenue growth over the next year to come from acquisitions, it said in a statement.

title: Foreign Threat Was Focus Before 9/11, Panel Finds
description: United States intelligence officials focused so much attention on the potential for attacks by Al Qaeda overseas that they underestimated reports before last Sept. 11 warning of a domestic attack, the joint Congressional committee investigating the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks has found.

title: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: Brewer's Profit Is Up
description: The South African company that bought the Miller Brewing Company, SABMiller, as it is now called, said revenue and earnings for the five months ended Aug. 31 were higher than during the period a year ago. The growth was buoyed by strong sales in Central and Eastern Europe as well as in Africa. Sales of the Miller Brewing Company's own lager in the United States were below that of year-ago levels, but in line with the company's expectations, Graham Mackay, the chief executive, said in a statement. The amount of beer sold in Poland and the Czech Republic increased compared with last year, as did volumes in most major African markets, except for South Africa. Growth in Russia was smaller than SABMiller had anticipated. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Astonish the Crowd. Cook a Cucumber.
description: THE king of cool has a warm side.

title: The Mango's Saucier Side
description: THERE'S a creation -- you can hardly call it a ''dish'' -- that is sold on street corners all over the world. It is cut fruit sprinkled with salt, cayenne or chili powder, and lime. Usually featuring mangoes, and meant to be eaten out of hand, it is a great snack and, by the standards of most Americans, exotic. Ten years ago, few of us would have conceived of combining salt and chili with fruit.

title: Radio Problem Could Last Years, Fire Dept. Says
description: New York City's fire commissioner said yesterday that it could be several years before all the necessary equipment for reliable communications inside the city's tallest buildings is bought or found and connected.

title: School Reform Initiative Names Director
description: CONSTANCIA WARREN, who for years has helped schools create partnerships with public and private organizations, has been named a senior program officer and director of the Urban School Reform Initiative at the Carnegie Corporation.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Microchip Predicts Higher Earnings
description: Microchip Technology, a maker of microchips for cars, appliances, computer equipment and security systems, said fiscal second-quarter earnings would be higher than expected. Shares of Microchip rose $1.64, or nearly 11 percent, to $17; they have fallen more than 30 percent this year. Revenue for the quarter ending Sept. 30 is expected to be $169 million to $171 million, up about 6 percent to 7 percent from the fiscal first quarter, company officials said. Steve Sanghi, chief executive of Microchip, said the company's largest business segments -- consumer and automotive products -- were showing strong growth despite the sluggish economy.

title: Verification Is Difficult at Best, Say the Experts, and Maybe Impossible
description: Although United Nations inspectors say they may be prepared to resume their work within three weeks of a green light from the United Nations Security Council, verifying Iraq's assertions that it has abandoned weapons of mass destruction, or finding evidence that it has not done so, may not be feasible, according to officials and former weapons inspectors.

title: Only Smiles, No Scowls, As Ewing Says Goodbye
description: For this day, at least, there was no acrimony. No angry fans. No critical news media. Patrick Ewing's retirement after 17 mostly distinguished seasons as a pro basketball player turned into a lovefest.

title: Global Street Fare Is Alive With Flavor
description: THERE is a certain absurdity in a cookbook about Mediterranean street food. You imagine the author tracking down a vendor of fried-pork sandwiches, cornering him on the fine points of a recipe that has never been recorded, and then going home and writing a recipe so that it can be prepared in a nonstick pan for a family of four and served on a pretty ceramic platter.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 25 about the opening of Trapeze School New York in Hudson River Park misstated the location of a school directed earlier by the new school's owner, Jonathan Conant. It was near New Paltz, not in Poughkeepsie. The article also referred imprecisely to the status of those earlier trapeze classes. Although the school closed as a business, classes are still offered by the nonprofit Center for Symbolic Studies under the name Trapeze Club at Stone Mountain Farm.

title: A Rush to Get It Right in Florida Produces More Election Wrongs
description: Six months after his state became a laughingstock for the 36-day stalemate in the 2000 presidential election, Gov. Jeb Bush declared that Florida would become a ''model for the rest of the nation'' in reforming elections. But now that Florida has spent $32 million to overhaul its voting system, some experts say the state may serve as a model of what not to do.

title: Review/Fashion; Candy Visions of Spring, A Little Blurred at the Edges
description: One observation to be made from a glance at the current issue of People magazine, which is devoted to the best and worst dressed, is that the culture has produced inordinate opportunities for people to look bad. If there were no such thing as the Radio Music Awards, maybe it would never have occurred to Kim Delaney to go out and find an evening gown that would make her look like an exaggerated serving spoon.

title: Terrorism's Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Just-in-Time Pastry
description: ARRIVING at the table like a piece of postmodern architecture on a plate, the white peach strudel at Danube didn't look the way I had expected.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: WISCONSIN: MAYOR PAYS TO SETTLE SUIT

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Life Sentence Sought In Stabbing
description: A federal prosecutor asked a federal judge yesterday to rule that when Mamdouh Mahmud Salim, a reputed official of Al Qaeda, stabbed a jail guard in late 2000, the act was related to terrorism and made Mr. Salim liable for a term of life imprisonment. The prosecutor, Robert Buehler, said that Mr. Salim, 44, who is accused of being a top aide to Osama bin Laden, was trying to take hostages and win the release of other terrorism suspects when he stabbed the guard. If the judge does not agree, Mr. Salim, who has pleaded guilty to the stabbing, could receive 14 to 17 years. His lawyer, Richard B. Lind, said that Mr. Salim never made hostage demands or sought to free other prisoners. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Not All Sunshine for Teensy Set's Troubadour
description: You almost don't want to meet Raffi in person. You want to preserve the vision of the man you know only as a voice, lulling squirmy children in the back seat of the car with original folk songs like ''One Light, One Sun,'' or standards with a twist like ''This Little Light of Mine.''

title: Manhattanville College Rises in Ratings
description: For much of its history, Manhattanville College was listed as a second- or third-tier school in the annual rankings compiled by U. S. News & World Report. But this year the college, in Purchase, N.Y., made the jump to the first tier among northern universities offering undergraduate and master's programs. The college, which has 1,430 full-time undergraduates and 1,000 graduate students, rose, in part, because of improved SAT scores and a better faculty-student ratio, college officials said. Merri Rosenberg

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINE, HARRY
description: PINE-Harry. Beloved husband of the late Annette, devoted father of Larry and Harriet, and the late Mark Pine. Adored grandfather of Debbie and Barry Kay, Lori and Roy Fabry, Ronni and Jordan Metzger, Jeff and Shadow Pine, Samara and Howard Gluck, and Jason Pine. Great grandfather of twelve. Dear brother of Jennie Gugick, and Helen Zeines. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 9:30 A.M. Thursday.

title: U.S. Names 7th Man in Qaeda Cell Near Buffalo and Calls His Role Pivotal
description: Federal officials today identified Kamal Derwish, a former resident of this city whose religious fervor had attracted a number of local young men, as the person who had helped arrange their training in what federal authorities say was a cell of Al Qaeda.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Protest Against President
description: More than two dozen people were injured and four former legislators were arrested after riot squads used water cannons to break up three days of street demonstrations demanding the resignation of President Luis Gonzlez Macchi. Local news reports described the 9,000 protesters as supporters of the president's main rival, Gen. Lino Oviedo, who lives in exile in Brazil but is seeking an amnesty that would allow him to run for president next year. General Oviedo fled after being accused of organizing coups, including one that resulted in the assassination of a vice president in March 1999. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRENADIER, SIMON
description: GRENADIER - Simon. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherisned member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Patricia Lampl, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: How U.S. Punishes States That Set Higher Standards
description: THE new federal education law lets students leave high-poverty schools that are deemed failing. Districts must now use some of their federal money to bus these students to better schools.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: PARAGUAY: PROTEST AGAINST PRESIDENT More than two dozen people were injured and four former legislators were arrested after riot squads used water cannons to break up three days of street demonstrations demanding the resignation of President Luis Gonzalez Macchi. Local news reports described the 9,000 protesters as supporters of the president's main rival, Gen. Lino Oviedo, who lives in exile in Brazil but is seeking an amnesty that would allow him to run for president next year. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENBERG, THEDIS
description: SCHENBERG - Thedis. Be loved wife of the late Edward. Dear sister of Frances Lacher. Devoted aunt of Didi and Irene Lacher. Cherished great-aunt of Sam Donaldson.

title: When It Comes to School Discipline, Bloomberg's Motto Is Safety First
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the Department of Education would aggressively ferret out and punish disruptive students in the public schools, particularly those in schools with high rates of criminal violence, and hold the principals more accountable for reducing disciplinary problems within their schools.

title: U.S. Moves Commandos to Base in East Africa
description: Hundreds of American Special Operations forces have been quietly moved to a military base in East Africa for missions against fighters with Al Qaeda who are believed to be hiding throughout the region, but especially in Yemen, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISCO, LEONARD GERARD
description: BISCO - Leonard Gerard. Passed away peacefully on September 11, 2002 in Saint Paul Les Trois Chateaux, France at the age of 99. Leonard Bisco is remembered as a prominent New York City attorney whose firm, Newman and Bisco, was involved in the merger of Manufacturer's Trust Co. and Hanover Trust Co. in the 1950s. In addition, he was an active participant in an important will contest in Florida involving the John Ringling North Estate and also handled a number of other significant, litigated matters in New York and elsewhere. He is survived by his loving children Susan M. Bisco, Martine Mileti and Dr. Michael Bisco, and grandchildren Alex Aaron, Deborah Bisco, Dr. Sharon Bisco and David Bisco. We will miss his generous spirit, graciousness and fine sense of humor. We will remember his passion for life and learning, his love of music, books and the arts. Cremation services September 16th in France. Memorial service in New York City to take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be sent to Saint Francis Breadline, c/o Saint Francis of Assisi Church, 135 W. 31 St., N.Y., N.Y. 10001.

title: The City Life; Stolen Glimpses
description: I don't know much about my neighbors in the window across the air shaft. I know that he sits with his knees up and his feet on the couch watching a ballgame late most evenings. She sits, facing the opposite way, with her knees up and her feet on the couch reading the paper early most mornings. The two are young and they have a cat that comes to the door in the dark apartment when the hall light goes on. It's taken me five years of unintentional glimpses through their window to learn this much. It seems like a quiet life over there. They've never looked my way when I've been looking theirs, but I know that if they caught my eye, I'd feel indicted. They clearly believe they get enough privacy even without closing the drapes. A lot of New Yorkers feel that way, and a lot of New Yorkers feel the way I do, too, which is entitled to look and somehow ashamed of looking at the same time.

title: Chefs Join Campaign Against Altered Fish
description: IN a pre-emptive strike against the newest genetically engineered food, 200 chefs, grocers and seafood distributors across 40 states plan to announce today that they have pledged not to purchase fish that have been altered through biotechnology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAVITIAN, ARMENO
description: TAVITIAN-Armeno. On September 15, 2002 at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Ohanes Tavitian. Loving mother of Henry and Aso Tavitian. Dear sister of the late Anahit Ohanessian and Haroutun Hokotzian. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, Tuesday, September 17th, 2-5 & 7-9PM. Funeral service at Saint Vartan's Armenian Cathedral, 630 2nd Avenue at 34th St, Wednesday 10:30AM.

title: Classical Elegance, With Food au Courant
description: ONCE upon a time, ladies and gentlemen dressed up to dine in fine restaurants. Propriety was expected for the theater, and for airplane travel, too. Nowadays, formality seems like ancient history, as vestigial as fish knives and sauce spoons.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Aramark, Philadelphia, named Sharpe Partners, New York, to handle online advertising for its convention and tourism services division, initially focusing on 14 national-park destinations that Aramark manages. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Text: Full Transcript from Testimony on Attacks
description: Following is the full transcript of the testimony yesterday of Eleanor Hill, staff director of an inquiry into the Sept. 11 attacks, before a joint Congressional committee, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. SEN. GRAHAM: Ms. Eleanor Hill, staff director of the joint inquiry committee. MS. HILL: Good morning, senator. Good morning, Chairman Graham, Chairman Goss, members of these committees. Before I proceed with my statement, I have a long written statement which I would like to submit for the record, and I am going to orally summarize it, given the length of what we have here. SEN. GRAHAM: Your full statement will appear in the record. MS. HILL: Thank you. But before I get into the main part of the statement, I do want to make clear to you and members of the committee that the information that is in this statement that we are going to present this morning has been cleared for public release.
