Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Saddam Hussein Makes an Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Defensive Breakdown Bewilders The Jets
description: On Monday, Ted Cottrell looked like a man who had lost plenty of sleep and was preparing for more of the same this week.

title: U.S. Pressing NATO for Rapid Reaction Force
description: The United States will press NATO to create a permanent rapid reaction force to help improve the alliance's combat readiness in the face of terrorist threats, senior American and European officials said today.

title: National Briefing | Consumers: 2 Bobble Head Dolls Are Benched
description: About 100,000 bobble head dolls sold at McDonald's restaurants in Illinois and northwest Indiana are being recalled because of fears over lead poisoning. The paint on some of the dolls contains excessive amounts of lead and may be hazardous if ingested. McDonald's officials said they had not received any reports of injuries or illness and were taking the step as a precaution with the cooperation of the Consumer Products Safety Commission. The dolls are in the likeness of the Chicago Bears players Brian Urlacher and Anthony Thomas and were sold in August and September. Daniel I. Dorfman (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Novelist Tried For Anti-Islam Remark
description: The writer Michel Houellebecq, who is as famous in France as a provocateur as he is for his sex-laden novels, went on trial on charges of inciting racial hatred by describing Islam as ''the most stupid religion.'' In his defense, Mr. Houellebecq said he had never shown disdain for Muslims, only for Islam. He made his remark about Islam last year while promoting his third novel, ''Plateforme,'' which includes a massacre carried out by Islamic extremists. If convicted, he could face a year in jail or a $50,000 fine, but the prosecutor told the court there were no grounds for a criminal prosecution. The court is to rule on Oct. 22. Alan Riding (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHIQUITA BRANDS INTERNATIONAL, Cincinnati, said it would buy substantially all the interests in Scipio, the owner of Chiquita's main distributor in Germany. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Cable Deal Moves Closer To Approval
description: The Comcast Corporation and AT&T said yesterday that their proposed cable television merger had cleared a Justice Department hurdle as the agency took no action under antitrust legislation. The companies said that the official waiting period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Act for government questions about the proposed merger had lapsed, meaning that the legislation can no longer be used by the Justice Department to stop the deal. Last December, AT&T agreed to sell its cable television business, the nation's largest, to Comcast for about $47 billion in stock. The deal, now worth about $28 billion, remains on track to be completed during the fourth quarter of this year, although several regulatory hurdles remain. The companies said they would continue to cooperate with the Justice Department on antitrust issues. Shares in both companies rose yesterday. Special Class A shares of Comcast rose 48 cents, to $24.30. AT&T rose 31 cents, to $12.63. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Plans Share Sale
description: Zurich Financial Services, Switzerland's biggest insurer, plans to sell about $2.5 billion of stock at less than half the current market price to improve its ability to pay claims. Zurich Financial will sell shares for at least 65 Swiss francs ($43) each, the company said. The stock closed Monday at 135 francs.

title: Irregular Season Begins: Dolphins Face Nemesis Jets
description: Zach Thomas, the Miami Dolphins' spark plug of a middle linebacker, was talking about losing streaks and the Jets the other day when he stopped himself so he could watch one of his favorite television commercials. It's the one where a sports bar is filled with quietly agonizing Jets fans, a quiet soon broken by the celebration of a teal-and-orange-clad Dolphins fan who has the temerity to raise his voice in a Jets-dominated establishment.

title: Rift Seen at U.N. Over Next Steps to Deal With Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 17  The United States insisted here today on keeping up the pressure on Iraq with a tough new Security Council resolution, while Russia, France, China and the Arab nations said Iraq's decision to allow the return of international weapons inspectors was enough to hold off stronger action for the time being.

title: TWO UNIONS AT US AIRWAYS AGREE TO CONCESSIONS
description: Two labor groups voted yesterday in favor of concessions proposed by executives at US Airways, which is operating under bankruptcy protection. Ticket agents and gate workers represented by the Communications Workers of America ratified a concession agreement by 75 percent, while mechanics represented by the International Association of Machinists ratified its package by 57 percent. On Aug. 28, the mechanics voted to reject the package, and US Airways said it would pursue the concessions through bankruptcy court. The union said it had decided to vote again after David N. Siegel, the chief executive, acknowledged that remarks he had made might have caused confusion before the first vote. All the major labor groups at US Airways have now agreed to concessions, which the airline needs to get a federal loan guarantee. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Hershey Auction Halted

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 8 with the front-page Home Front column in the Job Market section, about the demographic profile of unmarried mothers in the city, misstated percentages for education levels and citizenship status. A corrected version appears today, on Page B3.

title: Lemon Fizzes on the Banks of the Euphrates
description: The trap is sprung. The name of the game is containment.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bond Issue
description: Thailand's government approved a $1 billion bond sale, the Southeast Asian nation's first global sale since the 1997-98 financial crisis. The 10-year bonds will be marketed to overseas investors next month, Sommai Phasee, the finance ministry's deputy permanent secretary, told reporters after a cabinet meeting. The country is seeking to pay about $1.6 billion of foreign-currency debt with money borrowed at lower interest rates. It owes the money to the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and the Japan Bank for International Cooperation.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If I were sitting in the Security Council, which I'm not, I would in the next days sleep with my eyes wide open and the boots on.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Wide Smoking Ban Is Urged
description: A group of Suffolk County lawmakers introduced a bill yesterday to ban smoking in virtually all workplaces, including indoor restaurants and bars. The bill is similar to proposals in Nassau County and New York City, and is part of an effort to tighten smoking restrictions uniformly downstate, the Suffolk legislators said. Smoking is currently permitted in Suffolk County bars that derive less than 40 percent of their revenue from food sales and in restaurants with fully enclosed and ventilated smoking sections. If approved, the law will take effect in 2004.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: GROCER'S PROFIT UP Tesco, Britain's biggest supermarket chain, reported first-half net profit rose 15 percent to $360 million, despite a slowdown in the growth of its same-store sales at its British stores from 7 percent last year to 3.9 percent. As it presses to expand overseas business in 10 countries from Thailand to Ireland, the retailer also reported a 79 percent increase in international operating profit, to about $90 million. Tesco's shares fell by 5 percent, however, because of slowing sales growth in Britain and disappointment with the firm's international sales growth, analysts said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Going to the Opera in Houston, but Watching It on TV
description: Luci Nix does not carry opera glasses when she watches Houston Grand Opera perform in the Brown Theater at the Wortham Theater Center. She is short, so she avoids sitting downstairs because a sea of heads usually blocks her view. Watching the company perform ''Rigoletto'' and ''Of Mice and Men'' last season, Ms. Nix and her husband abandoned their lower-balcony subscription seats at intermission and moved nearby to catch the rest of the show on video monitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSKIND, MARJORIE H.
description: SUSSKIND-Marjorie H. On September 17, 2002. Daughter of Mildred and Louis Friedman. Beloved wife of the late David Susskind and the late Ira Schwam. Mother of Judith Gloch and Lawrence Susskind. Mother-in-law of Arthur Gloch and Leslie Tuttle. Grandmother of Lily and Noah Susskind. Private services being arranged at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, Bklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMINGHAM, BETH RENY
description: BERMINGHAM-Beth Reny, 74. Of Scarsdale, on September 17, 2002 surrounded by her family. She was the dearly beloved wife of John H. Bermingham for 52 years. Mother of seven children, sons Thomas V. II, John H. Jr., Jerrold G. and Douglas McDonald (deceased) and daughters Maryclaire Fouse, Paula Filippone and Amy Wilson. Grandmother of 15. A 1948 graduate of College of New Rochelle, she was a former president of Catholic Women's Club of Westchester and of Immaculate Heart of Mary School PTA. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home on September 18, 7-9PM and September 19, 2-4 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale, N.Y., September 20, at 10AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Rev. Thomas V. Bermingham, S.J. Scholarship Fund, Fordham University, Bronx, NY.

title: Saddam Hussein Makes an Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Drop in Overseas Sales Hurts Oracle
description: Blaming lower-than-expected sales in Europe and Asia, the Oracle Corporation reported first-quarter software sales today that were on the low end of earlier projections.

title: Bronx Boy, 5, Is Hurt in Fall From Bus
description: A 5-year-old Bronx boy was critically injured yesterday afternoon when he apparently fell out of an emergency side door of a city school bus that was taking him home from kindergarten, the authorities said.

title: Saddam Hussein Makes an Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Inspectors: 63 Experts from 27 Countries
description: The United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission, better known by the acronym Unmovic, was created in December 1999. It inherited the mandate of the United Nations Special Commission, known as Unscom, which the Security Council inaugurated at the close of the Persian Gulf war in 1991 to disarm Iraq of chemical and biological weapons and missiles with a range of more than about 100 miles, and to ensure that Iraq not reacquire such weapons.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Pro-Indian Editor Shot
description: The editor of The Srinagar Times, Sofi Ghulam Mohammad, 65, was wounded by gunmen presumed to be anti-Indian militants. He has come under attack several times by militants who accused him of being pro-India. His paper backed the state elections that began on Monday, which militants vowed to disrupt. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Not Just Crunchy, This Sea Salt
description: Sea salt, especially from France, is the seasoning du jour. Whether it actually seasons better than ordinary table salt or kosher salt is open to debate. But coarse-grained sea salt does add crunch, and some varieties have other distinctive characteristics as well.

title: Massachusetts Democrats Pick Nominee For Governor
description: Shannon P. O'Brien, the Massachusetts state treasurer, won a heavily contested Democratic primary for governor tonight and will face Mitt Romney, the Republican venture capitalist, in the general election.

title: BAYER GRANTED UNITED STATES APPROVAL FOR H.I.V. TEST
description: Bayer, Germany's largest drug maker, said yesterday that it had received Food and Drug Administration approval for a test that identifies H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The test, called Versant, can detect the amount of all major types of human immunodeficiency virus in the blood and can help in monitoring the disease and measuring the effectiveness of any therapy, Bayer said. Bayer is based in Leverkusen, Germany. The product will compete with two tests made by Roche Holding of Switzerland. Bayer's test eliminates a stage needed in the Roche system and covers with a single test the range of infection levels that required two Roche tests, Bayer said.

title: Atlantic Canada
description: Aseven-day fly-drive vacation to Nova Scotia costs $799 a person, based on double occupancy, with departures through Oct. 31. The price, for flights from New York or Boston on Air Canada , includes seven nights' accommodations, a rental car with unlimited mileage and admission to a dinner theater. From Chicago or Atlanta, it's $1,069. Call Maxxim Vacations in St. John's, Newfoundland, at (800) 567-6666 or visit www.maxximvacations.com .

title: G.M. and Canadian Workers Reach Pact, Averting Strike
description: General Motors and the Canadian Auto Workers union agreed tonight on a new three-year contract covering 19,000 workers in Canada, just five hours before a strike deadline set by the union.

title: Gotti Brother Must Stay In Solitary, For Now
description: A federal appeals court panel yesterday blocked the release of Peter Gotti, the brother of John J. Gotti, from solitary confinement into a general prison population after prosecutors contended that he is still able to coordinate criminal activity from prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPLAS, ROMAIN JEAN BERNARD
description: dePLAS-Romain Jean Bernard. On September 14, 2002 at age 31. Beloved son of Pierre dePlas and Roberta Gootrad. Devoted brother of Joanna dePlas. Dearest grandson of Violet Butler Ledger. Memorial service on Thursday, September 19, at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at 73rd St., 3 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Museum of Modern Art to support the Internship Program in the Memory of Romain dePlas.

title: Industrial Complex Available for $1
description: It is no secret that the jobs are leaving this city. Every assembly line worker, machinist and scientist could see it coming four years ago, when the pharmaceutical company Bayer, which once employed 3,000 people here, sold an undeveloped 400 acres near the airport that it had held in reserve for decades as a new headquarters site.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bristol: Escaped Prisoner Captured
description: A prisoner who escaped from Bristol Superior Court lockup on Monday was captured that evening at a motel. The prisoner, Scott D. Wells, 35, of Plainville, was charged yesterday with escape from custody and criminal mischief and is being held in $1 million bail. Mr. Wells climbed over a chain-link fence holding pen and fled through a courthouse door Monday afternoon after being arraigned on domestic violence charges, the state police said. He was rearrested about 10 p.m. at the Southington Motor Lodge after a tip from employees. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about preparations for Fashion Week in Manhattan referred imprecisely in some copies to the starting day of the spring shows. While the shows started yesterday, those on the runways in Bryant Park begin today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANSCHER, BERNARD
description: ANSCHER-Bernard, 80. Died September 4, 2002, Miami, FL. Founder National Molding Corporation, Farmingdale, N.Y. Survived by loving family. Funeral private.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: NOVELIST TRIED FOR ANTI-ISLAM REMARK The writer Michel Houellebecq, who is as famous in France as a provocateur as he is for his sex-laden novels, went on trial on charges of inciting racial hatred by describing Islam as "the most stupid religion." In his defense, Mr. Houellebecq said he had never shown disdain for Muslims, only for Islam. He made his remark about Islam last year while promoting his third novel, "Plateforme," which includes a massacre carried out by Islamic extremists. If convicted, he could face a year in jail or a $50,000 fine, but the prosecutor told the court there were no grounds for a criminal prosecution. The court is to rule on Oct. 22.

title: Saddam Hussein Makes an Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Buoyed by Hope And Powered by Passing
description: Wellington Mara has watched a few Giants games through the years with the measured perspective of a realist. He would never believe a 50-point deficit could be overcome, nor would he fret with a 50-point advantage. When the St. Louis Rams kept shaving the Giants' lead Sunday, from 17 points to 3 to 2, what Mara thought in the fourth quarter was that even if the Rams took the lead, the Giants might still win.

title: Pairings: A Versatile Accompanist for Lamb and Many Other Foods
description: YOU won't find a lot of features about Crozes-Hermitage in wine publications. Nobody calls a Crozes ''killer,'' or brings along a bottle to make a big impression on a client. But when I find a few bottles of Crozes on a restaurant wine list, I know right away that a brain is at work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDKIN, CORDELIA CLARK
description: RUDKIN-Cordelia Clark, 77, of Fairfield, CT, died Monday, September 16, 2002 at Norwalk Hospital, after a courageous battle with cancer. A lifelong resident of Fairfield, Sis was born on November 28, 1924 to the late Charles Cameron Clark, an architect in both NYC and CT, and Agnes Selkirk Clark, a landscape architect. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday 11 AM at Trinity Episcopal Church, 651 Pequot Road. in Southport. Memorial donations may be directed to Pequot Library Assoc., 720 Pequot Ave. Southport CT 06497. For further information go to www.leskofuneralhome.com

title: U.S. Diplomats Seek Immunity From London Driving Fee
description: The diplomat did not want anyone to know he had talked to a reporter. Not about the explosive subject of London's proposed daily fee on cars driving into the center of town.

title: Hyundai heir announces Seoul run
description: SEOUL:  Chung Mong Joon, the son of a billionaire tycoon who ran unsuccessfully for president of South Korea 10 years ago, declared his candidacy for president Tuesday on a platform that promises to continue President Kim Dae Jung's policy of reconciliation with North Korea.

title: Devil Rays Get the Best Of the Yanks' Relief Corps
description: It was probably asking too much for the Yankees to be perfect without Mariano Rivera, the best reliever in their history. Until tonight, though, Rivera's replacements had converted all 16 save opportunities during his last two stints on the disabled list.

title: An Umbrella in the Outfield
description: When I was 14, I was watching ABC's "Monday Night Baseball" telecast of a game between the Cubs and Giants at Candlestick Park. Somebody hit a ball down the right field line and it bounced toward the small, enclosed shack where the Giants' relievers sat. As the ball skipped toward that area, a reliever closed the door just as the ball slipped through. The ball was gone, and the fielder chasing after it was utterly confused.

title: Bornstein Named Adviser to N.F.L.
description: Steve Bornstein, a former president of ESPN and of ABC Television, was named an adviser to the N.F.L. yesterday to provide advice on television and media issues.

title: Afghans Intercept Fuel Truck Aimed at U.S.-Run Air Base
description: Preventing what might have been a major terrorist attack on American troops, the Afghan police on Saturday intercepted a booby-trapped tanker gorged with jet fuel and destined for the American military air base north of Kabul, the commander of international peacekeeping troops said today.

title: GUIDANT FORECASTS MAJOR INCREASE IN SALES IN 2003
description: The Guidant Corporation expects sales of more than $4 billion in 2003, about one-third more than this year's projected revenue, as the company sells more devices used in heart surgery. The estimate includes sales from the planned purchase of a rival, the Cook Group, a purchase that is expected to close in January, the company said. Including Cook, per-share profit is forecast at $2.15 to $2.21 next year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of $2.17. Guidant is buying Cook to secure the right to sell a drug-coated artery-clearing tube called a stent. For 2002, Guidant, based in Indianapolis, expects sales of $3 billion to $3.2 billion and profit of $2 to $2.06 a share. Thomson First Call estimated $2.07 a share.

title: Commander's Visit Part of Growing Role for Qatar
description: The commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, Gen. Tommy R. Franks, arrived here today for talks about the rapidly expanding American military presence in this gulf state that is expected to play a key role in a war against Iraq.

title: Getting It Right in the Rhone
description: ACCEPTED wisdom decrees that Crozes-Hermitage, from the Rhone Valley, has never really been a wine to stir one's soul or excite the palate. The Dining section's tasting panel vigorously begs to differ. Not since this group was assembled in May has a wine captured our enthusiasm as much as the 23 Crozes-Hermitage wines we sipped last week. So much for wisdom.

title: If Death Takes a Holiday, Where Does He Go? The Twilight Zone
description: ''The Twilight Zone'' is back, huh? When did it go away? Episodes of the original anthology series of suspense tales, which ran from 1959 to 1965, continue to show up on television. The show inspired a theatrical film in 1983, a short-lived weekly series in 1985 and a television movie in 1994.

title: Defiant California City Hands Out Marijuana
description: Christopher Krohn, mayor of this laid-back beach town, wore his pinstriped suit to work today because he wanted to appear serious before the television cameras.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, JULIAN A.
description: GREGORY-Julian A. Of Wilton, Connecticut died September 16. He was a graduate of Princeton University, Class of 1935 and University of Michigan Law School, Class of 1938. Son of the late Julian A. Gregory and Virginia Evans Gregory, he is survived by his sister, Virginia Perry, his wife Margaret, son Julian A. Gregory, Jr., daughter-in-law Molly, and five grandchildren. He was a former Selectman of the Town of Wilton and founding partner of the New York City and Wilton law firm of Gregory and Adams. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 19 at 2:00 P.M. at the Wilton Congregational Church, Route 33, Wilton, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be sent to Princeton University or the Wilton Library Building Fund.

title: Man Admits Poisoning Food in Rival's Shop, Killing 38 in China
description: A jealous business rival has confessed to spiking the food in a snack shop in eastern China with rat poison, killing 38 people, mostly schoolchildren, and sending hundreds more to the hospital, state news organizations reported tonight.

title: Democrats Try Compromise On Domestic Security Bill
description: Senate Democrats struggled furiously today to reach a compromise on worker rights in an effort to get the stalled homeland security bill moving again.

title: Checketts Is Sorry Ewing Left
description: When Patrick Ewing put together his plans to announce his retirement, he asked Dave Checketts, the former president of Madison Square Garden, to introduce him at his news conference yesterday.

title: The Eagles Commandeered Spurrier's Spotlight
description: With the ball at the Redskins' 5-yard line with a little more than a minute remaining and 37 points and a 30-point lead already compiled, Philadelphia faced fourth down and 4. Eagles Coach Andy Reid decided to call a measly countercutback run by Duce Staley that lost a yard.

title: Players Please Trottier By Adjusting to Pace
description: Bobby Holik, a 12-year veteran in the N.H.L., called his first training camp with the Rangers one of the most challenging he had experienced in several years.

title: N.Y.U. Bolsters Economics Faculty
description: New York University has hired THOMAS J. SARGENT, an economic theorist whose work with the Nobel Prize winner ROBERT E. LUCAS Jr. raised questions about the effectiveness of federal economic policy. He joined N.Y.U. this month from Stanford University, but will remain a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution at Stanford. At N.Y.U., he will teach graduate students and undergraduates and help shape the graduate program in macroeconomics.

title: Corrections
description: A sports headline in some copies yesterday about the Angels' defeat of the Oakland A's misidentified the team for which Troy Glaus plays. It is the Angels.

title: A's and Angels Raise Their Games in Amazing Race
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 17  All even with 12 games to play, the next three against each other. That's the situation for the Oakland Athletics and the Anaheim Angels after Monday night's 4-3 victory by the A's in the American League's only remaining unsettled playoff race.

title: 300 Firms Competing to Help Remake Downtown
description: More than 300 architecture and planning firms, including those of the notable architects Philip Johnson and Robert A. M. Stern, have answered the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation's call for more innovative concepts for the World Trade Center site, rebuilding officials said yesterday.

title: Doubts Now Raised Over Extending Force Beyond Kabul
description: A new State Department report on Afghanistan raises sharp questions about expanding an international peacekeeping force beyond Kabul, suggesting that it will be mainly up to the Afghan government to secure its outlying areas.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about a visit in Cairo with Naguib Mahfouz, the Nobel Prize-winning author, misidentified the American translator of several major Arabic novels who completed a new English version of Mr. Mahfouz's ''Children of the Alley'' in 1996. He is Peter Theroux; Paul Theroux, the writer, is his brother.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Republicans Wielding Iraq as an Issue in Senate Races in Conservative States
description: Republicans have gone on the offensive on Iraq and related national security topics in a handful of tight Senate races in recent days, in a sign of how they hope to use the issue against vulnerable Democrats in conservative states.

title: 'Sopranos' Draws Record Viewers to HBO
description: Powered by an expansive promotional campaign and another wave of laudatory media coverage, the fourth-season premiere of HBO's ''The Sopranos'' on Sunday night attracted 13.4 million viewers, becoming the most-watched show in the history of the cable channel.

title: Louima Case Returns, But Memories Are Hazy
description: As a federal judge began questioning potential jurors for the fourth trial of Charles Schwarz in the Abner Louima case yesterday, many of the people called to federal court in Brooklyn said they had only hazy memories of the case that has made headlines on and off for five years.

title: Runyan Says There's Nothing Left to Prove, Except to Herself
description: Marla Runyan does not want to look back on her storied running career and regret not having run a marathon.

title: Sri Lankan Rebels Drop Demand for Separate State
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 18  Sri Lankan Tamil separatist rebels backed away today from their demand for a separate state, saying their long and bloody civil war was aimed at creating a "homeland" within the nation for the Tamil minority.

title: Barrick to Cut Gold Hedging and Build 4 More Mines
description: Barrick Gold, once the gold industry's leading proponent of hedging as a protection against falling prices for metal, said today that it would reduce its forward sales position -- the amount of gold still in the ground that it has already sold for future delivery -- by one-third.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 11 Charged With Selling Heroin
description: Ten men and a woman were indicted yesterday in connection with a heroin ring in Brownsville, prosecutors announced. The authorities said the 11 had been selling about 1,000 $10 bags of heroin a day, mostly from two buildings on Chauncey Street. Investigators from the Kings County district attorney's office videotaped buyers at the buildings. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: TELECOM SHARE ISSUE The China Unicom Group began the country's second-largest domestic share issue, giving mainland investors a rare opportunity to buy shares in one of the largest companies in a booming telecommunications industry. The 11.5 billion yuan ($1.4 billion) share offer from the company, China's No. 2 cellular carrier, was priced near the low end of expectations because of poor sentiment after a number of other initial public offerings, analysts said. China Unicom will use proceeds from the share sale to expand its wireless telephone system. Sinopec, a Chinese refining company, held the country's biggest share issue. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, GEORGIANNA
description: WERNER-Georgianna. Mrs. Georgianna Werner on June 19, 2002 at her home. She was the wife of the late Ludlow. She is survived by her sister Freida H. Wormley of Washington, D.C., a stepson Ludlow Werner, Jr. of Chicago, IL, and numerous nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 21, 2002 at 1:00 PM at the Religious Science Building, 14 East 48th Street, New York, New York.

title: Playing By Different Rules
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Let Us Now Praise Famous Housing for the Rural Poor
description: Mason's Bend in western Alabama is home to five buildings by the renowned Rural Studio of Auburn University.

title: Plates Aplenty to Feed a Crowd
description: The time of turkey draws near. What to serve it on?

title: Oscar de la Renta and Michael Kors
description: Highlights of the spring 2003 collections including Oscar de la Renta and Michael Kors.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Shortfall
description: For the fourth time in less than two years, Cable and Wireless of Britain warned that revenue would fall short of previous forecasts. The company said its corporate telecommunications division, which is its biggest unit and provides Web-based services for major corporate clients in the United States, Europe and Japan, would probably post a first-half loss of 120 million ($185 million) before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, with sales falling 6 percent, to $2.5 billion. Cable and Wireless had previously forecast a 10 percent increase in the unit's revenues. Its shares fell as much as 8 percent to their lowest price in 14 years before recovering. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Videophone Redux (Dreams Die Hard)
description: Videophones have seemed like a great idea for at least 60 years, and it might be another 60 before anybody actually uses them. The latest entrant in this gee-whiz gadget category is the Vizufon, a telephone that displays color video at 15 frames a second -- half the speed of regular television.

title: Cash Diverted From Research On the Spine
description: In July 1998, Gov. George E. Pataki signed into law a program devoting part of the state's traffic fines to research on spinal cord injuries, a measure that was promoted by Christopher Reeve and other well-known paralyzed people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANT, BETTIE ALEXANDER
description: GANT-Bettie Alexander, 46. Died peacefully in her sleep at her home in Manhattan last weekend. ''Alex'' Gant was the building editor of ''This Old House'' magazine. Donations in her name may be made to the American Diabetes Association, PO Box 2680, North Canton, OH 44720. Funeral services will be held on September 20th, at 2 p.m., at the Church of the Holy Comforter in Burlington, NC. A memorial service will take place at 4 P.M. on October 1, at Christ & St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street in Manhattan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Arbitration Likely On Police Pay
description: After months of public feuding and litigation, Nassau County is close to an agreement with the Police Benevolent Association on picking a five-member arbitration panel to decide a new union contract and resolve other disputes, officials said yesterday. Police officers averaged about $100,000 last year, including overtime related to Sept. 11. County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi says that Nassau County's fiscal crisis requires a three-year wage freeze and givebacks, or else he will have to cut other programs. The union says it wants to help but has had no raise for nearly three years. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENGELSDORF, WINIFRED P.
description: BENGELSDORF-Winifred P. Of Bethesda, Md, on Sept. 16, 2002. Beloved wife of Harold D. Bengelsdorf. Mother of Wendy Golladay of Colorado Springs, Co. and Laurie Horvitz of Bethesda, Md. Beloved grandmother of Karen and Kevin Horvitz. Services will be held in the chapel of Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Avenue at Harrison Street NW on Friday, September 20, 2002 at 9:30AM. Interment to follow.

title: Moving Digital Pictures to a TV Screen for Editing and the Works
description: Digital camera manufacturers operate on a tacit assumption that everyone has a computer for downloading the images from the camera. Editing software is loaded separately on the PC for manipulating images and e-mailing them to family and friends. Visioneer is betting that a significant number of people do not have PC's and would like to use a digital camera with their television sets.

title: Option Expense Rules Seen Within a Year
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board will decide within a year whether companies in the United States will have to treat stock option grants to employees as expenses, the head of the group said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Actor Faces Punishment
description: The official press has branded as a ''national traitor'' a Vietnamese actor who starred with Mel Gibson in the Vietnam-era film ''We Were Soldiers,'' saying the film, about the battle of Ia Drang, distorts historical truth. The army newspaper Quan Doi Nhan Dan demanded stern punishment for the actor, Don Duong, which might include a 10-year ban on playing in any movie. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 26 Accused Of Drug Smuggling
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday announced the arrests of 26 people in the United States and Colombia after an investigation that they said dismantled an organization that imported millions of dollars worth of heroin and cocaine into the United States. A former resident of New York, Gaston Moreno, was arrested and identified by prosecutors as the leader of the organization. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: A Tribute Gone Awry, On the Wings of Pigeons
description: It was meant to be a dignified tribute on Sept. 11: a flock of doves soaring majestically past Lower Manhattan's altered skyline. There was only one problem. Those weren't doves. They were pigeons. And many of them couldn't fly.

title: House Panel Secures Help In Britain For Inquiry
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee said yesterday that it was widening its investigation of business practices at Global Crossing and Qwest Communications after securing the cooperation of two British telecommunications companies.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Stricter Accounting Rules
description: The Australian government announced stringent audit and corporate disclosure rules yesterday after a series of company failures and accounting shocks both at home and abroad. Closer scrutiny of accounting practices and a more transparent financial reporting framework are the central planks of the government's overhaul, which will be backed by legislative amendments early next year. The Australian treasurer, Peter Costello, said the country's corporate laws had been modernized in recent years to be among the best in the world, and ahead of the United States.

title: Politics Returns in Forest Fire Debate
description: Even on a day when a late-summer rain coats the arthritic woods, it is clear that Idaho Panhandle National Forest is sick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANKER, DONALD J.
description: ANKER-Donald J., M.D. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL., formerly of New York City. Loving husband and best friend of Carol. Devoted father of Elisabeth and Jonathan. Cherished son of Lillian and the late Seymour. A compassionate and well liked anesthesiologist in practice for 25 years, he was a truly happy person who enjoyed life. His aunts, uncles, in-laws, cousins, nephews, niece and many wonderful friends will mourn his premature passing.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TELECOM SHORTFALL For the fourth time in less than two years, Cable and Wireless of Britain warned that revenue would fall short of previous forecasts. The company said its corporate telecommunications division, which is its biggest unit and provides Web-based services for major corporate clients in the United States, Europe and Japan, would probably post a first-half loss of 120 million ($185 million) before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, with sales falling 6 percent, to $2.5 billion. Cable and Wireless had previously forecast a 10 percent increase in the unit's revenues. Its shares fell as much as 8 percent to their lowest price in 14 years before recovering. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: It's Hotter in New York Than in Miami
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards, still seething over Sunday's humiliating 44-7 loss to New England, stood before his players and coaches today in a team meeting and did everything he could to contradict his image as a mild-mannered coach. Yelling, pounding his fist to his chest, smashing his hand down on a projector, Edwards used the word ''embarrassed'' at least a dozen times in delivering a pointed message to his players as they began preparations for this weekend's critical game at Miami.

title: National Briefing | Education: Communications Grants
description: The Annenberg Foundation is giving $100 million each to the endowments of the communications schools that were founded by Walter Annenberg at the University of Pennsylvania and the University of Southern California. The schools will use the revenue for scholarships, new faculty and other projects. Lia Miller (NYT)

title: Cabinet Member Has Cancer
description: Ann M. Veneman, the secretary of agriculture, announced today that she had an early form of breast cancer but would continue working while she underwent radiation treatment.

title: Corrrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday about people in Angola who are trying to reunite their families after 27 years of civil war misspelled the name of a television program that functions as a national message board. The title is "Nacao Coragem," or "Courageous Nation" ("Nao Coragem" would have meant "No Courage").

title: The Perils of Valuing Lives
description: The original idea behind the government's Sept. 11 compensation fund was to provide the families of the World Trade Center victims with prompt compensation in exchange for their agreement not to sue the airlines. Congress offered little guidance as to how the program might actually work, leaving Kenneth Feinberg, the program's special master, with the exquisitely difficult task of assigning monetary value to human lives. In the end, we think he and the administration have come up with what Congress intended -- an attractive, secure and expeditious alternative to the uncertainties of litigation.

title: Sorrow and Liberties
description: Anthony Romero's first day on the job as the new executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union was Sept. 4, 2001. He was anxious to get started as he strode into the A.C.L.U. headquarters at the lower tip of Manhattan. From his 18th-floor office he had an amazing view of New York Harbor and, appropriately, the Statue of Liberty.

title: Annan Tells Iraq It Must Allow Unfettered Weapons Inspections
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan told Iraq today that he expected ''full and unconditional cooperation'' with United Nations weapons inspectors when they return to the country, as American officials charged that Iraq was seeking to limit the sites that inspectors could examine.

title: Rumsfeld Says Other Nations Promise to Aid Attack on Iraq
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that a number of countries had privately pledged direct military support for any offensive against Iraq. His assertion that opposition to Saddam Hussein's rule had gained broader international support came just hours after Congressional leaders said a vote would be held before the November election on whether to authorize President Bush to take whatever military action he deems necessary.

title: Product From Company With Checkered Past Monitors Umpires' Ball-Strike Calls
description: The key official of the company that provides the computer technology that Major League Baseball uses to monitor and evaluate its umpires has been disciplined by two stock exchanges and the New York State attorney general's office, and the company itself has twice been fined by the attorney general's office.

title: U.S. and Iraq: The Ground Shifts
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the successor to the Hubble Space Telescope misstated the name of a company that will help build it. The company is Ball Aerospace, not Bell.

title: Am I Dad, or a Tutor?
description: If you're a parent with a child in school, late September is the time of year when you may find yourself wondering: Why, at my age (in my case, over 40), am I still doing homework? Who decided that parents must oversee every book report, give practice spelling tests and correct long division? Our parents never helped with homework. They sipped gimlets or watched Walter Cronkite while we toiled away in our bedrooms, conjugating verbs.

title: U.S. and Iraq: The Ground Shifts
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: EMC Introduces Products
description: The EMC Corporation, the world's largest maker of computer data-storage machines, has developed software products that can manage information on machines of its rivals, including International Business Machines. EMC's chief executive, Joseph M. Tucci, announced the suite of software, collectively called ControlCenter, yesterday at the Storage Decisions technology conference in Chicago. The company will record sales from the new software in the fourth quarter, according to its vice president, Chuck Hollis. Because I.B.M. and its rivals -- Hitachi, Sun Microsystems and Network Appliance -- have not agreed to share technology to allow EMC programs to run on and control their machines, EMC developed its own software interfaces, Mr. Hollis said. Shares of EMC, based in Hopkinton, Mass., fell 46 cents, to $5.40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCHARD, ANNE HILL
description: BLANCHARD-Anne Hill, 48. Of Manhattan and Erwinna, PA., died on September 16, 2002. Beloved wife of Edward Vermont Blanchard Jr. and loving mother of Lydia, Catherine and Cordelia; she was also the cherished daughter of W.T. Hill of Huntsville, AL and devoted sister of Liz Hill of Ann Arbor, MI; Bill Hill and Susan Hill of Huntsville, AL; and James Hill of Mineola, NY. Professor of economics at Queens College and former Chair of the department, Anne was an energetic and tireless advocate for women's education and economic well-being. She was a dedicated Trustee of the American Folk Art Museum and served on the Museum's Executive Committee. A prominent collector, Anne was instrumental in recognizing the work of contemporary self-taught artists and helped shape the burgeoning field of outsider art. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, September 21, 2002 at 11AM at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave at 90th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53 Street, New York, New York 10019.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Pataki's Debate Questions: How Many? Who's There?
description: The debate over debates among the candidates for governor turned murkier yesterday, with H. Carl McCall and Gov. George E. Pataki in effect agreeing to share the stage at only one debate despite news media outlets' plans for several forums.

title: Burnitz Tries to Climb Out of a Hole
description: The crowds by now have thinned out, except for the many who turned out last night to cheer for the Cubs' Sammy Sosa. Sosa appeased them by tossing baseballs to fans behind the visitors' dugout at Shea Stadium during batting practice.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Gilat's Losses To Be Larger Than Expected
description: Gilat Satellite Systems, which makes equipment that links telephone networks by satellite, said its second-quarter losses would be larger than expected, in part because of debts it might not be able to collect from WorldCom. The company, based in Israel, said it would have losses of $35.7 million, or $1.53 a share, compared with $14.7 million, or 63 cents a share, during the period last year. Because of a sluggish telecommunications market and reduced spending on telephone equipment, Gilat said, it has to renegotiate about $450 million in debt. The company has also created provisions, set at about $12 million, in case it cannot collect money owed to it by WorldCom, which filed for bankruptcy in July. But Yoel Gat, Gilat's chief executive, said some new sales agreements and efforts to cut costs ''will positively impact to our results beginning in the fourth quarter and beyond.''

title: Daschle Sharply Attacks Bush's Economic Policies
description: The Senate majority leader offered a blistering assessment of President Bush's fiscal policies today, citing two million lost jobs, weak economic growth and a stock market decline that he called unparalleled since Herbert Hoover.

title: Ski Free
description: Several Utah ski resorts are tossing in a day's ski pass (worth up to $67) when visitors book four days' accommodations this ski season. The Stay and Ski in 2003 program is available at Alta, Brighton, the Canyons, Deer Valley, Park City, Sundance and other resorts. The ticket offer is good for one or two people in each room. There are no blackout dates for the passes but they may apply to room availability. Guests receive a voucher from the lodging company, which is presented at the ski area ticket window; (800) 754-8824 or www.skiutah.com .

title: Suffolk County Police Arrest 4 Officers in Drug Investigation
description: The Suffolk County Police have arrested four police officers and 10 others on narcotics charges, the authorities said early this morning.

title: After Promise of Purity, a Cruise Ship Calls On Monterey
description: Shrouded by a dense fog, the vast white vessel slid silently into the bay this morning and anchored far from shore, like a ghost ship unwilling to be noticed.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Clifford Berman was named to the new post of senior consumer marketing public relations specialist at Euro RSCG Middleberg, New York. He had been executive vice president and general manager for consumer marketing at Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, New York, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc. Middleberg is part of the Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners unit of Euro RSCG Worldwide, a division of Havas.

title: Maya Carvings Tell of a War of 2 Superpowers
description: When a hurricane ripped through the jungle of northern Guatemala a year ago, an uprooted tree at the base of temple ruins at Dos Pilas exposed stones bearing one of the longest texts of Maya hieroglyphs ever found.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: GENERAL MAGIC TO SHUT ITS OPERATIONS General Magic of Sunnyvale, Calif., announced yesterday that it would cease operations effective immediately because it had been unsuccessful at raising additional capital or arranging a merger. Kathleen Layton, the president and chief executive, said the decision stemmed from continued poor economic conditions along with the slow pace of corporate spending on information technology. The company, which makes Internet voice technology, said 15 General Magic employees would be retained for 60 days by OnStar, the Web-based driver assistance service from General Motors , to help transfer the operation of OnStar Virtual Adviser to another vendor.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: JUDGE APPROVES BANKRUPTCY PLAN FOR HOULIHAN'S
description: Houlihan's Restaurants Inc., which had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because of heavy competition in the casual-dining industry, won court approval for its reorganization plan. Judge Arthur B. Federman of United States Bankruptcy Court approved a plan allowing holders of about $70 million in secured bank debt to receive $12 million in five-year term debt, $30 million in preferred stock redeemable in five years and 100 percent of the company's common stock, the company said. The restaurant chain, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., will have access to a $10 million credit facility, provided by a syndicate led by Fleet National Bank. The company expects to emerge from bankruptcy protection by Oct. 1, said its bankruptcy attorney, Larry Frazen.

title: PAYCHEX TO BUY ADVANTAGE PAYROLL FOR $240 MILLION
description: Paychex Inc., a seller of corporate payroll and personnel services, agreed to buy the closely held Advantage Payroll Services Inc. for $240 million in cash, gaining about 49,000 clients. The deal will enable Paychex to offer its human resources and retirement services to a new crop of small and midsize businesses, it said. The company, which is based in Rochester, expects the acquisition of Advantage to add $75 million in sales over the next year. Advantage is based in Auburn, Me.

title: Antique Furnishings At the Click of a Mouse
description: Stylists and designers have discovered Chanadet, a little antiques shop on the Internet (www.chanadet.com), which offers vintage decorative objects and textiles, as well as new wares. The owner, Diane Baldessari, has more stashed in her Upper West Side apartment, so a phone call or an e-mail message could turn up what you have been searching for. This week's Web offerings include a 1940's American schoolhouse chalkboard in a red wood frame ($98) and a 1940's Swedish rag rug, above, 24 by 60 inches, for $145. Among new pieces are pillowcases of vintage ticking ($140 to $165) and cotton tablecloths from Provence ($56 to $66). Buyers in Manhattan can pick up merchandise (212-873-5983); shipping is extra by U.P.S. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: 2 Koreas Celebrate Decision to Reconnect a Railway
description: About 100 South Korean soldiers walked through the barbed-wire barricade this morning on the southern side of the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas, beginning to clear away mines in preparation for rebuilding of the final link in the North-South railroad that was shut down during the Korean War.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bridgestone Investigation
description: The Fair Trade Commission searched the offices of Bridgestone and several other companies that make rubber shock absorbers amid allegations of price fixing. Government regulators also searched the offices of Yokohama Rubber, Kawaguchi Metal Industries and others that reportedly worked together to set prices for the shock absorbers, which are used on bridges and other large structures. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Testimony on Attacks
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony yesterday of Eleanor Hill, staff director of an inquiry into the Sept. 11 attacks, before a joint Congressional committee, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. The full transcript is online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Alluding Obliquely to That Tragic Day
description: It is probably impossible for any New Yorker to bring any sense of distance to watching a dance about the attack on the World Trade Center. For that reason perhaps Hernando Cortez's fascinating new ''Two Hours That Shook the World,'' performed by Cortez & Co. Contemporary/Ballet on Friday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, felt as problematical as trying to make sense of the actual event.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Executive Leaving
description: Vivendi Universal said Philippe Germond, the head of its telecommunications unit, which holds a 44 percent stake in France's second-largest phone company, is leaving to join Alcatel as its chief operating officer. Mr. Germond, 45, was a close ally of Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi's former chief executive, who was ousted in a boardroom coup in June. Mr. Germond will assume his new post on Jan. 1 and will replace Jean-Pierre Halbron, who is to retire at the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELMAN, BERTIE
description: FINKELMAN - Bertie. On September 18, 2002. Beloved mother of Barry and Joan, loving sister of Shirley Frederick, cherished grandmother of Michele & Marc, and Eric. Services Friday, 11:30 AM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: AT HOME WITH: Frederic Schwartz; The Man Who Dared the City To Think Again
description: FREDERIC SCHWARTZ flinched at a flash of light outside the window of his architecture studio in SoHo. ''Did you see that? It's an airplane,'' he said, pointing at the fuselage of a commercial jet banking harmlessly over the Hudson River.

title: A new campaign on Fox TV guarantees to push the envelope.
description: TWO Fox television networks, reinforcing their brand image of brash risk-taking that sometimes steps over the line, are planning two clutter-busting initiatives that are sure to be controversial.

title: Peter W. Stroh, 74, Ex-Chairman of Brewery
description: Peter W. Stroh, a former chairman of the Stroh Brewing Company, died on Tuesday at his home in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. He was 74.

title: Book Publicity Party Animals
description: The fashion industry plays. Magazines party. The fall social season is upon us, but book publishers remain as disinterested as they have been in recent years in giving their authors publication parties. Why are publishers so stingy when it comes to what was a ritual of their game? It's the economy, stupid, they say. Anyway, they don't believe the parties sell books.

title: Uptown Settlers Unsettled
description: ON a hot afternoon last week, Hector Gonzalez rested his iced tea on a paper napkin and rubbed his hand over the cool white tiles on his kitchen counter. His three children, who are 3, 9 and 11, watched Spanish-language soap operas from the plastic slipcovers of a plush sofa. A certificate on the wall commended his daughter Liliana for making the second-grade honor roll.

title: Cable's Ultimate Endurance Test: Wiring the South Pole
description: CABLE modems and digital subscriber lines promise customers high-speed connections to the Internet. What isn't so swift in many regions of the country, however, is the hookup by cable and telephone companies.

title: WHAT I LIKE ABOUT YOU
description: WB, Friday night at 8, Eastern and Pacific times; 7 Central time

title: Outlawing Roaming Gangs Of, Um, Cats
description: The Board of Health stepped into a simmering feud between two neighbors tonight, approving a new law against cats that roam and damage property.

title: Campaign Season; The Ambitions of Administration Aides
description: There has been no shortage of people from the Clinton White House interested in running for office, but this election cycle made clear that for many, accomplishment has fallen short of ambition. Hopes were dashed on Primary Day (or, in the case of Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, before Primary Day).

title: Sex Museum Says It Is Here to Educate
description: MoSex, the new Museum of Sex, five years in the making and opening next week in a former retail space and (reputedly) a recent brothel on Fifth Avenue and 27th Street, is not taking its X rating lying down,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, J.J.
description: GREENBERG - J.J. The Board, Faculty and Staff of the Pardes Institute of Jewish Studies in Jerusalem and the American Pardes Foundation, Inc. mourn the tragic and untimely passing of J.J. Greenberg, son of our dear friends and distinguished faculty members Yitz and Blu Greenberg, brother-in-law of our esteemed Board member Abbie Gottesman Greenberg and brother of Moshe Greenberg, David and Mindy Greenberg, Deborah and Jonathan Greenberg, Goody and Eric Will, and grandson of Sylvia Genauer. May J.J.'s memory be a blessing and may the entire Greenberg family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ruth Cummings Sorenson, Chair Rabbi Daniel Landes, Director and Rosh Yeshiva Pardes Institute Mark Levenfus, President Jayne Rosengarten, Executive Director American Pardes Foundation

title: Zeigler's Comeback Nearly Complete
description: Dusty Zeigler ripped off his helmet at practice today and bent forward, trying to catch his breath, like the other linemen. For the first time since last season, Zeigler, the Giants' center, participated in all the drills his teammates were doing, without a trainer shadowing him like a caddie.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Falun Gong Members Go On Trial
description: Fifteen members of the banned spiritual group Falun Gong went on trial in the northeastern city of Changchun on charges of hijacking local cable television programming. On March 5 this year, normal cable programming in Changchun was interrupted for nearly half an hour during prime time and replaced by materials promoting Falun Gong. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: Corrrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday about people in Angola who are trying to reunite their families after 27 years of civil war misspelled the name of a television program that functions as a national message board. The title is "Nacao Coragem," or "Courageous Nation" ("Nao Coragem" would have meant "No Courage").

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People have said there was no smoking gun. But there was still a lot out there that was never pulled together.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOT, CHARLES E. (NED)
description: ROOT-Charles E. (Ned). Died September 17, 2002. His family and friends will hold a celebration of love at the Hotel Wales, 1295 Madison Ave (between 92nd and 93rd Sts), Sunday, September 22nd, 35PM in the Pied Piper Room.

title: Mystery Music Stops Paris Opera
description: Phantom of the opera? Maria Callas returning on the 25th anniversary of her death? Perhaps not, but strange voices could be heard in the Opera Garnier on Monday evening as a production of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' opened the 2002-3 season. With the public soon becoming restless, a voice from the audience finally asked loudly, ''Can't someone stop that?''

title: Japan Will Buy Shares From Its Troubled Banks
description: Under heavy political pressure to bail out the nation's financial industry, the Bank of Japan said today that it planned to buy stocks from banks.

title: U.S. FAILED TO ACT ON WARNINGS IN '98 OF A PLANE ATTACK
description: The United States intelligence community was told in 1998 that Arab terrorists were planning to fly a bomb-laden plane into the World Trade Center, but the F.B.I. and the Federal Aviation Administration did not take the threat seriously, a Congressional investigation into the Sept. 11 attacks has found.

title: In Quietly Courting Africa, White House Likes Dowry
description: Africa, the neglected stepchild of American diplomacy, is rising in strategic importance to Washington policy makers, and one word sums up the reason: oil.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Slowdown Projected
description: One of Australia's leading economic barometers fell in July for the first time since 1994, raising concerns that the country's commodity-driven economy might finally be succumbing to the effects of the slowdown in the United States. The drop in the monthly Westpac Banking Corporation/Melbourne Institutes index of economic activity suggests slower growth toward the end of this year, economists said, despite surveys showing that business and consumer confidence remain strong.

title: Bush Sends Congress a Proposed Resolution on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 - President Bush asked Congress today for sweeping authority to use ``all means he determines to be appropriate, including force'' to disarm Iraq and dislodge Saddam Hussein, and warned: ``If the United Nations Security Council won't deal with the problem, the United States and some of our friends will.''

title: CLOROX INCREASES FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS ESTIMATES
description: The Clorox Company raised its first-quarter earnings estimate yesterday because of cost cuts and sales of more-profitable items. Profit will be 52 cents to 55 cents a share in the quarter, which ends Sept. 30, Clorox said. The company, which makes Pine-Sol cleaner, Black Flag insecticide and its namesake bleach, had expected a profit of 50 cents to 52 cents. Clorox, which is based in Oakland, Calif., has cut jobs and reduced supply expenses, using the savings to spend more on marketing new products. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to report a profit of 51 cents a share.

title: It's Out With the New, In With the Old
description: Retirement crept into Rodney Peete's mind last winter after 13 years as a journeyman quarterback in the N.F.L. He had not started a game since 1998. He had not thrown a pass since 1999. In all his years as a starter and a backup, he had not won the Super Bowl ring he coveted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLIFF, MARILYN
description: SLIFF-Marilyn. Mother of our very dear friend Harvey, Marilyn was a loving and compassionate human being who will be sorely missed by all. Our sincere condolences to the entire family. Jane and Larry David

title: Donald L. Campbell, 98, Dies; Helped Open Fuel Floodgates
description: Donald L. Campbell, the last of the four engineers who, as World War II began, invented a cheaper and more efficient process to ''crack'' large hydrocarbons into smaller molecules useful for things like fuel and plastics, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Brick, N.J. He was 98.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Review For Murder Suspect
description: A Nassau County judge yesterday ordered the man accused of fatally shooting a Roman Catholic priest and parishioner to undergo observation at a mental hospital after the man refused an evaluation of his fitness to stand trial. The man, Peter J. Troy, above, is charged with killing the priest and parishioner inside Our Lady of Peace Church in Lynbrook in March. Judge Daniel J. Cotter ordered that Mr. Troy be sent to Pilgrim State Hospital for observation after he refused. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Judicial Nominee Says His Views Will Not Sway Him on the Bench
description: Prof. Michael W. McConnell, a leading conservative scholar who has written forcefully about his opposition to abortion and to what he considers excessive separation of church and state, told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that none of those views would matter if he were confirmed to a federal appeals court seat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKS, MURRAY M.
description: SACKS-Murray M., 84. On September 9, 2002. Cherished husband of Lila for 59 years. Loving father and father-inlaw of Meryl Sacks and Ricka and Yoel Rak. Beloved grandfather of Ariel, Benjamin, and Carmi. Also survived by his dear sister, Rose Margolies. A decorated naval officer, he serviced his country during World War II with the same devotion he gave to his family. Founded and headed the Sacks Curtain Company in New York City for 37 years. Retired to Palm Beach, Florida, and recently to Poway, California, where services were held on September 12th. His warmth, sense of humor, and generous heart touched all who knew him.

title: A Nightclub Yearning to Be A Video Game
description: ''We like to think that we have reinvented the nightclub,'' said Jill Buchanan, a designer of Vue, which is opening tonight. The invention is a 360-degree-surround cinema -- a diorama on steroids -- with eight projectors inside a 30-foot dome (projection above). For special occasions, patrons can choose from 20 3-D and 2-D environments. (Harper's Bazaar supplied its own images -- logos and scenes from the television show ''Absolutely Fabulous'' -- for a party on Saturday night, to celebrate Fashion Week.)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: KENYA: OPPOSITION CHOOSES CANDIDATE The National Alliance Party named Mwai Kibaki, leader of the opposition in Parliament, as its presidential candidate to challenge the governing party's 39-year hold on power. President Daniel arap Moi is expected to set a date for the election by the end of this year. Mr. Moi, 78, has been president for 24 years. His term under the current constitution ends in January and he is supporting Uhuru Kenyatta, son of Kenya's first president, Jomo Kenyatta, as the governing party's candidate. (AP)

title: Formulas for a Clean Election
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: AUSTRIA: NEW LEADER FOR RIGHT-WING PARTY The far-right Freedom Party, in turmoil since the withdrawal of its de facto leader, Jorg Haider, over the weekend, named a little-known government minister, Mathias Reichhold, left, as chairman. Mr. Reichhold, 45, the transport minister, faces an uphill battle in elections this November. The party's support has been badly eroded by internal strife, which began when Mr. Haider forced out several senior officials, including Susanne Riess-Passer, who also served as vice chancellor. Mr. Haider then declined to take the helm, saying that he had been threatened and that he feared for the safety of his family. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nissan In China Deal
description: Nissan Motor will spend as much as $1 billion to form a venture with Dongfeng Motor in China. Nissan's president, Carlos Ghosn, will reportedly sign an agreement in Beijing this week that gives it a 50 percent share of the new venture. Japanese news media reported that Nissan planned to make 150,000 cars annually in China beginning in 2004. In the last several months, Nissan's rivals, Toyota Motor and Honda Motor, have announced plans to make cars in China. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Matters; Getting There Is Half The Battle
description: IS New York going about the process of rebuilding Lower Manhattan backwards, sort of cart before the horse?

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: A Higher Christian-Muslim Toll
description: At least 915 people were killed in clashes between Christians and Muslims in the central city of Jos last September, according to a report issued by the government of Plateau State. The number was almost double an earlier estimate. More than 10,000 people are believed to have been killed in religious or ethnic conflicts across the country since the end of military rule in 1999. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Review/Fashion; Kors and de la Renta Sing The Old Familiar Tunes
description: Between them, Oscar de la Renta and Michael Kors dress the young, the social and the surgically ageless, and their spring 2003 collections yesterday in the big tents in Bryant Park had everything their clients will want. Jaunty Bermudas, thonged sandals, tempting color and a slight nod to their favorite recreational pastimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, LENORE ELIAS BERG
description: GINSBURG - Lenore Elias berg. Of Boynton Beach FL, died peacefully on September 17, 2002. Loving wife of Everett Ginsburg and wife of the late David J. Lobel. title: What the Well-Dressed Traveler Will Slip On, Lug and Pop

''I love their sensibility,'' said Ed Burstell, the vice president at Bendel, who brought Flight 001 to the store. ''It's really focused and edited.'' The new shop (far right), which resembles the inside of a cargo plane, offers Flight 001's signature line, including eye masks ($5), slipper socks ($5) and jet-lag pills ($12). There are also travel totes and luggage (right) from Lexon, Ocaba and Mandarina Duck. On Bendel's second floor, 712 Fifth Avenue (56th Street); (212) 247-1100. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

description: There appear to be more problems with the books at the A.& P.

description: DAVID D. RODRIGUEZ, the executive director of the Apollo Theater Foundation, does not get easily worked up. He is as smooth and steady as the jazz notes that drift from the bass that he sometimes plays as a sideman on stage.

description: Ending a lesson on the downside of magazines identified with a single personality, Rosie O'Donnell announced yesterday that she was parting ways with Gruner & Jahr USA.

description: The European Commission made its best-yet offer today to Russians living in the Baltic seacoast enclave of Kaliningrad, offering them a ''simplified travel document'' that would allow direct trips across European territory to Russia.

description: Hundreds of companies worldwide form a shadow network capable of providing money and logistical support for continued attacks by Al Qaeda and other loosely connected militants, investigators and financial regulators in Europe and the United States say.

description: Global economic forces are crushing millions of coffee farmers around the world, the British charity Oxfam said in a report released today.

title: Sports of The Times; The Once-Bitter Rivalry That Is No More
description: IT was a rivalry like few others, one of the best in sports, nearly sibling -- it was Macy's and Gimbels, Chanel and Este Lauder, Hershey and Nestl, except with bats in their hands. At first they came from brotherly boroughs, connected by subterranean trains and a vehement detestation of one another. Their seven-decade-long trolley and subway series was historic, intense and dripping with animosity, encompassing nearly everyone from the players to the fans to the local postmen and probably the dogs that chased them, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACK, RODGER
description: MACK-Rodger. The Syracuse University family mourns the passing of a dedicated teacher, renowned sculptor and respected friend and colleague. He began his 34 years at SU in 1968 as a professor of sculpture, and went on to serve as the first director of the School of Art and Design in the College of Visual and Performing Arts from 1982 to 1991. A bronze caster of international repute, he helped build the program, buildings and foundry that turned the school into a major educational art and design center. A 1991 recipient of a Chancellor's Citation for Exceptional Academic Achievement, he received numerous awards, grants and honors including those from the Ford Foundation, the National Foundation for the Arts and the New York State Council on the Arts, as well as a Fulbright Grant for study in Italy. Our heartfelt condolences to his family, loved ones and scores of professional artists and graduate students across the world who regard him as their mentor.

title: Latin Grammys Return, With the Focus on the Music
description: The much-beleaguered Latin Grammy Awards ceremony, which took place at the Kodak Theatre here, finally had its night on network television tonight after last year's broadcast, scheduled for Sept. 11, was canceled.

title: Contempt at Interior
description: Accounting failures in the private sector have been big news lately. But the granddaddy of accounting failures belongs to the public sector -- the federal government's handling of money held in trust for more than 300,000 Native Americans.

title: Steady-Output Faction Is Expecting Victory in OPEC
description: Oil ministers from countries that want to hold production steady and keep prices high claimed victory on Wednesday night and this morning before a meeting this afternoon of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, saying that a consensus had been reached in their favor.

description: In Long Island's long-running battle over immigrant day laborers, each side is claiming a victory.

description: Commuting by train can be a herdlike affair. But for years, those commuting from New Jersey to New York have lacked even the rudimentary amenity of their own waiting area, sharing a concourse in Pennsylvania Station with Amtrak passengers.

title: Turner Has the Dolphins Thinking About Offense
description: There's a swagger back in the Miami Dolphins' offense, one not seen since quarterback Dan Marino, a future Hall of Famer, retired after the 1999 season. The presence of Ricky Williams, a new, full-service power runner, has helped, but the team's new offensive coordinator has created just as much of a buzz.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: GENERAL MAGIC TO SHUT ITS OPERATIONS General Magic of Sunnyvale, Calif., announced yesterday that it would cease operations effective immediately because it had been unsuccessful at raising additional capital or arranging a merger. Kathleen Layton, the president and chief executive, said the decision stemmed from continued poor economic conditions along with the slow pace of corporate spending on information technology. The company, which makes Internet voice technology, said 15 General Magic employees would be retained for 60 days by OnStar, the Web-based driver assistance service from General Motors , to help transfer the operation of OnStar Virtual Adviser to another vendor.

title: DEUTSCHE BANK IN TALKS TO SELL EQUITIES SERVICES UNITS
description: Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, said it was in talks aimed at selling much of its global equities services businesses to the State Street Corporation of Boston. The units, which provide securities lending and record-keeping services, included the domestic custody businesses in the United States and in Britain. It excluded the domestic custody businesses in Germany and elsewhere in Continental Europe. The bank said it hoped to complete the negotiations by the fourth quarter but gave no indication of the price being discussed. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Little-Known Team Wins a Title
description: The Greater New York Bridge Association's Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams is usually won by players with national and international reputations. But this year was different. The winners 10 days ago, in play at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street in Manhattan, were four players little known to fame who had outlasted all the favorites en route to the title. Franco Baseggio, Andy Stark, John Fout and Erik Secan won the final by the slender margin of 4 imps against Jon Greenspan, Bob Blanchard, Bjorn Fallenius, Sam Lev and Joyce Sillins.

title: While America Slept
description: The initial findings of a Congressional committee that has been reviewing the performance of America's intelligence agencies before Sept. 11 are profoundly disturbing. While the investigation has not found that the agencies collected information pointing to the date and targets of the attacks, it has discovered reports that Osama bin Laden and his followers hoped to hit sites in the United States and that they might employ commercial airliners as weapons. The response of spy organizations -- and the government at large -- was anemic.

title: World Business Briefing: Australia
description: STRICTER ACCOUNTING RULES The Australian government announced stringent audit and corporate disclosure rules yesterday after a series of company failures and accounting shocks both at home and abroad. Closer scrutiny of accounting practices and a more transparent financial reporting framework are the central planks of the government's overhaul, which will be backed by legislative amendments early next year. The Australian treasurer, Peter Costello, said the country's corporate laws had been modernized in recent years to be among the best in the world, and ahead of the United States. (Dow Jones)

title: More Than One Way to Kill a Vampire
description: BAD guys just don't die the way they used to. In early games, your enemies would simply fall down or disappear. As games became slicker, the death sequences became more elaborate; blood squirted, heads were chopped off, bodies exploded. This is enough for most game designers, but Buffy the Vampire Slayer and The Mark of Kri take things further, with an almost fetishistic approach to violent death.

description: A computerized system designed to keep track of the thousands of foreign students attending educational institutions in the United States will not be fully operational by a January deadline set by Congress, the Justice Department inspector general said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco's Backlog Of Orders Falls About 30%
description: Cisco Systems, the world's largest maker of equipment to link computers, said yesterday that its backlog of orders had declined by about 30 percent in the last 12 months. The company said its backlog -- an accumulation of unfilled orders -- totaled $1.4 billion as of Sept. 9. That compared with a $2 billion backlog as of Sept. 14, 2001, according to a Form 10-K report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. ''Cisco does not believe that its backlog, as of any particular date, is necessarily indicative of actual net sales for any future period,'' the company said in the filing. Cisco said last month that this quarter's sales would be unchanged or would rise by a ''very low, single-digit'' percentage from the $4.83 billion for the quarter ended July 27. Cisco's order backlog fell even more steeply in the previous year. The company's backlog declined to $2 billion as of September 2001 from $3.4 billion as of September 2000, a 41 percent drop, according to a previous regulatory filing. Shares of Cisco fell 25 cents, or about 2 percent, to $12.29.

title: Afghan Dream: A Smooth Road To Anywhere
description: A while ago, Abdul Ahad pooled his savings with two fellow drivers, borrowed from relatives and friends, and came up with $10,000 to buy a secondhand truck from Pakistan. He runs cattle to Kabul, the capital, from grazing pastures in his home province of Laghman, in the mountains 100 miles to the east, and returns with tomatoes, onions and other vegetables from Kabul's markets.
