title: Plates Aplenty To Feed A Crowd
description: WITH fall only four days away, thoughts turn to the coming holiday season and its inevitable rounds of entertaining. It's never too early to plan: for dinner hosts this year, there is an affordable alternative to fine china. All the plates shown here are under $10, and many can be used alongside dinnerware already in the cupboard.

title: Imported From Vienna, A Rebel Among Rebels
description: Dagobert Peche designed thousands of objects for the Wiener Werksttte in Vienna in the teens and 20's of the last century, but never took to its modernist creed. ''He believed in the exact opposite of expressing the nature of materials,'' said Christian Witt-Drring, the curator of a show about Peche (pronounced PEH-kuh), opening Oct. 11 at the Neue Galerie museum. Peche, who died of cancer at 36, designed table legs that swelled like haunches by R. Crumb and tapered to an impossible delicacy (right). Through Feb. 10 at the museum, Fifth Avenue and 86th Street; $10. The catalog, ''Beyond Utility: Dagobert Peche and the Wiener Werksttte'' (Yale University Press), is $65. EVE M. KAHN

title: Arming the Arms Inspectors
description: If the United Nations Security Council rushes to send inspectors back into Iraq on Baghdad's promise of cooperation and under the old rules, it will be playing a chump's game, one Saddam Hussein has won countless times. Once in, the inspectors will face delay, obstruction, bugging and a succession of manufactured crises. These will prompt familiar fights among the major powers over whether a particular Iraqi act constitutes a major violation. Soon the United States will declare the whole exercise a failure and invade Iraq.

title: Economic Scene; Lobbying by businesses overwhelms their campaign contributions.
description: WITH so much at stake, economists have long wondered why businesses and interest groups do not contribute more to political campaigns. Individuals, organizations and companies gave a total of nearly $3 billion to national campaigns in 1999 and 2000. That may seem like a lot, but it is only 0.15 percent of annual federal spending. For perspective, note that spending on advertising and promoting cigarettes was five times what was spent in all elections held in 2000.

description: THRUSH-Donald Bell. Born in Brooklyn, NY on November 19, 1918, he died in Vero Beach, FL. on September 15, 2002. He served in W.W. He owned Thrush Press 1946-1988 and served the printing industry through local and national associations, most notably as past chairman of the Printing Industries of America and Graphic Arts Mutual Insurance Co. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Jocelyn Lake Thrush; three children: Lauriston Thrush Avery; William Lake Thrush and Dana Thrush Foote; seven grandchildren and his sister, Eugenie Thrush of Westport, CT. title: CHESAPEAKE REDUCES PROFIT FORECAST ON LOWER SALES
description: The Chesapeake Corporation, a maker of paperboard and plastic packaging, reduced its full-year profit forecast because of project delays and lower sales and prices. Profit before some costs will be $1.30 a share to $1.50 a share, the company said. Chesapeake said in July that it would earn $1.60 to $1.80 a share this year. Profit was hurt by delays in closing plants in Scotland, the company said. Lower prices for food packaging and weaker sales of technology-related packaging also hurt profit, the company said.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: CELESTICA LOWERS EARNINGS ESTIMATES Celestica, the contract electronics manufacturer, cut its third-quarter sales and earnings estimates yesterday, blaming slower demand from some of its largest customers. Celestica dropped its revenue forecast to $1.9 billion to $2 billion for the quarter ended Sept. 30, from previous guidance of $2.1 billion to $2.4 billion. It said that earnings per share would be 18 to 22 cents, which would be lower than a previous estimate of 26 to 33 cents. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected, on average, that revenue would be $2.24 billion and earnings 28 cents a share. The weaker outlook comes after a poor second quarter in which the company, which is based in Toronto, said it would lay off up to 15 percent of its staff and close manufacturing plants because sales had declined. Shares fell $3.23, or 17 percent, to $15.58. (Reuters)

title: Council Wants Liberty Bonds To Build More Homes for Poor
description: More than half of any new apartments built with the special financing created by Congress in response to the terrorist attack on Sept. 11 should be offered at below-market rents for low- and moderate-income families, City Council leaders said yesterday.

title: A Sideshow Worth the Price Of Admission
description: Tina Brown was stalled on the runway. A half-hour before the Diane Von Furstenberg show began on Tuesday, Ms. Brown, tanned, tousled, pantsuited, antennas quivering, seemed momentarily uncertain about where to direct her focus. And who could blame her? Even people without Ms. Brown's hunger for the boldfaced would develop instant-onset attention deficit disorder at Ms. Von Furstenberg's shows.

title: As Cellphone Options Grow, Sites Help Sort Them Out
description: NAVIGATING the options when shopping for cellular service has always been a struggle, to say the least, but lately it seems to be reaching a new level. Turn on the television and you see ads for flashy new phones and new types of wireless plans, some with new and confusing terminology. Walk into a mall and you see pushcarts and booths selling a wide array of phones and plans just outside the full-size stores of the national carriers.

title: A Stab at Celebrity Glamour Fails to Save TV's 'BattleBots'
description: THEY called in the heavyweights. But not even the 80's sitcom icon Gary Coleman and Carmen Electra of ''Baywatch'' fame could save ''BattleBots,'' the groundbreaking television show in which homemade robotic warriors battled to the death. The Comedy Central cable network has decided not to renew the program for next year.

title: The Dorm Desktop as Portal to Cable TV
description: WHEN their dormitories open tomorrow, Northwestern University students will experience a new kind of media mix: cable television delivered to their computer screens.

title: All It Takes Is a Fingerprint: Unlocking Portable Data
description: The Thumbdrive, a tiny data storage device, is aptly named. It is no bigger than a thumb. But this month the name will take on another meaning when the manufacturer, Trekstor USA, begins selling a device that unlocks its data with a fingerprint instead of a password.

title: KODAK STICKS TO ITS SECOND-HALF ESTIMATE
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the photography company, reiterated its second-half profit forecast and told investors the sluggish economic recovery would hamper sales growth. Second-half profit will be $1.35 to $1.75 a share. Third-quarter profit excluding some one-time gains will be 70 cents to 80 cents a share, the chief executive, Dan Carp, said at the annual investors' meeting in New York. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected 70 cents. Mr. Carp raised cash flow estimates and said promotions for digital cameras and services would keep sales from falling. The company did not give a specific forecast for sales but said annual revenue would grow 3 percent to 5 percent once the economy recovered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENBERGER, WALTER S.
description: LOWENBERGER-Walter S. September 17, 2002. Husband of Hannah (nee Loeb) Lowenberger. Father of William A. (Alayne) Lowenberger of McCandless, PA., and Phyllis D. (Richard A.) Miller. Grandfather of Lauren Lowenberger. Graveside services from Elmlawn Cemetery, Tonawanda, NY Friday at 11:00 AM. No prior visitations. In lieu of flowers donations to Temple Ohav Shalom, 8400 Thompson Run Road, Allison Park, Pennsylvania 15101. For more information Amherst Memorial Chapel Inc.

title: Greek Wedding: Made in America
description: As a Mexican-American girl in northwest Indiana, I received my first schooling in segregated classes with other children like myself. We were not allowed to mix with the blond and blue-eyed students who populated the rest of the school, separated as we were even at playtime.

title: Pipeline Receives Tentative Approval
description: Federal regulators gave tentative approval yesterday to the Millennium Pipeline, a proposed 425-mile natural gas conduit from Lake Erie to Westchester County that has drawn opposition from many residents and local officials.

title: Internet Stereo Pushes Limits Of a Wake-Up To the World
description: Having the world on a string may remain a dream, but at least you can have the world's news and music on your shelf. The Streamium MC-i200 from Philips Electronics is a compact bookshelf stereo system that connects to the Internet with a cable or D.S.L. connection to play online music and radio from around the globe. The device can also stream music from online music services like AOL Music, MusicMatch and Radio Free Virgin.

title: Ending a Long Battle, New York Lets Housing and Gardens Grow
description: A protracted dispute between New York City and hundreds of community gardeners ended yesterday when the city agreed to preserve some 500 community gardens and use others to build more than 2,000 apartments during the next year, a 20 percent increase over the normal production of city-sponsored housing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, HAZEL
description: WEINBERG - Hazel, M.D. Died September 17, 2002. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and its graduates are deeply saddened by the loss of a beloved and devoted colleague who played an important role in the life of her many students and colleagues. Dr. Weinberg was a member of the Institute's Council of Fellows, Teaching Faculty, Training Committee and a Training and Supervising Analyst. She was also on the faculty of The New York Hospital Cornell Medical Center. Relied upon for her deeply caring understanding of others and for her ability to transcend intellectual conventions, she approached patients with an unfailing respect for their uniquely personal qualities. She was an especially caring and supportive colleague in times of need. A former dancer, her artist's investment in authenticity led her to be outspoken and direct-at times eschewing institutional process and circumstance - but her warmth and compassion were always present. For many years Hazel struggled with a variety of illnesses, truly bearing more than her share of tribulation, yet she was undaunted in her ability to carry on until the end. In that too, she was exemplary. We shall miss her deeply. Charles Harrington, Ph.D., President, Board of Trustees Joerg Bose, M.D., Director, White Institute Rebecca Curtis, Ph.D., President, White Society

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Nazi-Era Claims Rejected
description: The country's highest court ruled that Greek courts could not order the German government to pay compensation for Nazi atrocities in Greece. The ruling followed a lower court decision two years ago that called on Germany to award $27 million to relatives of victims of a massacre in the village of Distomo in 1944. Germany rejected the claims, saying it paid Greece $67 million in the 1960's. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Growing Concerns on the Health of HealthSouth
description: John Darling lost faith in HealthSouth, the country's largest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, six years ago. That, he says, was when a therapy session conducted by an unlicensed HealthSouth employee left him with pain so severe than he still spends most days flat on his back.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Teachers' Class Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: Rats Carry a Message
description: To the Editor:

title: YUKOS TO CONTINUE OIL SHIPMENTS TO UNITED STATES
description: The Yukos Oil Company, Russia's second-largest oil producer, said direct crude oil shipments to the United States appeared to be economical, and it would continue shipping oil through the end of this year. Yukos shipped a tanker of oil to the United States for the first time in July, though it later encountered problems after a pending lawsuit disrupted payment for the oil. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Settlement Averts Strike by Home Health Aides
description: A scheduled strike by 3,000 home health aides in the New York area was averted yesterday when their employer, Premier Home Health Care Services, reached a tentative settlement with the health care union 1199/S.E.I.U.

title: JACK IN THE BOX EXPECTS EARNINGS GROWTH OF 10%
description: Jack in the Box Inc., a hamburger chain with stores mainly in the Southwest, said it expected growth in per-share earnings of 10 percent to 15 percent as part of a plan to become a national restaurant company. Profit is expected to rise to $2.46 a share next year, from an expected $2.06 this year, the company said. Jack in the Box said it would also evaluate other restaurant companies for possible acquisitions to balance the risk of expanding only its fast-food business. The company will introduce products including lighter fare and increase the percentage of stores owned by franchisees to 35 percent from 20 percent in five years. Jack in the Box is based in San Diego.

title: ChevronTexaco Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOBROVE, NAOMI WILKES
description: BOBROVE-Naomi Wilkes. On September 16th, 2002. Loving wife of the late Louis. Surviving are her brother and sister John D. Wilkes and Ruth Wilkes Davis. Two daughters Elisabeth (Libby). Bauer and Ann Parker, sonin-law Robert Parker. Adoring grandchildren Owen Bauer, Amanda Parker and Jacob Parker. Graveside service Thursday (today) 12:30 Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings, New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Counterterrorism Officials
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that at least one police commander dedicated to preparing for possible terror attacks must be established in each of the city's five boroughs. Mr. Kelly said that he might ultimately decide to create counterterrorism specialists, above the rank of captain, at each precinct. Mr. Kelly has already assigned about 1,000 officers to counterterrorism duties. Al Baker (NYT)

title: No Keys, Just Soft Light and You
description: IT may resemble a popular image from science fiction: high-tech control panels that appear to be little more than colored light. But Canesta, a Silicon Valley start-up company, says it is about to unveil a technology that will make such controls a reality.

title: Data Swells, As Do Ways To Store It
description: I HAD forgotten how big ''small'' devices for portable file storage used to be until recently, when I beaned myself on the head with an old SyQuest cartridge while sorting through a high shelf of old computer stuff. The cartridge -- a 5.25-inch monster about a half-inch thick that could store a whopping (for 1991) 44 megabytes of data -- hit the floor with a significant thud and I experienced a dual epiphany: removable file storage has changed a lot in the last 10 years, and I really should clean my home office more often.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: PANEL MOVES TO OVERRIDE VETO

title: Campaign Season; On the Gore Watch, Signals Are Mixed
description: In Washington, it has become known as the Gore watch -- the speculation among aides and friends to the former vice president about whether he will run for president in 2004. Some advisers, particularly those who would like to have a campaign to work on in 2004, have taken hopeful note of any sign of Al Gore's political movement. For example: Mr. Gore announced yesterday that he would give a speech in California on Monday about Iraq.

title: Prompt Hearings Are Ordered For Owners of Seized Cars
description: A federal appeals court panel ruled yesterday that people accused of driving while intoxicated and other offenses must be promptly allowed to challenge the city's seizure of their cars. The decision, which overturns a lower court, strikes at an impoundment policy started by the Giuliani administration.

title: Survival of Softwares Fittest
description: For me, one of the most painful stories to emerge from the tech crash is that of Casady & Greene (C&G), a small software company for whom, before joining The Times, I once wrote user manuals.

title: Cuba Says U.S. Lied on Terror
description: Cuba's foreign minister today angrily rebutted State Department charges that his government was providing the United States with false leads on terrorism, and he accused one American official of ''lying with impudence.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the United States' request for permission from Britain to base B-2 bombers at an air base on Diego Garcia to increase pressure on Iraq misstated the type of weapon the aircraft would carry. It would be satellite-guided bombs, not laser-guided ones.

title: Hollywood Balks at High-Tech Sanitizers; Some Video Customers Want Tamer Films, and Entrepreneurs Rush to Comply
description: After months of watching a gradual proliferation of companies offering sanitized versions of Hollywood hits to sensitive or politically conservative consumers, movie studios and filmmakers have decided it is time to get a handle on this phenomenon.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: New Leader For Right-Wing Party
description: The far-right Freedom Party, in turmoil since the withdrawal of its de facto leader, Jrg Haider, over the weekend, named a little-known government minister, Mathias Reichhold, left, as chairman. Mr. Reichhold, 45, the transport minister, faces an uphill battle in elections this November. The party's support has been badly eroded by internal strife, which began when Mr. Haider forced out several senior officials, including Susanne Riess-Passer, who also served as vice chancellor. Mr. Haider then declined to take the helm, saying that he had been threatened and that he feared for the safety of his family. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday about people in Angola who are trying to reunite their families after 27 years of civil war misspelled the name of a television program that functions as a national message board. The title is ''Nao Coragem,'' or ''Courageous Nation'' (''No Coragem'' would have meant ''No Courage'').

title: GREETINGS FROM TUCSON
description: WB, Friday night at 9:30, Eastern and Pacific times; 8:30 Central time

title: Formulas for a Clean Election
description: To the Editor:

title: President Leaving Thompson Unit
description: In a shake-up at the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson, the agency said yesterday that Brian Heffernan, who has led the office as president for four years, was leaving, effective immediately.

title: City to Seek Power to Evict Some Families From Shelters
description: The city will ask a state court today to allow the eviction of homeless families from shelters if they engage in gross misconduct or fail to seek or accept suitable apartments, the commissioner of homeless services told a City Council committee yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSKY, MORTIMER
description: LIPSKY-Mortimer. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Co., P.C., mourn the passing of our esteemed partner and founder. His intellect, his passion for knowledge and learning, his resolve and determination, was an inspiration to all. He so ably taught and guided us. This compassionate man had a deep understanding and love for all mankind. He deeply loved his family, whom he protected, fought for, honored, and was so proud of. This was so evident in his actions and deeds. The love, devotion, care, respect, and dedication that he bestowed upon his wife Ann, who passed away, was admired & respected. To his children, Mark, Judy, Joel & Shari, his wife Norma, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, our heartfelt condolences. Mort will be truly missed, but not forgotten.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: Plea In Giordano Sex Case
description: A woman pleaded guilty yesterday to arranging sex between former Mayor Philip A. Giordano, left, and her underage daughter and her niece, the state's attorney's office said. The woman, 31, whose name is being withheld to protect the children's identity, was convicted of two counts of risk of injury to a minor and two counts of conspiracy to commit risk of injury to a minor. The woman, who court papers said was a prostitute, could be sentenced to up to 40 years in prison and receive a $1 million fine. The woman, who pleaded guilty to related federal charges last week, will testify that Mr. Giordano, who faces state and federal charges, paid for sex with the girls, who were 8 and 11. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hotel Worker To Get Back Pay
description: A federal judge has ordered a Midtown hotel and a businessman to pay $351,0000 in back pay and damages because of overtime violations. Judge Gerard Lynch found that the Hotel Stanford and its president, Joon Gab Kwon, violated federal and state overtime laws. Judge Lynch found the defendants had not provided time-and-a-half pay to a maintenance worker, Keun-Jae Moon, a Korean immigrant who worked 90-hour weeks. Hotel officials have not decided whether to appeal, said Kevin Hirson, a lawyer. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: PATENT-DISPUTE PAYMENT TO CURB BORGWARNER'S PROFIT
description: BorgWarner Inc., a maker of automobile transmission parts, said yesterday that it expected third-quarter and 2002 profit to fall short of forecasts as it pays for a patent settlement. Quarterly profit is expected to be $1.10 to $1.15 a share, up from net income of 70 cents a share a year earlier, a spokeswoman, Mary Brevard, said. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was $1.26. Third-quarter costs of the patent settlement will be about 16 cents a share, Ms. Brevard said. The third-quarter costs are about $6.5 million from a $25 million settlement with Honeywell International, BorgWarner said. The company paid Honeywell the $25 million in a partial settlement of the dispute over turbochargers, the companies said in July.

title: Williamsburg With a Birch Ceiling And Voltairean Wallpaper
description: It's not unusual for a bar to open in Brooklyn. It is unusual for a bar as stylish as the Red and Black to open in a former wholesale fish market in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The Red and Black's most striking feature is a birch-covered, vaulted ceiling, above, stained with a custom mix of methanol and aniline dye and running the length of the bar. ''It was a way to make a tall space more intimate,'' said Craig Shillitto, a principal in Weeve Projects, which designed the space. It is also doing a penthouse on Lafayette Street in Manhattan.

title: For McCall, It Takes Time To Travel Money Trail
description: Not that voters have necessarily noticed, but H. Carl McCall has been missing in action.

title: Israel Moves on Arafat's Compound After Bomber Kills 5
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 19 - A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up in a Tel Aviv bus outside the city's main synagogue today, killing five people and wounding scores. Several hours later, Israeli tanks and armored vehicles encircled Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah and demanded over loudspeakers that he surrender wanted men who were inside with him.

title: Leading Benefactor's Late Checks Fray the Nerves of Arts Groups
description: Alberto W. Vilar, a Cuban-American money manager who in just the last three years distinguished himself as perhaps the world's most lavish benefactor of opera and classical music, has failed to make payments to at least two prominent arts groups in the wake of high-tech stock losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROTA, BARBARA
description: SIROTA - Barbara. Loving soul mate to Marvin, devoted mother to Leslie and Douglas Hirsch and Hallie Sirota. Cherished sister of Susan and Ken Burg. Adored grandmother of Evan and Andrew Hirsch. Aunt of Emily, Hal, Harold, Suzanne, Larry and Craig. Loyal friend of many. Services 11:30 A.M. today at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

title: U.S. Company To Take Over Karzai Safety
description: The State Department plans to hire a private company to help protect President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, a job currently handled by American Special Operations soldiers.

title: Sports of The Times; Tee It Up; Be the First, Suzy Whaley
description: GO for it, Suzy Whaley.

title: Bronx Councilman Wins Primary for State Senate
description: The city's Board of Elections said yesterday that Ruben Diaz Sr. had defeated the incumbent state senator, Pedro Espada Jr., by 113 votes in the Sept. 10 Democratic Senate primary in the Bronx, ending an unpredictable contest complete with courtroom battles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMINGHAM, BETH RENY
description: BERMINGHAM-Beth Reny, 74. Of Scarsdale, on September 17, 2002 surrounded by her family. She was the dearly beloved wife of John H. Bermingham for 52 years. Mother of seven children, sons Thomas V. II, John H. Jr., Jerrold G. and Douglas McDonald (deceased) and daughters Maryclaire Fouse, Paula Filippone and Amy Wilson. Grandmother of 15. A 1948 graduate of College of New Rochelle, she was a former president of Catholic Women's Club of Westchester and of Immaculate Heart of Mary School PTA. Family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home on September 18, 7-9PM and September 19, 2-4 & 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale, N.Y., September 20, at 10AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Rev. Thomas V. Bermingham, S.J. Scholarship Fund, Fordham University, Bronx, NY.

title: $10 Million Accord Backed By Plaintiffs in Boston Case
description: A lawyer for 86 people suing Boston's Roman Catholic Archdiocese in the case of a pedophile priest said today that all the plaintiffs had agreed to accept a $10 million settlement from the church. The decision will apparently end one of the most notorious chapters of the scandal over sexual abuse by clergy members.

title: Formulas for a Clean Election
description: To the Editor:

title: City Ends Talks for Developers To Build S.I. Movie Studios
description: New York City officials broke off talks yesterday with a development group including the actor Danny Aiello that had planned to build film studios and a waterfront commercial complex at the site of the former Navy home port in Stapleton, on Staten Island.

title: After a Move, Still More Devilish Details
description: MY brother was waiting outside my new house with his huge moving truck and three assistants when I pulled up to the curb one recent morning.

title: Needing Each Other
description: Even at the level of a Potemkin village, Pyongyang fails to work anymore. Feet are the principal means of locomotion along the capital's broad, traffic-free avenues. At the city's clunky neo-Victorian main train station, the posted schedule of arrivals and departures is as chock-full as ever, but even at rush hour, no train is in sight, and there are few ostensible passengers.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Weathering Acidanthera

title: Corrections
description: Four photographs in the special ''Nation Challenged'' section on Sept. 11 with a listing of victims of the terrorist attacks were published in error. The one labeled David Seima Aoyama showed a woman whose identity is still unknown. The picture labeled William Cashman showed another man with the same name. The one labeled Jonathan Connors was a duplicate of the picture of another victim, Kevin Connors. The picture labeled Thomas H. McGinnis was a duplicate of the picture of Glenn Thompson. Correct pictures appear here.

title: U.S. Seeks To Deny Bail To Accused
description: The government said today that soon after four of the seven men charged here as a cell of Al Qaeda arrived in Pakistan in the spring of 2001, supposedly for religious education, they were told ''you are going to meet the most wanted one,'' meaning Osama bin Laden.

title: Let Us Now Praise Famous Housing for the Rural Poor
description: Mason's Bend, a hamlet in western Alabama, is home to five buildings designed by the renowned Rural Studio of Auburn University, 165 miles away in Auburn, Ala. The most recent is the Lucy House, above, with exterior walls made of recycled carpet tiles donated by Interface Inc., an Atlanta-based company. The stacked tiles are steadied by thin steel columns and compressed into a mass so dense it is said to repel both fire and water. The four-bedroom 1,500-square-foot house, which cost $32,000 to build, was among the final projects overseen by Samuel Mockbee, a founder of the Rural Studio, who died of leukemia at 57 last December.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KANEB PIPELINE OPERATING PARTNERSHIP, Richardson, Tex., a fuel transporter, agreed to buy a 2,000-mile fertilizer pipeline, from the closely held Koch Industries, Wichita, Kan., an energy trader, for $140 million.

title: The Eagles Were Ever So Close
description: The play still haunts Brian St. Pierre.

title: Transit Links Called Vital To a Revival of Downtown
description: The rebuilding of Lower Manhattan requires making direct transit links to Kennedy and Newark airports, burying West Street and erecting a major transportation center, a group of business and real estate officials say in a paper that is to be released today.

title: Happy Birthday :-) to You: A Smiley Face Turns 20
description: TWENTY years ago today, Scott E. Fahlman, a computer scientist at Carnegie Mellon University, posted an electronic message on a university bulletin board system suggesting that a colon, a minus sign and a parenthesis be used to convey a joking tone.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: FALUN GONG MEMBERS GO ON TRIAL Fifteen members of the banned spiritual group Falun Gong went on trial in the northeastern city of Changchun on charges of hijacking local cable television programming. On March 5 this year, normal cable programming in Changchun was interrupted for nearly half an hour during prime time and replaced by materials promoting Falun Gong. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: Bush Orders Faster Track For Approval Of Projects
description: President Bush ordered federal agencies today to speed environmental reviews for major transportation projects, arguing that excessive red tape had impeded the construction of airports and highways.

title: Physicists' Antimatter Recipe Is More Sci- Than Fi
description: Physicists working in Europe announced yesterday that they had passed through nature's looking glass and had created atoms made of antimatter, or antiatoms, opening up the possibility of experiments in a realm once reserved for science fiction writers. Such experiments, theorists say, could test some of the basic tenets of modern physics and light the way to a deeper understanding of nature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONROY, CHARLES P.
description: CONROY-Charles P. On September 17, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Mary A. (Doyle). Son of Dennis J. and Elizabeth (McWade). Devoted father of Maryanne Shortell, Charles P., Gerard M., Brian D., Joseph E. and Kevin J. Grandfather of nine, uncle, and grand-uncle. Brother of Dennis J., the late Elizabeth McCarthy, Joseph J., Veronica T. Casey and the Reverend Edward M. Burial services private.

title: E.D.S. Says Quarterly Profit Will Fall Short, and Shares Plunge
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings would fall well short of projections, and its shares plummeted almost one-third in after-hours trading.

title: Four Experiments in Little Living
description: IF the designers and decorators who cater to the upper echelons of residential customers have learned one thing over the years, it's this: think big. That has never been truer than now, when the old real-estate maxim ''Location, location, location'' has given way to the expansionist credo ''Size is everything.''

title: Campaign Season; Former Friends on Dueling Talk Shows
description: They are two of Washington's best-known names, and they have not spoken to each other for years, not since Hillary Rodham Clinton was the first lady and George Stephanopoulos wrote a critical memoir about working for President Bill Clinton. Could that change now that Mrs. Clinton has become Senator Clinton and Mr. Stephanopoulos has taken over as the host of the Sunday morning ABC talk show ''This Week''?

title: Whiff of Chocolate, and the Sweet Smell of Success
description: The exultation was as pungent as the aroma from the chocolate factory on Cocoa Avenue today as residents and workers in this ultimate company town saw the trustees who control Hershey Foods suddenly retreat from their plan to sell the company, the nation's largest candy maker.

title: A Titian Is No Longer at Large; Its Thief Is
description: The package was almost comically nondescript, a brown paper parcel stowed in a cheap plastic shopping bag and stashed, as promised, at a bus stop in west London. But inside was the long-lost Titian masterpiece that investigators had been hunting for seven years.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sri Lankan Rebels Yield on State Demand
description: Sri Lankan rebels backed away today from their demand for a separate state, saying their long and deadly civil war was aimed at creating a ''homeland'' within the nation for the Tamil minority.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban's Founder Still Eludes Search
description: Somewhere in the mountain fastness north of here, in tribal lands beyond the reach of Afghanistan's central government, Mullah Omar Mohammed is believed to be hiding.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Who Will Be The Godfather?
description: Fatherhood, it seems, is an impulse that cannot be denied, not even to an imprisoned mobster separated from visitors by glass. That is the moral of the revelation this week that a Sicilian Mafia man managed to impregnate his partner. The development had less to do with connubial cunning than persistent litigation: after years of appeals to the Justice Ministry, the father-to-be was allowed to provide sperm to his partner, who then used in-vitro fertilization. But Italian mercy has its limits. The mobster, identified only as ''G.R.,'' will be allowed to hold his baby only 10 minutes every month at the maximum-security prison in central Italy where he resides. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Work Begins on Oil Pipeline Bypassing Russia and Iran
description: Construction formally began today on a new pipeline to carry oil from the Caspian Sea to the Mediterranean coast of Turkey, bypassing Russia and Iran.

title: Festival Mishaps Can't Dim Lyon's Latin American Spirit
description: ''Terra Latina'' is the title of this year's Lyon Dance Biennial, devoted to dance in Latin America. True to form, the three-week event, the 10th since 1984, offers what other major international festivals do not: a concentrated overview of dance in a single country or in theme-related regions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, BETTY
description: GOODMAN-Betty. Perfect wife and partner to Arthur. The best mother to Jaye and Peter, Marian and Mark. Adored and doting grandmother to Cristopher, Josh, Nicholas and Jordan. She was the loving center of our family and friends and will be missed more than words can express. Rest in peace, you are always with us. Funeral services Friday 9:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Friends may call Thursday evening 6-9 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center.

title: U.S. Proposes Hedge Fund Rules To Prevent Terrorist Financing
description: The Treasury Department said today that it wanted to require the vast and largely unregulated hedge fund industry to hunt for and tell the government about suspicious clients that may be linked to terrorism.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Confusion Over Europe Treaty
description: Only 16 percent of Irish people polled understand the Treaty of Nice, the European Union pact on expansion that faces a possible second rejection by voters in a referendum this autumn, a government survey found. If ratified, the treaty will allow Eastern European countries like Poland and Hungary to join the union more easily. Irish voters narrowly rejected it in June 2001, and campaigners against the measure have questioned the constitutionality a second vote. More than 40 percent of people polled could not state a single issue related to the treaty, which critics also say compromises Ireland's traditional neutrality. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Oh, Rats
description: Rats breed voraciously and are said to have 15,000 descendants before they die in a year.

title: Senate Candidates Go on Attack Over Social Security
description: The United States Senate campaign, which has been dominated by questions about ethics, veered today toward equally contentious issues about the future of Social Security.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Teachers Approve New Contract
description: Public school teachers, who walked out this month, voted yesterday to approve a three-year contract. The union's vote tally will not be available until the school board votes on the contract on Tuesday. A tentative deal ended a two-day strike, and teachers returned on Sept. 6. Officials familiar with the settlement say it provides annual raises of 4.4 to 4.9 percent.

title: Pakistan Arrests at Least 7 Militants, Including Suspect in Bombing
description: The police arrested at least seven Pakistani militants in raids in Karachi this morning, including the suspected mastermind of a car bombing last May that killed 11 French engineers and 3 Pakistanis, officials said in a statement tonight.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Discovers Loss
description: Swiss Life said an accounting error led it, Switzerland's biggest life insurer, to record a $168 million profit in the first half of last year when it actually posted a loss. The company, which is based in Zurich, said it mistakenly booked an unrealized investment gain as a realized gain on its income statement for the first half of 2001. As a result, Swiss Life posted a profit of 253 million francs ($168 million) in the first half of 2001 when it should have had a loss of a million francs, the chairman, Andres Leuenberger, above, said. ''This isn't balance sheet fraud,'' Mr. Leuenberger said at a press briefing. ''The income statement wasn't correct. It's a mistake that we have to admit. We will do everything so that it won't happen again.''

title: Iraq in a Hard Place
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including comments on the inevitability of war with Iraq and two reader reviews from the Toronto Film Festival.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In Murder Plot
description: A man who admitted to helping murder and dismember another man in what officials said was an attempt to seize the man's apartment was sentenced yesterday to 25-years-to-life in prison. The defendant, Rahman Williams, 22, of Manhattan, was found in the apartment of the victim, Gerry Pollard, 49, in May 2001. Prosecutors said Mr. Williams and two other men assaulted Mr. Pollard near his apartment in the Dyckman Houses in Inwood. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: DO OVER
description: WB, tonight at 8:30, Eastern and Pacific times; 7:30 Central time

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPLAS, ROMAIN
description: dePLAS - Romain. Words cannot express our grief over the loss of such a warm, talented, and engaging person whose love, devotion and brilliance brought so much to our lives. How he will be missed. May he rest in peace and his endearing memory help sustain his family and other loved ones. Romain will be forever in our hearts and souls. Dan & Giovanna Rosenbloom

title: Democrats Start Petition To Force Vote on Drug Bill
description: Democrats in the House, backed by two Republican senators, began an effort today to force Republican leaders to schedule a vote on a bill that would accelerate the approval and marketing of generic drugs.

title: No Link to Al Qaeda in Arrests in Germany
description: German prosecutors say they have found no evidence so far to link a couple charged with planning a Sept. 11 attack in Germany to Al Qaeda or any other international terrorist group.

title: I Think, Therefore IM
description: EACH September Jacqueline Harding prepares a classroom presentation on the common writing mistakes she sees in her students' work.

title: Florida Seeks Federal Help In Its Voting
description: Gov. Jeb Bush asked the federal Justice Department today for help in Florida's November general election, seeking to avoid a repeat of the chaos at the polls in two Florida counties in last week's primary election.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Panel Moves To Override Veto
description: A City Council committee yesterday approved sending Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's veto of an amendment to the term-limits law back to the full Council for an override vote next week. The amendment would give Speaker Gifford Miller and seven other council members an extra two years in office. The measure passed in July by a vote of 46 to 2, well over the two-thirds majority needed to override Mr. Bloomberg's veto. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: The German Problem
description: At a meeting in the Axel Springer building in Hamburg on Aug. 27 with about 30 American friends of Germany, the defense minister who had been recently booted out of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's cabinet for financial irregularities was asked why Germany was so loudly opposed to President Bush's campaign to oust Saddam Hussein.

title: On the Go, Stalked All the While By a Bland Corporate Voice
description: For years, computers have been telling us when we have mail. A beep. A whistle. And more recently computers have also read e-mail messages aloud. Now iSpeak has developed a talking application for the PocketPC.

title: Study Says Middle Class to Lose Much of Bush Tax Cut's Benefit
description: Nearly all middle- and upper-middle-class families will lose some of the income tax cuts scheduled over the next eight years as they are forced to pay a separate tax originally intended to make sure that the rich cannot live tax-free, a study released today found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONFANTINI, PETER
description: BONFANTINI-Peter. Of Somers, N.Y. Died September 16, 2002. Former partner of Rattazzi Restaurant in Manhattan. Husband of Stephanie. Father of Lawrence and Alfred. Also survived by four grandchildren. Memorial Mass Saint Joseph's R.C. Church, Croton Falls, N.Y. Sat., 11AM. Interment private.

title: Campaign Season; Barbra Streisand to Step Up for Democrats
description: Whatever you do, don't call it coming out of retirement. But Barbra Streisand, the Republicans' poster child of Hollywood liberalism, is coming out of a two-year period of not working to raise money for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. She will sing at a gala at the Kodak Theater (home of the Academy Awards and ''American Idol''), on Sept. 29, at an event that is expected to raise $4 million to power the Democratic effort to win a House majority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANK, LENA GREENSPAN
description: BLANK - Lena Greenspan. Devoted wife of the late George, beloved mother of Barbara Wolfson and Dr. Wesley (Nanette) Blank. Loving grandmother of Ross, Daniel, Leah, Hadass and Rebecca. Services are today, 10:30AM at Ocean Parkway Jewish Center, 550 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLDSTEIN, SOPHIE G.
description: HOLDSTEIN-Sophie G. On September 17 at 100 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Walter M. Holdstein and mother of Jill Edelson and Margot Harley. Her grandsons Geoffrey, David, Andrew and Joshua Edelson and great - grandchildren Charlotte, Annabel, Oliver, Benzi and Mia Edelson will all miss Raggy. Services Friday, September 20, at 1 P.M. at Temple Emanul-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: French Free Top Civilian Official Jailed for War Crimes
description: Maurice Papon, the highest-ranking French civilian ever to be brought to justice for Nazi war crimes in World War II, walked free from prison today because of old age and poor health.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hearings Set On Queens Plane Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board will open hearings in Washington next month on the crash of American Airlines Flight 587, the Airbus A-300 that went down in Queens last Nov. 12, the board said yesterday. The hearings, to begin Oct. 29, are expected to last four or five days. The crash, which killed all 260 people on board and 5 on the ground, occurred after the vertical portion of the plane's tail fell off. The board said it would explore the adequacy of design standards for the tail and the rudder, the system of inspecting the plane, pilot training and the role that wake turbulence might have played. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Unwanted Coins
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Clothier Posts Profit
description: Europe's largest clothing retailer, Hennes & Mauritz, said its third-quarter profit rose 53 percent, more than expected, as it opened stores and sold more products at full price, while still reducing inventories. Net income rose to 1.24 billion kronor ($133.3 million) in the quarter from 810.2 million kronor a year earlier. By limiting discounts, the company, which is based in Stockholm, raised its gross margin, or the percentage of sales remaining after product costs are subtracted, to a record 54 percent from 51.3 percent a year earlier. It cut inventory 15 percent, to 5.3 billion kronor.

title: Drive-Ins, Near Death, Arise From The Weeds
description: IT was Saturday night, and Ed Gudinas could have been in Brockton, Mass., on a cushy couch, watching a movie on his large-screen home theater with surround sound. Instead, he was sitting in a camp chair on an open field, swatting the occasional mosquito and watching ''Men in Black 2,'' the first half of a double feature on a 50-by-110-foot screen at a drive-in more than 100 miles from home.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first day of Sukkot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: A Slice of Paradise at the Razor's Edge
description: THERE are many things I loathe in the world -- traveling and slow walkers, among them -- but near the top of my list is shaving.

title: Higher Home Heating Bills Expected This Winter
description: Consumers should expect to pay more to heat their homes this winter because rising demand and declining supplies are driving up the prices of natural gas and heating oil, analysts say.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3Com Loss Narrows On Lower Costs
description: One of the world's leading makers of computer-networking equipment, the 3Com Corporation, said yesterday that its first-quarter net loss had narrowed because of lower costs. Revenue fell 22 percent. The loss narrowed to $32 million, or 9 cents a share, from $232.4 million, or 67 cents a share, in the year-earlier period, the company said. Sales in the period ended Aug. 30 dropped to $304.7 million from $389.6 million. It was the 10th consecutive loss for 3Com, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., and which had quarterly revenue of as much as $1.6 billion five years ago when it challenged Cisco Systems for the top rank in the networking industry.

title: Los Angeles Archdiocese Trims Jobs and Ministries
description: On the heels of dedicating its $189 million cathedral complex, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles is laying off workers and paring services to close a $4.3 million budget deficit.

title: Excerpts: Bush's National Security Strategy
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's outline of "The National Security Strategy of the United States." The full text is online at nytimes.com.

title: 'The Heavenly Tree Grows Downward'
description: Selected Works by Harry Smith, Philip Taaffe and Fred Tomaselli

title: Officials Warn That Transfusions Carry the Risk of West Nile Virus
description: Federal health officials said yesterday that they were nearly certain the West Nile virus had been transmitted through blood transfusions, and that they were accelerating efforts to develop tests to detect the virus in blood.

title: WorldCom Creditors Said to Be Restless
description: Bert C. Roberts Jr., WorldCom's chairman, and John W. Sidgmore, its chief executive, are coming under increasing criticism from the company's creditors, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: Miami Running Back Works With New Focus
description: Standing on the Rose Bowl turf last season in the afterglow of another national championship for Miami, Willis McGahee watched his teammate Andre Johnson hoist the crystal football symbolic of that success. So McGahee made himself a promise.

title: Experts Say Nuclear Plants Can Survive Jetliner Crash
description: Seeking to counter assertions that the nation's nuclear plants are vulnerable to attacks like the one on the World Trade Center, 19 prominent nuclear experts have concluded that a reactor containment building could easily withstand the force of a jetliner crash.

title: Slovaks, Casting Ballots, Seem Likely to Choose Change
description: The only apparent certainty in elections this weekend in Slovakia is that Vladimir Meciar, the thrice-elected, thrice-ousted former prime minister, is unlikely to regain office.

title: Court Filings Hold Messages For Al Qaeda, Officials Say
description: Federal prosecutors warned today that Zacarias Moussaoui might be issuing coded messages to other followers of Al Qaeda through handwritten court motions and urged a federal judge to bar him from filing documents that might contain secret messages.

title: Knight Ridder Cuts Estimate For Earnings in Third Quarter
description: The publishing company Knight Ridder reported a continuing slump in advertising yesterday and lowered its third-quarter earnings estimate, igniting a sell-off in newspaper stocks. By the end of the day, shares in the industry's largest companies were down 4 percent to 7 percent in a flurry of late trading. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 2.8 percent for the day.

title: A Civil War Within a Trade Dispute
description: What began as an obscure trade dispute between Europe and the United States has turned into a political brawl over $100 billion in corporate tax breaks that pits many of America's biggest companies against one another.

title: Brother Of Bison Dele Found in Coma
description: Miles Dabord, the subject of a international manhunt in connection with the disappearance of his younger brother, the former N.B.A. player Bison Dele, and two others off the coast of Tahiti, was arrested last night as he lay comatose in a California hospital.

title: U.S. Seeks Russian Support on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  President Bush reached out to Russia today, hoping to get its backing behind his tough approach toward Iraq. The White House expressed guarded optimism afterward, while Russian officials were reserved and said more dialogue was needed.

title: Transcript of Sen. Pierre Claude Nolin's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Tuesday, Sept. 12, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Canadian Senator Pierre Claude Nolin . This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORD, HOPE (MCWILLIAM)
description: FORD-Hope (McWilliam). Age 79 of Orleans, MA. September 12. Wife of Russell Ford. Mother of Russell Jr. of Westport, CT., Holly Ridgway of Chester, CT., Lucia Morgan of Harvard, Catherine Daly of Dover, sister of Susan Stevens of Orleans. Also survived by six grandchildren, 12 nieces and nephews. Memorial service will be held at 11 AM September 21 at the Church of the Holy Spirit, Orleans, MA. Memorial donations may be made to Hospice & Palliative Care of Cape Cod, 270 Communication Way, Hyannis, MA. 02601.

title: Creative Partners Completes Buyout
description: Creative Partners in Stamford, Conn., has completed a management buyout from Earle Palmer Brown in New York, part of Panoramic Communications.

title: Time to Change the Way Options Are Taxed
description: THE argument about stock options is finally turning to something worth arguing about. Not whether they are an expense to the companies that issue them -- the answer to that question has long been clear -- but how much they are worth.

title: Browsing In Splendor
description: In Paris, as they say, shopping is life. For quality, luxe, glamour and sheer fun, no antiques fair beats the Biennale des Antiquaires, a show that takes place every other year in the Carrousel du Louvre. This year, the Biennale runs from today through Sept. 29.

title: The Vision Thing
description: This is the way the recovery ends -- not with a bang but with a whimper.

title: Ergonomics: Backpack To the Future
description: SURE, you can grab newspaper, books, water bottle and CD player, and stuff them willy-nilly in your old sagging canvas backpack. Or you can step up, putting your needs and your stuff together with an ergonomic pack that not only makes your back feel good, but may even make it feel better.

title: Jets' Thomas Faces Inquiry
description: A lawyer for Bryan Thomas, the Jets' first-round draft pick last spring, said yesterday that he expects to meet with detectives for the Port Authority police and members of the Queens district attorney's office early next week to provide information that he said contradicts allegations that Thomas was involved in a domestic dispute with his girlfriend at La Guardia Airport Tuesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELSEN, PEARL
description: DANIELSEN-Pearl. Of Sea Cliff, NY, formerly of Flushing, NY on September 18, 2002. Beloved wife of the late John A. Danielsen. Loving mother of Gwynne Lennon (Mike) and Claire Darcy (Charles). Dear grandmother of Michael Lennon, Kathleen Lennon, James Lennon, Craig Darcy, John Lennon and Christine Darcy. Visiting Friday 2-5 & 7-9PM, Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Head. Funeral service Saturday 10AM at the funeral home. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, New York.

title: In Saddam Hussein's Words: It's for Oil
description: Following are excerpts from a letter to the United Nations General Assembly from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, as presented orally yesterday and recorded by The New York Times:

title: Drive to Tie Up Legal Loose Ends
description: A few weeks after he was elected mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg said that one of his first goals was to disentangle the city from a web of lawsuits, and to try to prevent future litigation. In the nearly nine months he has been in office, Mr. Bloomberg's administration has been remarkably swift at doing just that.

title: France to Appeal for the Return of Vichy War Criminal to Prison
description: The French government said today that it would seek to overturn the decision to free Maurice Papon, the highest-ranking French civilian ever to be convicted of Nazi war crimes in World War II.

title: Circling Their Stogies Against Mayor
description: MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG, scourge of the smoking class, has journeyed to the heart of enemy territory. The mayor was in Athens yesterday. After spending more time there today, he heads for Istanbul.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: GOODRICH PLANS LESS EQUITY FINANCING FOR TRW DEAL
description: Goodrich, the maker of aircraft landing gear, plans to sell assets to reduce the amount of equity financing it will need for its $1.5 billion purchase of the aeronautical business of TRW Inc. Equity-linked securities issued for the purchase will be ''substantially smaller'' than the $400 million projected in June when the acquisition was announced, the chief financial officer, Ulrich R. Schmidt, said. Goodrich had planned to issue $1.1 million in debt to finance the rest of the purchase.

title: Conjuring Up Atmosphere Only Anime Can Deliver
description: The title ''Spirited Away'' could refer to what Disney has done on a corporate level to the revered Japanese animation director Hayao Miyazaki's epic and marvelous new anime fantasy. The picture is being promoted as Disney's ''Spirited Away,'' although seeing just 10 minutes of this English version of a hugely popular Japanese film will quickly disabuse any discerning viewer of the notion that it is a Disney creation. The towering, lost dreaminess at the heart of the film is an unmistakable obsession of this director. Actually, rather than Disney's ''Spirited Away, the movie could better be considered Mr. Miyazaki's ''Through the Looking Glass.''

title: A Stellar Gathering of Femmes Proves a Bit Fatale
description: Unless you have a special fondness for color, glamour and elegance -- unless, to be more precise, you are enamored of classic couture, great French actresses and lush musical orchestration -- there is no good reason to see ''8 Women,'' Franois Ozon's sumptuous and rigorous derangement of plausibility, coherence and proper taste. But who ever went to the movies for good reasons?

title: FORD'S JAGUAR UNIT PLANS TO CUT 400 JOBS IN BRITAIN
description: Ford Motor's Jaguar luxury-car unit said yesterday that it was offering early retirement incentives to cut 400 jobs, or 3.8 percent of its British work force, to reduce costs. The reductions will come mostly from managers and will be voluntary, a spokesman said. Ford intends to make the cuts by the end of the year from Jaguar's three assembly plants. Jaguar said earlier that it was reducing production in September and October at the Halewood factory in Liverpool, England, where the X-type is built. The spokesman said the 400 jobs were not related to those cuts. Jaguar employs 10,600 workers in Britain.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Review/Fashion; At Blass, Dramatic Clothes Minus the Drama
description: At some point in the history of runway fashion -- maybe the moment was Saint Laurent's homage to the Cossacks in the 1970's -- designers began to assume that they needed to offer more than the theater already inherent in parading clothes on the bodies of women with necks as long as Champagne bottles. They had to become auteurs too, creating elaborate narratives for their garments, conveyed with the help of interviews and press notes, and revolving around, say, the idea of a young Sicilian widow who picks herself up, moves to Mykonos and opens a disco, putting grief behind with the aid of a rhinestone-studded crocheted bikini. For anyone choosing not to write a script, there was the option of revisiting one already committed to celluloid -- ''This season I was thinking about 'Last Year at Marienbad,' and now so will you.''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: $40 MILLION STUDY OF EXTENDED NO. 7 LINE

title: OPEC Leaves Quotas Intact, but Says It Can Pump More
description: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries left its current production quotas intact at a meeting today but declared that it was ready to pump extra oil on short notice if shortages developed, including any resulting from an American attack on Iraq.

title: The Politics of War
description: Congress seems all but ready to sign off on an omnibus resolution proposed yesterday by President Bush that would authorize the use of force against Iraq, even in the absence of United Nations support. Independent American action may ultimately be the course the nation chooses to take, but at this stage Congress and the American people deserve some time to ponder the matter and to give the Security Council a chance to act. Even the most ardent advocates of going to war ought to realize that doing so in concert with other nations, and with the explicit approval of the Security Council, would be far preferable to military action by the United States and Britain.

title: Encouraging ratings for 3 networks that tried early debuts.
description: IT'S early. Very early.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about Hollywood's hope for more profits in China misstated the English title for a film by the director Jiang Wen, who was quoted as saying that deplorable conditions in movie houses were one reason people preferred to watch pirated DVD's. The film is ''Devils on the Doorstep,'' not ''Devil at My Doorstep.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Personal Income Tax Revenue Falls
description: New York State collected about $8.7 billion in personal income tax between April and August, a drop of about 21 percent from the same period a year ago, the state comptroller's office reported. The amounts collected on 2002 tax returns and prepayments on estimated earnings for this year have declined. Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for the comptroller's office, said that unemployment had risen since last year and many of those with jobs were no longer receiving large bonuses. The comptroller's office estimated that 2002 earnings accounted for $2.3 billion, a decline of about 31 percent, and final tax returns brought $1.1 billion, a drop of about 32 percent. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: $752 Million In Aid Is Due For Farmers Hit by Drought
description: The Bush administration said today that it would provide $752 million in emergency aid for livestock producers in the West and elsewhere. The move could aid a Republican Senate candidate as well as drought-stricken ranchers.

title: Jets Seek Improvement On the Defensive Line
description: Larry Webster knows what is like to play for a stifling defense, knows the feeling of watching an opponent's desperate offense pass again and again. He played tackle for the Baltimore Ravens in 2000, the season they set a record for the fewest points allowed in a 16-game season and won the Super Bowl with perhaps the greatest defense in National Football League history.

title: A Deal on Fuel Economy Rules Could Increase Oil Consumption
description: House and Senate negotiators reached an agreement today on new fuel economy rules that would increase oil consumption, rather than decrease it, unless the Bush administration takes more aggressive action.

title: The Rangers Unveil a Spacious Practice Paradise and Say Goodbye to Rye
description: For 23 years the Rangers practiced at a suburban rink in Rye more suited to families than a professional hockey team.

title: Weekender | Candlewood Isle, Conn.
description: CANDLEWOOD ISLE, about 10 miles from Danbury, isn't exactly the place in Connecticut to buy a weekend home if your goal is getting away from it all. From the Friday gatherings at sunset -- the children frolicking in the playground while their hovering parents catch up on the week's events over slices of pizza and plastic glasses of wine -- to the Saturday night cocktail parties on the beach to the potluck holiday dinners at the clubhouse, this association of about 750 people (about half of them second-home owners) buzzes with social activity.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: Record Power Demand Reported
description: For the second year in a row, the Long Island Power Authority reported record summertime demand for electricity. With temperatures exceeding 90 degrees for much of the summer, use from June through August grew nearly 10 percent from the same period a year ago, said Richard M. Kessel, left, the authority's chairman. Demand for those months set a record of 6.6 million megawatt-hours. Since 1998, the demand for electricity during the summer has risen by nearly 22 percent, said Michael Lowndes, a power authority spokesman. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Bush Outlines Doctrine of Striking Foes First
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  The Bush administration published today its first comprehensive rationale for shifting American military strategy toward pre-emptive action against hostile states and terrorist groups developing weapons of mass destruction. The strategy document also states, for the first time, that the United States will never allow its military supremacy to be challenged the way it was during the cold war.

title: The Coveted Highways of Madison Avenue
description: EVER notice how cars in commercials always seem to be on a fantasy drive? The road is challenging, the scenery is great and there isn't another car in sight. Forget the car -- wouldn't it be nice to find a road like that?

title: Cordiant Chairman Will Resign Soon
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London said yesterday that Charles Scott, the chairman since 1995, would resign as soon as a successor is named.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Report Faults Juvenile Training School
description: The Connecticut Juvenile Training School, the state's new $57 million juvenile correction center for boys, is an ''unconscionable failure'' and no better than the troubled center it replaced, according to a report released yesterday by the state's attorney general and child advocate. The commissioner of the Department of Children and Families, Kristine D. Ragaglia, left, said in response that the school was a work in progress. The report cites a high risk of youth suicide, improper use of restraints and inadequate schooling. The investigation that led to the report began in November 2001, after complaints from youth and staff there. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: A Timid Academician, Tempted by Modernism
description: Not all art deserves to be remembered. Sometimes, though, retrieving things from the dustbin of history can be illuminating, and that is the case with a show of paintings and drawings by the forgotten French academician Pascal-Adolphe-Jean Dagnan-Bouveret at the National Academy of Design Museum.

title: Umpires Want Ball-Strike Monitor Gone
description: The umpires union called yesterday for Major League Baseball to end its association with the company whose pitch-tracking system baseball officials use to monitor and evaluate umpires.

title: Murder Charges Are Dropped In Motorcycle Gang Fight
description: Prosecutors dropped murder charges today against a member of the Hells Angels motorcycle club, saying he may have been justified in firing the shot that killed a member of a rival club at a Hells Angels event in February. Members of the other group, the Pagan Outlaw Motorcycle Club, had crashed the event, many of them wielding bats and other weapons.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA: MOSQUE BLOWN UP Saboteurs blew up a mosque in the Serbian part of Bosnia just three months after it was reopened following its destruction during the 1992-1995 war. Muslims expelled by Serbian forces at that time have only recently begun to return to the area, near the southeastern town of Gacko. Relations among Bosnia's Serbs, Muslims and Croats remain tense seven years after the war ended, and an election next month is expected to return more nationalists to power in the country, which is divided between a Serbian republic and a Muslim-Croat federation. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Should Our Colleges Be Ranked?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $40 Million Study Of Extended No. 7 Line
description: A transit panel decided yesterday to award a $40 million contract to study the best way to extend the No. 7 line from Times Square to the West Side of Manhattan. The four-year contract would cover a comprehensive environmental and engineering study. The extension of the line, promoted by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, would be an important part of a plan to develop a new business district, possibly including a sports stadium, in a 59-square-block area stretching from West 24th Street to West 42nd Street, and from the Hudson River to as far east as Eighth Avenue. The transit committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted to award the contract to the engineering firm Parsons Brinckerhoff Quade & Douglas, and the full board of the M.T.A. is expected to approve the contract next week. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: GROWTH FORECAST CUT The Italian finance minister, Giulio Tremonti, slashed the government's forecast for 2002 economic growth by more than half, to about 0.6 percent, saying a global economic slump has hurt exports and manufacturing. In a speech to the lower house of Parliament on the economy, Mr. Tremonti also trimmed the government's forecast for next year's growth to 2.3 percent, from 2.9 percent. "What is worrying are tensions in the oil markets, falling stock markets, an unexpected decline in production and the negative performance of vast areas of the European economic landscape," Mr. Tremonti said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERS, ROBERT
description: PETERS-Robert. The Board, members, and staff of the Greater New York Hospital Association, (GNYHA), mourn the passing of Robert Peters, of Rio Rancho, NM, beloved father of Theresa Bischoff, President of NYU Hospitals Center and Past Chair of the GNYHA Board of Governors. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the Peters and Bischoff families and their many friends. Edward A. Stolzenberg, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater New York Hospital Association

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend last Friday about a tour of trees in three New York City boroughs misstated the way that a European beech tree in Kissena Park, Queens, came to have a heart inscribed in its bark 25 feet up. Because trees grow from the tips of their branches, not from their base, the carving would have been done at that height, not at eye level.

title: Hell on Wheels, and Nerves; If Ever There Was a Mean Street, It's the Cross Bronx
description: If you have ever wondered if you are in hell, it has been said, then you are on a well-traveled road of spiritual inquiry.

title: Editor of Atlantic Monthly Is Shifting to Another Post
description: Michael Kelly, editor of The Atlantic Monthly, is stepping down after three years to become editor at large beginning with the November issue. Cullen Murphy, currently the managing editor, will retain that title but take over the magazine's top editorial position and run the day-to-day operations.

title: Zimbabwe's Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Refining His Motion Pays Off For Collins
description: This is how a quarterback learns to throw a football: He is 7 or 8 years old and he grabs it and throws it and makes his big brother laugh. ''You're throwing it like a baseball,'' Kerry Collins is told.

title: 2 Former Executives of Tyco Get Extra Day to Raise Bail
description: A Manhattan judge gave L. Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H. Swartz, the two top former Tyco executives who are charged with looting the company, another day yesterday to post millions of dollars in bail.

title: N.F.L. Has Ally in Madden Game
description: If you accept the notion that the most valuable, most elusive, most revered and most coddled sports viewers in the galaxy are the beer-guzzling, nachos-eating, fantasy-football-playing, video-game-loving guys 18 to 34 years of age, then something dramatic has happened two weeks into the National Football League season.

title: Port Operators On West Coast Cancel Threat Of a Lockout
description: West Coast port operators tonight called off a threatened shutdown of all cargo terminals in Los Angeles and Long Beach after the longshoremen's union ended what management called a slowdown and resumed full staffing at a major terminal.

description: Klemens Gasser & Tanja
