description: ALASKA: GROUP TRACKS OIL AND GAS SPILLS

title: Fast Getaways, From a Desert Spa to a Hawaiian Resort
description: Whether your idea of a quick getaway involves driving to a hotel across town or flying across the country, there are a number of travel deals available this fall, ranging from a high-end spa vacation in the Arizona desert to a family outing in the Allegheny Mountains. J. R. Romanko

title: Cuts Lessen Space Station's Value to Science, Report Says
description: The International Space Station will never be a first-class research laboratory if recent decisions to reduce its crew size and scientific equipment remain in effect, according to a report by a panel of experts.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kremlin Opposes K.G.B. Statue
description: The Kremlin said that it opposed restoring a monument to Feliks Dzerzhinsky, the founder of what became the K.G.B., that was pulled down after the failed coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1991. ''Today there are calls to put back the monument to Dzerzhinsky,'' Vladislav Surkov, the deputy chief of staff for President Vladimir V. Putin, told Interfax. ''Tomorrow other people will demand that Lenin's body be taken out of the mausoleum.'' Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow said last week that he wanted to put the monument back up. Human rights groups and liberal politicians accused him of trying to curry favor with Mr. Putin, who was a lieutenant colonel in the K.G.B. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Suffolk Says Drug Ring Involving Police Officers Was Informal but Lucrative
description: Four police officers from three New York-area agencies have been arrested on charges involving the sale and use of cocaine and anabolic steroids, Suffolk County authorities announced yesterday. Ten other people they associated with were also arrested on drug charges, officials said.

title: New Detail About the Bickering Builders of the Bomb
description: BROTHERHOOD OF THE BOMB

title: A's Win, And Lead By a Game
description: The Oakland Athletics nosed ahead in their stretch drive with the Anaheim Angels today by winning, 5-3, with the help of a two-run, tie-breaking home run by Terrence Long, Tim Hudson's gritty pitching and perfect relief.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Boorish Gods And Sad Swine

title: A Paean to Women
description: This plate for St. Bridget is among 39 honoring women through the ages in Judy Chicago's ''Dinner Party'' (1979), now at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WorldCom Creditors Said to Be Restless

title: Scott Richter
description: Elizabeth Harris Gallery

title: Hussein, in a Letter to General Assembly, Says Bush Wants to Control Mideast Oil
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq accused the Bush administration today of seeking to ''destroy Iraq in order to control the Middle East oil'' and asserted that Mr. Bush had made ''distortions'' to lead Americans to think Iraq had a role in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Should Our Colleges Be Ranked?
description: To the Editor:

title: Friends of Dorothy From Over the Rainbow
description: ''Don't Ask Don't Tell'' takes a notorious public-domain stinker from 1954 -- the numbingly dull science-fiction thriller ''Killers From Space'' -- and fixes it up with a new, tongue-in-cheek soundtrack. A technique pioneered by Woody Allen (who turned a Japanese spy movie into ''What's Up, Tiger Lily?'' in 1966) and later adapted by the television series ''Mystery Science Theater 3000,'' it's a gag that's worn a bit thin over the years, though ''Don't Ask'' still finds a few chuckles.

title: At Site of Ancient Olympics, Bloomberg Pitches for 2012's
description: Soon after arriving here this morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg strode into a colossal white marble stadium where athletes have competed since the fourth century B.C., and where the first modern Olympics were held in 1896.

title: All of a Sudden, It's DVD Season
description: Rarely have DVD releases been as prolific as they are this week and next. First, though, back up to Sept. 10 for ''Near Dark'' (1987), Kathryn Bigelow's hybrid western horror film (with a dash of sexual mythology) about a pack of vampires (Bill Paxton, Lance Henriksen, Adrian Pasdar, Jenny Wright) on the road. ''Daddy, I'm bit,'' as one of them puts it in this eerie early work by the director of ''Blue Steel,'' ''Point Break'' and, most recently, ''K-19: The Widowmaker.'' The two-disc set from Anchor Bay ($29.98) has a commentary by Ms. Bigelow and a documentary with plenty of lively observations by Mr. Paxton and others.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Secrecy In Litigation
description: Federal judges in South Florida are considering a proposal to limit secrecy in litigations, including a ban on secret settlements. Federal judges in South Carolina have proposed similar rules. The Florida study was prompted by the concerns of Judge James Lawrence King of Federal District Court, who recently declined to sign a blanket confidentiality order in an age-discrimination case. ''The founding fathers intended that American courts would no longer conduct 'star chamber' proceedings,'' Judge King wrote. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for performances last Saturday night only.

title: Cup Rivalry Renewed in Shadows of Past Glories
description: Roland Garros is the house that the four Mousquetaires built, and today their latest generation of successors stood at various stages of attention as the draw for this year's Davis Cup semifinal was conducted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, VIRGINIA TONS MEIRE
description: ARNOLD - Virginia Tons meire, 95. Died on Monday, September 16 at her home in Mamaroneck, NY. She is survived by her two sons James Michael, Jr. of Manhattan and E. Barton of Lenox, MA. Her daughter Nancy Arnold Goldstein of Manhattan and her three granddaughters: Jocelyn, Gillian Goldstein and Emma Arnold. For information contact the George T. Davis Funeral Home in New Rochelle, New York.

title: A Tower of Dentists Wears a Golden Crown
description: It is the undisputed king of the Brooklyn skyline, the most populous borough's only widely recognized piece of architecture that is not a roller coaster. Its gigantic clock tower looms up in half the apartment windows in town, a communal wristwatch that sometimes seems to be watching you.

title: Mayor for the Moment, But Not Much to Say
description: The acting mayor of New York City did not hold a news conference yesterday, sign any bills into law, or express any viewpoints on public sculpture, term limits or the situation in the Middle East.

title: A Dead Husband's Mistress Turns Out to Be a Mister
description: Antonia (Margherita Buy) lives with her husband, Massimo (Andrea Renzi), in a bright, modern villa in a garden suburb of Rome. Her life is orderly, elegant and comfortable until Massimo, crossing a busy street with his cellphone in hand, is killed by a speeding car. Antonia's numb, bitter grief is soon complicated by her discovery, in a box from her husband's office, of a painting with an inscription on the back that appears to be from his mistress.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 5 on a Bus in Tel Aviv
description: A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up in a Tel Aviv bus outside the city's main synagogue today, killing five people and wounding scores. Several hours later, Israeli tanks and armored vehicles encircled Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah and demanded over loudspeakers that he surrender wanted men who were inside with him.

title: Global Crossing Memos Released
description: Executives at Global Crossing raised concerns about accounting at the company as early as August 2000, investigators at the House Commerce Committee said today, citing memorandums obtained from the company.

title: Alomar Is Planning to Return to Mets
description: Roberto Alomar did not take long to realize that New York was unlike Cleveland, Baltimore, Toronto and San Diego, whether it was maneuvering through traffic on his drive from his Queens home to Shea Stadium, handling the incessant news media attention or dealing with what became very frustrated fans.

title: MetroStars to Have A Home for Playoffs
description: Plans for the MetroStars' new stadium in Harrison, N.J., across the Passaic River from Newark, may still be on the drawing board, but the club announced yesterday that it will play any Major League Soccer playoff matches this season at Riverfront Stadium in Newark.

title: Intelligence Officials Discount '98 Report From Caribbean of Plot to Hit Trade Center
description: A 1998 intelligence report about a plot to crash a bomb-laden plane into the World Trade Center originated with a police official in a small Caribbean country who contended that the operation was to be mounted by Libya on behalf of Iraq, United States intelligence officials say.

title: BUSH SEEKS POWER TO USE 'ALL MEANS' TO OUST HUSSEIN
description: President Bush asked Congress today for sweeping authority to use ''all means he determines to be appropriate, including force'' to disarm Iraq and dislodge Saddam Hussein, and warned: ''If the United Nations Security Council won't deal with the problem, the United States and some of our friends will.''

title: Still Very Much a Player, Scowcroft Straddles the Worlds of Business and Government
description: Brent Scowcroft, the former national security official whose voice on Iraq policy has attracted considerable attention, plays so many different public and private advisory roles that even he has trouble keeping them straight.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Acclaim Entertainment Expects 4th-Quarter Loss
description: Acclaim Entertainment, which develops video games and software for game consoles, said yesterday that it expected a loss for the fiscal fourth quarter and for its fiscal year 2002 because of slow sales for two of its games -- Turok: Evolution and Aggressive Inline. The company, based in Glen Cove, N.Y., also said it would cut its forecasts for the next two quarters. Acclaim said it would have a loss, excluding some costs, of 11 cents to 13 cents a share for the quarter that ended Aug. 31. Shares of Acclaim dropped 51 cents, about 25 percent, to $1.56; they have fallen about 70 percent this year. Gerard F. Agoglia, chief financial officer for Acclaim, said company executives were ''disappointed with our performance for the quarter,'' but looked forward to growth in the next fiscal year.

title: How the West Was Overrun: Cowboy Chic Finds a Following
description: THE first sign that something was going on was when Cowboys & Indians magazine materialized on my parents' coffee table. They began traveling to cowboy poetry readings; Clint Black quietly replaced Barbra Streisand in the CD player. Finally, my parents confessed: they had bought property in Montana and were planning to build a log cabin in the wilderness.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Circuits yesterday with an article about video jockeys, showing James Ellis rehearsing his video act for a rock concert, carried an incorrect credit. It was by Farah Yusuf.

title: Stanley Steemer Selects Agency
description: Stanley Steemer International of Dublin, Ohio, which sells home cleaning products and services, has named Young & Laramore in Indianapolis to handle the creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $30 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANT, BETTIE ALEXANDER
description: GANT-Bettie Alexander, 46. Died peacefully in her sleep at her home in Manhattan last weekend. ''Alex'' Gant was the building editor of ''This Old House'' magazine. Donations in her name may be made to the American Diabetes Association, PO Box 2680, North Canton, OH 44720. Funeral services will be held on September 20th, at 2 p.m., at the Church of the Holy Comforter in Burlington, NC. A memorial service will take place at 4 P.M. on October 1, at Christ & St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street in Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Tribunal Indicts Ex-General
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague has indicted a retired general who was the Croatian Army's chief of staff during the Balkan wars of the early 1990's. Janko Bobetko, 83, is the highest-ranking Croat sought by the tribunal, and he has been linked to suspected war crimes committed in 1993 during a swift incursion by the Croatian Army into territory held by rebel Serbs. The general has said he would rather die than surrender. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Bound for Las Vegas, 2 Men Take a 9/11 Detour to Jail
description: The distance between a convention in Las Vegas and a brick jail here in the lush plains of western Arkansas proved far shorter than Gurdeep Wander and Harinder Singh ever could have imagined.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: SECRECY IN LITIGATION

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: ECONOMY SEEN STABILIZING The Bank of Japan held its economic assessment steady for a third consecutive month, repeating its view that Japan's economy has almost bottomed out thanks to continued strong exports. But the central bank also reiterated its concerns that volatile global stock prices could hurt the economy, which prompted the plan it announced on Wednesday to buy stockholdings from banks. "Japan's economy, despite persistent weakness in domestic demand and large uncertainty over the global economy, has almost stabilized as a whole with exports and production continuing to increase," the bank said. (Dow Jones)

title: Radio Telescope Proves A Big Bang Prediction
description: After 271 20-hour nights of staring at the Antarctic sky, a radio telescope at the South Pole has confirmed a critical prediction of the Big Bang theory of the origin of the universe, astronomers from the University of Chicago and the University of California announced here today.

title: Japan Court Says Company, Not Inventor, Controls Patent
description: The Tokyo District Court has rejected attempts by a Japanese scientist, Shuji Nakamura, to obtain the rights to his inventions, a ruling that preserves the right of companies to control patents developed by their employees.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Eating Like Animals

title: Bundle Up
description: The rising price of natural gas, while still well below the sharp spike of two years ago, points to higher heating bills for consumers this winter. Page. C5.

title: Helping the Jobless
description: For 23 years, Felix Batista rode the elevator up 106 floors to work as a member of the wait staff at the Windows on the World restaurant. On Sept. 11, everything changed. Mr. Batista was on vacation with his family, and that decision saved his life. That day, he lost 73 coworkers and his job.

title: Nike Spot Wins An Emmy Award
description: A spot for Nike celebrating athletes, famous and otherwise, was awarded the annual commercial Emmy Award by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

title: Antarctic Cruises
description: Savings of 10 percent are available on two Antarctica cruises aboard the 110-passenger Endeavor, a Lindblad Expeditions ship. On Nov. 30, a 17-day program starts with two days in Santiago, Chile, followed by a cruise, departing from the Falklands, for Antarctica. Rates begin at $8,490 a person, based on double occupancy, before the discount; air fare from the United States is extra. On Dec. 13, a 26-day program adds South Georgia and South Orkney Islands. Rates start at $12,990 a person, double, before the discount. Passengers can explore Antarctica by Zodiac, on foot or in kayaks. Information: (800) 397-3348 or www.expeditions.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, MARION
description: BROOKS-Marion, 87. On September 18, 2002. Beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother, sister, aunt and great aunt.

title: No Moves by AOL Board on Its Chairman
description: The position of Stephen M. Case, whose continuation as chairman of AOL Time Warner has met opposition from some major shareholders and directors, was not discussed at the board meeting yesterday, a company spokesman said.

title: Fire Unions Call for Inquiry on Radio Failures
description: The leaders of New York City's fire unions yesterday called for an independent investigation into the widespread communication problems that plagued firefighters during the World Trade Center disaster, saying that they had lost confidence in the city's review.

title: Sports of The Times; Notre Dame's Gain Is Now Soccer's Loss
description: IN Shane Walton's first sport, hands were used only for surreptitious pushing, discreet tugging of jerseys and the occasional illegal deflection of the ball (see: Maradona, Diego).

title: Windows on Autumn
description: Autumn in New York: It begins tomorrow and promises crisp days that are good for dining at a restaurant with a view.

title: Inspections With Teeth
description: If there's a new conciliatory mood here in Baghdad, it's even better hidden than Iraq's Scud missiles.

title: Bush Lobbies Putin to Back U.S. Action Against Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 - Administration officials said today that they were encouraged by a telephone conversation that President Bush had with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia seeking support for American action against Saddam Hussein, and that differences between the governments over Iraq were exaggerated.

title: Mislabeled as Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Accounts
description: * Qwest Communications International, Denver, to the New York office of Initiative Media North America, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as the broadcast agency of record, with spending estimated at $35 million out of the total budget of $100 million. Initiative takes over from OMD, New York, which is part of the Omnicom Group, as was the previous agency on the creative part of the account, the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide. Qwest dismissed DDB Chicago last month and moved the creative duties to an Initiative sibling, the New York office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of Interpublic.

title: Review/Fashion; Dressing Up the 50's Wife, With a Naughty Kick
description: To follow Sean Combs into a fashion show is a little like jumping in behind an ambulance at rush hour. The traffic parts, the lane clears, and you have the electric thrill, so potent in New York, of riding in on someone else's coattails.

title: A Daughter Campaigns to Show Pataki's Gentler Side
description: ''The man you call governor is the man I call Dad,'' Emily Pataki told a small audience waiting patiently to begin their afternoon bingo game at the William Kohler Memorial Senior Center in Mahopac, N.Y., yesterday.

title: Pakistan Allows Kashmir Raids, Militants Say
description: Officials from three Pakistani militant groups said in interviews this week that the government of Pakistan has allowed Islamic guerrillas to resume small-scale infiltrations into Indian-controlled Kashmir. India has repeatedly demanded that Pakistan halt the practice, which brought the two nuclear-armed rivals to the brink of war this spring.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Peasant on Elizabeth Street, the first venture of John LaFemina and Frank DeCarlo, is notable for its rustic Italian food cooked over a wood fire. Now, at their second restaurant, pizz, which opened recently on the Lower East Side, they have taken the simple premise of Peasant and made it even simpler.

title: National Briefing | Washington: $400 Million For Kennedy Center
description: President Bush signed legislation that will provide $400 million to renovate the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, linking the center to the Mall with a pedestrian plaza. The bill also authorizes construction of two educational buildings. The center is the nation's busiest performing arts complex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRYFOOS, GEORGE E.
description: DRYFOOS-George E. Of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. 83, died September 14, 2002 at home. Survived by wife Joy (Gidding), son Paul, daughterin - law Cynthia Rodgers, grandchildren Amy and Rose, brother Robert Dryden, niece Emma Dryden, and many friends. An actor for two decades, previously worked in low income housing field. Former Village Trustee, elected Delegate to 1968 Democratic Convention and organizer of Concerned Democrats of Westchester. A founding member of Creative Arts Council and Fair Housing Committee. A Celebration of Life will be held October 5th 4 P.M. at the Andrus Community Auditorium, Hastings. Donations may be made to a charity of one's choice.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Selling European, Buying American

title: G.E. and the Rest of Us
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Mosque Blown Up
description: Saboteurs blew up a mosque in the Serbian part of Bosnia just three months after it was reopened following its destruction during the 1992-1995 war. Muslims expelled by Serbian forces at that time have only recently begun to return to the area, near the southeastern town of Gacko. Relations among Bosnia's Serbs, Muslims and Croats remain tense seven years after the war ended, and an election next month is expected to return more nationalists to power in the country, which is divided between a Serbian republic and a Muslim-Croat federation. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Silicon Valley Concern Says It Thwarted Software Theft
description: A Chinese software programmer was arrested Tuesday after a Silicon Valley company complained that he had tried to steal software used in seismic imaging of oil fields, company officials said today.

title: King and Mullin Join City Hall of Fame
description: Two talented Brooklynites, Chris Mullin and Albert King, were inducted into the New York City Basketball Hall of Fame yesterday, along with six others.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: MICROSOFT ENTERS WIRELESS HOME NETWORKING Hopping on the bandwagon for wireless home networking products, Microsoft announced 10 new products yesterday. The products, which include wireless base stations and Ethernet adapters, will be available in the next few weeks for $29.95 to $219.95. Smaller companies like NetGear, D-Link, Linksys and SMC now dominate wireless home networking. Microsoft, however, said that its products would be easier to use. "The process of setting up a wireless network has simply been too complex for the people looking to share their broadband Internet connection," said Lisa Brummel, vice president for the company's home products division. Microsoft's track record selling consumer electronics, however, is decidedly mixed. Earlier offerings of a 900MHz cordless phone and USB speakers failed to find many buyers. Shares in Microsoft closed the day at $ 47.20, down 55 cents, or 1.15 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the shrinking Italian population of Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, misstated the year that national attention was drawn to the neighborhood by the murder of a black teenager, Yusuf K. Hawkins, by a group of local youths. It was 1989, not 1991.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Shares Plunge After Departure Is Announced
description: Shares of Nextel Communications fell 16 percent after the company said the chief operating officer, James Mooney, would leave on Sept. 30. Timothy Donahue, president and chief executive, will assume Mr. Mooney's role while the company, a mobile telephone provider, searches for a successor, according to Nextel, which is based in Reston, Va. Mr. Mooney, 47, said he was leaving for personal reasons and considering work opportunities closer to his home in the New York City area. Nextel expects to add two million subscribers this year, the company said. The stock fell $1.30, to close at $7.

title: Rumblings of War: Why Germans Balk
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Wednesday about the revival of ''The Twilight Zone'' understated Rod Serling's role as a writer of the original series, for which he was also the host. He was responsible for more than half the scripts; he did not merely write for the series occasionally.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's a God-forsaken hole in the ground.''

title: Republicans Delay Plan for New Tax Cuts
description: Republican leaders in the House have decided against pushing for a new round of tax cuts to help investors, effectively killing for this year a proposal floated last month by President Bush, Congressional aides said today.

title: China's Cyberspace Censorship
description: Type ''Jiang Zemin'' into the Internet search engine Google, and one of the first things to appear is a Web site that is sharply critical of the Chinese president, with topic headings like ''Exposing the Crimes of Jiang Zemin.'' China's leaders, who are not keen on critiques of the ruling order, recently responded by blocking access to Google, and then by unblocking it but reining in the scope of its searches. In doing so, China is stifling the free dissemination of ideas within its borders and hurting its prospects for building a modern economy. China's leaders should reconsider.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: J. D. EDWARDS TO USE I.B.M. DATABASE IN PACKAGE J. D. Edwards & Company plans to sell a package of business programs that includes database software from I.B.M., a blow to other database vendors like Oracle and Microsoft . J. D. Edwards, whose software manages inventory, accounting and customer relations, will sell the package to midmarket customers, which J. D. Edwards defines as having annual sales of $250 million to $3 billion, said Lenley Hensarling, the company's vice president for product management. The announcement expands the alliance between I.B.M. and J. D. Edwards, under which they make sure their programs work together and recommend each other's software.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Security Cited In Proposals On Lawsuits From Sept. 11
description: Transportation safety officials are proposing tight new procedures to limit the possibility that sensitive airport security information will become public, and exploited by terrorists, in lawsuits stemming from the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: 'The Heavenly Tree Grows Downward' -- Selected Works by Harry Smith, Philip Taaffe and Fred Tomaselli
description: James Cohan Gallery

title: BERKSHIRE INVESTS $212 MILLION IN LLOYD'S UNIT
description: Berkshire Hathaway, the holding company run by Warren E. Buffett, is investing $212 million in a unit of Lloyd's of London, the 300-year-old insurance market. The funds will enable a Lloyd's businesses, known as Trenwick Managing Agents' Syndicate 839, to sell more insurance and take advantage of price increases insurers have been putting in place since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Investing in the Lloyd's syndicate may help Berkshire's General Re unit sell more reinsurance, analysts said. Berkshire invested $93 million in Trenwick, and freed up $119 million in new underwriting capacity by providing reinsurance on some of the syndicate's business. The transactions raised Trenwick's underwriting capacity to $512 million, it said.

title: Memorial Service Held for Rote
description: Kyle Rote became celebrated as a football player, but at a memorial service yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan, he was also remembered as a social activist, a fund-raiser for charities, a mentor for young teammates and a soul-searching poet.

title: Residential Real Estate; Rare Condo Conversion For Central Park West
description: The recent conversion of a 17-story neo-Renaissance building at 93rd Street into a condominium was a rare event along Central Park West. And there aren't likely to be many more newly offered apartments for sale along that elegant avenue any time soon.

title: Derek Davies, 71, Top Editor Of Influential Asian Review
description: Derek Davies, an editor of the Far Eastern Economic Review for 25 years who built the magazine into a major source of news and comment on the region despite his love-hate relationship with its prickly rulers, died on Sept. 15 in Antibes. He was 71 and lived in the south of France.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Lynn Bolger was named executive vice president for agency development at the New York office of ComScore Media Metrix, part of ComScore Networks. She had been chief executive and managing director at FastBridge, New York, a subsidiary of Initiative Media North America, part of Initiative Media Worldwide. Initiative is a division of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Violence and Sentiment Waging a Hip-Hop War
description: ''Snipes,'' directed and partly written by Rich Murray, is a hectic, blood-soaked melodrama that traffics in the brutal, by now tired gangster mythology of hip-hop. Nelly, the rap superstar, plays an up-and-coming Philadelphia rapper who goes by the name Prolifik. His glowering image stares down from just about every wall and lamppost in the city, thanks to the efforts of an eager young fan named Erik (Sam Jones III), who works for Prolifik's shady record company, putting up promotional posters, or snipes.

title: Bush-Hitler Remark Shows U.S. as Issue In German Election
description: A reported remark by a German minister comparing President Bush's tactics over Iraq to those of Hitler envenomed a close-fought German election today and demonstrated how anti-Americanism had moved to the center of political debate here.

title: Solheim Cup Doesn't Look Like a Friendly Matchup
description: The last Solheim Cup produced controversy, great golf and an emotional victory by Europe.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the creation of atoms made of antimatter referred incorrectly to antiprotons, which are components of antimatter. They carry a negative charge, not a positive one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JONATHAN (J.J.)
description: GREENBERG - Jonathan (J.J.) Kolot: The Center for Jewish Women's and Gender Studies mourns the tragic loss of J. J., who lived his life devoted to equality, learning, joy, and tikkun olam. We extend our sympathies to our friend and advisor, Blu and to Yitz, Moshe, Abbie, David, Mindy, Deborah, Jonathan, Goody, Eric, Sylvia, and all of their children. We remember J. J. making a Miriam's Cup with us just this Spring. May J. J.'s memory serve as a blessing and inspiration to others for generations to come. Sally Gottesman, Advisory Board Chair Lori Lefkovitz, Academic Director Deborah Meyer, Managing Director

title: Afghan Women's Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Airport Security, a Year Later
description: With complaints about airport snafus on the increase as security is tightened, the temptation is growing to soften and delay the tough new requirements imposed after Sept. 11. That would be a terrible disservice. With a number of deadlines approaching, the government, airport operators and airlines should be concentrating on how to meet the requirements, not how to dodge them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLAPPER, BLANCHE
description: KLAPPER-Blanche. Darling. You are my evening star. I adore you. Happy Birthday, Marvin

title: Dress Code Gets Sleek
description: Baggy uniforms and uniform pants that disappear into a player's shoes are out. So are uniform alterations and memorial messages on caps.

title: Missy Stevens -- 'A Year of Change'
description: Prue Venables -- 'Objects'

title: Question Marks And Astral Signs
description: Questions, questions and more questions: after a summer packed with a couple of hits (''Hairspray,'' ''Frankie and Johnny'') and a definitive miss (''I'm Not Rappaport''), fall begins with enough up-in-the-airs to fill a bundle of balloons.

title: In Arizona, a Race Fueled by Fiscal Fumes
description: One recent governor of Arizona was impeached after campaign finance irregularities; another was forced to resign after a fraud conviction. The current office holder, whose term ends in January, is leaving behind a $400 million budget deficit that could grow to $1 billion by the time her successor is sworn in.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: An Appreciation; Hayes, the Fastest Runner Ever, Also Revolutionized Pro Football
description: Bob Hayes will always be the World's Fastest Human.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: NICARAGUA: EX-PRESIDENT OUSTED Lawmakers ousted former President Arnoldo Aleman from his leadership post in Congress, a crucial step in efforts to strip him of immunity from prosecution and try him on charges of stealing $100 million during his presidency. The majority of leftist Sandinistas and supporters of President Enrique Bolanos voted to replace the governing board of congress, which Mr. Aleman had led. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMMEL, PATRICIA BARRY
description: GAMMEL - Patricia Barry. On September 13, 2002, from cancer. Patty loved life, her family and friends. She touched everyone with her energy, kindness and generosity. Patty loved to play tennis, dance, laugh, cook, read voraciously, drink a glass of Chardonnay, and most of all, to celebrate Christmas with her family, friends or anyone who needed a place to go. She was the only one we ever knew who could do the Sunday New York Times crossword puzzle in ink without a mistake. During the span of her professional career, Patty positively impacted the lives of many in just as many different ways, from her volunteer activities, to being a teacher, to positions she held with State government and charitable foundations, and as a mentor throughout. She was an activist in the civil rights movement, a VISTA volunteer, and an A.I.D. worker in Vietnam. Patty's presence in our lives was a remarkable blessing. A memorial service will be held at Saint Michael's Church, 505 Broome Street, Fernandina Beach, FL. on October 12, 2002 at 2PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Bellflower Center for Prevention of Child Abuse, attn: Development Dept., 11811 Shaker Blvd, Suite 220, Cleveland, OH. 44120.

title: MOVIE GUIDE

title: TRANSACTIONS

title: Stocks Dive, Nearing Lows Hit in July
description: As investors digested more disappointing news on earnings and new signs that the economic recovery could be weaker than expected, stocks tumbled yesterday to their lowest level since the overall market hit a five-year low in July.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Growth Forecast Cut
description: The Italian finance minister, Giulio Tremonti, slashed the government's forecast for 2002 economic growth by more than half, to about 0.6 percent, saying a global economic slump has hurt exports and manufacturing. In a speech to the lower house of Parliament on the economy, Mr. Tremonti also trimmed the government's forecast for next year's growth to 2.3 percent, from 2.9 percent. ''What is worrying are tensions in the oil markets, falling stock markets, an unexpected decline in production and the negative performance of vast areas of the European economic landscape,'' Mr. Tremonti said.

title: Mansions: Taking Comfort in a Lot of Room and a Lot of Rooms
description: WHO -- Jerry Alhadeff, a retired seafood and floral distributor, and Judy Alhadeff, a former secretary.

title: Order, Clarity and Balance in Poussin and Claude
description: The cole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, ensconced in the convent of the Petits-Augustins on the Rue Bonaparte since 1829, is the world's oldest surviving art school. Formally established in 1796, it actually began in 1648 with the founding of the Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture by Cardinal Mazarin and Louis XIV. After the French Revolution it joined with the Academy of Architecture to become the cole des Beaux-Arts. Over the centuries the cole set official standards, becoming a bastion of French academic art.

title: Should Our Colleges Be Ranked?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gliding By On 4 Wheels
description: After repeatedly circling the block, you finally see a parking spot. But it's tight. You will have to back in and out several times to squeeze in. If only you could turn the wheels toward the sidewalk and order the car to glide into the space by itself.

title: In Jury Pool, A Racial Divide Over Memories Of Louima Case
description: A middle-age black man from Nassau County sat in the jury box in Brooklyn federal court one day this week and answered questions from a judge about his memory of news reports describing the assault of Abner Louima and the prosecution of former police officers for it. He remembered a lot, it turned out.

title: Warnings Sought for Popular Painkiller
description: Citing evidence that thousands of Americans unwittingly take toxic -- and potentially fatal -- doses of acetaminophen, a panel of expert scientists today urged stronger warning labels for the painkiller, the main ingredient in nearly 200 over-the-counter cold and headache remedies, including Tylenol.

title: Living the Fantasy At Full Throttle
description: THERE'S a motorcycle on my tail, and it's bugging me. He's a reasonably serious dude. (I think so, anyway; what do I know about motorcycles?) In any case, as we head up the mountain maybe 20 yards apart, he's leaning hard into the switchback curves, back and forth, left and right, swiveling with fluid aggressiveness on the upright axis and making sharply acute angles with the road. He's cool to watch through the rearview mirror of this purring and potent hot-guymobile I'm at the wheel of, this manifestation of my wished-for middle-age libido, though I feel it as a clear affront that I can't lose him.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Acquisition Approved
description: Germany's largest utility, E.ON, won approval for its 10.7 billion euro ($10.47 billion) acquisition of Ruhrgas with more conditions as the government aims to remove a court injunction blocking the takeover. The Economics Ministry was forced to reassess the purchase of Ruhrgas, Germany's largest natural gas company, after a court in Dsseldorf blocked it on July 13, citing procedural errors. E.ON and Ruhrgas must sell more stakes in other utilities and natural gas to rivals, the deputy economics minister, Alfred Tacke, said.

title: Going Undercover in the Service of Her Majesty
description: The director Shekhar Kapur's remake of ''The Four Feathers'' is a tepid, shallow tributary of larger, deeper bodies of waters like the historical revisionist film dramas ''Last of the Mohicans'' (which was also a remake) and ''Little Big Man.'' Heath Ledger stars as Harry Feversham, an officer in Queen Victoria's army, full of mellow bonhomie and a cheeky modesty. In the late 1800's he and his unit are in training in the British Army, and ''Feathers'' gives us a protracted and reverent look at their life.

title: Juan Rivera Makes Case For Playoff Roster Spot
description: Juan Rivera is playing his way back into the Yankees' lineup at just the right time. With a chance to be the starting left fielder in the playoffs, Rivera is enjoying a strong September and had a double and his first career home run tonight.

title: Cold Master of Trickery, Political and Otherwise
description: Mesmerizing is the only word to describe Tim Roth's profoundly sinister portrayal of a ruthless magician, hypnotist and mind reader in Werner Herzog's surreally flavored historical epic, ''Invincible.'' His gleaming hair slicked back, his cold eyes glowing phosphorescently in his cadaverous head, Mr. Roth's character, who calls himself Erik Jan Hanussen, exudes the icy elegance of a European Gatsby who has just wafted up from the tomb.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: City Unemployment Remains High
description: New York City's hard-hit economy has yet to show signs of rebounding, according to new data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. The August unemployment rate edged down to 7.6 percent, from 7.7 percent in July, but remains far above the national average of 5.7 percent. The number of jobs in the city appears to have declined very slightly in August, but the drop was smaller than in August 2001. ''The rate of decline is tapering off,'' said James Brown, an analyst for the labor department. New York State's unemployment rate fell to 5.8 percent, from 6.1 percent in July, but the number of private-sector jobs fell by about 2,800. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Notes From Boston; Big Dig Bluster
description: Tampering with the townscape is a local tradition. It was 1630 when the city founders first began the process of digging, dredging and fabricating the historic Shawmut Peninsula. In short order, they had filled enough marsh and wetland to transform a 489-acre scrap of land, about the size of Central Park, to 2,055 acres. Workers used horse, wagon and shovel to behead most of Boston's obliging three hills. Of the three, one, Fort, vanished completely; another, Beacon, was halved; the third, Copps, is intact as a burial ground due to its tenacious, well, remains.

title: Woody Allen's Ex-Best Friend on the Record, Sort Of
description: HAIR covering her eyes like one of those expensive Upper East Side lap dogs, Jean Doumanian comes rushing into the conference room of her production company. She's nearly a half-hour late, but she's so warm, so effusive, so funny in her style of apologies, who can be annoyed? The traffic, the horrible traffic, she's saying -- C'mere, let her take you by the arm to the window so you can see the horrible traffic -- then, Y'know, we've met before, I never forget a face, look out there, look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELVIN, JEAN
description: KELVIN-Jean. On September 17, 2002. Adoring wife of the late Zel, cherished mother of Alice, Ann and Harold. Also survived by her daughter-in-law Renee and two grand-daughters Aurea and Jocelyn. She will be remembered as a caring woman with a sense of style-taking pride in both her home and family.

title: An Aging Groupie Saving Souls With Rock 'n' Roll
description: In ''The Banger Sisters'' Goldie Hawn infuses Suzette, the world's most luscious middle-aged groupie, with the same concentrated sunshine her daughter Kate Hudson gave to the role of a much younger rock 'n' roll camp follower in ''Almost Famous.'' Like daughter, like mother, you might say. It would be an understatement to describe Ms. Hawn as extraordinarily well preserved. At 56, she still has that zing.

title: Bob Hayes, Stellar Sprinter and Receiver, Is Dead at 59
description: Bob Hayes, a pigeon-toed sprinter who broke world records, won two gold medals in the 1964 Tokyo Olympics and then became a feared pass receiver for 11 seasons in the National Football League, died Wednesday night in his hometown of Jacksonville, Fla. He was 59.

title: Suffolk Leader Unveils Plan to Close $111 Million Gap
description: The Suffolk County executive, faced with a growing budget gap, outlined a spending plan for 2003 today, and predicted the county's ''most difficult budget process yet.''

title: Report Finds Drop in Average City Class Size
description: New York City schools are making progress toward the city and state goal of limiting classes in the youngest grades to 20 pupils, but more than one-fourth of children in kindergarten through third grade are in classes with more than 25, according to a report released yesterday by the city's Independent Budget Office.

Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. description: Milwaukee

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Date Set For Europe Referendum
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern announced that a national referendum would be be held on Oct. 19 to decide whether to ratify the Treaty of Nice, the European Union pact that sets the stage for enlarging the union. Polling will take place on a Saturday for the first time, an effort to increase turnout over the 35 percent when voters rejected the treaty in June 2001. Of the 15 countries in the union, only Ireland requires a referendum to approve the treaty; national legislatures in the other countries have already done so. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: HealthSouth Tries to Allay Uneasiness Of Investors
description: The HealthSouth Corporation, acknowledging that it is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, sought yesterday to quell increasing concerns over its Medicare billing practices and stock sales by its chairman.

title: The Face (And Soul) Of Africa
description: AS of today, the Museum for African Art, formerly of SoHo, officially makes the leap to Long Island City, Queens. And it does so with a very beautiful show titled ''Facing the Mask,'' which happens to be all about moving.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: J. D. Edwards To Use I.B.M. Database In Package
description: J. D. Edwards & Company plans to sell a package of business programs that includes database software from I.B.M., a blow to other database vendors like Oracle and Microsoft. J. D. Edwards, whose software manages inventory, accounting and customer relations, will sell the package to midmarket customers, which J. D. Edwards defines as having annual sales of $250 million to $3 billion, said Lenley Hensarling, the company's vice president for product management. The announcement expands the alliance between I.B.M. and J. D. Edwards, under which they make sure their programs work together and recommend each other's software.

description: Following is the full text of President Bush's new national security strategy. The document, entitled "The National Security Strategy of the United States," will soon be transmitted to Congress as a declaration of the Administration's policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALTON, GEORGE E.
description: DALTON-George E. On September 17, 2002 of The Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, Inc. Born in Floral Park, NY on July 13, 1923. Graduate of St. Francis Xavier High School Class of 1941 and Syracuse University Class of 1948. Three-and-a-half years in the U.S. Army Air Force during World War II. Former president of the Metropolitan Funeral Directors Association and of the NY State Funeral Directors Association, Member of Catholic Cemetery Guild of Brooklyn, Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity, Floral Park Lions Club, Floral Park Knights of Columbus, Floral Park American Legion, New Hyde Park Elks and Blinded Veterans Association. Beloved son of the late Thomas F. and Irene (Harper) Dalton. Devoted husband of Dell (nee Serviss). Loving father of Matthew, Timothy, Christopher and Martha Cerasano. Fond father-in-law of Alison and Susan Dalton and Mark Cerasano. Cherished grandfather of Robin, Lane, Emily, Alysa and Timothy J. Dalton, Holly Cerasano and Jason Power. Reposing Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Ave (at R.R. Plaza) Floral Park. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 AM at St. Anne's R.C. Church. Interment Our Lady of the Isle Cemetery, Shelter Island Heights, NY. In his memory donations to St. Gabriel's Retreat House, P.O. Box 3015, Shelter Island Heights, NY 11965, or Foundation Fighting Blindness, P.O. Box 17279, Baltimore, MD. 21297-0495, will be appreciated.

title: Ral Chibas, 86, Castro Ally Who Fled to Miami in Motorboat
description: Ral Chibas, a former close associate of Fidel Castro who defected to Florida in an outboard motorboat in 1960 in order, he said, to ''make it known to the Cuban people that I did not like what their government is doing,'' died on Aug. 25 in a Miami hospital. He was 86 and lived in Miami.

title: Fantasy of Future and the Here and Now
description: Joss Whedon, who so breezily linked vampires with adolescent angst to create ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer,'' has a new series billed as a ''sci-fi/western,'' and this time the wrenching together of genres is tortured. In its rough first episode on Fox tonight, ''Firefly'' is even more of a confusing mess than the description makes it sound. It's a crazy quilt of ''Star Wars,'' ''Mad Max'' and ''Stagecoach,'' just to mention the most obvious films it calls to mind.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Microsoft Enters Wireless Home Networking
description: Hopping on the bandwagon for wireless home networking products, Microsoft announced 10 new products yesterday. The products, which include wireless base stations and Ethernet adapters, will be available in the next few weeks for $29.95 to $219.95. Smaller companies like NetGear, D-Link, Linksys and SMC now dominate wireless home networking. Microsoft, however, said that its products would be easier to use. ''The process of setting up a wireless network has simply been too complex for the people looking to share their broadband Internet connection,'' said Lisa Brummel, vice president for the company's home products division. Microsoft's track record selling consumer electronics, however, is decidedly mixed. Earlier offerings of a 900MHz cordless phone and USB speakers failed to find many buyers. Shares in Microsoft closed the day at $ 47.20, down 55 cents, or 1.15 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Worker Crushed In Accident
description: A factory worker was crushed to death Wednesday night when an 8,000-pound stack of recycled paper collapsed and struck him in the head, the police said yesterday. No one else was injured. The worker, Manuel Lucero, 54, of Brooklyn, had climbed on top of the stack to remove some plastic in one of the bundles shortly before 8 p.m. when he fell to the ground and the bundles tumbled on top of him, the police said. Mr. Lucero, who was working at Rapid Recycling Corporation in Greenpoint, was pronounced dead at the scene, they said. A spokesman for the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration said the incident was being investigated. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Tuition Is Frozen, but State Colleges Cost More
description: The cost of attending New York's public colleges has risen steadily despite a seven-year freeze in tuition, because fees charged by individual campuses have doubled in that time, according to a report released today.

title: G.M. TO RESUME NO-INTEREST LOANS ON 2002 MODELS
description: General Motors said yesterday that it would offer 60-month no-interest loans on remaining 2002 models, matching rivals' offers. The loans will cover all 2002 models and will run from Sept. 30, a spokeswoman said, adding that no-interest loans will continue on most 2003 models. The automaker had ended the loans on 2002 models this month after it said it had sold most of the vehicles. It said it had about 300,000 of its 2002 models in inventory at the end of August, less than the backlog of 450,000 a year earlier. Ford and Chrysler are offering no-interest loans on most 2002 and 2003 models.

title: Germany faces austerity measures no matter who wins
description: FRANKFURT:  Regardless of who wins Sunday's national election, the next German government is likely to adopt new austerity measures to rein in its surging budget deficit to bring it in line with the strict fiscal limits imposed by the European single-currency pact, according to officials and private analysts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, BETTY
description: GOODMAN-Betty. Perfect wife and partner to Arthur. The best mother to Jaye and Peter, Marian and Mark. Adored and doting grandmother to Cristopher, Josh, Nicholas and Jordan. She was the loving center of our family and friends and will be missed more than words can express. Rest in peace, you are always with us. Funeral services Friday 9:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Friends may call Thursday evening 6-9 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center.

description: Andrew Kreps Gallery

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an Op-Ed article yesterday by Jessica T. Mathews and Charles G. Boyd about the need for coercive inspections in Iraq contained added language that does not represent the authors' views. They would strongly oppose the use of United Nations weapons inspectors as spies.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Group Tracks Oil And Gas Spills
description: More than 50,000 gallons of oil and gas is spilled into Cook Inlet each year, an environmental group said, citing data reported to the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation. An evaluation of seven pipeline companies' performance ranked Unocal as having the worst spill rate, said the group, Cook Inlet Keeper. Two Alaska pipeline companies, Cook Inlet and Kenai, had the best record. Douglas Jehl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCHARD, ANNE
description: BLANCHARD - Anne. The Chapin School is deeply saddened by the loss of Anne Blanchard, wife of trustee Edward V. Blanchard and mother of Lydia, Catherine and Cordelia. Anne was a true friend of the school and will be missed by the entire Chapin community. Our sincere sympathy goes to the family. Ella M. Foshay, '65 President, Board of Trustees Sandra J. Theunick Head of School

title: Revival Works A Transformation
description: It takes more than two to dance the tango of love, lust and loneliness that is Lanford Wilson's ''Burn This.'' In the soulful, eye-opening new revival at the Union Square Theater, which features a sensational cast led by Edward Norton and Catherine Keener, a character alludes to a dance piece as less a pas de deux than a pas de quatre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROTA, BARBARA
description: SIROTA-Barbara. The Board of Directors of the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation mourn the passing of Barbara Sirota, a dedicated Director and friend of the Foundation. Her caring support and attention touched all who knew her.

title: Maazel Shows His Firm Hand From the Start
description: LORIN MAAZEL had a great deal riding on Wednesday night's season-opening concert with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, his first as its music director. It's been a long while since an appointment to this important post has engendered such heated debate in the larger field of classical music. Doubters questioned whether this high-powered, veteran maestro had the fresh artistic vision to lead the Philharmonic into a new era at a challenging time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, EMILE
description: MOSES-Emile. On Sept. 13, 2002. Beloved husband of Hannah for 60 years. Devoted father of Maureen, Janice, and Deborah. Adored grandfather of Joshua. A man of learning, intelligence, and sterling integrity. His life was wholly dedicated to the wellbeing of his family. He will live on in our hearts forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLAS, ASTRID HATABIAN
description: ZOLAS-Astrid Hatabian. On September 18, 2002. Beloved mother of Dr. Fimi Zolas Cohen and Dr. Edward Zolas. Funeral Saturday, 10 AM, at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, 630 2nd Avenue, New York City. Cremation private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, LENORE ELIAS BERG
description: GINSBURG - Lenore Elias berg. Of Boynton Beach FL, died peacefully on September 17, 2002. Loving wife of Everett Ginsburg and wife of the late David J. Lobel. Beloved mother of Steven and Helen Lobel, Michael and Tina Lobel, and Betsy and Dr. Charles Fenell. Much loved grandmother of Claudia and Kevin Bell, Emily and David Lobel, Jessica, Angela and Celia Fenell. Proud greatgrandmother of Dylan Bell. Adored stepmother of Bonnie Browdy, Fran and Robert Soltz, Anita and James Weil and Barbara Ginsburg. Devoted step-grandmother to Jennifer and Christopher Lenney, Julie Soltz, Robyn and Stefanie Browdy, and Michael and Joshua Weil. Loyal friend to many. Funeral on Friday, September 20, 10AM, ''Riverside - Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR train station), Great Neck, NY.

description: The only memento Ruth Gonzlez's relatives in Los Angeles want from her cannot be found among the thick ceramic mugs, elaborate woodcarvings or brightly colored weavings she sells at her airport souvenir shop here.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about the creation of atoms made of antimatter referred incorrectly to antiprotons, which are components of antimatter. They carry a negative charge, not a positive one.

title: His Not to Reason Why
description: Heath Ledger (above), as the dashing Harry Feversham seeking to reclaim his good name as a British officer, joins a cavalry charge in the Sudan in Shekhar Kapur's ''Four Feathers,'' the tale of lost honor, adventure and military derring-do in the heyday of Queen Victoria's empire. The cast of this latest remake -- the 1939 version starred Ralph Richardson -- includes Wes Bentley as Harry's best friend and Kate Hudson as his love.

title: The Lap of Luxury, Round the Corner
description: TEN years ago, Lisa Eggerton won the grand prize in a raffle, a weekend in New York, ''which I thought was totally useless because I lived in New York,'' said Ms. Eggerton, 34, now a vice president in the San Francisco office of Magnet Communications, a public relations firm. In vain, she tried to swap her coals-to-Newcastle winnings, finally shrugging, packing light and checking into her getaway spot: the Essex House.

title: Chief Executive to Step Down at Credit Suisse Group
description: Seeking to end criticism of the Credit Suisse Group over his leadership, Lukas Mhlemann said today that he would give up the role of chief executive at the end of the year.

title: Divorce Judge Wants New Filing From Wife of Former G.E. Chief
description: A Connecticut state court judge said yesterday that an affidavit filed by Jane B. Welch in her pending divorce from John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric, must be revised to meet state guidelines.

description: NOVICK-Sylvan. Town and Village Synagogue-Tifereth Israel mourns the loss of its long standing member and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Pearl and the entire family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Cantor Shayna Smith Dr. Roselyn Kolodny, Pres.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Arrest In Reporter's Killing
description: After a siege of more than a week, the police in Rio de Janeiro have arrested a powerful gang leader, Elias Pereira da Silva, and charged him with the murder of Tim Lopes, a prominent television reporter. Mr. Lopes was kidnapped and killed early in June, just as he was beginning an investigation of drug trafficking in slum neighborhoods controlled by the gang. His death became a symbol of the government's inability to control criminal groups, generating street demonstrations and demands for a reorganization of the police. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACCARINO, JOE
description: YACCARINO-Joe. 2/5/19 to 9/20/96. The music you loved evokes your spirit. Still listening, Nancy

title: For a Paean to Heroic Women, a Place at History's Table
description: Call it what you will: kitsch, pornography, artifact, feminist propaganda or a major work of 20th-century art. It doesn't make much difference. ''The Dinner Party,'' the extravagant ceramic and textile homage to women through history that Judy Chicago dreamed up and translated into reality in the 1970's, is important.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 7 about the resignation of the chief of Mount Sinai Medical Center's liver transplant program misstated the month that a healthy donor died after an operation to transplant part of his liver to his brother. It was January, not July.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: ENERGY PROPERTY SOLD In a move to strengthen its balance sheet, the independent power producer Calpine said it had agreed to sell its British Columbian oil and gas properties to the Pengrowth Corporation. Calpine, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said it would receive $248 million, or 391.6 million Canadian dollars, for the properties from Pengrowth, which is based in Alberta and administers the Pengrowth Energy Trust . "The divestiture further enhances Calpine's liquidity and financial strength," said Calpine's chief financial officer, Bob Kelly. The sale includes about 167,000 net developed acres and 380,000 net undeveloped acres of petroleum and natural gas rights. (Reuters)

title: Spies and Assassins Pack Plenty of Pow
description: You could call ''Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever'' the dark side of ''Spy Kids.'' Not only because a family is swept into the espionage biz, with a little boy as the bait used in a battle between a pair of disaffected spy-agency renegades, but also because the picture looks as if it were lighted with a 20-watt bulb. And it is dim in more ways than one.

title: Pataki Faults McCall on Taxes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki released a series of advertisements yesterday, including two that are critical of his Democratic opponent, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall. One is running on upstate stations; this one is running on cable television channels in the suburbs of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, RUTH (NEE GOLDFARB)
description: GREEN-Ruth (nee Goldfarb). Age 94. Of Jamaica Estates, N.Y. On Wednesday, September 18, 2002. Devoted mother of Jeffrey Jacobson. Cherished grandmother of Dr. Michael Jacobson and Marla Buckley. Great grandmother of Conor Aidan Buckley. Graveside service 1PM today at the Mount Hebron Cemetery, Queens, N.Y.

title: 36 Hours | Burlington, Vt.
description: A HIP, outdoorsy city in the northwestern corner of Vermont, Burlington is perhaps best known for its peace-loving, hippie roots. Representative Bernie Sanders, the independent who is Vermont's only representative in the House, was once the socialist mayor of the city. Ben & Jerry's, where corporate activism was dished out along with premium ice cream (at least before it was sold to a conglomerate), opened its first scoop shop at the corner of College and Battery Streets in 1978. Though the enduring activism can turn self-righteous at times, Burlington does manage to show its irreverence -- and tolerance for cold weather -- when it holds a parade and festival each winter at Mardi Gras. Perched on the eastern shore of Lake Champlain, the sixth-largest lake in the United States, and sandwiched between the Adirondacks of New York and the Green Mountains of Vermont, the Burlington area offers plenty of outdoor activities, from flat-water kayaking to stellar hiking. Funky shops, coffee houses and collegiate energy pervade the area, which is the home of the University of Vermont. WENDY KNIGHT

title: Pataki Goes on the Attack in Ads, but McCall Is Unfazed
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday released his first negative television commercials in his re-election campaign, a sign of the heightening rancor and increasing competitiveness in a general election race only 10 days old.

title: Powell Urges Strong Stand, Fast, for Move Against Iraq
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell implored Congress today to pass swiftly the strongest Iraq resolution possible, arguing that anything less would undermine efforts to build international support for ousting Saddam Hussein.

title: Morgan Stanley Reports Decline That Is Worse Than Expected
description: Morgan Stanley said yesterday that net income in its third quarter fell 13 percent from a year earlier, pulled lower by sour financial markets and a poor environment for investment banking.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERN, ISAAC
description: STERN-Isaac. The Carnegie Hall family will never forget our Founder and President, Isaac Stern, for his humanity, his music and his heroic rescue of Carnegie Hall from the wrecker's ball. Countless lives have been touched by his music, energy, passion, and humor, for to be in his presence was to breathe a different atmosphere. He was an inspiration-as a musician, as a leader, as a friend and colleague. Words cannot express how deeply he has been missed over the past year, here on 57th Street and around the world. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Robert Harth, Executive and Artistic Director

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Telecom Unit Sold
description: Teleglobe, a fiber optic voice and data network operator that sought bankruptcy protection in May, is selling its main business to Cerberus Capital Management and another company for $155.3 million. Cerberus, which is based in New York, and TenX Capital Partners of Philadelphia will assume control of Teleglobe's voice and data business through unnamed affiliates, Teleglobe said. Teleglobe sought protection from creditors when its parent, BCE Inc., stopped financing the unit, which has amassed $3.1 billion in losses since 2000. Teleglobe borrowed billions of dollars to build a fiber optic network, then failed to generate enough revenue to repay debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, CHARLES F.
description: SCOTT-Charles F. The Officers and Employees of the Riverside Memorial Chapels mourn with profound sorrow the passing of one of our mentors. Charlie was a beacon in funeral service, lighting the path along our 105 year journey, helping to bring us to where we are today. To his beloved wife, Rose, their devoted children, and the entire Scott family, we share in their grief of loss, and extend our heartfelt sympathy. Charles S. Salomon, Pres.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Vivendi Gets License To Develop Marvel Comics Games
description: The Vivendi Universal Publishing Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a 10-year licensing agreement with Marvel Enterprises to use 4,700 superheroes and characters -- including the likes of Spider-Man and the Incredible Hulk -- in Internet-based video games. Under the deal, which begins immediately, Vivendi Universal Games will be permitted to use the characters in online multiplayer games. These are games in which players interact and compete over the Internet from their own computers. The length of the deal is a reflection of the fact that while there has been much talk about the potential for online games, the business models are not yet clear and the technology needed to make the games popular is still in its infancy. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Agreement Sets Up Rules for Holocaust Claims
description: An international commission established in 1998 to settle insurance claims for Holocaust victims and their heirs has reached an accord with a consortium of European insurance companies on the procedures for people to apply for reparations, commission officials said today.

title: Cordiant Chairman Will Resign Soon
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London said yesterday that Charles Scott, the chairman since 1995, would resign as soon as a successor is named.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS-Ruth. Four yearsher song has ended but the melody lingers on. Oh, how we miss you. Joyce, Jason, Greg, Jordana

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Priest Accused Of Abuse
description: A Roman Catholic priest was arrested yesterday and charged with endangering the welfare of a child and sexual abuse, the authorities said. The police said the priest, the Rev. Jorge P. Pintado, 39, is accused of groping a 16-year-old boy through his clothing at the rectory of the Church of the Good Shepherd in Upper Manhattan. Father Pintado, who lives in Queens, could face up to a year in prison if convicted. He does not have an assignment in New York, but was invited by a parish group to say Mass. In 2000, Father Pintado was assigned to St. Joan of Arc Church in the Bronx, but left for health reasons, said Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the Archdiocese of New York. There were no other complaints against him, Mr. Zwilling said. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: FURNITURE MAKER SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 425 WORKERS
description: Furniture Brands International, the maker of the Broyhill, Lane and Thomasville lines, said yesterday that it would lay off 425 workers and close a plant in Thomasville, N.C., because of sluggish demand. The plant employs 300 people and makes Thomasville bedroom and dining room furniture, one of the company's more expensive lines, a spokesman said. An additional 125 workers at support operations will lose their jobs. The cuts represent about 6.6 percent of the company's work force. Furniture lines made at the North Carolina plant will be produced at other plants or by contractors, the company said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GUILFORD MILLS, Greensboro, N.C., a maker of textiles, said it had won a bankruptcy judge's approval for a reorganization plan that would eliminate more than $125 million in debt. Senior lenders will own 90 percent of the company, with existing stockholders owning 10 percent.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economy Seen Stabilizing
description: The Bank of Japan held its economic assessment steady for a third consecutive month, repeating its view that Japan's economy has almost bottomed out thanks to continued strong exports. But the central bank also reiterated its concerns that volatile global stock prices could hurt the economy, which prompted the plan it announced on Wednesday to buy stockholdings from banks. ''Japan's economy, despite persistent weakness in domestic demand and large uncertainty over the global economy, has almost stabilized as a whole with exports and production continuing to increase,'' the bank said.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/World Music; From the Mediterranean, A Sea of Ethnic Sounds
description: The abundance of the Mediterranean Sea extends to the music of the countries that border it, with each style shaped by millenniums of commerce and strife yet as distinct as a local wine. This weekend, with ''Music Around the Mediterranean,'' the World Music Institute and the Center for Traditional Music and Dance revive and expand what used to be an annual event: the center's international dance party, held in the picnic garden of an old Queens beer hall.

title: Regulator Voices Suspicion On First Boston Analysts
description: The Massachusetts regulator investigating the practices of research analysts at Credit Suisse First Boston told the New York attorney general yesterday that his staff had found conduct at the firm that might have violated criminal statutes.

title: Now Opening For Business: McCartney
description: ''I don't want people to come in and just think garments, garments, garments, buy, buy, buy,'' Stella McCartney said yesterday as workmen banged hammers, readying the Stella McCartney store, her first, for its opening tonight.

title: CBS Refuses Request Not to Show The Masters
description: The National Council of Women's Organizations made its expected appeal to CBS Sports yesterday that it not broadcast the Masters next year because the Augusta National Golf Club has no female members.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Orient Point: Union Details Objections
description: A settlement of the strike at Plum Island Animal Disease Center foundered because management refused to restore 30 of the 76 strikers to their jobs and insisted on replacing them, the union said. Maintenance and support workers have been on strike since Aug. 13. Agreement was reached on pay and benefits, the union, the International Union of Operating Engineers, said, but the refusal to restore strikers was unacceptable. An official of LB&B Associates, the subcontractor that helps operate the research center for the federal Department of Agriculture, confirmed that replacements were an issue but declined further comment. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: 3 Finalists in Los Angeles For Job as Chief of Police
description: The city's police commission recommended three finalists today for the job of police chief, including two former leaders of the New York Police Department, William J. Bratton and John F. Timoney.

title: U.N. Planning New Tower In Nearby Park
description: The United Nations is considering temporarily moving out of its headquarters to a new 35-story office building under a deal with the city that would allow it to renovate its crumbling Secretariat building.

title: Bush to Outline Doctrine of Striking Foes First
description: On Friday, the Bush administration will publish its first comprehensive rationale for shifting American military strategy toward pre-emptive action against hostile states and terrorist groups developing weapons of mass destruction. The strategy document will also state, for the first time, that the United States will never allow its military supremacy to be challenged the way it was during the cold war.

title: City to Pay Millions To Homeless Forced To Sleep in an Office
description: New York City has agreed to pay millions of dollars in penalties dating to 1995 to homeless families who were forced to stay overnight in a Bronx office while awaiting emergency shelter, a violation of court orders.

title: Houses or Gardens in New York City
description: The battle over New York's community gardens has gone on so long that it's hard to believe that somebody has finally found a solution. Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the New York State attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, have now announced what looks like a workable way out of the legal briar patch that would preserve 500 gardens while dismantling others to build much-needed city housing.

title: An Office Disciplinarian Gets His Way in the End
description: ''Secretary,'' a small groundbreaking comedy, is a contemporary Cinderella story with a kink and a wink. Its endearing heroine is Lee Holloway, a repressed, masochistically inclined young secretary who blooms under the spanking hand of her boss, E. Edward Grey (James Spader), a grim, tight-lipped lawyer who presides over an office where the computer has yet to replace the trusty old typewriter.

description: BARKIN-Jesse H. Passed away September 19, 2002 at age 99. Beloved and loving husband of Ruth for over 73 years. Loving father of Elyse Rabin Barkin and Stephen Barkin, caring-father-in law of Madeline. Adoring grandfather of Lynne Cooke, Julie Gans Cray, Dr. Jeffrey Barkin and Dr. Elizabeth Barkin Leight. A past President of The Jewish Memorial Hospital, Trustee of UJA Federation, Founder of The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Trustee of Congregation B'nai Jeshurum, member Temple Emanu-El, Old Oaks Country Club, Palm Beach Country Club, and the Harmonie Club. Funeral private.

description: A federal appeals court ordered a judge in Newark yesterday to release the entire contents of a Justice Department letter that describes the evidence prosecutors gathered in their five-year investigation of Senator Robert G. Torricelli's campaign and personal finances.

Putin of Russia seeking support for American action against Saddam Hussein, and that differences between the governments over Iraq were exaggerated.

title: Roddick and Blake Fall to the French
description: It had been 70 years since the French were host to the Americans in a Davis Cup match at Roland Garros. During that span, rackets went from wood to titanium, tennis attire from long flannel pants to sweat-wicking shorts, and players from amateurs to full-blown professionals.

title: Daimler Buys Stakes in Asian Trucking
description: DaimlerChrysler said today that it had taken a double plunge into the Asian truck market, spending $1.14 billion to buy stakes in the truck operations of Hyundai Motor of South Korea and in the Fuso truck division of Mitsubishi Motors of Japan.

title: Altruism, Not Party, Prods Democrat
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20  Faced with the choice of accepting his dream job under a Republican president or remaining in Congress to try to help the Democrats take back control of the House, Representative Tony P. Hall of Ohio said he never gave a thought to partisan concerns.

title: Karl L. Brown, 76, Developer of Accelerators That Treat Cancer
description: Karl L. Brown, a pioneer in the development of compact linear accelerators used for cancer treatment, died on Aug. 29 in Stanford, Calif. He was 76 and lived in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: DELAY IN POWER PLANTS HURTS DUKE ENERGY'S PROFITS
description: The Duke Energy Corporation said yesterday that its profit would drop more than forecast this year because of a slump in energy trading that has forced the company, the No. 2 United States utility owner, to halt work on three power plants. Delaying the plants in Nevada, New Mexico and Washington will bring a third-quarter charge of as much as $300 million, Duke said in a statement. Profit this year will fall to $1.95 to $2.05 a share and may drop further next year, it said. Duke was expected to earn $2.46 a share this year, the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Duke fell $1.02, or 4.8 percent, to $20.40, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Bush administration's adoption of a doctrine of pre-emptive action against hostile countries placed a passage in quotation marks erroneously in a description of the 33-page document prepared for Congress. The comment  that the president has no intention of allowing any foreign power to catch up with the huge lead the United States has opened since the fall of the Soviet Union more than a decade ago  was the writer's summation of interviews with senior administration officials.

title: The Sandwiches Stay, but One of These Brothers May Have to Go
description: An out-of-court settlement could finally end one of New York's most appalling food fights, the battle between two brothers operating rival culinary landmarks bearing the name Manganaro.

title: U.S. Inquiry on Pricing of Prostate Drug
description: LONDON, Sept. 20 (Dow Jones/AP)  The British pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca P.L.C. said today that it was being investigated by the United States government over the pricing and marketing of its prostate-cancer drug, Zoladex.

title: Lassiter's Strategy Upsets U.S. Officials
description: Africa led the men's competition and Europe led the women's standing at the end of the first day of the two-day World Cup of Athletics in Madrid. But yesterday's men's 1,500 meters race was the center of attention as well as controversy.

title: A Relaxed Tony Bennett Is a Master of Surprise
description: Tony Bennett is not a vocalist given to pumping personal psychodrama into a song. A supremely confident swinger, he would rather play the genially reverent custodian of the American popular songbook, concentrating on the pleasure to be found in his material. He is so comfortable on the stage that he makes relaxation and rhythmic command appear synonymous. Yet because he relishes abrupt dynamic shifts and stylistic juxtapositions, his singing is full of surprises. A song that begins as a half-whisper can build to a fierce final shout, and jazz riffing can transform into flowery semioperatic flourishes.
