His intellect, experience and guidance were greatly appreciated by the building and he will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his entire family on their tragic loss. The Board of Directors 20 East 9th St Corp

title: Review/Fashion; Fuel for Fantasies Of Misspent Youth
description: One afternoon last week, I noticed a woman gesticulating in the doorway of an office building on Seventh Avenue. She had a medium build and wore a green and white kilt, paired with a snug-fitting cropped blazer in army green, scrunched boots and a dangling wool scarf, which the weather did not require.

title: An Anxious Debate Over War and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing the Limits of Law, and of Lawsuits
description: When establishing the Victim Compensation Fund last year, Congress foresaw a potential legal nightmare. It thus imposed one condition before victims of the Sept. 11 attacks could receive money from the fund: They had to waive their right to sue anyone except the terrorists. But recent claims suggest that Congress did not go far enough. It should reconsider whether lawsuits arising over the events of Sept. 11, other than those against the terrorists, should be allowed at all.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: War Crimes Indictment Sent Back
description: The government sent an indictment against its retired army chief of staff back to the United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague. It cited what it said was a procedural error in the charges against Janko Bobetko, the most senior Croat to be indicted in connection with the Balkan wars of the early 1990's. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Belgium Confronts Its Heart of Darkness; Unsavory Colonial Behavior in the Congo Will Be Tackled by a New Study
description: No less than other European powers, Belgium proclaimed its colonial mission to be that of spreading civilization. But while Britain and France, say, had global empires, Belgium's attention was focused overwhelmingly on the vast, resource-rich Central African territory of Congo, 75 times larger than Belgium itself. The deal was implicit: in exchange for extracting immense wealth from its colony, Belgium offered schools, roads, Christianity and, yes, civilization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, VIRGINIA TONS MEIRE
description: ARNOLD - Virginia Tons meire, 95. Died on Monday, September 16 at her home in Mamaroneck, NY. She is survived by her two sons James Michael, Jr. of Manhattan and E. Barton of Lenox, MA, her daughter Nancy Arnold Goldstein of Manhattan and her three granddaughters: Jocelyn, Gillian Goldstein and Emma Arnold. For information contact the George T. Davis Funeral Home in New Rochelle, New York.

title: Curtis Cuffie, 47, Artist of Life on the Streets
description: Curtis Cuffie, a sculptor of elaborate and witty assemblages of objects found in the street who developed his technique during years of homelessness, was found dead on Sept. 13 in his Manhattan apartment. He was 47.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Infected Deer Found Outside Eradication Zone
description: A buck infected with chronic wasting disease was found in Portage County, about 100 miles north of the deer eradication zone the State Department of Natural Resources set up in southern Wisconsin. The discovery has forced the department to re-evaluate its strategy for ridding the deer population of the disease, though no decision has been announced. The animal was shot on a game farm. It is not clear whether the department plans to eradicate the remaining deer on the property. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Bergen County Officials Praise Plans to Redevelop Meadowlands Arena Site
description: The day after a half-dozen companies unveiled competing proposals for redeveloping the Continental Airlines Arena site in the Meadowlands, officials here in Bergen County found plenty to like in the details. They praised the way the plans de-emphasized retailing in favor of family entertainment. They lauded the proposals' links to mass transit.

description: Amid the canyons of the financial district, it is hard to imagine how one could conceal an acre of public space that offered daylight, harbor breezes and a gull's-eye view of the East River waterfront.

title: BUSH HAS RECEIVED PENTAGON OPTIONS ON ATTACKING IRAQ
description: The Pentagon has completed and delivered to President Bush a highly detailed set of military options for attacking Iraq, Pentagon and White House officials said today.

He will be remembered as a brilliant and caring man who took pride in the achievements of his children and grandchildren, and who was always available to help those in need.

title: Havana To Unlock Hemingway Papers
description: The Cuban government has agreed to allow access to a trove of Ernest Hemingway's papers that experts say promises to illuminate the period in which he wrote some of his most significant works.

title: The New Jersey Ethicist
description: As the senior senator representing a large Northeastern state, I am often offered little presents from constituents -- a TV, a couple of Italian suits, a grandfather clock, a little jewelry for the girlfriend. What can I say? People just feel a special gratitude. Not long ago one constituent flipped out and started blabbing to the feds and the press. Now I'm up for re-election, and my opponent can't talk about anything else except my so-called ethics. ANONYMOUS, WASHINGTON

title: Mets Deny Team Is Plagued by Marijuana Use
description: Nine days from the end of an underachieving season, the Mets closed ranks yesterday in the face of another embarrassing development. After failing in every way possible to attach on-field success to last winter's highly touted reshuffling of the roster, the Mets are finishing out the season responding to allegations of widespread drug use on the team.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Troops To Chechnya
description: The Interior Ministry said it would send another 1,200 troops to battle separatists in Chechnya, beefing up a force that already numbers 80,000 soldiers. The move follows President Vladimir V. Putin's pledge this week to station troops in the province ''forever.'' The government has twice announced plans to reduce or end its military presence in Chechnya, turning over most duties to the local police and militia. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Appeal Filed Against Papon Release
description: The Paris prosecutor's office said it had filed an appeal against a court ruling this week that released Maurice Papon, the most prominent Frenchman to be tried for collaborating with the Nazis. After a public outcry over the release, Justice Minister Dominique Perben ordered the prosecutor in Paris to seek a reversal of the decision by a three-judge appeals court panel to free Mr. Papon, 92, on grounds of poor health and old age. Prosecutors said they had based their appeal on the idea that the release disturbs public order, citing as proof protests -- albeit small -- in French cities since the ruling. Mr. Papon had served 3 years of a 10-year sentence for signing deportation orders for more than 1,500 Jews. Elaine Sciolino (NYT)

title: On the Air Again, Still Contrary
description: Steve Post was in familiar mode, deploring commercialism on public radio. Then he caught himself. ''Here I go,'' he said on the phone, ''criticizing the hand that bites me.''

title: It May Be a Late Start, but It's Right on Time for Ivy Teams
description: They are college football's caboose, the eight Ivy League teams that start playing after almost every other team has taken the field. That time has arrived. Today Columbia, Harvard, Princeton and the rest of the Ivies will be in uniform, doing their Division I-AA best and not thinking ahead to any possible postseason games, because the Ivy League teams stop playing when the regular season ends.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nuclear Power Scandal Grows
description: A scandal involving the nuclear energy industry widened as three of the country's largest power companies announced the temporary closing of reactors for emergency inspections. The closings came after the companies admitted they had hidden inspection data revealing cracks in structures. The largest utility, the Tokyo Electric Power Company, said it had had failed to report 29 cases of falsifying and ignoring inspection records of its nuclear plants. The Chubu Electric Power Company and the Tohoku Electric Power Company also acknowleged that they had failed to report or repair cracks at nuclear plants. Howard W. French (NYT)

description: Noise pollution. Prostitution. Smoking. Now the City Council has taken on another hot-button quality-of-life issue: changing tables.

title: Bronx Man Is Second in City This Year to Die Of West Nile
description: A 75-year-old man from the Bronx died on Tuesday of the West Nile virus, becoming the second fatality in the city this year caused by the mosquito-borne illness, health officials said yesterday.

title: MEDTRONIC AND BOSTON SCIENTIFIC SETTLE PATENT DISPUTE
description: Medtronic Inc. agreed yesterday to pay the Boston Scientific Corporation $175 million to end a dispute related to a delivery system for devices that prop open arteries. The settlement ends Medtronic's yearlong battle to avoid paying the amount that arbitrators awarded after finding the company infringed a Boston Scientific patent for rapid delivery of stents, the tiny tubes used to prop open arteries cleared by angioplasty procedures. Medtronic stopped selling the system last year while it appealed the ruling. The agreement, which includes cross-licensing of some patents, ''resolves the vast majority of pending litigation'' between the companies, said a Boston Scientific spokesman, Paul Donovan.

title: Spending Mark Seen For Governor's Race
description: The race for governor of New York State is on pace to be the most expensive non-presidential campaign in American history, with more than $70 million spent -- and six weeks to go until Election Day. The final total is likely to be between $120 million and $150 million.

title: Ricky Jay, a Man Who Believes More in Magicians Than in Magic
description: Ricky Jay is one of the world's eminent performers and scholars of magic. His latest book, ''Dice: Deception, Fate and Rotten Luck'' (Quantuck Lane Press/Norton), will be published next month. Until Oct. 20 he may be seen in his one-man show, ''Ricky Jay: On the Stem,'' directed by David Mamet and playing at Second Stage Theater in Manhattan. Emily Eakin spoke with him.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: PORT CARGO MOVES WITHOUT INTERRUPTION

title: Man Is Arrested in the Fatal Shooting of a Homeless Man in Queens
description: A 52-year-old electrical engineer walked into a wooded area in Queens frequented by homeless people, pulled a shotgun from his trench coat and shot a man to death on Thursday night, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; Drug Testing Is Baseball's Biggest Joke
description: THIS is what the Mets' horrid season has come down to: jokes. Not only jokes about the team's miserable play, but also jokes about baseball's version of the marijuana monologues. Like the one about the Mets scout, while looking for talent, leaving no stoner unturned. And you know, no one can ever say the Mets aren't hungry to win, because they've always got the munchies.

title: Democrats Are Fined $243,000 for Fund-Raising Violations
description: The Democratic National Committee has agreed to pay civil fines and turn over to the Treasury a total of $243,000 to settle accusations that it took more than $1 million in illegal foreign contributions in 1995 and 1996, according to Federal Election Commission records released today.

title: Robert Wilson, Astrophysicist And Satellite's Advocate, 75
description: Sir Robert Wilson, a British astrophysicist who helped develop an early orbiting observatory that provided numerous insights into celestial bodies as humble as comets and as spectacular as supernovas, died on Sept. 2 in Chelmsford, England. He was 75.

title: Harvard President Sees Rise In Anti-Semitism on Campus
description: Harvard University's president, Lawrence H. Summers, used a quiet prayer meeting on the first day of classes here this week to condemn what he termed growing anti-Semitism at Harvard and elsewhere.

title: Listen Up, You Geniuses: This Jackpot May Be Yours
description: It is that time of year again. The telephone rings and the news is akin to hitting the lottery or winning an Oscar.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 4 about commercial real estate in Vancouver, Wash., referred incorrectly to two residential buildings and an underground parking garage that are part of a downtown project. While the buildings are substantially completed, they are not yet occupied. The garage is scheduled to open in March; it is not already in use.

title: Japanese Leader Faces Questions Over North Korea Meeting
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan, facing criticism from news organizations at home instead of the praise he expected after his recent summit meeting in North Korea, has made two statements about high-profile issues involving North Korea almost as afterthoughts.

title: Yanks Clinch Tie For Division Title
description: The gimpy Yankees are limping to their fifth consecutive title in the American League East. They clinched at least a tie tonight when they beat the bumbling Detroit Tigers, 5-1, on the damp lawn of Comerica Park.

title: CIGARETTE SHARES FALL AS LAWSUIT PROCEEDS
description: Shares of cigarette makers including the Philip Morris Companies and R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings fell after a federal judge in New York certified a nationwide class-action lawsuit against them. The companies said they would ask the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to reject Thursday's order by District Judge Jack Weinstein. The suit, known as Simon II, is the first in which a judge has consolidated all tobacco-related litigation before him, including the punitive-damage claims of smokers, labor unions and health insurers. Judge Weinstein set a trial date of Jan. 20. Defendants are Philip Morris, R. J. Reynolds, the Loews Corporation's Lorillard Tobacco, British American Tobacco's Brown & Williamson and the Vector Group's Liggett Group.

title: An Anxious Debate Over War and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAXBERG, NETTIE
description: WAXBERG-Nettie. Dearest mother, thank you for loving me and our family so selflessly and so completely for so long. Your warmth, smile and happy voice will forever remain in our hearts and memories. Our love always, your daughter, Leni, son Gabriel, grandsons Jimmy, Andy. Granddaughters - in - law Nancy, Robyn. Great-grandchildren Elissa, Rachel and your entire family. Services Sunday 12 noon at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Zia, Defender, Gives Credit Where It's Due: To Declarer
description: The world's great players always attract a following of kibitzers, watching their every move. When the kibitzer sees something memorable, he eagerly reports it to the press, hoping for reflected glory. But this can happen in reverse, in man-bites-dog fashion.

title: Kickoff
description: JOE DRAPE'S TOP MATCHUPS

title: Help for Palestinian Reformers
description: The scene in Tel Aviv on Thursday was sickeningly familiar -- the exploded bus, the blackened bodies, the sheer terror of a Palestinian suicide bomber at lunch hour on a packed downtown street. The work of an Islamic militant group, it was the second suicide attack in Israel in two days after six weeks without one. Israel reacted by waging a tank assault on the Ramallah compound of Yasir Arafat, lobbing rockets, tearing down most of his headquarters, and digging a trench and running barbed wire around the ruins.

title: Anger as Policy: A Debate Over Ignoring Arafat
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's reaction to the suicide bombing in Tel Aviv on Thursday was simple and immediate: Yasir Arafat ''must be removed from here once and for all.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AIR CANADA, Dorval, Quebec, the world's 10th-largest carrier, will introduce on Sunday Zip Air Inc., a discount airline with six jets serving several western Canadian cities. Air Canada itself will no longer compete in the low-fare market in that region.

title: Hyundai Predicts a Tripling Of Sales in the U.S. by 2010
description: Hyundai Motor America, on a sharp rebound since dealing with a quality problem with its cars, intends to sell a million vehicles a year in the United States by the end of the decade, nearly triple its current pace.

title: With No Other Choice, Jets' Rookie Is Ready
description: Forget the fact that Jon McGraw might have been the first player in Jets history to play the violin at the club's rookie show -- he played the theme from ''The Last of the Mohicans'' -- or that he majored in finance at Kansas State. Today at practice he looked like he belonged at free safety.

title: Court Overturns Award of $164 Million to a Bear Stearns Investor
description: A federal appeals court has overturned a jury's verdict ordering the Bear Stearns Companies to pay $164.5 million to an investor who lost money speculating in the currency futures market.

title: Incumbent Appears Unseated in Westchester Assembly Race
description: After a careful count of ballots in a Democratic primary for State Assembly in Westchester County, a political newcomer appears to have unseated a 10-year incumbent.

title: Washed in the Sound of Souls in Transit
description: It's understandable that so far most American composers of note have avoided writing works that deal with Sept. 11. The event is still too close, too immense. But the need to come to terms with it artistically, at least in some manner, is also real. So give John Adams credit for trying. Mr. Adams's ''On the Transmigration of Souls,'' commissioned by the New York Philharmonic and Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, received its premiere on Thursday night at the first subscription concert of the Philharmonic's season, conducted by Lorin Maazel in his second appearance as the orchestra's music director.

title: Some in Congress, Recalling Vietnam, Oppose War
description: In a city where the talk is of when, not if, there will be war with Iraq, a small group of Democratic die-hards in the House is trying to rally opposition to military action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, LILA
description: LERNER-Lila. On September 20th after a brief illness, beloved wife of Max K. Lerner for 59 years, loving mother of Helene Lerner, Beth Seeger and her husband Bill. Adoring grandmother of Jared and Erica Seeger and Heath Robbins. Loving sister of Edith Tunick and her husband Jerry. Cherished aunt. Services Sunday 11:15 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th street and Amsterdam Ave. NYC

title: Face of Bensonhurst
description: To the Editor:

title: 9/11 Contractors Near Agreement On Insurance
description: The construction companies that excavated the debris from ground zero were near agreement with the city yesterday on a deal to use federal emergency money to buy $1 billion in insurance, which the companies would use to defend themselves against any lawsuits from residents, property owners and workers connected with the cleanup.

title: TANKS AND TRENCH BOTTLE UP ARAFAT IN HIS COMPOUND
description: The Israeli Army tightened its choke hold on Yasir Arafat today, demolishing all but one building in his compound and digging a trench around it, according to Palestinians inside.

title: An Anxious Debate Over War and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Population Still Shrinking
description: The State Statistics Committee reported a population decline of 505,900 people in the first six months of 2002, to 143.4 million. The drop was slightly less than in the same period last year but the population continues to fall by about one million people annually. The number of births grew by 50,000 compared with the first half of 2001, but in a sign of the continuing health crisis the number of deaths also increased by nearly 50,000. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Life Insurers Feel the Strain of Shaky Markets
description: The nation's life insurance companies are straining under a welter of new financial burdens, even as Americans -- shaken by terrorist attacks and the slumping stock market -- sign up for life insurance in increasing numbers.

title: Eli Lilly in Deal For the Rights To a New Drug For Diabetes
description: Eli Lilly & Company will pay up to $325 million to Amylin Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company based in San Diego, for the rights to a potentially promising treatment for diabetes, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Housing the Homeless Mentally Ill
description: In the 19th century, the plight of the mentally ill in the poorhouses of New York prompted calls for reform. A quarter century ago, the state began closing its discredited psychiatric wards. Now there's a new set of scandals. Gov. George Pataki and his aides can't shy away from accepting responsibility for the system that in too many cases is failing mentally disabled New Yorkers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MILDRED
description: KATZ-Mildred. On September 19, 2002. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great - grandmother. New York City school teacher for over thirty years.

title: Outdoor Therapy Camp Workers Charged in Hiking Death of Boy
description: Two employees of a wilderness therapy camp in central Utah have been charged with child-abuse homicide in the death of a 14-year-old boy two months ago on a desert hike.

title: Atonement in the Boardroom
description: Jack Welch's gut told him it was time to give up his lavish retirement perks, and investors can only hope that his decision is contagious. Mr. Welch insisted there was nothing improper about his retirement deal in a Wall Street Journal op-ed article last Monday, but nevertheless announced he would start paying General Electric an estimated $2 million a year for the use of the company jet, Manhattan apartment and other perks that were part of a 1996 agreement to keep him on the job for another few years.

title: South Beach Debut
description: The 90-room Courtyard by Marriott, Miami South Beach officially opened this month, with introductory rates of $99 to $109 a night through Dec. 26. The hotel, which has a rooftop pool, is two blocks from the Miami Beach Convention Center and is near the Lincoln Road Mall. It occupies a restored 1941 Art Deco building at 1530 Washington Avenue. Rooms have two telephones with data ports; a restaurant serves breakfast only. Information: (305) 604-8887 or www.courtyard.com .

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Tax Cut Only For Small Business
description: Malaysia, forecasting growth of as much as 6.5 percent next year, limited a widely expected corporate tax cut to small companies as it focused on reducing government spending. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, left, said that Malaysia would cut to 20 percent from 28 percent the income tax on the first 100,000 ringgit ($26,330) of chargeable income for Malaysian companies that have paid-up capital of 2.5 million ringgit ($685,240) or less.

title: An Anxious Debate Over War and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Gains From War Talk But Does Not Talk About It
description: Senior Republican Party officials say the prospect of at least two more weeks of Congressional debate on Iraq is allowing their party to run out the clock on the fall election, blocking Democrats as they try to seize on the faltering economy and other domestic concerns as campaign issues.

title: G.M. Takes a Leap of Faith Into the Russian Car Market
description: General Motors will cut the ribbon on Monday on a risky $340 million bet: that it can prosper in the Russian car market by building a new sport utility vehicle designed by its local partner, AvtoVAZ, Russia's largest and most controversial car company.

title: Lawyer Proves a Thorn for Enron's Partners
description: An unassuming Atlanta lawyer has quietly become one of the biggest hazards facing the giant banks and law firms that helped create the off-balance-sheet partnerships often blamed for Enron's downfall.

title: Visit to Qaeda Camp Makes 6 Suspects Dangerous, U.S. Insists
description: Three days of bail hearings in the case of six men accused of being members of a sleeper cell of Al Qaeda ended today, with the government repeating that the men posed a danger to the community because they attended a terrorist training camp in 2001.

title: Old-Fashioned Football Family, but a Tight End for the 21st Century
description: The two most important elements in Greg Olsen's life are football and family.

title: Devils Start Anew, and Tie
description: The Devils had plenty to work on during their first preseason game tonight against Pittsburgh, including their new system, run by their new coach, and an experiment with four scrambled lines. They got extra time to do it as the game went into overtime, and Pat Burns's coaching debut with the Devils ended in a 4-4 tie.

title: An Anxious Debate Over War and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: MALAYSIA: TAX CUT ONLY FOR SMALL BUSINESS Malaysia, forecasting growth of as much as 6.5 percent next year, limited a widely expected corporate tax cut to small companies as it focused on reducing government spending. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, left, said that Malaysia would cut to 20 percent from 28 percent the income tax on the first 100,000 ringgit ($26,330) of chargeable income for Malaysian companies that have paid-up capital of 2.5 million ringgit ($685,240) or less. (Bloomberg News)

title: Vols Are Superior, in Modest Way
description: Tennessee has the third-largest stadium in college football, a coach with the second-best winning percentage among active coaches and a national championship trophy from 1998. National Football League stars? The Volunteers have contributed 17 first-round draft choices, including Peyton Manning, whom Indianapolis selected first over all in 1998.

title: Governor's Race Is Expected To Set a Record for Spending
description: The rancorous race for governor is on a pace to be the most expensive nonpresidential campaign in American history, reports made public today showed, with more than $70 million spent with six weeks to go until Election Day.

title: ORACLE EXECUTIVE QUITS AS A DIRECTOR OF APPLE COMPUTER
description: The billionaire software executive Lawrence J. Ellison, whose Oracle Corporation has had six straight quarters of falling sales, quit as a director of Apple Computer after five years that included bringing back Steven P. Jobs to lead a turnaround. ''He just didn't have time to come to the board meetings,'' Mr. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, said in an e-mail message. Company filings show Mr. Ellison missed at least a quarter of Apple's meetings. Mr. Ellison is trying to reverse Oracle's sales slump, which has contributed to an 83 percent plunge in the share price since a September 2000 peak.

title: Why I'm Fighting Federal Drug Laws From City Hall
description: How did I, a mayor of a small town in California, wind up in a tug of war with the Drug Enforcement Agency?

title: Washington United Way Names an Interim Chief
description: The troubled United Way of the National Capital Area yesterday appointed one of Washington's best-known charity leaders as its interim head.

title: Tyson-as-Baby-Sitter Ad Went Over the Line
description: In a culture that we are told demands daring and extremes, it is not difficult to imagine someone devising a promotional campaign that includes a commercial starring Mike Tyson as a lullaby-singing baby sitter.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: WISCONSIN: INFECTED DEER FOUND OUTSIDE ERADICATION ZONE

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: 10,000 More Layoffs At Alcatel
description: The phone equipment maker Alcatel said it would increase the number of layoffs at its factories by about 10,000 by the end of next year because of further weakening in demand for its products. Alcatel said it expected second-half revenue to drop about 10 percent below that for the first half. Alcatel and its rivals, including Ericsson of Sweden and Lucent Technologies, have suffered a sharp drop in demand for phone equipment as phone companies slash investment. Alcatel now expects to have about 60,000 employees by the end of next year, compared with 130,000 at the end of 2000. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Al Qaeda Money Trail Runs From Saudi Arabia to Spain
description: Spanish and American investigators believe that hundreds of thousands of dollars flowed from Saudi Arabia into the accounts of Spanish companies that were used as conduits for money to Al Qaeda and other radical Islamist groups, law enforcement and intelligence officials said.

title: White House, In Shift, Backs Inquiry on 9/11
description: The White House gave in today to growing Congressional demands for an independent investigation of last year's terrorist attacks, setting the stage for a comprehensive inquiry into the failures and vulnerabilities that made the hijackings possible.

title: Teachers Dig Deeper to Fill Gap in Supplies
description: In the two years since she gave up a business career to become a New York City teacher, Leslie Fiske has become a relentless bargain hunter. She combs the newspaper ads in August for hot deals on crayons and glue sticks. She has discount cards for Staples and Barnes & Noble, and has enlisted friends in the corporate world to donate stickers, pencils and award certificates.

title: Bhopal Seethes, Pained and Poor 18 Years Later
description: Eighteen years after thousands of people died here in a cloud of gas, the only monument to their memory is a rain-worn statue of a mother holding a baby and covering her face as another child hides behind her skirts.

title: Computer Recycling Bill
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 20 (Bloomberg News)  California may become the first state requiring computer makers to charge buyers to recycle the machines. Gov. Gray Davis has until Sept. 30 to sign or veto a measure that would require computer makers and sellers of television sets to add a $10 fee to purchases starting Jan. 1, 2004. Environmentalists say the law is needed to deal with the more than six million discarded monitors and TV sets waiting to be recycled. It is illegal in California to put them in a landfill because they contain hazardous materials.

title: Review/Fashion; Giving the Body A Frank Embrace
description: When the hot Latino music came on and the first models stepped out in skintight sheaths ventilated under the bosom, it was as if Narcisco Rodriguez had opened a steam valve in the middle of the spring 2003 collections.

title: An Anxious Debate Over War and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABERSKI, DR. EUGENE
description: SABERSKI-Dr. Eugene. Died at home September 19, 2002. Loving husband of the late Norma Saberski. Devoted father of Jean Rosen, Neda Birbrower and Lloyd. Also survived by Jay Rosen, Barry Birbrower, Dale Saberski and nine grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Loving brother of Ruth Goldenheim, Irwin Wilma Mendelowitz. Services Sunday, 10:00 AM, Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Donations to Planned Parenthood or Phelps Hospice.

title: An Anxious Debate Over War and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: With More Ice Time, Cohen Looks Ahead
description: At the beginning of her career, Sasha Cohen huddled happily along rink rails with bunches of friends as they waited for the music. Skaters swarmed over the practice space, shrinking Cohen's ice time to 40-minute daily sessions.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first day of Sukkot, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Rate Rises
description: Canada's inflation accelerated in August, with the consumer price index up 2.6 percent from a year earlier, compared with a 2.1 percent advance in the year to July, Statistics Canada reported. The higher rate was mainly a result of a rise in cigarette taxes, auto insurance premiums, and electricity and gasoline prices, and was partly offset by a sharp drop in natural gas prices. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Lead Paint Suits Echo Approach to Tobacco
description: A trial under way in Rhode Island, the first state to file such a suit against paint manufacturers and one in which nearly 80 percent of the housing is believed to contain lead paint, is being closely watched by cities and states around the country.

title: China Frees AIDS Activist After Month of Outcry
description: China's most prominent advocate for AIDS patients, Dr. Wan Yanhai, was unexpectedly released today after nearly a month's detention by China's State Security apparatus.

title: Transit Union Opens Talks With Long List of Grievances
description: Negotiations got off to a tense start yesterday for New York City's 34,000 subway and bus workers, as their union demanded major improvements in wages and benefits to catch up with their suburban counterparts.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Sept. 6 about changes in workplace policies in India's software industry misstated the value of the country's exports for the fiscal year ended March 30 and the percentage that went to the United States. Total exports were $44.3 billion; $7.54 billion was the figure for software and related exports only. Of the total, 21 percent went to the United States; the two-thirds figure also applied only to software exports.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: FALUN GONG MEMBERS SENTENCED Fifteen members of the banned spiritual group Falun Gong were given sentences ranging from 4 to 20 years in prison for hacking into a cable television system in the northeastern city of Changchun, a court official said. The incident on March 5 marked the start of a campaign by Falun Gong supporters, who have commandeered TV signals in at least four areas to show videos opposing the government's crackdown on the movement. (AP)

title: Microsoft Buys Stake in Game Developer
description: The Microsoft Corporation bought a 49 percent stake in the British game-software developer Rare Ltd. from the Nintendo Company, the maker of the GameCube video-game system, a Nintendo vice president said today.

title: When a Perfect Scheme Doesn't Work Perfectly
description: In ''Trapped,'' a pointless little kidnapping thriller, Kevin Bacon and Courtney Love are Joe and Cheryl Hickey, a pair of extortionists who, with Joe's cousin Marvin (Pruitt Taylor Vince), have devised what they imagine to be a quick, foolproof moneymaking system. Since it has already gone like clockwork four times (each abduction netting them a cool quarter of a million dollars without a hitch or an injury), they are unprepared when the fifth couple on their hit list, Will and Karen Jennings (Stuart Townsend and Charlize Theron), an anesthesiologist and his wife, fight back.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: PROSECUTORS PURSUE ANDREOTTI Prosecutors have asked an appeals court to sentence former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti to 24 years in prison for complicity in the 1979 killing of a journalist. Mr. Andreotti, 83, who was prime minister seven times and is a senator for life, was acquitted of the charges three years ago but the prosecutors are appealing that verdict. They say Mr. Andreotti's aides, in collusion with the Mafia, conspired to kill Mino Pecorelli because he was about to publish revelations that could have ruined Mr. Andreotti's career. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUJICA, JOHN C.
description: MUJICA-John C. On September 19, 2002. Loving uncle of Jo-Ann Vize and Patricia Winn. Beloved brother-in-law of Olga. Also survived by seven grandnieces and nephews and six great-grandnieces and nephews. Funeral from Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home Inc., 36-46 Bell Blvd. on Monday. Mass of Christian Burial at Sacred Heart R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-5, 7-9 PM Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about stronger warning labels for the painkiller acetaminophen, the key ingredient in Tylenol and other headache remedies, misspelled the name of a Food and Drug Administration official who said science lacked information to understand why alcohol and the drug were a potentially dangerous combination. She is Dr. Sandra Kweder, not Kweber.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Burmese To Join U.S. In Search
description: A delegation from Myanmar is to visit Hawaii next month to meet with American military experts in preparation for a joint mission to recover the remains of United States servicemen whose aircraft crashed in what was then Burma during World War II. The visit will be an exception to an American ban on travel to the United States by high-ranking Myanmar officials. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, IVAN D.
description: GERSON-Ivan D. Dear Ivan, nine long years have passed. You are loved and missed by your family. Rest well. Love, your wife, Liana and your daughter, Tara

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Sept. 12 about the Democratic primary in Florida misstated the name of the university that employs Susan MacManus, a political science professor who discussed ways that the troubled election could help the Democratic Party. It is the University of South Florida, not Southern Florida.

title: The Legality Of Using Force
description: As Congress confronts the prospect of war, it should consider some constitutional fundamentals. The Bush administration would have us believe that international law contains only ambiguous or advisory requirements. In fact, the United Nations Charter was ratified as a treaty by the Senate after World War II, and the Constitution explicitly makes all treaties ''the supreme law of the land.''

title: After Incident, Baseball Seeks to Correct Stadium Security
description: The Kansas City Royals' first-base coach was in the wrong place at the wrong time, but fortunately for him, his team was in the right place -- the first-base dugout.

title: Next, They'll Be Claiming That Their Wine Is Better
description: Gov. Gray Davis might call it a rounding error, but France has regained its ranking as the world's fifth-largest economy, eking out a narrow margin over California.

title: A. L. Turkevich Is Dead at 86; Ascertained Moon's Makeup
description: Anthony L. Turkevich, a scientist who was the first to figure out what the moon is made of -- and who did it before astronauts brought back any samples -- died on Sept. 7 at his home in Lexington, Va. He was 86.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Ad Agency Posts Profit
description: Havas S.A., a French advertising company whose clients include Volkswagen and Intel, said that cost reductions helped it post a first-half profit. Havas, based in Paris, had net income of 15 million euros ($14.8 million), in contrast to a loss of 28 million euros for the period a year earlier. Havas expects little improvement in the ad market in the second half and next year, said Alain de Pouzilhac, its chief executive. To help it weather the worst slump in the industry in a decade, the company has shed 10 percent of its work force. ''The year 2003 will be just as bad as 2002,'' Mr. Pouzilhac said. ''Those who thought I was always too optimistic will be very disappointed. We're living in a confused, hesitant and uncertain world.''

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: 10,000 MORE LAYOFFS AT ALCATEL The phone equipment maker Alcatel said it would increase the number of layoffs at its factories by about 10,000 by the end of next year because of further weakening in demand for its products. Alcatel said it expected second-half revenue to drop about 10 percent below that for the first half. Alcatel and its rivals, including Ericsson of Sweden and Lucent Technologies , have suffered a sharp drop in demand for phone equipment as phone companies slash investment. Alcatel now expects to have about 60,000 employees by the end of next year, compared with 130,000 at the end of 2000. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: An Anxious Debate Over War and Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERN, ISAAC
description: STERN-Isaac. The Carnegie Hall family will never forget our Founder and President, Isaac Stern, for his humanity, his music and his heroic rescue of Carnegie Hall from the wrecker's ball. Countless lives have been touched by his music, energy, passion, and humor, for to be in his presence was to breathe a different atmosphere. He was an inspiration-as a musician, as a leader, as a friend and colleague. Words cannot express how deeply he has been missed over the past year, here on 57th Street and around the world. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Robert Harth, Executive and Artistic Directo

title: On Tape, Convict Insists That Only He Raped Jogger
description: A convicted murderer-rapist insisted in a taped interview that he alone was responsible for beating and raping a jogger in Central Park in 1989, and said that five young men convicted of the crime had nothing to do with the attack.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Bush administration's adoption of a doctrine of pre-emptive action against hostile countries placed a passage in quotation marks erroneously in a description of the 33-page document prepared for Congress. The comment -- that the president has no intention of allowing any foreign power to catch up with the huge lead the United States has opened since the fall of the Soviet Union more than a decade ago -- was the writer's summation of interviews with senior administration officials.

title: FX Channel Hopes to Run Joe Six-Pack For President
description: Ever since television started the reality-show craze, people have jumped off cliffs, been submerged in a container of rats and bungee-jumped off tall buildings.

title: Old Comrades? McCain Sings Pataki's Praises
description: Senator John McCain once referred to the governor as ''Comrade Pataki.'' The governor, in turn, called Mr. McCain ''anti-New York'' and fought to dash his presidential dreams two years ago by keeping his name off the New York ballot.

title: Screening Luggage
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkey to End Its Afghan Stint
description: Turkey will not extend its term as commander of the security force in Afghanistan, the Turkish foreign minister said today in Istanbul. NATO diplomats said, however, that Germany had expressed an interest in possibly taking over a joint command of the force in December.

title: U.S. Embassy in Jakarta Reports a 'Credible Threat' in an Area of Islamic Militancy
description: The American Embassy here said today that it had ''credible threat information'' that Westerners in central Java ''may be targeted for violence in the immediate future.''

title: Top Turkish Candidate Barred From Election
description: The leader of Turkey's most popular political party was barred today from running in the Nov. 3 elections because of his conviction three years ago for reading a poem that a court said incited religious hatred.

title: Following Marino Is Now Easier for Fiedler

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Bombing Suspect Captured
description: One of India's most wanted men, Abu Salem, has been detained in Portugal, Indian officials said. The Indian police believe Mr. Abu Salem was involved in bombings in 1993 in Bombay that killed more than 250 people. The bombings were believed to be retaliation for the killing of Muslims in riots that followed the destruction of a 16th-century mosque in 1992. Amy Waldman (NYT)

description: The Commerce Department announced yesterday that it would give the group that manages the Internet's address system another year to demonstrate it is up to the task, despite widespread dissatisfaction with the way the organization has handled its responsibilities in the four years it has been under government contract.

title: Screaming the Lyrics (and Watching Out for Windmillers)
description: Snapcase is a band from Buffalo that likes to make its audience move. It would be misleading to say that Snapcase makes dance music, but it wouldn't be entirely inaccurate. On Sunday night at Irving Plaza, Snapcase played a vigorous, angular set of hard core, the genre that draws from punk rock and heavy metal. While Daryl Taberski screamed the lyrics, a big space opened on the dance floor, and a few of the group's most charged-up fans showed off their moves.

It was one of her few private moments, a respite during her 12-year quest to bring to justice the military officers she believes masterminded the murder of her sister Myrna.

title: Can't Keep Him Down: Jolson Pops Up Again
description: ''AFTER I die, I'll be forgotten,'' Al Jolson said in one of his many bleak moods more than a half-century ago. Did any performer ever handicap his own future less accurately? Although often denounced since the 1960's for his blackface persona and full-throttle sentimentality, Jolson has inspired four separate stage shows since 1995 alone, each vying to restore his name to a Broadway marquee.

title: Commercial Property; Expanding Law Firms Soaking Up Office Space
description: AT a time when financial services companies, traditionally the mainspring of New York's economy, are laying off workers and putting unneeded space on the sublet market, another sector is showing surprising strength.

title: Sept. 15-21: INTERNATIONAL; NAZI RELEASED
description: Maurice Papon, the highest-ranking French civilian ever to be convicted of Nazi war crimes, walked out of prison after serving only three years of his 10-year sentence, infuriating Jewish groups and the families of the victims.

title: The Height of Ambition
description: Let me get this straight. The civil engineer who came up with a new way to build skyscrapers didn't consider fire prevention because that is usually the province of the architect; the Port Authority is exempt from fire codes; the construction firm that applied an inadequate amount of fire retardant to the beams was Mafia-connected; the Sheetrock in the fire stairs was vulnerable in an explosion; there really was no study of the potential problems an aircraft traveling 600 miles per hour could cause. And the owners of the building reaped $30 million a year in profits, and the federal government bailed them out of liability? God bless America is right. The dreamers, so called, and everyone who cut corners to make a buck should be prosecuted. I don't know when I've been so enraged.

title: In Charity, Where Does a C.E.O. End and a Company Start?
description: TYCO INTERNATIONAL'S lawsuit against its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, is shining a harsh light on yet another area ripe for abuse by imperial chief executives: the murky line between corporate philanthropy and their personal philanthropy.

title: CRIME
description: The title of SHRINK RAP (Putnam, $24.95) is at once a witty reference to the substantive psychological themes in Robert B. Parker's third Sunny Randall novel and a flip disclaimer of any such serious intention. The smart plot has the Boston private eye on a national book tour with a best-selling author who is being stalked by her former husband, an unethical and possibly unhinged psychiatrist. The situation proves ideal for Parker's patented brand of knowing humor, yielding glossy snapshots of dithering book dealers, dollar-driven publishers and awe-struck fans, and one very nice full-length portrait of Melanie Joan Hall, a big-league author so shrewd about her career yet modest about her talent (''I can't write,'' she says, ''but I can think''), you can't begrudge her her diamonds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, HERMAN DANIEL, SR.
description: FARRELL-Herman Daniel, Sr., passed away peacefully on September 18th, 2002 in Pembrook Pines, FL at the age of 92. Mr. Farrell is remembered throughout New York and Kingston, Jamaica, as a respected member of the business community for his work in the dress manufacturing industry and as an owner of Farel of New York, a men's tailoring company in the Jamaican capital. Mr. Farrell served in the U.S. Navy during WWII from 1943 to 1945. He is survived by his loving son, Herman ''Denny'' Farrell, Jr., his daughter-inlaw, Theresa Adele Farrell, his grandchildren, Monique Gladys Farrell-Guidry (Malcolm), Herman Daniel Farrell, III (Nancy), his greatgranddaughters, Simone Adele Guidry and Madeline Jones-Farrell, and his loving companion, Cynthia Phillips. Mr. Farrell was predeceased by his wife. A wake will be held on Monday, September 23rd, 6-9 PM, at Benta Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave., NYC. Funeral services will be private and held on Tuesday, September 24th.

title: Deregulation Blues
description: To the Editor: ''When One Way Costs More,'' by Matthew L. Wald (Practical Traveler, Sept. 1), is another example of airlines' gouging for the bottom line. How dare they ''debit memo'' travel agents when they have just about driven them out of business already? The public wouldn't have to resort to ''back to back'' or ''hidden city'' ticketing or throwaway round trips if there were a rational fare structure or any concept of public service left in the industry. Bring back some regulation!

By the time she had filmed two episodes, the producers of the police drama were so impressed that they asked her to join the series full time.

title: Discounting Teens
description: When I hire local teenagers to do odd jobs, I pay about what they'd earn at a fast-food restaurant. I pay adults doing similar work at least twice as much and add a hefty tip, since they have families and basic living expenses. It's not the money but the message: I don't want the teenagers to think this might provide a lucrative career. Is this pay inequality ethical? Joan Hess, Fayetteville, Ark.

title: A Pox on Our House
description: I'm the tribal chairman of the Cheyenne River Sioux tribe. We're in west-central South Dakota, probably farther away from civilization than any other reservation in the United States. You would think that being out here, we wouldn't be so worried about potential terrorist attacks. I don't think that Al Qaeda is the least bit concerned about Native America. But smallpox is highly contagious. A lot of the tribal council members are jet-setting around the country. One carrier could travel to 10 major cities in the United States in just a couple days' time and spread it God knows where.

Retired to Boca Raton, Florida. Had lifelong interest in and love of New York City, its history and culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ELIOT
description: YOUNG-Eliot, M.D. Of Somers, N.Y., formerly of Milton, MA. On September 19, 2002. He was an attending physician at Brigham and Women's Hospital and the Deaconess Hospital in Boston. Dr. Young is survived by his loving wife of 51 years, Dorothy, his caring sister Eleanor Tankel and three beloved children, Susan Geringer, Dr. Lawrence Young, Beth Goettisheim, and seven loving grandchildren. title: Chow Time
description: From his expansive balcony, Stephen Chow looks out over Hong Kong and retraces each step of his career as fondly as a general recounting a victorious campaign. There, across the harbor in Kowloon, is the government housing project where he grew up. The TVB studios, where he caught his first break, are over there, near the old airport. And down the hill are the two apartments he bought after his breakthrough success a decade ago. Chow's view from the Peak, Hong Kong's toniest district, is of a city conquered, an entertainment industry vanquished and in his thrall. There are no more worlds for this show-biz Alexander to conquer.

title: Sexed Ed
description: I went to junior high during those last awkward years when girls were segregated into home-ec classes and boys into shop. It was the early 70's, and some of us had been reared in the spirit of ''Free to Be You and Me,'' so the whole separatist system already seemed antique and faintly comical. In sewing class, where we concocted unsightly tote bags, I earned a D-plus, but I didn't much care. In cooking class, we learned how to make, for our future husbands, English-muffin pizzas and mock apple pie with Ritz crackers, though I think even we knew that adults didn't serve those particular dishes to one another. A lot of the girls spent the hour passing nasty notes and snarfing hunks of brown sugar straight from the canister. I used to stare at the teacher and wonder where she got the muumuus she always wore to class.

description: Russians got a glimpse of how the other side lives and thinks Thursday evening at the premiere of ''Oligarch,'' a film chronicling the wild early years of Russian capitalism.

title: Sept. 15-21: INTERNATIONAL; VIOLENCE AGAIN
description: Israeli forces shelled Yasir Arafat's offices and demolished buildings in his compound in Ramallah after a suicide bomber on a Tel Aviv bus killed six people and wounded dozens, the second such bombing in two days after a lull of more than a month.

title: At Home With the Past
description: NEW JERSEY has so many historic houses and buildings that a dedicated history lover could spend a month just visiting the places where George Washington slept. Even without Washington connections, the state's most memorable historic structures are more than splendid survivors. The oldest of the buildings described here has served as a backdrop for three busy centuries of history. The youngest is a quiet remnant of the Jazz Age. Each house communicates eloquently about the people who lived in worked within its walls.

title: A Mother's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Time for Subplots as the Pursuit Begins
description: The number is staggering: $700 million. It is not the purchase price of a professional sports franchise or prime Manhattan real estate, or the alleged bonus packages for a posse of recently indicted corporate executives. The reported figure is the collective sum that has been outlaid for the coming pursuit of sailing's oldest and most coveted prize.

title: After Graduation, Lessons in Renting
description: THE F train packed at day's end with 20-something commuters rumbles toward Brooklyn, but passengers look animated, not exhausted, and chat away as though they're off on a college football weekend. They are living out their dreams of making it in New York City even though they cannot afford Manhattan rents and often make the commute twice a day -- once to work, and once to hang out in SoHo or the Village, East or West.

title: N.Y.U., Fearful of Publicity, Cancels Class on Ground Zero
description: A New York University course that was to have focused on the intersection of politics, finance, design and culture in the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan has been canceled because of concerns about the potential political fallout from the course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLTZ, MAX G.
description: SOLTZ-Max G. Died peacefully on September 19, 2002 at age 94. Beloved husband of Christine. Loving father to Ivy, Billy and Mark. Doting grandfather to Nicole, Julia and Carolyn. Adored fatherin - law of Belinda and Yvonne. Cherished uncle of Karin and Robert. Loyal and devoted friend of many. He served his country with honor during World War II. He was a loving and compassionate man whose memory will remain forever in our hearts.

title: Laurie Sorabella, Robert Carroll
description: Laurie Ann Sorabella, a daughter of Janice Hardy Sorabella of Ridgewood, N.J., and Dr. Philip Anthony Sorabella of Mahwah, N.J., is to be married today to Robert Anthony Carroll, a son of Joan Carroll of Spring Lake, N.J., and the late Joseph M. Carroll. The Rev. Elizabeth A. Lerner will officiate at the Unitarian Universalist Church in Annapolis, Md.

title: Germans Vote in a Tight Election in Which Bush, Hitler and Israel Became Key Issues
description: Germans vote Sunday in one of the closest elections of the postwar era with the Social Democrats of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder running only slightly ahead of the conservative alliance led by Edmund Stoiber in a race that is too tight to call.

title: The Costs of Bursting Bubbles
description: A year after terrorism dealt a seemingly lethal blow to America, talk of resilience and economic recovery is in the air. The nation's inflation-adjusted gross domestic product has risen for four consecutive quarters following a mild downturn in the first nine months of 2001. While the estimated 3.2 percent growth rate over the past year is subdued when compared with the more vigorous rebounds of the past, the hope is that it's a down payment on bigger and better things to come.

title: Don't Call Us and We Won't Call You
description: THOSE who want proof that the state's no-call list is working need only consult Anne Kuckro, an architectural historian who lives in Wethersfield. Although Mrs. Kuckro can quickly call to mind the smallest details of an old house, she cannot remember the last time she received a telemarketing call. The reason: She is one of the 767,000 names and almost a half-million phone numbers on the State Department of Consumer Protection's no-call list, which means most telemarketers may not call her.

title: Job Requirements
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Reviving Memories Of Yet Another Evil
description: IN all the talk about the evils of Saddam Hussein, the Balkan wars of the 1990's may seem a distant memory. But their horrors are very much alive for anyone attending the United Nations special war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.

title: Beck Is Back And Feeling Very Blue
description: Beck has been such a smart-aleck for so much of his career that it's hard to take his new album, ''Sea Change'' (Geffen), at face value. After reshuffling any number of styles and perfecting his half-ironic deadpan, Beck has now come up with an entire album of slow songs about heartbreak and desolation, solitude and death. ''These days I barely get by/ I don't even try,'' he intones in the album's first track, ''The Golden Age,'' and he stays glum through a full dozen songs. Beck, who was the paragon of post-modern multiplicity in the 1990's, has never made such a monolithic album. Like a true depressive, ''Sea Change'' barely budges from its woes.

title: Infatuated Investors May Be Missing Dell's Flaws
description: TECHNOLOGY stocks have fallen flat, but Dell Computer's shares still have fizz. They are down only 8.65 percent this year.

title: 'Blessings'
description: In the early hours of June 24 a car pulled into a long macadam drive on Rolling Hills Road in the town of Mount Mason. The driver cut the engine, so that as the car rolled down the drive and into the oval turnaround between the back of the big white claoard house and the garage, it made only a soft swishing sound, like the whisper of summer rain those first few moments after the dirty gray storm clouds open.

title: Kelly Cole, William Dobson
description: Kelly Ann Cole, a daughter of Frances A. Cole of New York and Barry G. Cole of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to William Joel Dobson, the son of Barbara Joyce-Dobson of Spartanburg, S.C. The Rev. Laurel Macaulay Jordan, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Mead Chapel of Middlebury College in Middlebury, Vt.

title: No Callers, Please -- We're Poets
description: It was inevitable that halfway through the movie ''Possession'' the elusive Victorian poetess Christabel LaMotte would strip to her petticoats and be deflowered. Few figures in literary history frustrate the modern sensibility the way the female Victorian poets do, with their maidenly longueurs, coquettish letters deflecting would-be visitors and long hours in darkened rooms that resulted in inexplicably fiery, sexy, sharp-witted verse. How did that get written? The movie and the novel by A. S. Byatt on which it is based posit an illicit affair between the poetess and a married poet, discovery of which makes it possible to root her Gothic fantasies in lived experience. The archives of the poets on whom Byatt modeled LaMotte -- Christina Rossetti, Emily Dickinson and Elizabeth Barrett Browning, with a smattering of Emily Bront -- offer nothing so explanatory. All these writers lived in their parents' homes for most or all of their careers (Elizabeth Barrett married Robert Browning at the age of 40, after she had established her reputation). None had much formal schooling. All were acutely shy and often sick. All refused callers.

title: Istanbul Greets Bloomberg With Apples and Sympathy
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg entered the Topkapi Palace here this morning near the end of his European trip, the first thing he saw was not the gold or jewels of the Ottoman sultans who lived there for nearly 400 years but a traveling exhibit of artwork inspired by the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Don't Beam Us Up Just Yet
description: Fans of futuristic ''Star Trek'' and military technologies could only shiver in anticipation last week when scientists announced a breakthrough in the production of antimatter, the magical material that could supposedly whisk us at warp speed across the galaxy or blow us to smithereens in a cataclysmic explosion. The scientists had clearly made a big leap along the road toward experiments that might help shed light on the characteristics of antimatter. But what a tiny step it was toward the nearly hopeless task of converting antimatter into a useful energy source or weapon.

title: No Brain, No Gain
description: Ideas, like addresses, go in and out of fashion. For example, the Paris department store Bon March was such a hit when it opened its gilt and glass doors in 1852 that mile Zola would ultimately write a savage satire skewering its bourgeois pretensions. Which is remarkable considering that in almost no time at all, the store, having fallen out of favor, aroused nothing more than a big, French yawn. And now? It's the hippest of Left Bank locations, a Gallic Dean & DeLuca and Bergdorf Goodman all rolled into one.

title: Made for Children, Fit for Parents
description: ADULTS today look back on childhood and remember boundaries: walls and rules that kept Slinkys, Legos and Barbies confined to the playroom. Today's children will not be held back. They have steadily annexed room after room in a kind of Manifest Destiny of the house, and now some of the most elegant living rooms are arrayed with random and dubious touches not from Christie's or Conran's but from Toys ''R'' Us.

title: You Bought a PC for His Dorm Room, but Did You Insure It?
description: JUNIOR is finally off to college. You saved for what seemed like a lifetime to get him there, traveled the country with him touring campuses and then stood sobbing as he packed -- but having the satisfaction that at least you were finished.

title: Christine Lai, Craig Elkind
description: Christine Lai, the daughter of Mei and George Lai of Carmel, Ind., was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to Craig Elkind, a son of Paula Elkind and Dr. Arnold Elkind of Highland Beach, Fla. Weston Hicks, who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to solemnize the marriage, officiated at the Old Whaling Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Water Quality Is Still a Concern
description: The League of Women Voters of Connecticut applauds Branford's efforts to clean up their piece of Long Island Sound (''In Branford, a Project That's Beach Friendly,'' Aug. 25). We, too, are very concerned about the water quality in our state, so much so, that in response to the Environmental Protection Agency's mandate that all communities with populations over 10,000 develop storm water management plans, the league is sponsoring two forums on this issue. One is for the public on Nov. 7 at 7:30 p.m. at the University of Connecticut's Stamford campus, and the other on the following day, Nov. 8, is geared to municipal officials and environmental professionals, which requires pre-registration and a fee.

title: Visiting Angkor
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Anticipating Angkor, A Dream Deferred'' (July 21): I had quite the opposite reaction from Phyllis Rose when visiting Angkor Wat after a long wait -- courtesy of an ironic preview.

title: The View From/New Haven; A Physicist at Yale Is Helping Baseball Umpires Make the Call
description: ROBERT K. ADAIR couldn't swing a baseball bat if he wanted to. In 1945 at age 20 during World War II in Germany he was shot in the head and right arm, and spent a year in an army hospital. Other than a terrifying scar, the head wound left no lasting damage, though his shattered arm left this baseball fan forever unable to take a cut at a fastball.

title: Art and Engineering
description: WHEN you ask some of New Jersey's furniture designers what attracted them to their line of work, they will say it was a marriage of two loves -- art and engineering.

description: To the Editor:

The family he so loved includes Joyce W., Ellen, Jeff, Jody, and Eva Karp; Lee and Kevin Chisholm; Dick Esten; Ben, Abby and Dr. David Magnus; Lynn and Dr. Arnold Fenton, Dr. Phil and Charna Weisman. Dan's enthusiasm for life especially embraced the work of Mote Marine Laboratory of Sarasota, FL and the American Society for Technion, 4601 Sheridan Street #

title: A Proposal Timeline for Compliance
description: The United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission (Unmovic) was created through the adoption of Security Council resolution 1284 in December 1999 with the mandate to disarm Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction and to operate a system to monitor Iraqs compliance. Last Monday, Iraq accepted the return of weapons inspectors without conditions. Here is a timeline for the resumption of inspections as proposed on Thursday by Unmovics chairman, Hans Blix.A Proposed Timeline for Compliance

title: The World; A Missile That Would Make Lenin Faint
description: COLD warriors would have gasped in disbelief if they could have foreseen the debut of a new American rocket last month. A giant 19 stories high, the Atlas 5, successor to America's first intercontinental ballistic missile, blasted off from Cape Canaveral, Fla., and roared into space to deploy a satellite. But Yankee smarts had little to do with the fiery success of the rocket's engines. Instead, the brains were Russian.

title: Arafat Remains Defiant Amid Rubble of His Compound
description: Sealed up with at least 200 men in his dust-choked offices while Israeli bulldozers leveled buildings just outside and issued dire warnings over loudspeakers, Yasir Arafat defiantly declared today that he would not capitulate. At the same time, he called on Palestinians to halt attacks inside Israel.

title: Check This
description: Q: This fall, you begin your first match against a computer since you lost to I.B.M.'s Deep Blue in 1997. Will your approach to Deep Junior be different from five years ago?

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Hitchhiking
description: To the Editor: After reading ''Radical Trust on the Road'' (Aug. 18), about Rob Nixon's hitchhiking experiences, a flood of memories returned of risk-free hitchhiking many years ago when I was in college, and later when I was in the Army -- yet I never once used my thumb.

title: Two Murders, One On Screen
description: ''After a sudden, violent loss, you feel a tremendous need to do something,'' the director Brad Silberling said recently, ''not only to keep your sanity but also out of an almost subconscious sense that if you just do everything right, somehow the person you've lost is going to walk back in the door.''

title: The Sunshine Warrior
description: Fort Leavenworth in midsummer is a sultry campus for the Army's new leaders, American and allied majors on the fast track and generals who have just earned their first star. When Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy secretary of defense, steps out of an Air Force Gulfstream into the Kansas heat, it is not just an overdue courtesy call and not just a peace overture to a rankled service. (He has just killed the Army's prized new $11 billion artillery piece, the Crusader.) It is one more engagement in the war over the coming war.

title: Lifestyles Of the Rich And Red-Faced
description: THE gossip columns and the glossy magazines got it all wrong.

title: Getting the Feel of the Outdoors Without Leaving Home
description: TONY and Margaret Casella love to sit on the broad front porch of the East Williston home they have lived in for 27 years. But as soon as it gets dark and they switch the lights on to read, the mosquitoes start to bite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWITZ, MAX
description: ABRAMOWITZ - Max. Be loved husband of Ida. Loving father of Arne (Deborah), Michele Clark (Sam) and Jayne Cohen (Laurence). Cherished grandfather of Hannah, Jeremy, Lauren, Margot, Ellen and Karen. Services were held on Friday, September 13th, 2002.

title: Laura Samberg, Michael Faino
description: Laura Jane Samberg, the daughter of Rebecca and Arthur Samberg of Ossining, N.Y., was married at her parents' house last evening to Michael Scott Faino, a son of Natalie Faino of North Reading, Mass., and John Faino of Mesa, Ariz. Rabbi Joel Braude officiated.

description: Hikaru Nakamura, at 14 America's most prominent grandmaster candidate, won the 32nd running of the Continental Open Tournament held at the Host Hotel at Cedar Lake in Sturbridge, Mass., Aug. 8 to 11.

title: Biggest Hurdle: Uncertainty
description: INVESTORS are getting creamed on Wall Street. Consumers are nervous. New jobs are scarce. Japan, the world's No. 2 economy, is stuck in a deflationary bog and Europe remains lackluster, providing scant hope for exporters.

title: Windows on Autumn
description: Autumn in New York: It begins tomorrow and promises crisp days that are good for dining at a restaurant with a view.

title: Bottling The Smell Of Lips
description: The summer's wave of clean, single-note scents like honeysuckle and tangerine has given way to something more manufactured: lipstick scents. At Barneys New York, Frdric Malle's new Lipstick Rose eau de parfum ($115) carries the familiar rosewater aroma of kisses on collars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, WALTER H.
description: GELLER-Walter H., 78. Of Sarasota, FL. Died Sept. 13, 2002. He was born June 23, 1924 in NYC and moved to Sarasota two years ago from Piscataway, NJ. He was a textile executive and a member of The Fabric Salesman's Guild. He graduated from North Carolina State University. He was an Army Veteran of WWII. He is survived by his beloved wife of 42 years, Veleda; devoted sons Howard, Ira and Steven; adored daughters-in-law Jill and Deirdre; cherished grandchildren Kylie, Brett, Shannen and Joshua; and dearly loved sister Rhoda Lawenda and brother-in-law David Lawenda. He will be fondly remembered and missed for his kindness and devotion to his family and friends. Memorial donations may be made to American Heart Association, POB 21475, St. Petersburg, FL 33742 or American Diabetes Association, POB 2680, North Canton, OH. 44720.

title: QUICK BITE/Carlstadt; Swinging By for a Bite, a Boat Ride or a Putt
description: I've been to the end of the plank twice without any goading from a pirate. For at one end of Paterson Plank Road is an unexpected oasis known as the Waterfront Cafe, Driving Range and Marina. On a lovely Thursday evening, my friend Fiona and I took the New Jersey Meadowlands Commission's fantastic boat tour of the ever-improving Hackensack River. The journey begins and ends at the cafe's marina. Though not far from our Manhattan workplace, we felt as though we were on vacation in a laid-back seaside town. After the boat trip, we dined at the cafe's outdoor Tiki Bar, while a three-piece band played in the parking lot. Our appetizer was Claudia's spicy shrimp ($8.95 for five), coated in a delicious soy-based sauce. For entrees, Fiona enjoyed the Waterfront burger ($5.95 with fries) while I wolfed down the chicken parmigiana ($12.95 with linguine). Topping off a terrific night, we played a round of mini golf ($5 per person) at the cafe's charming 17-hole course. I marveled at Fiona's mastery of the back eight. Nine days later, on a dreary Saturday, I brought my parents to the Waterfront Cafe. We opted for the casual but tasteful dining room. (The second floor is available for catered parties.) Mom went for the chicken marsala ($12.95), Dad selected a daily special, pork chops in an apple raisin sauce ($15.95), and I tried the eight-ounce filet mignon ($16.95). The portions were generous, the food nicely prepared, and all of the entrees came with salad, potat, and vegetables. Meanwhile, my dad mercilessly quizzed a waitress about the olive oil, and Mom was pleased to hear Billy Joel's ''Captain Jack'' on the dining room speakers. Minutes from the madness of Routes 3 and 17, what a pleasure to find a peaceful place equally fine for Fiona or the folks. Jack Silbert

title: Sept. 15-21: INTERNATIONAL; THREATS IGNORED
description: A 1998 Central Intelligence Agency report, revealed by the joint Congressional panel investigating the intelligence failures of Sept. 11, was the first public evidence that there was specific intelligence about terrorist plans to crash airplanes into the World Trade Center. Officials said, though, that those plans did not appear to be connected to the Sept. 11 attack.

title: Piniella Releases His Frustrations
description: After watching his team struggle through a six-week stretch that undermined its season, Lou Piniella was understandably frustrated.

title: 401(k) Investors Want More Advice
description: By an overwhelming margin, people who participate in 401(k) retirement plans want more investment advice from their employers, according to a recent poll.

description: Contemplative and teary-eyed, the crowds start arriving at dawn and maintain their quiet vigils long after nightfall.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Toronto Film Festival misstated the titles of two films that were screened. They are ''Moonlight Mile,'' not ''Miracle Mile,'' and ''Secretary,'' not ''The Secretary.''

title: Investing; For Lovers of Risk, There's Iraqi Government Debt
description: FEW investments are expected to benefit from an attack on Iraq, but one obscure asset may be a winner if Saddam Hussein and his government are toppled. That, at least, is the hope of those who hold Iraqi debt.

title: Americans' Mood Shifts In Semifinal In France
description: James Blake wanted another chance, and he wanted it in a hurry. He wanted another chance to show his captain and his country that he could make right what had gone wrong on Friday, when he lost an uneven, occasionally ill-tempered singles match and put the United States in an 0-2 hole against France in this Davis Cup semifinal.

title: Saints Fans Are Losing the Paper Bags
description: Any discussion about the New Orleans Saints inevitably includes a roll call of lowlights, from years of bumbling play, to running back Ricky Williams's wearing a wedding dress next to a tuxedoed Mike Ditka on the cover of a national magazine. Throw in one playoff victory in 35 years and it is no wonder that Saints fans made wearing paper bags on their heads a staple of Bayou fashion.

title: A Marriage, Untended and Unraveled
description: IN the quiet of summer, while many in Westchester were slipping away on vacation, or watching their lawns turn brown in the drought, or enjoying a brief respite from the heat in the air-conditioning of Metro-North or their cars, or watching their children on the softball diamond, a book arrived on bookstore shelves carrying the disturbing title ''Westchester Burning'' (The Dial Press).

title: Thinking Big
description: After reading Muschamp's article, I felt excitement and elation. He did justice to the architects who are collaborating in an unprecedented manner to create a plan that would be an honor to those who died in the World Trade Center attack and a triumph for those who live in, or simply visit, New York.

description: With the general election less than seven weeks away, the strategies of the main candidates for governor have taken shape, as the Democrats try to close the lead in the polls that the Republican incumbent, George E. Pataki, has forged by reaching across party lines.

title: Lauren Robinson, Victor Blas

title: City Recalls Improperly Labeled Indian Sweets Containing Nuts
description: City health officials have recalled three South Asian-style dessert products that contain nuts, saying they do not come with a warning about their ingredients and could be dangerous to people with food allergies.

description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon has informed the Bush administration that he plans to strike back if Iraq attacks Israel, according to Israeli and Western officials.

title: Thinking Big
description: The first World Trade Center was a monument to misguided builders, bankers and bureaucrats. The second one, as proposed in your magazine, would be a monument to the egos of architects. Look at almost all of those isolated, stand-alone statements; they relate to nothing except themselves.

title: Still Headlining, Saxophonist Recalls Blues-and-Ballads Partner
description: THE tenor saxophonist Houston Person and the vocalist Etta Jones performed together for 35 years, so long that many fans assumed they were a married couple.

title: Young Backup's Late Scoring Pass Lifts Irish to 4-0
description: Until today, Pat Dillingham had never thrown a pass for Notre Dame. His first attempts were awkward, as expected. Upon returning to the bench and speaking to the injured starting quarterback, Carlyle Holiday, Dillingham said: ''Got any hints for me? The pass rush is a lot faster than in practice.''

title: Jennifer Kornreich, Michael Geller
description: Jennifer Ivy Kornreich, a daughter of Andrea and Michael A. Kornreich of Mount Kisco, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Andrew Geller, the son of Judith and Allen H. Geller of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

description: HAUSMAN-Richard. On September 21, 2002. Beloved son of the late Dorothy and Jack Hausman.

description: JEFFREY R. TYLER, lead manager of the $386 million American Century Strategic Allocation: Aggressive fund, is still wary of the faltering stock market, though not as much as he was last spring.

description: COLLINS-J. Foster. Died September 4 in San Diego comforted by his wife, Lee, and three children. Foster was a gentle man, dedicated to his country and world peace. Services: September 23, San Diego and October 20, McLean, VA. Contact family at oceanworkers.com/JFC.
