title: Giants' Offensive Line Is Shoving the Doubts Aside
description: The room where the offensive linemen gather at Giants Stadium is windowless, and the concrete block walls seem to absorb all sound. A dominant voice would be muted. But there is not really a preeminent presence among the Giants' linemen in these meetings, they say; the linemen are all about the same age, from similar backgrounds and with similar sensibilities, all part of the same experiment.

title: Prayers for Healing Cross Cultural Lines
description: OVER a career that has spanned three decades and produced about 50 volumes, the writer and illustrator Jane Breskin Zalben has become best known for her children's books about Jewish holidays, as celebrated by Beni the Bear and Pearl the Lamb.

title: Retirement Not Spoken Here
description: As economic woes pile up, there's a quickening drumbeat of frustration: people have to put off that retirement party, or, worse, hang up the golf bag and drag themselves back to the working world. But for some, the idea of retirement is as alien as endlessly soaring stock prices.

title: Dele and Dabord: The Twisting Trail Of Two Brothers
description: In two separate rows across the length of her dining room table, the mother laid out pictures of her sons. From birth to christening to adolescence and into adulthood, Brian and Kevin -- taking up a row each -- smiled back at Patricia Phillips through more than 30 years.

title: The Bubble Has Burst, But Strengths Remain
description: WAS the economic success of the 1990's largely an illusion? Was it all little more than an elaborate stage set propped up by a speculative bubble in technology, by cheerleaders for the new economy who wildly overestimated the potential for growth and by phony accounting that only temporarily hid huge losses at companies like Enron and WorldCom, which have since gone bankrupt?

title: The Nation: Tips, Please; A Nation of Informers -- or Alert Citizens
description: WHAT should Eunice Stone have done?

title: Campaign Season; Lawmaker's Immigration Views Fall Flat
description: For a while, Representative Tom Tancredo, left, a Colorado Republican, was praised by some constituents for insisting that the Immigration and Naturalization Service deport Jesus Apodaca, 18, an illegal Mexican immigrant who graduated with honors last spring from a suburban Denver high school.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Celebrating Dulcimers

title: From Glass Dreams, A Dazzling Reality
description: YOICHI OHIRA has worked in glass for more than 30 years, first as a glass blower in his native Tokyo, then, since 1973, as a glass designer on the island of Murano in Venice. While not the first Japanese artist to produce glass there, he was the only one to remain and make Venice his home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTHROP, JOHNSTON FILMER
description: NORTHROP-Johnston Filmer. Of Greenwich, CT and Nantucket, MA on September 19, 2002. After graduating from Yale in 1943, he served with distinction in WWII as head of a bomb disposal unit for the USNR in the Pacific. After the war he joined the CIA, serving in the US and Germany. He was then recruited into investment banking, first with JH Whitney, followed by Electric Bond and Share, Merrill Lynch, Security Pacific and Manufacters Hanover Trust, from which he retired in 1986. He is survived by his beloved wife, Lucile Gray Northrop, her two daughters and three grandchildren and, from his marriage to the late Abby Willard Northrop, a daughter Abby Willard Northrop of Washington, DC and a son Johnston Willard Northrop of Bedminster, NJ and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:30 AM on September 25, 2002 at St. Matthew's Church in Beford, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be sent to the Nantucket Conservation Foundation, Inc., PO Box 13, Nantucket, MA 02554.

title: 'Blue Latitudes'
description: When I was thirteen, my parents bought a used sailboat, a ten-foot wooden dory that I christened Wet Dream . For several summers, I tacked around the waters off Cape Cod, imagining myself one of the whalers who plied Nantucket Sound in the nineteenth century. I read Mo-Dick , tied a bandanna around my head, even tried my hand at scrimshaw. This fantasy life offered escape from the fact that I could barely sail-or caulk, or knot anything except a shoelace. One day, bailing frantically with a sawed-off milk jug after gashing the Wet Dream against a rock, I found my whaling dream had become real. I was Ishmael, the Pequod sinking beneath me.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about executives with work experience in several countries misstated the tenure of one such manager, Robert Bishop of Silicon Graphics Inc. He joined the company in 1986 and returned in 1999 from a four-year hiatus to become chairman and chief executive; that was not his starting year.

description: Composer's Daughter at Concert

title: Creative Fare Where Train Whistles Blow
description: IF location is a major factor in deciding the success or failure of a business, Iron Horse Grill could not be more favorably situated. But from its vantage point on Pleasantville's main street, next to a busy Metro-North train station and around the corner from the Jacob Burns Film Center, this restaurant offers more than convenience.

title: A Sledgehammer and Pluck Pay Off After 18 Years
description: THE evolution of 292 East Third Street is a classic real estate story. As Andrew Castrucci says, what oil is to Texas, real estate is to New York. Whether you profit from it might depend on shrewdness. Or it might have more to do with pluck, luck and patience.

title: Breaking Ground

title: The Playa
description: There have been many manifestations of the ultracool black man, from Duke Ellington's sophisticated swing to Miles Davis's icy panther stare, from Richard Roundtree's ghetto stroll to Will Smith's getting jiggy with it. At 31, Damon Dash, the chief executive of Roc-a-Fella Enterprises, is the godfather of a new rebirth of cool. His uniform is as well known in hip-hop as Diana Vreeland's was in fashion. Vreeland, the notorious Vogue editor in chief, always wore a black turtleneck and black slacks. Dash always rocks a baseball cap, seldom wears more than two colors at once, and never steps out in the same sneakers twice. Today, he's in a red-and-white athletic jersey, jeans and red-and-white sneakers, topped by a red-and-white cap. He likes Versace suits for formal occasions, but finds laughable the idea of needing to wear a suit to be taken seriously. ''I'm not trying to sound like a rebel,'' Dash says, ''but I feel that hip-hop is so new there should really be no protocol about my culture. And if there is, it should be my protocol.''

title: Dotillism
description: Nudes, landscapes, water lilies: few of the serial images in THE PRINTS OF ROY LICHTENSTEIN: A Catalogue Raisonn 1948-1997 (Hudson Hills, $125) resemble the comic-book style for which the artist is best known. Lichtenstein also painted still lifes, interiors, flags, mirrors, and portraits of Monet's cathedrals, Warhol's flowers and Picasso's bulls. All his work used dots, stripes and lines -- made to look, he said, as though done by committee. The book illustrates how Lichtenstein's visual tropes evolved. For instance, he made his first ''brushstroke'' print in 1965, in primary yellow outlined in black; he likened it to a stamp. Lichtenstein continued to develop his use of the ''brushstroke'': in his serial seascapes and picture frames of the 1980's, it came to represent form, motion and space in varied colors. Similarly, Lichtenstein's use of Benday dots expanded, to reflect the standardization of beauty and of violence in his work; they also represented mirrors, he said, by which spectators saw themselves. Later, the dots became stars in his American flag, and with the Chinese landscapes of 1996, Lichtenstein transformed dots into water, mountains, clouds and light. Mary Lee Corlett, a research associate at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and Ruth E. Fine, curator of modern prints and drawings there, have done a masterly job. Though Lichtenstein may not have kept assiduous records of how, when and what he printed, art enthusiasts can be grateful Corlett and Fine found out. Elissa Meyers

But when he conjures up a squadron of flying pigs and doesn't have the heart to wipe out the cutest one, Spencer's life as a misfit takes a turn for the sublime. title: Must-See Metaphysics

The 38-year-old creator of ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' grins and gazes up at the Serenity, a pirate vessel of the future. The ship dominates the Hollywood set of Whedon's newest genre-bender, ''Firefly'' -- a show that is part cowboy shoot-'em-up, part space opera, with a sneaky existential streak. At once majestic and junky, the Serenity resembles a blown-up kid's toy, and its interior has been filled with oddball details. A tiny plastic bobble-headed dog sits on the dashboard, and the ship's low-tech engine is reminiscent of an overgrown eggbeater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILMOT, MOLLIE N.
description: WILMOT-Mollie N. A resident of Palm Beach, FL, died peacefully after a long illness on Wednesday, September 18, 2002. Born in Chicago, IL, she was the daughter of Charles and Gladys Oliver Netcher. She graduated from the Foxcroft School and was married to Eddie Bragno, Albert Bostwick and Paul Wilmot. A glamorous figure in Society in New York, Palm Beach and Saratoga Springs, Mollie's philanthropic activities reflected her interests in The NYC Ballet, The National Museum of Racing, The National Museum of Dance and supporting the equine research at The Veterinary College of Cornell University. Her worldwide travels were often in pursuit of her love of art, fashion and horse racing. Mollie loved to entertain her many friends from every walk of life. Mollie's generosity, kindness and sense of humor will be missed by her many friends. She was truly in a class unto herself. The Mass of the Resurrection will be held at 10:30 A.M. on Tuesday, September 24, 2002, at St. Edward's Catholic Church, 144 No. County Road, Palm Beach, FL. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to either: Cornell University for Equine Research, Attn: Ms. Allison Smith, Executive Director, Alumni Affairs & Development, College of Veterinary Medicine, Ithaca, NY 14853, or to: The Peggy Adams Animal Rescue League of the Palm Beaches, 3200 North Military Trail, West Palm Beach, FL 33409. Since Mr. Bush took office, it has often been hard to locate that sentiment in his foreign policy. The latest and most definitive articulation of his views, published on Friday, reflects a good deal more modesty and generosity than earlier expressions, but it also bristles with bald assertions of American power. Mr. Bush's Texas supporters may like it -- he instructed his staff to write it in plain English so ''the boys in Lubbock'' could read it -- but it is sure to make the rest of the world uneasy, including America's closest allies.

title: Renaissance Men

Maybe training as an astronaut doesn't qualify him to be a Renaissance man in the same category as, say, Leonardo da Vinci, but it sure tops a little race-car driving on the side. Lately, it's not enough for a man to master a single job, or even a single field of endeavor. Today's master of the universe is a hyphenate. We have actors who are also writer-directors, singers who are painters, painters who are directors, sports stars who are designers, designers who are talk-show hosts and athletes who are politicians, to mention just a few of the more vivid examples.

title: Outstanding Alien
description: The entrance to Peter Saville's London home is deceptively unadorned. A run-down facade, overgrown with shrubs, masks a dazzling Day-Glo interior that shelter magazines have lined up to photograph. Tall velvet curtains and a baroque mix of modern furniture, Asian objets d'art and fluorescent artwork dominate the open plan. ''It's very neo-Performance,' don't you think?'' says Saville, 47, referring to the psychedelic 1970 film. It's certainly an appropriately eclectic environment in which to interview a pioneer of British style culture who is feted for his reinterpretation of disparate visual codes. But there is one off note: the Enyaesque CD of ocean sounds playing in the background.

Television crews stalked every faintly recognizable face with Animal Planet zeal. From the recently opened furniture store, Danish and European Antiques, to New Design Concepts's carpet and rug showroom, a five-year tenant, to Terra Tile and Marble and Bilotta Home Center, staples of the street since 1994, the storefronts along this under-a-mile stretch of the road that runs between Routes 100 and 9A offer consumers the gamut of services for building, renovating and decorating.

title: Pippa Loengard, Weston Almond
description: Philippa Sara Margery Loengard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard O. Loengard Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to Weston Meredith Finch Almond, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Weston Almond of New York. Canon Petero Sabune, the vicar for community ministry at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Incarnation.

title: Where Is the Ham of Yesteryear?
description: THE GOOD REMAINS

title: Editorial Observer; Justice Rehnquist's Ominous History of Wartime Freedom
description: When America is at war, according to Chief Justice William Rehnquist, people have to get used to having less freedom. There is a limit to what courts will do to help those deprived of rights, he says, because judges have a natural ''reluctance'' to rule ''against the government on an issue of national security during wartime.'' In fact, there is ''some truth,'' he concludes, to the Latin maxim ''inter arma silent leges'' -- in time of war, the law is silent.

title: Sept. 15-21: NATIONAL; PAYING UP
description: Hoping to kill a story that has embarrassed one of the country's best-known businessmen and the company he ran, General Electric said John F. Welch Jr., its retired chief executive, would pay about $2.5 million a year for perks he has received in retirement, including use of a Boeing 737, tickets to sports events and a luxury apartment. David Cay Johnston

title: Sandra Jerez, Patrick Supanc
description: Sandra Irina Jerez and Patrick Moore Supanc were married yesterday by the Rev. Al Rollins, an Episcopal priest, at Meridian House in Washington.

title: Tamme McCauley, Mark Eglington
description: Tamme Simon McCauley and Mark John Eglington were married last evening in Carmel, Ind. The Rev. Dr. Ronald J. Dingle, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Bren and Melvin Simon.

title: Thinking Big
description: Herbert Muschamp, the other creative thinkers who participated in the project and The Times itself have done a tremendous service by positing such a vast -- yet utterly imaginable -- reinterpretation of Lower Manhattan (Sept. 8). Profound thanks to you all.

description: JOANNE KELLAR BOUKNIGHT, an architect from Cos Cob, Conn., who thinks our lives would be far more pleasant if our closets were well organized, once observed a squirrel perform its own version of household storage.

title: G.O.P. Sees Risk of Politics In Investing Of State Funds
description: An effort by Gov. James E. McGreevey to take a bigger role in overseeing New Jersey's investment funds drew accusations today that the $73 billion investment portfolio could become an avenue for patronage.

title: Separated at Birth: Fashion and Prize Fights
description: OF all the people gathered on Ninth Avenue Wednesday night to watch Marc Jacobs's spring 2003 runway show, I'm fairly sure I was the only one thinking about prizefighting. As I scanned the impressive turnout of Hollywood and rap celebrities, along with the most powerful people in the fashion world, the room brimmed with an energy that was oddly libidinal. This tension feels familiar, I thought. It feels like the mood at ringside before a big fight in Las Vegas.

title: Germany's Leader Holds Off Conservative Rivals
description: BERLIN, Monday, Sept. 23 - Chancellor Gerhard Schroder appeared to be clinging to power early this morning after Sunday's German elections, but with a tiny majority and a great debt to his coalition partner, the Greens.

title: Amy Frome, Lawrence Saperstein
description: Amy Gabrielle Frome, a daughter of Patricia Frome and Robert Frome, both of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Lawrence Adam Saperstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Saperstein of Roslyn Harbor, N.Y. Rabbi Lee Friedlander officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Democrat Puts Dream Job Over Party to Quit House
description: Faced with the choice of accepting his dream job under a Republican president or remaining in Congress to try to help the Democrats take back control of the House, Representative Tony P. Hall of Ohio said he never gave a thought to partisan concerns.

title: Elephants
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Around the Water Hole'' (July 28) by Rob Nixon: Anyone planning to visit the Addo Elephant National Park in South Africa should read Lyall Watson's magnificent book ''Elephantoms'' (Norton), on the lore and history of elephants. Much of the story takes place in the territory in and around this national park.

title: Cook's Tour
description: BLUE LATITUDES

title: Glacier Pushes Avalanche of Ice Onto Village; Scores Are Missing
description: A mammoth chunk of ice split from a glacier in the Caucasus Mountains and swept downhill late Friday, leaving perhaps 100 people dead and a 12-mile trail of devastation across roads, rivers and at least one village in southwestern Russia.

title: Where Does Your Garden Grow?
description: IN the 1960's, when residents petitioned the city to plant gardens on vacant lots, they became, in effect, sanctioned squatters. They gardened knowing they might have to one day give up the land to make way for development.

title: Edgemont Coach Reaches Milestone With 100th Victory
description: Brian Connolly won his 100th game as coach at Edgemont High School yesterday when the Panthers defeated previously unbeaten Eastchester, 43-23.

title: The World: The War Wagon; Democrats Play the Loyal Opposition
description: AS President Bush sought Congressional support last week for a resolution authorizing ''all means that he determines to be appropriate, including force'' to confront Iraq, the nation heard little dissent from the Democrats.

title: Families Realign for Sunday 'Guilt' TV
description: GAY FELDMAN, a photographer's representative who lives in Manhattan, is only half kidding when she says she would chain the door to her children's bedroom ''with a shackle'' to keep them from interrupting her Sunday night date with Tony Soprano.

title: A Mother's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Israeli Siege, Arafat Stays Defiant
description: With what remained of his compound under fire from Israeli troops, the Palestinian leader rejected demands to surrender 50 terror suspects, but at the same time urged a halt to attacks on Israeli civilians.

title: Sleepy Hollow and G.M. Agree on Development Deadline
description: The village of Sleepy Hollow has reached a new agreement with General Motors for the development of the company's 97-acre property along the Hudson River. The former automobile plant has been closed since June 1996, and was torn down in 1999.

title: From Headstrong Heroines to Sly Vixens
description: BEFORE recitals in her native Finland, the soprano Karita Mattila has been struck by a remarkable sound: silence.

title: Gazeteer
description: 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath condo at 453 East Putnam Avenue, $485,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVICKAR, H. KANE
description: McVICKAR-H. Kane. On September 9, 2002 after a brief illness. Beloved husband of Jane, loving brother of Malcolm and Harry, and stepfather of David P. Jamison. He graduated from St. Mark's School and Harvard. He served as a Captain in the U.S. Army Signal Corps. in World War II. He then was a securities analyst for several metropolitan firms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, IRVING
description: FRANKEL-Irving. On September 20, 2002, 75, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, lost his three and a half year battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Miriam. Cherished father of Sheryl, Larry and Marc. Father-in-law to Faye and Laurie. Devoted ''Popi'' to Stefani, Steven, Corey and Brian. His brilliant mind, quick wit and generosity of spirit will be sorely missed by all. Services to be held on Monday, September 23, at 12 noon, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made by calling 1-800-IFANGEL.

title: Would You Buy After-Shave From This Man?
description: Mathieu Kassovitz is arranging himself on some wooden crates before the camera at a fashion shoot in Manhattan. He has come directly off the Concorde from Paris, where it is already evening, and his eyelids are heading south. With the photographer Matthias Vriens and his team clustering close, Kassovitz gets down to business. He stares into the lens as if he needs to fix it. Vriens is talking about how some models spring to life at the pop of a flash. You can almost hear him thinking, This isn't one of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, REBECCA KONIGSBERG
description: BERMAN-Rebecca Konigsberg. Teaneck, NJ, August 14. 72 years young. Cherished by daughters Julie, Diane, Irene, late husband Martin. School teacher, union member, artist, peace activist, folk singer, gardener, ''madrina'' to Guatamala. Collector of jokes, owls, friends. Celebrate Becky's life: October 13, 3:30 pm, Central Unitarian Church, 156 Forest Avenue, Paramus.

title: Word for Word/Roots; Portrait of the Arab As a Young Radical
description: LAST fall, Kamel Daoudi, an Algerian-born computer specialist who lived most of his life in France, was arrested in Leicester, England, on suspicion that he was part of a plot by Al Qaeda to blow up the American Embassy in Paris. He is also suspected of directing communications between a cell in France and Al Qaeda. Deported to France and charged with ''associating with criminals connected with a terrorist plot'' and carrying false identity papers, he was sent to a prison south of Paris, where he is awaiting trial.

title: Hillary Eigen, Michael Grippaldi
description: Hillary Dawn Eigen, the daughter of Patricia and Neil Eigen of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Grippaldi, the son of Eunice and Joseph Grippaldi of Parsippany, N.J. Rabbi Renee Feller officiated at the Americas Society in New York.

title: She Wears the Pants
description: Her logo runs on a slant, as if leaning into a fierce wind, while her clothes evoke the Catheresque dream of women pulling up stakes (and skirts) and heading West. Forward, ho!

title: Time to Do Your Homework, Dad
description: To the Editor:

title: On Security Panel, Executives Think the Unthinkable
description: THE Homeland Security Advisory Council, a group of leaders from business, academia and state and local government, was created by executive order in March. Its 21 members have been meeting monthly in Washington to advise the Bush administration on strengthening domestic security.

title: Thinking Big
description: While a few of the projects are revolutionary and beautiful by themselves, collectively this parade of modern structures is similar only to Las Vegas Boulevard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEROSA, MARTHA
description: GEROSA-Martha. NY College of Podiatric Medicine and Foot Clinics of NY Board of Trustees, administration, faculty, staff and students extend our deepest sympathy to our Chairman of the Board Alfred G. Gerosa on the loss of his beloved wife Martha, and to daughters Martha Ann and Nina, son-in-law Patrick, grandchildren Jason, Diana, Jesse and Asia, and Martha's brothers Allen and William. Martha was a great lady who will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Louis L. Levine, President John Brunetti, Vice Chairman Michael Trepal, DPM, Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, J.J.
description: GREENBERG-J.J. On behalf of The Wexner Foundation and the Fellows and Alumni of the Wexner Graduate and Israel Fellowship programs, we mourn the untimely death of JJ Greenberg, son of our dear friends and colleagues, Rabbi Yitz and Blu Greenberg. JJ's passionate commitment to Jewish life and love of Israel have set an extraordinary standard for all leaders. His name will ever inspire us. To the entire Greenberg family, we offer our deepest sympathy and support. Leslie and Abigail Wexner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARADER, MARGARET
description: ARADER-Margaret (nee Byrne). Of Malvern, PA, formerly of Chappaqua, NY, on September 17, 2002. She was loved by all who knew her and will be missed by her five children, two grandchildren and her beloved extended family. A Memorial Mass will be held at 10 AM, on Saturday October 12, at St. John and St. Mary ''Little Church,'' Chappaqua, NY. Contributions may be made to either Country Day School of the Sacred Heart, 480 Bryn Mawr Ave, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010; or St. Ann's Memorial Fund, 502 South Main St, Phoenixville, PA 19460.

title: For Those Who Park Cars on the Street, Sunday Is No Longer a Day of Rest
description: Free parking on Sundays may not be around much longer. This year, the Department of Transportation started charging for parking on Sundays at 3,600 meters on the East Side of Manhattan and an additional thousand on the West Side. Now the city is considering eliminating free Sunday parking in other areas throughout the five boroughs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGIN, RITA
description: ROGIN-Rita. Died on September 18, 2002, in Del Mar, CA. She was born Rita Farrer on Januray 17, 1925, in New Brunswick, NJ, to the late Lena and Herman Farrer. She will be remembered for her dedicated work for Haddassah, Douglass College and National Organization for Women. She was a patron of the arts, an avid reader, a gourmet cook and a talented gardener. She was committed to her extended family. She is survived by three children, Barry, Heidi and Abner Taub, and three grandchildren. Her marriage to Jerome Taub ended in divorce. Funeral services are Sunday, September 22, at 1 PM, at Crabiel Funeral Home, 239 Livingston Avenue, New Brunswick, NJ.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Athens Olympic Work Makes Chaos the Norm
description: WITH two years left before the Olympic Games return to their birthplace, Athens is struggling to prepare for the million visitors expected to descend on it for the 2004 Summer Games. Until then, travelers might want to consider a quick prayer to the city's patron, the goddess Athena, for the patience to deal with the chaos resulting from the preparations.

title: The Nation; 'Suicide Pact'
description: AS most everyone knows by now, the Constitution is not a suicide pact -- to use the phrase of the moment. But where does it come from and what does it mean? The answer is complicated, reflecting the nation's ever-shifting balance between liberty and security.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-22

title: Jackie Raven, 51, Dancer and Promoter of Tap
description: Jackie Raven, a performer and promoter of tap dancing, died on Aug. 19 at her home in Setauket on Long Island. She was 51.

title: Corrections
description: The On the Contrary column on Sept. 1, about an economists' study of worker taxation, misstated the circumstances in the example of low-wage earners who pay high effective tax rates. These workers had been unemployed but found full-time work and have therefore lost Medicaid and other benefits; they had not already been employed full time.

title: Clemens Motivated After Ball Hits Him
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21  Michael Rivera's batted ball bit the ground once and then whacked Yankee pitcher Roger Clemens on the left shin Friday night. It was painful enough for Clemens that Detroit's Robert Fick had belted his first pitch of the inning over the right-field fence to cut the Yankees' lead to 2-1. Now, Clemens had men on first and third with no outs in the bottom of the sixth.

title: Unsettled Jets Face a 'Must Win'
description: There was a time when the Jets approached the Miami game with a smirk, gleefully anticipating signs that the Dolphins were primed to be turned into mental mush again as the Jets continued their inexplicable winning streak.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVITT, STACY
description: LEVITT-Stacy. It's 14 years since we parted in the dentist's office. We'll always miss you, sweetie. Love, Mommy and Michael

title: More Sports, More Risk
description: IN the spring of his fourth grade year, Hunter Berman of Chappaqua was playing baseball, lacrosse, tennis and soccer. Hunter's baseball coach noticed that Hunter, then 9, seemed to be throwing from the side of his arm instead of pitching fully from overhead. At the coach's suggestion, Hunter's parents took him to an orthopedist, who discovered a stress fracture in the growth plate of the child's shoulder. The doctor diagnosed the fracture as an overuse injury.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Think City; Illuminating High-Voltage Commute
description: TO drive an electric car you have to be a bit of an extrovert. I learned this behind the wheel of the Think City, a tiny, odd-looking commuter vehicle that I drove to the train station for two weeks.

title: Letters
description: Our history of the twin towers enthralled readers, who called it part expose, part catharsis. The response to the architects' proposals, here and on our Web site, was exuberantly enthusiastic -- and contentious. Some saw inspiration in their blueprint; others a theme park.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Page 9 of Arts & Leisure today with an article about the musical ''Little Ham'' reverses the identities of two members of the creative team. Richard Engquist, a lyricist, is in the center and Judd Woldin, the composer and a lyricist, at the right.

title: Sept. 15-21: SCIENCE/HEALTH; WEIGHT MATTERS
description: Those tremendous cosmic gravitational sinks known as black holes used to come in two weight classes: small (the mass of a huge star) and super (the heft of billions of stars). Now the Hubble Space Telescope has found evidence for a new middleweight class. John Noble Wilford

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNTHANZ, ADA
description: BRUNTHANZ-Ada. On September 21, 2002, at age 81. Beloved wife of the late Walter Brunthanz. Loving sister of William Vassilious of East Northport, Long Island. Dear aunt of Gregory Vassilious of Acworth, GA, and Maritza Wilde of Oxford, CT. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Services at St. George's Church, 209 E. 16th St, NY, NY 10011, at a time to be announced. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to St. George's Church.

title: Lauren Braun, Sean Costello
description: Lauren Joan Braun, a daughter of Barbara Sayers Braun of New York and Dr. Kenneth Braun of Wichita, Kan., is to be married today to Sean Michael Costello, a son of Theresa and Thomas Costello of Cape May, N.J. Rabbi David M. Posner is to officiate at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: In a Broker's Notes, Trouble for Salomon
description: AS investigators pore over WorldCom, the telecommunications giant that collapsed in July, their work has increasingly become a study of the close and intricate relationship between it and its equally large financial partner, Citigroup.

title: From Farm to Tract To Neighborhood
description: WHEN Marvin and Shirley Cohen put their deposit on Lot 37 in the Woodcrest development in this suburb, which was then called Delaware Township, the builders, Morris and Harold Sarshik, drove a tough deal.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: EDWARD G. ROBINSON plays the archetypal mild-mannered office wimp in Fritz Lang's juicy old-fashioned romantic thriller SCARLET STREET (1945). Robinson is a cashier who's just been honored for his 25 years on the job. He's married to a harridan who criticizes him constantly. His only pleasure is painting on Sunday afternoons, and he's not half-bad. His life turns upside down after he saves a pretty young woman (Joan Bennett, at peak gorgeousness) from what seems to be a mugging. He's soon in love with her, and she used him to the point of tragedy - Sunday at 9 p.m. and Friday at midnight on CUNY; Friday/Early Saturday at 1:10 a.m. on Channel 21.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMOSE, CELIA
description: SAMOSE-Celia. In loving memory of your birthday, September 19. Grandchildren

title: By Land and Sea, In Pursuit of Food
description: Food is the focus of several travel itineraries on land and sea this fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPFOGEL, REGINA
description: RAPFOGEL - Regina. Friends and staff of Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty mourn the passing of Regina Rapfogel, mother of our dear friend and leader, CEO William Rapfogel, and Freda Fried. Beloved wife of the late Hyman Rapfogel; mother-in-law of Judy Rapfogel and Matthew Fried; grandmother of Michael, Chaim and Moshe Rapfogel, and Abraham and Kenneth Fried. She served many great causes with dedication and compassion, most recently at United Jewish Council of the East Side, and will be greatly missed. Joseph C. Shenker, President Merryl H. Tisch, Chairman Rabbi David Cohen, Sr. Exec.

title: . . . And Party Favors for All
description: DR. FREDERIC BRANDT, a Miami dermatologist, was seated at the dinner table serenading his guests. ''I won't grow up,'' piped the doctor in a wavering falsetto.

description: To the Editor:

title: From the Opening Kickoff, Army Is Dismal
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 22  After losing to Division I-AA Holy Cross and being shut out by Rutgers, Army appeared to stand a slim chance of beating Louisville today.

title: Katherine Kaplan, Gregg Degn
description: Katherine Anne Kaplan and Gregg Alan Degn were married yesterday in Cold Spring, N.Y., under the gazebo at the foot of Main Street, alongside the Hudson River. Dennis A. Zenz, a village justice of Nelsonville, N.Y., officiated.

title: Global Warming
description: To the Editor: I read ''Global Warming an Issue for National Parks'' (Sept. 1) on the plane coming home from a tour of the Alaskan glaciers. The highlight of my vacation was a helicopter ride to the spectacular Juneau icefield glaciers. Landing and walking on the glacier and viewing the spectacular scenery was awesome. It was sad to hear the stories of how glaciers in the low elevations have been thinning by several hundred feet in the last 40 years, and of how glaciers have retreated so substantially in just the last 10 years.

title: Mexico Weighs Electricity Against History
description: Mexico, starved for electricity, is reviving plans to dam its biggest river, the Usumacinta. The dam could provide power to millions, but at a cost: the destruction of precious Mayan ruins.

title: Some Don't Believe System Is Broken
description: The article, ''Fixing a System Many Admit Is Broken'' (Aug. 18), gave no consideration to the fact that the growth of primaries has weakened the parties as institutions. This has meant that other political actors such as interest groups have gained in power, which many of us find lamentable. Many of us do not think the party nomination system is ''broken.''

title: Terpsichore, Thalia and Yoko
description: THE LIVES OF THE MUSES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, EDWARD D. (TED)
description: JOHNSON-Edward D. (Ted). Book editor. Of Brattleboro, VT, and previously NYC and Brooklyn. Died Sunday, September 15, 2002, of lung cancer. Survived by his wife Veronica E. Johnson and their son Christopher B. Johnson.

title: Psychotherapy at the Price of Volunteering
description: IN Connecticut, you can barter four hours of volunteer work in a soup kitchen for a private hour of therapy with a psychologist, courtesy of a group known as Volunteers in Psychotherapy or V.I.P.

title: Sports of The Times; The Means to an End, Once in a While
description: FOR a sports club owner, wealth created the means to purchase a franchise, but the means have seldom justified the desired end: a championship.

title: A Door to the Brownstone Next Door
description: Q. I own and occupy a four-story, three-family brownstone in Manhattan. If I were to buy and renovate the adjacent brownstone, would the building code allow me to use a single floor of the adjacent brownstone by installing a door through the party wall? Would it matter if the remaining three floors of the new brownstone were rented to one or more tenants, or sold as co-op apartments? . . . Tracy Butler, Manhattan.

title: No Longer Jobless, but Probably Tan
description: A little more than a year ago, Jens Rasmussen said, he was an executive recruiter who hired accountants. That was before he rashly left his job without lining up another, and spent a month discovering just how tough it was to find work in New York.

title: On Racy Christopher Street, Anxiety Over a Possible BID
description: For 13 years, George Forbes has worked at the Lucille Lortel Theater Foundation, which sits on Christopher Street near a chocolate factory and a store that makes leather whips and chains. Mr. Forbes enjoys the diversity of this famous street, but he also misses the family businesses that have been displaced. Garbage and late-night noise have also grown, he said.

title: Thinking Big
description: Restoring the skyline is a bold stroke, and the right one. All new buildings in Lower Manhattan these past 30 years have been foothills to Yamasaki's minimalist sculpture. The proposed twin towers restrike the balance. And a 2,100-foot broadcast tower could be a spectacular cap and show New York at its finest.

title: No Ill Wind in Hood River
description: ON a sunny afternoon in May, I was strolling through the weekly Saturday Market in Hood River, Ore., when a great gust of wind came swooshing through the parking lot where it is held. The vendors selling produce and crafts seemed well prepared. A few stretched out their hands to secure a precarious item or two, but most of the goods were already properly weighted or tethered.

title: 2 Doctors Cited for Work Developing Artificial Kidney
description: The doctor who developed the artificial kidney despite serious equipment shortages in the Nazi-occupied Netherlands and the doctor who later adapted it to extend the lives of millions are among the five winners of the 2002 Lasker awards for medical research.

description: BASEBALL

description: To the Editor:

title: Dogs to Trains, a Room of Their Own
description: IT'S virtually impossible to walk into Charlie Hirschberg's cellar without uttering at least a restrained ''Wow!''

title: Rangers Working on New Line After Taking a Hard Line
description: The impasse between the Rangers and the unrestricted free-agent forward Martin Rucinsky has grown so wide that Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, said today, ''I don't see any way that he's going to be back.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESTRIN, HARVEY
description: ESTRIN-Harvey. On September 21, 2002, after a sixmonth struggle with complications from surgery. Beloved wife of Trudy Kane; loving father of Glen, Mitchell and Nancy; dear brother of Morton; devoted grandfather of William. One of New York City's most respected studio musicians, he can be heard on countless jingles, recordings and films. In the '50's he played with name bands, including Tommy Dorsey and Sauter-Finegan. He lead a studio orchestra at the 92nd Street Y for many years, playing primarily the music of Sauter-Finegan. Two concertos were written for and recorded by him, one by Harold Farberman and the other by Irwin Bazelon. He appeared as soloist with the New York Philharmonic, performing the Bazelon Concerto. The New York Times called him ''a talented multiinstrumentalist,'' as the Bazelon showcased his versatility on many instruments. Harvey Estrin loved life and enjoyed it to the fullest. Services 11:45 AM, Monday, September 23, at ''The Riverside,'' Amsterdam Ave at 76th St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONEPARTH, SHEPARD
description: BONEPARTH-Shepard. On September 9, at age 82, of West Palm Beach, late of Westchester and New York City. Predeceased by his wife Diane. Loving husband of Roslyn. Also survived by two sons and four grandsons. Graveside services were held September 12th.

title: New York Sports Teams Get a New Practice Facility
description: The Knicks, Rangers and Liberty are all packing up their practice bags and moving. The three teams, which play home games at Madison Square Garden, used to practice at separate locations. The Knicks used facilities at Purchase College, the Rangers were at Rye Playland and the Liberty were nomadic, practicing at a variety of sites. But this week, the Madison Square Garden Training Center opened in Tarrytown. Madison Square Garden and the three teams are a unit of Cablevision. Officials at Madison Square Garden would not disclose the cost of the center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESNER, LOUIS A.
description: WIESNER-Louis A. Passed away September 20, 2002, at the age of 86, in the company of his family. Loving husband of Elizabeth, father to Jonathan, Liz, Meg, and Andrew, grandfather to Britta and Spencer, and father-in-law to Mary Ann and Dave. He will be remembered as a committed humanitarian who worked tirelessly on behalf of refugees around the world for the past 35 years, first as a Career Officer with the Department of State, and then later as a member of the Board and Executive Committee of the International Rescue Committee. A service will be held at Christ Church in North Conway, NH. Donations in his memory can be made to the International Rescue Committee, 122 East 42nd St, NY, NY 10168, www.theirc.org.

title: In the Region/Long Island; 1 Subdivision, 36 Architects With a Modernist Flair
description: ON land surrounded by dense trees and low-bush blueberries in the area of Bridgehampton and Sagaponack that is just north of the South Fork's main road, 36 internationally known architects are designing 36 houses that are being built on speculation.

title: Campaign Season; What to Watch for This Week
description: If Republicans can sink Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's domestic security bill, Mr. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut and a possible presidential contender, would lose a platform on which he has achieved some prominence. Would this damage his political viability?

title: A Mother's Legacy; How Traffic Lights Can Fight Global Warming
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Beats Fordham On a Field Goal
description: In a game of heroics, Columbia acted last. The Lions' Nick Rudd made a 37-yard field goal with 10.5 seconds left to play last night, giving Columbia a 13-11 victory over Fordham in its season opener at Wien Stadium.

title: Like Rock Stars Abroad, Like 'Hmm, Yes' at Home
description: ''I'M no good if I don't swim,'' Moses Pendleton said as he stepped into his house from his sunflower gardens, where on a balmy September day bees danced their jig. ''I'm like Moses going up his mountain. I have to meet Tom each day '' -- Mount Tom, a low-slung ridge that shadows a private lake beneath -- ''and swim in his cool waters. He's my think tank, he's where I go to sort through the day's events, to conjure ideas, to float into oblivion. I do my best work in there.''

title: Melbourne

title: Ranch Dressing
description: Most people who gain entrance to Hollywood's inner beltway make a dash for the fast lane. In the early 80's, when fame found the Dereks -- John and Bo -- they happily drove straight for the ditch. For his part, Derek homme, who died of a heart attack at 71 in 1998, openly disdained the phony glitz of show biz and acted only when he was broke, before stopping altogether in the late 60's to pursue a bohemian life as a photographer and, later, as a rather spotty auteur. Bo -- who careened to stardom as Dudley Moore's cornrowed love interest in ''10'' -- adopted her husband's awkward career trajectory, following up her renown by declining one million-dollar offer after another. Instead, the couple opted for a more rough-hewn life, raising horses on their ranch in the Santa Ynez Valley in California and brushing off party invitations with all the casual detachment of a prize filly shooing away a swarm of flies with its tail.

title: Herzog Goes Hollywood? Yes, but Actually No

He employed tribes of South American Indians as extras, hiring prostitutes to keep them happy on location; he shot scenes involving monkeys that made audiences wince long before there were ''we've been kind to animals'' disclaimers. For a generation of moviegoers, the German director Werner Herzog is the epitome of the fearless, visionary filmmaker. But to American audiences, at least, he has had rather a low profile recently. So it may be mostly loyal fans who will be shocked to learn where Mr. Herzog now lives: Los Angeles.

title: The Big Business of Small Towns
description: The town of Hershey, Pa., no doubt breathed a sugared sigh of relief earlier this month when a county court blocked a proposed sale of Hershey Foods on the grounds that selling the candy maker might cause the community ''irreparable harm.'' Rural Coudersport, Pa., knows this fear well: its largest employer, the giant cable operator Adelphia, declared bankruptcy in June. But that is the ever-present threat confronting the ''one-company town,'' that smaller American town or city whose identity and economic future is so intertwined with the large business headquartered there. (Sometimes, of course, a place outgrows its dependence, if not its ties; Battle Creek, Mich. -- a k a ''Cereal City'' -- will always be a Kellogg town, even if in recent years the Japanese car-part manufacturer Denso has become Battle Creek's largest employer.) title: 'When the Emperor Was Divine'
description: The sign had appeared overnight. On billboards and trees and the backs of the bus-stop benches. It hung in the window of Woolworth`s. It hung the entrance to the YMCA. It was stapled to the door of the municipal court and nailed, at eye level, to every telephone pole along University Avenue. The woman was returning a book to the library when she saw the sign in a post office window. It was a sunny day in Berkeley in the spring of 1942 and she was wearing new glasses and could see everything clearly for the first time in weeks. She no longer had to squint but she squinted out of habit anyway. She read the sign from top to bottom and then, still squinting, she took out a pen and read the sign from top to bottom again. The print was small and dark. Some of it was tiny. She wrote down a few words on the back of a bank receipt, then turned around and went home and began to pack.

title: 'Fourteen'
description: Our family originated in Brooklyn, but the time I came along in 1952 we had moved to Queens, and all I remember of Brooklyn is the one square block surrounding Annunciation, the parish that served as the center to the Lithuanian community in Williamsburg. That block always came to me in reverse. We`d drive in from Queens, two full cars even in my earliest recollections. We three youngest boys shared the back seat in the wagon, which faced out the rear window. That was no picnic. Once you got done making faces at the guy driving behind you and found out he wasn`t amused, you had to just sit there all the way to Brooklyn while he stared you down. Sometimes I worried maybe he`d call Dad and tell him I was being snotty. It`s confusing for a kid, riding backwards and having all the landmarks spring out at you from the corners of your eyes; you couldn`t even read the exit signs on the Brooklyn Queens Expressway. But eventually the Kosciusco Bridge would appear, we boys just called it the Erector Set Bridge, and I knew we were almost there.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

title: After the Hailstorm, the Rescue Mission

Not the weather service, the farmer down the street or the songbirds that are usually attuned to natural disasters predicted that golf ball-size hail would be pelting my garden on a sweltering Sunday in mid-June. It began with brutal winds. Halfway through, the rain changed direction to horizontal, and then hail pelted down bushels of immense and weighty stones for the grand finale. Worst of all, it went on and on. The repercussions pretty much ruined the rest of summer for a lot of gardeners.

title: Left Behind
description: One Saturday morning in November 1994, Ramsey Clark, attorney general under President Johnson and more recently a spokesman for radical Arab causes, met in his Manhattan office with a criminal defense lawyer named Lynne Stewart. Clark wanted Stewart to take on a new client -- Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, a blind Egyptian cleric and the spiritual leader of the worldwide jihad movement, whose most recent address before the Metropolitan Correctional Center was a fourth-floor apartment in Jersey City. The sheik was about to go on trial for directing a conspiracy among his followers to bomb sites around New York City, including bridges, tunnels and the United Nations. His previous attorneys, the left-wing lawyers William Kunstler and Ronald Kuby, had been taken off the case because they represented other defendants who had conflicts of interest with Abdel Rahman. The sheik had dismissed his court-appointed lawyer. A month before trial, Clark told Stewart that only she could do the job.

He continued in NYC at WABCTV and WOR-TV. After retiring, he worked independently at Universal Studios in Orlando and with Corniche Productions in NY. title: Private Sector; He Wants All Those Millionaires To Open Accounts at Chase
description: Count Regis Philbin among the swelling ranks of concerned J. P. Morgan Chase stockholders. Mr. Philbin, the television personality perhaps best known as the host of ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' was on hand last Wednesday to cut the ribbon at the official opening of a new Chase bank branch in Times Square. Mr. Philbin, a customer of the branch, who has had an account at Chase for nearly 20 years, said he had owned the bank's stock for a while and even bought more on Wednesday, the day after the company announced that it would report disappointing earnings in the third quarter. The stock fell 5 percent last Wednesday and is down more than 44 percent this year.

description: In a rat-tat-tat burst of dialectical rhetoric, President George W. Bush came out of a meeting with Congressional leaders to blaze away at the dictator of Iraq: ''For 11 long years, Saddam Hussein has sidestepped, crawfished, wheedled out of any agreement he has made. . . . He is stiffing the world.''

title: Sept. 15-21: SCIENCE/HEALTH; ANTIMATTER ARRIVES
description: Physicists at CERN, the Swiss particle physics laboratory, have created anti-atoms made of matter's opposite, antimatter, raising the prospect of experiments that could test some of basic theories of the nature of the universe.

title: BackTalk; The Long Count Is a Long Memory
description: Seventy-five years later, Budd Schulberg still vividly remembers the emotions that engulfed him in less than half a minute's time while he sat in front of a ''big, fancy'' floor-model radio at his parents' Hollywood home. Schulberg, who wrote the boxing novel ''The Harder They Fall,'' and his father, B. T. Schulberg, a well-known movie executive and avid boxing fan, leapt exultantly from their chairs when Jack Dempsey, trying to regain his heavyweight title from Gene Tunney, knocked down Tunney and, in the opinion of some observers, knocked him senseless in the seventh round.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STERN, ISAAC
description: STERN-Isaac. The Carnegie Hall family will never forget our Founder and President, Isaac Stern, for his humanity, his music and his heroic rescue of Carnegie Hall from the wrecker's ball. Countless lives have been touched by his music, energy, passion, and humor, for to be in his presence was to breathe a different atmosphere. He was an inspiration-as a musician, as a leader, as a friend and colleague. Words cannot express how deeply he has been missed over the past year, here on 57th Street and around the world. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Robert Harth, Executive and Artistic Director

Gastroenterology has irritable bowel syndrome. Rheumatology has fibromyalgia. Neurology has chronic migraine headaches. In my field, cardiology, this disorder is syndrome X.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGER, RONALD
description: ROGER - Ronald. Passed away on Septemeber 20, 2002. He is survived by his beloved and loving wife Bobbie Koppel Roger, his children Robin Roger Goodspeed and son-inlaw Roger Goodspeed, of Larchmont, NY, and Randall Koppel Roger and daughterin-law Kathi Nuckolls Roger, of Boca Raton, FL, and grandchildren Lily, Elizabeth, Sam, Juliana and Brandon. Born, raised and married in Brooklyn, he and Bobbie lived in University Heights, OH, for most of their lives before moving to Chautauqua, NY, and Boca Raton, FL. Ron was a successful sales representative for many childrens' clothing companies, but his life was his family and many friends. His sense of humor, kindness, generosity and intelligence were extraordinary, and his spirit lit the world. He will be fondly remembered and sorely missed.

But the early steps have been calculated not to interfere with the Bush administration's campaign to build diplomatic and political support for taking action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, FAYE DIAMOND
description: BERMAN-Faye Diamond. Born July 25, 1919, in Syracuse, NY. Devoted daughter of the late Kate (Kabaker) and Samuel C. Diamond. Beloved sister of the late Marian Sattinger, sister of Walter Diamond (Dorothy). Graduate of Syracuse University and the Maxwell School of Journalism; earned MA in history from the University of Rochester. She was a high school history teacher for many years in Rochester and taught labor history for the Cornell School of Labor Relations. Lover of human rights, The Constitution, reading, teaching, political discussions, The New York Times, National Public Radio, hardware stores, her typewriter, and letters to the editor. Predeceased by her dearly loved husband Harold Berman and son Richard. Survived by her daughter Ellin, son-in-law Michael Sheffery, beloved grandson Harold Sheffery, family dog Sandy, nieces Lisa Feldman (Sid), Andrea Sattinger, Diane Sattinger and family friend Randy Wilkins, Patricia Berman (Sam Englestadt), Boo Greenberg (David), and nephew Paul Berman (Yvonne), great-nieces and nephews Lindsay, Mark, Jacob, Mathew, Susan, Aly, Mac, Jonathan, Michael, Judy and Joanne. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to either the ACLU or The 12th Floor Nursing Unit, Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021, Attn: Donna Miele, RN.

description: For more than 200 years, from the Methodist settlers who feared the devil to the post-war suburban pioneers who feared falling property values to the just plain fearful parents of the recent past, the people in this town have repeatedly agreed: no liquor.

description: HODGSON-William Sprague. Of Mineola and Cutchogue, NY, on September 21, 2002. Retired Senior Property Representative, Port Authority of NY and NJ, 35 years of service. Alumnus Milton Academy 1939, and Harvard University 1943. U.S. Army Intelligency Officer with the Americal Division, Pacific Theater of Operations, WWII. Beloved husband of Eileen (nee Hunt). Also survived by five daughters, four sons, sixteen grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Visitation Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Ave, Mineola, LI. Funeral Mass Wednesday, Corpus Christi RC Church. Interment Sacred Heart Cemetery.

description: Across Japan these days, by the first or second grade, elementary school students commonly talk out of turn and wrestle with one another in class.

description: Just as the bizarre and contentious history of Roger Clemens, a pitcher for then New York Yankees, Mike Piazza, a catcher for the New York Mets, was beginning to fade from memory, a McDonald's promotion threatens to refresh it.

Norman Schwarzkopf to Rudolph W. Giuliani are publicly announcing they have had it, and millions of men across the nation are being tested, as early as their 40's and 50's, and discovering they have it, too.

title: Improved Techniques Provide Better Results For the Transplanted
description: EXCEPT for the occasional sunburn, male pattern baldness is hardly a health issue, physically speaking; psychologically, though, it's a serious matter. Men joke about being bald, but losing their hair can make them feel diminished and self-conscious, and no wonder. Studies have shown that society sees them as older, less attractive, less likely to succeed and less virile than men with a full head of hair.

description: CODEY-Frank J. III. 60, of Bay Head, NJ, died Friday, September 20, 2002, at his residence. Devoted father of Frank J. Codey IV, Tres Codey Isa and Carey Ann Codey, beloved brother of Lawrence R. Codey, Carol Ann Lott, and Kate Manning and cherished grandfather of three and friend to many. Funeral services Tuesday, September 24, 2002, at 9:30 AM, from the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd, Wall, NJ, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at 10:30 AM, at Sacred Heart RC Church, Bay Head. title: Accounts
description: * Sara Lee Sportswear, Winston-Salem, N.C., a division of the Sara Lee Corporation, to Publicis in Mid America, Dallas, part of the Publicis division of the Publicis Groupe, as the United States agency for the Champion and Just My Size apparel brands. Billings were estimated by Adweek at $20 million. Publicis in Mid America is already a Sara Lee roster agency, handling the account of the Sara Lee Bakery Group. Another Sara Lee roster agency, Temerlin McClain, Irving, Tex., owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, had been the Just My Size agency; Champion's campaigns were created on a project basis.

title: Adieu, My Magazine!
description: Rosie O'Donnell soldiers on, but now without her Rosie: The Magazine. She must have abandoned it with fathomless sorrow, just as I, with great regret, must announce my decision to step away from Tim: The Tim Magazine, effective immediately. The editorial autonomy I had been led to expect has been gradually stripped from me, and I no longer feel that the magazine represents the true Tim experience. (Sharp-eyed readers may have noticed that the current cover story -- ''Tim: What's His Problem?'' -- departed from the largely Tim-positive stories the magazine had run in its first year.) I have no desire to rehash the events that brought us to this pass, but I would like to correct certain misconceptions that have been spread in the press:

title: Some Tyco Board Members Knew Of Pay Packages, Records Show
description: Though the board of Tyco International has said that it was unaware of the extravagant pay packages and loans given to the company's top executives, minutes of the board's compensation committee show that group knew of many of the payments for months before the board took steps to disclose them.

description: James Mitchell, a British author of espionage and suspense novels that were praised in the United States, died Sept. 15 in Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, England. He was 76 and lived in Newcastle.

title: Joan Littlewood, Figure in British Theater, Dies at 87
description: Joan Littlewood, the producer-director-author who was one of the most important and original figures responsible for the regeneration of the British theater during the key decades of the 1950's and 60's, died Friday in London. She was 87.

description: First came Jimmy Bonaventure, a beefy 31-year-old tractor salesman who showed up at the public hospital covered in red spots.

description: VINNY TESTAVERDE was wrong about nearly everything yesterday. He reacted poorly to blitzes, and that led to two interceptions and 10 of Miami's 30 points, and he fumbled once.

title: R.H. Donnelley To Purchase Yellow Pages From Sprint
description: The Sprint Corporation agreed to sell its yellow pages directory business yesterday to R. H. Donnelley -- which published the first yellow pages directory in 1886 -- for $2.23 billion.

title: Approval Is Seen for Military Action Against Iraq
description: Congress will soon pass a resolution giving President Bush power to take military action against Iraq, Republicans and Democrats predicted today, but Democrats called for some refinements.

title: 4 Killed as Palestinians Demonstrate to Back Besieged Arafat
description: Thousands of Palestinians demonstrated across the West Bank and Gaza last night and into the early morning today in support of Yasir Arafat, defying Israel's efforts to leave him powerless in his largely leveled compound. Four Palestinians were shot and killed by Israeli troops trying to enforce curfews ignored by protesters.

title: Bush Goes to N.J. to Press Effort to Unseat Torricelli
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  President Bush went to New Jersey today in one of his most important campaign trips of the election season, attacking the Democratic-controlled Senate and helping to raise money for the Republican who is trying to unseat Senator Robert G. Torricelli and help shift the balance of Senate power back to the Republicans.

title: GERMANY'S LEADER RETAINS HIS POWER AFTER TIGHT VOTE
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder clung to power early this morning after parliamentary elections on Sunday, but with a tiny majority and a great debt to his coalition partner, the Greens.

title: Indian Point 2 To Test Safety Amid Criticism
description: Inside a converted warehouse here, a dozen emergency workers were tracking multiple equipment failures at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant a few days ago.

title: Dayne Makes Holes And Quiets Critics
description: Ron Dayne is playing for the Giants in an age when critics -- and everyone seems to be a critic -- often treat an athlete as a hero today and a bum tomorrow.

title: Pataki and McCain Unite (Teddy Would Have Smiled)
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator John McCain of Arizona, political enemies two years ago, stood on Theodore Roosevelt's porch today for a show of Republican Party unity, while H. Carl McCall sought to shore up black support with visits to churches and a parade in Harlem.

title: Rafael Druian, 80, Violinist and Conductor
description: Rafael Druian, a violinist and conductor who served as the concertmaster for the New York Philharmonic, the Cleveland Orchestra and other ensembles, died on Sept. 6 in Philadelphia. He was 80 and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Executive Resigns At Golin/Harris
description: A top executive of the Golin/Harris International public relations agency, Richard J. Wolff, is unexpectedly resigning, effectively next Monday.

title: A Band Ignores Geography
description: New Orleans and Lagos both seemed equally close to Benin when the Gangbe Brass Band made its euphoric New York debut at Joe's Pub on Wednesday night. The band has the world in its grasp; its music leaps among the many ethnic traditions of its home, Benin, and beyond to Africa and the New World's African diaspora, seguing from traditional voodoo rhythms to jazz without missing a syncopated beat.

title: Virginia Tech and Miami Boost the Big East
description: Shortly after his team out-sumo-wrestled Texas A&M on the inhospitable grounds of the Aggies' Kyle Field on Saturday, Virginia Tech Coach Frank Beamer proclaimed that the Hokies' charter was ''going to rock on the way home.''

title: It's Lights Out on Leiter Again
description: In a season in which so much has gone wrong for the Mets, it seems a little much to pick apart the fact that Al Leiter drew the starting assignment for an afternoon game. At night, Leiter is nearly unhittable, compiling a major league-best 1.94 earned run average. But in the daytime, as evidenced by yesterday's performance, a strange transformation takes place.

title: Self-Doubts At the Helm Of the Czech Republic
description: The symposium was titled ''The Playwright as President.'' But the centerpiece was not a play but a speech, a 1,600-word meditation of self-deprecation and self-doubt read in a sandpapery voice by Vaclav Havel, the playwright turned president of the Czech Republic.

title: The Show Must Go On, Without Bizzy Bone
description: How many people are in Bone Thugs-n-Harmony? On Tuesday night the answer depended on what time it was. At 11:30, when the group took the stage at the B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, there were four members. Forty-five minutes later the quartet had been reduced to a trio, permanently it seemed.

title: Guys Are Warming Up To Yoga and Pilates
description: AS a boy, Gilead Kreiter liked to stand on his head. So when his wife started taking yoga four years ago, he said, ''Maybe I should try that.'' Though he exercised regularly -- playing basketball and swimming -- he did not feel limber. ''My back was so stiff I couldn't sleep on my stomach anymore,'' said Mr. Kreiter, 48, a trader for a hedge fund on Wall Street.

title: Richmond Journal; Quilt Helps Patch Lives Torn by Abuse
description: Battered women in Virginia's 68 shelters designed to hold off abusive spouses and boyfriends are resorting to an old homespun outlet for their fears and frustrations. At night in their sanctuaries they are concocting a giant quilt filled with confessional messages of depression and resistance in the common hope for a safer existence.

title: You Bought a PC for His Dorm Room, but Did You Insure It?
description: Junior is finally off to college. You saved for what seemed like a lifetime to get him there, traveled the country with him touring campuses and then stood sobbing as he packed  but having the satisfaction that at least you were finished.

description: SON OF THE SOUTH

title: Off Sicily, Tide of Bodies Roils The Debate Over Immigrants
description: The 15 dead bodies found in the hours immediately following the shipwreck were only the beginning.

title: Is Home Depot a Fixer-Upper?
description: Low mortgage rates have fueled a housing boom, but that has not done much to help the shares of Home Depot , the nation's largest home-improvement chain.

title: Playing With Lindros and Bure, Nedved Finds His Place
description: After producing a goal and two assists last night in the Rangers' 6-4 preseason victory over Philadelphia at Madison Square Garden, Petr Nedved was asked, only slightly tongue in cheek, if he was going to phone his friend Martin Rucinsky to say that he need not bother signing with the Rangers as an unrestricted free agent after all.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Firefighter Accused Of Child Sex Abuse
description: An off-duty city firefighter was charged yesterday with sexually assaulting a 6-year-old girl while he was a guest at a party at her Bayside home, the police said. The firefighter, Kenneth Dorsey, 41, of Elmont, Nassau County, was arrested Saturday night and charged yesterday morning with sodomy and endangering the welfare of a child, said Detective Robert Price, a police spokesman. The girl's parents called the police, Detective Price said, after she told them that she had been assaulted after she walked into an unlocked bathroom that Firefighter Dorsey was using. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Eagles' Offense Has A Free and Easy Time
description: Since Dallas had beaten Tennessee, and a more talented Philadelphia team had lost to Tennessee, it figured that when the Cowboys met the Eagles today at Veterans Stadium, peculiar things could happen. Indeed, after the first quarter, the unexpected reigned.

title: Patents; The patents commissioner seeks to reinvent a notoriously backlogged office and process.
description: IN their appropriations committee reports for 2002, both the House and the Senate made it clear they were not happy with the Patent and Trademark Office. It was not the first time, and the patent office's customers have not been happy with the agency for a while, either.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Past Problem With Escalator
description: The Sears store where a developmentally disabled boy died after falling three stories from the top of an escalator was issued a citation for a major code violation in October 2001 in connection with the same escalator, according to records of the Department of Buildings. But it was unclear yesterday whether there was any connection to the death of the boy, Malcolm Lawrence, 9, of Crown Heights. The city issued the citation to Sears for serious safety problems with the escalator at its King Plaza store. The citation followed a September 2001 accident on the escalator. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Plannned Schedule Of Bond Offerings
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today and a four-week bill to be auctioned tomorrow.

title: The Findings Against Enron
description: With its preliminary findings that Enron violated public disclosure rules in its dealings with banks, a bankruptcy examiner's report highlights numerous avenues for criminal investigators seeking to bring a case that the company's deluge of deals with off-the-books partnerships involved potential fraud.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the appointment of Robert Egger as interim head of the United Way of the National Capital Area misstated a word in a quotation from him about the need for accountability to contributors. He said, ''I know the average giver to this organization is someone who makes 40 or 45 grand a year'' -- not a week.

title: Lights, Camera, Action -- Cut!
description: Jim Bosche awoke at 3:30 a.m. in his fourth-floor downtown loft one day last spring to find a white-hot light flooding through his bedroom blinds, the kind of intense beam seen in depictions of alien abduction.

title: Democratic Insurgents Criticize Party
description: To hear officials of the Brooklyn Democratic organization tell it, Primary Day turned out none too shabbily. They point to the resounding victory of the party's leader, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., and they point to the ease with which some party-backed incumbents glided to victory, despite challenges from well-organized insurgents.

title: Wells Has Issues, but Winning Isn't One of Them
description: All the side issues have made September a complicated month for David Wells, the big Yankees pitcher with the big victory total. He missed one start because of stomach flu. He came to work one day last week with a slightly scratched eye caused by dust. Earlier in the month, his face was bruised and he lost two teeth in an early-morning altercation in a Manhattan diner.

title: Decision Time on the Everglades
description: Two years have passed since Congress approved a $7.8 billion measure to restore the Florida Everglades. The bill commanded overwhelming bipartisan support and provided the framework for what could be the most ambitious environmental restoration project in history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUTHANZ, ADA
description: BRUTHANZ-Ada. On September 21, 2002, at age 81. Beloved wife of the late Walter Bruthanz. Loving sister of William Vassilious of East Northport, Long Island. Dear aunt of Gregory Vassilious of Acworth, GA, and Maritza Wilde of Oxford, CT. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street today, Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Services at St. George's Episcopal Church, 209 East 16 Street, NY, NY 10011, Tuesday, 2 PM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to St. George's Church.

title: Greasepaint on the Pillow: Becoming a Mime in Dreamland
description: When John Kelly falls asleep, there are no guarantees that he'll wake up as the same person. In his still undercooked new performance piece, ''The Paradise Project,'' which runs at the Kitchen through Wednesday, Mr. Kelly enchantingly demonstrates the dangers of going to bed if you happen to be an exceptionally flexible fellow with a habit of morphing into exotic alter egos.

title: Takeover of Bcom3 Is Cleared by Holders
description: As expected, shareholders of the Bcom3 Group in Chicago voted overwhelmingly on Friday to approve a $3 billion deal by which Bcom3 will be acquired by the Publicis Groupe in Paris.

title: Police and Fire Radios
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring Dancers of the Avant-Garde
description: The emphasis was on the international and eclectic at the 18th Annual New York Dance and Performance Awards ceremony on Friday night at the Joyce Theater. Known familiarly as the Bessies, the awards are the dance equivalent of Oscars and Tonys, honoring artists in predominantly avant-garde or downtown dance and performance art for exceptional achievement during the past year.

title: Forrester's Commercial Focuses on Torricelli's Ethics
description: This advertisement, titled ''Black and White,'' is the first commercial that Douglas R. Forrester, New Jersey's Republican nominee for United States Senate, has released that focuses solely on the ethical problems of the Democratic incumbent, Senator Robert G. Torricelli. It was first broadcast on Thursday on television stations in New York and Philadelphia and is scheduled to run through today.

title: A Modern Musician Plays the Host While Playing the Piano
description: The young pianist Vijay Iyer isn't known for making superfriendly tonal harmony and swing rhythm; in his own quartet as well as in his cooperative trio, Fieldwork, there is plenty to hang on to in the way of rhythms and compositional structure, but the music isn't especially cozy. Still, during his solo piano set on Thursday night at the Jazz Standard -- part of a five-day series within the Verizon Music Festival, which is presenting a fine array of solo jazz pianists -- he played short pieces, paused to introduce new songs, welcomed the audience a few times and played host.

title: After the Fall, a Reinvented Janus
description: When Mark Whiston publicly accepted the job as chief executive of the new Janus Capital Management on Sept. 3, he turned his attention quickly to the firm's future, not its past. He talked about offering a full family of funds under "one globally recognized brand." He spoke of "best-of-breed-type offerings" and "balancing the constraints of manufacturing with the needs of distribution."

title: Minefields Abound in Attempts to Reduce Debts

She was the beloved wife of the late Julius Eisenberg and the late J. Alex Margolis and the sister of the late Esther Golding Korman and the late Rube Golding. She is survived by her devoted son Arthur Joel Eisenberg; grandchildren Jesse, Jason, Julie and Ian Eisenberg, Yvette Eisenberg Melendez, grandchildren-in-law Linda Kadowaki Eisenberg and Marcos Melendez; and greatgrandchildren Michaela and Max Melendez and J. Katsuki Eisenberg; School teacher of PS 89 in the Bronx for 37 years; Village Clerk of Port Chester. Services will be held on Monday, September 23, 11 AM, at KTI Congregation in Port Chester, NY. No flowers, donations to Hadassah or KTI.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lower Manhattan Business Aid
description: State officials have announced a $10 million program to help small Lower Manhattan businesses pay to train employees. The program provides up to half of the companies' costs, with a maximum of $125,000 per business and $4,000 per employee. Businesses from 14th Street to the Battery with fewer than 500 workers are eligible, according to the Empire State Development Corporation, which is administering the program. Requirements and other information are available at (800) 456-8369 and at www.nylovessmallbiz.com. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Giants Finally Get Their Wind in a Game That's Hardly a Breeze
description: An eastward wind pushed at Kerry Collins's back during today's pregame coin toss, which Seattle won. The Giants had the choice of direction, and Collins jabbed a finger toward the east end zone in Giants Stadium. ''We'll stay this way,'' Collins said in a moment that would have been completely forgettable except that, some two and a half hours later, Giants place-kicker Matt Bryant felt the same wind pushing him in the back as he faced the goal posts, 47 yards distant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTO, SARA SCHEIN
description: LITTO-Sara Schein. Passed away at home on September 18, 2002. Adored, respected mother and best friend of Marilyn Sue Goodman. Cherished and devoted daughter of the late Louis and Mary Schein. Treasured sister of the late Samuel Bud Schein, Bernard Schein and Selwyn Schein. Caring sister-in-law of Ruth Schein. Loving aunt of Robert (Isabel), Ilyse and Jessica Schein and the late Eric Schein. Loving almost-sister of Annette Taitt, beloved friend, respected colleague, retired New York City School teacher. Her character, compassion and courage will guide us always. Sorely, sorely missed, she will live forever in our hearts.

Bloomberg's visit to Athens misidentified the ancient games that were played at the site of the Panathenian Stadium, where he discussed New York City's bid for the 2012 Olympics. They were the Panathenian Games, not the ancient Olympics. A caption also misstated the age of the arena on the site. Although the original structure was built around 330 B.C., the marble one was built for the first modern Olympics, in 1896.

Terms were not disclosed. Ads created by CRK Advertising, New York, the Klein in-house agency, will appear in editions of Maxim published in countries including Britain, France, Russia and the United States.

description: Under pressure from weak economic and profits news, declining markets abroad and worries about a war with Iraq, the Nasdaq composite index dropped to a six-year low today while the two other major stock indexes fell to their lowest levels since the overall market hit a five-year low in July.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot and Killed
description: An 18-year-old man was shot and killed early yesterday in Midwood, the police said. The man, whose name was not immediately released, was shot just before 4 a.m. on Ocean Parkway between Avenues J and K. The man was taken to Community Hospital of Brooklyn, where he died about 20 minutes later, officials said. The police said that no further details were available and that there were no suspects in the case. Jayson Blair (NYT)
