description: To the Editor:

title: It's Not Over For One Diva, Who Is Back At the Met
description: In bygone days, great divas embarked on lengthy cycles of farewell performances. Dame Nellie Melba's farewell extended over seven years. Even more extreme was Adelina Patti, who began her first farewell tour in 1887, continued making appearances until 1906 and occasionally popped out of retirement even after that for one more goodbye.

title: Readers and Writers Debate Columnist's Exit
description: The sudden, crashing end of Bob Greene's 24-year career as a columnist for The Chicago Tribune reverberated throughout his city and profession last week. As the few details of his 1988 sexual encounter with the 17-year-old subject of one column trickled out, readers and journalists argued over Mr. Greene's downfall with the passion usually reserved for sports or politics.

title: Copyright Hurdles Confront Selling of Music on the Internet
description: When the world's major media companies gave in to the idea of selling music over the Internet, it seemed to herald a sonic paradise, where every song ever recorded would be available to listen to and perhaps download, legally, with a few clicks and a small monthly fee.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: PAST PROBLEM WITH ESCALATOR The Sears store where a developmentally disabled boy died after falling three stories from the top of an escalator was issued a citation for a major code violation in October 2001 in connection with the same escalator, according to records of the Department of Buildings. But it was unclear yesterday whether there was any connection to the death of the boy, Malcolm Lawrence, 9, of Crown Heights. The city issued the citation to Sears for serious safety problems with the escalator at its King Plaza store. The citation followed a September 2001 accident on the escalator.   Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Mets' Image as Bad As Their Record Is

title: Report Finds Minority Ranks Rise Sharply on Campuses
description: The number of minority students attending American colleges and universities jumped 48 percent in the 1990's, with all minorities posting double-digit gains in college enrollment, according to a study by the American Council on Education.

title: 2 Suspected of Al Qaeda Links Are Arrested in a Karachi Raid
description: At least two Algerian men were arrested in joint raids by American and Pakistani officials in this port city on Saturday, Pakistani intelligence officials said today. One Pakistani official said eight other Algerians were captured in a subsequent raid in the city, but his account could not be confirmed.

title: Competitors to Viagra Get Ready to Rumble
description: IN the four years since Bob Dole proclaimed the restorative wonders of Viagra, millions of men have filled millions of prescriptions to the delight, presumably, of millions of sexual partners. Now the drumbeat has begun for two similar medications that, if approved next year as expected, could offer new competition to one of the most famous pharmaceutical brands.

title: Jets' Running Game Is Going Nowhere
description: Curtis Martin had blood on the front of his uniform when he ducked into a tunnel beneath Pro Player Stadium today, finally free of the humidity and heckling and the other symbols of a Sunday gone wrong for the Jets. The plan had been for him to run left, right and through the Miami Dolphins, but Martin mostly found angry arms and hands wrestling him to the ground during the Jets' 30-3 loss to the Dolphins, ending the Jets' eight-game winning streak against them.

title: 5 Altering Years for a Police Department
description: More than five years have passed since Abner Louima became a household name in New York City, a chilling symbol of what could go wrong in a Police Department praised for making the city a safer, cleaner place.

title: At Airport In Boston, A Closer Look At ID Papers
description: Logan International Airport in Boston will announce on Monday that it is installing scanners that can check the authenticity of hundreds of kinds of driver's licenses and passports, check the bearer's name against government ''watch lists,'' and generate lists, with photos, of whose document was checked and when.

title: Congress's Unfinished Business
description: Consumed by a possible war with Iraq, Congress is ignoring several urgent domestic priorities. The federal budget is slipping further into the red, but there is no agreement on what to do about it. Indeed, Republicans are sharply divided among themselves on spending. The latest Florida election debacle has failed to dislodge the House and Senate from their impasse on ballot reform. The homeland security measure remains mired in a dispute over the rights of workers in the new department. And the chances of passing legislation on energy, bankruptcy and a patients' bill of rights are slipping away each day.

title: Takeover of Bcom3 Is Cleared by Holders
description: As expected, shareholders of the Bcom3 Group in Chicago voted overwhelmingly on Friday to approve a $3 billion deal by which Bcom3 will be acquired by the Publicis Groupe in Paris.

title: Jack Potter, 74, Illustrator Who Turned to Teaching, Dies
description: Jack Potter, an innovative illustrator of the 1950's who suddenly dropped out of the field and achieved his widest influence as a teacher of drawing and conceptual thinking at the School of Visual Arts, died at his home in New York on Sept. 14. He was 74.

title: Metro Matters; Court System As a Mirror Of Public View
description: PERHAPS the most outstanding characteristic of the American system of justice is its flexibility. It keeps finding ways to reflect the public mood -- often helped along by pragmatism.

title: Tentative Pact Reached in Boeing Strike
description: The Boeing Company and 1,400 workers represented by the United Automobile Workers at the company's helicopter plant near Philadelphia have reached a tentative contract agreement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Teenager Injured In Shooting
description: A 15-year-old girl was in stable condition after being shot in the chest yesterday morning in Mount Eden, the police said. The girl, whose name was not immediately released, was shot just after 1:30 a.m. near the corner of East 174th Street and Grand Avenue. Two men who were believed to be involved fled soon after shots were fired, the police said. The girl was taken to Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: A Chance to Sleep Through the Night
description: AS surely as middle age brings on a receding hairline and, all too often, a growing waistline, it also brings, for most men, an embarrassing problem. Its medical name is B.P.H., for benign prostatic hypertrophy, or hyperplasia and, as its name implies, it is an enlargement of the prostate that is not caused by cancer. It shows up as a problem with urinating.

title: Corrections

He is William M. Cromwell.

title: The Problem Gets Fixed, So What's the Problem?
description: AS a child, my husband had strabismus, a misalignment of the eyes that guaranteed him a one-way ticket to hell every day at recess. Nicknamed Clarence after the 1965 movie, ''Clarence, the Cross-Eyed Lion,'' continuously teased and taunted in junior high school, he grew up feeling self-conscious but powerless, unable to look people straight in the eye.

title: The Eye of the Reporter, The Heart of the Novelist
description: There's always a notebook in my purse. I learned my lesson one day many years ago when I found myself at the scene of a crime, taking notes on the back of checking account deposit slips. Before I was a novelist, I was a columnist; and before I was a columnist, I was a reporter; and the reporter is always there, jumbled amid the Altoids, the keys and the lipstick, there forever in the notebook.

title: High-Altitude Rambos
description: Dr. Bob Rajcoomar, a U.S. citizen and former military physician from Lake Worth, Fla., found himself handcuffed and taken into custody last month in one of the many episodes of hysteria to erupt on board airliners in the U.S. since the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Op-Art
The Rural Life; Ready for Fall
description: I promised myself this year that I'd cut the thistles before they went to seed. But I notice that thistledown is in the air and lying in clumps at the base of the plants and that the bumblebees are working urgently on the thistle heads that still remain purple. For a few nights last week the sky caught a late glow well after the sun fell behind the birch trees on the hill west of here. The light seemed to lift the stray, abbreviated bands of clouds apart from the soft opacity of the blue behind them, a blue that memory alone can't do justice to. I go outside at night now just to admire how steep the temperature gradient has become, how the mercury seems to roll off the table once dark comes.

title: A conversation with an insider: 'We bred a tough bunch of entrepreneurs'
description: Candace Johnson is president of Europe Online SA, a satellite broadband Internet service provider based in Luxembourg. A serial entrepreneur, Johnson moved to Europe from the United States 20 years ago. Having written her first business plan as a child (for a lemonade stand), she went on to become co-founder of the Astra satellite system and founder of Loral CyberStar-Teleport Europe, the first independent European satellite network. She also is a founding shareholder in London-based Ariadne Capital and a director of early stage investor Sophia Euro Lab, based in Sophia Antipolis, France. She was interviewed by Tim Phillips for the International Herald Tribune.

title: Mayor of New York Drops By For a Visit With the U.S. Troops

title: Again, Bavaria's Favorite Is Germany's Runner-Up

Many married couples take part.

title: Nuclear Dangers Beyond Iraq
description: President Bush wisely warns of the danger posed by a nuclear-armed Iraq, but he remains unevenly engaged in other efforts that would stem the spread of nuclear weapons. Saddam Hussein's nuclear potential has been repeatedly cited by the administration as the one unassailable reason why the American people should support an invasion of Iraq. Yet ours is a dangerous stance: If we remove the threat of Saddam Hussein while leaving the rest of our nonproliferation policy unchanged, we will achieve only a marginal improvement in our security against nuclear terror. To make an invasion of Iraq worthwhile, a new investment in nuclear security is urgently needed.

title: A Regular Romantic Path Examined at Close Range
description: ''Peter and Vandy,'' a new two-hander by Jay DiPietro, has a ''smartest kid in the class'' quality about it. You'd give it good grades in a drama school seminar for the unflashy but effective dialogue and for the acting of Mr. DiPietro and Monique Vukovic, who portray the title couple over several years in the life of a strained love affair. The defensiveness and unease the two actors find in the characters is credible and well wrought.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: LEADER SAYS INDIA LIES ABOUT KASHMIR On the eve of the second stage of voting in closely watched state assembly elections in Indian-held Kashmir, President Pervez Musharraf dismissed Indian assertions of a high turnout in the first stage as lies. General Musharraf said that at most 10 percent of voters cast ballots in the first round on Sept. 16; India says 47.5 percent voted. The nuclear-armed countries both lay claim to Kashmir and nearly went to war this year over Pakistan's support for anti-Indian militants. India has accused Pakistan of trying to disrupt the elections.

title: Annan Proposes Fewer Reports And Less Talk for a Better U.N.
description: After years of major cost cuts and staff reductions to streamline the United Nations bureaucracy, Secretary General Kofi Annan today proposed a program of more modest changes to make it ''a more effective instrument.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: West Point: Body Found At Academy
description: A military police officer missing for more than two months was found dead last weekend in a wooded area at the United States Military Academy. Forensics reports indicated that the officer, Sgt. Alan Two Crow, 27, of the Cheyenne River Sioux reservation in Eagle Butte, S.D., probably broke his neck in an accidental fall. His body was found by several civilians who were looking for Sergeant Two Crow after his family complained that West Point was not doing enough to find the sergeant, who was on a four-day leave when he disappeared in July. Lt. Col. James Whaley, a West Point spokesman, responded that officials were concerned and conducted an intensive search for the missing man that included use of helicopters, platoons and search dogs. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Reporter's Notebook: G.O.P. Preparing for a Domestic Focus
description: Over the weekend, a senior White House official sent over findings of a Pew Research Center poll that suggested that the public trusts Republicans more than Democrats to deal with corporate corruption. "The domestic agenda?" the official wrote. "We say, 'bring it on.'"

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERBSTMAN, MANDEL
description: HERBSTMAN - Mandel. Grand wit, humor, intelligence, never forgotten. Love, Vera

title: Moscow Journal; Waiter, Forget the Boar. I'd Rather Have Oxygen.
description: After a decade of gorging on French food, fast cars and giant profits, Russia's rich are slowing down to smell the flowers -- and the oxygen.

title: Georgia Tech Loses Hollings for Season
description: Georgia Tech's Tony Hollings, the junior tailback who was leading the nation in rushing, is out for the season with a torn ligament in his right knee.

title: Bush Lowers the Terror Alert to `Yellow'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  President Bush lowered the nationwide terror alert today, in part because of the recent arrests of suspected terrorists near Buffalo, the White House said.

title: World of the Dying Patient
description: Death and the journey toward it that is the dying have forever held fascination and fear. To some, as Seneca wrote, death is a punishment, to others a gift, and to many a favor. For those with terminal illnesses, those perceptions  and a host of others like anxiety, fear and denial  surface in some form.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Euthanasia Ban Ends
description: A law decriminalizing euthanasia took effect yesterday, making Belgium the second country, along with the Netherlands, to permit doctors to kill terminally ill patients. Patients wanting to end their lives must be conscious when the application is made and doctors must consult another physician before acting. Opponents of the law say it fails to distinguish between terminal illnesses and incurable diseases. Supporters say it is needed because without it so-called mercy killings would continue to be practiced in secret. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Nuclear Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: White Man's Burden
description: We should listen to Karl Rove when he lauds former presidents. For example, Mr. Rove has lately taken to saying that George W. Bush is another Andrew Jackson. As Congress considers Mr. Bush's demand that the Homeland Security Department be exempt from civil service rules, it should recall that those rules were introduced out of revulsion over the ''spoils system,'' under which federal appointments were reserved for political loyalists -- a practice begun under Jackson.

title: Pakistan Arrests 3 in Terror Investigation
description: Acting on a tip from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Pakistani police and intelligence officials today arrested three men near Peshawar, in northwestern Pakistan, and began investigating them for possible links to Al Qaeda, a senior police official said.

title: Minaya's Impact Felt By the Brewers, Too
description: Speaking last week at an awards luncheon of the Latino Sports Writers and Radio Announcers Association, Omar Minaya pointed out that he had been hired as the general manager of the Montreal Expos by the commissioner of baseball, not by a club owner or president. In other words, until the people who operate teams follow the commissioner's lead, Major League Baseball will still come up short in the hiring of blacks and Hispanics for high-ranking front-office positions.

title: In a Battered Taxi, a Nurse to India's Poorest
description: On a recent morning 20 miles from this city in the northwest Indian state of Rajasthan, Pauline Alexander and Kusum Bishwas were in the back of a rattling old taxi, cooling their hands on bottles of soda and discussing a girl who had almost died.

title: Ryder Cup TV Schedule
description: Friday, Sept. 27

title: Newer Cornerbacks Excel, So Sehorn's Role Is Unclear
description: So long as Will Peterson makes a habit of finishing games with interceptions, it is hard to imagine a situation in which he will be replaced -- even by Jason Sehorn, who has been serving as a nickel back while recovering from knee surgery.

description: BASEBALL

title: His Status Uncertain, Hernndez Is Impatient
description: There is a chance Orlando Hernndez made his final home start for the Yankees last night. Hernndez has one more scheduled start, on Saturday in Baltimore, and from there his future is uncertain.

title: Parts of U.S. Gulf Coast Warned of Advancing Hurricane
description: Tropical Storm Isidore was strengthening in the Gulf of Mexico about 465 miles south of the Louisiana coast this afternoon, and forecasters issued a hurricane watch for the northern gulf coast, from Cameron, La., to Pascagoula, Miss., meaning the storm could regain hurricane status and hit the area within 36 hours.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, LLOYD
description: GREENE-Lloyd. On September 22, 2002 at age 76. Beloved mother of Sarah Wrightson. Loving sister of Claire List. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 919 Michigan Ave., Suite 1100, Chicago, IL 60611-1676.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, MIRIAM
description: FRANKEL-Miriam. On September 23, 2002. Miriam was born in Brooklyn on March 20, 1922 to Louis and Kate (Singer) Furlanger. Wife of Jerome Frankel, mother of Larry (wife Faith) and Paul (wife Evy) and grandmother of six. Service Tuesday 10 AM at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck. Interment at Sharon Gardens.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prison Art Show To Proceed
description: A public display of prison inmate art will go forward after the Manhattan art gallery that agreed to show the artwork complained that state prison officials were attempting to censor the show. A spokesman for the state correction commissioner, Glenn S. Goord, said yesterday that the state would allow the show to go forward in November because none of the art is to be sold. The gallery, the White Box Gallery in Chelsea, had accused officials of the Bayview Correctional Facility of ordering the gallery to return artwork created by its prisoners. Earlier this year, the state canceled an art show in Albany after protests that a serial killer, Arthur Shawcross, was among the prisoners who had made money from the art sale last year. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: North Korea's 'Open Door'
description: North Korea has taken a significant step toward reducing its isolation by starting a reconciliation with Japan, an enemy for many decades. Given North Korea's frightening arsenal and medieval view of the world, this was a welcome development at a tense time.

title: German Outcome Casts Renewed Chill Over Economy
description: Investors abandoned the German stock market in droves today, reflecting fears that the re-election of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder will consign the country to economic paralysis.

Lorenz. Her sister Eleanor S. Graf, & her brother-in-law Karl; also by her two nieces, Angelia, Kathleen, and her nephew and godson, Frederick B. Graf. description: It is not easy being the hardest-working man in subway show business.

title: Northern Afghan Region Still Roiled by Rivalries and Fighting
description: Soldiers still enforce the 10 p.m. curfew here, striding into the street with weapons raised and letting out a bloodcurdling roar to bring cars to a stop. It has been 10 months since the Taliban were chased from this city, heralding the collapse of their rule across the country. But the city and the northern Afghan region as a whole have refused to settle down.

title: Markets in Brazil Plunge On Worries Over Election
description: The Brazilian real fell by more than 4.5 percent and stock and bond markets also fell sharply today, as investors concluded from the latest opinion poll that the left-wing presidential candidate Luiz Incio Lula da Silva may be on his way to an outright victory in the first round of voting Oct. 6, an outcome many businesspeople here dread.

title: Lessons for Avoiding a Snack Attack
description: A few states and scattered schools around the country have begun to realize that good nutrition should not take a back seat to other kinds of learning if students are to be at their best both in and out of the classroom.

title: A New Choice For Flying Coast to Coast
description: A New England air charter company plans to enter the New York-to- Los Angeles market later this year with charter flights on specially configured airliners.

title: A New Sort of School Board, Bland and Calm
description: In case anyone doubted that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's new Panel for Educational Policy would act differently from the Board of Education that it replaced, the panel's first public meeting yesterday proved it a different animal entirely.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Campaign Season column on Sunday, about an advertisement for Senator Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, that mentions his support for gay issues misspelled the surname of the ad's producer. He is Chris Mottola, not Mottolas.

title: O'Neill Cool on New 30-Year Bond Sales
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 23 (Bloomberg News)  The United States government does not need to resume selling 30-year Treasury bonds, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today.

title: F.B.I. Had History of Contacts With One Terrorism Suspect
description: In June 2001, when Sahim A. Alwan returned home from what he has called a harrowing 10 days in one of Osama bin Laden's training camps, a message was waiting for him on his answering machine from the chief terrorism investigator at the Buffalo office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: U.S. Suspects Ukraine of Selling Radar to Iraq
description: The United States, relying on an analysis of clandestine tape recordings, has concluded that President Leonid D. Kuchma of Ukraine personally approved a plan in July 2000 to sell Iraq an advanced radar system that can detect approaching aircraft without their pilots' knowledge.

description: People

title: Bonds Believes Time Is Still on His Side
description: He has been the most valuable player a record-breaking four times, has been a perennial All-Star, is the leading batter in the National League and holds the single-season home run record. So, Barry Bonds was asked before a game at Dodger Stadium, has there been any distinction in the game that has eluded him?

title: Requiring Children To Pledge Fair Play
description: The Nassau County Legislature, whose sometimes testy debates hardly evoke the best in sportsmanship, decided today to hold thousands of young athletes to a higher standard.

title: Panel to Evaluate Columbia U. School of Journalism
description: Columbia University's president, Lee C. Bollinger, named nearly three dozen people yesterday to a task force that will explore the future of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism and the way future journalists should be taught.

title: Cuomo Will Remain on Ballot As Liberal Party Candidate
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, who quit the Democratic primary a week before the Sept. 10 primary, will officially remain on the ballot as the Liberal Party candidate for governor, with the passage of a deadline last night to remove his name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOHN DE LACY
description: KELLY-John de Lacy. Beloved husband of Ayn. Father of Allison, Philip, Daria, Gordon, Damian and the late Mark and de Lacy, Jr. Gramps to Jacqueline, Rosalie, Gabrielle, Sean and Justin. RC Mass Thursday, 10 AM, St. Mary of the Assumption Church, Katonah, New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Jets Coaches Must Make Next Move
description: WHAT a difference one game makes. Giants fans are celebrating as if they received untraceable freebies that fell off a truck. On the other hand, Jets fans have a crushed feeling from being run over by the very same truck of fortune.

title: Court Reverses 2 Convictions Over Pictures
description: The Washington Supreme Court has overturned the convictions of two men for taking pictures underneath women's skirts at a shopping mall and a food festival. Calling the conduct ''reprehensible and disgusting,'' the court nonetheless held on Thursday that Washington's voyeurism statute did not apply to photographs taken in public places.

title: An End to the Louima Case
description: The Abner Louima police torture case ended not with a bang but a whimper last weekend, when federal prosecutors struck a deal with a key defendant. On the eve of yet another retrial of Charles Schwarz, they agreed to drop their case in exchange for Mr. Schwarz's acceptance of a five-year prison sentence for a perjury charge. It is an unsatisfying resolution, but it is understandable why both sides agreed to it.

title: HIDDEN HILLS
description: NBC tonight at 9:30, Eastern and Pacific times; 8:30, Central time

title: Anti-Abortion Lobbyists Tying Up Bankruptcy-Overhaul Bill
description: Two powerful lobbying groups on Capitol Hill that usually have no issue in common, credit card companies and anti-abortion campaigners, have collided over the fate of a bill to overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSLOW, LOTTIE
description: ROSLOW - Lottie, 93. In Brooklyn, September 23, 2002. Deeply loved wife of the late David Roslow. Beloved mother of Ilsa Schwartz and Dorna Theaman, grandmother of Leah Medway and Seth Schwartz, great-grand-mother of Drew Medway. Graveside services 2:30PM today, New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Arab TV Channel Prepares For a War in Its Backyard
description: For more than a year, the lively television newsroom of Al Jazeera, filled with journalists from the Arab world and backed by Qatar, a little-known American ally in the Middle East, has caused angst in the Bush administration. In the event of a war against Iraq, it may be in a position to cause more.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: A Canyon Less Grand
description: A political commercial that intended to show the state's greatest natural wonder, the Grand Canyon, may have mistakenly included an image from Utah. The commercial was for Proposition 201, an initiative that would allow slot machines at racetracks. In the advertisement, shot in a studio, a character named Joe Arizona points to a view of a canyon and says, ''We don't have one of the seven wonders, we have the wonder.'' Geologists who saw the image said it was of Dead Horse Point State Park near Moab, Utah. A spokeswoman for the Proposition 201 campaign said she had no explanation for the image. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Medical Conditions Create Vulnerability to Vaccine
description: Many more people today are at risk of serious side effects from the smallpox vaccine than in the past, when vaccination was routine.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 16 about flooding in Dresden, Germany, misstated the number of people believed to have been killed in the city during the Allied bombing and subsequent firestorm of February 1945. According to the city government, the toll was as many as 35,000 people  not 100,000. (A reader reported the error by e-mail on Aug. 17; this correction was delayed for fact checking.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROBERT WINTHROP
description: WHITE - Robert Winthrop. Sculptor, died Saint James, NY, on September 21, 2002. White was born in New York City on September 19, 1921, son of Lawrence Grant White, and Laura Chanler White; and grandson of the architect Stanford White. His death occurred after a long illness. He attended Portsmith Abbey School and Rhode Island School of Design. In World War II, he served in The Corsair Fleet of Anti-Submarine Sailing Vessels, U.S. Coast Guard, and The Office of Strategic Services. A Fellow of The American Academy in Rome, 1952-1955, and Member of The Century Association, he served as First Vice President of The National Academy of Design. He had numerous one-man exhibitions at The Davis Gallery and The Graham Gallery in Manhattan. He is survived by his wife, Claire Nicolas White, two sons, Sebastian and Christian, a daughter, Stephanie, and seven grandchildren. A service will be held at Saint Philip and James Roman Catholic Church, Saint James, NY, at 12 noon, September 25, 2002.

title: The Fabric of Family Life, Disrupted by a Broken Leg
description: FAMILY MATTERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERERA, GEORGE
description: PERERA-George. The faculty, staff, and students of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons (P&S) mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, Dr. George Perera. Dr. Perera graduated from P&S in 1937, and later served as professor of medicine and associate dean of the faculty of medicine at Columbia. He was an alumni trustee from 1974 to 1980. In addition to his interest in education, Dr. Perera was committed to advancing efforts for world peace. He was an active member of the American Friends Service Committee and went on missions to the Middle East, USSR, Cuba, Cambodia, and Vietnam. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and friends. Gerald Fischbach, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University Thomas Q. Morris, M.D. Vice President for Health Sciences and Vice Dean of the Faculty of Medicine Columbia University

title: Bill to Brake Recognition Of Tribes Dies in Senate
description: An attempt by Connecticut's two United States senators to impose a moratorium on the federal Bureau of Indian Affairs' power to recognize new Indian tribes died in a Senate floor vote yesterday.

title: Tatu's 20-Year Run Nears an End in Dallas
description: When ANTONIO CARLOS PECORARI first came to the United States from Brazil in 1981 to play for the Tampa Bay Rowdies of the North American Soccer League, his true objective was to make enough money to buy a house free and clear back home in So Paulo.

title: Gardens and Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Protesters Seek Public Access to Renovated Tweed Building
description: Agroup of community leaders and elected officials asked the Bloomberg administration recently to consider opening the first two floors of the Tweed Courthouse, including its splendid rotunda, to the public. Miffed that the administration has yet to respond to their plan, a few dozen people gathered yesterday in front of the courthouse to call for access to the storied building, which was recently renovated at a cost to the public of $89 million.

title: Footlights
description: Reading and Writing

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLBACH, WALTER
description: STOLBACH - Walter. With great sorrow, Caren and Michael mark the passing of their beloved father, Walter, on September 21, 2002. Burial beside our beloved late mother, Miriam at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY, Tuesday, September 24, 10:30 AM.

title: Ex-Hostages Seek Release of Iraqi Funds
description: A group of American citizens who were held hostage by President Saddam Hussein after the invasion of Kuwait in 1990, and who later won legal damages against Iraq, asked a federal judge yesterday to order a New York bank that holds Iraqi assets to release the funds so the judgments can be paid.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen sank to a three-month low against the dollar as expectations mounted that Japan's economic rebound had stalled. In New York, the yen settled at 123.79 cents, up from 123.35 cents on Friday.

title: New Meaning For W.C.: With Children
description: THE mayor's office and the City Council don't always get along, but over the years they have cooperated beautifully on one issue. In perfect harmony through several administrations, they have foiled every conceivable effort to put toilets on the street for a citizenry in need of relief. Teamwork like that does not come easily.

title: Bracing for a Storm to Land, Louisiana Declares Emergency
description: With Tropical Storm Isidore spinning around the Yucatn peninsula and forecasts predicting it would intensify into a hurricane and slam into the Gulf Coast, Gov. Mike Foster of Louisiana declared a state of emergency today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISEN, CHARLES JACOB
description: EISEN-Charles Jacob. On September 23, 2002, at home in Great Neck, NY. Alumnus of New York University, Certified Public Accountant. Captain in the U.S. Army during W.W. II. Beloved husband for 52 years of Sylvia K. Eisen, father of Amy Eisen Krupsky, Elizabeth Eisen and Claudia Eisen Flack, grandfather of Rachel and Lydia Krupsky, Samuel and Natalie Dworkin, Nathaniel and Caleb Flack. Also survived by his sister Rose E. Simon, brother Dr. Herman N. Eisen, and sons-in-law Kenneth J. Krupsky and Stuart H. Flack. Funeral services will be held 2 PM, Tuesday, September 24 at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, with interment following at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Jewish Theological Seminary, New York, N.Y.

title: NEW PLAN TO MEET SMALLPOX ATTACK
description: Federal health officials today instructed states to prepare to vaccinate every American in the event of a biological attack using smallpox, and issued a detailed plan showing how each state could quickly inoculate as many as one million people in the first 10 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, NANCY MINTZ
description: SILLS-Nancy Mintz. Of Albany, NY. Beloved wife of Stephen Sills, MD. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Ronnie and Tom Lindberg, Eric and Joanne Sills. Doting and adored grandmother of David, Samantha, Anders, Jonathan and Sarah. Much loved sister of Janie Batkin of Greenwich, CT. Devoted daughter of the late Selma and Sam Mintz of Great Neck, NY. Her mother-in-law, Edna Sills, niece Amy Knox and nephew Andrew Batkin, cousins, friends and legal colleagues join in mourning the passing of this special lady. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, September 25 at Congregation Beth Emeth, Albany, NY at 1:00 PM.

title: A Ryder Cup, Perhaps, Without Rancor
description: We already know the Ryder Cup will be different this year. What we don't know is how much different. How much will the one-year postponement of the event, because of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, change the attitude of the participants, the galleries, and even change the news media's coverage of golf's most emotional event?

title: Con Ed Acquiring Site for a Midtown Substation
description: Consolidated Edison announced yesterday that it had begun proceedings to acquire four buildings in Midtown Manhattan that it plans to demolish and replace with an electrical substation.

title: Interest Rate Left Unchanged
description: Policymakers at the Federal Reserve voted to leave a key short-term interest rate at its current level of 1.75 percent, the central bank said this afternoon. But members of the Fed's Open Market Committee made it plain they are prepared to push interest rates lower.

title: Netting Exposes N.H.L. to Criticism and Praise
description: From his seats in Section 68, behind the goal line on the Eighth Avenue end of the rink at Madison Square Garden, Ernie Gellman peered through the black netting Sunday night and considered the changed perspective.

title: Williams Will Sell Its Stake in Pipeline
description: The Williams Companies agreed today to sell its stake in a natural gas pipeline from western Canada to the American Midwest to Enbridge for $173 million in cash to reduce debt.

title: Times Company Names Regional Chief
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that P. Steven Ainsley would become president and chief operating officer of its regional newspaper group. He will succeed Lynn O. Matthews, 57, who retires at the end of the year.

title: Achilles' Heel for Giants: Offense Stalls in Red Zone
description: Tiki Barber spiked the ball in rage when the Giants failed to score on fourth down at the Seattle 1-yard line just before halftime on Sunday, and he regretted it.

title: Bottled Baby Octopuses Turn Out to Be Pygmies
description: In century-old jars of alcohol on museum shelves in Paris and Washington and off the coasts of Indonesia, Senegal and the Caribbean, zoologists are stumbling upon dozens of species of tiny octopuses once believed to be babies of their larger relatives.

title: Jets' Playbook Open to Page One
description: With the Jets reeling from two consecutive blowout losses in which the offense managed 10 points, Coach Herman Edwards planned to meet with the offensive coordinator Paul Hackett tonight to sort through an offense that is not merely adrift, but is close to sinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINSKEY, DOROTHY MARIE
description: LINSKEY-Dorothy Marie. Of Stratford, CT. Daughter of the late Patrick and Mary Alice Lynch Flynn, born February 5, 1902 in Brooklyn, NY. She was the Deputy Director of Administration for the Civil Court for the City of New York. She graduated from St. John's University. She leaves a daughter Marie L. Cullen of CT., and a son Edward G. Linskey Jr., of AZ. For information Cody-White Funeral Home, Milford, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, SAUL
description: FISHMAN - Saul. Beloved husband of Cecile, devoted father of Howard (Ellen), and Robert (Karen), adored grandfather of Justin, Brandon, Jessie, and Peter. Loving brother of Anne, Libby, and Faye, also survived by many nieces and nephews. Services Tuesday 10 A.M. at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Shiva will begin September 29th (evenings).

title: Mediterranean Musical Tour, Tambourines Keeping Time
description: Echoes of bygone empires and reflections of recent civil wars, trance-healing rhythms and brass-band party music, classical love lyrics and current wedding songs were all part of Music Around the Mediterranean, a three-day festival presented last weekend at Bohemian Hall in Astoria, Queens, by the World Music Institute and the Center for Traditional Music and Dance. In a lineup that started with the Italian-American Giglio brass band from Brooklyn and wound up with a Rom (Gypsy) violinist from Turkey, Kemani Cemal, it was easy to hear ideas that had mingled along routes of trade and conquest.

title: Germany Speaks
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's narrow re-election in Germany, after a bitter campaign focusing on his opposition to a war with Iraq, has sent a thunderbolt across the Atlantic and into the White House. In a clear sign of American displeasure, President Bush offered only an icy acknowledgment of Mr. Schrder's victory. The chancellor has responded with the right gesture -- immediate removal of a minister quoted as making an odious comparison between Mr. Bush's tactics and those of Hitler. There is more Mr. Schrder should do. For their part, Mr. Bush and his aides need to recognize the uneasiness of the Germans and many others over the prospect of a war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOPHER, SASSOON
description: SOPHER-Sassoon. Wednesday, September 18, 2002 in Geneva, Switzerland. Mr. Sopher was born in Basrah, Iraq, on May 25, 1906. He was the devoted husband of Rachel for 64 years. He was the devoted father and father-in-law of Frederic and his wife Joyce and of Jamil and his wife Lynn, and the devoted grandfather of Margaret, Peter and Philip.

title: Missing Limb? Salamander May Have Answer
description: In a closetlike room at the ''Leg Lab'' here, salamanders stare blankly out of clear plastic drinking cups. The lab is so named because many of the animals have had, or will have, a leg cut off. But the salamanders recover, with perfect new limbs growing back in weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAY, OLGA M.
description: JAY-Olga M. On September 22, 2002. Dear wife of Theodore. Loving mother of Mark, Jeremy and Leslie Seltzer. Cherished grandmother of Michelle. Funeral service at Larchmont Temple, Tuesday September 24 at 12:30 PM.

description: To the Editor:

description: RIKER-Anne T. ''Nancy'' (Cox), 91, of Weston, MA, formerly of Sarasota, FL and Tucker's Town, Bermuda, on July 21, 2002. Wife of the late Samuel Riker who died in 1970. She is survived by her daughter Anne T. ''Susie'' Buttrick of Concord, MA and sons, Samuel of Tucker's Town, Bermuda and Robert T. of Sarasota, FL. She also leaves her sister Frances B. Cox of Sarasota, FL, eight grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 27, at 2PM in Trinity Episcopal Church, 81 Elm St., Concord, MA. Her ashes will be buried at Holy Trinity Church, Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, on November 9, 2002. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be made to the Massachusetts Audubon Society, 208 South Great Road, Lincoln, MA 01773.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Beiersdorf's Share Gain
description: Beiersdorf shares rose as much as 19 percent after The Financial Times Deutschland said the Procter & Gamble Company planned to bid for Allianz's 43.6 percent stake in the company, which makes Nivea skin cream. Procter & Gamble told Allianz, the giant insurer, that it had ''concrete interest'' in the stake, the newspaper said, citing unidentified people in the industry. An offer for the shares, with a market value of about 3.7 billion euros ($3.63 billion), is expected soon, the paper said.

title: Isles' Martinek Makes Up for Lost Time
description: Radek Martinek still loves to play hockey and he will flash a smile that is missing one big front tooth, but practically everything else in his life has changed since he last played defense for the Islanders.

title: Fed Differences on Rate Cut Give Markets a Bumpy Ride
description: Stocks fell today as investors got a surprise dissent from two Federal Reserve policymakers, another dose of weak data on the economy and more disappointments on corporate earnings.

title: When Having a Meeting Is Like Going to a Movie
description: HE guys who built and who are marketing the newest marvel of futuristic videoconferencing did not look real happy about it, but I call them like I see them.

title: Museum of City of New York Names Director
description: The Museum of the City of New York, left reeling earlier this year by the resignation of its director and a rescinded pledge to move it to the elegant Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan, named the president of the National Building Museum in Washington as its director yesterday.

title: A Route to Avoid
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Strike Deadline At Ford
description: The Canadian Auto Workers union said that Ford Motor Company's local unit would be its next target for negotiations on a new labor contract with the Big Three North American automakers. The union, which agreed on a three-year contract with General Motors of Canada last week, said its 12,900 members at Ford would go on strike if no deal was reached by Oct. 1. The talks with Ford will center on the company's plan to close an F-150 pickup truck plant in Oakville, Ontario, next year with the loss of about 1,500 jobs.

title: Mayor With a Well-Worn Passport; Bloomberg as Envoy, Selling the World on New York
description: He learned in Athens that the mayor of Moscow is a fan of ''Jesus Christ, Superstar.'' He lunched with the mayor of Istanbul in a former Turkish prison that is now a Four Seasons Hotel. And he ate a spoonful of a very sweet, very sticky white paste, a delicacy that was served to him in a glass of water by Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, the spiritual leader of more than 220 million Orthodox Christians.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Borgata Hotel, Casino and Spa, which is scheduled to open in Atlantic City, N.J., in summer 2003, named Schadler Kramer Group Advertising, Las Vegas, as its first agency of record. Billings for the introductory campaign were estimated at $10 million. The Borgata is a joint venture of the Boyd Gaming Corporation and the MGM Mirage.

title: STATE PANEL SEEKS CHANGES IN HOMES FOR MENTALLY ILL
description: A high-level Pataki administration panel said today that New York should largely abandon its decades-old system of adult homes for the mentally ill, and called for hundreds of millions of dollars in spending on new services and housing for residents of the homes.

title: The Enron Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods Says Ryder Cup Remarks Were Meant to Be Funny
description: SUTTON COLDFIELD, England, Sept. 24  Although Tiger Woods won't be playing for a $1 million this week, he insisted his motivation for the Ryder Cup won't be a problem.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Cut Down to Size

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Airline Executives Going to Congress to Ask for More Financial Aid
description: Airline executives, facing industrywide losses that could approach $7 billion this year, will ask Congress today for additional financial aid. That would come on top of the $5 billion in cash the government handed out after closing down all air space in the United States after the terror attacks last year.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BELGIUM: EUTHANASIA BAN ENDS A law decriminalizing euthanasia took effect yesterday, making Belgium the second country, along with the Netherlands, to permit doctors to kill terminally ill patients. Patients wanting to end their lives must be conscious when the application is made and doctors must consult another physician before acting. Opponents of the law say it fails to distinguish between terminal illnesses and incurable diseases. Supporters say it is needed because without it so-called mercy killings would continue to be practiced in secret.

title: Israel, Jews and the Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesians Distrust Report By C.I.A. on Qaeda Suspect
description: ''Beware of U.S. Propaganda.'' That front-page headline in one of the leading newspapers here this morning spoke to far more than just the article below it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATI, HELEN
description: PRATI-Helen, 78. Of Riverdale, NY, on September 17, 2002. Born October 9th, 1923 in Nesquehoning, PA. Registered nurse, trained at Bellevue, NYC. Loving mother, devoted wife, always gracious, kind and beautiful. She will be sadly missed but fondly remembered by her son Armand, family and friends. Memorial service Saturday September 28, at Saint Gabriel's Church, Riverdale, NY.

title: F.D.A. Staff Voices Doubts on AstraZeneca Cancer Drug
description: The staff of the Food and Drug Administration has found ''several bothersome issues'' with data submitted by AstraZeneca that appear to jeopardize the company's chances for approval of its cancer drug, Iressa.

title: For Sale (Maybe): Giacometti's Legacy; A Proposed Auction Draws Fire in Paris
description: For Christie's, the opportunity to auction 36 Giacometti sculptures this fall seemed like a splashy way of consolidating its presence in a Paris art market that only recently opened to foreign companies. But behind this coup lay the challenge of holding the sale without being drawn into the imbroglio that has accompanied the Giacometti legacy for the last decade. Christie's may not have succeeded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMBERT, KURT
description: KOMBERT-Kurt. Age 67, died September 13, 2002. Loving father of Mark, Karen, Nancy and Lorie. Devoted brother of Erwin. Cherished grandfather to Maxwell, Henry, Alexander, Samuel, Nicole, Scott, Sarah, Adam, Lucy and Zoe. You are loved and missed by your family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, GERALD
description: FRANKLIN-Gerald. 77 years old, died on September 21, 2002. He was a lawyer and writer. He is survived by his loving wife Roberta Franklin and his two children David and Leslie Franklin, and their fabulous grandson Parker Gerald Berger. Memorial service will be held on Friday, September 27, at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Ave., East Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to either NYU Cardiology Department, or to the NY Tisch School, Art Department of Dramatic Writing.

title: PRESIDENT REBUFFS MOVES BY GERMANY TO MEND RELATIONS
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder, who won narrow re-election on Sunday in part by opposing an American war in Iraq, tried today to patch up relations with Washington, but President Bush broke with protocol and refrained from making the customary congratulatory telephone call to the German leader.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: More Tension With Morocco
description: A simmering dispute over Spanish territories on the coast of Morocco flared up again with the Moroccan foreign minister suddenly canceling a visit to Madrid aimed at easing relations between the Mediterranean neighbors, who have also clashed over immigration and fishing rights. Foreign Minister Mohamed Benaissa accused Spain of having landed a helicopter on a disupted islet that was at the center of a weeklong military standoff in July. Spain strongly denied the accusation. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Carving Up The Caspian
description: Russia and Azerbaijan signed an agreement dividing up their share of the Caspian Sea, along with its potentially rich gas and oil reserves. The agreement -- signed by Presidents Vladimir V. Putin and Heydar Aliyev in Moscow -- essentially bypassed Iran and Turkmenistan, which also border the sea and have argued for a broader multilateral agreement dividing its resources. Russia signed a similar agreement with Kazakhstan in May. Iran has argued that the Caspian should be divided equally among the five nations but Russia, Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan have argued that the division should be based on the length of shorelines, leaving Iran and Turkmenistan smaller shares. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: BLACK & DECKER REDUCES ANNUAL SALES ESTIMATES
description: The Black & Decker Corporation said the retailer Home Depot Inc. would stop carrying some of the company's Price Pfister plumbing products, reducing sales by about $15 million this year and $50 million annually. The faucets and fixtures will not be carried at the home-improvement chain's stores in the East and the Midwest, Black & Decker said. The company expects the products to continue to be sold in Home Depot outlets in the West. Black & Decker, the nation's largest maker of power tools, had expected the change and said third-quarter and full-year profit would meet or exceed forecasts. The company is forecast to earn 83 cents a share in the quarter and $3.03 for the year, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.

title: At U.N., U.S. Calls for End to the Siege of Arafat
description: The United States proposed a Security Council resolution today that criticized Israel in unusually strong terms, while administration officials accused Israel of undermining Palestinian reform efforts by confining Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, in his compound in Ramallah.

title: Nuclear Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Oil Workers Go On Strike
description: Oil workers protesting the proposed privatization of government-owned refineries began a two-day strike, shutting down gas stations in the capital, Abuja, and Lagos, the country's commercial center. The refineries have been so poorly run for years that Nigeria, the world's sixth-largest oil exporter, must import vast quantities of refined fuel to satisfy domestic demand. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Leader Says India Lies About Kashmir
description: On the eve of the second stage of voting in closely watched state assembly elections in Indian-held Kashmir, President Pervez Musharraf dismissed Indian assertions of a high turnout in the first stage as lies. General Musharraf said that at most 10 percent of voters cast ballots in the first round on Sept. 16; India says 47.5 percent voted. The nuclear-armed countries both lay claim to Kashmir and nearly went to war this year over Pakistan's support for anti-Indian militants. India has accused Pakistan of trying to disrupt the elections. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: PARKING FINES TO RISE TO UP TO $105 Fines on some parking violations will rise next Tuesday, almost doubling for certain offenses. The violations that will have the higher fines generally involve violations of no-stopping or no-standing rules, said Sam Miller, a spokesman for the City Department of Finance. Alternate-side-of-the-street and meter-violation fines will not go up. The fines, which are currently $55, will be going up to $85 or $105, depending on the violation. "Most of these fines have not been increased since 1975," Mr. Miller said. The state authorized the city to increase fines in July. (AP)

title: Lawyer Caught In Tyco Tangle Leaves Friends Wondering
description: There is no question that Mark A. Belnick, a star litigator who helped Congress track down missing millions in the Iran-Contra affair, made some costly errors in judgment while he was general counsel at Tyco.

title: More Than an Academic Exercise
description: The Sept. 11 hijackers, it was recently revealed, code-named the Pentagon ''the Faculty of Fine Arts'' and the twin towers ''the Faculty of Urban Planning.'' An Internet message from one plotter spoke of ''19 certificates for private study and four exams,'' and ended, ''Regards to the professor.''

title: Recession Cut Incomes and Swelled Poverty Rolls, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - The number of poor people in the United States rose last year to 32.9 million, an increase of 1.3 million that pushed up the proportion of Americans living in poverty for the first time in eight years, to 11.7 percent, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 16 about flooding in Dresden, Germany, misstated the number of people believed to have been killed in the city during the Allied bombing and subsequent firestorm of February 1945. According to the city government, the toll was as many as 35,000 people -- not 100,000. (A reader reported the error by e-mail on Aug. 17; this correction was delayed for fact checking.)

title: Market Place; NASD Sues Star Analyst Over Research
description: Regulators from the securities industry sued Jack B. Grubman, the former analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, and an assistant yesterday, contending they wrote misleading research on the telecommunications company Winstar Communications.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Federal Judge Rules El Paso Drove Up Natural Gas Prices

title: Some Retirees Look Abroad for Prescription Drugs
description: After months of intense debate, proposals aimed at helping the elderly pay for prescription drugs did not make it out of the Senate this summer. Neither the Republican plan, which involved government subsidies to private insurers, nor the Democratic plan, which would have expanded Medicare benefits, garnered the 60 votes needed.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, Page 12 of Money & Business on Sunday was interchanged with Page 12 of Sunday Styles in some copies. The error misplaced the continuations of three articles -- one about the economic uncertainty that is slowing businesses' spending; one about the murky line between companies' philanthropies and those of their chief executives; and one about the uses of humiliation in a new generation of television commercials. The full articles may be found online today, at nytimes.com/corrections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, REVEREND GEORGE A. III, (HOPPY)
description: ROBINSON - Reverend George A. III, (Hoppy), from Marion, MA., Minister of The Unitarian Universalist Church, Flushing. Died September 22 at age 51. He also served congregations in East Rochester, MA., and Ashby, MA. He was a passionate hiker and lover of wilderness. He will be deeply missed by his family and all those he touched in his life. His family asks that donations be made to Joslin Diabetes Center, 1 Joslin Place, Boston, MA. 02215. A memorial service will be held at The Flushing Church, Sept. 29, 11 AM, 14754 Ash Avenue, 718-353-3860.

title: Stampeded on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Forrester Has 'Priorities Straight,' Bush Says at Stop in New Jersey
description: President Bush began a nationwide Congressional campaign swing today with a stop in New Jersey, where he urged voters to replace Senator Robert G. Torricelli, who was recently admonished by the Senate Ethics Committee, with ''a man who has got his priorities straight.''

title: Guidance on the Prostate Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Steve Price, chief operating officer at Publicis in Mid America, Dallas, was promoted to chairman and chief executive. He succeeds Barry Krause, who was named chairman and chief executive at Publicis in New York. Both agencies are part of the American operations of the Publicis Groupe.

title: 'Eye Candy' and Fakery In Wrestling? Objection!
description: Being a professional wrestler, it turns out, is no easy way to make a buck.

title: Germs in the Laundry
description: Q. How hygienic is it to wash clothes at a public coin laundry? Have there been any studies of what diseases can be transmitted?

title: Jan de Hartog, 88, Author of His Own Life
description: Jan de Hartog, the Dutch novelist and playwright, the author of the 1951 Broadway hit ''The Fourposter,'' died Sunday in Houston. He was 88 and lived in Houston.

title: ON THE GROUND: In Tucson; A Distinct Western Flavor And Plenty of Sunny Days
description: If you're lucky enough to be headed for Tucson on a business trip, set aside a day or two for some outdoor fun. With the sun shining an average of 350 days a year, and with a setting in a 2,400-foot-high Sonoran desert basin surrounded by mountain ranges, Tucson, an old mining and cowboy town, is a modern center for fresh-air activities.

title: Battle Brews Over a Hispanic Nominee to Appeals Court
description: The nomination of Miguel Estrada to a federal appeals court, which the Senate Judiciary Committee takes up this week, may produce the most contentious judicial fight yet in the Bush administration.

title: Heel Pain: A Step Backward
description: In recent years, people suffering from the painful heel ailment known as plantar fasciitis have been turning for help to an ultrasonic method also used to treat kidney stones and gallstones.

title: Bengals May Never Come Out at Night Again
description: Oct. 19, 1992 -- The Bengals play on ''Monday Night Football.''

title: International Steel Will Buy Acme Metals
description: International Steel Group Inc., a steel company created through the purchase of mills formerly owned by LTV Corporation., won court approval to buy the mill and other assets of bankrupt Acme Metals Inc.

title: If Smallpox Breaks Out: Questions and Answers on the U.S. Vaccination Plan
description: Routine smallpox vaccinations were ended in the United States in 1972, and the disease was declared eradicated in 1980. But now, faced with the possibility of a terrorist attack, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have adopted guidelines for a mass vaccination in the event of an outbreak.

title: Steelcase Shows Big Loss
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 23 (Bloomberg News)  Steelcase Inc. , the leading maker of office furniture, had a second-quarter loss of $7.3 million, caused by falling demand. The company said third-quarter sales would be the lowest since an industry slump started.

title: Defense Also Struggles To Keep Up With Miami
description: Although the offense was the focus of the Jets' gloomy post-mortem today, the defense did not escape notice.

title: Wall Street Is in Need Of Some Silver Inside Clouds
description: The weak economy, profit warnings from many big companies, falling stock markets abroad and the prospect of war with Iraq helped send the Nasdaq composite index to a six-year low yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: CIVILIZED VIVENDI MEETING Jean-Rene Fourtou, the new chairman and chief executive of Vivendi Universal , said he would replace his ousted predecessor, Jean-Marie Messier, left, as supervisory board chairman of the company's utilities unit Vivendi Environnement . Mr. Fourtou said that the board meeting, with Mr. Messier in attendance, had been conducted in a "civilized" manner. Mr. Fourtou confirmed that Mr. Messier, who was chairman of Vivendi Environnement's supervisory board when he was pushed out in a Vivendi Universal board coup in July, would remain as a member of the Vivendi Environnement board. Mr. Fourtou declined to respond directly to questions on whether Vivendi Universal planned to sell its stake in Vivendi Environnement. Vivendi is planning a news conference tomorrow to announce its new strategy. (Reuters)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Andersen Faces a New Inquiry by I.R.S.
description: Arthur Andersen, which was convicted of obstruction of justice for shredding Enron audit records, must answer questions about tax shelters that involve up to $1.6 billion in improper deductions, according to a petition filed on behalf of the Internal Revenue Service today.

title: Cross-Country Champion Switches Her Gears
description: Sonia O'Sullivan's running career has brought many medals, among them gold in the 1998 world cross-country championships, silver in the 5,000 meters in the 2000 Sydney Olympics, and silver in the 5,000 and 10,000 meters in the European championships last month.

title: Sting of Last Year's Recession Was Not as Mild as Many Think
description: In speeches around the country, Federal Reserve officials have helped turn the phrase mild recession into perhaps the most popular description of the recent downturn. Measured by the output of goods and services, the officials note, the recession that began early last year looks like one of the weakest in decades.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Expanded Domestic Partner Benefits
description: City Comptroller William C. Thompson and several City Council members announced a bill yesterday to require companies that have contracts with New York City exceeding $100,000 to provide the same benefits to domestic partners that they do to employees with spouses. Similar laws exist in some cities in Western states. Some council members see the bill as an extension of a 1998 law that gave domestic partnership benefits to city employees. Jennifer Steinhauer

title: Schools Teach 3 C's: Candy, Cookies and Chips
description: School is back in session, but do you know what your children are learning about a matter of lifelong importance? That matter is food and drink, the substances that sustain health and life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCE, ELISABETH ROOT
description: LUCE-Elisabeth Root, 47. Died on Wednesday, September 18, in Palm Beach, Florida. Devoted daughter of Peter Paul Luce and Margaret Hamilton Howe, mother of Henry Luce Hagenbuch, Hunter Blackwood Hagenbuch and Hilary Winters Hagenbuch, sister of Meredith Hamilton Luce (Billingsly), Christena Charlotte Luce McNicol and Clare Middleton Luce Abbey. Service 10 AM Wednesday, September 25, at Grace Cathedral, Nob Hill, San Francisco, California. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Nick Traina Foundation, 2280 Octavia Street, San Francisco, California 94115.

title: Digital Cable May Be Next For the N.F.L.
description: The Jets had just been thrashed by Miami on Sunday, 30-3, and CBS switched to bonus coverage of the Kansas City-New England game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFINGER, FAITH WINSOR
description: GOLDFINGER-Faith Winsor. On September 22, 2002 in her adopted London. Our thoughts are with her husband Peter, daughters Pippa and Toni and grandsons. A best loved friend of many, she lit our lives.

title: Blair Presents Dossier on Iraq's Biological Weapons
description: LONDON, Sept. 24  Britain today published a long-awaited dossier asserting that the regime of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was continuing to expand stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons and had plans to use them. Arguing for urgent action by the West, it said that some of the weapons could be deployed within 45 minutes.

title: Justice Dept. Staff Said to Be Opposing Satellite TV Merger
description: Staff members of the Justice Department have recommended that the government block the proposed $11.2 billion merger of the two largest satellite television broadcasters, DirecTV and EchoStar, because it would be anticompetitive, lawyers involved in the review said today.

title: Here They Are, Science's 10 Most Beautiful Experiments
description: Whether they are blasting apart subatomic particles in accelerators, sequencing the genome or analyzing the wobble of a distant star, the experiments that grab the world's attention often cost millions of dollars to execute and produce torrents of data to be processed over months by supercomputers. Some research groups have grown to the size of small companies.

title: F.D.A. Tells Barr to Delay Cancer Drug
description: Barr Laboratories must delay introducing its own version of AstraZeneca's Tamoxifen cancer drug, the Food and Drug Administration said today. Barr said it would sue the agency.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Strong Demand For Telecom Shares
description: China United Telecommunications received 36 times the subscriptions for its shares as there was stock available, the sale manager, China International Capital, said. The shares available to individual investors will start trading on the Shanghai stock exchange on Oct. 9, China United said. China United sold 2.75 billion shares to individual investors at 2.30 yuan each, part of its 5 billion share sale to raise 11.5 billion yuan ($1.4 billion).

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Injuries In Quake
description: Western England and Wales were hit by an earthquake with a magnitude of 4.8, which caused two shocks over a 30-second period and prompted many people near the epicenter in the West Midlands to leave their homes in their nightclothes. No one was injured but there were brief power failures, and the police evacuated an apartment building in Bradford as a precaution. Glenn Ford, a senior seismologist at the British Geological Survey said, ''It's an extremely large earthquake in U.K. terms but not large in world terms.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZACK, DAVID
description: ZACK-David. 85. Of New York City and Princeton, NJ, September 22, 2002. Beloved husband of 60 years of the late Beatrice Bodin; devoted father of Brian G. (Virginia August); Donald B. (Ellen Okun); beloved grandfather of Rebecca, Ian and Daniel Zack and Rachel, Elizabeth and Andrew Zack. Retired partner David Berdon & Co., CPAs; past president, New York State Society of CPAs. Interment private.

title: More U.S. Aid Urged To Upgrade Schools
description: Speaking at a Queens elementary school where students start lining up for lunch before 10 a.m. because of overcrowding, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called yesterday for more federal aid to fix aging schools and build new ones.

title: All the News Google Algorithms Say Is Fit to Print
description: Google, the rapidly growing online search engine, introduced a service yesterday that uses its search algorithms -- but no human editors -- to create a news page that looks not much different from those of many news Web sites.

title: Israel, Jews and the Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Consumer Prices Fall
description: Hong Kong consumer prices fell for a 46th straight month in August as high unemployment forced retailers to continue discounting goods. The consumer price index declined 3.3 percent from a year earlier, the government said. The largest decline in prices was for gas, water and electricity charges, which dropped 8.5 percent, the report showed. Housing slipped 6.4 percent, and the cost of home appliances and other durable goods fell 5.5 percent. Food prices declined 2.6 percent.

title: Family Leave In California Now Includes Pay Benefit
description: Gov. Gray Davis signed a bill today to establish paid family leave to care for a new child or an ailing relative, giving California workers the most expansive family benefit in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASH, RICHARD
description: KASH-Richard. On September 22, 2002. Loving father to Rachel and Lauren. Son of the late Anne and David Kash. Brother to the late Ira Kash. Graveside service Wednesday, September 25th, 10:30 AM, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Still 'Kissin Time' for the Weathered
description: Lust isn't just for the young anymore. As more baby boomers pass 50, middle-aged rockers are insisting they're still hot blooded. The Rolling Stones, Bonnie Raitt and now Marianne Faithfull, who performed on Thursday night at Irving Plaza, still make earthy passion a priority.

description: SOFTWARE

title: Colon Cancer in Men
description: To the Editor:

title: HAUNTED
description: UPN tonight at 9, Eastern and Pacific times; 8, Central time

title: Legal Heavyweights to Help Decide Sept. 11 Fund Appeals
description: For almost a year, the Sept. 11 Victim Compensation Fund has been defined by only one public face: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master in charge of administering it.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Clear The Way
description: Chicago police officers and parking enforcement aides plan to step up enforcement this week of regulations protecting the city's 72 miles of bike lanes. Motorists who drive, idle or park in a bike lane could face $100 fines and have their vehicles towed. ''Cars parked in bike lanes force bicyclists to swerve out into faster motor-vehicle traffic and endangers lives,'' said Bea Reyna-Hickey, the director of the city's Department of Revenue. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Smoothing the Furrowed Brow, the Botox Way
description: WE are being lured into the realm of instant gratification and eternal youth -- namely an after-hours appointment with Dr. Alan Matarasso, the wildly popular provider of self-esteem and personal serenity via cosmetic plastic surgery and Botox injections -- by a barrage of Botox commercials and news that the Food and Drug Administration is angry at Botox for promising the public a wrinkle-free future. Vanity, thy name is human. (Botox has unisex appeal. Ask the doctor. Quietly. Everybody gets it; nobody is supposed to know.)

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF MIDAS QUITS AS IT FORECASTS LOSS
description: Midas Inc., the operator of auto repair shops, named Gary Vonk as acting chief executive after Wendel Province resigned. The company also forecast a third-quarter loss. Mr. Province, 54, quit because of the company's ''disappointing performance,'' a spokesman, Bob Troyer, said. Mr. Vonk, 49, who had been chief operating officer, was also promoted to president. Midas will report a ''modest'' loss in the quarter ending Saturday because of higher-than-expected medical claims from employees and the severance packages for Mr. Province and another executive, the company said.

title: As Iraq Rejects New U.N. Rules, Oil Prices Hit a 19-Month High
description: Crude oil rose to a 19-month high yesterday after Iraq refused to accept new United Nations resolutions on weapons inspections, raising the chances of a United States attack on Iraq, the supplier of 2 percent of the world's oil.

title: Emmy Award Winners
description: Here is a list of winners of the 2002 Emmy Awards, presented at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles on Sunday night by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences:

title: Gore, Still Coy About Plans for 2004, Calls Bush's Policy a Failure on Several Fronts
description: Former Vice President Al Gore accused the Bush administration today of weakening the war on terrorism by turning the country's attention to Saddam Hussein. He also said the Congressional resolution on Iraq sought by President Bush was too broad and did not do enough to seek international support for a possible military strike.

title: New Plan for Smallpox Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23  Federal health officials today instructed states to prepare to vaccinate every American in the event of a biological attack using smallpox, and issued a detailed plan showing how each state could quickly inoculate as many as one million people in the first 10 days.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Palm Loss Widens As Sales Fall
description: The hand-held computer maker Palm Inc., whose stock has dropped below $1, said its first-quarter loss widened as sales fell 20 percent. The net loss widened to $258.7 million, or 45 cents a share, from $32.4 million, or 6 cents, a year earlier, Palm said. Sales in the quarter ended Aug. 30 declined to $172.3 million from $214.3 million. The company recorded costs of $219.1 million related to the eventual separation of its software and hardware divisions. Palm, which last month was removed from the Standard & Poor's index of the 500 biggest companies, has had losses in six of the past seven quarters as slow economic growth led consumers and businesses to spend less on electronics.

title: A Timely Dose of Drug News
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Warner To Sell Digital Singles Online
description: The Warner Music Group, a unit of AOL Time Warner and one of the world's largest record companies, said yesterday that it would begin selling digital singles of popular music at prices starting at 99 cents through online retailers like BestBuy.com and MTV.com. The move signals a shift in the established music industry's strategy as it seeks to lure consumers away from downloading unauthorized copies of music free over Internet file-trading services. The Universal Music Group has announced plans for a similar service to be introduced this fall. The sales transactions for Warner's service will be handled by RioPort, an application service provider.

title: Year After 9/11, Fashion Week Speaks of Recovery and Money
description: Some people outside the fashion business may regard Fashion Week as a frivolous and frolicsome affair, sprinkled with glitz and waifs, designers and groupies. New York City tourism and economic officials, though, take it quite seriously.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Mass Grave May Hold Victims Of Stalin
description: The human rights group Memorial said it had unearthed a mass grave near St. Petersburg that may contain thousands of victims of Stalin's terror in 1937 and 1938. The grave -- near a military firing range in the forest outside Toksovo, about 20 miles north of St. Petersburg -- was discovered last month. Forensic experts have discovered 50 separate pits containing bones, including skulls showing evidence of execution. A site with some 8,000 remains was discovered north of St. Petersburg in 1996 but a Memorial spokeswoman told the Interfax news agency that the new site could hold as many as 30,000 remains. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)
