The error misplaced the continuations of three articles -- one about the economic uncertainty that is slowing businesses' spending; one about the murky line between companies' philanthropies and those of their chief executives; and one about the uses of humiliation in a new generation of television commercials. The full articles may be found online today, at nytimes.com/corrections.

title: The Lawsuit Culture In a Changed Land
description: To the Editor:

title: In Nablus, Back-Room Schools Spring Up to Spite Curfew
description: Tracing the letter A in the air, Jamila Mabruk introduced a group of Palestinian second-graders to the English alphabet this week in a cramped classroom set up in a shoemaking workshop.

title: Review/Fashion; Sass and Dash From Ralph Lauren and Miguel Adrover
description: You could not find two more unlikely bedfellows than Ralph Lauren and Miguel Adrover. One commands a global empire, while the other is two months behind in the rent. Yet, within an hour of each other on Saturday night, they effectively closed the New York spring 2003 collections with powerful views of a new plurality in fashion.

title: Bucs Send the Rams' Season Further Into the Abyss
description: If anyone could rescue the St. Louis Rams, raise them from their doldrums, stir them from their slumber, it was supposed to be the team in the pewter helmets. The Rams and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers always bring out the fight in the other, going at it like brothers, pushing buttons, testing wills, trying to outshine by any means necessary.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: CONSUMER PRICES FALL Hong Kong consumer prices fell for a 46th straight month in August as high unemployment forced retailers to continue discounting goods. The consumer price index declined 3.3 percent from a year earlier, the government said. The largest decline in prices was for gas, water and electricity charges, which dropped 8.5 percent, the report showed. Housing slipped 6.4 percent, and the cost of home appliances and other durable goods fell 5.5 percent. Food prices declined 2.6 percent.

title: Rapid-Reaction Force Gets Support From NATO Ministers
description: BERLIN, Sept. 24  NATO defense ministers gave broad support today to American proposals for a rapid-reaction force, after Washington's warnings that a NATO incapable of rapid, modern, mobile warfare will become increasingly irrelevant to the United States.

title: Hunky, Wise, Romantic or Kooky. Just Like Your Doctor.
description: How do you like your doctors, classy or sassy? You get the choice this week, as two networks unveil medical series. Each is set in San Francisco, each takes broad swipes at H.M.O.'s and other bureaucratic ogres, and each features a hunky British doctor. But you won't have any trouble telling these shows apart. Classy is the word for ''Presidio Med,'' which begins on CBS tonight, then returns tomorrow night, when its second episode competes suture-to-suture with the debut of ''MD's'' (that's the sassy one) on ABC. ''MD's,'' which tries to mix pathos, satire and offbeat humor, sets itself the tougher task but falls farther from the mark.

title: U.S. Deploys Troops to Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 24  The United States deployed about 200 troops today to the West African nation of Ivory Coast, where 100 American schoolchildren have been trapped in a rebel-held city since last week.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: HIDDEN HILLS

title: Multiple Births and Older Women
description: Multiple births are riskier than single ones. The same is true for pregnancies among older woman. So is it riskier still when both circumstances occur? Apparently not, researchers have found.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Coalition for the Prevention of Alcohol Problems, Washington, is asking the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to significantly expand its review of the marketing practices used to sell the new flavored malt alcoholic beverages known as malternatives or alcopops. The coalition, a group of more than three dozen advocacy organizations, is urging the bureau to study extensively what effect the brand names of the products have on teenagers as well as adults; most of the products are named after popular liquor brands though they contain no distilled spirits.

title: A Wild, Fearsome World Under Each Fallen Leaf
description: Dr. Edward O. Wilson, Pellegrino university research professor and honorary curator in entomology of the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard University, winner of two Pulitzer prizes and scientific honors too numerous to recount, is on his hands and knees, pawing in the leaf litter near Walden Pond.

title: Letters
description: ATimely Dose of Drug News

title: Paying Tribute to a Master With His Own Hard Music
description: The drummer Art Blakey, who died in 1990, ushered Wynton Marsalis into a contender's position in the jazz world, bringing him into the dynastic Jazz Messengers group at the age of 17 in 1979. So when Mr. Marsalis and the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra paid tribute to Blakey at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night, there was bound to be more sentiment than in the usual jazz repertory concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, SCOTT BRIAN
description: GILBERT-Scott Brian, 47. On September 19, 2002. peacefully from complications of liver disease at Johns Hopkins. This native New Yorker touched and saved countless lives as an addiction treatment professional. Scott taught his children to love a good argument, to laugh, but most of all to be about something. He is survived by wife Jean, children Janet and Eli, his mother Bunny, grandmother Mae, brother and family Richard, Laura, Jenny and Brigitte. Memorial services will be held at Temple Emanuel, Kensington, MD., September 25th, at 11 AM. Donations may be made to Johns Hopkins Transplant Research Fund, 1 Charles Center, Baltimore, MD. 21201.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ASPEN PUBLISHERS INC., New York, a unit of Wolters Kluwer N.V., Europe's largest tax and legal publisher, acquired Accounting Research Manager, an Internet database of accounting and auditing information, form Arthur Andersen L.L.P., Chicago. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Striking Tableaus for a Clash of Cultures
description: The monumental flight of steps across the back of the stage has almost become a clich of contemporary set design, but Michael Yeargan's worked very well in the Mark Lamos production of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' which returned to City Opera on Saturday night after a two-year hiatus. The steps, and the two huge sets of screens that slid easily across the front and back of the stage to define the space of Butterfly's house, lent themselves to striking visual images supported by Robert Wierzel's fine lighting.

title: Israel, Jews and the Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, JACK
description: NEUMAN-Jack. Age 89, died September 21, 2002. Beloved and cherished husband of Anita. Loving father of Linda, Joe and Robert, and stepfather of Henry and Barbara. Cherished and loved Poppa to Susan, Jay, Mindi, Richard, Marilyn, Jon, Laura, Mark, Debbie, Jonathan, Danielle, Sharon, and Andrew. Devoted great-grandfather to Michael, David, Max, Sarah, Dylan, Sammy, Ilana and Jake. He was an ardent and respected handball player. His love will remain with us forever.

title: A Minor Celebration For Mets Hopefuls
description: Shortly before the start of Sunday afternoon's game against the Montreal Expos, with only a handful of fans in the Shea Stadium seats, the Mets lined up their minor league standouts at home plate. In a season that has been a lost cause on and off the field, when even the Mets' minor leaguers have been linked to the recent uproar about marijuana use, the Mets were allowing themselves a moment of hope.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELDE, EDITH CURTIS
description: VELDE-Edith Curtis. Age 97, formerly of Staten Island. Beloved wife of the late Donald L. Survived by brothers, William and Robert Curtis, sisterin-law, Isabelle van de Velde, niece, Leslie van de VeldeLaughren, nephews, Thom Velde and Peter Velde, and other nieces and nephews. Memorial service will be held at the Church of the Incarnation, September 30 at 4:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Ave., NYC 10016. Interment will be in Tremont, IL

title: 3 Retired Generals Warn Of Peril in Attacking Iraq Without Backing of U.N.
description: Three retired four-star American generals said today that attacking Iraq without a United Nations resolution supporting military action could limit aid from allies, energize recruiting for Al Qaeda and undermine America's long-term diplomatic and economic interests.

title: Taking Taiko, Japan's Big Drum, Into the Hip-Hop Age
description: The grimacing man wielding the wooden sticks was the Japanese taiko master Eitetsu Hayashi, who said he was offering a primitive prayer with his drumming.

title: Ripple Effect of Health Coverage
description: A new report from a federal advisory panel warns that when a member of a household lacks health insurance, the whole family may suffer the consequences, even if other members are covered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEROSA, MARTHA JANE BERRY
description: GEROSA-Martha Jane Berry, devoted and faithful wife of Alfred George Gerosa for fifty-three years, beloved mother of Martha Anne Gerosa and Nina Berry Gerosa, loving grandmother of Jason and Diana Fulton and Jesse and Asia McGrath-Gerosa, caring sister of Allen and William Berry, died peacefully at her home on September 20th, 2002, in the presence of her husband and children. She graduated from the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, Virginia in 1952 with a B.S. in Education. She was a very active member in her church and served for a number of years as the Treasurer of the Altar Guild. She was a passionate pianist and animal lover and not only supported groups which protected wildlife but also actively cared for animals in her backyard. She had great compassion for others in the community and received much pleasure from serving as a volunteer and Treasurer for Meals on Wheels, both because of the people with whom she visited and the people with whom she worked. A Memorial Service will be held on September 28th, 2002, at 2:30 P.M. at the Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea located on Route 9A in Elmsford, New York. The family requests that donations be given to Meals on Wheels, Municipal Building, 1 Heineman Place, Harrison, N.Y. 10528, or the Saw Mill River Audubon Society, 275 Millwood Road, Chappaqua, N.Y. 10514, in lieu of flowers.

title: Mind the Label 'Mental'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Day After
description: As soon as American troops are rolling through Saddam Hussein's palaces, the odds are that this holy Shiite city 100 miles south of Baghdad will erupt in a fury of killing, torture, rape and chaos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, FRANCES HUM PHREY
description: HOWARD - Frances Hum phrey. Age 88, of Washington, D.C., died Monday, September 23, 2002. Beloved mother of The Hon. William Ray Howard of Minneapolis, MN. and Anne Louise HowardTristani of San Juan, P.R. Grandmother of Andrew William Howard, Daniel Eaton Howard, Dennis Ray Hubert Tristani, William George Howard Tristani and Christine Frances Gloria Felisa Tristani. Predeceased by her brothers, Hubert H. Humphrey, former Vice President of the United States of America, Ralph Humphrey and her sister Fern Baines. Family will receive friends Thursday, September 26th from 5-8PM at Joseph Gawler & Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Ave., N.W. Memorial services will be held at a later date in Washington, D.C. and Minneapolis, MN. The family suggests that expressions of sympathy be made to the Frances Humphrey Howard Endowment, Hubert Humphrey Institute of Public Affairs, University of Minnesota, 301 19th Ave So., Minneapolis, MN. 55455.

title: Waiting to Hear From Saddam Hussein
description: On the packed flight from Damascus to Baghdad I kept rehearsing the message I hoped to deliver personally to Saddam Hussein: The only chance you have to avert the further devastation and suffering of your country and people is to allow unconditional and unfettered access by United Nations weapons inspectors. Period. Full cooperation. No gimmicks.

title: In Georgia, a Shot at Congress for 5 Blacks
description: If Democrats in Georgia have drawn the new lines for Congressional districts as cleverly as they think they have, the party will win four additional seats in the House in the November elections, and the state's delegation will include five African-Americans, the most ever from any state.

title: Blood Sport as Politics
description: An extraordinary event in England removed Iraq from the headlines: Four hundred thousand men, women and children, landowners, farmers, farm workers, farriers, blacksmiths, woodmen, a bishop or two, many famous names, many unknown, marched through the streets of London. They were protesting against the way the majority of city-dwelling, politically correct New Labor members of Parliament were neglecting the countryside, presiding over the slow death of farming and, in particular, proposing to make the country sport of fox hunting a criminal offense.

title: News Analysis; McCall's Finances May Hinge on Polls
description: For H. Carl McCall, the key to attracting the big campaign donations he desperately needs to wage a successful campaign for governor could lie in public polls scheduled to be released on Wednesday and early next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, CYNTHIA
description: KRAUSS-Cynthia. On September 22, 2002. Beloved wife of Stanley. Loving sister of Burton and Stanley Gilman. Devoted stepmother of Clifford Krauss and Hillary Albert. Cherished grandmother of Elyse, Nicole, and Melanie Albert. And a loving aunt. We will all mourn our loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSSY, GEORGE H.
description: BOSSY-George H. On September 18, 2002 at age 74. He was an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. He is survived by his wife Sanda, three sons, three grandsons, two sisters and a brother. A memorial service will be held Saturday, September 28th, 3 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: The DNA of a New Industry
description: Nearly all scientists are eager to see practical applications of our work. In biology and medicine, recent discoveries have fueled the development of vaccines, drugs and devices that provide enormous benefits to the public's health. Such advances increasingly depend on an active biotechnology sector that can take advantage of basic research.

title: PEREGRINE SYSTEMS SAYS IT FACES 2ND U.S. INQUIRY
description: Peregrine Systems, a business software maker under investigation by federal regulators over inflated sales figures, said in court papers yesterday that it was also being investigated by the Justice Department. According to a sworn statement filed by the chief financial officer, Ken Sexton, in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., the Justice Department began its investigation in August. Peregrine announced in May that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started a formal investigation after the company reported that sales had been inflated. Peregrine sought bankruptcy protection on Sunday to reorganize $607 million of debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESNER, LOUIS A.
description: WIESNER-Louis A. The Board of Directors and the staff of the International Rescue Committee note with great sorrow the passing of our dear retired colleague, Louis A. Wiesner. As a member of our Board and Executive Committee, Lou made extraordinary contributions to the IRC and the cause of refugees. We have been inspired by his selfless leadership, unwavering commitment and strong passion for helping the world's most vulnerable people. On behalf of the Board and staff, we extend our condolences to his wife, Elizabeth; his children, Jonathan, Liz, Meg and Andrew; his grandchildren, Britta and Spencer; his daughterin-law, Mary Ann, and his son-in-law, Dave. Winston Lord and James C. Strickler, M.D., Co-Chairmen of the Board

title: Guide for Mass Smallpox Vaccinations: Recipe With Missing Ingredients
description: The new guidelines for states on mass smallpox vaccinations are most notable for what was omitted: unanswered and often unaddressed are critical questions like timing, costs, feasibility and the multiple problems of preparing health care workers to conduct vaccinations and communicating the plans to the public.

title: Rising Star Lost in Russia's Latest Disaster
description: Nearly 6,000 feet up the Caucasus Mountains last Friday evening, Sergei Bodrov Jr., Russia's hottest young movie star, had wrapped up the second day of shooting on his latest film and was preparing to descend to the flatlands.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Accused Of Home Invasion
description: An off-duty correction officer was arrested yesterday on charges that he demanded money from a man at gunpoint as he tried to force his way into the man's apartment. The two men struggled inside the apartment as the victim's wife called out the window for help, the police said. The officer, Eddie Pena, 37, fled into the street empty-handed, the police said, and was caught by the police on the street a few blocks away from the apartment building, on West 162nd Street in Washington Heights. Mr. Pena joined the Correction Department in 1988. Jacob H. Fries (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Editor Charged With Stock Fraud
description: The longtime editor of the weekly Yiddish-language newspaper Der Blatt has been arrested on charges that he committed stock fraud in Florida, the authorities said yesterday. The editor, Jack Brach, 44, must return to Florida next week to face charges and will plead not guilty, his lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, said. Prosecutors in Fort Myers, Fla., said that in 2000, Mr. Brach persuaded an investor to buy $25,000 worth of stock in a company called Internet Technologies.com that Mr. Brach was involved with. But the stock certificate issued to the investor was worthless, prosecutors said. Mr. Brach, 44, of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was editor of Der Blatt, a weekly published in Williamsburg, as recently as July 2001, but the paper was closed yesterday and his current title could not be confirmed. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: IN-LAWS
description: NBC tonight at 8, Eastern and Pacific times; 7, Central time

title: Talented U.S. Women Are Spinning the Globe
description: While Pax Americana may be a thing of the past in men's basketball, the United States women's national team is busy asserting its global hegemony.

title: Gore Criticizes Bush Over Stance on Iraq
description: Former Vice President Al Gore accused the Bush administration of weakening the war on terrorism by turning the country's attention to Saddam Hussein. He also said the Congressional resolution on Iraq sought by President Bush did not do enough to seek international support.

title: Unilever Predicts 10% Earnings Growth
description: Unilever, the world's biggest food and soap maker, said today that sales growth accelerated in the third quarter, and predicted earnings per share would rise about 10 percent after an increase in advertising and the introduction of new products.

title: Columbia Halftime Gibe Irks Some at Fordham
description: Halftime satire by Ivy League bands is a routine hazard at football games. But Fordham University students and alumni say a Columbia University band announcer went too far Saturday with an off-color gibe, apparently about the priest sexual-abuse scandal.

title: National Briefing | Education: Room, Board And Cable
description: Undergraduates at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., can now watch cable television on computers in their dormitory rooms, in what administrators believe is a national first. For $120 a year, students get 20 cable stations via the Internet. They can even split their screens between term papers and television. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Joan Littlewood, British Theater Pioneer Of 'Oh What a Lovely War,' Dies at 87
description: Joan Littlewood, the producer, director and author who was one of the most important and original figures responsible for the regeneration of the British theater in the 1950's and 60's, died Friday in London at the home of her assistant. She was 87.

title: Spain Blames Basque Separatists for 2 Deadly Bombings
description: MADRID, September 24  A Spanish policeman was killed today and three other officers were injured in an explosion blamed on Basque separatists. The blast came only hours after two people, presumed members of the armed separatist group E.T.A. were blown up, apparently by their own bomb.

title: Judge Says Supplier Inflated Gas Prices In California Crisis
description: An administrative law judge concluded today that the El Paso Corporation illegally helped to drive up prices for natural gas in California during the state's power crisis in 2000 and 2001, the first time any federal regulatory official has determined there was widespread manipulation of energy supplies.

title: Five Children of Illegal Immigrants Return to School After the State Intervenes
description: Five children, who were removed from their schools here by the district superintendent three weeks ago because their mothers were in the United States illegally, were allowed to return to school today after state education officials intervened.

title: In Court, 'a Widow' Recalls 'A Band Called the Beatles'
description: It seemed not to matter that her late husband was among the icons of the 20th century, a member of perhaps the most influential rock group of all time, or that she herself has unquestioned celebrity. Yoko Ono was still asked her name, occupation and connection to John Lennon in a civil trial that opened yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: JDS Uniphase Predicts Lower Sales
description: JDS Uniphase, the maker of fiber optic components, said yesterday that its sales this quarter would be lower than previously expected as a slump in the telecommunications industry continues. The company said revenue would be $190 million to $200 million, down from a previous forecast of $210 million, and a 40 percent decline from the period last year. The market for JDS Uniphase's products, which include lasers used to transmit signals over fiber optic systems, has weakened after the financial collapse of several large communications companies like Global Crossing and 360networks. Shares of JDS fell 27 cents, to $1.87. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCAVULLO, MIRIAM DUFFY
description: SCAVULLO-Miriam Duffy. A kind and gentle woman, wife of the late Victor Kiernan Scavullo, on September 15th at home in Rye, New York. Her five children, eleven grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren deeply mourn her passing. Memorial donations may be directed to The Osborn, 101 Theall Road, Rye, New York 10580.

title: New in So Paulo
description: The Hilton Sao Paulo Morumbi is to open Sept. 30 in the city's financial center. The 485-room hotel will have a rooftop spa and health club with an indoor pool, two restaurants (one with a working artist's studio), two bars and 24-hour room service. Introductory rates of $159 a night, single or double, are available through Feb. 28, 2003. Information: (800) 445-8667 or www.hilton.com .

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, Page 12 of Money & Business on Sunday was interchanged with Page 12 of Sunday Styles in some copies. The error misplaced the continuations of three articles -- one about the economic uncertainty that is slowing businesses' spending; one about the murky line between companies' philanthropies and those of their chief executives; and one about the uses of humiliation in a new generation of television commercials. The full articles may be found online today, at nytimes.com/corrections.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Introduces Fee-Based Game Service
description: Yahoo, owner of the most-used Internet search site, introduced a fee-based video-game service for customers yesterday, featuring high-speed Internet connections. Users of the Games on Demand service can download and play more than 40 titles, including Zapper, Civilization III and Star Trek Armada II. Prices start at $4.95 for the rental of one game for three days, and rise to $14.95 to rent 10 games for 30 days, Yahoo said. The games are being offered through Yahoo's high-speed Internet-access service with SBC Communications Inc. The companies agreed earlier this month to sell the service over SBC's phone lines in 13 states. Yahoo is working toward gaining more revenue through subscriptions and less through advertising, it has said.

title: Publishers are trying to salvage magazines that many advertisers and readers have left behind.
description: GRUNER & JAHR USA'S last-ditch effort to save the venerable McCall's -- by hitching the struggling women's service magazine to the talk show host Rosie O'Donnell -- ended ignominiously last week when Ms. O'Donnell walked away from the joint venture after just 18 months.

title: Phone Number Links Moussaoui to Hijackers, Prosecutors Say
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24  Federal prosecutors offered today the most detailed evidence to date of a connection between Zacarias Moussaoui and the Sept. 11 hijackers, saying that investigators had found a business card at the Pennsylvania crash site of United Airlines Flight 93 bearing a telephone number that Mr. Moussaoui had called in the weeks before the terror attacks.

title: Suites Are Increasingly Doing Double Duty
description: A growing number of traveling executives are doing more than snoozing or watching pay-per-view movies in their hotel rooms these days. With companies tightening travel budgets as the economy continues to stumble, these travelers are holding business meetings or entertaining clients in their hotel suites instead of renting traditional spaces, hoteliers and corporate-meetings specialists say.

title: A Clue to Why Gays Play Russian Roulette With H.I.V.
description: Most young gay and bisexual American men who were found to be infected with the AIDS virus in a recent study were unaware of their infection, according to a finding reported recently at the 14th International AIDS Conference in Barcelona by Dr. Duncan MacKellar, an epidemiologist at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Swedes Are Out Sick Longer, and Budget Is Ailing
description: Anki Stenemyr, an energetic 58-year-old personnel manager in a Stockholm engineering consultancy, survived a sideswipe auto collision in July 2000 with no noticeable injuries but suffered lingering pain from whiplash.

title: BOEING TO BUY ALL OF PILOT TRAINING VENTURE
description: The Boeing Company said it had agreed to buy the stake held by its partner, FlightSafety International, in their joint venture to train pilots. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Boeing and FlightSafety, which is owned by Berkshire Hathaway, each contributed $100 million in assets in 1997 to form the joint venture, which now has 800 employees and $200 million in annual sales. FlightSafety, which is based at LaGuardia Airport, will focus on its main business, training pilots of business jets, regional aircraft and other planes smaller than those made by Boeing, said a spokesman, Roger Ritchie.

title: Former Chief of Time Warner Defends Sale to America Online
description: Gerald M. Levin, the former chief executive of Time Warner who agreed to sell the company to AOL, publicly defended his decision for the first time since he retired last spring amid mounting disappointment with the deal.

title: Radar-Guided Gratitude
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanwha Consortium Is Cleared to Buy Control of Insurer
description: An international consortium led by the Hanwha Group, a conglomerate with interests ranging from chemicals to real estate, won approval today to buy control of Korea Life Insurance from the government, which took it over in 1999.

title: The Umpires File Another Grievance
description: In the latest development in the dispute between the umpires and Major League Baseball, the World Umpires Association filed unfair labor practice charges against the commissioner's office yesterday. The dispute had previously produced a lawsuit by baseball against the umpires and two grievances by the umpires against baseball.

title: Authorities Say Experience Puts Them Ahead of Curve
description: Health officials in New York and New Jersey said yesterday that they were probably ahead of most of the nation in preparing for any form of bioterrorism, including a smallpox outbreak.

title: U.S. Guide for Mass Smallpox Vaccinations: Recipe With Missing Ingredients
description: The new guidelines for states on mass smallpox vaccinations are most notable for what was omitted: unanswered and often unaddressed are critical questions like timing, costs, feasibility and the multiple problems of preparing health care workers to conduct vaccinations and communicating the plans to the public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, FAYE DIAMOND
description: BERMAN-Faye Diamond. Born July 25, 1919, in Syracuse, NY. Devoted daughter of the late Kate (Kabaker) and Samuel C. Diamond. Beloved sister of the late Marian Sattinger, sister of Walter Diamond (Dorothy). Graduate of Syracuse University and the Maxwell School of Journalism; earned MA in history from the University of Rochester. She was a high school history teacher for many years in Rochester and taught labor history for the Cornell School of Labor Relations. Lover of human rights, The Constitution, reading, teaching, political discussions, The New York Times, National Public Radio, hardware stores, her typewriter, and letters to the editor. Predeceased by her dearly loved husband Harold Berman and son Richard. Survived by her daughter Ellin, son-in-law Michael Sheffery, beloved grandson Harold Sheffery, family dog Sandy, nieces Lisa Feldman (Sid), Andrea Sattinger, Diane Sattinger and family friend Randy Wilkins, Patricia Berman (Sam Englestadt), Boo Greenberg (David), and nephew Paul Berman (Yvonne), great-nieces and nephews Lindsay, Mark, Jacob, Mathew, Susan, Aly, Mac, Jonathan, Michael, Judy and Joanne. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to either the ACLU or The 12th Floor Nursing Unit, Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021, Attn: Donna Miele, RN.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend on Friday with the continuation of a review of exhibitions at the Museum for African Art in Long Island City, Queens, misstated the home country of the Mende people, creators of a helmet mask shown. They live in Liberia and Sierra Leone, not in Nigeria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONCIC, HELEN
description: SIMONCIC - Helen. Bovis Lend Lease is deeply saddened by the passing of Helen Simoncic, mother of our newly appointed CEO, Charles A. Bacon, III. Our sympathies are extended to Charlie and his entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARE, GERARD A.
description: O'HARE-Gerard A. Of Baldwin on September 22nd, 2002, after a valiant battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Annette P. Cherished father of Michele Novelli (Dominic), Amy Potter (Van), Timothy (Nancy), and Alicia and Megan O'Hare. Dear brother of Marie O'Hare Scesney and Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, S.J. Adored grandfather of Devon, Rhiannon and Aidan. Reposing at Fullerton Funeral Home, 769 Merrick Rd, Baldwin. Mass of Christian Burial St. Christopher's Church, Thursday 10:30 AM. Visiting Tuesday 7-9PM and Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Donations to Good Shepherd Hospice, 578 Mineola Avenue, Carle Place, New York 11514, would be appreciated.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Optimistic Survey On Travel Expectations

title: Venezuela Economy Falters, Despite Abundant Oil
description: When Pasquale Iachini and Alfonso Marozzi arrived here from Italy half a century ago, they started small, buying an old Fiat truck to transport dirt and supplies. Venezuela boomed in the years that followed, and their company, Yamaro Construction, grew into a leading builder of bridges, highways and other public projects.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOTTEL, BERTHA
description: MOTTEL - Bertha. Twelve years. Time flies. You have terrific grandchildren. Love, Ger

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHART, STEPHANIE
description: REINHART-Stephanie. The Board and staff of The Joyce Theater mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Stephanie Reinhart. We will miss her passion, knowledge and dedication to dancers and the art of dance. We send our deepest sympathies to her husband Charles, daughter Ariane and her family.

title: Safety Board Revises Its Report On '94 Plane Crash in Indiana
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it had revised its findings about a 1994 crash of a commuter plane in Roselawn, Ind., that killed all 68 people on board, softening its harsh criticisms of the European manufacturer of the aircraft and of French regulators.

title: Blunt Advice And No Pity Get Ratings For Dr. Phil
description: In his first week as host of his own daytime talk show, ''Dr. Phil,'' the psychologist Phillip C. McGraw made a verbally abusive mother cry. In another segment he told a lawyer who is suing a fast-food chain for making his client's daughter fat that his case was absurd.

title: Putting a Premium on Helmets
description: Motorcyclists who do not wear helmets have much higher hospital costs if they crash than those who wear them, a new study has found.

title: Brain Size Is Linked to a Gene
description: Most people have around 100 billion nerve cells in their brain. But the roundworm, down at the other end of the scale of animal complexity, figures out everything it needs to know about life with exactly 302 neurons. Researchers have now gained what seems to be a major insight into how nature builds brains of such different capabilities.

title: Front Row
description: The spring 2003 collections in New York officially came to a close on Sunday, and with them came an end to the visions of Woodstock that had kept fashion so woozily enthralled for two seasons. Gone are the peasant skirts, distressed leathers, chunks of turquoise, blouses made to look as though they should be put on Russian stacking dolls. Peasant chic, in all its reverence for the multicultural, has been replaced by a kind of white-bread chic, a set of references rooted in a fondness for ideas, institutions and habits distinctly American.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKIN, JESSE H.
description: BARKIN-Jesse H. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jesse H. Barkin, a cherished friend of UJA-Federation. With his wife, Ruth, Jesse expressed an admirable commitment to Jewish and other humanitarian causes. We extend our deepest sympathy to Ruth, and to the entire Barkin family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & CEO

title: Debt Vise Tightening Quickly For Indonesian Auto Venture
description: Tough enough to barrel over potholes with 12 people on board, the Kijang minivan built by Astra International was once the undisputed king of Indonesia's crowded, corrugated city streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, DR. NORMAN
description: NATHANSON-Dr. Norman. The Officers, Trustees and members of the Hollywood Golf Club note with sorrow the passing of their longtime friend and member, Dr. Norman Nathanson. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. Paul M. Weltz, President Burton J. Esrig, Secretary

title: Gift of Life: 2 Strangers, Yet 2 Twins
description: I am belly down on the operating table, a living donor: unpaid, unrelated and unknown to a person with leukemia near death in another hospital and waiting for my marrow. I banter with the surgeons who will extract marrow through needles probing my rear pelvic bone.

title: HONEYWELL SAYS IT SETTLED ASBESTOS CLAIMS
description: Honeywell International said it had settled asbestos claims brought against it in West Virginia, as the trial began in a state court. Honeywell is among more than 200 companies being sued by ex-employees who say they were exposed to asbestos. Terms of the settlement and the number of claims affected were not disclosed. Exxon Mobil, Owens-Illinois and the Union Carbide unit of Dow Chemical are among the other defendants in the trial, which began yesterday in Charleston, W. Va.

title: Peter Kowald, 58, Jazz Bassist And Traveler
description: Peter Kowald, the German bassist who worked in the realm of free improvisation and brought to his musicianship a lifetime of wide traveling and study and an admiration of interdisciplinary art, died early Saturday morning after a performance in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He was 58 years old, and died of a heart attack at the home of his friends and colleagues, the bassist William Parker and the dancer Patricia Nicholson.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I would hate to try to do this tomorrow.''

title: WAL-MART REPORTS SLUGGISH SEPTEMBER SALES
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, said yesterday that sales this month would rise near the lower end of its forecast as shoppers pare shopping lists to necessities like food and clothing. The company expects sales at stores open at least a year to increase 4 percent to 6 percent in the five weeks ending Oct. 4. Last week consumers at Wal-Mart discount stores bought more basic goods like household cleaners, underwear and medicine, the retailer said. Wal-Mart's same-store sales rose less than expected in July and August as customers spent less in the slow economic recovery.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Another Gesture From The North
description: Marking a new stage in efforts at reconciliation, North Korean athletes flew into the southeastern port city of Pusan to compete in the Asian Games, which start on Sunday. The North refused to take part in the 1986 Asian Games in Seoul and in the 1988 Olympics there. All four South Korean television networks interrupted regular programming yesterday to broadcast the Northern athletes' arrival. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Nasdaq Falls to 6-Year Low

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, Page 12 of Money & Business on Sunday was interchanged with Page 12 of Sunday Styles in some copies. The error misplaced the continuations of three articles -- one about the economic uncertainty that is slowing businesses' spending; one about the murky line between companies' philanthropies and those of their chief executives; and one about the uses of humiliation in a new generation of television commercials. The full articles may be found online today, at nytimes.com/corrections.

title: Good Times in Beverwijck, Before Logrolling Caught On
description: To celebrate the 350th anniversary of the founding of Beverwijck, which eventually became Albany, the Albany Institute of History and Art has organized an exhibition, "Matters of Taste: Food and Drink in 17th-Century Dutch Art and Life." It includes 55 Dutch and Flemish still life and genre paintings showing food and drink by such artists as Pieter de Hooch, Jan Steen and Adriaen van Ostade.

title: Internal Notes Questioned Qwest's Swaps
description: In testimony and in documents presented at a Congressional hearing today, current and former executives of Global Crossing and Qwest Communications International indicated that people in the companies had qualms about swaps of fiber optic network capacity that are now at the heart of federal investigations.

title: Yes, Improvising While Improvising
description: Most of Sonny Rollins's recent appearances in New York have been two-hour-plus affairs; waiting for him to warm up and start delivering on a high level is part of the ritual. That a saxophone player can still perform this kind of show in his 70's is remarkable; that it's expected of him makes one worry for his health.

title: New Director at Genetics Institute
description: DAVID BOTSTEIN will become director of Princeton University's Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics in July, taking over the position formerly held by Princeton's president, SHIRLEY M. TILGHMAN. A genetics professor at Stanford University, Dr. Botstein helped develop a method for mapping genes. Dr. Tilghman said a paper describing the technique was the beginning of modern human genetics. "Without it, we would not have had the human genome project," she said. Dr. Botstein said he hoped to develop project labs like the ones he created while he was at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in which students work on current research questions. Princeton is completing a building for the institute, which was established in 1999. JAMES BROACH is the institute's interim director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OELSNER, HOPE BRYAN
description: OELSNER - Hope Bryan. Died peacefully September 20 in Manchester, VT, at the age of 84. She was a beloved and wonderful wife, mother, grandmother, sister and aunt who devoted her life to her family. She was the cherished and very loving wife of Edward C. Oelsner Jr. for 50 years, until his death in 1990, and the well-loved and caring mother of four children, her sons Edward C. Oelsner III of New York City and James L. Oelsner of Littleton, Colorado, and her daughters Glenny Glenn of Centre Island, N.Y., and Lesley Oelsner of New York City, all of whom survive her. She was the fond grandmother of Hope, Wooderson and Edward Glenn, and of Elizabeth, Edward, Frederick and Benjamin Oelsner. She was born in Garden City, N.Y., the second of seven children of Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Bryan, and lived most of her life on the North Shore of Long Island, later moving to Lost Tree Village, North Palm Beach, FL, and summering in Arlington and then Manchester, VT. She is survived by her brothers James T. Bryan of Laurel Hollow, NY and the Venerable Robert A. Bryan of Ipswich, MA., and by her sisters Ruth Colgrove of Locust Valley, NY, Joy Bacon of New Paltz, New York, and Hazel Tracy of Londonderry, VT. She is survived also by 41 nieces and nephews. She was an avid amateur painter, pianist, and golfer. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Manchester Music Festival, P.O. Box 1165, Manchester Center, VT. 05255.

title: Advanced Placement Awards Are Announced
description: Two students from Manalapan High School in New Jersey are among 24 students nationwide to receive 2002 Siemens Awards for advanced placement in college, which are based on scores on advanced placement tests. The winners from the region include MATTHEW MEOLA and JULIE WU, Manalapan High School; EMILY R. RUSSELL, Choate Rosemary Hall, Wallingford, Conn.; and LEE-KAI M. WANG, Sutherland High School, Pittsford, N.Y. Each student will receive a $3,000 scholarship from the Siemens Foundation. Among the 18 math and science teachers honored by the foundation were SARAH R. WAGNER, Summit High School, Summit, N.J., and YVETTE S. BECK, Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx.

title: Mets Lose To Pirates And Recall Lost Season
description: The Mets and the Pirates had good reason if they did not recognize each other tonight. The last time they met they were opening the season at Shea Stadium, and the Mets were embarking on what they thought would be their path to the World Series. Pittsburgh won two of three games in that series to start a strong April as the Mets showed signs that they might not be as good as advertised.

title: Play Nicely, Everyone. In Nassau, It's the Law.
description: Kyle Christensen, 14, a high school freshman who has wrestled on school and after-school teams for years, thinks of himself as a good sport. But that does not mean he is all for the pledge of good sportsmanship that the Nassau County Legislature adopted on Monday.

title: Market Place; Tyco Took Profit on Bad Deal, Then Paid Bonuses to Executives
description: Tyco International claimed a profit on an investment even as the company lost money on it, a review of the transaction shows. Tyco then used that profit as an excuse to pay almost $24 million in bonuses to top managers.

title: Energy Company Tied to California Price Ruling Gave to Pataki
description: A Texas energy company found to have illegally manipulated markets in California has given $40,000 to Republican committees and Gov. George E. Pataki in the last two years. The contributions have come as the company seeks approval from the Pataki administration for an energy plant near Albany and an undersea pipeline.

title: Investors Discouraged by Increase in Unemployment Claims
description: There is some good news in the rising level of initial claims for unemployment insurance, a rise that has been more rattling than reassuring to investors recently.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Jeweler Settles Sex Harassment Suit
description: Bailey, Banks & Biddle, the jewelry retailer, has settled a sexual harassment lawsuit in which six female employees at the company's Westchester and Long Island stores complained that a store manager had groped them and that the company had done little about it. The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, where the workers' complaint had been filed, announced yesterday that the company had agreed to pay $250,000 to the women. It also agreed to reissue its policy on sexual harassment but admitted no wrongdoing. In March 2001, the women sued the retailer, claiming a manager, Kevin Mantell, had acted inappropriately. He worked in a Long Island store, was transferred to a Westchester location, and then was dismissed for reasons unrelated to the suit. Mr. Mantell said yesterday, ''Quite frankly, I don't care what happens'' to Bailey, Banks & Biddle. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Vice Chairman of Yeshiva Board Moves Up
description: RONALD P. STANTON, chairman and chief executive of Transammonia Inc., a fertilizer and petroleum gas trading company, was named chairman of Yeshiva University's board of trustees last week. Mr. Stanton has been vice chairman of the Yeshiva board for a decade and heads the university's $400 million capital campaign. Last year he was one of 10 donors to give more than $10 million at the start of the campaign. He graduated from City College of New York. The former chairman of Yeshiva's board, ROBERT M. BEREN, did not seek another term. Jennifer Medina

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Dell Announces Pact With Lexmark
description: The Dell Computer Corporation announced a deal with the printer maker Lexmark International yesterday to sell printers for home and business use. The companies did not disclose the financial terms of the agreement, which will begin with a strong push for Lexmark products during the coming holiday season, and will lead next year to Dell-branded laser and inkjet printers and the lucrative printer cartridges to keep the machines going. Dell has historically sold printers from several manufacturers with its systems, including Hewlett-Packard, which ended its long relationship with Dell earlier this year. Any increase to Dell's bottom line will be minimal, said Ashok Kumar, an analyst with US Bancorp Piper Jaffray, but could be more important over time as the market matures and ''Dell is forced to identify incremental revenue streams.'' John Schwartz (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Sells Shares
description: Brit Insurance Holdings plans to raise 204.2 million ($318 million) by selling stock, joining other Lloyd's of London insurers in asking investors for more money to finance new policies. Brit, which is based in London, will sell shares to existing investors at 64 pence each, 10 percent less than yesterday's closing price, the company said. Brit wants money to underwrite about 1 billion of premiums next year as prices increase.

title: National Briefing | Consumers: A Recall By General Motors
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling about 597,000 of its 2000-2002 Chevrolet Tahoe, Cadillac Escalade, GMC Yukon and Denali sport utility vehicles because passengers are pinching their fingers in the seats. The models, built from September 1999 through February, have a mechanical head restraint designed to fold when second-row seats are moved from upright to stowed position, said a spokesman, Jim Schell. Fourteen people, including 10 children, inadvertently pinched fingers in a slot in the upholstery while the headrest was folded down, the company said.

title: Children Evacuated From Ivory Coast School by French Troops
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Sept. 25  About 100 American schoolchildren trapped for six days in a rebel-held city here were evacuated today by French soldiers, as American Special Forces landed nearby in the capital.

title: Predators at the Door
description: Low-income homeowners can be easy targets for unscrupulous lenders. They are frequently forced to refinance their mortgages in the so-called subprime market, where interest rates are higher. Too often, such loans are also loaded with conditions -- including excessive fees and balloon payments -- that are potentially ruinous to the borrower. The victims, disproportionately, are the elderly, African-Americans and immigrants.

title: From the Thinnest of Wines, the Richest Spirit: Cognac
description: ''WE live very simply,'' Winston Churchill wrote to his wife in 1915 from his temporary quarters in Surrey, south of London, ''but with all the essentials of life well understood and well provided for -- hot baths and cold Champagne, new peas and old brandy.''

title: Schrder's Little Win
description: As an observer of the German body politic I have been reminded of the inert patients in the film ''Awakenings'' -- thanks to a new drug, they regain their old vitality for a brief moment, only to sink back into paralysis.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SINGAPORE: AUTOMAKER IN DEBT TALKS Executives from the Indonesian carmaker Astra International began talks in Singapore with a committee of leading creditors, including Mizuho Holdings, UFJ Holdings, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, ABN Amro and BNP Paribas , over restructuring Astra's $824 million in debt. In addition to asking for more time to pay, Astra wants creditors to let it invest more of its revenue in plants and products to compete better with foreign imports, according to Michael D. Ruslim, an Astra director. The company hopes to reach a new agreement by the end of next month. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Kyrgyzstan Seeks Reward For Helping Fight Terror
description: The president of Kyrgyzstan said today that his country was moving to strengthen democratic and human rights and should be rewarded with an increase in American aid for supporting the United States in its campaign against terrorism.

title: Shift in Tee Placement By European Captain
description: Thanks to a decision by Sam Torrance, the 10th hole at the Belfry will lose some of its mystique for this year's Ryder Cup.

title: The Daunting Smallpox Plans
description: The federal government's latest plan for dealing with a smallpox attack underscores how difficult that task would be. Officials suggested this week that even a single case of smallpox could trigger a nationwide program of voluntary vaccinations. The first priority would be to isolate and care for the sick and to vaccinate anyone who had close contact with them. But the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has also instructed state and local governments to prepare for emergency, large-scale vaccinations if needed.

title: 2 Democrats in House Upbraid Armey for Remarks About Jews
description: Two top House Democrats today criticized the majority leader, Dick Armey, for what they called disparaging comments toward Jews made at a campaign appearance last weekend. Mr. Armey dismissed the complaints as partisan politics.

title: Bure Is Hurt And Rangers Hold Breath
description: The biggest question facing the Rangers after their 2-1 overtime exhibition loss to the Devils last night at Madison Square Garden was the condition of Pavel Bure's right knee.

title: Gunmen Raid Hindu Temple Complex in India, Killing 29
description: Assailants opened fire with automatic weapons at a Hindu temple complex here on Tuesday night, killing at least 29 people and wounding 74, in a state still reeling from communal violence earlier this year.

title: Jitters for Securities Industry As Goldman Plans New Job Cuts
description: Limping toward the end of a dismal year, Wall Street firms are struggling to decide how many more employees to dismiss before dividing up their shrunken profits.

title: Jets' Offensive Line Struggles With Inexperience
description: When the Jets' offensive line lost its coach to a new job, its left guard to free agency and its right tackle to the expansion draft, the result was predictable: a unit in transition.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Deficit Deadline Extended
description: A slowdown in economic growth in the 12-country euro zone forced the European Commission to grant member states an additional two years to balance their national budgets. The commission's president, Romano Prodi, said members' budgets should be at or close to balanced by 2006 at the latest. The commission acknowledged that Germany might exceed the deficit ceiling this year, and warned that France would come dangerously close. The limit is 3 percent of gross domestic product. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: BUSH IS THWARTED ON WORKER RIGHTS
description: A moderate Republican senator gave Democrats the margin they needed today to keep President Bush from firing workers in a new Homeland Security Department, setting up a veto battle with an administration that sees such a transformation of federal work rules as vital to national security.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Hurricane Watch Issued
description: Tropical Storm Isidore was strengthening in the Gulf of Mexico south of Louisiana yesterday afternoon, and forecasters issued a hurricane watch for the Gulf Coast, from Cameron, La., to Pascagoula, Miss., meaning the storm could regain hurricane status and hit the area within 36 hours. The National Hurricane Center in Miami issued a projected course that would have the storm make landfall early tomorrow in southeastern Louisiana, then head inland. Some vulnerable coastal towns were evacuated, inland hotels began filling up and crabbers removed their traps from waters along the Louisiana coast.

description: ''Our case is simply this. Not that we take military action come what may. But that the case for Iraqi disarmament is overwhelming.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, ROBERT OLIVER
description: JORDAN-Robert Oliver, 69. Died peacefully at home on Sunday, September 22, 2002 surrounded by his family and friends after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Bob spent his professional life at Compton Advertising. After it merged with Saatchi & Saatchi, he became the chairman of the New York Office. Bob is survived by his wife, Susan Spindler Jordan, his daughter Alexandra Susan, his sons David Oliver and Harrison Edward of Weston, CT., and Nicholas Royal of St. Paul, MN., and one granddaughter. Bob was predeceased by his son, Robert Thomas Jordan, 34, a bond trader at Cantor Fitzgerald who died in last year's terrorist attack on the World Trade Center. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to the Rob Jordan Crew Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Dave Grant, Orange Coast College, 2701 Fairview Road, Costa Mesa, CA. 92628. A memorial service in celebration of the life of Robert O. Jordan will take place on Saturday, September 28, at 11AM at the Norfield Congregational Church in Weston.

Her ashes will be buried at Holy Trinity Church, Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, on November 9, 2002. In lieu of flowers, gifts in her memory may be made to the Massachusetts Audubon Society, 208 South Great Road, Lincoln, MA 01773.

description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged to a four-year low yesterday, as investors digested a surprise dissent from two Federal Reserve policy makers.

description: The Walt Disney Company said today that its board had endorsed a plan by the chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, to address problems at the ailing company.

title: LOWE'S TO OPEN 60 STORES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The Lowe's Companies, a leading home-improvement retailer, said yesterday that it planned to open more than 60 stores in the New York metropolitan area and northern New Jersey in the next five years. The expansion is expected to cost about $1 billion and create more than 10,000 jobs, the company said. Lowe's will open stores this week in Roosevelt Field, New York, and Holmdel, N.J., and begin construction on its first outlet on Staten Island. Lowe's is expanding in major cities to compete head-on with its larger rival, Home Depot Inc. Lowe's, based in Wilkesboro, N.C., plans to open 123 stores in the United States this year and 130 in 2003.

title: Argentina Says It Will Skip International Loan Payment
description: The Argentine economy minister announced today that his country would no longer use its diminishing foreign reserves to pay back loans from the International Monetary Fund and other multitlateral lenders and would thus miss at least one payment due next month, a move that pushes Argentina closer to a formal break with those bodies.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Unionist Deadline Comes Under Fire
description: Roman Catholic politicians attacked a new demand for the Irish Republican Army to disband by Jan. 18, saying it threatened to collapse Northern Ireland's four-year home rule. The criticism was in response to an ultimatum given last week by the Ulster Unionist Party. David Trimble, the Unionist Party leader and the province's first minister, imposed the deadline after pressure from hard-line constituents over the I.R.A.'s failure to disarm in accordance with the 1998 peace accord. Mr. Trimble and other unionists said they would resign if the deadline was not met. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: NATO Chief Urges Unity Despite Differences on Iraq
description: BERLIN, Sept. 25  The NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, today urged the allies not to let disputes over Iraq weaken their unity and strengthen their enemies.

His generous support and positive leadership will long be remembered and cherished. We extend our condolences to his wife, Joyce, and the entire Karp family. American Technion Society Evelyn Berger, President Lawrence S. Jackier, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvyn H.
