Bush's presidential campaign in 2000 while she was a producer for NBC.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: UNIONIST DEADLINE COMES UNDER FIRE Roman Catholic politicians attacked a new demand for the Irish Republican Army to disband by Jan. 18, saying it threatened to collapse Northern Ireland's four-year home rule. The criticism was in response to an ultimatum given last week by the Ulster Unionist Party. David Trimble, the Unionist Party leader and the province's first minister, imposed the deadline after pressure from hard-line constituents over the I.R.A.'s failure to disarm in accordance with the 1998 peace accord. Mr. Trimble and other unionists said they would resign if the deadline was not met.    Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Stephanie Reinhart Dies at 58; Fostered New Trends in Dance
description: Stephanie Reinhart, an innovative arts administrator who had an international impact in promoting new trends in contemporary dance as co-director of the American Dance Festival and as co-artistic director for dance at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 58 and lived in Durham, N.C., and Manhattan.

title: Restrooms for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Season; McCain Won't Benefit From Book Parties
description: A book party celebrating the new memoir by Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, is being sponsored by Frederick W. Smith, chairman and chief executive officer of FedEx Corporation. FedEx, the largest all-cargo air carrier in the world, also ranks among the top transportation lobbying forces in Washington. The panel that it lobbies, the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, was once headed by, you guessed it, Senator McCain, now the committee's ranking Republican.

title: Mexico City Journal; The Rich, Famous and Aghast: A Peep-Show Book
description: Prepare for a photographic journey through Mexico's twilight zone. It is a world lit by ballroom-size chandeliers, with walls draped in bright Asian silks and floors covered with Arab rugs. It is cluttered with stuffed safari animals and teddy bears, Roman Catholic icons, golden Buddhas and statues of smiling black slaves.

title: The Dissent of Schrder and Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: DEFICIT DEADLINE EXTENDED A slowdown in economic growth in the 12-country euro zone forced the European Commission to grant member states an additional two years to balance their national budgets. The commission's president, Romano Prodi, said members' budgets should be at or close to balanced by 2006 at the latest. The commission acknowledged that Germany might exceed the deficit ceiling this year, and warned that France would come dangerously close. The limit is 3 percent of gross domestic product.

title: Latin American Cuisine Takes to the Stage
description: YOU don't have to look very far in the theater district to find fabricated, artificial, soulless restaurants that nonetheless pack in the crowds. Why not? ''Cats'' also ran forever.

title: Sports of The Times; At Little Wofford, Big Challenges
description: EARLY on, my father passed on a maxim well known to pool sharks and golf hustlers: never beat a man by more than you have to.

title: In Chelsea, Some Fish Stews Among the Pork Chops
description: THEY sit at the counter with their sunglasses pushed up on their heads, baggy shirts covering guns, radios, handcuffs. They eat rice, beans, pork chops, sliced avocado. They sit at the tables shoveling it in, tall uniformed men in shiny boots and the creased caps of the highway patrol or mutt-faced beat walkers in rumpled blue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIBUNO, MARIO P.
description: TRIBUNO - Mario P. Of Princeton, New Jersey, formerly of Sands Point, New York, died Monday, September 23, in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Mario retired in 1980 as CEO of GB Raffetto Inc. He is survived by his wife, Marie Louise, son Robert of Cedar Rapids, daughter Diane of Auckland, New Zealand and three grandchildren. Services 11 AM Friday at St. Matthews Catholic Church in Cedar Rapids. Contributions to Hospice of Mercy, 701 10th St., SE, Cedar Rapids, IA. 52403-1292.

title: Abortion Pill Slow to Win Users Among Women and Their Doctors
description: Two years after the abortion pill was introduced in the United States, abortion providers say that only a small percentage of women seeking abortions are using it and few doctors outside of abortion clinics are offering it.

title: Deloitte's Chief To Step Down Next Spring
description: The chief executive of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, one of the four remaining large accounting firms, told his partners yesterday that he would step down next year.

title: NUMBER OF PEOPLE LIVING IN POVERTY INCREASES IN U.S.
description: The proportion of Americans living in poverty rose significantly last year, increasing for the first time in eight years, the Census Bureau reported today. At the same time, the bureau said that the income of middle-class households fell for the first time since the last recession ended, in 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOURAN, DANIEL P.
description: McGOURAN-Daniel P. Age 60, of Ramsey, NJ, formerly of Leonia, NJ on September 22. Husband of Margaret ''Pat'' McGouran, father of Suzanne, Daniel and Peter. Father-in-law of Rachel. Grandfather of Matthew and Kevin. Brother of Michael. V.P. of Raymond James & Associates. Visiting Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM at the Frank A. Patti & Kenneth Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main St, Fort Lee. Mass at 10AM St. John R.C. Church, Leonia, NJ. 201-944-0100.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Gun and Drug Raids
description: A hundred people were arrested on charges of selling drugs and firearms during overnight raids at their homes in 39 towns in Bergen County and in Paterson and Passaic in Passaic County, the authorities said. ''This puts a major dent in drug distribution and drug dealing in Bergen County,'' the Bergen County prosecutor, John L. Molinelli, said after the suspects were arraigned in a makeshift court at an armory in Lodi. Mr. Molinelli said a task force of local, county, state and federal law enforcement agencies began undercover drug purchases in June after the police in several Bergen towns reported increases in illegal drug sales in their communities. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Campaign Season; Cheney's Travel Budget Raises Eyebrows
description: Vice President Dick Cheney's staff says he needs an extra $100,000 for his travel budget for ''additional unplanned official trips.''

title: Schrder Uses London Visit To Try to Fix Rift With U.S.
description: With German ties to Washington corroded by his opposition to war on Iraq, the newly re-elected chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, flew to London tonight, apparently to ask Prime Minister Tony Blair to help mend Berlin's deepest trans-Atlantic rift in years.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: U.S. Indicts Rebel Leader
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft announced the indictment on drug charges of Carlos Castao, the head of Colombia's outlawed United Self-Defense Forces paramilitary group. Reuters reported that Mr. Castao offered to turn himself in but United States officials were skeptical. ''If he wants to turn himself in that's great,'' said a senior State Department official. ''But Pablo Escobar used to make those statements, too,'' he said, referring to the drug kingpin who was shot dead by the police in 1993. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: Around Town

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: COLOMBIA: U.S. INDICTS REBEL LEADER Attorney General John Ashcroft announced the indictment on drug charges of Carlos Castaño, the head of Colombia's outlawed United Self-Defense Forces paramilitary group. Reuters reported that Mr. Castaño offered to turn himself in but United States officials were skeptical. "If he wants to turn himself in that's great," said a senior State Department official. "But Pablo Escobar used to make those statements, too," he said, referring to the drug kingpin who was shot dead by the police in 1993.    Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Dead End
description: I happened to be in Israel on Sept. 11, 2001, and on Sept. 12 went to the Israeli Defense Ministry to talk to security experts there about what Israel had learned from dealing with Palestinian suicide bombers that might help America. The main lesson, they said, was this: In the end, the only people who can effectively stop suicide bombers are those in the community they come from. Only if their political and spiritual leaders delegitimize suicide bombing, only if their security forces and intelligence agencies are mobilized to prevent it, can it really be stopped. Israel, they told me, could never penetrate Palestinian society the way Palestinians could. Therefore, the ultimate task for Israel was to find the right pressures and incentives to get the Palestinians themselves to stop the bombings.

title: Lynn Talks Good Game, And Giants Respond
description: Graduate assistants in college football make fast-food money for double-shift workloads, and Dick Tomey, the head coach at the University of Arizona, wondered how Johnnie Lynn would respond. It was 1987, Lynn had just ended an eight-year N.F.L. playing career with the Jets, and he was being offered a job usually filled by unmarried 22-year-olds who were not good enough to play professionally.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Ericsson Demonstrates Phone Technology
description: Ericsson has demonstrated mobile-phone technology capable of switching between existing cellular networks and faster so-called third-generation systems, a spokesman, Mads Madsen, said. On Monday, Ericsson demonstrated a dual-mode handset to Telia A.B., Sweden's biggest phone company, and to Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., Mr. Madsen said. Hutchison, which is based in Hong Kong and has invested $16 billion in faster wireless licenses, plans to start offering such services in Europe this year. ''We think we're the first to do this,'' Mr. Madsen said, confirming a report that appeared yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. Ericsson last year began offering handset technology to other manufacturers after merging its mobile-phone business with that of Sony.

title: Judges Back Rule Changes For Handling Class Actions
description: The top policy-making body for the federal judicial system today endorsed changes to the rules for class-action lawsuits that are intended to protect individual plaintiffs from becoming trapped in a legal process that may not serve their best interests.

title: U.S. Sends 200 Troops to Aid Americans Trapped in Ivory Coast Violence
description: The United States sent about 200 troops on their way today to this West African nation, where 100 American schoolchildren have been trapped in a rebel-held central city since Thursday.

title: Leon Hart, 73, Massive End And Heisman Trophy Winner
description: Leon Hart, who won the 1949 Heisman Trophy as a massive end at Notre Dame and played on Detroit Lions teams that won three National Football League championships, died yesterday at a hospital in South Bend, Ind. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, EUGENE
description: SANDLER-Eugene. The Officers, Directors, Administration and Staff of Gurwin extend deepest sympathy to Julian Sandler, member of our Gurwin Jewish-Fay J. Lindner Residences Board of Directors, on the loss of his beloved father, Eugene, a resident of Gurwin. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Martin Eglow, President, Lindner Residences Lawrence Simon, President, Gurwin Center Joseph Gurwin, Chairman Gurwin Center Herbert H. Friedman, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, FRANCES
description: SIMON - Frances. Beloved wife of the late Nat Simon. Loving mother of Leslie Simon-Plumlee, EsteLee Price, Michael and Jerry Simon. She was a longtime owner of the Penguin Restaurant in NYC. She will be remembered as a woman who lived and died with style, grace, beauty and dignity. Graveside services Thursday, September 26, at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ.

title: Giambi Hits Two Homers, Setting Mark For Brothers
description: John Giambi reared his sons on tales of Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris, the larger-than-life home run heroes he read about in newspapers growing up in West Covina, Calif. His sons did not always hit home runs, but they have grown up to combine for the greatest power season ever by brothers. In doing so, they passed another Yankees legend.

title: Civilian Board on Police Misconduct Defends Itself on Claim That It Is Soft
description: Officials of the Civilian Complaint Review Board defended the agency yesterday against allegations by a former employee who told a legislative hearing that the panel is ineffective, tolerates racial discrimination and is biased toward the police.

title: Miscellany
description: The Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, laid off 14 employees, or 6.5 percent of its total staff of 216.

title: Airline Food That's Best Sampled With Tongue in Cheek, And 6 Special Pastas at a Time
description: Christian Delouvrier, the executive chef at Lespinasse, 2 East 55th Street, acknowledged that he was inspired by airline food -- the sort found on the Concorde -- to come up with Le Quicker (bottom), a new one-plate lunch served Wednesday through Friday. A big square porcelain plate is fitted with dishes holding small portions of soup, salad and a main course, served all at once. Lobster bisque, bean salad and John Dory with mushrooms was one variation last week. Dessert comes separately, in a full-size serving. Everything is $28.

title: Wines of the Week
description: Driving down Napa Valley's main road, Highway 29, this time of year is like walking into a bakery. The sweet, buttery smell of fermenting grapes permeates the air, reminding me of blackberry pies fresh from the oven.

title: 'SPIDER-MAN' PUBLISHER SEES HIGHER PROFITS AND SALES
description: Marvel Enterprises Inc., the publisher of comic books including ''Spider-Man,'' increased its third-quarter and full-year profit and sales forecasts after an agreement with Vivendi Universal to develop games. The agreement includes an upfront payment and is primarily responsible for an $8 million increase in Marvel's forecast for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization in both the third quarter and full year, the chief executive, Peter Cuneo, said. Marvel, which is based in New York, expects net income in the third quarter of $3 million to $5 million, up from a prior forecast of $3 million to $4 million, the company said. Full-year profit is expected to be $18 million to $21 million, up from $18 million to $20 million, excluding $4.6 million of costs recorded in the first quarter, Marvel said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bloody Sunday Inquiry Moves To London
description: A four-year inquiry into the Bloody Sunday killing of 14 civilian protesters in 1972 by British troops in Northern Ireland moved to London to hear testimony from British soldiers who say their lives would be at risk in the province. Most of the 300 soldiers scheduled to give evidence will not be identified by name, except for well-known senior officers. The first military witness, retired Gen. Frank Kitson, insisted that British troops ''knew perfectly well that they could not under any circumstances just shoot people.'' Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: After Storm, Scholar Starts at Princeton With a Whisper
description: Cornel West hurried into the seminar room with a fat volume of Plato tucked under his arm, nodded to the students and without ceremony started to talk about Plato and his mentor, Socrates. He leaned forward, as if to share a secret, and in a voice no louder than a whisper explained that Socrates had decided to leave his father's craft of stonemasonry to become ''a sculptor of men and women.''

title: New York by the Wineglass
description: IT'S early on a Thursday night in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and a handful of locals have gathered at D.O.C., a rustic little corner wine bar that resembles a farmhouse kitchen. At one table, a couple is playing cards. At another, one of the owners is flirting with several women, recommending dishes with dramatic gestures toward the hand-written menu, while at a third, a solitary woman is reading a magazine, sipping red wine and nibbling from a platter of Sardinian cheeses. A dog is tied up outside.

title: Article 2002092591765830328 -- No Title
description: Covering the Mets has become an experiment in the bizarre. They have been long out of it and baseball has become almost a secondary pastime around the team. Off days, though, can do wonders, and Manager Bobby Valentine was in an upbeat mood before Tuesday's game in Pittsburgh.

title: Networks and I.O.C. To Discuss Bidding
description: Network officials will meet with the International Olympic Committee's marketing commission today in Lausanne, Switzerland, to discuss the process for bidding on the television rights to the 2010 Winter Olympics and possibly the 2012 Summer Games.

title: Proposal for Ailing Amtrak Cuts 6 Long-Distance Trains
description: House Republicans who have been holding up money for Amtrak for the fiscal year that begins next week have a new plan that could kill six of the railroad's 41 long-distance routes.

title: Online Fans Start to Pay the Piper; Praise From Some for Subscription Services to Download Music
description: Recently, more than a few music fans who were diehard advocates of swapping songs illegally through Napster and its clones have found themselves doing something they never would have predicted: subscribing to Internet services that abide by copyright laws and paying for the music they download.

title: Appointment at Newark Institute
description: The New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark has appointed a longtime Johns Hopkins University professor, WILLIAM C. HUNTER, to lead the biomedical engineering department it started in July 2000. Professor Hunter is known for his research on heart contractions. His expertise lies in using complex engineering tools like applied radiology and magnetic resonance imaging to study the human heartbeat. Lia Miller

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, MARY
description: SPRUNG-Mary, 92. In Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late Murray Sprung, devoted mother of Peggy and John, mother-in-law of Richard Neimeth and Riki Sprung, sister of Sam Norkin, grandmother of Deborah, Pamela, Amy, Lisa, Jason and Larry and great-grandmother of 12. A camp director, teacher and care giver, her kindness and good deeds live on. She was the queen of our hearts, which are heavy with loss.

title: Rams Are Searching for a Victory and Direction
description: With a nod of respect to the Dallas Cowboys, the first America's team, and to the Atlanta Braves, who have also dared to wear the moniker, the St. Louis Rams looked most fit to carry the tag into the new millennium.

title: Blair Says Iraqis Could Launch Chemical Warheads in Minutes
description: Britain asserted today that the Iraqi government of President Saddam Hussein could launch chemical or biological warheads within 45 minutes of an order to use them and acquire a nuclear weapon in one to five years.

title: Three for Two
description: Avalon Resorts is offering every third night free at its seven properties the Caribbean and Gulf of Mexico. In Cancun, for example, there are three beach-front choices: the Avalon Bay ($59 a person a night and up), the Avalon Grand ($79 a person and up) and the Baccara (from $74 a person). At the Avalon Reef Club in Belize, rates start at $79 a person. It's $69 and up at the Avalon Excalibur in Acapulco and the Avalon Grand, in a rain forest in Panama. Except at the Baccara, these rates include all meals, domestic alcoholic beverages, tips and taxes. They are based on double occupancy, and children up to age 12 stay and eat free in the same room as two adults. Valid to Dec. 20, with some restrictions and blackouts; (800) 261-5014 or www.avalonvacations.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSA, AUGUSTINO R.
description: POSA-Augustino R. On September 24, 2002. Beloved companion of Allan Schwartz. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. Thursday, 102PM and 5-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Patrick's Cathedral, 51 Street and 5th Ave, Friday, 9:30AM. Entombment is to follow at Trinity Cemetery.

title: I.N.S. Ignored Possible Link Of Airport Killer to Terrorists
description: An Egyptian immigrant who went on a July 4 shooting spree at Los Angeles International Airport told immigration officials nearly a decade ago that the Egyptian authorities had accused him of being affiliated with a known terrorist organization, officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a professional wrestler's lawsuit claiming workplace sexual harassment gave an outdated name for her employer. It is World Wrestling Entertainment Inc., not World Wrestling Federation Entertainment Inc.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 25 Accused Of Insurance Fraud
description: Twenty-five people who state authorities said were involved in two auto insurance fraud rings were charged yesterday with cheating insurance companies out of more than $200,000. The state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, said yesterday that the defendants had planned accidents or created false accident reports, then sought treatment for fake injuries. The defendants are accused of filing more than $725,000 in false bills, officials said, but little more than $200,000 was paid out. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: It's the Sweetest Spot, Where Dessert Comes First
description: Sugar is sexy, Jerry Suqi said, as if he were revealing a simple truth, not pitching a product. Sugar, he added, is sinister.

title: Teacher Shortages Are Usually a Myth
description: EDUCATION analysts often say the nation faces a looming teacher shortage. Growing enrollment and the retirement of baby-boom teachers will aggravate the need, as will a new federal law that bans unqualified teachers.

title: Shortcuts To a Standard
description: THERE was a time when a homey Provenal dish of cooked fish and vegetables with aioli -- the region's garlicky mayonnaise -- intimidated me. First of all, the mayonnaise was handmade. Second, the fish used in the classical dish was salt cod. Twenty years ago, both were beyond my abilities, or so I thought, and I would not have dared to break with tradition. Who was I to mess with the canon?

title: Hearings Set On Measure To Promote Digital TV
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee will hold hearings today on a bill intended to spur the development of digital television. It would render most current televisions obsolete by 2007 and require the Federal Communications Commission to support copy-protection technology designed to prevent consumers from copying and redistributing digital television programs.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Celebrity's Sisters Feared Kidnapped
description: Two sisters of the celebrity Thalia, one of Mexico's most popular entertainers and the wife of Sony Music's chairman, Tommy Mottola, were ambushed last weekend after leaving a play, according to witnesses. Ernestina Sodi, left, and Laura Zapata have been missing since Sunday evening, news reports said, but their family has not filed a kidnapping report with the police. Kidnappings have increased in Mexico, and victim's relatives routinely avoid filing reports out of fear that law enforcement officers are involved. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: North Korea Forms Zone for Capitalism
description: In the most significant reversal of economic policy since North Korea was founded, that Communist nation has announced the establishment of an autonomous capitalist investment zone near its border with China that would operate free of central government interference for 50 years.

description: To the Editor:
