description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, HELEN K.
description: BRODSKY-Helen K. On September 23, 2002, of West Hempstead, NY. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Devoted mother of William and Joan Brodsky, Tina and David Bellet, Howard and Kathy Brodsky. Adored grandmother of Michael and Aleta; Stephen and Elizabeth; Jonathan; Suzanne and Stacey; Benjamin, Jacob, David and Peter. Cherished great-grandmother of Isabel, Matthew, Joshua and Mira. Services on Wednesday, 9:15 A.M. at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: Times Square, With Ketchup; No Cloning, Lots of Razzle-Dazzle at New McDonald's
description: It is commonplace for new restaurants in New York to hire publicists, to have the tryout periods known as soft openings and to wallow in industrial materials, plasma screens and bare brick walls. So the surprise at the splashy 17,000-square-foot restaurant in Times Square that officially opens today with such pretensions (but without a red velvet rope) is the name over the door: McDonald's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZIG, WILLIAM F., M.D.
description: HERZIG-William F., M.D. Loving husband, father, grandfather, great grandfather. Survived by his loving wife, Rita Wynne Herzig; son Dr. Steven Herzig and his wife, Dr. Cathy; daughter Karen Herzig Sherman and her husband, Howard; grandchildren Melissa, Robin, Amanda, Shoshana and Jeremy; and great grandchildren Samantha and Alison. He was born September 27, 1909. He was a graduate of the University of Vienna Medical School in Austria, 1938 and a gastroenterologist for 50 years at Beth Israel Medical Center. He will be remembered as a man of integrity, a brilliant and caring doctor who was always available to help those in need. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, Plaza Memorial 91st and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Palestinians March in Gaza After an Israeli Raid Kills 9
description: Thousands of Palestinians marched in the streets here today in angry mourning for nine people killed before dawn in an Israeli infantry raid, the deepest incursion into this sprawling city in the two-year conflict.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: TORRICELLI OPPOSES RELEASE OF MEMO

title: Seven Characters in Search of a Reason
description: The revival of Michael Weller's ''Split'' is a peculiar theatrical enterprise. For one thing, when the play was first performed in 1978, it was a one-act comedy; two years later, a second one-act was affixed to the beginning, almost as an introduction or a prequel, and with separate titles the two were presented together under the rubric ''Split.'' So to some extent the current production by the Broken Watch Theater Company, now at the Lion Theater on Theater Row, is adopting a new identity for ''Split,'' presenting it as a single, unified work. For another thing the director, Drew DeCorleto, has for some reason switched the two acts so the action now proceeds chronologically in reverse.

title: Tropical Storm Bearing Down on Gulf Coast
description: Tropical Storm Isidore gained speed and a little muscle as it continued its northward trek across the Gulf of Mexico this afternoon and a predicted landfall after midnight in southeastern Louisiana, the center of a hurricane watch for 300 miles of gulf coast, from Cameron, La., to Pascagoula, Miss.

title: Vaccinating America
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutors Say Business Card Ties Suspect to Flight 93 Pilot
description: Federal prosecutors today offered the most direct evidence to date of a connection between Zacarias Moussaoui and one of the Sept. 11 hijackers, saying investigators had found a business card at the Pennsylvania crash site of United Airlines Flight 93 bearing a telephone number that Mr. Moussaoui had called in the weeks before the attacks.

title: A Pink Garlic From France, So Strong That Others Pale
description: Eat a dish heavily seasoned with the pink French garlic sold under the brand name Ail Rose de Lautrec, and those within breathing distance may not realize it's a connoisseur's garlic. But using it in cooking makes a difference. The pink-skin cloves are crisp and juicy but somewhat less sticky than everyday white-skin garlic, and they keep well. The flavor is extremely sharp. All but one layer of skin is removed before the garlic is shipped, so peeling is quick. Fairway sells bunches of about 17.5 ounces, usually seven bulbs, for $5.99, and 2.2-pound bunches for $9.99. The smaller bunches are also being sold at Balducci's, Hay Day and Sutton Place Gourmet markets, for $11.99. In the coming weeks, they will be at Whole Foods in Chelsea, and at Agata & Valentina and Citarella.

title: President's Vocabulary Now Omits Gore's Name
description: Perhaps it is a dislike so pure that he dares not speak its name. Perhaps President Bush considers a dispute with his 2000 presidential opponent beneath him. Or perhaps, as the White House insisted, the president meant absolutely nothing by a noticeable omission.

title: Federal Advisory Panel Backs New Cancer Drug
description: A panel that advises the Food and Drug Administration recommended approval yesterday of AstraZeneca's cancer drug Iressa, despite concerns by the agency's staff about the drug's effectiveness.

title: AIRLINE CONSIDERS WAYS TO CUT NONLABOR COSTS
description: United Airlines is forming a task force to look at how to reduce nonlabor costs and generate revenue, Glenn F. Tilton, the new chief executive, said in a phone message to employees this week. While executives are negotiating with unions over labor concessions, the task force will look at how to wring money out of areas like network efficiency, technology and air traffic. The group, made up of four executives at United, will be assisted by consultants from McKinsey & Company. Mr. Tilton said that United's biggest rivals were ''examining the value they offer to customers,'' and that United had to do the same to keep up. The task force will report to a three-member review board that includes Jake Brace, the chief financial officer. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Attacks on Gays Upset Los Angeles Suburb
description: A heavy worry has settled over the normally carefree streets here after a gay man was attacked earlier this week by two men swinging a baseball bat and a metal pipe. The police say they believe the motivation for the beating was homophobia.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the failure of legislation proposed by Connecticut's two senators that would have temporarily halted federal recognition of new Indian tribes misstated the number of those currently recognized in the state. It is three, not two; as the article later noted, the Eastern Pequots were recognized recently.

title: 335 Yards. 6 Scores. Just a Game's Work.
description: The anatomy of an Ian Smart run goes something like this: wait for fullback T. J. Brocking to smack a defender, explode through a hole, break a tackle, run free.

title: Programming Helps BSkyB Pull Ahead Of Rivals
description: Hanging on the walls of British Sky Broadcasting's headquarters in West London are pictures of Bart Simpson and of Sarah Michelle Gellar of ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer.'' They are just two of the reasons B Sky B keeps signing up thousands of new customers while rival pay television companies across Europe are going under.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Charlie Palmer's Latest

title: On Daschle
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including interpretations of Tom Daschle's remarks on Iraq policy and complaints about magazine wine ratings.

title: Judge Orders Delay in Certifying Results of 2 Bronx Primary Races
description: Amid allegations of poll irregularities, a State Supreme Court justice ordered the City Board of Elections yesterday to delay the certification of the results of the Democratic primary in Bronx races for the State Senate and Assembly.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Smoking Ban Proposed
description: Mayor Thomas M. Menino of Boston is proposing a ban on smoking in all city workplaces, including bars, restaurants and universities. Mr. Menino said the plan, which would, in effect, ban smoking from almost all indoor places in the city, protects workers from the effects of inhaling second-hand smoke while at work. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed similar legislation last month for New York City. In 1998, Mr. Menino enacted regulations that restaurants must either partition off smoking areas or put them at least six feet away from eating areas. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Accounting at Xerox Is Under Inquiry
description: More than five months after it paid a $10 million fine to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission charge of fraudulent accounting, Xerox is back under investigation for the same accounting missteps.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Files On The Missing To Be Opened
description: Responding to longstanding requests from families of several hundred people presumed to have been kidnapped and killed during the military dictatorship of 1964 to 1985, the Ministry of Justice has agreed to open police records from that era. The government has already paid more than $10 million in indemnities to about 250 victims of official repression. The new policy of ''unrestricted access'' for relatives and human rights groups is intended to help them find clues to the fate of those who disappeared. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: AWARNING ON COMBAT SYSTEMS

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: More Telecom Services
description: China Mobile (H.K.) Ltd., one of the world's largest mobile-phone companies, is buying 300,000 phones equipped for fast data transfers as it prepares to begin a multimedia messaging service next month. The bulk order will enable it to buy handsets at a discount and resell them at ''favorable'' prices to ''mid- to high-value subscribers,'' the company said.

title: Cornucopia of New Statistics Shows City's Best and Worst
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg issued his report card for New York City's government yesterday, portraying it as having endured a difficult fiscal year, and at times even thriving. As a document, the report card, known as the Mayor's Management Report, said as much about Mr. Bloomberg, the manager, as it did about the city he steers.

title: Henson Called Up, Dressed Up and Left Behind
description: Drew Henson could have easily been in Detroit last Sunday. If Henson had stuck with football, he very likely would have been selected near the top of the National Football League draft. The Lions, looking for a quarterback with the third pick, might well have taken Henson instead of Joey Harrington. It could have been Henson taking the first snap in Ford Field history.

title: The Dissent of Schrder and Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; The Mosquito, Bypassed By the Buzz
description: THIS is the dawning of the age of anxiety, when there are so many threats looming that you have to think for a minute. Does an amber alert mean a child has been snatched or a sleeper cell is stirring?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the prospects for Food and Drug Administration approval for the cancer drug Iressa by AstraZeneca referred incorrectly to the term for its clinical trials. They are known as Intact trials, not ''intact''; the term is an acronym for ''Iressa nonsmall-cell lung cancer trials assessing combination therapy.''

title: Second Ruling Against U.S. Death Penalty
description: A federal judge in Vermont has ruled that the federal death penalty law is unconstitutional, saying the law denies defendants' rights to due process, allowing evidence and procedures that could not be used at trial to be used to sentence a convicted person to death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEINS, SYLVIA
description: ZEINS-Sylvia. On September 23, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Moe, loving mother of Wallace and Rosalind, cherished grandmother of Ariana, Dawn, Molly, Claude and Jed. Services Thursday, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Art Museum Outside Philadelphia Plans Move
description: The financially beleaguered Barnes Foundation filed court papers today asking for permission to move its remarkable Impressionist-laden art collection from its longtime Main Line suburban home to a new downtown building that would be constructed with $150 million in grants from two other foundations.

title: A Surplus of Grapes Is a Boon for Buyers
description: UNWANTED grapes left hanging on the vines, tanks full of last year's wine, wineries sold or for sale: it looks as if hard times have hit the California wine business. Yes, but sometimes looks can be deceiving.

title: The Dissent of Schrder and Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dissent of Schrder and Gore
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Leader Denounces Bush Remarks on Security as Partisan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, angrily accused President Bush today of using the Iraq issue for political fodder and said he should apologize.

title: Investors Discouraged by Increase in Unemployment Claims
description: There is some good news in the rising level of initial claims for unemployment insurance, a rise that has been more rattling than reassuring to investors recently.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Refugee Camp Population Nears 2,000
description: Almost 2,000 refugees are living in a camp at Sangatte in northern France that houses mainly Afghan and Kurdish immigrants attempting to reach Britain through the Channel Tunnel, according to French Red Cross officials. The camp was built in 1999 to accommodate about 900 refugees. It has been a bone of contention between France and Britain, and the two countries agreed in July to close the camp by early next year. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, HELEN VAN COURT
description: WILLIAMS-Helen van Court. On September 22, 2002, beloved daughter of the late Charles Chauncy Williams, and Helen Beryl Williams. A resident of The Isabella Home, retired Administrative Assistant at The Babies Hospital, Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, NYC. Member of The Ft. Washington Collegiate Church since 1961. Visitation at The Ft. Washington Collegiate Church, 729 West 181 St, on Thursday 10-11 A.M. Funeral service 11 A.M. Interment Mount Hope Cemetery.

title: Balking at a Compromise That Might Save a Deal
description: In his long uphill battle to acquire DirecTV, Charles W. Ergen, the chairman of EchoStar Communications, may have one last slim chance to salvage his satellite television deal. So why is he reluctant to take it?

title: AOL Time Warner and Disney Revive Talks on News Venture
description: Trying to conserve cash, AOL Time Warner and the Walt Disney Corporation have revived long-running talks about combining their CNN and ABC News operations into a joint venture in an effort to cut costs, people involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: It's Time To Get Real, Starry Eyes
description: The actress Debra Eisenstadt, who starred in the Off Broadway and film versions of David Mamet's ''Oleanna,'' made the video feature ''Daydream Believer'' as her graduate thesis at the New School University in Manhattan. It's the best kind of homemade movie, created with skill, modesty and a pleasing awareness of what works in an ultra-low-budget format that tends to be performance and storytelling, rather than visual expressiveness and technical polish.

title: A Mock Emergency at Indian Point Follows the Script
description: A fake nuclear disaster unfolded today in a series of fake news briefings conducted against a stately blue curtain that looked borrowed from the set of ''The West Wing.'' Only it was not the White House under siege, but the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant and its surrounding communities.

title: Some Suburban Restaurant Chains Are Learning About Life in the City
description: Elizabeth Ikner, a manager of the Chili's restaurant nestled in a busy strip of offices and stores in the center of this city's rejuvenated downtown, pivots left, takes a stutter-step and claims some space with a strong move forward, dodging busboys and waitresses. It is 4 o'clock in the afternoon, and the restaurant is nearly empty of customers, but still the workers have little room to maneuver.

title: Full Disclosure for Judicial Candidates
description: The Constitution requires the Senate to give its advice and consent on nominees for federal judgeships. But in the case of Miguel Estrada, the Bush administration's choice for a vacancy on the powerful United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, the Senate is not being given the records it needs to perform its constitutional role. The Senate should not be bullied into making this important decision in the dark.

title: It's got (ho-hum) tradition on its side. Now Hershey wants to whip up some enthusiasm.
description: DAYS after the end of a bitter takeover battle that riveted Wall Street, Hershey Foods is drastically changing how it talks to Main Street, introducing ads asserting that it's the chocolate, stupid.

title: Memorial for Holly Solomon
description: A memorial service for Holly Solomon, the art dealer who died in June at the age of 68, will be held tomorrow at 6 p.m. at the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street.

title: DRUG MAKER SAYS BLADDER TREATMENT WORKS WELL
description: Indevus Pharmaceuticals said its experimental treatment for overactive bladder worked well in a study, setting off a 57 percent increase in its stock price. Indevus said it planned to seek federal approval during the second quarter of next year for the bladder therapy, called trospium. The company, based in Lexington, Mass., said trospium works by relaxing smooth muscle tissue in the bladder, helping decrease contractions that can cause problems like incontinence.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: JEWELER SETTLES SEX HARASSMENT SUIT

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHLACHET, PETER
description: SCHLACHET-Peter: Beloved forever remembered, forever missed, forever adored, your Ann

title: Man Missing After Swim In East River
description: A man was missing last night after he and a college friend tried to swim early yesterday from the banks of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to Manhattan and back again, the authorities said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed to Keep Rates Steady With Rare Dissenting Votes

title: Yoko Ono Says Ex-Aide Stole Tapes
description: Yoko Ono sat on the witness stand in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday as her lawyer showed a jury home videotapes of her and John Lennon playing with their son, Sean, on a Long Island beach in 1980.

title: New Director at Genetics Institute
description: DAVID BOTSTEIN will become director of Princeton University's Lewis-Sigler Institute for Integrative Genomics in July, taking over the position formerly held by Princeton's president, SHIRLEY M. TILGHMAN. A genetics professor at Stanford University, Dr. Botstein helped develop a method for mapping genes. Dr. Tilghman said a paper describing the technique was the beginning of modern human genetics. ''Without it, we would not have had the human genome project,'' she said. Dr. Botstein said he hoped to develop project labs like the ones he created while he was at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in which students work on current research questions. Princeton is completing a building for the institute, which was established in 1999. JAMES BROACH is the institute's interim director. Karen W. Arenson

title: Dynegy to Pay $3 Million In Settlement With S.E.C.
description: Dynegy, one of the nation's largest energy traders, agreed today to pay $3 million to settle accusations that the company had used a series of off-balance-sheet partnerships to doctor its financial statements and mislead investors.

title: Israel Resists New U.N. Measure to End Siege
description: The United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution before dawn today demanding that Israel lift the five-day siege of Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah, but Israel took no action, saying it had ''difficulty in accepting'' elements in the measure.

title: Rumsfeld Urges NATO To Set Up Strike Force
description: NATO defense ministers today gave broad support to American proposals for a rapid reaction force after Washington's warnings that a NATO incapable of rapid, modern, mobile warfare would become increasingly irrelevant to the United States.

title: WYNDHAM IS SELLING 13 HOTELS TO CUT DEBT
description: Wyndham International Inc., the hotel company controlled by investors Thomas Lee and Leon Black, agreed to sell 13 hotel properties in the United States to Westbrook Hotel Partners IV for about $447 million to reduce its debt. The properties, operating under the names Doubletree, Radisson, Hilton and Embassy Suites, are various cities including Minneapolis, Philadelphia, and Chicagom a spokesman, Andrew Jordan, said. Wyndham expects to complete the sale within three to four months. Wyndham, which is based in Dallas, is working to cut obligations related to expansion in the 1990s that left it with $3.32 billion in debt at the end of the second quarter, Mr. Jordan said. Wyndham has been selling assets and this month finished refinancing $287 million of debt maturing in 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBOTT, WILLIAM R.
description: ABBOTT-William R. On September 20. Beloved husband of Helen, devoted father of Linda and Joan. Beloved grandfather of Chloe and William. Memorial service St. George's Church, 16 St and Rutherford Pl, NYC, Friday, September 27, at 2 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, IRA SAMUEL
description: GOLDBERG - Ira Samuel. Born December 4, 1928 in the Bronx, to Philip and Pauline. Married the late Malka Dobekirer, December 21, 1957, daughter of Jechil and the late Szejncia Dobekirer. Died September 15, 2002, in Manhattan. Played bass in the U.S. Seventh Army Symphony Orchestra, Dallas Symphony, and Pittsburgh Symphony. Taught music in New York City junior high schools and area Hebrew schools. Led Labor Zionist Alliance and synagogue activities, and compiled three-volume Bibliography of Jewish Music. Proud father and grandfather to Raymond and Elana, and their sons Leor, Ayal, Allon, Noam, Eitan; Leonard and Regina, and their sons Michael, David; and Miriam. Ira had a memorable sense of humor, shared his wide-ranging knowledge with family and friends, sustained communities, and demonstrated a commitment to doing the right thing.

title: China Says Sect Is Broadcasting From Taiwan
description: The spiritual group Falun Gong has used Taiwan as a base for its increasingly bold and often successful attempts to hijack satellite transmissions and beam antigovernment messages all over mainland China, the Beijing government said this evening.

title: Columbia U. Head Apologizes To Fordham Over Public Gibe
description: The president of Columbia University apologized to his counterpart at Fordham University yesterday for a public gibe by a Columbia marching band announcer during halftime at the Columbia-Fordham football game on Saturday. The remark alluded to the sexual abuse scandal in the priesthood.

title: Tips Past the Tipping Point
description: IT'S a pop quiz that's given thousands and thousands of times a day. A waiter clears your table and then presents the bill. In this case, let's say, it amounts to $63.21, $58.40 of which is for food and drinks, and $4.81 for the sales tax. You hand over your credit card and await the flimsy sales chit, which you will sign after you add a tip and calculate the total. But how much tip?

title: Soothing Visual Poetry at the River's Edge
description: In a way, ''Riverrun'' is a win-win viewing experience. If this nighttime screening of film and video organized by the Whitney Museum of American Art and Minetta Brook, a nonprofit art organization, sometimes seems a little repetitious, the setting is spectacular. With the Holland Tunnel Ventilation Building as a 100-foot-high screen at the end of Pier 34, on West Street at Spring, and with the Hudson River, New York Harbor and the lights of Lower Manhattan and Jersey City as backdrops, what's not to like?

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Princeton: Teachers' Contract Accepted
description: The Princeton Regional School Board voted 9 to 0 last night to accept a contract that will increase teachers' salaries nearly 5 percent each year for the next three years. The vote marks the end of contentious negotiations between the board and the Princeton Regional Education Association, which represents 308 teachers and other professionals. The union held a two-day strike at the start of the school year. The three-year contract gives association members yearly raises of 4.5, 4.7 and 4.6 percent. Union members ratified the contract last week. The union refused to release the exact vote count, but said only six members voted against the agreement.

title: Guilty Pleas Are Expected At Homestore
description: Three executives of the online real estate company Homestore.com have agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges of securities fraud and to cooperate with an investigation into Homestore.com and a related inquiry into AOL Time Warner, one of its business partners, two people involved in the investigations said yesterday.

title: Leaked Letter From Prince Charles Stirs Protests
description: LONDON, Sept. 25  Prince Charles found himself embroiled today in an embarrassingly public dispute not over romantic attachments, or even fox-hunting, but over his habit of writing to government ministers with letters tilting at red tape, political correctness and the creeping invasion of a "blame culture" in Britain.

title: Advances at Bell Labs Based on Fraudulent Data, Panel Says
description: Extraordinary advances claimed by scientists at Bell Labs are based on fraudulent data, a committee investigating the matter reported today.

title: When Tricky Little Parts Never Outshine the Whole
description: Jamie Bishton is known primarily as a former standout dancer with the companies of Twyla Tharp and Mikhail Baryshnikov. That may change. Two new dances presented by Jamie Bishton/Dance on Thursday night at Joyce SoHo suggested that Mr. Bishton is well on his way to a solid career as a choreographer. He dances big, filling the stage like a sudden gust of breeze, but no detail or nuance is slighted. He also seems to be an artist who has a relaxed appreciation of the everyday world and popular culture. All of this comes together in ''From a Life Together'' and the reworked ''Things That Cannot Be Painted.''

title: Mike Webster, 50, Dies; Troubled Football Hall of Famer
description: Mike Webster, whose Hall of Fame pro football career was followed by more than a decade of physical and psychological turmoil apparently brought on by repeated blows to the head on the field, died yesterday in a Pittsburgh hospital. He was 50.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Automaker In Debt Talks
description: Executives from the Indonesian carmaker Astra International began talks in Singapore with a committee of leading creditors, including Mizuho Holdings, UFJ Holdings, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, ABN Amro and BNP Paribas, over restructuring Astra's $824 million in debt. In addition to asking for more time to pay, Astra wants creditors to let it invest more of its revenue in plants and products to compete better with foreign imports, according to Michael D. Ruslim, an Astra director. The company hopes to reach a new agreement by the end of next month. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Helping Haiti
description: For the past two years, the international community has been in a terrible bind over Haiti. Results of the tainted May 2000 legislative elections were rejected by the opposition, and since then a combination of political gridlock and governmental abuse has sent the Haitians further into misery. The United States and other donors withheld contributions, hoping to spur President Jean-Bertrand Aristide into political and human rights reform and his opposition into negotiations with him. Neither he nor they have complied.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Insurance Executive Resigns
description: The chief executive of AMP Ltd., Paul Batchelor, resigned after a bailout of its British unit, Pearl, and a regulatory inquiry sent its shares falling 15 percent in three days. AMP is Australia's largest life insurer. Mr. Batchelor joined two other executives in leaving the company. The chief financial officer, Marc de Cure, resigned earlier this month and the chairman, Stan Wallis, will leave in six months. Andrew Mohl, the chief operating officer, was named acting chief executive.

title: California Fire Advances on Hillside Homes
description: Thick, pungent smoke wafted over Los Angeles today, not from millions of exhaust pipes but from a ferocious wildfire in the San Gabriel Mountains that has consumed more than 9,000 acres of brush and trees. At least 44 structures, many of them weekend cabins, have been destroyed so far, and about 1,500 people evacuated.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Yale Union Plans Protest
description: Labor leaders predict that several hundred union members and their supporters will commit civil disobedience and be arrested today in a demonstration protesting the failure to reach a new contract with Yale University and Yale-New Haven Hospital. The contract dispute involves 4,000 clerical, technical, service maintenance at the university and 150 food workers at the hospital. Deborah Chernoff, a union spokeswoman, said the demonstration would be peaceful. The dispute also involves efforts to unionize Yale's 2,600 graduate students as well as 1,800 service and maintenance workers at the hospital. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: On Issue of 4th-Grade Test, It's Trenton vs. U.S.
description: It is still unclear whether fourth graders in New Jersey will have to take the long and much-criticized state achievement test this spring, as their predecessors have done for the last four years.

title: Accenting the Secular in a Modern Paean
description: The brief introduction may have masked it, if you couldn't make out the rearranged notes of the famous opening chord. But when Branford Marsalis's quartet simmered down and let the bassist Eric Revis take up a new, strong four-note line, the crowd at the Bottom Line on Thursday started whooping and shouting in recognition. In short order the group was ripping into John Coltrane's four-part suite ''A Love Supreme.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Sept. 5 about CRH, a building materials maker, referred incorrectly to its market share in Ireland. Analysts and industry experts estimate that at 70 percent, not 80.

title: Hip-Hop D.J.'s Arrest Casts Light on Rivalry
description: For the last six months, two hip-hop radio stations in New York City have given new meaning to the phrase ''ratings wars.''

title: The Once-a-Year Search For the Perfect Citron
description: Rafaat Mwasy hefted an etrog in his hand, testing the fruit's size and weight, poking at the thick, bumpy skin with a toothpick, looking for unsightly holes or bruises.

title: An Elusive, Whimsical Autograph
description: THE AUTOGRAPH MAN

title: Deal for Sears and Carrier
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company stores will begin selling heating and cooling systems from the Carrier Corporation, replacing the Trane brand of the American Standard Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, JEFFREY S.
description: SILVERMAN-Jeffrey S. On September 23, 2002. Adoring and loving husband of Lisa. Adoring and loving father of Lucy and Jack Silverman, Amanda Feinsod, and Jason Silverman. Father of Jessica and Evan Silverman. Beloved grandfather of Alexa and Max Feinsod, and Samantha Silverman. Son of Roberta Silverman. Beloved brother of Kenneth Silverman. Brother of Richard and Barry Silverman. Treasured and beloved son-in-law of Lynne and Mickey Tarnopol. Chairman and CEO of Brand Partners Group, Inc. and former Chairman and CEO of Ply Gem Industries. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at Central Synagogue, 55th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: Technology's Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pataki Attack Turns McCall's Own Words Against Him
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election campaign is broadcasting this 30-second commercial in upstate New York. It is his second attack ad of the campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCALPIN, JEANIE GERST
description: McALPIN-Jeanie Gerst. On September 16, 2002. Age 64. Beloved wife of Benjamin B. McAlpin III. Devoted sister of Kate Davis. Adoring aunt of Susan Castle of Alexandria, Va. and Shannon Blocker of Bankock. Also survived by two nieces, one nephew. three grand-nieces and one grand - nephew. Memorial service to be held Christ Church, Greenwich, CT., 12 noon, Saturday, September 28. Interment private.

title: Fancy Baking in Williamsburg, From France by Way of Brazil
description: Plenty of Polish pastries are still to be found in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. But Fabiane's Cafe and Pastry, 142 North Fifth Street (Bedford Avenue), is a new outpost for fancy baking. French palmiers, florentines, hazelnut-chocolate pyramids and passion fruit mousse cakes are $3.50 to $4. Fabiane Lima (below), who owns the shop with Jimmy Tuohy and Giles Cooper, trained at the French Culinary Institute and has worked with Jacques Torres and Patrice Caillot. Ms. Lima is from Brazil, and her background comes through in moist little slabs of coconut-yuca cake ($3). The cafe and bakery also serves excellent panini on toasted bread from the Sullivan Street Bakery ($5.95 to $6.95).

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: PLEA BARGAIN FOR PROSECUTOR'S SON

title: If Test Scores of Students Swell, So May Superintendents' Wallets
description: New York City school superintendents will receive bonuses of up to $40,000 -- about a quarter of their base salaries -- if test scores in their districts significantly improve this year, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday.

title: Money Can't Drive Woods at the Ryder Cup
description: Although Tiger Woods won't be playing for $1 million this week, he insisted today that his motivation for the Ryder Cup will not be a problem.

title: F.B.I. Agent Was Tracking Radical Linked to Hijacker
description: An F.B.I. agent in Phoenix who suspected that operatives of Al Qaeda might be taking aviation-related training in the United States was tracking an Islamic radical with close ties to a Sept. 11 hijacker, according to a Congressional report released today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: For Remarks on Iraq, Gore Gets Praise and Scorn
description: With a single speech on Iraq, Al Gore has succeeded in once again breaking away from the Democratic presidential pack on foreign policy, defying a popular president on the issue of the day and saying publicly what many Democrats here had been saying only in private.

title: Pataki Picks Up Pace While McCall Tries To Narrow Money Gap
description: With 41 days before the election and a comfortable lead in the polls, Gov. George E. Pataki is campaigning as if it were the final week, deploying supporters and negative ads to batter his Democratic opponent in a bid to effectively end the race before it really starts.

title: A Doyenne Does a Turn as a Princess
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its 119th season on Monday night with a gala performance of Act II of Giordano's ''Fedora,'' Act II of Saint-Sans's ''Samson et Dalila'' and Act IV of Verdi's ''Otello,'' a suitably festive yet substantial program that fulfilled several goals at once.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bombings Kill 3
description: A policeman was killed today and three other officers were injured in an explosion only hours after two people, presumed members of the armed Basque separatist group E.T.A., were blown up, apparently by their own bomb. The policeman, Juan Carlos Beiro Montes, suffered fatal wounds when a bomb was detonated as he and a colleague approached a pro-E.T.A. banner that had been booby-trapped. Officials said the killing was E.T.A.'s response to the loss of two of its members on Monday night in Bilbao, where they were blown up while transporting a back-pack filled with 20 to 33 pounds of dynamite. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Courville Gains Quarterfinals
description: Jerry Courville Jr., who won the title in 1995, advanced yesterday to the quarterfinals of the United States Mid-Amateur Championship at the Stanwich Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Gay Man May Sue for Sex Bias, Federal Court Says
description: A butler at a Las Vegas hotel who says male co-workers harassed him because he is gay may sue his employer for sex discrimination, a divided federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled yesterday.

title: In Japan, Rebels In the Classroom
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONIKOV, BARBARA
description: KONIKOV-Barbara. Congregation Ahavath Torah mourns the passing of our dearly departed friend and community leader, Barbara Konikov, wife of our beloved Cantor, Velvel Konikov. We will sorely miss this wonderful individual who served as a role model for our entire community. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Shmuel Goldin Jeffrey R. Parker, President

title: Consumer Confidence Declines For the 4th Consecutive Month
description: Consumer confidence declined 1.3 percent in September, to a 10-month low because of falling stocks, weak employment numbers and a growing concern about a potential war with Iraq.

title: After Impasse, F.D.A. May Fill Top Job
description: President Bush intends to nominate Dr. Mark B. McClellan, a member of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, to fill the long-vacant job of commissioner of food and drugs, administration officials said today.

title: Britain's Case: Iraqi Program to Amass Arms Is 'Up and Running'
description: The British government's report on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction makes an explicit and extensive case that Saddam Hussein has been working to break through barriers that have constrained him from rebuilding his military and the deadly weaponry that he possessed a decade ago.

title: 21 Chinese Children Die in School Accident
description: Twenty-one children were killed, many of them suffocated in a pile of bodies, after a guardrail gave way on a darkened stairwell at a middle school in northern China, state news organizations reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOLOMON, HOLLY
description: SOLOMON-Holly. A memorial service to be held at The Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, on Thursday, September 26th at 6 P.M.

title: Few of Those Eligible Register For Cleanup Help Near 9/11 Site
description: With just a week left to sign up, only about a quarter of the New York City residents eligible to have their apartments tested and cleaned to remove leftover World Trade Center dust have registered, federal environmental officials said today.

title: Cannelloni of a Complex Character
description: BARBARA LYNCH'S food is almost universally robust, even when she is offering a vegetarian pasta dish. Her cannelloni, for example, filled with mushrooms, squash and an enriched bchamel, are as big and rich as any made with meat. Two make a generous main course.

title: Kidd Is Happy Playing With Nets, So They're Happy, Too
description: Heading into the start of training camp next week, Jason Kidd has given the Nets strong indications that he will re-sign with them upon becoming a free agent next summer.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Joyce Berlin was named to the new post of head of traffic and media at Berwald Design, Centerport, N.Y. She had been advertising account manager at Shoot magazine, New York, published by VNU USA.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOME DEPOT INC., Atlanta, the largest home improvement retailer, agreed to acquire Floors Inc., Landover, Md.; Arvada Hardwood Floor Co., Denver; and Floorworks Inc., Phoenix, three companies that supply and install flooring for residential construction. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Many Concerns Settle 8,000 Asbestos Suits
description: Hundreds of corporations swept into a huge asbestos trial in West Virginia have settled claims brought by some 8,000 people over the last week, lawyers for each side said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHART, STEPHANIE
description: REINHART-Stephanie. The Board of Trustees and staff of Theatre Development Fund send our condolences to our beloved trustee, Charles Reinhart, and his family, on the passing of his wife and partner, Stephanie. Her contribution to the world of dance was immeasurable. Our thoughts and prayers are with you. John F. Breglio, Chairman Victoria Bailey, Exec. Dir. Theatre Development Fund

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, GRANT M.
description: THOMPSON-Grant M. Former senior executive with the William Esty Advertising Agency of New York, died Friday, September 13, 2002, in Burlington, VT. He was 86. Grant was born January 24, 1916, in Cincinnati, OH., to Samuel and Elizabeth van Nes Thompson. He was married in 1941 to Helen Morrison, also of Cincinnati, who survives him. Grant was a graduate of Williams College and veteran of World War II, serving as a naval officer aboard the destroyer U.S.S. Caperton in the Pacific. He was awarded the Bronze Star for bravery in action in 1944. After the war, Grant began a successful career in advertising and marketing with Procter and Gamble in Cincinnati. He and his family moved to Old Greenwich, CT in 1951, when he joined William Esty. While there, he brought the famed slogan ''Winston tastes good, like a cigarette should'' to the American advertising lexicon. He was followed into the advertising business by his son and grandson and retired to Vero Beach, FL. in 1976. He was also a longtime summer resident of Nantucket, MA. In addition to his wife, Grant is survived by his children, Geoffrey, Christie Thompson Sumner, and Anne Stannard Thompson, as well as seven grandchildren.

title: Robert O. Jordan, 69, Ex-Chief Of New York Advertising Office
description: Robert O. Jordan, who helped create advertising campaigns for clients as diverse as Procter & Gamble and The National Enquirer, died Sunday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 69.

title: Wanted: A 9/11 Victim's Survivor, Old Enough for a Scholarship
description: Free tickets to Europe, back and forth, whenever necessary. Living quarters and three squares a day, paid in full. A graduate education at an ancient university with storied alumni like Adam Smith and Lord Kelvin, practically just for the asking.

title: Marijuana for the Sick
description: To the Editor:

title: Act I, Scene 1: A Cellphone in the House? Seize It!
description: When a cellphone goes off in the theater -- or at the ballet, the opera or the movies -- the inconsiderate offender could soon face more than just the huffy stares of neighbors.

title: Cheney's Travel Budget Raises Eyebrows
description: Vice President Dick Cheney's staff says he needs an extra $100,000 for his travel budget for "additional unplanned official trips."

title: Winners of MacArthur Grants Announced
description: A photographer who captured images of the World Trade Center from its construction more than 30 years ago to the day the towers fell, 11 scientists whose work ranges from self-changing robots to earthquake-resistant buildings, and an economist who explored executive compensation were among the 24 winners of the $500,000 ''genius awards'' announced yesterday.

title: 7 Christian Charity Workers Killed in Pakistan
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 25  Seven Pakistani Christian charity workers were gagged, tied to chairs and executed with single shots to the head this morning in a carefully planned attack in a high-rise office building near the heart of Karachi, the police said.

title: 2 Agencies Join Forces In Alliance in Dallas
description: Wong Doody said yesterday that it would form a strategic alliance with Gilliatt Paris, an agency in Dallas. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World War II Refugees Who Shared Little but Pain
description: When Nandor Andrasovits, a Hungarian riverboat captain, took home movies on his vessel of refugees fleeing the horrors of World War II, he could never have guessed the future of the films. Discovered 12 years ago by Peter Forgacs, a Hungarian media artist, those movies are at the core of an exhibition at the Getty Center here recreating the terrors, the starvation and, yes, the joys of Jews fleeing Slovakia to the Black Sea and then to Palestine.

title: INSIDE
description: Terror Alert Level Lowered

title: Vivendi Seen Refocusing On Telecom
description: When the chairman of Vivendi Universal clarifies the company's strategy on Wednesday, he will propose focusing it in the direction of broadcasting and telecommunications, the chief executive of one of Vivendi Universal's biggest units said today.

title: Beauty in the Eye of the Scientist
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A School Teaching Audacity
description: The Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising in Irvine, Calif., teaches, among other things, that audacity is a virtue.

title: Moscow: Fluid, Eclectic, Electric
The Mood and Food of Montreal
The Future, at the Doorstep
description: Warp-speed commutes to neighborhood planets may not exist outside science fiction yet, but many staples of the genre, particularly communications devices, are edging their way into everyday life as we know it -- so far.

title: Satin in a Glass
description: Cognac, properly made and aged, is the best brandy in the world.

title: A Zeffirelli Spectacle, Back for Another Eyeful
description: When it opened in 1987, Franco Zeffirelli's ''Turandot,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday evening, seemed a veritable symbol of operatic excess. This show is spectacle incarnate, Cecil B. DeMille meets P. T. Barnum, with monumental sets and glitter, acrobats, a magnificent Chinese dragon and a large, ragged chorus, forced down to the lip of the orchestra pit by the sets (which, with their risers, steps and pagodas, offer the masses little actual room to stand) and by the cruel minions of the princess Turandot.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: A Red Maple's Surprise

title: California Culprits
description: Federal investigators have now unearthed further evidence that market manipulation by energy companies played an important role in California's power crisis in 2000 and 2001. We have long known that clever trading strategies devised by companies like Enron helped jack up the price of power. Now comes a ruling from an administrative judge at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that the El Paso Corporation illegally inflated the price of natural gas. Because natural gas is used to produce much of California's power, inflating its price had the effect of driving up the cost of electricity.

title: Welch Divorce Court Hearing Is Canceled
description: A court hearing today in the divorce of John F. Welch Jr., the former chairman and chief executive of General Electric, from his wife, Jane, has been canceled, suggesting that a settlement is being discussed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Executives Convicted
description: A prominent embezzlement case has ended with two executives from Sibur, a petrochemicals company, being declared guilty of abuse of office and sentenced to seven months in prison by a Moscow court. The court, however, immediately released the executives, Yakov Goldovsky and Yevgeny Kovshits, because they had already served the time during the trial. The Kremlin selected Sibur, which worked itself out from under the control of the state-controlled gas company Gazprom, to showcase its efforts at cracking down on corruption at Gazprom. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: UKRAINE: GOVERNMENT DENIES AIDING IRAQ President Leonid D. Kuchma's administration brusquely rejected American accusations that Mr. Kuchma had approved a plot to smuggle military equipment into Iraq in 2000, saying the White House was acting in concert with antigovernment protesters who want to topple him. "The interests of certain political circles in Ukraine and abroad coincide," Mr. Kuchma's top aide, Viktor Medvedchuk, said. The United States said on Monday that it has suspended $55 million in aid to Ukraine after concluding that Mr. Kuchma approved a plan to sell Iraq a radar system that could detect approaching objects without their knowledge. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: The Ever-Darkening World Of Television Police Work
description: Three high-profile crime shows arriving in the next few days are full of flash and dazzle. But beneath that kinetic surface, a deep undercurrent reflects a threatening world where police are dirty, politicians are sleazy, personal lives are messy and people go missing because of their own disturbing secrets. The old ''Dragnet'' days of bright, orderly crime-solving have given way to a dark vision that is especially pertinent for our times, sending a message that would be terrifying if the new series weren't so entertaining. But they are captivating, two of them among the best new series the season has to offer. Willfully or not, these crime shows tap into the social current in the guise of entertainment.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Evian It's Not
description: In an effort to reduce its dependence on Malaysia, which supplies Singapore with about half its water, the nation has found a new use for its waste water, as well as a new word to describe it. Starting in February, waste water from sinks, baths and toilets is going to be pumped into reservoirs for all to drink after ''conventional'' treatment at waterworks. As part of its campaign to win public acceptance, the government has begun calling the recycled waste ''newater'' and has handed out more than 650,000 bottles. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: In Las Vegas, A Fantasy Suite For Reality TV
description: Las Vegas used to be where you went to get away from the real world. Now ''The Real World'' on MTV has gone there: seven strangers cast to live in a converted six-room suite on the 28th floor of the Palms Casino Resort. The ''Real World'' suite was specially tailored by the Jerde Partnership architectural firm, which designed the Palms for George Maloof, its owner. The challenge, said Sharmila Tankha, the project architect, was to create visually distinct settings, comfortable enough to jump-start relationships among the occupants. (In the first episode, last week, relationships were definitely jump-started.) The materials had to be theatrical, yet usable by hotel guests after the filming. One lounge area, above, has panels of leather and purple velvet, gold silk drapes and a great view of Las Vegas. With filming over, the suite starts at $5,000 a night. At 4321 West Flamingo Road, Las Vegas; (866) 942-7770.

title: Magazines Talk Books
description: In a very dicey economic time for magazines, when many find it difficult to sustain themselves, two new ones have just started up, about books of all subjects. Which speaks not only to a particularly bravura entrepreneurial spirit but also to speculation that there are enough people out there who are willing to spend money for their love of commentary about books and the writers who produce them.

title: Robert Whitehead Tribute
description: A memorial service for Robert Whitehead, the Broadway producer who died on June 15 at 86, will be held on Monday at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street. Among those expected to speak are Hume Cronyn, Julie Harris, Rosemary Harris, Patti LuPone, Audra McDonald, Austin Pendleton, Aaron Sorkin, Eli Wallach and Joseph Wiseman.

title: Furnishings That Speak Many Languages
description: IN this time of anything-goes decorating, it's not surprising to find a wealth of places to shop for exotic accessories or that one piece of furniture that can distinguish a room. For Eskandar, a British clothing designer, left, there are no decorating trends -- only layers of textures and styles from many countries. ''It's the art of choosing pieces that live well together that interests me,'' said Eskandar, whose new boutique opens today on the third floor of Bergdorf Goodman. ''If something speaks to you, use it.''

title: ALLEGHENY ENERGY SUES MERRILL OVER A TRANSACTION
description: Allegheny Energy , an energy trading firm, filed a lawsuit yesterday against Merrill Lynch , accusing the firm of fraud in the sale of a trading unit to Allegheny last year for $409 million. The suit came one day after Merrill filed suit against Allegheny seeking $115 million in payments from Allegheny for the sale of that trading unit. In its suit, Allegheny said Merrill officials had inflated revenue and engaged in sham trades with Enron that artificially lifted the value of Merrill's trading unit in 1999. David Barboza (NYT)

title: Daschle Defends Democrats' Stand on Security
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  Pent-up partisan rancor over domestic security legislation and Iraq policy erupted today when Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, demanded an apology from President Bush for saying the Senate was "not interested in the security of the American people."

title: In Russia, Executive Returns And a Company Disappears
description: It was a day of bewildering developments in Russian business. A kidnapped oil company executive mysteriously reappeared after 12 days in captivity, while a Russian oil trading company, painstakingly pursued in the Russian courts by a foreign investor, disappeared without a trace.

title: Conditions Are Said to Improve in Iraq
description: Malnutrition and death rates are declining and education is improving in Iraq as a result of a United Nations program that supplies food, medicines and equipment, an official of the world organization reported today.

title: Bush and Daschle Comments on Security and Politics
description: Following is an excerpt from President Bush's speech on Monday in Trenton and a transcript of the response yesterday by the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc.:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Dresdner Executive Resigns
description: The chief executive of Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, Leonhard Fischer, resigned after clashing with his superiors at Dresdner's parent company, Allianz, over how to stem losses. Mr. Fischer, 39, is leaving after two and a half years. The chief executive of Dresdner Bank, Bernd Fahrholz, 55, will take over Mr. Fischer's responsibilities.

title: Congress Nearing Draft Resolution on Force in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 26  The White House and the Congressional leadership proposed new terms today for a resolution authorizing President Bush to use military force in Iraq, dropping language that many members considered too broad and imposing new procedural conditions.

title: Officials Find No Felony Against Moss
description: After spending Tuesday night in a jail cell for his arrest on suspicion of bumping a traffic control agent with his Lexus sedan on a downtown Minneapolis street, Minnesota Vikings receiver Randy Moss was charged with two misdemeanor offenses yesterday and released.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: MOVE TO EASE FLOW OF INFORMATION China has long been a place where even routine government data, as mundane as the working hours of the central bank or the release date of common statistics, can be treated as state secrets, with those who leak information punishable by law. But a group of legal scholars have been given a mandate by the State Council, China's cabinet, to draft a law defining the types of information that can be released to the public, according to China Youth Daily, a government newspaper. The lawyers will draw clearer distinctions between public information and official secrets and seek to speed up the release of information that is not classified. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: 2 Arrested Over Video Of Homeless
description: A video popularized on the Internet that shows homeless men pummeling one another, pulling out their teeth with pliers and hurling themselves into walls has resulted in the arrest of two Las Vegas men.

title: A Fashion School That Teaches Audacity at First Glance
description: Not since Barbie has pink been so brazenly displayed as in the new Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising, a private vocational school in Irvine, Calif. A 53,000-square-foot concrete warehouse in an industrial area has been turned by Clive Wilkinson Architects, designers of the TBWA/Chiat/Day offices in Marina del Rey, into a striking laboratory for creativity. ''Pink is an extremely personal color that relates strongly to cosmetics and the beautification of the human body,'' Mr. Wilkinson (inset) said. The architects divided the space into classrooms, meeting rooms, labs, faculty areas and a spacious lobby, above -- all linked to a corridor ringing the building.

title: Clocking the Grand Prix to a Thousandth of a Tick
description: TIMING is everything. This is true for most sports in which the aim is to be the first to reach the finish line. It is particularly true for motor sports, where the difference between first place and also-ran can be measured in thousandths of a second.

title: National Briefing: South
description: MISSISSIPPI: STORM DISPERSES LAWMAKERS

title: Judge Rules For 3 Insurers On Coverage Of Twin Towers
description: Larry A. Silverstein's $7 billion claim that the World Trade Center suffered two separate terrorist attacks was dealt a setback yesterday when a federal judge ruled that 3 of 20 insurers owed him insurance payments for only a single attack.

title: A Helper Who Never Forgets To Update Your Address Book
description: At most big companies, there is usually someone responsible for sending out the e-mail and making the phone calls needed to keep electronic address books up to date. For people who run their own businesses at home, however, updating phone numbers and e-mail and postal addresses is another one of those tasks that rarely, if ever, get done.

title: Pleas Expected In Investigation Of WorldCom
description: David F. Myers, the former controller for WorldCom, is expected to plead guilty as early as today on two felony counts stemming from the multibillion-dollar accounting scandal that pushed the company into bankruptcy, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Government Denies Aiding Iraq
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma's administration brusquely rejected American accusations that Mr. Kuchma had approved a plot to smuggle military equipment into Iraq in 2000, saying the White House was acting in concert with antigovernment protesters who want to topple him. ''The interests of certain political circles in Ukraine and abroad coincide,'' Mr. Kuchma's top aide, Viktor Medvedchuk, said. The United States said on Monday that it has suspended $55 million in aid to Ukraine after concluding that Mr. Kuchma approved a plan to sell Iraq a radar system that could detect approaching objects without their knowledge. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: As Tropical Storm Isidore chugged up the Gulf of Mexico, slowly losing steam, one Tulane student circulated a bulletin on the Internet:

description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli-Arab Hero Is Praised, but Not Embraced
description: Something about the tall thin man waiting at the bus stop struck Rami Mahamid as suspicious. There was all that dust on his shoes and then there was that big black duffle bag in his hand.

title: Showtime, Microsoft Style
description: A RECENT visit to Download.com reminded me why the entertainment industry is in such a panic over the Internet. The most popular program on the site's Top 50 list during the week of Sept. 15 was KaZaA Media Desktop, a Napster-like file-sharing program. It was downloaded 2.7 million times.

title: In Policy Shift, U.S. Will Talk To North Korea
description: President Bush will send a senior American diplomat to North Korea early next month, the White House said today, ending 20 months of internal debate on whether to open talks with a country that Mr. Bush lumped with Iran and Iraq as part of an ''axis of evil.''

title: Scenery for the Dancers Provided by the Band
description: Troy Powell took on a difficult assignment in ``The Tyner Project,'' presented by the 2002 Verizon Music Festival on Sept. 17 at Alice Tully Hall. Mr. Powell had to set his dance along a narrow rectangular strip of the stage, shared with members of the McCoy Tyner Quintet ranged across the back. The musicians and their gear provided a busy backdrop for dance. And Mr. Powell had to calibrate precisely the high-energy, expansive dancing of Ailey II, the junior troupe of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, to find a balance between the dance and the gleaming, percussive jazz.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Handspring Cuts Work Force
description: Handspring, a maker of hand-held computers, has dismissed about 80 workers, or 20 percent of its worldwide work force, as part of an effort to reduce costs and become profitable as sales decline. The company has about 320 workers left in its Mountain View, Calif., headquarters and in Geneva, a spokesman, Allen Bush, said. The cuts, many in the marketing department, are necessary to reduce the break-even point, he said. Handspring, which competes against larger rivals like Palm Inc. and Hewlett-Packard, has not had a profit since its initial public offering in 2000. Second-quarter worldwide shipments of all hand-held computers fell 3.5 percent from a year ago as a shortage of new models hampered sales, a market researcher, Gartner Dataquest, said in August. ''We had been saying that $90 million in sales would be a break-even point for us,'' said Brad Driver, Handspring's director for investor relations. ''Now it is somewhat less than $90 million.'' Shares rose 8 cents, to $1.10. They are off 84 percent this year.

title: Meeting the Threat of Smallpox
description: To the Editor:

title: Rights Workers in Honduras Still Live in Fear
description: A quarter-size bullet hole that cut through a cinder-block wall marks where Jos Santos Callejas was shot dead by a quick burst from an AK-47 the night of Aug. 26.

title: New Jersey's Dreadful Senate Race
description: With control of the Senate up for grabs, and polls indicating a neck-and-neck race between Senator Robert Torricelli and his Republican challenger, Douglas Forrester, New Jersey is getting plenty of attention from both national parties. President Bush made a campaign stop in the state this week. Meanwhile, not far up the New Jersey Turnpike, Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, was trying to rally support for the beleaguered Mr. Torricelli. Unfortunately, the net effect of these dual appearances was not to sharpen the campaign dialogue but rather to underscore how badly both camps are treating voters.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Documents On Emission Standards Publicized
description: Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, released documents showing that the Interior Department had toned down a National Park Service recommendation for even tougher emissions standards for snowmobiles than those made final this month. The senator said the documents showed the administration had discounted advice from the agency most knowledgeable about snowmobiles and their hazards. The Park Service had favored a ban on snowmobile operations in Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks, but the Interior Department decided in June to allow those operations to continue. Douglas Jehl (NYT)

title: Meeting the Threat of Smallpox
description: To the Editor:

title: Nils Bohlin, 82, Inventor of a Better Seat Belt
description: Nils Bohlin, inventor of the three-point safety belt for cars, which is credited with saving countless lives since it was introduced in Europe in the 1950's, died on Saturday in Tranas, Sweden. He was 82.

title: A Laurel for Schrder
description: To the Editor:

title: Awaiting Digital TV
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Chief Urges Allies Not to Let Iraq Divide Them
description: The NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, urged the Western allies today not to let disputes over Iraq weaken their unity and strengthen their enemies.

title: Unions Lobby to Safeguard Proposed Agency's Workers
description: Today was National Action Day for federal employee unions. The event mobilized thousands of members from all 50 states to bombard senators with faxes, calls and e-mail messages to support provisions to protect workers in the proposed Homeland Security Department.

title: General Electric Outlook Gives Traders a Reason to Buy
description: General Electric led a rally in stocks yesterday, helping the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index record its biggest gain in six weeks.

title: Report Is Skeptical of Drug
description: Xigris, a $7,000-a-dose sepsis treatment from Eli Lilly, should not be widely used until another study confirms its benefits, according to a report today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Waiting Games

title: U.S. Focuses On Executive At Homestore
description: Federal investigators examining possible accounting fraud at the online retailer Homestore.com and AOL Time Warner are now turning their attention to Peter Tafeen, a Homestore executive who worked closely with counterparts at AOL to devise complicated deals between the companies, people involved in the inquiries said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Software Maker Cuts Outlook
description: Shares in the software maker Dassault Systmes fell 18 percent after the company warned for the third time this year that its sales forecast for 2002 would be lower than expected. The company, based in Paris, said business in the United States, Germany and Sweden was particularly slow. Dassault said sales would rise 4 to 5 percent this year, to 775 million euros to 785 million euros ($760.7 million to $770.6 million), down from an earlier forecast of as much as 810 million euros. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Matters of Heaven and Earth Sprinkled Among the Verses
description: His band had fallen silent, and Conor Oberst was asking questions about Jesus. ''Is it true what I heard about the Son of God?'' he mumbled, strumming some chords on his guitar. ''If I dried his feet with my dirty hair, would he make me clean again?''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firms Solicited For Downtown Studies
description: State and city redevelopment officials said they were seeking consulting firms to study ways to enhance and expand residential and retail project offerings along streets in Lower Manhattan. On Monday, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the Department of City Planning issued calls for proposals to conduct the studies. The proposals are due Oct. 14 and outlines of the studies can be found at www.renewnyc.com. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Austrian Concert Hall in New York Opens Its First Full Season
description: Last spring the Austrian Cultural Forum opened an attractive, intimate concert hall and exhibition space and began assembling programs that look at both Austrian and American music with an emphasis on the contemporary. The hall, at 11 East 52nd Street, seats about 80 and is equipped to present chamber works, recitals, electronic music and film. There was a run of performances to celebrate the opening in April, but on Sept. 18 the forum opened its first full season with the first of four concerts by the Pierrot Lunaire Ensemble from Vienna.

title: United Air's Unions Offer Plan to Save Billion a Year
description: Hoping to steer United Airlines away from a bankruptcy protection filing, the company's five unions presented executives last night with a long-awaited proposal to save $1 billion a year in labor costs for five years.

title: Nearly 96, Judge Keeps an Iron Grip on the Gavel
description: A DELICIOUS spookiness tinges the air in this federal judge's book-lined chambers, and not just because the venerable jurist-in-charge happens to be three days short of yet another landmark decision, this time for longevity rather than judicial perspicacity.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about continuing health and social problems in Bhopal, India, 18 years after the deaths of thousands of people in the poisonous gas leak there, misstated the date of the accident. It was December 1984, not October.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: E-Zpass Gets $30 Million Loan
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority said it would lend the troubled E-ZPass system $30 million to ensure that the system's books are balanced when a new operating company, ACS State and Local Solutions, takes over the toll-collection system's operations in February. The loan will be repaid with interest early next year, when the system's $350 million debt is refinanced, said Joe Orlando, a spokesman for the authority. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Records On Priests To Be Released
description: A judge ordered that thousands of pages of church documents concerning 85 priests accused of sexual abuse be released to lawyers for plaintiffs suing the archdiocese. One lawyer, Roderick MacLeish Jr., said he believed this was the first time in the country a judge had ordered the release of records on so many priests. Mr. MacLeish said he requested the records as part of an effort to show a pattern of mishandling sexual abuse accusations. No date was set for the release of the documents. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: THAT WAS THEN
description: ABC, tomorrow night at 9, Eastern and Pacific times; 8 Central time

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Professors Chip In
description: Professors at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro will get raises under this year's state budget, but the roughly 1,000 groundskeepers, janitors, secretaries and other support workers were denied salary increases, even though many earn less than $18,000 annually and have seen their take-home pay dwindle for years. So the school's 800 professors are contributing to raise $250,000 for a one-time holiday bonus fund for the staff. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: 9 Suspended From School Team Over Alcohol
description: Nine Harrison High School students were suspended from the football team for a week after attending an unsupervised gathering at one of their homes Saturday night in which beer and other alcoholic beverages were served, school and police officials said today.

title: Accounts
description: * H. J. Heinz Co. , Pittsburgh, to Doner, Southfield, Mich., to handle pet-food brands including 9-Lives cat food and Kibbles 'n Bits dog food, which are being spun off to Del Monte Foods along with products like Star-Kist tuna. There had been no previous agency of record on the pet foods account, with billings estimated by Adweek at $10 million to $15 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel Raises Cash
description: Europe's biggest maker of phone equipment, Alcatel, sold its 6.1 percent stake in the military electronics maker Thales to raise money for its overhaul program. The sale, which raised $307 million cash, brings Alcatel's ownership in Thales down to 9.7 percent from 15.8 percent. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, EUGENE
description: SANDLER-Eugene. The Hillel family expresses its deep sympathy to treasurer Julian Sandler and family on the passing of his beloved father, Eugene. May the Sandler family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Edgar M. Bronfman, Chair Lynn Schusterman, Co-Chair Michael Steinhardt, Co-Chair Richard M. Joel, President

title: M&T Is Said to Be in a Deal for Allfirst
description: The M&T Bank Corporation, whose largest investor is the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, is planning to announce today that it has agreed to buy Allfirst Financial from Allied Irish Banks for $3 billion in cash and stock, executives close to the negotiations said late last night.

title: The Gap Chooses a Disney Executive to Run Its Business
description: The Gap Inc. , the clothing retailer famous for its khaki pants and denim skirts, reached outside of the retail industry today and plucked its new leader from the world of theme parks and family entertainment. Gap said today that it had chosen Paul Pressler, a former executive at the Walt Disney Company who ran its global theme park and resorts division, to become its president and chief executive.

title: Economic Scene; Employment and prosperity affect body inflation.
description: CLOSE to half the American population is estimated to be overweight, a condition that has serious economic consequences because of its impact on labor supply and health care.

title: The Ultimate Shabby Chic: Bare-Naked Spaces
description: AT the new condominiums now going up at 497 Greenwich Street, a few million dollars will buy next to nothing, exquisitely wrapped, which is the selling point. Twenty-two apartments set behind a Modernist facade of 11 stories of cascading glass are being sold as lofts for an average of $1,000 a square foot. Some of the bigger, higher lofts have an asking price of $3.5 million.

title: A Hollywood Restaurant Evokes Valentino
description: The Falcon restaurant, on a down-market stretch of Sunset Boulevard, has become a hot Hollywood hangout. It has the bloodlines. It is owned by Mike Garrett and Tommy Stoilkovich (who also own the clubs Voda, Lounge 217 and Pearl Dragon). And it was designed by the architects John Friedman and Alice Kimm, who did Club Sugar in Santa Monica and the Brig bar in Venice. The Falcon, named for Rudolph Valentino's Falcon Lair estate, replaced the Vienna Hofbrau. It has a clubby, relaxed, dark 2,400-square-foot interior with a central bar. Large windows, left, open onto an 1,800-square-foot patio with fireplace and high, white stucco walls, on which movies will be screened. It serves comfort food in an environment that mixes comfort with zebrawood walls, ebony-stained floors, metal-trim windows and fake-alpaca-wool ottomans. The bar is covered in brass micarta, a new woven brass laminate. Falcon is at 7213 Sunset Boulevard (near La Brea Boulevard); (323) 850-5350.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Andrea Cautela was named to the new post of director for sales and marketing at the Syndicated Network Television Association, New York. She had been managing director for marketing services at The New York Times, New York, published by The New York Times Company.

title: County Budgets Pinched by State Medicaid Changes
description: County governments across New York State are facing big budget shortfalls next year, largely because of new health-care costs that Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature have thrust upon them.

title: Junior Welterweight Bout Set for Oct. 13
description: Now that the junior welterweight Tokunbo Olajide knows his opponent for Oct. 13, he can be expected to start studying videotape of the fighter to determine his weaknesses, right? Not exactly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, JOSEPH NATHAN
description: KANE-Joseph Nathan. On September 22, 2002 in his 104th year. Beloved brother of Ann Kane Madier. Devoted uncle of Nancy Newman, David N. Kane, and greatniece, Emily Newman. He left the world a legacy of many famous books. Among those most widely circulated are ''Famous First Facts'' and ''Facts About the Presidents''. Services Friday, September 27, 11 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Japan Markets Resume Their Search for the Bottom
description: With another bout of selling today, Japan's leading stock market index finished erasing all its gains from one week ago, when the nation's central bank startled investors by announcing an unorthodox plan to buy company shares held by wobbling commercial banks.

description: To the Editor:

title: Tyco's Chief Says Earnings Will Be Lower Than Expected
description: In his first presentation to analysts and investors since his appointment as Tyco International's new chief executive in late July, Edward D. Breen said yesterday that the company's earnings in the fourth quarter would be much lower than earlier expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, LILLIAN
description: ALTMAN-Lillian. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Lillian Altman, beloved sister of Louis Katz. We extend our deepest condolences to Louis and family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Calling All Amigos and Amigas Of Kmart in 10 Markets
description: The Kmart Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection last January and has closed hundreds of stores, is trying to revive itself by appealing to the growing Hispanic market in the United States. More than 55 percent of all Hispanics in this country live within 15 minutes of a Kmart store. The company has begun an entertainment and lifestyle magazine in Spanish called La Vida, with a circulation of a million in 10 key markets. Three of those are in California: in the Los Angeles area, which has 59 stores; San Diego; and Palm Springs. Marc Anthony was on the cover of the first issue, which came out last week. Kmart products for the Hispanic market include cookware, utensils, Christmas ornaments and artificial flowers for the Day of the Dead.

title: Hollywood's Gadget Factories
description: A MINIATURE camera disguised as a lipstick generates a building's 3-D blueprint. An electronic card lets a PC user masquerade as the network system administrator. A wireless device copies all the data from a nearby computer.

title: Dubious Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Yoko Ono's Lawyer Attacks Ex-Assistant's Credibility
description: A former assistant to John Lennon and Yoko Ono denied in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday that he had stolen hundreds of photographs of the couple, saying he took them with his own camera. But a lawyer for Ms. Ono cast doubt on the assistant's credibility, asking him about entries from his own diary in which he wrote of deceiving Mr. Lennon and stealing the couple's stereo equipment.

title: Makeovers in San Pablo Designed to Catch the Eye
description: Ace Architects of Oakland, Calif., has done face-lifts on 14 shops in San Pablo. ''The city wanted to increase pedestrian use and give businesses a shot in the arm,'' said Lucia Howard, a partner in Ace with David Weingarten. The pictures show, from left, California Furniture, which now displays a silhouette of California and a pleated Mission-style awning; a Hostess Bakery Outlet that sports a tilted logo; and the Lady Bug beauty salon, which has a red-orange facade highlighted by an orange-dotted green ladybug. The project cost $425,000, and the city has commissioned Ace to do 20 more buildings on 23rd Street. ELAINE LOUIE
