The destinations run from small design studios and woodworking shops to clothing boutiques, pet stores and nightclubs, and the specialties include furniture and product design, architecture, fashion and graphics.

title: Why Iraq Can't Be Deterred
description: As the United States moves closer to war with Iraq, some have suggested relying instead on deterrence to deal with the threat Saddam Hussein poses. Those who favor deterrence acknowledge that the containment regime that constrained Iraq during the 1990's has frayed beyond repair, but argue that Mr. Hussein can still be kept in check by American threats to respond to any new Iraqi aggression with force -- including nuclear bombardment, if necessary.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Slow Compliance With U.S. Education Law
description: The United States education secretary said in a visit to New York City yesterday that it would take many months to ''work out all the kinks'' in a law giving students at failing schools the right to transfer to better schools. The secretary, Rod Paige, left, paid a visit to Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein in the Bronx yesterday, and said it would take time to ensure that New York City and other school districts were in compliance with the law, which was signed in January. But in New York and other cities, students were not able to transfer this fall because they were notified too late or because there was no room in higher-performing schools. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Response Time To Police Calls Is 29% Faster
description: New York City police officers were able to get to the scenes of reported crimes much faster in the past year, according to the mayor's office, which said the average response time had been cut by nearly three minutes, even as the number of officers on patrol declined and the number of radio calls increased slightly.

title: Those Earthy Elizabethans
description: With its black-and-white floor tiles and wooden rood screen, the church of St. Luke-in-the-Fields in the West Village evokes the flavor of Renaissance Dutch painting: a clean soapy tang. It seems an appropriate setting for the early-music ensemble called My Lord Chamberlain's Consort, which specializes in music four centuries old. The title of the Consort's concert last Friday, ``Keeping Up With the Joneses,'' was indicative of the fey quality characteristic of Elizabethan England, which often emerges as an earthiness masquerading as perfect decorum.

title: Frequent-Flier Discount From Southeast Airlines

The airlines' Club $59 charges a yearly fee of $99 a person and $199 for up to four family members. For that, it guarantees a one-way fare of $59 (there are a limited number of seats available to club members on each flight). There are no blackout dates, and members get separate check-in and priority boarding. Call (866) 425-8259 or visit www.flyseal.com . These are scheduled public charter flights, and various fees and taxes are extra. The $59 fares are available to nonmembers, but some seats cost more.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Venture May Expand
description: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation will probably join a semiconductor venture run by NEC and Hitachi early next year. The Mitsubishi business that makes dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips will be folded into Elpida Memory, a 50-50 venture owned by NEC and Hitachi, according to people at the company. The companies will conclude terms of the deal next month, The Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported. When completed, the companies will hold about 11 percent of the global chip market. Ken Belson(NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Violence On The Rise
description: Bombings in Northern Ireland increased 80 percent in the year ended March 31, to 318, according to the first report from the province's Policing Board, an independent oversight body formed under the 1998 peace accord to increase public confidence in the police. Most attacks, by paramilitaries or sectarian rioters, were against residential buildings, and involved small homemade explosives. Shootings increased by 8 percent, to 358, nearly double the rate when the main paramilitary groups declared cease-fires in 1998. The rise in attacks is seen as a sign of grass-roots dissatisfaction with political reforms and heightened tensions between Protestants and Catholics, particularly in Belfast. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: 6 Teams to Create Designs for Rebuilding Lower Manhattan
description: Six teams of architects, artists and designers, representing 27 firms from five countries, were chosen today by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to create new designs for the World Trade Center site and nearby areas.

title: Taking Kissinger to Task, Perhaps Even a Bit More
description: The feverish position paper called ''The Trials of Henry Kissinger,'' which began a two-week run yesterday at Film Forum, may not be a breakthrough in filmmaking, but it is unwavering and arresting. This picture is so rich with sound bites that it's like a chocolate dessert: you know you shouldn't have one more bite but the next thing you know you're cramming in another mouthful. And it's full of savory mouthfuls; each eloquent interview from the procession of talking heads is like a soliloquy. The film is an ad hominem attack that would more aptly be called ''The Conviction of Kissinger,'' because just about every on-camera statement is as convincing as the trail of information uncovered by the merciless detectives on ''C.S.I.''

This was a eulogy for the world's fastest human, who died of prostate cancer and heart and kidney ailments last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGNER, ALFRED PAUL
description: BERGNER-Alfred Paul, 59. Of Bethesda, Maryland, on Tuesday, September 24, 2002, of a brain tumor. He was the beloved husband of 34 years and the best friend of Jane Cohen Bergner; the beloved father of Lauren Jill Bergner, of New York, NY and Justin Laurence Bergner, of Arlington, VA.; the devoted son of Isidore Bergner, of Washington, D.C.; and the brother of Faye Miller, of Beverly Hills, CA. An attorney who maintained his own law practice in Washington, DC, concentrating on Federal taxation, estate and retirement planning and probate, he lived bravely for 17 months with and in spite of a brain tumor. From 1967 through 1968, he clerked for Chief Judge William Drennen of the United States Tax court, in Washington, DC. It was in Washington that he met his wife, also a tax lawyer. Following his clerkship, he practiced law with the Washington, DC tax firm of Wenchel, Schulman & Manning where he became a partner. This was followed by partnerships in other Washington law firms until he commenced his own law practice in 1991. From 1988 through 1989, he served as president of the Washington, DC Chapter of the American Friends of the Hebrew University. He founded the Alfred P. and Jane Bergner Family Scholarship at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, Israel, making it possible annually for a college student who is a member of Washington Hebrew Congregation to spend the junior year studying at the Hebrew University. He continued to serve on the national board of the American Friends of the Hebrew University. In addition, for many years he served as a Trustee of the Hebrew Home of Washington, DC, and he remained as a member of the Home's honorary board. He served as member of the past - parents fundraising committee of the National Cathedral School, as well as chair of the fundraising committee for parents of the Amherst College Class of 1995, from which college both he and his daughter graduated. A native of New York, NY, he graduated in 1959 from the Bronx High School of Science and cum laude in 1963 from Amherst College, following which he received an LL.B. degree from Harvard Law School in 1966 and a Masters in Taxation degree from the Graduate Tax Program at New York University in 1967, prior to clerking on the Tax Court. He was admired by his family, friends and clients for both his fortitude and his devotion to those whom he loved and for whom he cared. He was a kind and gentle person with a wry sense of humor, high intellect and outstanding judgment. Memorial contributions may be made to either (1) The Adult Brain Tumor Program, The Hassenfeld Cancer Center, New York University School of Medicine, Attention: Dr. Jonathan L. Finlay, Director, 317 East 34th St, 10th Fl, New York, NY 10016; or (2) The Brain Tumor Clinic, Duke University Medical Center, Attention: Dr. Allan H. Friedman, Co - Director, Trent Drive, Duke South, Rm 4520, Durham, NC 27710. Edward Sagel Funeral Direction, Inc 800-217-9403.

title: Abduction-Notification System Can Now Send Online Alerts
description: The Amber Alert system, set up to notify the public quickly about missing or abducted children, relies mainly on the conventional media. In states that have adopted the system, the messages are broadcast on television and radio, posted on electronic freeway signs and, in some states, delivered to toll booth operators and even lottery ticket terminals. Soon, those messages could start appearing on the screens of computers connected to the Web.

But in a series of advertisements that begin running today, they are joining with 86 other recording artists to speak out against unauthorized music file-sharing, claiming it threatens the livelihood of everyone from recording artists and writers to sound engineers and record-store clerks.

With the exception of Schubert's big A major Sonata (D. 959), the program was devoted to premieres, and with the Schubert representing the Viennese mainstream, the other works were by composers from Israel (Ron Yedidia), Mexico (Samuel Zyman) and England (Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji).

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Move To Ease Flow Of Information
description: China has long been a place where even routine government data, as mundane as the working hours of the central bank or the release date of common statistics, can be treated as state secrets, with those who leak information punishable by law. But a group of legal scholars have been given a mandate by the State Council, China's cabinet, to draft a law defining the types of information that can be released to the public, according to China Youth Daily, a government newspaper. The lawyers will draw clearer distinctions between public information and official secrets and seek to speed up the release of information that is not classified. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: HANDSPRING CUTS WORK FORCE Handspring Inc. , a maker of hand-held computers, has dismissed about 80 workers, or 20 percent of its worldwide work force, as part of an effort to reduce costs and become profitable as sales decline. The company has about 320 workers left in its Mountain View, Calif., headquarters and in Geneva, a spokesman, Allen Bush, said. The cuts, many in the marketing department, were necessary to reduce the break-even point, he said. Handspring, which competes against larger rivals like Palm Inc. and Hewlett-Packard , has not had a profit since its initial public offering in 2000. Second-quarter worldwide shipments of all hand-held computers fell 3.5 percent from a year ago as a shortage of new models hampered sales, the market researcher Gartner Dataquest said in August. "We had been saying that $90 million in sales would be a break-even point for us," said Brad Driver, Handspring director for investor relations. "Now, it is somewhat less than $90 million." Shares rose 8 cents, to $1.10. They are off 84 percent this year. (Bloomberg News)

title: Meeting the Threat of Smallpox

title: Moving a CD Collection Into Your Hip Pocket
description: Q. I have a few hundred compact discs of classical music. Is there a portable device on which all these CD's can be stored and indexed? How much sound quality is lost when you convert a song from a compact disc to the MP3 format?

title: U.S. Children Evacuated From Rebel-Held Ivory Coast City
description: About 100 American schoolchildren trapped for six days in a rebel-held city here were evacuated today by French soldiers, as American Special Forces landed nearby in the capital.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Brazil's jobless rate fell slightly in August, ending four months of rising unemployment. The government statistics institute said the seasonally adjusted jobless rate had fallen to 7.2 percent in August, compared with 7.4 percent in July, though it was still higher than last August's 6.2 percent rate. Rising steadily for four months, unemployment has become a leading election issue and has hurt support for the government candidate, Jos Serra, who currently trails the front-runner Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of the left-wing Workers Party by 25 percentage points in some opinion polls. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Putting The Fab In Prefab
description: MATTHEW HRANEK, a New York photographer, expects his new house to materialize the way his mail-order deliveries do: on the back of a truck.

title: McCall Answers Negative Ads
description: H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and Democratic nominee for governor, released this 30-second ad yesterday to be shown on upstate New York broadcast stations and cable stations in the suburbs of New York City. It is his first ad in a week and the first in response to two negative ads by Gov. George E. Pataki in the past week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, HARRIET & JEFFREY
description: GINSBURG-Harriet & Jeffrey. The Board of Directors, Officers and Employees of Seeds of Peace extend their condolences to our esteemed Board Member, Alan Ginsburg, and his family on the loss of his wife, Harriet, and his son, Jeffrey. Harriet's strength and love kept Alan and the family together and allowed them all to make meaningful contributions to the world. We extend our deepest love and condolences to Alan, his children, grandchildren and Diane. Words cannot express how sad we are. Seeds of Peace

title: Suddenly, the Diamondbacks Are Looking Mortal
description: It officially became worrisome today for the World Series champions. No more days of rest and decoy lineups and leisurely anticipation of the playoffs for Arizona. An unexpected urgency crept into the remains of the regular season, like a shadow sliding across the outfield.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a hip-hop disc jockey's complaint that she was assaulted by a disc jockey at a rival radio station gave a misspelled surname in some copies for the complainant's spokeswoman. She is Getty Gizaw, not Gizow.

title: Knee Surgery Puts Bure On the Shelf
description: Pavel Bure, the high-scoring right wing whom the Rangers are counting on to help lead them to the playoffs for the first time since 1997, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his right knee today to repair torn cartilage, the club announced yesterday.

title: The Healthy Politics of Iraq
description: President Bush and the Democrats in Congress are suddenly in meltdown mode over the issue of who is playing politics on the eve of a possible war with Iraq. Mr. Bush has begun using the campaign against terrorism in his stump speeches, declaring that Democrats are ''not interested in the security of the American people.'' Yesterday Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, fired back with an impassioned denunciation of Mr. Bush. Meanwhile, Al Gore is accusing the president of being political, and being accused of the same thing by the White House. None of this is unhealthy. We just wish all this intensity was being directed at the issue of Iraq instead of people's political motives.

title: Mortgage Applications Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25  An index measuring applications for mortgages rose last week to the second-highest level in more than a decade of record keeping as mortgage rates declined further, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

title: No Laughing Matters: Misery Loves Comedy
description: LIVE FROM NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENHECK, SHERRY
description: ROSENHECK - Sherry. On September 24, 2002. Beloved daughter of Sam and Betty. Beloved sister of Arthur. We will miss you always. Services Friday, September 27, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Bomb Suspect's Detention Without Charges Is Challenged
description: The American Civil Liberties Union said that it would file legal papers today in United States District Court in Manhattan challenging the government's decision to detain Jose Padilla in a military jail without charges or trial.

title: GOODYEAR TO LAY OFF 450 WORKERS IN TENNESSEE
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it would lay off 450 workers, or 12 percent of the work force, at a Tennessee factory after its sales declined last month. The layoffs will begin Monday at a Union City, Tenn., plant that has about 3,800 employees, a spokesman, Clint Smith, said. Goodyear said last week that its August sales of replacement tires for cars and light trucks slid more than the industry's 8 percent decline. Sales to automakers also declined as the industry total rose 3 percent, the company said.

title: A Theater Gets A New Name: Al Hirschfeld
description: The Martin Beck Theater on West 45th Street will be renamed for the illustrator Al Hirschfeld, in tribute to his running 76-year chronicle of the life of Broadway and its greatest performers.

title: Federal Court Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyco Rewarded an Executive During a Grand Jury Inquiry
description: Tyco International agreed to pay a severance package of $44.8 million in cash to Mark H. Swartz, its chief financial officer, while he was under investigation by a grand jury in Manhattan that later indicted him on fraud charges.

title: Tony Blair's Role: Statesman, or Poodle?
description: When President Bush had a problem this month making his case on Iraq to the Europeans, the man he sought out was Tony Blair, Britain's prime minister. When Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany had a problem this week with Washington about Iraq, he too went to see Mr. Blair.

title: Tired of Chasing Dustballs? Let a Robot Do the Job
description: It may look more like an oversize Frisbee than Rosie the robotic housekeeper of ''Jetsons'' fame, but Roomba is, in fact, a fully automatic robot vacuum cleaner for homes and small offices. Its maker, iRobot, bills this seven-pound $199 sweeper as the Intelligent FloorVac.

title: 11-Year-Old Collapse Motivates Calcavecchia
description: Mark Calcavecchia has vivid memories of his last Ryder Cup. That could be a problem.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Sanctions For Unpaid Parking Tickets Are Lifted
description: More than 37,000 New Jersey drivers whose licenses were suspended for unpaid parking tickets will have them temporarily reinstated by the state, officials have announced. Hundreds of irate drivers had clogged the city's courthouse on Monday after receiving suspension notices over the weekend, saying the tickets in question were inaccurate or had long since been paid. Transportation Commissioner James P. Fox said that affected drivers could continue to drive until the validity of the summonses was figured out.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Storm Disperses Lawmakers
description: With Tropical Storm Isidore bearing down on the Gulf Coast, lawmakers recessed a deadlocked special session on proposed changes in the state's civil justice system until Oct. 7. House and Senate negotiators have for two weeks failed to reach consensus on how to cap jury damage awards, apportion financial responsibility among multiple defendants and deal with class-action lawsuits against drug companies in a special session called by Gov. Ronnie Musgrove to deal with the lack of affordable medical malpractice insurance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARCHMAR, BOEHM, AN NA
description: KARCHMAR - BOEHM - An na. Born in Warsaw, Poland on July 30, 1906, passed away on September 24. She was the loving wife of Herman Boehm, widow of Stephan Karchmar, devoted mother to Robert Karchmar, and mother-in-law to Yosefa Klein-Karchmar and Sylvia Karchmar. She was the matriarch of her family around the world: Vivian Pires of Brazil, the Bermans of Australia, the Dorits of Mexico, and the Karczmars. To countless other friends, including Irena Starzec, bound into Anna's family by love, she was a teacher, mentor, inspiration and confidante; a charismatic and proud woman whose fierce spirit, humor, and determination moved both people and mountains. To granddaughters Lara Karchmar and Dorian KarchmarKotzin, great-grandsons Benjamin and Dylan Orr, and many ''young-people'' who adopted her over the years, she was, simply, Nana: Grande-Dame in furs and pearls; fearless reprimander of any table or chair leg foolish enough to stub a small toe; extravagant giver of cherished heirlooms and words of wisdom, of glamorous memories, traditions and home-cooked meals. A born diplomat, elegant in every possible sense of the word, hostess extraordinaire, a charmer with a backbone of steel, she set the standard for generosity and spirit. She was a Holocaust survivor, fluent in five languages, who had lived in Warsaw, Paris, London, Rio de Janeiro, and New York. Her unerring sense of style and beauty translated themselves into a career in fur and jewelry design, and the fine arts. She created around her a unique atmosphere that imprinted itself on all who knew her. Her absence will leave a perpetual void in our hearts. Services at 11:00AM Friday, September 27, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Doctors Without Borders would be appreciated.

title: Mission Possible
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Hiring Ends Until Budget Passes
description: The Transportation Security Administration, which was set up after the Sept. 11 attacks to supervise air safety, has frozen most of its hiring because Congress has not approved its budget for the fiscal year that will begin on Tuesday, the agency said today.

title: Fighting Street to Street
description: To understand why an invasion of Iraq may not be the cakewalk that the White House expects, pay $20 (round trip) and board an Iraqi Airways flight that soars from Baghdad straight through the American-enforced ''no-flight zone'' to Basra on the southern tip of Iraq.

title: Mollie Wilmot, Socialite, Dies
description: Mollie Wilmot, the socialite with the oversize white sunglasses who rose to celebrity in 1984 when a tanker ran aground at her Palm Beach, Fla., mansion, died on Sept. 17 at her apartment in Manhattan.

title: After Attack on Temple, Indian City Remains Quiet
description: Late Tuesday night, as gunmen were still battling police forces inside a Hindu temple complex about 20 miles from here, this city's police commissioner, K.S. Kaushik, called a meeting of his top officers.

description: MANHATTAN: JUDGE RULES AGAINST LENNON AIDE

title: Judge Says City Failed to Give Required Care to Cuffed Inmates
description: Afederal judge has found the city's Department of Correction in contempt for failing to comply with an order requiring monthly medical checkups for inmates whose hands are cuffed behind their backs for security reasons on trips outside a jail.

title: U.S. Gave Secrets To Terror Suspect
description: Federal prosecutors mistakenly turned over 48 classified F.B.I. reports to Zacarias Moussaoui in what a federal judge described as a grave security breach, the government acknowledged in court documents released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, SYLVIA
description: PARKER-Sylvia. On September 26, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Jack Parker and Lawrence Hecht. Devoted mother of Jill Roeder and the late Nancy Parker and stepmother of Dale Sanserviero. Loving grandmother of Jennifer and Michael Mostel. Graveside service Sunday 11:30 A.M. at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Making Money on Fiber, the El Paso Way
description: IT is when times are good that a management's -- and a board's -- true colors can show. As the El Paso Corporation struggles to deal with a ruling that it acted improperly in last year's California energy crisis, investors may want to look back at how things were in early 2001, when El Paso was a Wall Street star.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: More Jobs Cut At Bank
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., the banking subsidiary of the German insurance company Allianz A.G., confirmed it is to cut 2,700 to 3,000 jobs as part of a new $684 million cost-cutting program. The company said 1,000 to 1,200 of the job cuts will come at the bank's troubled investment banking operations, Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein. Dresdner Bank is already cutting 8,000 jobs as part of a restructuring that began in May 2000. Those cuts are expected to reduce costs by $1.27 billion. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Eduard Gufeld, 66, Chess Grandmaster and Writer
description: Eduard Y. Gufeld, a chess grandmaster and prolific chess writer who coached many Russian players, including the former women's world champion Maya Chiburdanidze, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 66 and had lived in Los Angeles since 1995.

title: PHILIP MORRIS REDUCES ITS EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Philip Morris, the world's biggest cigarette maker, slashed its annual profit forecast yesterday for the second time this year because of lower-than-expected sales and higher promotional spending. Per-share earnings will rise 3 to 5 percent this year, Philip Morris said. In July, the company said profit would be at the low end of its forecast of 9 to 11 percent. Philip Morris's share of sales in the United States has picked up slightly since July, when it reached a low of 49 percent. The company said third-quarter profit would be about $1.26 a share, a cent more than analysts' estimates. Shares of Philip Morris rose $1.25, to $42.73. The company released the revised forecast after the markets closed.

title: 'Biggie and Tupac'
description: Directed by Nick Broomfield

title: German Technology Stock Market to Be Dissolved
description: Two and a half years ago, the bursting of the dot-com bubble erased most of the market value of Germany's technology sector. Now, the market itself is being scrapped.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holiday Shemini Atzeret, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Finding Lyricism in Tragedy
description: After just three days the Metropolitan has its first triumph of the new season with Richard Strauss's ''Elektra,'' the 1992 Otto Schenk production, last presented three years ago. At the end of Wednesday night's performance, the soprano Deborah Polaski, who had nailed the punishing title role, and the soprano Karita Mattila, radiant as Chrysothemis, Elektra's weak-willed younger sister, received ecstatic ovations. But if pressed to give top credit to one artist for the performance's success, I'd pick James Levine, who conducted a shimmering, supple and lucid account of this 1909 work with a libretto by Hugo von Hofmannsthal.

title: Germans in U.S. With Data On a Top Qaeda Suspect
description: German police officials have traveled to Washington to exchange information with American investigators about Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a top suspect in the Sept. 11 terror attacks who is thought to have inside knowledge of the Hamburg cell of Al Qaeda, according to the German Interior Ministry.

title: Other Trials, Like Poverty, Are on Sarajevo's Mind
description: Ten years ago today, this city was under siege, its beleaguered residents hoping desperately for the resumption of an international airlift to see them through the bleak Balkan winter.

title: GEMSTAR-TV GUIDE REPORTS A LOSS OF $954 MILLION
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International, the publisher of TV Guide magazine and electronic television-program information, said yesterday that it had a preliminary second-quarter loss of $954 million, or $2.32 a share, because of a write-down of the value of assets. In the same quarter last year, the company had a loss of $135 million, or 33 cents. Sales fell 15 percent, to $272 million. Gemstar, based in Pasadena, Calif., is delaying the release of final second-quarter results until the completion of an auditing review. The company, which said last month that it would restate 2001 results because of disputed fees from a rival, had $1.26 billion in costs to write down the value of intangible assets.

title: Ex-Councilman Changes His Mind And Awaits His Day in Court
description: If ever there was a member of the City Council with a reputation for honesty, it was Sheldon Leffler. Long regarded as one of the most thoughtful elected officials in the city, he had a record of unblemished integrity throughout nearly a quarter of a century as a city lawmaker.

title: Corrections

On Page 1 of the section, the artist was Colleen Mulrenan; on the continuation, Peter Hutton.

description: WHO -- Kennedy Lemke, 40, a computer network administrator.

title: Zahringer Defeats Courville to Win Mid-Amateur Title
description: George Zahringer III has a long list of accomplishments in his career as an amateur golfer, but it was not until today that he won his first national title. At age 49, Zahringer became the oldest player to win the United States Mid-Amateur championship when he defeated Jerry Courville Jr., another prominent amateur in the metropolitan area, 3 and 2.

description: Following is a transcript of remarks President Bush made yesterday in the Rose Garden at the White House after a meeting with members of Congress on a Congressional resolution on Iraq, as recorded by The Federal News Service:

description: DON'T expect much fine dining or many luxury accommodations along the Maine portion of the International Appalachian Trail. But there are enough suitable food and lodging choices here to sustain you through a weekend trip.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

description: To the Editor:

title: Law Dean Installed as N.Y.U. President
description: As law dean at New York University, John Sexton typically wore sweaters and corduroy slacks to the office and rarely stood on ceremony. Yesterday, dressed in a flowing purple academic robe with a red collar, he used the pomp of his formal installation as N.Y.U.'s 15th president to urge an audience of 900 to help transform the university.

title: Timeless Themes, Suddenly Timely
description: No, it was not planned as a response to Sept. 11. Bill Viola's newest video work, ''Going Forth by Day,'' an ambitious meditation on the epic themes of human existence (individuality, society, death and rebirth) was well under way before that fatal date. Then, amazingly, events caught up with it, and the cycles he had already shot (rebirth, the path of life, catastrophic flood, final journey, and part of a resurrection narrative) took on a new intensity. Shooting continued, but now infused with a ''raw, emotional energy'' and a heightened sense of purpose.

title: Bomb Suspect's Lawyers Decry Detention
description: Lawyers for a man accused of plotting to explode a radioactive bomb in the United States filed court papers yesterday, calling it illegal for the military to detain him in isolation without charging him.

title: Tiger Woods on Top Of List of Endorsers
description: For the fourth consecutive year, the golfer Tiger Woods was named the top product endorser in sports in a survey by Burns Sports and Celebrities in Evanston, Ill., a company that helps match athletes with advertisers.

title: Drug-Gang Arrests Seen as Positive Step at Brooklyn Complex
description: The five gangs sharing 30 acres of turf got along splendidly. For at least the last five years, the police say, ''The Rough Riders,'' ''The Little A-Team,'' ''The Front Crew'' and the other gangs agreed to dtente. Business was thriving in each little slice of the sprawling Cypress Hills housing complex in Brooklyn, and there was little need to fight.

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: Verizon Sells Telecom Stake
description: Verizon Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its 20 percent stake in the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand for 1.6 billion New Zealand dollars ($754.7 million). Merrill Lynch, which paid Verizon about 4.35 New Zealand dollars ($2.05) a share is offering to sell them to investors for 4.45 to 4.55 New Zealand dollars a share, said Paul Masi, co-head of Merrill's Australian business. Verizon, which is trying to pay back about $6 billion in debt, bought the stake from the New Zealand government in 1990 and said in October last year that it wanted to sell the shares to raise cash.

title: New Software Quietly Diverts Sales Commissions
description: Some popular online services are using a new kind of software to divert sales commissions that would otherwise be paid to small online merchants by big sites like Amazon and eToys.

title: Though Nets Got Close, They Have Far to Go
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott does not usually need a confidence boost.

title: Rolling Stones Revel in the Act of Survival
description: In rock 'n' roll, idealism gets old pretty quickly. Angry young frontmen seem a lot less vital once they mature into middle-age earnest frontmen. Maybe that's why Mick Jagger still puts on such a great show -- because that seems to be the only thing on earth he really cares about. He stands for nothing, he falls for nothing, and it's starting to seem as if he -- and his band -- might last forever.

title: The Greater Nuclear Danger
description: While the Bush administration has been pushing hard for military action to neutralize Iraq before it gets nuclear weapons, Washington has been moving much more slowly to eliminate an even more troubling nuclear threat -- the vast array of bomb-grade materials that lie poorly protected around the world, waiting for some terrorist and rogue state to buy or steal them. Indeed, the only reason to fear that Saddam Hussein will have a nuclear arsenal any time soon is the possibility that he might get his hands on some of this loosely guarded material. Left to his own devices, he is years away from developing nuclear weapons, according to two authoritative assessments issued this month. The top priority in the fight against nuclear terrorism must be to safeguard all fissile materials that would make such terrorism possible.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bedford: School Bus Strike In Westchester
description: Union bus drivers serving seven public schools in Westchester County failed to show up for work yesterday in what officials are calling a wildcat strike. About 4,100 students in the Bedford Central School District and 750 private-school students were without bus service. Schools Superintendent Bruce Dennis said that the district was negotiating with the bus company, Baumann & Sons, about supplying other drivers until the company settled with its union members. About 80 drivers, bus monitors and mechanics of Teamsters Union Local 456 have been negotiating a five-year contract with Baumann since the summer, when their last contract expired, said Mark Portnoy, the bus company's labor negotiator. He said both sides had met on Tuesday and agreed on a wage increase of 5 to 8 percent in the first year with additional increases to follow, but that no terms had been reached on holiday and sick pay. The drivers currently are paid $15.03 an hour.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Credit Curtailed
description: To slow the explosive growth of consumer credit, the Bank of Korea said today that it would cut back the loans it makes to commercial banks at preferential rates. Analysts said that the reduction, to a total of $8 billion outstanding from $9.7 billion, signaled that the central bank was preparing to raise interest rates. Credit card debt has ballooned in South Korea in recent years, and easier access to mortgages has pushed property prices up. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, MARY M. (NEE EISENMENGER)
description: CONNOLLY-Mary M. (nee Eisenmenger) on September 25, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Harold. Loving mother of Harold X. and his wife, Barbara. Much loved grandmother of Keara, Kristin, Melissa & Caitlin. Great-grandmother of six. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 & 7-9 pm, at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Mass Monday, 10 AM, at Holy Family Church in New Rochelle. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne. In lieu of flowers, donations to the College of Mt. St. Vincent in the Bronx.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Charity To Get New Chief
description: The September 11 Fund, which raised $501 million to help the victims of the terrorist attack, said yesterday that Carol Kellermann, currently the president of Learning Leaders Inc., one of the oldest school volunteer programs, would become its new leader in October. Ms. Kellermann, 51, a lawyer who has served in several nonprofit and government jobs, will replace Joshua Gotbaum and will oversee the $170 million remaining in the fund. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: A 60's Family, and Dick Clark, Too
description: If there is one show whose relentless advance hype should cause viewers to run the other way, it's ''American Dreams,'' about a Philadelphia family in 1963 and the 15-year-old daughter, Meg, whose dream is to dance on ''American Bandstand.'' The series' early mawkish promos (with the tag line ''Remember the innocence'') gave way to recent ones with a distorted sense of history. (''It was a time of challenge when we changed as a nation and the American dream was stronger than ever.'' Whatever that means.) And the show's central gimmick is the definition of cynical recycling. Dick Clark is one of the executive producers, and the series uses clips from his old ''American Bandstand'' shows. It's easy to see why he would care if Meg Pryor gets on ''Bandstand,'' but why should we?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, CAMILLA S.
description: ARMSTRONG - Camilla S. Formerly of Chevy Chase, MD, on September 19, 2002. Beloved mother of Stephen of Washington, D.C. and Brian of New York City. Beloved grandmother of Katrina Armstrong Randall, David and Nicholas. She is also survived by three great-grandchildren William, Samantha and Katharine Randall. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 5, at 11:30 A.M. at New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, 1313 New York Avenue N.W., Washington, D.C. Memorial gifts may be made to the New York Avenue Foundation (for the Community Club), New York Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Sluggish U.S. Economy a Global Concern
description: Despite nearly daily news of economic strife in Brazil and Argentina, a growing number of economists and governments around the world worry that the biggest risks to the global economy are emanating not from Latin America or Asia but from the United States and Europe.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Party Is Over For Millionaire Convict
description: Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire novelist and member of the House of Lords, was ordered moved from a so-called open prison to a closed one for having violated his home visit rules by going to a party in a neighboring county while on release. Lord Archer, 62, is serving a four-year term for perjury and perverting the course of justice in his 1987 libel trial against a London newspaper that reported he had paid hush money to a prostitute, but he is permitted home visits and time out to work at a local theater. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: HELEN OF TROY IS ACQUIRING SIX BRANDS FROM P.&G.
description: The Helen of Troy Corporation, a maker of hair care products, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Vitalis and five other consumer brand names from Procter & Gamble. Terms were not disclosed. Under the agreement, Helen of Troy will buy Vitalis, Condition 3-in-1, Final Net and Ammens directly. It will acquire two other brands, Sea Breeze and Vitapointe, through license agreements. Helen of Troy, based in El Paso, licenses personal care products and accessories under the Vidal Sassoon and Revlon brand names. It also sells products under its own brands.

title: At Disney, Speculation Over Executive's Successor
description: Speculation at the Walt Disney Company has already begun about who will take the place of Paul Pressler, the former chairman of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts, who is leaving to become chief executive of the Gap. A Disney executive said no decision had been made, but an announcement is expected in the next week. Several internal candidates are being considered.

title: Modernism in Iran
description: ''The Hand,'' below, a painting circa 1960 by Hossein Zenderoudi, is an emblem of modern Iranian visual culture in ''Between Word and Image'' at the Grey Art Gallery.

title: Defend the Country, Not the Party
description: In the days after Sept. 11, 2001, President Bush made a strong effort to work hand in hand with Congressional leaders to build a bipartisan consensus for the war on terrorism. In the State of the Union address he said eloquently, ''I'm a proud member of my party. Yet as we act to win the war [and] protect our people . . . we must act, first and foremost, not as Republicans, not as Democrats, but as Americans.''

title: 36 Hours | Santa Fe, N.M.
description: FOR generations, since Georgia O'Keeffe arrived here in the 1920's, visitors have been drawn to Santa Fe for its food, art, limpid sunshine and multiple intersecting cultures. In recent years, however, what summertime visitors have found are crowds. Hundreds of thousands of tourists jam America's oldest capital city from Memorial Day to Labor Day, which makes autumn the ideal time to arrive. The days are still warm, the evenings pleasantly brisk, the street corners filled with the acrid scent of roasting green chilies (you can buy bags of the stuff, warm from the roasters), and the aspen leaves are beginning to look molten. Best of all, Santa Fe regains its ancient, charming somnolence. It's a slow-moving town again, and better for it. GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

title: A Biotechnical Tuxedo Gives Its Wearer a Lift
description: You can tell how recent one of Jackie Chan's movies is by the size of his nose. Gauging its spread is like counting the rings in the core of a tree: if it looks as if he has broken it one more time, you know you're catching something newish.

title: Scientists Say They've Found Elusive Protein That Might Help Fight AIDS
description: Scientists said yesterday that they had identified an elusive substance that allows some people to remain healthy for many years after being infected by the virus that causes AIDS. The finding could lead to a new approach to fight the disease.

description: Spirited Away

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FURMAN, DON
description: FURMAN-Don. September 27, 1992. Time will never explain how much you are missed. Love, your sweets, Rikki, Allison & Fred

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Joint Bid For Retailer
description: Two rivals trying to buy the Belgian retail group GIB agreed to join forces, cutting short an anticipated bidding war. Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille, a holding company owned by a Belgian financier, Albert Frere, and Ackermans & Van Haaren, another holding company, offered 43 euros ($41.98) a share for the company, which holds 1.3 billion euros ($1.27 billion) in cash and owns retail assets including a chain of hamburger restaurants. Analysts expect GIB shareholders to accept the joint bid. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, JOE
description: COLLINS-Joe, died peacefully in his sleep on Thursday, September 12, 2002. He worked as a Foreign Correspondent for the London office of the New York Times for many years during and after W.W. II and will be sadly missed by all of his family. The funeral was held in Worthing, Sussex, England on Friday, September 20. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Eha.

title: Farmland Investors Lose Ruling
description: Shareholders of Farmland Industries today lost a bid to form a committee to represent their interests as Farmland, the largest United States farm cooperative, reorganizes under bankruptcy protection.

title: Down the Road Apiece
description: When John Lee Hooker died in June 2001, he was 83 years old, and he had lost not a trace of his original blues. In a way, old age seemed to distill Hooker into something bluer than he was as a young man, if only because the blues is a lifelong music, a lifelong affliction. What rock 'n' roll is we're still finding out. Young bands come and go -- reinventing the original spark in the music -- while the Rolling Stones, who are on a worldwide tour and performing in New York and New Jersey this weekend, push onward into new ground simply by growing old and continuing to perform. Nearly everyone has pointed out that this is not the kind of path-breaking the Stones had in mind when the band began, eons ago, when the thought of growing old still sickened them. But it's the only kind of path-breaking they have left.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ClearOne Shares Plunge On Forecast
description: ClearOne Communications Inc. shares fell as much as 50 percent yesterday, their biggest decline ever, after the maker of videoconferencing products said it would break even, excluding certain items, in the fiscal first quarter. Shares of ClearOne fell $4.40, or 49 percent, to $4.49 in Nasdaq trading of 2.69 million shares, 27 times the three-month daily average. The stock, which was the third-biggest decliner on Nasdaq, fell as low as $4.42. ClearOne Communications was expected to have a profit of 20 cents a share, the average estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call, excluding costs for staff reductions and an inventory write-off.

title: Op-Art
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nippon Considers Write-Offs
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation will discuss with third parties whether it needs to book losses on the overseas investments of NTT DoCoMo Inc.in the six-month period ending Monday, the president of NTT, Norio Wada, left, said. His comment came after The Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported that DoCoMo is expected to book 500 billion yen ($4.07 billion) in valuation losses on its shareholdings in overseas companies. The NTT group will discuss the matter with third parties including auditing and consulting companies and investment banks, Mr. Wada said. DoCoMo said earlier that it would carry out any write-downs if necessary after it conducts an overall study of its businesses, including the value of overseas partners' shares and other factors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Killed In Subway
description: A woman was killed yesterday afternoon by a northbound A train at Times Square, officials said. Witnesses said she threw herself in front of the train. Trains were rerouted and delays were caused just before the start of the evening rush. The police said the woman, whose name was not immediately released, was killed and her body taken to Bellevue Hospital Center. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it received word of the death shortly before 4 p.m. Some northbound trains were rerouted from Eighth Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas, and southbound trains, normally express, were converted to local local service between 59th Street and Canal Street. The scene at the 42nd Street station was cleared shortly before 5 p.m., the M.T.A. said. Daisy Hernndez (NYT)

title: FORD SAYS IT WILL CUT SEVERAL THOUSAND JOBS THIS YEAR
description: The Ford Motor Company will cut several thousand factory jobs in the United States by the end of the year under its turnaround plan, the chief operating officer, Nicholas V. Scheele, said yesterday. The reductions are part of a previously announced plan to eliminate 35,000 jobs, including 12,000 last year, and close five factories by 2005. No more factories will be shut down because market share would go down, Mr. Scheele said in an interview at the Paris auto show. The chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., is aiming to have the company reach pretax profit of $7 billion annually by 2005. The company lost $5.45 billion last year.

Then came multiculturalism, globe-trotting biennials, the Internet and other such mind-dilating phenomena, and the perspective changed. Modern and contemporary, Western and non-Western are now recognized as overlapping categories.

title: An Uneasy Rider on the Road to Self-Discovery
description: OF all the dramatic transformations Jack Nicholson has undergone in his 44-year screen career, none is more astonishing than his embodiment of a retired, widowed insurance executive from Omaha in Alexander Payne's film ''About Schmidt.'' Plodding in a weary, stiff-legged shuffle, his shoulders bowed, his features half-frozen into the guarded, sunken expression of someone who has devoted decades of thought to actuarial calculation, his character, Warren Schmidt, is a staid Middle American everyman who finds himself adrift at the precarious age of 66.

Nine players were on the platform, in various twosomes and a trio, performing music by Mozart, Ravel, Poulenc, Debussy and Bach. The sound was delicious, the musicianship impeccable. And though only pianos were at work (until the Bach concerto, for three pianos and strings), this was real chamber music, made by strong personalities playing off and with each other.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Introduces New Handset
description: Nokia, the world's biggest mobile-phone maker, yesterday introduced a handset that works on both existing and faster wireless networks in a bid to defend its market share against rivals like Motorola. The model, named 6650 and Nokia's first based on the so-called third-generation technology, is capable of capturing, viewing and sending both still pictures and video clips. The handset uses wideband code division multiple access technology. The phone is part of an effort to get customers to replace their handsets as markets saturate. Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., which next month will become the first phone company to offer faster wireless services in Europe, has chosen phones made by NEC and Motorola, the world's second-biggest handset maker.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Taming Saigon
description: As Vietnam seeks to define its own boundary between liberty and license, the authorities have issued edicts intended to tame the increasingly energetic nightlife of Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon. Bars, nightclubs and karaoke parlors will have to keep down the music and close their doors at midnight, after which all singing and dancing will be banned in the city. According to the newspaper Tuoi Tre, all activities that could incite violence or ''arouse people's sexual desires'' will have to stop. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Syphilis Cases Are Increasing, Officials Say
description: The number of syphilis cases reported in New York City increased more than 50 percent in the first six months of this year compared with the same period last year, mirroring a national trend that has mostly affected gay men, city health officials said yesterday.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: LACK OF MONEY FOR SPACE STATION Russia might have to suspend its manned missions to the International Space Station because of a "desperate" cash shortage, the director of the Russian part of the station said, raising the prospect of a crisis in the laboratory's operations. The official, Valery Ryumin, said that the Energiya company, builder of the Soyuz spacecraft, which ferries astronauts and supplies to the station, had run out of money and that without new funds, launches would stop in 2004. The Soyuz, which is not reusable, is designed to remain docked to the space station for long periods and to serve as an emergency escape vehicle, crucial functions the American space shuttle does not perform. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City May Alter Trash Rates
description: The Bloomberg administration is considering increasing or eliminating the cap on how much trash haulers can charge businesses to remove heavy garbage, a move the Giuliani administration had opposed. The businesses that would be affected are generally restaurants, markets and those discarding metal and glass. The maximum rate, $12.20 per cubic yard of loose refuse and $30.19 per cubic yard of compacted waste, was set in 1996 and has not been increased since. Yesterday, Jos Maldonado, chairman of the Business Integrity Commission, which regulates the rates, said the agency hoped to decide within months. ''By any measure, the current rate cap is inadequate to ensure that haulers can realize a profit,'' Mr. Maldonado said. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: GoAmerica Plans To Cut 50% Of Its Work Force
description: GoAmerica Inc. plans to cut 50 percent of its jobs and said it no longer needed to raise as much as $15 million in financing this year as it reduces costs and teams up with companies, including EarthLink Inc., to lift sales. The company, a provider of wireless Internet services, said it would cut 100 jobs through the end of the year. EarthLink, the third-largest United States Web-access service, agreed to buy part of the company's subscriber base and provide hardware, billing and network services to GoAmerica, the companies said. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. GoAmerica, based in Hackensack, N.J., is focusing on bolstering software and service revenue and attracting more subscribers, it said.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NOKIA INTRODUCES NEW HANDSET Nokia, the world's biggest mobile-phone maker, yesterday introduced a handset that works on both existing and faster wireless networks in a bid to defend its market share against rivals like Motorola . The model, named 6650 and Nokia's first based on the so-called third-generation technology, is capable of capturing, viewing and sending both still pictures and video clips. The handset uses wideband code division multiple access technology. The phone is part of an effort to get customers to replace their handsets as markets saturate. Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. , which next month will become the first phone company to offer faster wireless services in Europe, has chosen phones made by NEC and Motorola, the world's second-biggest handset maker. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, ROBERT M.
description: McCARTHY-Robert M. On September 26, 2002. Beloved husband of Claire K. (nee Keahon). Loving father of Irene, Patricia, Robert and Kevin. Dear brother of Geraldine. Fond grandfather of Alexander, Daniel, Kelly and Matthew. Visitation Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Mc Laughlin & Sons Funeral Home, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:30 AM St. Patrick's Church, Brooklyn. Interment St. Anthony's Cemetery, Nanuet, New York.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Judge Throws Out $1.25 Billion Legal Fee
description: A judge threw out a $1.25 billion legal fee awarded to lawyers who represented California in the settlement between 46 states and the tobacco industry, saying the amount was ''irrational.'' R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings, along with Brown & Williamson Tobacco and Lorillard, had challenged the award by an arbitration panel, calling it excessive. The State Supreme Court judge, Nicholas Figueroa of New York, agreed, finding that ''whatever the merit'' of the California lawyers' ''efforts during the tobacco wars, the rationale chosen by this panel'' to reward those efforts exceeded their power. The judge sent the dispute to the Tobacco Fee Arbitration Panel for a rehearing. The lawyers could appeal the decision.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Slovakia: Prime Minister Asked To Stay
description: President Rudolf Schuster asked the outgoing prime minister, Mikulas Dzurinda, to form a new government after reformist parties won a surprise victory in last weekend's parliamentary election. Three parties from Mr. Dzurinda's previous coalition are expected to join with the recently formed pro-business party of a television magnate, Pavol Rusko. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Foreigners Evacuated
description: French soldiers evacuated more foreigners, mostly French, from Bouak, the rebel-held city where some 100 American schoolchildren were rescued on Wednesday. Mutinous soldiers agreed to a cease-fire for the evacuation. Nigeria sent three fighter jets to the country in what could become an intervention by a West African peacekeeping force. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Dozens Killed as Russian Forces Battle Chechen Fighters
description: Military and security forces clashed today with a large group of Chechen fighters in a southern Russian republic, Ingushetia, in the largest battle this year in Russia's war in the Caucasus.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Display Maker Sold
description: Hynix Semiconductor said it had agreed to sell its flat-panel display manufacturing unit to the BOE Technology Group of China for $380 million. An earlier deal to sell the unit to a buyer in Taiwan failed when the buyer's financing fell through. Shares of Hynix, which is $6 billion in debt and run by its creditors, rose the daily limit of 15 percent on the news. BOE Technology is state-owned. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGENSTEIN, BERNARD
description: ROGENSTEIN-Bernard. On September 25, 2002. Born July 11, 1939. Loving and devoted husband of Lucille. Proud and loving father of Gregg and Steven. Brother of Fredric. A true Renaissance man who loved life and all it had to offer. Services Friday 2 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Cites City On Inmates
description: A federal judge has found the city's Department of Correction in contempt for failing to comply with an order requiring monthly medical checkups for inmates whose hands are cuffed behind their backs for security reasons on trips outside a jail. In August 2000, Judge Harold Baer Jr. of United States District Court ordered the city to examine each inmate put under additional security each month to make sure the restraints were not causing harm or making injuries worse. In a ruling issued yesterday, Judge Baer cited the department's ''chronic noncompliance'' with the order in imposing fines of $200 for each instance of failing to perform an initial medical examination. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group , to handle the creative and media parts of its account, with spending estimated at $30 million. The duties had been handled by Sicola Martin in Austin, Tex., part of the Young & Rubicam unit of WPP.

description: Five Paterson teenagers accused of fatally beating a homeless man in June 2001 were ordered today to stand trial on murder charges, while five co-defendants pleaded guilty to lesser charges and agreed to testify against the others.

title: Joseph Nathan Kane Dies; Master of Minutiae Was 103
description: Joseph Nathan Kane, whose lifelong obsession with facts led him to write exhaustive reference works that cataloged such things as the nicknames of presidents, when the first Eskimo Pie was created (1922), when the first camels were brought to America (1721) and the precise patent number of the first safety pin in the United States, died on Sunday in West Palm Beach, Fla.

description: Federal election regulators approved a loophole tonight that would let charitable, religious and educational groups run television advertisements just before elections, commercials that would otherwise be barred under the new federal campaign finance law.

title: Moss Sorry for Car Incident
description: Randy Moss said his palms were sweaty as he stood at a podium at the Minnesota Vikings' practice facility in Eden Prairie, Minn., yesterday and apologized for his actions in a traffic incident in Minneapolis on Tuesday. Moss, the Vikings' leading receiver, spent Tuesday night in jail and was charged Wednesday with two misdemeanors that carry a sentence of up to 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine.

description: After a two-day respite, stocks plunged yesterday as investors were served more earnings disappointments and more weak economic data. The only good news, if it could be called that, was that the three major stock gauges did not fall to new lows.

description: With highly detailed options for attacking Iraq now before President Bush, a Pentagon war game conducted this week revealed worrisome shortages in some military equipment, military and Defense Department officials said today.

Silverstein, for just a single terrorist attack, rather than two, misattributed a quotation that described the ruling as a setback for him. It was from a statement by Michael Barr, a lawyer for Royal Indemnity, an insurer -- not a continuation of the statement by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Lifelike, Abstract or Funky, What Exactly Is a Drawing?
description: For a quarter-century, the Drawing Center in SoHo has been one of the New York art world's most valuable institutions. Founded in 1977, the center has produced exhibitions that any good museum would have been proud to create, and it has given hundreds of young and emerging artists their first New York exposure. Now, in celebration of its 25th anniversary, the Drawing Center has assembled a show of nearly 400 drawings representing most of the artists who have been included in its ''Selections'' series of exhibitions, as well as those who have had exhibitions in the Drawing Room, the gallery across the street where solo shows are usually presented.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters To Use Ads
description: City firefighter unions have prepared full-page newspaper advertisements to criticize the city for blocking proposed changes in their pension system, the unions said yesterday. The ads, set to run today under the headline ''Save the FDNY,'' argue that the changes would help prevent retirements. Many firefighters say they cannot afford to pass up the opportunity to retire on salaries increased by the overtime they earned after the World Trade Center attack. The changes would allow firefighters to use their highest-earning year, not their last year, when calculating pension benefits. City officials say that the city has already made significant pension adjustments sought by the unions and that this proposal would cost too much money. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

The film, which also stars Susan Sarandon as Mr. Hoffman's wife, takes its title from the Rolling Stones ballad of the 70's, the movie's time period. The Brad Silberling drama balances pathos with humor in a study of parents trying to cope with tragedy and a young man torn between a sense of obligation and a need to break free.

A film is an act of imagination, a highly individual impression of things -- and sometimes very idiosyncratic. It is not a policy directive.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Gucci's Profit Falls
description: After a global slowdown in the luxury goods industry, the Gucci Group said that profit fell 55 percent in the second quarter because of decreased sales in the Gucci brand. Net income fell to 42.8 million euros ($41.8 million) from 95.4 million euros a year ago. The chief executive, Domenico De Sole, warned that Gucci would miss its earnings forecast for the year if a war begins with Iraq. Although sales of its signature brand decreased, the company said that sales increased in its other designer houses, including Stella McCartney, Alexander McQueen and Sergio Rossi. Kerri Shaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility's Loan Extended
description: British Energy, the troubled nuclear power producer, sidestepped bankruptcy when the government extended a 410 million ($638.5 million) credit line until Nov. 29 and increased the amount to 650 million ($1 billion). The initial loan was set to expire tomorrow. British Energy's battered shares rose as much as 23 percent before falling back. The company warned that it might become insolvent if it is unable to find long-term financing. British Energy's nuclear reactors produce one-fifth of Britain's electric power. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Rules Against Lennon Aide
description: A former personal assistant to John Lennon who is being sued by Lennon's widow, Yoko Ono, was dealt a setback in court yesterday. The former assistant, who wrote a book and magazine articles about the couple, contends that he is not bound by a confidentiality agreement he signed in 1979, but Judge Leonard B. Sand of United States District Court ruled yesterday that the agreement does apply. Ms. Ono wants the assistant, Frederic Seaman, to surrender the copyright on 374 photographs and various documents. Mr. Seaman, who pleaded guilty to stealing documents from the Lennon home in 1983, has argued that the photographs are his own. The ruling yesterday prompted talks on a possible settlement, lawyers for both sides said. Closing arguments in the case are scheduled today. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: Yoko Ono Wins Case Against Lennon Family's Ex-Assistant

description: Two men who served 13 years for a murder they did not commit filed a federal lawsuit yesterday accusing the City of New York and the Bronx district attorney's office of malicious prosecution, false imprisonment and violation of their civil rights. The suit, which was filed in Manhattan, also names as a defendant the assistant district attorney who prosecuted the case, Allen Karen. Mr. Karen and a spokesman for the district attorney's office would not comment. The wrongly accused men, Jose Morales, above, and Ruben Montalvo were freed last summer by Judge Denny Chin of United States District Court after hearing testimony that another man had admitted the killing of Jose Antonio Rivera. Judge Chin wrote that he had ''yet to hear any semblance of a reason'' why the district attorney had repeatedly barred testimony suggesting that the defendants were innocent. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: This week the director Milos Forman was at his Connecticut house considering an adaptation of ''Embers,'' a novel by the Hungarian writer Sandor Marai. More than 20 years ago Mr. Forman and the playwright Peter Shaffer retreated to Connecticut to hammer out a screenplay for ''Amadeus,'' Mr. Shaffer's acclaimed play about the rivalry between the composers Antonio Salieri and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

description: A spokeswoman for the Chinese government complained today that an American naval ship -- one described by the Pentagon as an oceanographic research vessel -- had violated international law by operating inside China's 200-nautical-mile economic zone.

description: BROWNLIE-Ian G.M. Of Shelter Island, NY on September 26, 2002. Loving husband of Marian. Devoted father of Heather Elizabeth Gordon Brownlie and John Cameron Gordon Brownlie. In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory may be made to St. Mary's Episcopal Church, PO Box 1660, Shelter Island, New York 11964.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: GUCCI' S PROFIT FALLS After a global slowdown in the luxury goods industry, the Gucci Group said that profit fell 55 percent in the second quarter because of decreased sales in the Gucci brand. Net income fell to 42.8 million euros ($41.8 million) from 95.4 million euros a year ago. The chief executive, Domenico De Sole, warned that Gucci would miss its earnings forecast for the year if a war begins with Iraq. Although sales of its signature brand decreased, the company said that sales increased in its other designer houses, including Stella McCartney, Alexander McQueen and Sergio Rossi. Kerri Shaw (NYT)

description: Johnny Miller is not certain he would cope well as a player in the current Ryder Cup atmosphere of intense nationalism and competition between the United States and the European teams.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 2 Sentenced In Gasoline Fraud
description: Two brothers who pleaded guilty to a scheme that allowed hundreds of millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold in the New York City area have been sentenced by a federal judge. The brothers, Mark and Waldo Schroeder, were executives with Blending Marketing and Service Inc., a defunct company based in Houston. The brothers admitted being part of a ring that falsified the results of chemical tests indicating that the gasoline passed clean-burning standards required in the Northeast for eight years. The brothers were the last of 10 defendants to be sentenced in the case, officials said. Mark Schroeder, the company's operations manager, was sentenced Tuesday to 11 months in prison, 5 months' house arrest and a $25,000 fine. Waldo Schroeder, the president, was sentenced to six months' house arrest and fined $10,000. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Louisville Upsets No. 4 Florida State
description: Henry Miller ran 25 yards for a touchdown in overtime as Louisville upset No. 4 Florida State, 26-20, tonight in a game played in a steady rain.

title: Gap Picks Chief From Outside the Clothing Trade
description: The Gap Inc. reached outside the fashion industry yesterday and chose Paul Pressler, an executive at Walt Disney, to become its president and chief executive. Mr. Pressler, who ran Disney's global theme park and resorts division, begins Monday.

description: Joy and Curse Of Life In a Bubble

title: 'We Are One Family': A Mideast Story
description: Fuad Abu Rumeileh made his usual morning rounds, delivering cups of coffee to customers from his tiny shop in East Jerusalem, still absorbing the remarkable turn of events that has restored hope for his ailing 7-year-old daughter, Yasmin.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Lack Of Money For Space Station
description: Russia might have to suspend its manned missions to the International Space Station because of a ''desperate'' cash shortage, the director of the Russian part of the station said, raising the prospect of a crisis in the laboratory's operations. The official, Valery Ryumin, said that the Energiya company, builder of the Soyuz spacecraft, which ferries astronauts and supplies to the station, had run out of money and that without new funds, launches would stop in 2004. The Soyuz, which is not reusable, is designed to remain docked to the space station for long periods and to serve as an emergency escape vehicle, crucial functions the American space shuttle does not perform. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSCOWITZ, REBECCA
description: HERSCOWITZ - Rebecca. Died September 8, 2002. Teacher and guidance counselor in the New York City school system. She was devoted to her family and had a strong commitment to Jewish causes. Survived by many nieces and nephews, their children and their grandchildren. She will be missed.

description: EVERY political candidate needs surrogates, and Gov. George E. Pataki could not find a better one than his 23-year-old daughter, Emily.

description: In their largest battle this year, Chechen fighters and Russian soldiers clashed in the southern republic of Ingushetia, and some Russian officials said it was possible that attacks could be ordered in Georgia.

title: U.S. Agribusiness Peddles To the Proletariat in Cuba
description: Capitalism and Communism rubbed shoulders today inside a rambling exhibition hall in a suburb of Havana, where Fidel Castro and nearly 300 American companies set aside four decades of estrangement to kick off the largest American trade show ever on this impoverished island.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Anthrax And Smallpox Scare
description: The Capitol in Salem reopened after confirmation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta that a white powder contained in a letter received on Wednesday sent to Gov. John Kitzhaber did not contain anthrax or smallpox. The Capitol was evacuated after the letter, which mentioned the deadly diseases and bore a return address in Pakistan, was received in the mailroom. The letter was flown to Atlanta for tests, and a mailroom worker and three state police troopers were decontaminated. The F.B.I.'s Portland field office is investigating. The responsible party could face life in prison. Judith Berck (NYT)

description: IS cleaning a dreaded necessity? Or is it a catharsis, a body-and-soul therapy session? When last we checked, Lady Macbeth was still working on that damned spot, and it has been more than 400 years now.

title: Web Site Fuels Debate on Campus Anti-Semitism
description: A Web site started last week by a pro-Israel research and policy group, citing eight professors and 14 universities for their views on Palestinian rights or political Islam, has opened a new chapter in a growing debate over campus anti-Semitism.

title: Touring Ireland
description: Starting at $698 a person, based on double occupancy, CIE Tours International has six-day escorted tours of Ireland from Oct. 15 to Dec. 5 and from Feb. 6 to April 29, 2003. That price includes round-trip air fare from New York, Boston or Baltimore-Washington, sightseeing on a motorcoach, four nights' accommodations with private bath, full breakfast daily, four dinners, various tours and taxes and tips. Stops include Dublin, Killarney, and the Clare coast. Most departures are on Thursdays. Information: (800) 243-8687 or www.cietours.com .

title: A Vexed Heart: Grits or Foie Gras?
description: When Reese Witherspoon flashes her thousand-watt smile, she projects a fundamental niceness that makes it impossible to begrudge her all the goodies that flutter into her lap like candy sequins raining down from Barbie Doll heaven. That smile isn't just any old beauty-pageant grimace. It has a backbone. The tirelessly chipper star, exuding the confidence of a miniature general who has never lost a battle, leads with her chin in a way that recalls the younger Sally Field. Every physical twitch signals an unflappable determination to conquer whatever challenge presents itself.

title: Isles Put DiPietro On the B Squad
description: Coach Peter Laviolette split the Islanders for two practices again yesterday in Syosset, N.Y., but the difference was that the first group included the team's best players and the second group looked like the 2002-3 Bridgeport Sound Tigers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cargo Inspections Allowed
description: Japan agreed to allow United States customs officials to be stationed at its largest ports to help intercept shipments of radioactive material and other weapons that could be used by terrorists. United States officers will be stationed in Tokyo, Yokohama, Kobe and Nagoya. The four ports together dispatch more containers to the United States than any region except China and Hong Kong. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Irish Sell Troubled U.S. Bank But Maintain Some Influence
description: Allied Irish Banks said today that it would sell its American retail banking subsidiary, Allfirst Financial, to the M&T Bank Corporation of Buffalo for $3.1 billion in cash and stock.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

description: NOW this is truly astonishing. A claim is afoot in New York City that men and women were having sex as long ago as the 1910's, and maybe even further back than that.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Brush Fire Threatens 10,000 Homes
description: A brushfire in the tinder-dry Angeles National Forest east of Los Angeles continued to rage out of control, consuming more than 31,500 acres. Nearly 3,200 firefighters, aided by 16 helicopters and 10 airplanes, struggled to contain the blaze, which broke out on Sunday. The fire threatened 10,000 homes in Mount Baldy Village, Glendora, San Dimas, LaVerne and Claremont and forced the evacuation of more than 2,000 residents. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Killed on 9/11, Fire Chaplain Becomes Larger Than Life
description: At the Holy Sepulcher Cemetery here, people come every day to stand before his gravestone and recite the prayer he wrote. Children, a street, a ferry and a federal law have been named for him. He has worked miracles, some say.

description: The foreign minister of Ukraine called American accusations that his country had sold a sophisticated radar system to Iraq groundless, and he invited international arms inspectors to visit Ukraine to investigate the charges.
