title: NORTHERN TRUST BUYS UNIT FROM DEUTSCHE BANK
description: The Northern Trust Corporation agreed to buy the United States index-tracking fund business of Deutsche Bank A.G. for about $260 million in cash, increasing assets under Northern Trust's management by about a third, to almost $450 billion. The purchase will place Northern Trust, which is based in Chicago, among the top 10 in the United States in terms of money management, said William A. Osborn, its chief executive. For Deutsche Bank, the transaction is part of a plan by the chief executive, Josef Ackermann, to reduce costs.

title: Think You Have a Book in You? Think Again
description: According to a recent survey, 81 percent of Americans feel they have a book in them -- and that they should write it. As the author of 14 books, with a 15th to be published next spring, I'd like to use this space to do what I can to discourage them.

title: Wider Use of Sophisticated Pacemakers Is Backed
description: Three leading medical groups have called for expanding the use of sophisticated pacemakers that can reduce the risk of sudden cardiac arrest but that have also been blamed for causing a painful side effect in some patients.

title: Three Mexican Army Officers Are Accused in 70's Killings
description: For the first time, Mexico has charged army officers with murdering suspected leftist enemies of the government, government officials said today.

title: Extortion Allegation Denied
description: The lawyer representing Jodi Turner, the woman linked to a published photo showing Mets pitcher Grant Roberts using marijuana, maintained yesterday that she was not guilty of any attempt at extortion.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Denial Of Falun Gong Link
description: Officials said they had found no evidence that members of the Falun Gong sect had used Taiwan as a base to interfere with television broadcasts to mainland China. The Chinese government made the accusation this week when it said members of the spiritual group, which is outlawed in China, had hijacked a Chinese satellite to beam its own message to Chinese viewers and had done so from a base outside Taipei, Taiwan's capital. The Mainland Affairs Council of Taiwan's cabinet urged China to resume its political dialogue with Taiwan and to provide accurate information about Falun Gong. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: With Big Assist From Bird, Johnson Enters Hall of Fame
description: Magic Johnson began calling the people close to him with the news that he had H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. On Nov. 11, 1991, one of the first people he telephoned was Larry Bird, his nemesis during the renaissance of the National Basketball Association during the 1980's.

title: Expat adviser : How to retrieve 'lost' credit data
World Business Briefing | Asia: China: CNOOC In Deal
description: CNOOC Ltd. plans to pay BP $275 million for a 12.5 percent stake in Indonesia's Tangguh natural gas fields. It would be the third purchase of overseas reserves that CNOOC, China's biggest offshore oil producer, has made this year. BP, Europe's biggest publicly traded oil company, would retain a 37.5 percent stake.

title: Seagal Lawsuit to Proceed
description: A judge has declined to throw out a $60 million civil suit against the actor Steven Seagal filed by his longtime production partner Julius R. Nasso, who claims that Mr. Seagal reneged on millions of dollars of commitments to make movies. The judge, Justice Joseph J. Maltese of State Supreme Court in Staten Island, ruled on Thursday that the case could proceed toward trial.

description: A year ago, Republicans and Democrats seemed to be girding for a showdown over special education.

description: President Vicente Fox, in one of the bitterest battles of his political life, worked today to stave off a strike at the government-run energy company, Pemex, the leading supplier of foreign oil to the United States.

In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to St. Clement's RC Church, Stamford, CT.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE STILL SEES A HIGHER QUARTERLY PROFIT
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the biggest gainer in the Dow Jones industrial average this year, reiterated that profit this quarter would rise 14 percent to 16 percent as it reduced costs and sold more new products like a Crest toothpaste for women. Procter & Gamble, the largest American maker of household goods, has raised its forecasts for four consecutive quarters. The company was expected to earn $1.10 a share for the quarter, excluding certain costs, according to the average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.

title: Unsung Hero of Sliding Tray Shows His Declarer Skill
description: For players at the top of the tournament pyramid, some equipment items are now taken for granted, but the efforts of those who introduced them are generally forgotten. Some recall that the bidding boxes, now used routinely, were developed by the Jannersten organization in Sweden, whose name is still on most of them.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Economy Still Strong
description: In the midst of a global economic downturn, South Korea continues to record strong economic gains. Industrial output in August was 8.5 percent higher than in August 2001, according to the National Statistical Office, with semiconductors up 25 percent and motor vehicles up 12.8 percent. The Bank of Korea reported that the current-account surplus, based largely on trade figures, was $150.9 million in August in contrast to a deficit of $12.7 million in July and a deficit of $143.4 million in August 2001. The current-account surplus from January through August was $3.63 billion, on its way to what the government predicts will be a $5 billion surplus for the year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Individuality comes first for Rome's small designers
description: ROME  A medieval web of small shops and artisans' workshops, Rome has hummed for centuries to the rhythm of steady, individual industry  butchers next to woodcarvers and candlemakers next to bakers.

title: U.S. Hog Herd Is Down
description: United States hog farmers, faced with widening losses, have reduced the breeding herd to the smallest since records began in 1963, pointing to diminished pork supplies by early next year, a government report showed. The nation's 81,000 hog farmers were holding back 6.054 million sows for breeding on Sept. 1, down 1.7 percent from 6.158 million on the same date a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said in a quarterly report.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SLOVENIA: NOVARTIS BID REJECTED The major shareholders of Lek Pharmaceutical and Chemical Company of Slovenia have rejected a takeover bid from Novartis. Novartis, the Swiss drug maker, failed to win support from two government funds that are Lek's largest shareholders after increasing its offer to 98,000 Slovenian tolars ($428.38) a share from 95,000. The higher bid valued the Slovenian company at about 1.22 billion Swiss francs ($812 million).

title: The Rolling Stones Revel In the Act of Survival
description: In rock 'n' roll, idealism gets old fast. Angry young frontmen seem a lot less vital once they mature into middle-aged earnest frontmen. Maybe that's why Mick Jagger still puts on such a great show -- because that seems to be the only thing on earth he really cares about. He stands for nothing, he falls for nothing, and it's starting to seem as if he and his band might last forever.

description: CROSBY-James H., Jr. On September 24. Services Saturday, September 28, 4 PM, Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St. Nicholas Ave. (at 141 St), NYC

title: 20-Year Sentence Recommended for Lindh
description: Justice Department prosecutors formally recommended today that John Walker Lindh, the Californian who was accused of fighting alongside the Taliban, be sentenced to 20 years in prison.

title: In a word : When colors take on different cultural hues
description: PARIS  What makes Red Square red? Any visitor to Moscow can see that the venerable square is predominantly gray, notwithstanding the blood-red crenellated wall that surrounds the Kremlin.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Mobilcom To Cut Jobs
description: The German telecommunications group MobilCom plans to cut nearly half of its work force, and freeze the rollout of its 3G wireless network. The decision to stop the 3G program would affect 1,000 jobs. Another 850 jobs would be cut from the main mobile business, saving around 130 million euros ($127 million) a year, which should make the unit profitable in the first half of 2003. The restructuring plan also includes a possible sale of the fixed-line business. The company's reorganization aims to attract new partners. The German government had promised a 400 million euros ($391 million) bailout during the election campaign.

title: Bush Stumps for G.O.P. and Against Iraq
description: President Bush finished off a lucrative week of political fund-raising tonight by collecting nearly $15 million in five days for Republican candidates and his party.

title: Troubled Boston Archdiocese Gets Loan
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston today secured a $12.5 million mortgage loan from the Knights of Columbus in an effort to maintain its daily operations and charitable organizations.

title: Germany Gets a 2-Year Term On U.N. Security Council
description: Germany was among five new nonpermanent members elected today to the 15-nation Security Council to serve a two-year term starting in 2003.

title: UNOCAL TAKES A CHARGE FOR CLEANUP COSTS
description: The Unocal Corporation, an oil and natural gas producer, said that it would take a charge of $22 million, or 9 cents a share, in the third quarter for environmental cleanup costs. The provision will lower quarterly earnings to 35 cents to 45 cents a share, the company, based in El Segundo, Calif., said in a filing. The forecast for per-share profit from operations is unchanged at the high end of a range of 45 cents to 55 cents, the company said. Nearly all of the costs are for cleaning up sites the company has closed or no longer owns, Unocal said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: The Jack Welch War Plan
description: You had to sympathize with poor Tom Daschle when he erupted on the floor of the Senate this week. After months of playing Clark Kent to George W. Bush's Superman, the guy looked as if he were about to become unhinged.

title: Bail Money for Tyco's Ex-Chief Is Accepted
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International who has been charged with looting $600 million from the company, was allowed to remain free yesterday after a judge accepted $10 million in bail put up by his former wife.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holiday Shemini Atzeret, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: When Singer and Players Go Their Separate Ways
description: One of the best things about Britt Daniel is that he seems to be in the wrong band. While his three bandmates keep the songs short and cold, Mr. Daniel adds heat, belting out the lyrics in a slippery voice that suggests an English accent filtered through his hometown of Austin, Tex.

title: Pataki Orders Strict Controls On Pollution In Rebuilding
description: The Pataki administration said yesterday that it would require the construction equipment at the World Trade Center site to adhere to strict air pollution controls -- a move that environmentalists and Democrats had called for all year.

title: As Thousands of Salmon Die, Fight for River Erupts Again
description: More than 10,000 chinook salmon have died in the Klamath River in northern California in recent days, leaving biologists stunned and Indian tribes and fishermen angered at the Bush administration, which they say caused the deaths by favoring farmers in one of the most contentious water disputes in the West.

title: News Media Win Ruling in Terror Trial
description: The judge presiding over the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui ruled today in favor of a coalition of news media plaintiffs who sought public disclosure of his court filings.

title: Taxing matters : Permanent U.S. expatriates can face hefty liabilities
description: A permanent move overseas can be an effective way of reducing your tax liability and widening investment horizons, but there are traps for the ill-prepared. Pre-expatriation tax advice should always be sought to make the most of planning opportunities in these areas.

title: Giacometti Sale On for Sure
description: A Paris court today turned down a last-minute effort to prevent Christie's France from selling 36 Giacometti sculptures belonging to the estate of the artist's widow. The auction, which is expected to raise some $6 million, will now take place here Saturday evening.

title: TREASURER NAMED IN LAWSUITS IS REASSIGNED BY XEROX
description: The Xerox Corporation removed Gregory B. Tayler as its treasurer and reassigned him to an unspecified job in Canada as federal prosecutors start investigating the company's accounting. Lawrence A. Zimmerman, the chief financial officer, will act as treasurer until a successor is found, the company said. Mr. Tayler will help the transition of Doug Lord, new president and chief executive of the Canadian operation, said Christa Carone, a company spokeswoman. Mr. Lord's appointment was also announced yesterday. Mr. Tayler was named in several shareholder lawsuits that contend there was accounting misconduct at Xerox, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURMAN, BERNARD
description: KURMAN-Bernard. Happy 1st Anniversary in Heaven. Always in our hearts. Frank and Ra

title: A Dutiful Son Sees That 'Joy of Sex' Swings On
description: IF shoemakers' children go barefoot and doctors' wives die young, then it follows logically that the son of the author of ''The Joy of Sex'' should have grown up in a state of profound sexual ignorance.

title: The Schools' New Carrot
description: A business group has agreed to finance a pilot project that offers bonuses of up to $40,000 to community and high school superintendents in New York City if the performance of their students improves. Schools Chancellor Joel Klein was right to accept the New York City Partnership's generous offer. Raising the stakes for superintendents makes sense as one way of determining whether certain corporate practices can succeed in helping to turn around troubled public school systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, RUTH
description: JACOBY-Ruth. Adored wife of Walter for 64 and a half years. Loving mother of Julian and Carolyn Jacoby, Donald and Kitty Jacoby. Devoted grandmother of David, Philip, Jonathan, Steven, Scott and Daniel. Great grandmother of Ryan, Lauren and Isabel. Cherished sister of Sylvia Kahn. A very special and beautiful LADY. She enriched the lives of many who were blessed to know her. She will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory to the charity of your choice. Services Sunday 10 AM at the ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: U.S. and W.T.O. Negotiate Drug Access
description: The United States and the World Trade Organization will try to come up with an agreement by year-end on how to give poor countries greater access to drugs to fight AIDS and other diseases, trade officials said today.

title: Mrs. Clinton Isn't Focus Of Inquiry, U.S.O.C. Says
description: The United States Olympic Committee yesterday clarified the scope of its review of a conversation between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and a member of the organization's site selection committee, emphasizing that Senator Clinton is not under investigation.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Charges Of Bribery
description: Leaders of the opposition Conservative Party accused the government of paying a bribe of nearly $400 million to North Korea to persuade its leader, Kim Jong Il, to play host to South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, in June 2000. They said the state-owned Korea Development Bank had transferred the money through companies in the Hyundai group. A spokeswoman for President Kim, who has made reconciliation with North Korea his main policy goal, said the accusation was ''baseless.'' Chung Mong Joon, an heir to a controlling stake in Hyundai Heavy Industries, is challenging the conservative candidate, Lee Hoi Chang, in the presidential election in December. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: All of Russian History, in One Glittery, Unbroken Take
description: ''Russian Ark'' is a magnificent conjuring act, an eerie historical mirage evoked in a single sweeping wave of the hand by Alexander Sokurov. The 96-minute film, shot in high-definition video in the Hermitage at St. Petersburg, consists of one continuous, uninterrupted take. Thanks to recent technological innovation, it is the longest unbroken shot in the history of film. As the Steadicam operated by Tilman Bttner (the German cinematographer of ''Run Lola Run'') floats through the museum's galleries and rooms, a cast of 2,000 actors and extras act out random, whimsical moments of Russian imperial history that dissolve into one other like chapters of a dream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESKIN, CLAIRE
description: DESKIN-Claire. On September 27th, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Mark. Loving mother of Michael H. Steinhardt and precious mother-in-law of Judy. Loving grandmother of David, Daniel and Fara (David) Berman; great-grandmother of Jacob, Joshua and baby girl Berman. Service Monday, 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bill to Ban Use of Metal Bats By Youths Is Hotly Debated

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, BAILEY. THE HONORABLE JUDGE BAILEY ALDRICH
description: ALDRICH-Bailey. The Honorable Judge Bailey Aldrich of Cambridge, MA., at home September 25, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth (Perkins) Aldrich. Loving father of Jonathan Aldrich and his wife Nancy of Cape Elizabeth, ME and David Aldrich of Brookline, MA. Cherished grandfather of Nathan, Oona, Thomas, and Tess. Interment will be private. For memorial tribute, please visit www.mem.com. J.S. Waterman & Sons, Eastman-Waring Funeral Service 617.536.4110.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHNER, BLANCHE
description: LEHNER-Blanche. Beloved mother of Lillian Lazarus and son-in-law Burt Lazarus. Cherished by her grandson Bruce Lazarus, and beloved wife of the late Jack Lehner. Survived by many loving nephews and nieces. Graveside services Monday, 10:30 AM, Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

description: What began a week ago as a tale of political intrigue involving a turncoat Republican and a secret tape recording became a big political problem today for Senator Tom Harkin, forcing his veteran campaign manager to resign.

title: Warren E. Burnett Is Dead; Colorful Lawyer Was 75
description: Warren E. Burnett, a whiskey-swigging, Shakespeare-quoting Texas lawyer who achieved near-legendary status by winning big jury awards, taking on seemingly impossible murder cases and defending the powerless, died on Monday while visiting Fort Davis, Tex. He was 75.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Unemployment Steady
description: Japan's unemployment rate remained at 5.4 percent in August, but the jobless rolls swelled for the 17th consecutive month. Though exports helped bolster growth in the first half of the year, companies continued to trim payrolls. The number of unemployed totaled 3.61 million in August, up 250,000 from August 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, LILA
description: LERNER-Lila. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member Lila Lerner. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Samuel Wasserman, Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, JAMES F., CSP.
description: FISHER-James F., CSP. On September 26, 2002 at age 74. Born in Selinsgrove, PA. in 1928, he grew up and was educated in the public schools of DeLand, FL. Ordained May 1, 1959 his assignments included years in Newman work at Berkeley, CA & Clemson, SC. His other ministry took him to Boston, St. Paul the Apostle Church in NYC, Rome, Fairbanks, AK., & Memphis, TN. Fr. Fisher, a student of history wrote numerous articles on American history and worked for Paulist Press from 1969 to 1972. He is survived by his brother Paul, age 80 and his sister Bernice 90. Viewing will be at The Paulist Fathers Rectory, 405 West 59th Street, NYC, on Monday, September 30 from 4-8 PM with a wake service at 7:30 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Paul the Apostle Church, NYC, on Tuesday, October 1 at 10 A.M. Burial will follow at Oak Ridge, NJ at the Paulist Fathers retreat house.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: INVESTMENT APPROVED China plans to allow Newbridge Capital, an American private equity firm, to buy a stake in the Shenzhen Development Bank, a step toward gradually opening China's financial sector to foreigners. The bank said in a statement that it expected the deal to be completed soon, but did not provide details. Newbridge Capital, which specializes in emerging market investments, is expected to buy a minority stake in the bank that would make it the largest single shareholder.

title: Russia and U.S. to Discuss Collaborative Oil Ventures
description: Energy executives and government officials from Russia and the United States will meet in Houston next week to discuss energy cooperation at a time when concerns over the safety of world oil supplies have been heightened by the Bush administration's push for action against Iraq.

title: M-bagging books to Europe : Letter to the editor
description: Regarding "Readers go postal" (July 27-28):

title: 12-Year-Old Is Charged In Sex Attack On Boy of 5
description: A 5-year-old boy was assaulted by several other boys in a school bathroom in the Bronx, and a 12-year-old boy was arrested in connection with the incident, the police said last night.

title: Downtown, A Debate Over Burying West Street
description: Almost from the beginning of the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, one point of near-universal agreement has been that Battery Park City is isolated from the rest of downtown. To rejoin it to the rest of the city, planners have proposed that West Street be buried and covered with a tree-lined promenade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHART, STEPHANIE. KEVIN MCKENZIE
description: REINHART-Stephanie. Kevin McKenzie, the Trustees, the dancers and the entire staff of American Ballet Theatre mourn the passing of Stephanie Reinhart, a brilliant advocate of dance. Her tireless dedication to the art form lent encouragement to an entire generation of dance ensembles. We send our deepest sympathies to Charles, Ariane and their family.

title: National Briefing: South
description: LOUISIANA: STORM CREATES DISASTER AREAS As Tropical Storm Isidore moved into the North, President Bush declared disaster areas in 15 parishes in Louisiana, where Gov. Mike Foster estimated at least $18 million in damage. More than 200,000 utility customers lost power in the storm, which moved ashore early Thursday along the Gulf Coast. Yesterday, the storm left nearly 10 inches of rain in Ohio, Kentucky and Tennessee but largely spared the flood-prone mountains in the region. Forecasters expected it to break up this weekend over the Northeast. (AP)

title: Heady Days for Makers of Luxury Vehicles
description: Sales of cars are shaky in most of the world's major markets, the United States and Germany are struggling to avoid slipping back into recession and war talk fills the air.

title: Sports of The Times; What Would Steinbrenner Do at Shea?
description: THAT grand sage of talk radio, Bill Mazer, posed a question the other day: ''What do you think George Steinbrenner would do if he owned the Mets?'' I giggled at the thought of the Boss as the symbol of raging superego, imposing his will on this fallen franchise.

title: An Old Hand in Miami Builds a Program From Scratch
description: As Don Strock drove onto the Florida International University campus to interview for a job three and a half years ago, he could not believe how much the university had changed since his only previous trip there in 1982. That was when Strock, a backup quarterback for the Miami Dolphins, and some of his teammates practiced on a soccer field there during an N.F.L. players strike.

title: DOLE FORMS COMMITTEE TO CONSIDER BUYOUT OFFER
description: The Dole Food Company formed a special committee to consider a buyout offer from its chief executive, David Murdock, that values the company, the world's largest fruit and vegetable producer, at about $2.5 billion. Five board members who are not current or former employees will act on the company's behalf, Dole said. Mr. Murdock offered $29.50 a share on Sunday for the 76 percent of the company that he and his family did not already own. Several shareholder lawsuits say the proposal undervalues Dole. The committee hired Goldman, Sachs as its financial adviser. Deutsche Bank is advising Mr. Murdock. Dole Food is based in Westlake Village, Calif.

title: Liberals Object To Bush Policy On Iraq Attack
description: Liberal Democrats, led by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, voiced reservations today about giving President Bush a free hand to attack Iraq before a new, tougher set of United Nations inspections is put into effect.

title: Corrections
description: A map in the World Briefing column on Thursday with a report about an agreement by the United States to return the Greenland town of Dundas, which it took over in 1953 when it widened the perimeter of an air base, showed the location erroneously. It is on the northwest coast, not the southeast.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about the Rolling Stones on tour misspelled a band member's surname at one point. He is Ron Wood, not Woods. The article also misspelled the surname of one American musician cited by band members as influential and the given name of another. The two are Billy Eckstine, not Eckstein, and Ritchie Valens, not Richie.

title: Agencies Say Crisis Plan At A-Plant Is Adequate
description: Two federal agencies identified weaknesses today in the emergency plan for the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, but concluded that the plan was more than adequate for protecting the public from a nuclear accident.

title: Let Them Walk On, and Inspire the Team
description: To the Editor:

title: Citing a Tight Bond Market, G.E. Makes a Loan to a Buyer
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had lent $235 million to the buyer of its electronic commerce unit because money was not available from the bond market.

title: Well South of the Border
description: Immigrants from South America in recent years have made a big impact on the city and its dining scene. Here are some informal, moderately priced restaurants that serve classic South American dishes.

title: FALLOUT ON DRUGS LOWERS WYETH'S EARNINGS PREDICTION
description: Profits for Wyeth, the pharmaceutical company, will be less than expected this year after studies linked its best-selling hormone drugs to cancer and heart disease. The company also put aside $910 million for fen-phen diet pill lawsuits. Wyeth expects earnings of $2.22 to $2.32 a share before a gain from selling part of Immunex and the charge for the legal reserves. The company, which changed its name from American Home Products, had been expected to earn $2.49 a share, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Premarin and other hormone therapies, intended to help prevent symptoms of menopause, made up about 15 percent of Wyeth's revenue last year. Wyeth shares tumbled $7.35, to close at $31.10, the largest decline in two months.

title: World Financial Officials Back New Debt Framework
description: The United States and the world's other leading industrial countries moved tonight to assuage global anxieties by declaring their willingness to help countries caught up in economic turmoil, mentioning both Brazil and Argentina as examples.

title: Investor Group Purchases Celtics
description: In a surprise move, the storied Boston Celtics were sold today for $360 million to a partnership that includes executives at two local investment firms.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about executive turnover at the Walt Disney Company gave an outdated name for the baseball team in which the company has a controlling interest. Since 1996 it has been the Anaheim Angels, no longer the California Angels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, ROSE (NEE KUTCHINSKY)
description: BLAU-Rose (nee Kutchinsky), 94 years old. Of Boca Raton, FL., on September 27, 2002. Loving wife of the late David Blau. Devoted mother of Harvey and Arlene Blau and Dr. Jeffrey and Lynn Blau. Cherished grandmother of Stephanie and Ronald Kramer, Elizabeth Blau, Melissa Blau, Victoria Blau and Alexandra and Paul Collins. Proud great grandmother of Nicole and Danielle Kramer and devoted sister-in-law of Hilda and Hal Schwartz. A private interment will be held in Florida on Monday, September 30, 2002.

title: Earnings News Sends the Dow Sharply Lower
description: After a two-day respite, stocks plunged yesterday as investors were served more earnings disappointments and more weak economic data. The only good news, if it could be called that, was that the three major stock gauges did not fall to new lows.

title: Milan's dilemma:How to replenish the fountain of youth
description: MILAN  For all its stellar designers, commercial clout and manufacturing skills, Italian fashion has a problem. Its well-spring of youth seems to be drying up. Since Stefano Gabbana, now 39, and Domenico Dolce, 44, founded their house at ages 21 and 25 respectively in the mid-1980s, not one single young designer has successfully matured.

title: Glen Rounds, 96, Folk Author
description: Glen Rounds, who was born in a sod house near Wall, S.D., and worked as a mule skinner, cowboy and carnival medicine man before beginning a long career as an author and illustrator, died yesterday in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 96.

title: Afghan Rivals Clash, Killing 17
description: Fighting has broken out between rival commanders in a mountainous area in northern Afghanistan, just weeks after the main factions agreed to disarm their men and prevent further clashes.

title: Cars for People With $300,000 Watches
description: For those people unsatisfied with mass-produced luxury cars, the Paris motor show offered a peek through the window of an even more rarefied world: custom-built automobiles.

title: Living the Artistic Life In 19th-Century Korea
description: ''Chihwaseon,'' the new film by Im Kwon-Taek, the prolific grand old man of South Korean cinema, is one eminent artist's biography of another. The subject of the film is Jang Seung-Ub, a 19th-century painter known by the pseudonym Ohwon who lived, in Mr. Im's rendition, like a vagabond rock star. Jang, born a commoner and discovered as a boy by a sympathetic aristocrat, dazzled and scandalized his country's politically fragmented ruling class and spent his long career in and out of favor, and in and out of trouble.

title: C.I.A. Chief Assails Panel Staff for Note Questioning Officer's Honesty
description: George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, angrily denounced the staff of the joint Congressional committee investigating the Sept. 11 attacks today for questioning the honesty of a senior C.I.A. officer who testified before the panel on Thursday.

title: Malaysia Suggests Jailed 9/11 Suspect Had Innocent Role
description: A biochemist who has been in jail in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, since December on charges that he was the host of a critical meeting for two hijackers in the Sept. 11 terror attacks was unaware of the men's identities and what they discussed, the Malaysian home affairs minister said on Wednesday.

title: Yankees Win and Leave Hint About Rotation
description: The presence of the Anaheim Angels hangs over the Yankees, so it was appropriate that a television showing the Angels' game hung above Andy Pettitte's head as he spoke by his locker tonight.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The thing I'm most happy about is I'm actually here in person, myself, to accept the award, that I'm living.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, JEFFREY
description: SILVERMAN-Jeffrey. DadYou are, and will always be, our super hero. We love you and will miss you forever. Love, Amanda, Michael, Alexa and Max

title: Plot Confirmed, Japan Feels No Less Pain
description: It took three months for Rumiko Masumoto to muster the courage to tell her family about her new boyfriend. Then, over dinner one August night in 1978, her brother recalls now, she shared her secret.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VARIAN SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT ASSOCIATES INC., Gloucester, Mass., a maker of gear used to make computer chips, said that it would cut its work force by 15 percent, to 1,370 employees, and that it expected to break even on a per-share basis in its fiscal fourth quarter.

title: Corrections; Bison Dele's Brother In Critical Condition
description: Miles Dabord, the brother of the former basketball player Bison Dele, remained in critical condition yesterday at a hospital in Chula Vista, Calif., where he has been in a coma since Sept. 14. The New York Times reported erroneously yesterday that he had died.

title: A Father and the Boy Who Killed His Son
description: Usually, movie actors address us head on, or in profile, and when we think of them, we tend to isolate striking facial details eyes, cheekbones, jawline, and so on. But what we see most of Olivier Gourmet, whose performance gives ''The Son,'' a new film by Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne, much of its devastating power, is the back of his head, which is striking mostly in its sheer ordinariness. Mr. Gourmet plays Olivier, who teaches carpentry to troubled boys in an unidentified Belgian city, and the film follows him quite literally, as the camera chases him on stairs, peeking through his thick glasses and over his rounded shoulders through the routines of his solitary, work-driven existence.

title: In Search for Democracy, U.S. Is Rejected as a Guide
description: Logically, the women in the political science class at the university here should be among America's best friends in the Arab world.

title: Testaverde Is Looking For an Offensive Spark
description: The two glaring statistics are easy to see, but hard to fathom.

title: Vogts Continues Winning Pace Over Five Decades at Bethpage
description: When Howard Vogts started the Bethpage High School football program in 1952, Ernest Hemingway's ''The Old Man and the Sea'' was published and the Yankees needed seven games to defeat the Brooklyn Dodgers in the World Series.

title: Outside 401(k) Plans, Stock Ownership Declines
description: The falling stock market appears to have scared some Americans away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNHEIM, MARIAN (GLUCHER)
description: MANNHEIM-Marian (Glucher). On September 26, 2002. Preceded in death by her beloved husband, Joseph. Survived by her devoted children, Philip (Susan) Mannheim, Susan (Zachary) Schwartz. Treasured grandmother of Caryn, Jessica, Amanda and Matthew. Cherished sister of Beatrice Glucher, Ruth Silverberg and the late Maurice Glucher. Remembered with love. Graveside service 11am September 30 at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Air Security Is Worth It
description: To the Editor:

title: Traces of West Nile Virus Found in Mother's Breast Milk
description: Traces of West Nile virus have been found in the breast milk of a mother who contracted the disease, probably from blood transfusions, health officials said yesterday. But so far her baby is healthy, despite being breast-fed while the mother was ill.

title: Ethics, Voters and New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, ABNER A.
description: LANDIS-Abner A. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Justice Dept. Denounces Secret Court On Wiretaps
description: The Justice Department has accused the nation's super-secret wiretap court of improperly trying to ''micromanage'' the workings of the executive branch, possibly in violation of the Constitution.

title: Yoko Ono Gets Photo Rights And Apology From Ex-Aide
description: A former personal assistant to John Lennon and Yoko Ono agreed yesterday to surrender the copyright to hundreds of photographs he took of the couple and delivered an apology for stealing from them.

title: Un-Hamptons in a Bottle
description: Peconic Bay Winery's nonvintage Local Flavor Merlot captures the heart of Long Island's signature red and the North Fork's ambience.

title: Rumsfeld Says U.S. Has 'Bulletproof' Evidence of Iraq's Links to Al Qaeda
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that American intelligence had ''bulletproof'' evidence of links between Al Qaeda and the government of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Beating Them To the Prewar
description: Daniel Webster's ideas haven't held this much sway in the White House for a century and a half.

title: Ray Hayworth, 98, Catcher Who Played With Ty Cobb
description: Ray Hayworth, a longtime catcher who was the last surviving teammate of Ty Cobb on the Detroit Tigers and the oldest living former major league player, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Salisbury, N.C. He was 98.

title: Ratings of Building Loans Fall on Insurance Worries
description: A leading credit rating agency said late yesterday that it had downgraded the ratings on $4.5 billion in loans on some of the most prominent office buildings in New York City because the buildings were not adequately insured against terrorism.

title: TRAIN TO KENNEDY DERAILS IN A TEST
description: A futuristic three-car elevated train, the precursor of a $1.9 billion automated light-rail system that is expected to carry millions of air travelers a year to and from Kennedy International Airport, derailed on a curve during a test run to the terminals yesterday, killing its operator, who was alone on board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, LOUIS
description: GORDON-Louis. 90, died September 22. Mourned by sons Joseph and Marc, their respective families, nieces, nephews, cousins and many friends. Memorial service Sunday, 1:30 PM, at Rosenthal Library, Qns Coll Flushing.

title: A New Arrival Roils the Waters Off New York; Ferryboats Begin to Compete With Harbor's Reigning King
description: A small yellow catamaran skimmed down the Hudson the other day, looking nothing like the lordly ferries that dominated the river back in the days of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt. Atop the catamaran stood a man, looking nothing at all like Vanderbilt.

title: WESTAR ENERGY REPORTS RECEIVING SUBPOENAS
description: Westar Energy Inc., owner of the biggest electric utility in Kansas, said yesterday that a federal grand jury was seeking documents and testimony about use of the company's aircraft and about its chief executive, David C. Wittig. Westar said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the company and employees, including those responsible for the operation of leased aircraft, were served multiple subpoenas by the United States attorney's office in Topeka, where the company is based. . Westar said on Sept. 24 that it would limit the pay and perks of Mr. Wittig and other executives. Westar said it would cooperate with the investigation.

title: Slave Labor in Irish Convents as Terrible as Prison
description: Even though its setting isn't a penal institution but a convent, Peter Mullan's grim, powerful film ''The Magdalene Sisters'' fits snugly into a long line of heartsick dramas in which innocent people are thrown behind bars to endure the degradation of prison. The inmates, all female, are the victims of a stringently moralistic brand of Irish Catholicism, now on the wane, that used to punish unmarried young women (many in their teens) for premarital sex. Some are confined simply because their frightened puritanical families consider them too unruly.

title: Kinder, Gentler Fascism
description: This summer the president of the Italian state broadcasting system, RAI, addressed the national congress of the National Alliance, the right-wing party led principally by what are known as ''post-Fascists.'' The official, Antonio Baldassarre, announced that it was time to ''rewrite history'' -- that is, as it is presented on Italian television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORMUTH, ROBERT A.
description: BORMUTH-Robert A. The Board of Directors and membership of the Bathing Corporation express great sadness at the recent passing of our most worthy and esteemed manager of fifty-four years, and extend our deepest sympathy to Joyce and his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKWOOD, JOAN
description: LOCKWOOD-Joan. On September 27, 2002. Beloved wife of Donald. Loving mother of Steven and Wanda Lockwood, and Lisa and John Winston. Adored grandmother of Rachel, Tracy, Scott and Robbie. Devoted daughter of Mary Rosensweig. Cherished sister of Doris and Jerry Miller, and Jackie and Patty Ross. Joan lit up our lives with her beauty, warmth and wonderful sense of humor and was loved by everyone who knew her. Whether on the stage or with her loving family, she was our shining star. Services will be held Sunday, September 29th at 11:30 AM at Boulevard-Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. We will always love you. Don, Steve and Lisa

title: Social security benefits : Career globe-trotters need to be wary
description: PARIS  If you are banking on U.S. Social Security as an important part of your retirement, think twice if you've done a lot of globe-hopping in your job career.

title: 3M REORGANIZES TO FOCUS ON GROWING MARKETS
description: The 3M Company, the maker of products ranging from Post-it notes to medical inhalers, reorganized into seven businesses from six to give more focus to faster-growing markets. Three of the business divisions will be new: safety, security and protection services; display and graphics; and transportation. The health care; industrial, consumer and office; and electro and communications divisions will remain. W. James McNerney Jr., the chief executive, is managing 2,500 cost-cutting projects, borrowing from methods he learned during his 18 years at General Electric.

title: When footwear takes a whimsical turn
description: MILAN  If Italy's independent footwear designers have their way, sensible leather day shoes will be relegated to the back of the shoe rack next season and for many more to come.

title: New Jersey Laureate Refuses to Resign Over Poem
description: A month after Amiri Baraka became the poet laureate of New Jersey, Gov. James E. McGreevey asked the writer and political activist to resign yesterday because a poem he read at a recent poetry festival implies that Israel knew about the Sept. 11 attack in advance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNFELD, LIZA
description: GRUNFELD-Liza. Mother of Naomi Kaplan, our diligent and devoted supporter of Yiddish theatre. Our deepest condolences. The Folksbiene Yiddish Theatre

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. Natural gas prices rose because of concern that a second tropical storm will interrupt production in the Gulf of Mexico. Natural gas for November delivery rose 15.2 cents, to $4.030 per million B.T.U.'s

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. Conflicting signals from government officials about a proposal to bail out banks by buying their shares weakened the Japanese currency. In New York, the yen settled at 122.84, up from 122.65 cents on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHRACH, ROBERT LEE
description: BACHRACH - Robert Lee. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Robert Lee Bachrach, son of our late president Alfred R. Bachrach, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. Herbert C. Bernard, Secy.

title: Woods in Ryder Cup: Another Uneasy Day
description: By losing two matches today, Tiger Woods dropped to 3-8-1 in Ryder Cup play, a shocking lack of success for a player ranked No. 1 in the world. Woods's low point today came in his foursome match, when he teamed with Mark Calcavecchia and lost to Sergio Garca and Lee Westwood, 2 and 1.

title: Griffin Is Getting Better All the Time for the Giants
description: After a 90-minute practice in their bubble today, the Giants returned to their locker room and had 90 minutes to shower, grab lunch, pack their bags, dress in their Sunday best and board buses to Newark Liberty International Airport for their flight to Phoenix and Sunday's game against the Arizona Cardinals.

title: Ruling Against Lumber Tariff Is Affirmed
description: The World Trade Organization affirmed an earlier decision that the United States broke trade rules in the way it calculated a tariff on Canadian lumber.

title: Havana Memo; Cuba Treats U.S. Visitors To Cigars and Prime Fidel
description: The Americans came bearing apples, cotton and soy products for sale. But the hottest commodity Cuba had to offer came, over cigars, after the American trade exhibition here this week had shut down for the night.

title: A Holiday in Hebron, Just for Jews, but Death Attends
description: It has been a particularly strange week in this particularly strange place: a week of dances and curfews, of celebratory palm fronds and blasting rifles, of rage and death on both sides of this torn city's stark Israeli-Palestinian divide.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Rescue Of Foreigners Completed
description: French soldiers finished evacuating foreigners out of the rebel-held city of Bouak, as mutinous soldiers prevented Ivoirians from leaving. The rebels, who have also held the city of Korhogo, reportedly took control of another northern city, Odienne. Leaders from West Africa are to meet in Ghana tomorrow to discuss the crisis. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony To Absorb Aiwa
description: The Sony Corporation said that it would absorb the Aiwa Company by Dec. 1 after completing a stock swap next week to make the company a wholly owned subsidiary. Aiwa, which makes televisions, stereos and compact disc players, will cease to exist. For the fiscal year ended in March, Aiwa's loss widened to 46.6 billion yen ($381 million) from 39 billion yen a year ago and sales fell 33 percent, to 196.3 billion yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASSECHES, PAULA TREINIS
description: BASSECHES-Paula Treinis, 95. Passed away after an extended illness. She was a pioneer, being one of the earliest female registered patent agents. Beloved wife of the late Jack Basseches, she is survived by sons Mark and Robert, daughters-in-law Janet and Harriet, grandchildren Julie, Stuart, K.B., Joshua, Jeffrey and Jessica, and great-grandchildren Aaron, Jacob, Sophie and Ivy. Contributions may be made to the Jewish National Fund.

title: Dockworkers Locked Out Of West Coast Terminals
description: West Coast port operators shut down cargo terminals from Seattle to Los Angeles tonight, in effect locking out unionized longshoremen. The terminals will remain closed until Sunday morning, company officials said.

title: Glenn Gould's Legacy: A Persistent State of Awe
description: The telephone call seemed to arrive from another world. It came not late at night as others had, but at 4:30 on an autumnal Sunday afternoon. It began differently as well: the voice was more intimate than it had been, as if a barrier had been removed.

title: Bush Rule Makes Fetuses Eligible for Health Benefits
description: The Bush administration issued final rules today allowing states to define a fetus as a child eligible for government-subsidized health care under the Children's Health Insurance Program.

title: Chasing A Dream But Getting Nowhere
description: ''I saw a film on DVD,'' says Xiao Ji (Wu Qiong), one of the alienated kids featured in the Chinese writer-director Jia Zhang Ke's new film, ''Unknown Pleasures,'' which will be shown tomorrow and Monday as part of the New York Film Festival, and he goes on to describe the opening of ''Pulp Fiction,'' in which Tim Roth and Amanda Plummer go from pancakes to packing heat to rob a diner. It's the life he'd have if he lived in America, he says, and in the very next scene the director cuts to a dance club that samples the surf- punk score of Quentin Tarantino's film. But being immersed in pop culture doesn't set the kids of ''Pleasures'' free; it's just another signpost of the things they can't have. There's not much that's unknown in their lives and not a lot of pleasure either.

title: Torricelli Says Vote Is on Issues, Not Ethics
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli tried to convince fellow Democrats today that his re-election campaign would ultimately be decided by policy issues rather than by the ethical questions that have so far dominated his re-election campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANGER, DAVID
description: GRANGER-David. Of New York City, died on September 27, 2002. Mr. Granger is survived by his wife Lee Mason Granger and by their son David Mason Granger and by his stepson Thomas Mason Clyde. A memorial service will be held later this Fall. Memorial contributions may be made to Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave., New York, New York 10021.

title: Suspect Faces Murder Charge After Arrest in Sex Attack

title: More Than One Option on Iraq
description: With the debate about Iraq heating up in Washington, it was good to hear a robust and eloquent appeal for caution yesterday from Senator Edward Kennedy. Almost no one in America thinks Saddam Hussein is an enlightened leader, but a lot of people would agree with Mr. Kennedy that Washington must exhaust other means of dealing with the Iraqi leader and his unconventional weapons before it turns to the use of force. That is not a view that the Bush administration always seems to share. Indeed, there are times when President Bush and his national security team seem all too eager to plunge into battle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORISON, GORDON I.
description: MORISON-Gordon I. Age 86, of Red Bank, NJ, died Thursday. He was a CPA for The Bank of New York retiring in 1980 after 28 years of employment. He retired as senior vice president. He is survived by his wife Ruth (nee Williams), daughter Laurie, grandson Stephen and niece Natalie. Services and interment will be private.

description: The indoctrination will begin on Tuesday. Coach Don Chaney will introduce the Knicks to the art of loose and free, fast and frenetic basketball.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: European Companies Buy Oil
description: TotalFinaElf, Eni and Repsol YPF, three of Europe's five biggest oil companies, agreed to buy oil directly from Iraq after it dropped a surcharge on sales. For Total of France, this week's purchase was the first in two years, a spokeswoman said, declining to specify the size of the cargo. Eni of Italy bought a million barrels of Iraqi oil, said Luciana Santaroni, a spokeswoman. Repsol YPF of Spain has agreed to oil exports and is awaiting United Nations clearance. The return of European companies to Iraqi ports may mean the end of a decline in sales from the nation, the Middle East's fifth-largest oil producer. Sales slid this year because of the surcharge and growing wariness about trading with the country.

title: Salomon Talks To the S.E.C. About Settling Conflict Cases
description: Representatives of Salomon Smith Barney met today with the top members of the enforcement staff at the Securities and Exchange Commission to outline a proposed settlement of the investigation into conflicts of interest between analysts and investment bankers.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bishops Act On Sex Abuse
description: The country's Roman Catholic bishops set guidelines for dealing with accusations of sexual abuse of children by priests and acknowledged that the church had often dealt inadequately with the problem. Under the guidelines, bishops in the 27 dioceses will name church officials to investigate accusations of abuse of minors. If abuses are discovered and a priest refuses to approach the authorities, the church will report the case to prosecutors. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Cheney Argues Against Giving Congress Records
description: Lawyers for the General Accounting Office and Vice President Dick Cheney clashed today before a federal judge here over which branch of government's claim is paramount: the executive power to keep records confidential or the legislative right to investigate how public money is spent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGENSTEIN, BERNARD
description: ROGENSTEIN-Bernard. The members of the Board, the tenants and staff of 17 East 89 St. express their profound sadness at the sudden death of our cherished neighbor, Bernie Rogenstein. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Lucy, sons Gregg and Steven, and his entire family. We are all diminished by this loss.

title: Reality TV Meets Politics
description: Now they've gone too far. That might be the first reaction of people who take their politics seriously to ''American Candidate,'' the new reality show that the FX cable channel, owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, is planning to air in 2004.

title: Bahrain Presence at Crucial Time Led to Arrest
description: Mukhtar al-Bakri could hardly have chosen a worse time and place for the wedding his family had arranged.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Slovenia: Novartis Bid Rejected
description: The major shareholders of Lek Pharmaceutical and Chemical Company of Slovenia have rejected a takeover bid from Novartis. Novartis, the Swiss drug maker, failed to win support from two government funds that are Lek's largest shareholders after increasing its offer to 98,000 Slovenian tolars ($428.38) a share from 95,000. The higher bid valued the Slovenian company at about 1.22 billion Swiss francs ($812 million).

title: Forgotten Soldiers of the Integration Fight
description: On Tuesday, Oct. 1, Oxford, Miss., will be coming to terms with one of the major events of its past. Forty years ago on that day, in the early morning, a force of nearly 30,000 American combat troops raced toward Oxford in a colossal armada of helicopters, transport planes, Jeeps and Army trucks.

title: After Bhopal
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Says Target in Gaza Raid Was Wounded, but Escaped
description: Israeli officials acknowledged today that a helicopter strike in Gaza City on Thursday had failed to kill its target, a bombmaker for the militant group Hamas who has been on Israel's wanted list for a decade.

title: Women's Group Lobbies Seven of Augusta's Members
description: The National Council of Women's Organizations sent letters to seven members of Augusta National Golf Club yesterday, its latest attempt to press the club, the host of the Masters, to admit women by next year.

title: As leather sales fall, small firms take stock
description: MILAN  Mipel, Italy's biannual leather goods trade fair, was an upbeat affair in contrast to the subdued event last September which came in the immediate aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Buyers were back in force, traditional quality leather is in favor again and the range of colors reflected the optimism.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: CHARGES OF BRIBERY Leaders of the opposition Conservative Party accused the government of paying a bribe of nearly $400 million to North Korea to persuade its leader, Kim Jong Il, to play host to South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, in June 2000. They said the state-owned Korea Development Bank had transferred the money through companies in the Hyundai group. A spokeswoman for President Kim, who has made reconciliation with North Korea his main policy goal, said the accusation was "baseless." Chung Mong Joon, an heir to a controlling stake in Hyundai Heavy Industries, is challenging the conservative candidate, Lee Hoi Chang, in the presidential election in December.

title: Despite Big Issues, Primaries Prompted Only 17% to Vote
description: Roiling life-and-death issues like war and terrorism and economic concerns were not enough to entice many people to the polls for midterm primaries this year, a new study shows.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about Miles Dabord, who went into a coma on Sept. 14 after being sought in the disappearance of three people including his brother, the former basketball player Bison Dele, misstated his condition at a California hospital. Mr. Dabord, whom the police in Tahiti suspect of having killed the three, did not die on Thursday. Last night he was reported in critical condition. A corrective article appears today, on Page D2.

title: Milosevic Says Srebrenica Was a Plot to Frame the Serbs
description: Slobodan Milosevic presented in court today a new version of his long-held theory that the destruction of Yugoslavia was a Western conspiracy.

title: Messing With Lubbock
description: To the Editor:

title: Shell Gets F.T.C. Approval To Acquire Pennzoil-Quaker
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group received approval today from antitrust regulators to buy the Pennzoil-Quaker State Company for $2.8 billion.

title: McCall Denies Impropriety in Helping Daughter Get Company Job
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall today denied any impropriety in helping his daughter get a job at a telecommunications company by writing on his official stationery to an executive and noting that millions of shares of the company's stock were held by the state pension fund that Mr. McCall controls.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bribery Accusations
description: A tribunal investigating corruption said a former foreign minister received bribes totaling more than $200,000 during his time in office. Ray Burke, left, who served in Parliament and the government from the 1970's to 1997, received payments in the 1980's from businessmen bidding for a radio broadcasting license and from builders and real estate developers seeking zoning permission for their property interests, investigators said. Mr. Burke has not commented on the finding. The report also found that a former press secretary for Mr. Ahern's Fianna Fail party, P. J. Mara, had obstructed the tribunal's investigations. Mr. Mara resigned yesterday from his position as head of the campaign for a forthcoming referendum on a treaty for expanding the European Union. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Beliefs; Churches and ethicists loudly oppose the proposed war on Iraq, but deaf ears are many.
description: Given that the United States is repeatedly said to be a religious country and that over 80 percent of its citizens are reported to be Christians, it is interesting how little has been made of the declarations by so many Christian leaders and ethicists that the Bush Administration's proposed war against Iraq is unjust and immoral.

title: Richter's Mean Streak Surfaces Against Devils
description: Mike Richter does not usually display a mean streak. But tonight, when he found someone parked too close to the crease, Richter, the Rangers' veteran goaltender, reacted like Billy Smith, the former Islanders goaltender.

title: Read This Slowly
description: In a nation that relishes speed, from fast cars to fast food, it has often been difficult to get people to embrace a more deliberate pace. But that may be changing, if ever so slowly.

title: MGM Mirage Seeks to Lure The Gamblers Of Cyberspace
description: MGM Mirage plans to start an Internet casino next month, becoming the first United States casino to confront the challenges involved in offering blackjack, roulette and craps to gamblers on home computers.

title: Yes Chairman Reacts Angrily to MSG's plans
description: The chairman of the YES Network reacted angrily yesterday to the MSG Network's plan to offer postgame coverage of the Yankees playoff series as special editions of its ''SportsDesk'' program.

title: Seen as Safety Net, 9/11 Program Is Anything But
description: The financial assistance program in New York State that officials described as a kind of ultimate safety net for those who lost their jobs or had their property damaged because of the World Trade Center disaster has given grants to only a small fraction of the people who applied. Indeed, program officials admit they have not even reviewed more than half of the nearly 73,000 requests for aid that they received in recent months.

title: A Button for All Occasions, Including Brown vs. Harvard
description: For the biggest football game of the year against its staunchest and most bitter foe -- and for the game that could conceivably decide the league championship, even though it is only the second game of the season, for all this you could, in most quarters on the Brown University campus today, cut the tension with, well. . . .

title: Giving the Designers a Chance
description: With the painful commemoration of Sept. 11 settling behind us, the city is ready to return to the weighty task of rebuilding Lower Manhattan. Thursday's naming of six architectural teams to craft new proposals for ground zero draws some of the most talented designers in the world into this complicated process. What they need are less-restrictive guidelines from their clients -- the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Such distinguished urban artists deserve the most thoughtful and flexible instructions about how to fill the gaping hole that dominates the city's downtown.

title: Vatican Expected to Seek Test of Sexual Abuse Policy
description: Roman Catholic officials in the United States and in Rome now say they believe that the Vatican is unlikely to give full support to the American bishops' new policy of permanently removing all sexually abusive priests from ministry.

title: Increased Attention on Iraq Is Raising Anxieties, Too
description: Carol Larkin, 51, is a Republican who served in the Navy and voted for President Bush, but do not get her started about a war with Iraq. ''No, no, no,'' she said emphatically. ''I think if we're going to be in Afghanistan, we need to finish that up. Why open two cans of worms when we can't close the first one?''

title: After Disputes on Scoring, School System Switches Provider of Reading Tests
description: After several bitter disputes over the scoring of standardized tests, the New York City school system has decided to scale back its relationship with CTB/McGraw-Hill and hire another company to create and score its annual reading tests.

title: U.S. PLAN REQUIRES INSPECTION ACCESS TO ALL IRAQ SITES
description: The Bush administration has drafted a stringent plan for arms inspections that provides for unrestricted access to all sites in Iraq, including Saddam Hussein's presidential compounds and palaces, and authorizes the use of military force if Baghdad interferes, according to European and American officials.

title: Some Officials Shaken by New Central Park Jogger Inquiry
description: Last summer, long after the Central Park jogger case had faded from sight and before it rose again like a spectral relic, investigators paid visits to two of the five men convicted in 1990 of the crime. And while many officials still believe that justice was done in that case, the results of those visits have shaken veteran law enforcement officials' confidence in the original convictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILTON, WENDY
description: HILTON-Wendy, 71. A specialist in Baroque dance, choreographer, writer, and teacher on September 21, 2002, died in New York City after a long illness. Ms. Hilton was a faculty member of the Juilliard School of Dance, and Stanford University. A memorial service will be held on October 18, 2002, 6:15 PM at Krour Thai Restaurant, 362 8th Ave., NY, NY. Donations in her memory can be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice, 10 Nathan Perlman Place, NY, NY 10003, or Juilliard School of Dance, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, NY, NY 10023.

title: Rumors of Gang Rites Rattling Paterson
description: Over the last three days, people here have been gripped with anxiety over a rampant rumor that a street gang planned to murder a mother and child as an initiation rite on Thursday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Investment Approved
description: China plans to allow Newbridge Capital, an American private equity firm, to buy a stake in the Shenzhen Development Bank, a step toward gradually opening China's financial sector to foreigners. The bank said in a statement that it expected the deal to be completed soon, but did not provide details. Newbridge Capital, which specializes in emerging market investments, is expected to buy a minority stake in the bank that would make it the largest single shareholder.

title: In Tehran, A Driver With a Lot To Say
description: ''Ten'' consists of a series of conversations -- the title tells you how many -- that take place between the driver of a car, a middle-class Tehran woman in her 30's (Mania Akbari), and various passengers, including her young son. The director, Abbas Kiarostami, in addition to being perhaps the most internationally admired Iranian filmmaker of the past decade, is also among the world masters of automotive cinema. But while his action-minded colleagues, in Hollywood and elsewhere, view every motor vehicle as a potential fireball, the more contemplative Mr. Kiarostami understands the automobile as a place for reflection, observation and, above all, talk.

title: Gold Cup Last Test Before $800,000 Bet
description: John Amerman was good at selling toys because he made prudent, calculated business decisions, a reason sales quadrupled at Mattel during the years he was the company's chief executive. That's big business, where there's no place for sentiment. Now Amerman is prepared to take the riskiest emotional gamble of his life, betting $800,000 that his prize racehorse can prove himself against the best in the world.

description: SISTER CHRISTINA GRAZIOSI, a native of a small town near Naples, Italy, has lived at the Convent of St. Birgitta in Darien since it opened as a guesthouse and a spiritual retreat 45 years ago.

title: The Stranger
description: Come on, Billy! How about thinking about the potential you have to help others? Fight for environmental justice, organize a concert against war, look around at the many people who could benefit from your help! You'd be surprised at the way thinking about someone else can affect your mood! And besides, women love men who get socially engaged -- it's a real turn-on!

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, Page 12 of Money & Business last Sunday was interchanged with Page 12 of Sunday Styles in some copies. The error misplaced the continuations of three articles -- one about the economic uncertainty that is slowing businesses' spending; one about the murky line between companies' philanthropies and those of their chief executives; and one about the uses of humiliation in a new generation of television advertising. The full articles may be found online today, at nytimes.com/corrections.

title: Private Sector; Singing the Virtues of Charter Flying
description: Fed up with commercial airline travel, Steven Green, a real estate developer, bought a small jet three years ago, renting it to others when he wasn't using it himself. That was a serendipitous decision.

title: The Game Still Spins On Their Fingertips
description: Larry Brown made sure he thanked his family and friends, all his teams, players and dozens of assistant coaches over the years. But he did not want to forget the memory of some other inductees into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: Poverty Is More Than a Matter of Income
description: Last week, in an annual autumn ritual, the Census Bureau released its latest statistics on poverty and income. After falling for four consecutive years, the poverty rate rose to 11.7 percent in 2001. But this figure, whether rising or declining, tells only part of the story about poverty in America: It measures only income. For a more complete picture -- and a more disheartening one -- it is necessary to measure the assets of the poor as well.

title: 'Life in the Theater' at Fleetwood
description: TWENTY-FIVE years after its premiere, it is clear that David Mamet's ''Life in the Theater'' is a nonplay, misperceived as a knowing inside look at the caprices of actors and overrated as a valentine to the theater.

description: ROTH-Ida. Sept 26, 2000. Our beloved ''Granny''. Two years in a world without you. Forever in our hearts. Diane and Larry

description: The six plans for the World Trade Center that were unveiled in July all featured lofty office buildings, and half called for structures of 80 stories or more. On Thursday, six new teams of architects were invited to take another crack at ideas for the site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHN, ROSE Z.
description: CAHN-Rose Z. Teacher, died September 27, 2002 in Brooklyn, NY after a long illness at age 92. Beloved widow of Bernard Cahn, devoted mother of Meta and Richard Cahn. She will never be forgotten for her good work, and will always be loved. A contribution to the Association for the Help of Retarded Children would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELDE, EDITH CURTIS

As a group dedicated to performing Billy Joel hits of the past, Big Shot so closely mirrors the original sound that sometimes even Mr. Joel himself can't tell the difference.

title: Not Just Any Lane

There's nothing too spectacular about the Chappaqua street -- just 11 typical suburban houses on a property that was developed, like so many others, in the mid-1950's. Before that it was pretty much a lot of thick underbrush, trees, poison ivy and rocks.

Gomes, who is the Plummer professor of Christian morals at Harvard University, performed an Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's paternal grandparents, Tatiana and George Peabody Gardner, in Prides Crossing, Mass.

title: 'The Piano Tuner'
description: It was afternoon in the office of Colonel Killian, Director of Operations for the Burma Division of the British army. Edgar Drake sat a pair of dark, rattling heating pipes and stared out the window, watching the sweep of rain. Across the room sat the Colonel, a broad, sunburnt man with a shock of red hair and a thick mustache that fanned out in combed symmetry, underlining a fierce pair of green eyes. Behind his desk hung a long Bantu lance and a painted shield that still bore the scars of battle. He wore a scarlet uniform, edged with braids of black mohair. Edgar would remember this, for the braids reminded him of a tiger's stripes, and the scarlet made the green eyes greener.

title: Sept. 22-28
description: U.S. TERROR UPDATE Federal prosecutors in Buffalo asked a magistrate to deny bail to six Yemeni-American men accused of attending a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan in the summer of 2001.

title: Writer On The Road: Vermont On A Dare
description: I had made it through the loneliest corner of Vermont all the way to the Canadian line and won a bet by doing so, but would my Oldsmobile ever make it back home again? My Oldsmobile -- as in my Brillo-colored 1983 ''Delta 88'' Olds; my Olds that had spent the entire winter up on cement blocks in our meadow; my Olds that had given 20 years of faithful service, but was now used mostly as a storage shed for canoe paddles, novel manuscripts and garden supplies. My Olds that, as I turned onto Main Street in Canaan, Vt., the last sizable town before Quebec, dripped four kinds of fluids, emitted bleating, squealing sounds that made pedestrians turn their heads and grimace, flashed warning lights I didn't even know it had, crying in pain, but plugging gamely on, fueled by the the macho bravado of its driver, with an additive of bittersweet pride.

title: Books to Please the Eye and Botany Lovers
description: GARDENERS, in my opinion, fall into two groups. One contains people who can't, or don't, want to keep the members of a plant family in their heads; they grow plants and arrange them intuitively, making connections through observation. The other contains the more linear thinkers, who may be just as artistic but love to categorize what they are planting; they want to understand how they contribute to the order of things in the universe. (This latter group may also ponder certain mysteries, like what was the first flowering plant and how did it come to be?)

title: Snowmobiles in Parks: Limits, but Not a Ban
description: THE contentious issue of snowmobiles in Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks, which has been debated for at least the past decade, was supposed to have been resolved with a federal ban that was set to start Nov. 15. Just a few months ago, the Environmental Protection Agency endorsed the ban, proposed under President Bill Clinton, and the National Park Service was ready to implement it, with the public's blessing. During the public comment period that ended in June, the park service said, it received an unprecedented 361,000 letters and e-mail messages, more than three-fourths of them in support of the ban.

The author's account of the nation's bubble years, which has been updated with a new afterword, illuminates the booming, self-indulgent 1990's by focusing on characters who seemed to embody the age -- including the casts of the O. J. Simpson trial and the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal -- and puncturing some of the reigning myths of the times. The result is ''an earnest, angry, poignant, foreboding book,'' Robin Toner wrote in the Book Review in 2001.

He had won a yearlong residency at the academy, then as now a leading center for independent study and research in the arts and humanities. There he was, in that ancient, cultured city, living and working in the academy's 11-acre complex of studios and villas atop the Janiculum, the highest hill within the walls of Rome, with its spectacular views. Yet all Johnson, 29 at the time, could think about was his native land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOMOLKA, LARRY JOSEPH
description: HOMOLKA-Larry Joseph. Artist and art historian, age 61, died in NYC on 22 September 2002 following a long illness with muscular dystrophy. Born May 21, 1941 in Oak Park, IL, he grew up in Mankato, MN. He received his B.A. degree with Honors in Art from Grinnell College, IA. He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and became a Woodrow Wilson National Fellow at Harvard University. There he earned a Ph.D. in the History of Art and Architecture. He taught at Emory University in Atlanta and later at Pace University and the Fashion Institute of Technology in NY. He lectured at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and was architectural historian for the Historic American Buildings Survey in Chicago (US Department of Interior). He had several exhibitions of his paintings throughout his career in NY and elsewhere. His work is in various public and private collections in the US, Germany, and Brazil. He leaves behind his mother Lillian in Mankato, MN, and a brother Donald in NY, as well as numerous friends. Any memorials should be donated to the Larry Homolka Scholarship Fund for Art, Grinnell College, Grinnell, IA 50112.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERERA, GEORGE A., M.D., MED. SC.D.
description: PERERA-George A., M.D., Med. Sc.D. The Department of Medicine notes with sadness the passing on September 14th of Dr. George A. Perera at the age of 91. Dr. Perera graduated from Princeton College in 1933 and from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1937. Following a chief residency in Medicine at the Presbyterian Hospital, Dr. Perera joined the Columbia Univeristy faculty and the Presbyterian Hospital staff. He served both University and Hospital with distinction until his departure in 1971. He was highly regarded as an expert in the field of hypertension, his work having been recognized by election to both the American Society for Clinical Investigation and the Association of American Physicians, and Columbia University awarded him its Alumni Medal in 1980. As a Professor of Medicine and as Associate Dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons he guided more than a generation of medical students with wisdom, energy, and dedication. We express our enduring gratitude for his many contributions. Joseph Tenenbaum, M.D. Interim Chairman, Department of Medicine Columbia University

title: Nothing Too Somber To Call Up Again
description: Things go boom on Peter Gabriel's ''Up'' (Geffen), his first album of solo songs since ''Us'' in 1992. Drums explode out of silence or rumble like distant earthquakes. Other sounds rustle and throb, crackle and ring; notes played by hand on tabla drum or electric organ spar with computer-processed burbles and distortions. Amid other projects like his soundtrack album for ''The Rabbit-Proof Fence,'' called ''Long Walk Home'' (Real World), and an overblown music-theater allegory, ''Ovo: The Millennium Show'' (Real World import), Mr. Gabriel has been working over these 10 songs for years. Each track on ''Up'' seems to open into shadowy subterranean chambers where the music gains both gravity and a surreptitious commotion.

Gene Hackman plays the jovial one, Mr. Hackman's character is a hometown boy who defected from his ultraconservative Southern upbringing (''The grits started leaving a bad taste in my mouth,'' he explains) and has come home as the enemy. Alan Parker's MISSISSIPPI BURNING (1988) is as disturbing as ever, a portrait of a terrifyingly racist culture not so far in the past. That's Frances McDormand as the deputy sheriff's thoughtful hairdresser wife, acting up a storm before we knew who she was - Today and Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 1 a.m. on AMC.

title: RESEARCHER DISMISSED
description: A top researcher at Bell Labs was fired last week after an outside review committee found that he had altered or invented data. The committee found that J. Hendrik Schn, 32, falsified experimental data at least 16 times between 1998 and 2001 while working with other scientists in the fields of superconductivity, molecular crystals and molecular electronics. The committee said only Dr. Schn was to blame and cleared about 20 others involved in the work. In a statement, Dr. Schn said he had made ''various mistakes in my scientific work.'' Bell Labs is the research arm of Lucent Technologies, based in Murray Hill. John Holl

Park Place took control of the Claridge, which had been in bankruptcy, in June 2001. A month later, it built a $25 million connector between it and the adjacent Bally's. Park Place also owns Caesar's Atlantic City and the Atlantic City Hilton. If approved, the hotel, with the Bally's name, will become the largest in Atlantic City, with 1,753 hotel rooms, 21 restaurants, 6,091 slot machines and 3,993 parking spaces. Robert Strauss
