title: Gazing Into a Coffee Cup And Seeing the World
description: IF you were, say, Rimbaud or Toulouse-Lautrec and living in New York today, would you be romanticizing latte instead of absinthe? Passing a Starbucks and peering through the plate-glass window at patrons mesmerized by a cup of strong coffee and a newspaper, the person next to them or nothing at all, it seems possible, at least for a fanciful moment, that you would. Coffee bars are the last refuge of conspicuous consumption. Designer labels are no longer chic, except among rap stars and tourists. Modesty is in. But the $3.75 grande latte at Starbucks is a permissible indulgence. Addictive, nonhallucinogenic and perfectly legal.

title: Looks Cool, Sounds Cool: Thank Sears
description: DUNCAN SHEIK, composer and recording artist, lives in a TriBeCa loft furnished mostly with instruments. A Yamaha baby grand piano has center stage; a small Hammond organ and a Wurlitzer keyboard stand in the background. There are drums in the glassed-in, soundproof studio. A Calrec console, eight feet across, once used by the British Broadcasting Corporation to record live classical music, dominates the control room, which is equipped for digital recording. He also has a Nord Electro keyboard, the newest acquisition, which simulates both the Hammond and the Wurlitzer.

title: Hand-Me-Downs
description: When I was 20, I worked in a nursing home. One day I overheard a conversation between Minnie, one of the veteran nursing assistants, and a woman named Amelia, who called her patients her babies. I was microwaving chicken-noodle soup, trying not to listen to Minnie sell the idea of foster-parenting to Amelia as if it were a piece of questionable real estate. ''It's not bad at all,'' Minnie said, ''and you can't beat the money.'' If they took in one more foster kid, they'd be able to swing buying a hot tub. My soup had gone volcanic, salty broth bubbling over the sides, adhering to the bowl like a chicken-colored membrane. There was nothing to do but chuck the whole thing or dump it over Minnie's head to watch the noodles burn worm tracks down her face. That was the other way to go.

title: First came the sitcom. Then came the murder. Then came the pornographic Web site. Now here comes the Holly wood biopic!
description: Had Bob Crane not been a sex addict, had he not been bludgeoned to death with his own tripod in an Arizona condo surrounded by an elaborate array of video equipment, had he not photographed hundreds of women naked in twosomes and threesomes and orgies and had his murder not gone unsolved, he would not be the subject of a new feature film. He would be remembered, if he was remembered at all, as the star of ''Hogan's Heroes,'' a hit CBS comedy that ran from 1965 to 1971 and was set in a P.O.W. camp during World War II. As the star of ''Hogan's Heroes,'' Crane enjoyed the same kind of fame as Gilligan or Greg Brady -- his character became part of America's collective pop-culture nostalgia. Embalmed by syndication, Crane would have been the wisecracking Hogan forever. But in the years since his death in 1978, when the porno pictures started surfacing in the tabloids and his secrets began to unravel, Crane became infamous. And in the age of ''Behind the Music'' and ''The Osbournes,'' decadence and self-destruction make for the best kind of celebrity.

title: When a Building Must Install Ramps
description: Q Our co-op building is 20 years old. Tenants have begged for ramps in the lobby, but none have materialized. Doormen pull carts and carriages up and down the stairs in the lobby. There are also no ramps in the garages. We have to pull baby carriages and grocery wagons up stairs without help. Many times, the wagons are so heavy we have to take items out so we can get the equipment up to level ground. Our side exits have steps but no ramps for carriages, carts or wheelchairs. Isn't this illegal? . . . J. Rinaldi, Flushing, N.Y.

It allows teachers and school administrators to perform their own ''show and tell'' for parents, who come to inspect, make judgments about the use of their tax dollars and form partnerships to promote their children's betterment.

title: When Politics Is Personal
description: Whether the comparison was Sontag's or the senator's, the assertion that the family of a 19-year-old in a serious car accident would not face the predicament of forgoing treatment or being crushed by debt is, unfortunately, dead wrong. Our 19-year-old son was catastrophically injured in a high-speed head-on collision when a van crossed the center line. We learned that families of a person with a severe head injury have options much like the ones the Domenicis describe. Brain injury creates a wide array of physical, mental and emotional impairments. Care for its mental and emotional consequences is limited, like care for mental illness. And although physically devastating injuries are covered, cost-containment pressures began almost immediately for us to ''give up'' on our son. Even though he made a strong recovery, health-insurance policies have painfully little coverage for the many rehab therapies needed for decades, if not for life.

title: Plea Bargain
description: The recent cases of Michael Kopper, the Enron book-cooker, and John Walker Lindh, the Taliban fellow-traveler, both ended with a practice that, according to Stephen Schulhofer, an N.Y.U. law professor, is wrongly considered almost ''inevitable'' by most players in the justice system: a plea bargain. Kopper exemplifies one common type -- the white-collar criminal with a good lawyer who agrees to help prosecutors hook bigger fish in exchange for a much lighter sentence than he might otherwise get (and thereby sparing the state the costs of a trial). Lindh typifies the defendant who pleads to avoid the possibility of execution; the government's reward includes not having to expose security sources (or, perhaps, a weak case) if the case goes to trial.

title: You Are What You Drive
description: About a year ago, in a burst of patriotism, my wife and I went out and bought a car. Well, yes, it was a Swedish car, but at the time this perfectly ordinary act of conspicuous consumption felt like -- and more to the point, was being widely promoted as -- an act of civic duty. Of course, there was more to the decision than the defense of our way of life. The two of us had arrived, in our mid-30's, at the grassy plateau of adulthood, having acquired over a decade or so all the trappings of that condition: each other, two children, real jobs and 30 years of mortgage debt. But it had been 10 years since our last car: a 1983 Oldsmobile Cutlass, a classic old-lady car passed down from a grandmother, with plush bench seats and a V-6 that accelerated silently and in its own good time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMANOFF, HIH PRINCE ALEXANDER
description: ROMANOFF - HIH Prince Alexander. Of Russia died in London, after a brief illness on September 21. Prince Alexander was a greatgrandson of the emperor Alexander III and the empress Maria Feodorovna, and a grand-nephew of the last tsar, Nicholas II. His grandparents were Grand Duchess Xenia, the eldest daughter of Alexander III, and Grand Duke Alexander Mihailovich, grandson of Emperor Nicholas I. Prince Alexander was the son of Prince and Princess Nikita of Russia. His mother was born Countess Maria Ilarionovna VorontsovDashkov. Prince Alexander was born in Paris on November 4, 1929. He spent much of his early life at Windsor in England, in France and in Italy. He attended Columbia University in New York City and was fluent in Russian, English, French and Italian. He had a superb memory and spent much of his life doing historical research and genealogy. If you needed an answer to a genealogical question, you turned to him, and he - adding fascinating historical anecdotes - would tell you without even consulting a book. Prince Alexander is survived by his wife, Princess Maria Immacolata, born Princess Valguarnera di Niscemi, her sister, Margarita, his brother, Prince Nikita, Nikita's wife Janet, and his nephew Theodore. Religious services were held in London, and a private memorial service will be given in New York City.

title: A Director Whose Class Is His Burden
description: IN the course of a career that began before the dawn of the sound era and lasted to the dawn, 40 years later, of the Streisand era, William Wyler was among the most successful and admired of American directors. If his star has dimmed in the years since his retirement in 1970 and his death in 1981, that may be because it burned so brightly when he was in his prime. No filmmaker has ever been so thoroughly honored by the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences: Wyler was nominated for best director 12 times, and won three Oscars; his 1959 biblical epic, ''Ben Hur,'' also received 12 nominations, and won 11; and Wyler's movies, all told, generated 127 nominations and 39 awards.

One contains people who can't, or don't, want to keep the members of a plant family in their heads; they grow plants and arrange them intuitively, making connections through observation. The other contains the more linear thinkers, who may be just as artistic but love to categorize what they are planting; they want to understand how they contribute to the order of things in the universe. (This latter group may also ponder certain mysteries, like what was the first flowering plant and how did it come to be?)

title: THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: MOSCOW

The lingering threats from 9/11 and the weakening economy and stock market are what have Nebraskans on edge. They will, he added, follow the president's lead -- if he makes the case -- but they are ambivalent, and they really don't want to fight this war alone.

I was doing my demo, and in the middle of the pitch he grabbed the vacuum cleaner, went into the bedroom, threw back the sheets, started to vacuum the mattress, then threw the collected dirt back on to the sheets and said, ''You know, Mrs. Jones, this is dead skin and body ash, and if your husband were to see this, he would ask, 'What is all this crud?' title: The World; Iraq's Future: New Polity or Pandora's Box?

The Kurds have not forgotten the chemical attack that Saddam Hussein visited upon them 14 years ago -- an indiscriminate assault that killed thousands and left thousands more maimed and ailing. The Shiite majority -- nearly 65 percent of the population -- has long resented its historical persecution and exclusion from the highest ranks of power by the Sunni minority. And the wide chasm between those of means and those who are poor adds the burden of class-envy to a society that could be facing a power vacuum.

title: Shabana Is Late for School

It was Shabana's first day of school, and she couldn't wait to burst out the door. Frishta, on the other hand, was moving slowly, taking her time as she finished cleaning up and getting dressed. ''It was no big deal,'' recalls Frishta, a tall, softly rounded 17-year-old. ''I'd been to school before.'' Frishta had been in elementary school in 1996, when the Taliban captured Kabul and promptly interrupted her education and with it, her daily routine and her young friendships. She'd waited more than five years to return -- what were five more minutes?

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: A Woman's Work
description: Why the question, ''How could a woman incite Rwanda's sex-crime genocide?'' Cruelty and evil are certainly not gender specific. Power is the great corrupter, and women have been less influenced by the corrupting influences of power only because they have generally been deprived of power throughout history.

title: Sorry, Your Services Are No Longer Needed
description: So for the last few weeks, you've noticed some changes at work. You're not asked to attend important meetings. Your co-workers seem more aware of what's going on than you are and have even been given some of your old responsibilities. And, most eerily, your boss is suddenly avoiding eye contact with you.

title: Great Television About Trivial TV
description: FOUR years ago, as ''The Larry Sanders Show'' ended its six-year run on HBO, the song playing over the final credits was ''Will You Love Me Tomorrow?''

title: Old Friends Return
description: What prompts editors -- to reissue classics like a Little Golden Book of Walt Disney's ''Pinocchio'' and ''The Charles Addams Mother Goose,'' or to bring out ''Eloise Takes a Bawth'' 40 years after it was written but never published?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, LLOYD
description: GREENE-Lloyd. On September 22, 2002 at age 76. Beloved mother of Sarah Wrightson. Loving sister of Claire List. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association, 919 Michigan Ave., Suite 1100, Chicago, IL 60611-1676.

title: The Most Successful Writer
description: Barside conspiracist, solitary sulker, prowler of bookstore aisles in search of what he knows he won't find, i.e., his book -- the author cheated of his rightful due in money and fame by the infamous publisher-agent-reviewer axis is an almost beloved fixture. They're not all paranoid. I've read a half-dozen good books myself in the past few months that successfully eluded more than cursory notice and are probably already back to pulp by now. This doesn't exactly unmask some tawdry Scrivenergate. Even without the eternal surfeit of sawdust-packed blockbusters, bird-brain celeb bios, conquer-the-cosmos manuals ad nauseam, the organs of the trade aren't big or wide or quick enough to catch every rock in the nonstop avalanche of output, and if countless authors thus consigned to undeserved obscurity for their Sisyphean labors refuse to succumb gracefully, they're profoundly human.

title: Sara Cooke, Kevin Lowe
description: Sara Reynolds Cooke and Kevin Edward Lowe were married yesterday at St. Martin-in-the-Fields Episcopal Church in Philadelphia. The Rev. Robert L. Tate performed the ceremony.

title: The Nation: Help Wanted; Out of a Job and No Longer Looking
description: THE American welfare state was supposed to be dead, victim of the free-market economy and its success in creating a job for anybody who wanted one.

title: Balancing the Budget On Backs of Elderly
description: HELENA TILLMAN lives a simple life at Peternana Terrace, an apartment complex for the elderly in Freeport. She goes for short walks in the building's courtyard, but mostly she sits on the yellow benches out front and visits with her friends.

title: For Sellers Of Food, Fewer Chairs At the Table
description: THE big companies that sell much of the food that Americans eat have huge appetites. In the last couple of years, they have been gobbling up one another.

title: Russia Takes Stock of a Nation's Transformation
description: They have already counted the four residents in the village of Pyalitsy on the Kola Peninsula above the Arctic Circle and confirmed the population of a hamlet called Ustye Vorzugi: one. In the Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Area in Siberia, they needed helicopters to track down families gathering cranberries in the bogs.

title: Firing Back From Iraq
description: Iraq's rejection of any new United Nations resolution that toughens the terms of disarmament appeared calculated to widen the gap dividing the United States and Britain from the other big powers at the United Nations as they were struggling to find a common approach to confront Saddam Hussein.

title: Starring, and Commuting
description: A YOUNG woman stops by the window booth of the Blue Moon Diner, where Andre Braugher is sitting with cup of coffee one recent morning, smiles, hands him a postcard and walks off.

title: McCall Defends Letters to Two Companies
description: With five weeks left until Election Day, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday dismissed mounting accusations that he used his influence as the steward of New York State's $105 billion pension fund to help relatives in their job searches.

title: Dream Homes
description: A SUB-ZERO refrigerator. A home theater with a wide-screen flat-panel television. An indoor pool and spa. Those are the possible makings of an adult's dream house. But a child's dream house -- well, it simply must have a ham light, right?

title: Tea in Italy
description: To the Editor: Regarding Madeline Drexler's essay ''Holding the Bag in Italy'' (Sept. 15), I must strongly disagree with her opinions about tea in Italy.

title: The Sidekick as Sad Sack Savant
description: WHEN ''The Larry Sanders Show'' went off the air, many of its fans mourned above all the departure of Hank Kingsley, Larry's on-camera sidekick. In the hands of the burgundy-voiced actor Jeffrey Tambor, whose

title: In Shape in Orlando
description: When you think of health clubs, you might well think of people in high-pressure cities like New York or Washington needing a workout to decompress. Surprisingly, though, according to the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association, New York ranks a lowly 17th in club membership, at 14.6 of every 100 people (over age 6). Washington is even further down the Stairmaster, at 24th.

title: Miss America? Oops, Missed It
description: Miss America still shed her tears of joy. There were still squeals as she walked the runway. The lyrics ''There she is'' still rang out.

title: Working to Restore Accabonac Environment
description: The fading of the Accabonac environment, people and way of life with the suburbanizing of East Hampton is sad, indeed [''In East Hampton, the Way of a 'Lost Tribe,' '' Sept. 22].

title: The Midtown Direct, Sometimes Indirectly
description: Commuters, check your tickets. And your tracks. Quickly.

title: When Politics Is Personal
description: While I applaud the efforts of Domenici and colleagues 2/3 I find it worrisome that they are motivated to legislate by personal experience. Lawmakers are disproportionately affluent, middle-aged white men who may not share the concerns important to the vast majority of their constituents. Ideally they would have the insight, compassion and sensitivity to perceive problems that afflict the common man without requiring a personal brush with tragedy to galvanize their legislative zeal. There are a lot of problems out there that don't affect these guys directly.

title: The Pugilist Novelist
description: Q: Your new book, ''Lullaby,'' is a darkly comic, subversive take on the horror genre and features a more or less unwitting serial killer. I understand that you wrote it in the aftermath of your father's murder -- during the trial of the man who was ultimately convicted.

title: Reclaiming An Ancient Virtuosity
description: TO play an ancient instrument is to be at once fortunate and cursed. Fortunate, because you can call up sounds that have all but disappeared from music, like words that have fallen out of a language. Cursed, because most people expect you to be a ''traditional musician,'' a messenger from the past whose peculiar duty it is to defy time itself. You have a role, and not merely an instrument, to play, and that role can quickly become a trap.

title: The Stranger
description: I never knew that Billy Joel had such a dark side. He may desire to be big in rock 'n' roll, but he holds a more important position -- that of poet, commentator on the human condition and friend, especially to the lonely and disheartened. The man is golden.

title: Paperback Highlights
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: Espousing Confidence
description: I am usually in sync with the Ethicist, but I disagree with his disapproving response to the husband who kept a friend's pregnancy a secret from his wife (Sept. 15).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OELSNER, HOPE BRYAN
description: OELSNER - Hope Bryan. Died peacefully September 20 in Manchester, VT, at the age of 84. She was a beloved and wonderful wife, mother, grandmother, sister and aunt who devoted her life to her family. She was the cherished and very loving wife of Edward C. Oelsner Jr. for 50 years, until his death in 1990, and the well-loved and caring mother of four children, her sons Edward C. Oelsner III of New York City and James L. Oelsner of Littleton, Colorado, and her daughters Glenny Glenn of Centre Island, N.Y., and Lesley Oelsner of New York City, all of whom survive her. She was the fond grandmother of Hope, Wooderson and Edward Glenn, and of Elizabeth, Edward, Frederick and Benjamin Oelsner. She was born in Garden City, N.Y., the second of seven children of Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Bryan, and lived most of her life on the North Shore of Long Island, later moving to Lost Tree Village, North Palm Beach, FL, and summering in Arlington and then Manchester, VT. She is survived by her brothers James T. Bryan of Laurel Hollow, NY and the Venerable Robert A. Bryan of Ipswich, MA., and by her sisters Ruth Colgrove of Locust Valley, NY, Joy Bacon of New Paltz, New York, and Hazel Tracy of Londonderry, VT. She is survived also by 41 nieces and nephews. She was an avid amateur painter, pianist, and golfer. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Manchester Music Festival, P.O. Box 1165, Manchester Center, VT. 05255.

title: Sept. 22-28: NATIONAL; COUNTRY CRIME
description: In a terrifying holdup in the small Nebraska farming community of Norfolk, three gunmen opened fire inside the U.S. Bank, killing five people. Over the past 6 years, bank robberies nationwide rose 17 percent, but, according to Federal Bureau of Investigation statistics, increased 82 percent in small towns. John W. Fountain

title: May I Speak to the Manager? A Storm at Marriott
description: FOR John J. Flatley, a multimillionaire property developer, the eviction of his trusted overseer was more than he could bear.

title: A U.N. Agency Is Revitalized by Re-entry of the U.S.
description: When President Bush told the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 12 that the United States would rejoin Unesco after an 18-year absence, the announcement went almost unnoticed. In a speech dominated by his call for international action against Iraq, Mr. Bush dedicated just 37 words to the end of the American boycott of the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: Classics Made New
description: For Wayne Cherry, the chief of design at General Motors, the station wagon created by the legendary Harley Earl was a seminal moment in car design. ''This was one of the dream cars of the 1950's Motoramas,'' Cherry says. ''It embodied optimism and excitement, and when you look at it today, it still strikes those emotional chords.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUSLOW, MICHAEL WHIT LOCK
description: TRUSLOW - Michael Whit lock. July 3, 1953-September 22, 2002. Loved always for his integrity, compassion, intense love of life, family and his fellow man.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Mercury Marauder; A Marquis in the Style of de Sade
description: THE Ford Crown Victoria and its fraternal twin, the Mercury Grand Marquis, are automotive mastodons, relics from a stage of car evolution when full-size body-on-frame sedans roamed the earth.

title: In 'Much Ado' at Hartford, the Party's the Thing
description: IT could be one of Nel Coward's marvelous parties or a swellegant soiree, Cole Porter style. But the song that propels the all- dancing payoff at Hartford Stage is ''I Won't Dance'' and that is a Jerome Kern melody.

title: Knowing Your Market Value Before You Plead for a Raise
description: IT was galling: Denise Geiger had just won accolades from her supervisors in her first-year salary review as a special education liaison to public school districts in Queens and Long Island. Then she was offered what she considered a paltry $3,000 raise from pay that she says was already below market rate.

title: A Whiff Of Japan
description: The fashion -- world's love affair with citron yellow has reached beauty counters, where new products made with yuzu (Japanese citron) are ripe for picking. Round and bright yellow, the fruit resembles a small grapefruit in look and scent but has sweeter overtones of mandarin orange. Yuzu zest and juice are prized in Japan for their fresh tangy fragrance. At Henri Bendel, a body buff scrub by Lather mixes yuzu with sugar cane ($24), while a body lotion and after-bath mist by Sonia Kashuk combines yuzu, ginger and tuberose ($9.99 each, Target stores). Lavett & Chin's Mandarin Yuzu hair-conditioning treatment includes exotic extracts of horsetail, Chinese skullcap and red algae to hydrate dry or damaged tresses ($34 at www.beautyhabit.com). The fragrant yuzu candle by Fresh is a tangy blend of yuzu, orange blossoms and Sicilian lemons ($45 at www.fresh.com). Chidoriya's Gold soaps ($12 at Bigelow Chemists in New York, 800-793-5433) are a feast for the eyes and nose, each wrapped in Japanese fabric, like a perfectly pleated yuzu dumpling.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FORST, BEA
description: FORST-Bea. Dear Bea, we miss you and think of you. Your Friends

title: Film Series and Film Openings
description: Opening This Week

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDIS, ABNER A.
description: LANDIS-Abner A. After a long illness. Loving husband of Constance Ross Landis and the late Elaine Schultz Landis. Devoted father of Geoffrey R. Landis. Caring stepfather of Beth L. Zager. Adoring grandfather. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Association, Inc, would be greatly appreciated (360 Lexington Avenue, 5th Floor, NYC 10017). Services private.

title: Business Founder at 14, Old Hand at 20
description: RON LAZAR remembers meeting Gregory Galant three years ago at a Chamber of Commerce dinner in Huntington. Mr. Lazar, a commercial broker in Melville who graduated from Dartmouth College in 1953, didn't realize he was chatting with a poised if precocious member of Huntington High School's class of 2001. Mr. Lazar invited him to attend the next meeting of the chamber committee he chairs on economic development.

title: Sept. 22-28: INTERNATIONAL; RESCUED FROM REBELS
description: After intense gunfire and shelling, French soldiers in the Ivory Coast rescued teachers and students trapped for six days in a school in Bouak, a rebel-held city. Among the rescued were over 100 American children, who were placed in the custody of American troops and then evacuated to neighboring Ghana. Norimitsu Onishi

title: In Ulster, Reliving Its Day of Infamy
description: OVER more than three decades of sectarian strife, Northern Ireland's Protestant and Roman Catholic communities have come to proclaim their suffering through solemn recitations. They list the legions of dead, the blown-up pubs and fish-and-chips shops, the attacks that claimed yet more innocent lives. Of all the names and dates in this culture of victimization, Jan. 30, 1972 -- Bloody Sunday, when British paratroopers shot and killed 13 unarmed civil rights marchers in Londonderry -- remains the province's most potent memory.

title: Not Your Father's Roadmaster
description: FROM A BUICK 8

title: Window Dressing
description: IN the beginning, 15 years ago, a balloon shade was still an innovation. And that's all that Robin Fisher and a partner were making in a small shop in West Hartford. Country Curtains, a national chain, had bought the shop's design, and the shade was selling well.

title: An Incumbent on Top of the Republicans' List of Endangered Species
description: Representative Connie Morella of Maryland was speaking last weekend before what ought to have been her kind of crowd. These were members of Common Cause, an organization that had worked for years with Mrs. Morella, a moderate Republican, on campaign finance reform and many other issues. But this evening the group was uneasy.

description: I, RHODA MANNING, GO HUNTING WITH MY DADDY

title: Beyond the Bossa Nova
description: TROPICAL TRUTH

title: INSIDE
description: Japan's Economic Woes

title: Flying as a Courier
description: To the Editor: After reading ''How to Fly as a Courier'' (Practical Traveler, Feb. 17) by Hope Reeves, I went online to the Air Courier Association and took one-year memberships for my wife and me. When I tried to use the service, I was given three telephone numbers to call for prices on a trip I had inquired about. Air Courier did nothing but provide me with these telephone numbers. When I told them I wanted to cancel our memberships, I was told to put it in writing and send the letter to their Colorado office. I complied, and the response was that my request was being looked at and I was to send back all the literature, documents and membership cards. I sent everything they requested by certified mail on May 8. On June 6, everything I sent was returned marked unclaimed.

title: With Court Nod, Parents Debate School Drug Tests
description: In this serene lakeside town, a group has gathered at the high school each week since August to try to hammer out a consensus on drug testing in the schools: a pastor, a basketball coach, a sheriff, a social worker, a superintendent and assorted parents, teachers, students and school board members.

title: Judge Won't Lock the Stable Until Horses Have a Home
description: Two weeks ago, a curious crowd gathered to watch a court proceeding at federal bankruptcy court involving a failed strip club called the Stingray, a bankruptcy lawyer named Frank Sinatra, and a stable of possibly homeless horses.

title: Shucks, It's Just Chowder
description: How many clams are needed to make chowder to serve the 20,000 tasters expected at the 14th annual Chowderfest on Long Beach Island Oct. 6? John Maschal, owner of Country Kettle restaurant, said he needed 5,000 to 7,000 clams for his 200 gallons of chowder. With about 15 restaurants taking part, and an average of 6,000 clams for each, that would be around 90,000. There are awards for both the Manhattan (red) and New England (white) varieties, voted best by tasters; $15 ($4 for children aged 4 through 12) buys unlimited tastings while $40 includes a T-shirt and an hour's head start.

title: Better Test Scores, Then a Bonus
description: To the Editor:

title: Long After the Atlas, a Shrug: Missile Site Draws No Bidders
description: The house in the Adirondacks has a Jacuzzi, an airstrip, an underground living space and even its own missile silo. But so far it has no takers.

title: Sept. 22-28; Politics of Pique
description: NOT so long ago, Bill Clinton and Helmut Kohl, then the chancellor of Germany, shared carpaccio, crab-stuffed mushrooms, sauteed squid and cured meats and cheeses in a run of friendly monster-meals on two continents. The next time Chancellor Gerhard Schrder comes to the White House, he may be lucky to get bread and water from President Bush.

title: In Partnering a Ballet, the Orchestra Must Also Dance
description: IT was the sort of clash that takes you straight back to first principles. Three summers ago, the dancers of the Maryinsky Theater in Russia's Imperial capital of St. Petersburg were ready to dance George Balanchine's neo-Classical masterpiece ''Symphony in C'' at the White Nights Festival. The work, set to a Georges Bizet score, was still quite new to them.

title: Rebels Without a War Wait for Help in Angola
description: For the thousands of rebel soldiers encamped in this desolate corner of Angola, the end of the country's long civil war seems certain.

title: You Can't Floss In Those Shoes
description: Just after midnight on a rain-slicked stretch of Manhattan's West Side Highway, Funkmaster Flex is taking a joy ride in his new toy, a gleaming 1966 Chevrolet Impala rolling on customized chrome wheels. ''This is my favorite old-school ride,'' Flex tells me with a broad smile. ''I'm so proud of this car because it took three years to get it together.'' The Impala's paint is a candy-apple red; its dashboard is festooned with sharp angles of spotless chrome; the seats are made from brand-new, buttery black leather that makes the interior smell like a Roche-Bobois showroom. Idling at a red light, the 454-horsepower engine strains under us like some caged ogre.

title: Streetscapes/East 93rd Street Between Madison and Park Avenues; Where City's Stately Mansions Made a Last Stand
description: THE world changed forever -- after the stock market crash of 1929. And one of the biggest changes was the end of the era of large mansions on the Upper East Side, as even the richest families found irresistible the convenience and economy of apartment living. But on 93rd Street between Madison and Park Avenues, several families sought to make a last stand of elegance. Now new owners are taking over two of the mansions.

title: Cellphone Maturity
description: If cellphone companies want to keep the party going, they'll have to say goodbye to the days of luring huge numbers of new subscribers; most people who want cellphones already have them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, SYLVIA
description: PARKER-Sylvia. Fondly remembering our friend for her generosity and devotion to the Lila Motley Cancer Foundation for so many years. Elaine Fabrikant, Sally Held and Bernice Locker

title: America's Cup Challengers Start Racing Tuesday
description: The long haul to the 2003 America's Cup starts here Tuesday with nine crews, three of them American, from six nations deploying 17 yachts in races for the right to challenge the Cup holder, New Zealand, next February.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, ELSIE
description: SHAPIRO-Elsie. September 27, 1992. Ten years have passed and we remember you with love every day

title: SUSPENDED DRIVER'S LICENSES
description: Reacting to the suspension of 37,000 driver's licenses by the City of Newark for unpaid parking tickets, officials of the New Jersey Administrative Office of the Courts last week began a review of city traffic records. Court officials said they would dismiss summonses more than three years old and would reinstate those drivers' licenses. Newark recently reported a backlog of 105,000 unpaid tickets estimated to represent between $3 million and $5 million in revenue. To collect the fines, in some cases for tickets that dated back a decade, the city had sent suspension notices. Jeremy Pearce

title: The Trust and Distrust
description: DOZENS of historic preservation groups awaiting grants for restoration projects will have to wait a little longer as a political showdown between the McGreevey administration and the well-connected members of the New Jersey Historic Trust continues to play itself out.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about investing in the American Century Strategic Allocation: Aggressive Fund misstated its total return for the 12 months through Sept. 19. It was down 7.9 percent, not 79 percent.

title: Free-Range Burritos; Is This McDonald's?
description: A FEW years after opening a boutique taqueria in his hometown, Denver, Steven Ells was eager to expand. His original Chipotle Mexican Grill restaurant -- named for a smoked and dried jalapeo pepper -- was doing well, as was a branch nearby he had opened to handle overflow crowds.

title: Penn State Does Little to Help Ailing Paterno
description: Joe Paterno was ailing this week. A bout with the flu prompted him to miss a booster luncheon on Wednesday, skip his radio show on Thursday and stay home Friday night rather than make his usual rounds of receptions at the Nittany Lion Inn. The 75-year-old Paterno looked fine today; it was his team that looked sick against Iowa for all but the final seven minutes of regulation time.

title: 6 U.S. Airlines Tighten Rule on Nonrefundables
description: Led by the bankrupt US Airways, all six major domestic airlines have recently added restrictions on nonrefundable tickets, making them worthless after the flight on which they are supposed to be used, unless the traveler reschedules the trip earlier.

title: Cynthia Strickland, Charles Szoradi
description: Cynthia Stewart Strickland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth DeVore Strickland of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Attila Szoradi, a son of Barbara Hill Szoradi and Charles Szoradi, both of Washington. The Rev. Jeffrey H. Walker, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Greenwich.

title: The Nation; For Germans, a Recession Is a Pretty Smooth Ride
description: IT'S hard to think of a cushier place to live through a recession than Germany.

title: A Few Strings Loose
description: THE PIANO TUNER

title: Hot Prices, but Few Are Calling Movers
description: PROSPECTIVE homebuyers and experienced real-estate agents know what has happened in Westchester County: a long upsurge in prices has catapulted the mean sale price of a single-family home past $682,000 in the second quarter of this year.

title: Brooklyn Journal; Tribute to Artist Who Introduced Bears to Wall St.
description: Time has been kind to the art of William Holbrook Beard, 19th-century painter of animal scenes at once satirical and fantastic. His most celebrated canvas, ''The Bulls and Bears in the Market,'' showing a bench-clearing brawl on Wall Street between animal armies, hangs prominently at the New-York Historical Society. It is often reproduced on posters and in newspaper and magazine articles about the volatility of the financial markets.

title: A Hot Shower and a Krispy Kreme Can Almost Set the World Right
description: THE atmosphere is something like Fluorescent Gothic, as in fluorescent ceiling lights, Gothic-arched mullioned windows, a long, rough-hewn table and dangling choir robes. It is the Men's Choir Room at Riverside Church in Morningside Heights.

title: Taking in Housemates To Help Pay the Bills
description: BEVERLY A. HARRIS had an 11-room Victorian house in Ossining that had plenty of maintenance costs and plenty of empty space.

title: Private Sector; An Economic Reality Check From Someone Who's Seen It All
description: At 90, Milton Friedman has witnessed nearly a century's worth of business scandals, booms and busts. How does the current crisis of confidence compare with past bouts of doubt?

title: Family Trees Bloom Again in a Prosperous China
description: For Chi Yugao, the battered ancestral temple next to his home is a constant reminder of the neglected family glory he hopes to restore. As a boy, he looked on as the Chi clan's ancient ancestral records, stored in the temple, were burned to ashes in a flurry of slogans and raised fists.

title: The Scenery, Though, He Won't Chew
description: P . G. WODEHOUSE once described a character as looking like a Welsh rarebit about to come to the height of its fever, and it is this very cheese dish at an acute stage of meltdown that Anthony Hopkins's face now resembles.

title: Corrections
description: The Long Island Journal column on Aug. 18, about a performance by Elvis Presley imitators at the Westbury Music Fair, misspelled the names of two other singers mimicked by Jack Byrnes, who was in the Westbury show. They are Engelbert Humperdinck and Bobby Darin. A reader reported the errors during the week of Sept. 9; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: At 85, a Director Who's Seen It All Keeps His Eyes Open
description: IT is not yet noon on a mild September day, but Yuri Lyubimov is already rolling. It is Day 1 of a new season at the famed Taganka Theater, and Mr. Lyubimov stands in the narrow aisle before the stage, cracking jokes and offering counsel as he greets his large company and a few guests scattered about the auditorium.

title: Diagnosis
description: I was the therapist for a woman with the symptoms and modus operandi that the patient in Lisa Sanders's article had (Sept. 8). She moved all over the United States claiming to be a college student, starting a new job or avoiding a boyfriend. I finally confronted her with the diagnosis of Munchausen. Her mother was also Munchausen and had a history of Munchausen by proxy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACHBACH, DOROTHY
description: RACHBACH-Dorothy, 86. Of Margate, FL, formerly NYC, September 24. Cherished mother of Linda Krull, Peter and Lindi Rachbach. Grandmother of nine; great-grandmother of seven. Beloved sister of Murray and Sally Kreisel, Henny Zeitlen, Ruth Frumkin, sister-in-law to Paul and Phyllis Rachbach. Loving aunt, good friend to many. A unique woman with a sparkling personality, stamina, and special talent for giving love. Services: Schwartz Bros. Chapel, Queens, today at noon.

title: Smoked Salmon and Lox Swim in Different Worlds
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Says City Was Prepared on 9/11
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, in his first detailed account of his administration's actions on 9/11, said mistakes were made at the World Trade Center, but the city was as well-prepared as could reasonably be expected. He also said he believed that some firefighters, aware of the peril, died after choosing to stay in the doomed buildings to save others.

title: Telecare Cuts 75% of Jewish Programming
description: SUNDAY afternoons at 1:30, Renee A. Landovitz of Long Beach looked forward to watching ''Hineni,'' a half-hour Bible program on Telecare, Cablevision's religion channel. But this month the program and the rest of a two-hour block of Jewish programming was canceled without notice.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: REFUGEE BOY

title: Aboard for the Shorter Haul
description: AFTER the terrorist attacks last Sept. 11 it was widely assumed it would take a long time, perhaps years, for the cruise industry to recover. After all, how many people were likely to fly to Florida or the West Coast to board a cruise ship?

title: The Merry Cemetery
description: In the remote little village of Sapanta (sah-PUNTS-ah), near Romania's border with Ukraine, the Merry Cemetery draws more paying visitors than mourners. Busloads of tourists pay about 40 cents each to meander the narrow paths among the 600 wooden crosses that capture the wit, work and daily life of a rugged and traditional peasantry. Everyone from the local barber, lumberjack, shepherd and gamekeeper to the village drunk are kept alive through carved and brightly painted pictures and earthy, sometimes witty, epitaphs.

title: The Stranger
description: After reading your account of Billy Joel's dismay over his single status and reminiscing about the first time I saw him perform (1974, Avery Fisher Hall), I would like to respond to his giant personal ad: ''Single, JWPF, 42, blue-eyed beauty awaits the Piano Man.''

title: Lyn Merrill, Adam Werbach
description: Emilyn Dene Merrill and Adam Michael Werbach are to be married today by Rabbi Helen Cohn at the Ahwahnee Hotel in Yosemite National Park in California.

title: Sept. 22-28: NATIONAL; OUT OF GAS
description: Shares of the El Paso Corporation, the nation's largest natural gas concern, plunged after an administrative law judge at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission said the company helped illegally drive energy prices to record highs in California in 2000-2001 by manipulating gas supplies. The company called the decision, which faces review by the four-member commission and, later, by a federal appeals court, ''unsupported by the evidence.'' Richard A. Oppel Jr.

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Q & A
description: Learning French in Canada

title: Palestinians Rally in Gaza to Mark 2 Years of Conflict
description: Thousands of Palestinians marked the two-year anniversary of their latest conflict with Israel today by holding a rally in Gaza City, staging marches in several West Bank cities and releasing balloons in defiance of an Israeli curfew in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

title: Screening for Ethics At Business Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Finally, the Rest of the World Triumphs Over Russia, 52-48
description: UPSETS were rife in the Russia versus the Rest of the World Match at the Kremlin in Moscow, Sept. 8-12. The ROW players overturned Russia, 52 to 48, for the first time. The two previous matches, at Belgrade in 1970 and at London in 1984, were won narrowly by the Soviet Union. But the earlier matches were under older time limits. This one was quick-play rules of 25 minutes per game plus a 10 seconds per move bonus.

title: Botanical Books for Eye and Intellect
description: GARDENERS, in my opinion, fall into two groups. One contains people who can't, or don't, want to keep the members of a plant family in their heads; they grow plants and arrange them intuitively, making connections through observation. The other contains the more linear thinkers, who may be just as artistic but love to categorize what they are planting; they want to understand how they contribute to the order of things in the universe. (This latter group may also ponder certain mysteries, like what was the first flowering plant and how did it come to be?)

title: The Stranger

Joel has the face of a pugilist, the soul of an artist, an immense talent and a true heart. Added to that now, apparently, is chronic self-pity. There is nothing wrong with feeling sorry for yourself, but it gets you nowhere on the dating scene, no matter how much dough or fame you've got.

title: Young but Not Youthful
description: Lauren Grodstein's acerbic first book of short stories, THE BEST OF ANIMALS (Karen and Michael Braziller/Persea, $23.95), is about urbane, irony-happy 20-somethings who also happen to be wimps. Grodstein's protagonists worry about pursuing what they want, and they tend not to get it -- at least not in the ways they had anticipated. ''Lonely Planet'' spins out the plight of a young businesswoman who sexually violates her dozing, drunken male friend. ''Such a Pretty Face'' compares the lives of twin sisters, of whom one is horrifically overweight, though she's engaged and a successful lawyer. The other, despite her trim body, refuses to date or engage with society -- she works as a secretary and is, at night, a blocked novelist. ''How the Stars Live'' is about a magazine photographer who cheats on his current girlfriend with his ex, a girl he couldn't love when he was dating her. And ''Gazelles'' acquaints us with an endearingly geeky high school student who doesn't sulk about the fact that people are spreading salacious rumors about her, but rather chooses to merrily (and safely) try them on for size. Only in her last two stories does Grodstein offer her characters much in the way of hope, and even then it's hard won. That's the very quality -- along with Grodstein's agile prose and clever observations -- that makes her stand out. Adam Baer

title: A Woman's Work
description: Pauline Nyiramasuhuko -- the very thought of her makes me ill (Peter Landesman, Sept. 15). It becomes ever harder to comprehend the seemingly limitless atrocities humans can inflict on one another. I am ashamed.

title: Smokestack Visionary
description: Last January, Larry Burns, General Motors' vice president for research and development and planning, unveiled the company's plans for the car of the future. It wasn't exactly a car but the underpinnings of one, sort of a 16-foot-long, two-dimensional wine carafe on wheels -- what Burns called the ''skateboard.'' The car would come in two parts, Burns explained. The car's power and control system would be encased in the skateboard, which could be kept for decades while customers shuffled car bodies as tastes changed. And the bodies, too, would be radically different from what we know, with the windshield extending all the way down to the floor because the car's essential systems are kept underfoot.

title: Marty! Marty! Marty!

title: A Mughal Splendor Regained
description: As dusk crept over the Mughal garden that frames Humayun's tomb, the summer air was sodden with heat. In the copious shade of a giant, gnarled ficus tree planted almost a century ago, the temperature hovered around 100 degrees and the occasional breeze could have come from the panting of a dragon. The sounds of India's past and present echoed across the grassy lawns. This was the same bird song that the Mughal rulers themselves must have heard more than 500 years ago. Trees shimmered with the twittering of thousands of tiny starlings. Peacocks strutted the grounds, gracefully undulating plumage in tow. Drifting into the garden from just outside its walls was the clicketyclack of trains running over track laid during the British Raj. From a slightly greater distance came the muffled roar and honk of modern-day New Delhi, the ungainly, sprawling capital of democratic, independent India.

The phrase, ''Let's Roll,'' began appearing in everything from car commercials to clothing lines, and Mr. Beamer's wife, Lisa, and 17 other petitioners filed with the federal government seeking to trademark it.

Or is she better off thinking the book is lost? Anonymous, Brooklyn

title: BackTalk; Imagine Randy Moss on a Therapist's Couch
description: Randy Moss will be running his routes against the Seattle Seahawks tonight, good news for the Minnesota Vikings and all of us who prefer he express his road rage within the white lines. Last week, Moss, the star receiver, was arrested and jailed after he was charged with pretending that a downtown Minneapolis traffic officer was a cornerback and pushing her along the street with the front of his Lexus until she fell down. What might have landed me in jail for the season was somehow perceived as the justifiable confusion of a man who is only used to heavy traffic when he is trying to catch a football. He was given the equivalent of a pushing penalty, charged with misdemeanors by the law and fined $50,000 by the Vikings.

title: Places in the Home Where There's Comfort, Peace or Quiet
description: EARLY morning in the Egan family's Larchmont home finds Louise Egan seated at her kitchen table in the chair nearest the window. Her husband and three children are asleep, and the house is silent. The sturdy wooden farm table is witness to meals and homework and family gatherings. But in the quiet hours between 5:30 and 7 a.m., before her family wakes, it is where Ms. Egan sits alone, reading, writing, thinking. It is, she said, the place in her house that holds, for her, ''the essence of home.''

title: 'Tropical Truth'
description: In the year 2000, Brazil commemorated not only the passing of the century and the millennium but also the five hundred years since her discovery. To this date, then, is attached an accumulation of meaning not shared with any other country in the world. And the flood of omens let loose at this juncture is closely allied with the psychology of Brazil-a failed nation ashamed of having once been called "the country of the future." In fact, those past expectations have today taken the form of a resignation that underlies new frustrations, but the magnitude of Brazil's disillusionment reveals that-fortunately or not-we remain very far from a sensible realism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERT, HARVEY L.
description: SILBERT-Harvey L. The American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend Harvey L. Silbert. An acclaimed humanitarian known for his wisdom and motivational skills, Harvey maintained a longstanding involvement in regional, national and international philanthropic causes. A highly regarded member of the Los Angeles legal community, he became active on behalf of The Hebrew University by spearheading the growth of AFHU's activities in California and throughout the West coast. Assuming a series of key leadership roles within American Friends, he served as Chairman of the Board of the Western States Region from the mid 1980s. He performed equally valuable leadership functions as the Chairman of AFHU's Board of Directors and as Deputy Chairman of the Hebrew University International Board of Governors. A tireless proponent of the University, Harvey personally brought delegations of supporters to Israel and encouraged their contributions to, and awareness of, activities in major disciplines. Harvey and Lillian became Benefactors of The Hebrew University in 1990. Their numerous and far-sighted contributions over the decades enhanced the University's physical and intellectual growth and will benefit Israel's people and humanity in general for generations to come. The Silbert's generosity led to the establishment of vital facilities on the Mt. Scopus campus, including The Harvey L. Silbert Center for Israeli Studies, a multidisciplinary think tank for eminent scholars and experts in public affairs. Harvey initiated funding for the Lillian and Harvey L. Silbert Humanities Building, a rich cultural reservoir of educational resources and the creation of the Silbert Wing at Hebrew University's Louis Boyar Building, housing the Rothberg International School. He and Lillian established the beautiful Lilliian Silbert Garden on the Mt. Scopus campus. Committed to helping the University achieve academic advances in diverse fields, he worked to establish the Avraham Harman Chair in Modern Jewish History and was the driving force behind the Harman Special Fund and the Bernard Cherrick Center for the Study of Zionism. He was a major contributor to the Sinatra International Student Center and the Streisand Building for Jewish Studies. Harvey Silbert was admired by all those who knew him, including Israel's top leaders in government, diplomacy and academia. In 1979, he received the Scopus Award for humanitarian service; the Scopus Award is American Friends' highest honor. In 1981, The Hebrew University conferred an honorary doctorate of philosophy on Harvey in recognition of his efforts to advance scholarship and human progress. At this moment of profound loss, we extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Lillian, to the Silbert's children Lynne and Kenneth, and to their grandchildren David, Greg, Jill, and Gina. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Peter Willner, Executive Vice President American Friends of The Hebrew University Greater Los Angeles Region Richard Ziman, Chairman of the Board Peter Weil, President Martinn Mandles, Vice Chairman of the Board The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menachem Magidor, President Professor Haim Rabinowitch, Rector Yigal Arnon, Chairman of the Board of Governors

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: STATEN ISLAND: BODY OF SWIMMER IS FOUND The body of a man who disappeared last week while trying to swim the East River has washed up on Great Kills Beach in Staten Island, the police said yesterday. The man, Peter Stein, 21, was swimming with a college friend, Jonathan Baum, 22, when a powerful current separated the two. They had tried to swim on Tuesday night from the banks of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to Manhattan and back. Mr. Baum told detectives that he last saw Mr. Stein struggling near a concrete support for the Williamsburg Bridge. Investigators said they believed that Mr. Stein had been drinking; they described the drowning as accidental. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: The Vision Of a Mystic In the City Of St. Francis
description: Olivier Messiaen's only opera, ''St. Franois d'Assise,'' is the wondrous, inspired and uncompromising work of a seminal 20th-century composer and profound Catholic mystic. It is also one of the most daunting operas to produce. The score calls for an orchestra of some 120 players, including 10 percussionists (5 alone are needed for the mallet instruments, like the xylophone and marimba), 3 performers on the ondes martenot and a chorus of more than 100. The work is complex and long, some four hours of music, which seems even longer in performance because Messiaen disregarded the conventions of narrative musical drama and instead strove to create a heightened opera that transcends time.

title: Academy of Music in the Land of Sweets
description: Before dawn yesterday 12 riggers with 4 cranes began installing a series of 250-pound panels on the scaffolded facade of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. One by one, as they were unfurled and carefully fitted onto a steel frame that swathed the building's second, third and fourth floors, images of a giant gingerbread house began to emerge. Brightly colored melted sugar outlined with giant jelly beans and slithering Gummi Worms recreated the building's 1907 arched window; peppermint sticks and Gummi Bears formed its cornice moldings and giant M&M's became its frieze. The names of composers like Haydn and Wagner, Brahms and Mozart on the original Beaux-Arts exterior now march down the building's facade in carefully handwritten white icing.

title: Saddam Hussein and Al Qaeda Are Not Allies

Arguing, as the president did last week, that the two are ''equally as bad, equally as evil and equally as destructive'' -- and that ''you can't distinguish between Al Qaeda and Saddam when you talk about the war on terror'' -- reinforces widely held misunderstandings about the extraordinary danger of the new religious terrorism.

title: West Coast Dock Lockout Felt All the Way to Wall Street
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30  West Coast port operators locked out 10,500 longshoremen today in response to what they said was a job slowdown, shutting 29 ports from San Diego to Seattle and sending waves of fear through the economy and Wall Street.

title: Letter Is Crucial in Lawsuit On Liability of Gun Makers
description: A letter from a federal firearms agent urging a gun manufacturer to help track the illegal use of its weapons has become crucial evidence in a lawsuit by 12 California cities and counties against the gun industry.

title: Gonzlez Captures Tour of Spain
description: Aitor Gonzlez won the Tour of Spain, taking the overall lead from his fellow Spaniard Roberto Heras, riding for the U.S. Postal Service team, on the final stage. The 27-year-old Gonzlez won yesterday's 25.5-mile time trial in Madrid and finished 2 minutes 14 seconds in front.

title: Skirting denial /Sex, please : Making love, not war, on the runway
description: MILAN  Can thigh-high hemlines, bright colors and bold patterns pep up the somber retail and political climate? That was the question posed in Milan as two Italian design houses faced off in the spring/summer 2003 season.

title: MediaTalk; CBS and Don Hewitt Consider His Future
description: People at ''60 Minutes'' are a confused lot these days.

title: Where Candidates May Fear to Tread, National Parties Stampede In
description: Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, made an impassioned argument this month against the ''nationalization'' of House races -- the growing influence of outside interest groups and national parties on what the founding fathers intended to be profoundly local elections.

title: Lean and Mean
description: Hank Aaron was talking about Yankees second baseman Alfonso Soriano, and what it means to be a skinny power hitter in an era when sluggers are built like middle linebackers. Aaron loves Soriano's game. He should. Because it is almost exactly like Aaron's more than four decades ago.

title: With Each Error, Season Slips Away From Jets
description: With each turnover, with each failure to tackle, with another game gone by without a touchdown, the Jets slip closer to the abyss of a lost season. A quarter of the season is finished, and the Jets are 1-3 and in a shambles, with a quarterback controversy looming and a panoply of problems that raise the question of how a team could regress so rapidly after going to the playoffs just nine months ago.

title: Rangers' News Is in the Injury Report
description: There were subplots galore in the Rangers' 4-3 preseason victory last night over the Boston Bruins, which the Rangers won on Jamie Lundmark's overtime goal at Madison Square Garden.

title: Disney Selects a Chief for Its Theme Parks and Resorts
description: The Walt Disney Company announced today that James A. Rasulo, the chief executive of Euro Disney, is being promoted to president of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts worldwide.

title: 1988 Warning Rejected at Nuclear Plant
description: The discovery in February that a reactor vessel in a nuclear power plant had corroded to the brink of rupturing may have shocked the plant's operators and federal safety regulators, but years ago, Howard C. Whitcomb saw it coming, or something like it.

title: ImClone Figure May Be Near To Plea Deal
description: Lawyers representing the former chief of ImClone Systems, Samuel D. Waksal, did not file pretrial motions by Friday, the deadline set by the judge. The missed deadline suggests that Dr. Waksal is close to a plea agreement regarding the federal charges against him, people close to the situation said.

title: Notre Dame Is No. 1 In Ranking by Times
description: The first New York Times computer ranking of the college football season has Notre Dame on top, followed by Southern California, Georgia, Miami and Virginia Tech.

title: Stock Market Ends Its Worst Quarter Since the '87 Crash
description: The stock market finished its worst quarter since the 1987 crash today with a sell-off that sent the Dow Jones industrial average to a four-year low and the Nasdaq composite index to a six-year low.

title: MediaTalk; Questions Raised On Disney Board
description: When the Walt Disney Company made one of its board members, former Senator George J. Mitchell, the co-chairman of its influential governance and nominating committee, it split the job that had been solely held by Stanley P. Gold. Mr. Gold is the board member who has been particularly critical of the chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, in recent months. The move raised the question of whether it was meant to reduce Mr. Gold's influence.

title: Review/Fashion; A Diversion In Bad Times: Flesh
description: It's hard for the world's leading designer, Tom Ford, to make a rational case for his new spring clothes when corporate profits are down and anti-globalization protesters are on the march here, and even harder when some of the most beautiful women on earth have to struggle to keep their fannies covered.

title: College Football | Wrapup; MONDAY MORNING QUARTERBACK
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: On College Football; Computer Loves Irish; Longhorns Are Left Out
description: Now half of those who care about college football will accuse The New York Times's computer of harboring sentimental hardware or worse. The first Times Computer Ranking of 2002 has love 'em or hate 'em Notre Dame at No. 1.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Decanting Wine
description: Decanting wine is hardly an essential part of the drinking experience, but for older (five years old is a good cut-off) or unfiltered red wines, it is a good idea. Decanting performs two services: it helps to aerate the wine, which will make it easier to taste, and it separates the liquid from any sediment that has accumulated in aging. Decanters come in many shapes and sizes; the only important thing is that they are wide enough to allow the wine to mingle with air. (As a side note, letting the wine "breathe" by simply opening the bottle does not do much. Better to decant.)

title: War of the Browsers Resumes With More Players This Autumn
description: Are we heading into Browser War II?

title: White House Letter; It's Not Time or Newsweek, By Design
description: Nicholas E. Calio, the White House lobbyist in charge of pushing the use-of-force resolution against Iraq through Congress, stares authoritatively from Page 107 of the current issue of Wine Spectator with a 1997 Chianti on his West Wing desk. The accompanying article reports approvingly that he has 1,000 more bottles at home, and that his favorite Bordeaux wines are Margaux, Pomerol and St. Julien.

title: Words of Optimism Ring Hollow After Giants Throw One Away
description: Kerry Collins thought the matter was settled when he jogged onto the field for the last 14 seconds of the first half today. This was the talk on the sideline: Collins would take the snap, drop to a knee and run out the clock, allowing the Giants to take a 7-point lead over Arizona into the locker room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPPA, FLORENCE V.
description: RIPPA-Florence V. 90, of Merrick, NY, died September 29, 2002. For information contact Lloyd Maxcy & Sons Beauchamp Chapel, 16 Shea Pl., New Rochelle, NY 10805. 914-632-2700.

title: Accounts
description: * Gillette Co., Boston, consolidated the worldwide media planning and buying duties on its account at offices of MindShare, part of the WPP Group. Advertising Age estimated that Gillette spends as much as $600 million annually on worldwide advertising for brands like Braun, Duracell, Gillette, Gillette Series, Oral-B and Right Guard. The media duties had been divided between offices of OMD, part of the Omnicom Group, which handled assignments in Europe and North America, and Universal McCann, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which handled assignments in Asian-Pacific markets and Latin America.

title: Yankees Answer Home-Field Question
description: Manager Joe Torre closed the Yankees' clubhouse at 11:40 this morning. There were details to discuss with his team: the starting pitchers for this week's division series against the Anaheim Angels, the reporting time for Monday's workout at Yankee Stadium. Torre did not mention anything about a potential makeup game with Tampa Bay on Monday afternoon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Body Of Swimmer Is Found
description: The body of a man who disappeared last week while trying to swim the East River has washed up on Great Kills Beach in Staten Island, the police said yesterday. The man, Peter Stein, 21, was swimming with a college friend, Jonathan Baum, 22, when a powerful current separated the two. They had tried to swim on Tuesday night from the banks of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to Manhattan and back. Mr. Baum told detectives that he last saw Mr. Stein struggling near a concrete support for the Williamsburg Bridge. Investigators said they believed that Mr. Stein had been drinking; they described the drowning as accidental. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: Rewarding a Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan's Police Force Struggles to Find the Resources It Needs to Combat Terrorism
description: For a senior Pakistani police official, the night of Sept. 12 should have been a time of triumph. The previous day, his officers helped capture 10 men suspected of being members of Al Qaeda, including Ramzi bin al-Shibh, a senior operative thought to have been intimately involved in planning the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Fund for Terror Attack Victims Offers Awards in 14 Test Cases
description: The man responsible for distributing billions of taxpayer dollars to thousands of families that lost relatives in the Sept. 11 terror attacks has offered awards in 14 test cases that were selected to gauge the fairness and scope of the awards.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about a plan by Singapore to use recycled waste water in its drinking supply referred incorrectly to the treatment process. According to a Singapore official, the waste water will undergo special treatment before being pumped into reservoirs; the mixed water will then undergo conventional treatment.

title: A Nation Facing Disaster
description: No country in the world has been struck as hard by the AIDS epidemic as Botswana, an arid, thinly populated land of 1.6 million inhabitants in southern Africa. An astonishing 39 percent of the adult population is infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, prompting President Festus Mogae to warn, ''We are threatened with extinction.'' The plight of Botswana is a sobering example of what can happen when the AIDS virus is allowed to spread widely before an all-out effort is mounted to contain it. Once deeply embedded, it is difficult to root out, even with generous aid from international donors. Other lands where the virus is beginning to take off, including China, Russia and Eastern Europe, had better take note.

title: Saroyan, Melville and Big Dreams
description: The size of dreams is a well-worn literary concern. How much is too much to hope for? How big is too big for me? And the converse, equally pungent: How little will do?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLAW, IRVING
description: BRESLAW-Irving. Age 96 years. Beloved husband of the late Lillian. Devoted father of Marc (Ilana) and Irene Grapel (Daniel). Cherished grandfather of David, Dan, Robert, Michal and Ilan. Services today, 11:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Europeans Fill the Cup, With Adrenaline
description: THE Ryder Cup is misnamed. It should be the Adrenaline Cup.

description: To the Editor:

title: E-Commerce Report; A Lands' End experiment in selling custom-made pants is a success, leaving its rivals to play catch-up.
description: WHEN Lands' End started selling custom-made pants on its Web site last October, even analysts who follow the business closely had trouble predicting the outcome, since no major merchant had tried anything like it.

title: Tasting Wine
description: There's nothing wrong with simply picking up the glass and drinking. But for the full experience, involve all of your senses (sight, smell, feel and taste  even sound if you pay attention to the sloshing noises you'll make). Once you try the full technique, you may find yourself appreciating elements of the wine you didn't even know were there. (Note: the wines picked by Andrea Immer to be tasted in this lesson are: Cavit Collection 2001 Pinot Grigio - Delle Verenzie, Beringer 2000 Napa Valley Chardonnay, Louis Jadot 2000 Beaujolais-Villages, and Wynns Coonawarra Estate 1998 Cabernet Sauvignon. All are available for under $20.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Struck and Killed By Car
description: A 32-year-old man was struck and killed by a car in Linden Hill early yesterday, the police said. The man, Michael Callas, was declared dead at the scene. The driver, Michael Carillo, was charged with drunken driving. Mr. Carillo was driving on 26th Avenue near 146th Street when his 2000 Nissan hit Mr. Callas, then slammed into a parked minivan, the police said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Injuries to Quarterbacks Put Harvard and Yale on Alert
description: Yale Coach Jack Siedlecki watched with disbelief the tape of Yale quarterback Alvin Cowan breaking his fibula on Saturday. Cowan was not even hit on his right leg. He was taken down by his torso on a rollout pass.

title: Paying for a Less Stressful SAT
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Killed After Gun Discharges
description: A man bled to death yesterday after a gun in the waistband of his pants discharged, severing an artery in his thigh, the police said. The man, Michael George O'Brien Bent, 30, was apparently adjusting the gun, an unlicensed .38-caliber Beretta, when it discharged. He tried to drive himself to Jacobi Medical Center, but was found dead at 3:30 a.m. in a parking lot about a mile away, on Boston Road in the Williamsbridge neighborhood, the police said.

title: And Then There Were Two; Prize Is Shared in Conductors' Competition
description: Twenty months, five continents, 362 contenders, and now, Saturday night on the stage of Carnegie Hall, it had come down to this: who would walk off the winner of the first worldwide conductors' competition?

title: Man With Box Cutters Is Arrested at Atlantic City
description: A 21-year-old student from Bulgaria who had worked the summer in New Jersey was arrested at Atlantic City International Airport yesterday after federal screeners examining his backpack found a small pair of scissors embedded in a bar of soap and two box cutters inside a lotion bottle, the authorities said.

title: As Digital Radio Stumbles, New Products Fill the Gap
description: Sensing an opportunity in the radio industry's slowness to adopt digital broadcasting, a number of chip makers and radio manufacturers have introduced products that use software in receivers to sharply improve the quality and reach of broadcasts transmitted in the analog format.

title: Opening the Bottle
description: When it comes to opening a bottle of wine, practice really does make perfect. But a few simple techniques will transform any drinker into a master of the task.

title: Lower East Side Journal; After Almost a Century, a Final Blintz
description: The other latke finally dropped on Delancey Street yesterday.

title: Years After Being Bought by I.B.M., Lotus Links Its Products
description: Lotus Software, which gained renown as the creator of some of the world's most widely used business software before being acquired by I.B.M. in 1995, is to announce upgrades to its major products tomorrow that will tie its software more closely to that of its corporate parent.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with a sports article about conflict over the exclusion of women from membership in the Augusta National Golf Club, in Georgia, was published in error. It showed the clubhouse at the Augusta Country Club, also in Georgia, not the one at the golf club.

title: Compressed Data; A Tale of Evil Venture Capital, and a Fair Start-Up
description: Despite the sweeping views of Queens and Central Park, the conference room in the Midtown Manhattan law offices of Morrison & Foerster was not exactly a theatrical set. But the performance -- a mock negotiation by a venture capital firm and an entrepreneur that the law firm staged one recent workday -- held the attention of an audience of about 50 lawyers, venture capital managers and business executives.

title: Surprising Actress as Woman Who Surprises Herself
description: Did she really just do that? Having dashed a terra cotta plate into smithereens, Sally Field is backed up against a ladder, breathing hard, as if in shocked retreat from a previously unidentified enemy. Her large, wet eyes are raw with astonishment, horror and a glimmer of satisfaction. It's the expression of someone who has just discovered a violence she had no idea was inside her.

title: After Demolition of Diner, Owner Vows He'll Return
description: After the World Trade Center buildings collapsed just four blocks from George Koulmentas's diner, he was back slinging hash browns as soon as the authorities allowed. When business in Lower Manhattan slowed after the attack, he had to stop keeping the place open 24 hours a day -- but still, he kept it open.

title: Calling Letters 'Distractions,' McCall Attempts to Move On
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall rallied his Democratic base yesterday, stumping at five Brooklyn churches and then at a street fair on the Upper West Side, where he dismissed questions about whether he had used his position to try to get jobs for his daughter and his cousin as ''distractions.''

title: ISRAELI PULLBACK ENDS 10-DAY SIEGE OF ARAFAT'S BASE
description: Under heavy American pressure, Israel withdrew tanks and troops today from Yasir Arafat's wrecked compound here, ending a 10-day siege of the Palestinian leader that had put the Israeli government in a diplomatic corner.

description: Roger Clemens was shopping at an electronics store in Boston before Game 7 of the 1986 American League Championship Series. He had some World Series tickets his family was not using, and the salesman at the store said he would love to go. So Clemens devised a trade, exchanging tickets for merchandise.

title: Monsters and Other Secrets of the Writing Life
description: Is there a monster in the house? Is there a baby writer sitting over there on the floor storing up memories of family fights and betrayals for future books? Beware. That was the message from writers on a panel at the New Yorker Festival called ''A Monster in the House,'' at the Directors Guild Theater Saturday.

title: The Berlin's Evolution on Display in French Compositions
description: As such things go in an era notoriously short on memory, Sir Simon Rattle will soon get the young lion's share of the credit (or blame) for lifting the Berlin Philharmonic out of its traditional Germanic mold. In fact, Claudio Abbado, in his 13 years as music director, went a long way toward modernizing and internationalizing the orchestra's repertory.

title: Italian Deal May Need Europe's Approval
description: Europe's competition commissioner, Mario Monti, said over the weekend that Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation would probably need European regulatory approval to buy an Italian television business from Vivendi Universal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, HELEN P.
description: McINTYRE-Helen P. Died on September 27. Beloved wife of Randall P. McIntyre. Devoted mother of Virginia McIntyre, Mark P. McIntyre and Archie McIntyre. Grandmother of seven. Sister of Warren B. Pond, Jr., and dear friend of many. Memorial service on October 5, 12:30 PM, at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests gifts to Helen's Fund at the Long Island Community Foundation, Jericho, NY.

title: Latin America Takes Talent and Pain to France
description: Why do people dance? As the 10th Lyon Dance Biennial moves through its final week, an always adventurous festival, this year devoted to dance in Latin America, came up with some surprising answers.

title: Exploring Harmonic Worlds
description: Louis Karchin has done a lot on behalf of new music as an administrator, conductor and teacher. On Tuesday night at Merkin Hall came a chance to hear what he has been achieving lately as a composer, which turned out to be quite a lot. Evidently he has the same drive in his workroom as he does in his public capacities: songs and chamber works of only the last five years were included, but they made a full program.

title: A Curtain Is Lifted on Faded Glory
description: The inner worlds of the once mighty and secretive Russian space program are laid bare in a new book of photographs.

title: Army Intrudes on Amazon Tribe
description: The Brazilian Armed Forces are building new bases in the territories set aside for the Yanomami, disrupting patterns of village life that have endured largely unchanged since the Stone Age.

title: A Question of Faith
description: A miracle has occurred in Siberia. Or it may be a hoax. Others believe science can explain it. It is a question, it seems, of faith.
